The Going to Calvary\r\n X. The Crucifixion\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK FIRST\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Jebel es Zubleh is a mountain fifty miles and more in length, and\r\nso narrow that its tracery on the map gives it a likeness to a\r\ncaterpillar crawling from the south to the north. Standing on its\r\nred-and-white cliffs, and looking off under the path of the rising sun,\r\none sees only the Desert of Arabia, where the east winds, so hateful to\r\nvinegrowers of Jericho, have kept their playgrounds since the\r\nbeginning. Its feet are well covered by sands tossed from the\r\nEuphrates, there to lie, for the mountain is a wall to the\r\npasture-lands of Moab and Ammon on the west\xe2\x80\x94lands which else had been\r\nof the desert a part.\r\n\r\nThe Arab has impressed his language upon everything south and east of\r\nJudea, so, in his tongue, the old Jebel is the parent of numberless\r\nwadies which, intersecting the Roman road\xe2\x80\x94now a dim suggestion of what\r\nonce it was, a dusty path for Syrian pilgrims to and from Mecca\xe2\x80\x94run\r\ntheir furrows, deepening as they go, to pass the torrents of the rainy\r\nseason into the Jordan, or their last receptacle, the Dead Sea. Out of\r\none of these wadies\xe2\x80\x94or, more particularly, out of that one which rises\r\nat the extreme end of the Jebel, and, extending east of north, becomes\r\nat length the bed of the Jabbok River\xe2\x80\x94a traveller passed, going to the\r\ntable-lands of the desert. To this person the attention of the reader\r\nis first besought.\r\n\r\nJudged by his appearance, he was quite forty-five years old. His beard,\r\nonce of the deepest black, flowing broadly over his breast, was\r\nstreaked with white. His face was brown as a parched coffee-berry, and\r\nso hidden by a red _kufiyeh_ (as the kerchief of the head is at this\r\nday called by the children of the desert) as to be but in part visible.\r\nNow and then he raised his eyes, and they were large and dark. He was\r\nclad in the flowing garments so universal in the East; but their style\r\nmay not be described more particularly, for he sat under a miniature\r\ntent, and rode a great white dromedary.\r\n\r\nIt may be doubted if the people of the West ever overcome the\r\nimpression made upon them by the first view of a camel equipped and\r\nloaded for the desert. Custom, so fatal to other novelties, affects\r\nthis feeling but little. At the end of long journeys with caravans,\r\nafter years of residence with the Bedawin, the Western-born, wherever\r\nthey may be, will stop and wait the passing of the stately brute. The\r\ncharm is not in the figure, which not even love can make beautiful; nor\r\nin the movement, the noiseless stepping, or the broad careen. As is the\r\nkindness of the sea to a ship, so that of the desert to its creature.\r\nIt clothes him with all its mysteries; in such manner, too, that while\r\nwe are looking at him we are thinking of them: therein is the wonder.\r\nThe animal which now came out of the wady might well have claimed the\r\ncustomary homage. Its color and height; its breadth of foot; its bulk\r\nof body, not fat, but overlaid with muscle; its long, slender neck, of\r\nswanlike curvature; the head, wide between the eyes, and tapering to a\r\nmuzzle which a lady\xe2\x80\x99s bracelet might have almost clasped; its motion,\r\nstep long and elastic, tread sure and soundless\xe2\x80\x94all certified its\r\nSyrian blood, old as the days of Cyrus, and absolutely priceless. There\r\nwas the usual bridle, covering the forehead with scarlet fringe, and\r\ngarnishing the throat with pendent brazen chains, each ending with a\r\ntinkling silver bell; but to the bridle there was neither rein for the\r\nrider nor strap for a driver. The furniture perched on the back was an\r\ninvention which with any other people than of the East would have made\r\nthe inventor renowned. It consisted of two wooden boxes, scarce four\r\nfeet in length, balanced so that one hung at each side; the inner\r\nspace, softly lined and carpeted, was arranged to allow the master to\r\nsit or lie half reclined; over it all was stretched a green awning.\r\nBroad back and breast straps, and girths, secured with countless knots\r\nand ties, held the device in place. In such manner the ingenious sons\r\nof Cush had contrived to make comfortable the sunburnt ways of the\r\nwilderness, along which lay their duty as often as their pleasure.\r\n\r\nWhen the dromedary lifted itself out of the last break of the wady, the\r\ntraveller had passed the boundary of El Belka, the ancient Ammon. It\r\nwas morning-time. Before him was the sun, half curtained in fleecy\r\nmist; before him also spread the desert; not the realm of drifting\r\nsands, which was farther on, but the region where the herbage began to\r\ndwarf; where the surface is strewn with boulders of granite, and gray\r\nand brown stones, interspersed with languishing acacias and tufts of\r\ncamel-grass. The oak, bramble, and arbutus lay behind, as if they had\r\ncome to a line, looked over into the well-less waste and crouched with\r\nfear.\r\n\r\nAnd now there was an end of path or road. More than ever the camel\r\nseemed insensibly driven; it lengthened and quickened its pace, its\r\nhead pointed straight towards the horizon; through the wide nostrils it\r\ndrank the wind in great draughts. The litter swayed, and rose and fell\r\nlike a boat in the waves. Dried leaves in occasional beds rustled\r\nunderfoot. Sometimes a perfume like absinthe sweetened all the air.\r\nLark and chat and rock-swallow leaped to wing, and white partridges ran\r\nwhistling and clucking out of the way. More rarely a fox or a hyena\r\nquickened his gallop, to study the intruders at a safe distance. Off to\r\nthe right rose the hills of the Jebel, the pearl-gray veil resting upon\r\nthem changing momentarily into a purple which the sun would make\r\nmatchless a little later. Over their highest peaks a vulture sailed on\r\nbroad wings into widening circles. But of all these things the tenant\r\nunder the green tent saw nothing, or, at least, made no sign of\r\nrecognition. His eyes were fixed and dreamy. The going of the man, like\r\nthat of the animal, was as one being led.\r\n\r\nFor two hours the dromedary swung forward, keeping the trot steadily\r\nand the line due east. In that time the traveller never changed his\r\nposition, nor looked to the right or left. On the desert, distance is\r\nnot measured by miles or leagues, but by the _saat_, or hour, and the\r\n_manzil_, or halt: three and a half leagues fill the former, fifteen or\r\ntwenty-five the latter; but they are the rates for the common camel. A\r\ncarrier of the genuine Syrian stock can make three leagues easily. At\r\nfull speed he overtakes the ordinary winds. As one of the results of\r\nthe rapid advance, the face of the landscape underwent a change. The\r\nJebel stretched along the western horizon, like a pale-blue ribbon. A\r\n_tell_, or hummock of clay and cemented sand, arose here and there. Now\r\nand then basaltic stones lifted their round crowns, outposts of the\r\nmountain against the forces of the plain; all else, however, was sand,\r\nsometimes smooth as the beaten beach, then heaped in rolling ridges;\r\nhere chopped waves, there long swells. So, too, the condition of the\r\natmosphere changed. The sun, high risen, had drunk his fill of dew and\r\nmist, and warmed the breeze that kissed the wanderer under the awning;\r\nfar and near he was tinting the earth with faint milk-whiteness, and\r\nshimmering all the sky.\r\n\r\nTwo hours more passed without rest or deviation from the course.\r\nVegetation entirely ceased. The sand, so crusted on the surface that it\r\nbroke into rattling flakes at every step, held undisputed sway. The\r\nJebel was out of view, and there was no landmark visible. The shadow\r\nthat before followed had now shifted to the north, and was keeping even\r\nrace with the objects which cast it; and as there was no sign of\r\nhalting, the conduct of the traveller became each moment more strange.\r\n\r\nNo one, be it remembered, seeks the desert for a pleasure-ground. Life\r\nand business traverse it by paths along which the bones of things dead\r\nare strewn as so many blazons. Such are the roads from well to well,\r\nfrom pasture to pasture. The heart of the most veteran sheik beats\r\nquicker when he finds himself alone in the pathless tracts. So the man\r\nwith whom we are dealing could not have been in search of pleasure;\r\nneither was his manner that of a fugitive; not once did he look behind\r\nhim. In such situations fear and curiosity are the most common\r\nsensations; he was not moved by them. When men are lonely, they stoop\r\nto any companionship; the dog becomes a comrade, the horse a friend,\r\nand it is no shame to shower them with caresses and speeches of love.\r\nThe camel received no such token, not a touch, not a word.\r\n\r\nExactly at noon the dromedary, of its own will, stopped, and uttered\r\nthe cry or moan, peculiarly piteous, by which its kind always protest\r\nagainst an overload, and sometimes crave attention and rest. The master\r\nthereupon bestirred himself, waking, as it were, from sleep. He threw\r\nthe curtains of the _houdah_ up, looked at the sun, surveyed the\r\ncountry on every side long and carefully, as if to identify an\r\nappointed place. Satisfied with the inspection, he drew a deep breath\r\nand nodded, much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cAt last, at last!\xe2\x80\x9d A moment after, he\r\ncrossed his hands upon his breast, bowed his head, and prayed silently.\r\nThe pious duty done, he prepared to dismount. From his throat proceeded\r\nthe sound heard doubtless by the favorite camels of Job\xe2\x80\x94_Ikh! ikh!_\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsignal to kneel. Slowly the animal obeyed, grunting the while. The\r\nrider then put his foot upon the slender neck, and stepped upon the\r\nsand.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nThe man as now revealed was of admirable proportions, not so tall as\r\npowerful. Loosening the silken rope which held the kufiyeh on his head,\r\nhe brushed the fringed folds back until his face was bare\xe2\x80\x94a strong\r\nface, almost negro in color; yet the low, broad forehead, aquiline\r\nnose, the outer corners of the eyes turned slightly upward, the hair\r\nprofuse, straight, harsh, of metallic lustre, and falling to the\r\nshoulder in many plaits, were signs of origin impossible to disguise.\r\nSo looked the Pharaohs and the later Ptolemies; so looked Mizraim,\r\nfather of the Egyptian race. He wore the kamis, a white cotton shirt\r\ntight-sleeved, open in front, extending to the ankles and embroidered\r\ndown the collar and breast, over which was thrown a brown woollen\r\ncloak, now, as in all probability it was then, called the aba, an outer\r\ngarment with long skirt and short sleeves, lined inside with stuff of\r\nmixed cotton and silk, edged all round with a margin of clouded yellow.\r\nHis feet were protected by sandals, attached by thongs of soft leather.\r\nA sash held the kamis to his waist. What was very noticeable,\r\nconsidering he was alone, and that the desert was the haunt of leopards\r\nand lions, and men quite as wild, he carried no arms, not even the\r\ncrooked stick used for guiding camels; wherefore we may at least infer\r\nhis errand peaceful, and that he was either uncommonly bold or under\r\nextraordinary protection.\r\n\r\nThe traveller\xe2\x80\x99s limbs were numb, for the ride had been long and\r\nwearisome; so he rubbed his hands and stamped his feet, and walked\r\nround the faithful servant, whose lustrous eyes were closing in calm\r\ncontent with the cud he had already found. Often, while making the\r\ncircuit, he paused, and, shading his eyes with his hands, examined the\r\ndesert to the extremest verge of vision; and always, when the survey\r\nwas ended, his face clouded with disappointment, slight, but enough to\r\nadvise a shrewd spectator that he was there expecting company, if not\r\nby appointment; at the same time, the spectator would have been\r\nconscious of a sharpening of the curiosity to learn what the business\r\ncould be that required transaction in a place so far from civilized\r\nabode.\r\n\r\nHowever disappointed, there could be little doubt of the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconfidence in the coming of the expected company. In token thereof, he\r\nwent first to the litter, and, from the cot or box opposite the one he\r\nhad occupied in coming, produced a sponge and a small gurglet of water,\r\nwith which he washed the eyes, face, and nostrils of the camel; that\r\ndone, from the same depository he drew a circular cloth, red-and\r\nwhite-striped, a bundle of rods, and a stout cane. The latter, after\r\nsome manipulation, proved to be a cunning device of lesser joints, one\r\nwithin another, which, when united together, formed a centre pole\r\nhigher than his head. When the pole was planted, and the rods set\r\naround it, he spread the cloth over them, and was literally at home\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nhome much smaller than the habitations of emir and sheik, yet their\r\ncounterpart in all other respects. From the litter again he brought a\r\ncarpet or square rug, and covered the floor of the tent on the side\r\nfrom the sun. That done, he went out, and once more, and with greater\r\ncare and more eager eyes, swept the encircling country. Except a\r\ndistant jackal, galloping across the plain, and an eagle flying towards\r\nthe Gulf of Akaba, the waste below, like the blue above it, was\r\nlifeless.\r\n\r\nHe turned to the camel, saying low, and in a tongue strange to the\r\ndesert, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are far from home, O racer with the swiftest winds\xe2\x80\x94we are\r\nfar from home, but God is with us. Let us be patient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he took some beans from a pocket in the saddle, and put them in a\r\nbag made to hang below the animal\xe2\x80\x99s nose; and when he saw the relish\r\nwith which the good servant took to the food, he turned and again\r\nscanned the world of sand, dim with the glow of the vertical sun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will come,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, calmly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe that led me is leading them. I\r\nwill make ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the pouches which lined the interior of the cot, and from a willow\r\nbasket which was part of its furniture, he brought forth materials for\r\na meal: platters close-woven of the fibres of palms; wine in small\r\ngurglets of skin; mutton dried and smoked; stoneless shami, or Syrian\r\npomegranates; dates of El Shelebi, wondrous rich and grown in the\r\nnakhil, or palm orchards, of Central Arabia; cheese, like David\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cslices of milk;\xe2\x80\x9d and leavened bread from the city bakery\xe2\x80\x94all which he\r\ncarried and set upon the carpet under the tent. As the final\r\npreparation, about the provisions he laid three pieces of silk cloth,\r\nused among refined people of the East to cover the knees of guests\r\nwhile at table\xe2\x80\x94a circumstance significant of the number of persons who\r\nwere to partake of his entertainment\xe2\x80\x94the number he was awaiting.\r\n\r\nAll was now ready. He stepped out: lo! in the east a dark speck on the\r\nface of the desert. He stood as if rooted to the ground; his eyes\r\ndilated; his flesh crept chilly, as if touched by something\r\nsupernatural. The speck grew; became large as a hand; at length assumed\r\ndefined proportions. A little later, full into view swung a duplication\r\nof his own dromedary, tall and white, and bearing a houdah, the\r\ntravelling litter of Hindostan. Then the Egyptian crossed his hands\r\nupon his breast, and looked to heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod only is great!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, his eyes full of tears, his soul in\r\nawe.\r\n\r\nThe stranger drew nigh\xe2\x80\x94at last stopped. Then he, too, seemed just\r\nwaking. He beheld the kneeling camel, the tent, and the man standing\r\nprayerfully at the door. He crossed his hands, bent his head, and\r\nprayed silently; after which, in a little while, he stepped from his\r\ncamel\xe2\x80\x99s neck to the sand, and advanced towards the Egyptian, as did the\r\nEgyptian towards him. A moment they looked at each other; then they\r\nembraced\xe2\x80\x94that is, each threw his right arm over the other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder,\r\nand the left round the side, placing his chin first upon the left, then\r\nupon the right breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace be with thee, O servant of the true God!\xe2\x80\x9d the stranger said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to thee, O brother of the true faith!\xe2\x80\x94to thee peace and welcome,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe Egyptian replied, with fervor.\r\n\r\nThe new-comer was tall and gaunt, with lean face, sunken eyes, white\r\nhair and beard, and a complexion between the hue of cinnamon and\r\nbronze. He, too, was unarmed. His costume was Hindostani; over the\r\nskull-cap a shawl was wound in great folds, forming a turban; his body\r\ngarments were in the style of the Egyptian\xe2\x80\x99s, except that the aba was\r\nshorter, exposing wide flowing breeches gathered at the ankles. In\r\nplace of sandals, his feet were clad in half-slippers of red leather,\r\npointed at the toes. Save the slippers, the costume from head to foot\r\nwas of white linen. The air of the man was high, stately, severe.\r\nVisvamitra, the greatest of the ascetic heroes of the Iliad of the\r\nEast, had in him a perfect representative. He might have been called a\r\nLife drenched with the wisdom of Brahma\xe2\x80\x94Devotion Incarnate. Only in his\r\neyes was there proof of humanity; when he lifted his face from the\r\nEgyptian\xe2\x80\x99s breast, they were glistening with tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod only is great!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, when the embrace was finished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd blessed are they that serve him!\xe2\x80\x9d the Egyptian answered, wondering\r\nat the paraphrase of his own exclamation. \xe2\x80\x9cBut let us wait,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clet us wait; for see, the other comes yonder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey looked to the north, where, already plain to view, a third camel,\r\nof the whiteness of the others, came careening like a ship. They\r\nwaited, standing together\xe2\x80\x94waited until the new-comer arrived,\r\ndismounted, and advanced towards them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, O my brother!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, while embracing the Hindoo.\r\n\r\nAnd the Hindoo answered, \xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s will be done!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last comer was all unlike his friends: his frame was slighter; his\r\ncomplexion white; a mass of waving light hair was a perfect crown for\r\nhis small but beautiful head; the warmth of his dark-blue eyes\r\ncertified a delicate mind, and a cordial, brave nature. He was\r\nbareheaded and unarmed. Under the folds of the Tyrian blanket which he\r\nwore with unconscious grace appeared a tunic, short-sleeved and\r\nlow-necked, gathered to the waist by a band, and reaching nearly to the\r\nknee; leaving the neck, arms, and legs bare. Sandals guarded his feet.\r\nFifty years, probably more, had spent themselves upon him, with no\r\nother effect, apparently, than to tinge his demeanor with gravity and\r\ntemper his words with forethought. The physical organization and the\r\nbrightness of soul were untouched. No need to tell the student from\r\nwhat kindred he was sprung; if he came not himself from the groves of\r\nAthene\xe2\x80\x99, his ancestry did.\r\n\r\nWhen his arms fell from the Egyptian, the latter said, with a tremulous\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Spirit brought me first; wherefore I know myself chosen to\r\nbe the servant of my brethren. The tent is set, and the bread is ready\r\nfor the breaking. Let me perform my office.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTaking each by the hand, he led them within, and removed their sandals\r\nand washed their feet, and he poured water upon their hands, and dried\r\nthem with napkins.\r\n\r\nThen, when he had laved his own hands, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us take care of\r\nourselves, brethren, as our service requires, and eat, that we may be\r\nstrong for what remains of the day\xe2\x80\x99s duty. While we eat, we will each\r\nlearn who the others are, and whence they come, and how they are\r\ncalled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took them to the repast, and seated them so that they faced each\r\nother. Simultaneously their heads bent forward, their hands crossed\r\nupon their breasts, and, speaking together, they said aloud this simple\r\ngrace:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather of all\xe2\x80\x94God!\xe2\x80\x94what we have here is of thee; take our thanks and\r\nbless us, that we may continue to do thy will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the last word they raised their eyes, and looked at each other in\r\nwonder. Each had spoken in a language never before heard by the others;\r\nyet each understood perfectly what was said. Their souls thrilled with\r\ndivine emotion; for by the miracle they recognized the Divine Presence.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nTo speak in the style of the period, the meeting just described took\r\nplace in the year of Rome 747. The month was December, and winter\r\nreigned over all the regions east of the Mediterranean. Such as ride\r\nupon the desert in this season go not far until smitten with a keen\r\nappetite. The company under the little tent were not exceptions to the\r\nrule. They were hungry, and ate heartily; and, after the wine, they\r\ntalked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo a wayfarer in a strange land nothing is so sweet as to hear his\r\nname on the tongue of a friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Egyptian, who assumed to be\r\npresident of the repast. \xe2\x80\x9cBefore us lie many days of companionship. It\r\nis time we knew each other. So, if it be agreeable, he who came last\r\nshall be first to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, slowly at first, like one watchful of himself, the Greek began:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I have to tell, my brethren, is so strange that I hardly know\r\nwhere to begin or what I may with propriety speak. I do not yet\r\nunderstand myself. The most I am sure of is that I am doing a Master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwill, and that the service is a constant ecstasy. When I think of the\r\npurpose I am sent to fulfil, there is in me a joy so inexpressible that\r\nI know the will is God\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe good man paused, unable to proceed, while the others, in sympathy\r\nwith his feelings, dropped their gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFar to the west of this,\xe2\x80\x9d he began again, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a land which may\r\nnever be forgotten; if only because the world is too much its debtor,\r\nand because the indebtedness is for things that bring to men their\r\npurest pleasures. I will say nothing of the arts, nothing of\r\nphilosophy, of eloquence, of poetry, of war: O my brethren, hers is the\r\nglory which must shine forever in perfected letters, by which He we go\r\nto find and proclaim will be made known to all the earth. The land I\r\nspeak of is Greece. I am Gaspar, son of Cleanthes the Athenian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy people,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwere given wholly to study, and from them I\r\nderived the same passion. It happens that two of our philosophers, the\r\nvery greatest of the many, teach, one the doctrine of a Soul in every\r\nman, and its Immortality; the other the doctrine of One God, infinitely\r\njust. From the multitude of subjects about which the schools were\r\ndisputing, I separated them, as alone worth the labor of solution; for\r\nI thought there was a relation between God and the soul as yet unknown.\r\nOn this theme the mind can reason to a point, a dead, impassable wall;\r\narrived there, all that remains is to stand and cry aloud for help. So\r\nI did; but no voice came to me over the wall. In despair, I tore myself\r\nfrom the cities and the schools.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words a grave smile of approval lighted the gaunt face of the\r\nHindoo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the northern part of my country\xe2\x80\x94in Thessaly,\xe2\x80\x9d the Greek proceeded\r\nto say, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a mountain famous as the home of the gods, where\r\nTheus, whom my countrymen believe supreme, has his abode; Olympus is\r\nits name. Thither I betook myself. I found a cave in a hill where the\r\nmountain, coming from the west, bends to the southeast; there I dwelt,\r\ngiving myself up to meditation\xe2\x80\x94no, I gave myself up to waiting for what\r\nevery breath was a prayer\xe2\x80\x94for revelation. Believing in God, invisible\r\nyet supreme, I also believed it possible so to yearn for him with all\r\nmy soul that he would take compassion and give me answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he did\xe2\x80\x94he did!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Hindoo, lifting his hands from the\r\nsilken cloth upon his lap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear me, brethren,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Greek, calming himself with an effort.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe door of my hermitage looks over an arm of the sea, over the\r\nThermaic Gulf. One day I saw a man flung overboard from a ship sailing\r\nby. He swam ashore. I received and took care of him. He was a Jew,\r\nlearned in the history and laws of his people; and from him I came to\r\nknow that the God of my prayers did indeed exist; and had been for ages\r\ntheir lawmaker, ruler, and king. What was that but the Revelation I\r\ndreamed of? My faith had not been fruitless; God answered me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs he does all who cry to him with such faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Hindoo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, alas!\xe2\x80\x9d the Egyptian added, \xe2\x80\x9chow few are there wise enough to know\r\nwhen he answers them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was not all,\xe2\x80\x9d the Greek continued. \xe2\x80\x9cThe man so sent to me told me\r\nmore. He said the prophets who, in the ages which followed the first\r\nrevelation, walked and talked with God, declared he would come again.\r\nHe gave me the names of the prophets, and from the sacred books quoted\r\ntheir very language. He told me, further, that the second coming was at\r\nhand\xe2\x80\x94was looked for momentarily in Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Greek paused, and the brightness of his countenance faded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a little\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is true the man told me that\r\nas God and the revelation of which he spoke had been for the Jews\r\nalone, so it would be again. He that was to come should be King of the\r\nJews. \xe2\x80\x98Had he nothing for the rest of the world?\xe2\x80\x99 I asked. \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 was\r\nthe answer, given in a proud voice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98No, we are his chosen people.\xe2\x80\x99 The\r\nanswer did not crush my hope. Why should such a God limit his love and\r\nbenefaction to one land, and, as it were, to one family? I set my heart\r\nupon knowing. At last I broke through the man\xe2\x80\x99s pride, and found that\r\nhis fathers had been merely chosen servants to keep the Truth alive,\r\nthat the world might at last know it and be saved. When the Jew was\r\ngone, and I was alone again, I chastened my soul with a new prayer\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nI might be permitted to see the King when he was come, and worship him.\r\nOne night I sat by the door of my cave trying to get nearer the\r\nmysteries of my existence, knowing which is to know God; suddenly, on\r\nthe sea below me, or rather in the darkness that covered its face, I\r\nsaw a star begin to burn; slowly it arose and drew nigh, and stood over\r\nthe hill and above my door, so that its light shone full upon me. I\r\nfell down, and slept, and in my dream I heard a voice say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98O Gaspar! Thy faith hath conquered! Blessed art thou! With two\r\nothers, come from the uttermost parts of the earth, thou shalt see Him\r\nthat is promised, and be a witness for him, and the occasion of\r\ntestimony in his behalf. In the morning arise, and go meet them, and\r\nkeep trust in the Spirit that shall guide thee.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in the morning I awoke with the Spirit as a light within me\r\nsurpassing that of the sun. I put off my hermit\xe2\x80\x99s garb, and dressed\r\nmyself as of old. From a hiding-place I took the treasure which I had\r\nbrought from the city. A ship went sailing past. I hailed it, was taken\r\naboard, and landed at Antioch. There I bought the camel and his\r\nfurniture. Through the gardens and orchards that enamel the banks of\r\nthe Orontes, I journeyed to Emesa, Damascus, Bostra, and Philadelphia;\r\nthence hither. And so, O brethren, you have my story. Let me now listen\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian and the Hindoo looked at each other; the former waved his\r\nhand; the latter bowed, and began:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur brother has spoken well. May my words be as wise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe broke off, reflected a moment, then resumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may know me, brethren, by the name of Melchior. I speak to you in\r\na language which, if not the oldest in the world, was at least the\r\nsoonest to be reduced to letters\xe2\x80\x94I mean the Sanscrit of India. I am a\r\nHindoo by birth. My people were the first to walk in the fields of\r\nknowledge, first to divide them, first to make them beautiful. Whatever\r\nmay hereafter befall, the four Vedas must live, for they are the primal\r\nfountains of religion and useful intelligence. From them were derived\r\nthe Upa-Vedas, which, delivered by Brahma, treat of medicine, archery,\r\narchitecture, music, and the four-and-sixty mechanical arts; the\r\nVed-Angas, revealed by inspired saints, and devoted to astronomy,\r\ngrammar, prosody, pronunciation, charms and incantations, religious\r\nrites and ceremonies; the Up-Angas, written by the sage Vyasa, and\r\ngiven to cosmogony, chronology, and geography; therein also are the\r\nRamayana and the Mahabharata, heroic poems, designed for the\r\nperpetuation of our gods and demi-gods. Such, O brethren, are the Great\r\nShastras, or books of sacred ordinances. They are dead to me now; yet\r\nthrough all time they will serve to illustrate the budding genius of my\r\nrace. They were promises of quick perfection. Ask you why the promises\r\nfailed? Alas! the books themselves closed all the gates of progress.\r\nUnder pretext of care for the creature, their authors imposed the fatal\r\nprinciple that a man must not address himself to discovery or\r\ninvention, as Heaven had provided him all things needful. When that\r\ncondition became a sacred law, the lamp of Hindoo genius was let down a\r\nwell, where ever since it has lighted narrow walls and bitter waters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese allusions, brethren, are not from pride, as you will understand\r\nwhen I tell you that the Shastras teach a Supreme God called Brahm;\r\nalso, that the Puranas, or sacred poems of the Up-Angas, tell us of\r\nVirtue and Good Works, and of the Soul. So, if my brother will permit\r\nthe saying\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the speaker bowed deferentially to the Greek\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cages before\r\nhis people were known, the two great ideas, God and the Soul, had\r\nabsorbed all the forces of the Hindoo mind. In further explanation let\r\nme say that Brahm is taught, by the same sacred books, as a\r\nTriad\xe2\x80\x94Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. Of these, Brahma is said to have been\r\nthe author of our race; which, in course of creation, he divided into\r\nfour castes. First, he peopled the worlds below and the heavens above;\r\nnext, he made the earth ready for terrestrial spirits; then from his\r\nmouth proceeded the Brahman caste, nearest in likeness to himself,\r\nhighest and noblest, sole teachers of the Vedas, which at the same time\r\nflowed from his lips in finished state, perfect in all useful\r\nknowledge. From his arms next issued the Kshatriya, or warriors; from\r\nhis breast, the seat of life, came the Vaisya, or producers\xe2\x80\x94shepherds,\r\nfarmers, merchants; from his foot, in sign of degradation, sprang the\r\nSudra, or serviles, doomed to menial duties for the other\r\nclasses\xe2\x80\x94serfs, domestics, laborers, artisans. Take notice, further,\r\nthat the law, so born with them, forbade a man of one caste becoming a\r\nmember of another; the Brahman could not enter a lower order; if he\r\nviolated the laws of his own grade, he became an outcast, lost to all\r\nbut outcasts like himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point, the imagination of the Greek, flashing forward upon all\r\nthe consequences of such a degradation, overcame his eager attention,\r\nand he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cIn such a state, O brethren, what mighty need of a\r\nloving God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d added the Egyptian, \xe2\x80\x9cof a loving God like ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe brows of the Hindoo knit painfully; when the emotion was spent, he\r\nproceeded, in a softened voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was born a Brahman. My life, consequently, was ordered down to its\r\nleast act, its last hour. My first draught of nourishment; the giving\r\nme my compound name; taking me out the first time to see the sun;\r\ninvesting me with the triple thread by which I became one of the\r\ntwice-born; my induction into the first order\xe2\x80\x94were all celebrated with\r\nsacred texts and rigid ceremonies. I might not walk, eat, drink, or\r\nsleep without danger of violating a rule. And the penalty, O brethren,\r\nthe penalty was to my soul! According to the degrees of omission, my\r\nsoul went to one of the heavens\xe2\x80\x94Indra\xe2\x80\x99s the lowest, Brahma\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nhighest; or it was driven back to become the life of a worm, a fly, a\r\nfish, or a brute. The reward for perfect observance was Beatitude, or\r\nabsorption into the being of Brahm, which was not existence as much as\r\nabsolute rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Hindoo gave himself a moment\xe2\x80\x99s thought; proceeding, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\npart of a Brahman\xe2\x80\x99s life called the first order is his student life.\r\nWhen I was ready to enter the second order\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, when I was\r\nready to marry and become a householder\xe2\x80\x94I questioned everything, even\r\nBrahm; I was a heretic. From the depths of the well I had discovered a\r\nlight above, and yearned to go up and see what all it shone upon. At\r\nlast\xe2\x80\x94ah, with what years of toil!\xe2\x80\x94I stood in the perfect day, and\r\nbeheld the principle of life, the element of religion, the link between\r\nthe soul and God\xe2\x80\x94Love!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe shrunken face of the good man kindled visibly, and he clasped his\r\nhands with force. A silence ensued, during which the others looked at\r\nhim, the Greek through tears. At length he resumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe happiness of love is in action; its test is what one is willing to\r\ndo for others. I could not rest. Brahm had filled the world with so\r\nmuch wretchedness. The Sudra appealed to me, so did the countless\r\ndevotees and victims. The island of Ganga Lagor lies where the sacred\r\nwaters of the Ganges disappear in the Indian Ocean. Thither I betook\r\nmyself. In the shade of the temple built there to the sage Kapila, in a\r\nunion of prayers with the disciples whom the sanctified memory of the\r\nholy man keeps around his house, I thought to find rest. But twice\r\nevery year came pilgrimages of Hindoos seeking the purification of the\r\nwaters. Their misery strengthened my love. Against its impulse to speak\r\nI clenched my jaws; for one word against Brahm or the Triad or the\r\nShastras would doom me; one act of kindness to the outcast Brahmans who\r\nnow and then dragged themselves to die on the burning sands\xe2\x80\x94a blessing\r\nsaid, a cup of water given\xe2\x80\x94and I became one of them, lost to family,\r\ncountry, privileges, caste. The love conquered! I spoke to the\r\ndisciples in the temple; they drove me out. I spoke to the pilgrims;\r\nthey stoned me from the island. On the highways I attempted to preach;\r\nmy hearers fled from me, or sought my life. In all India, finally,\r\nthere was not a place in which I could find peace or safety\xe2\x80\x94not even\r\namong the outcasts, for, though fallen, they were still believers in\r\nBrahm. In my extremity, I looked for a solitude in which to hide from\r\nall but God. I followed the Ganges to its source, far up in the\r\nHimalayas. When I entered the pass at Hurdwar, where the river, in\r\nunstained purity, leaps to its course through the muddy lowlands, I\r\nprayed for my race, and thought myself lost to them forever. Through\r\ngorges, over cliffs, across glaciers, by peaks that seemed star-high, I\r\nmade my way to the Lang Tso, a lake of marvellous beauty, asleep at the\r\nfeet of the Tise Gangri, the Gurla, and the Kailas Parbot, giants which\r\nflaunt their crowns of snow everlastingly in the face of the sun.\r\nThere, in the centre of the earth, where the Indus, Ganges, and\r\nBrahmapootra rise to run their different courses; where mankind took up\r\ntheir first abode, and separated to replete the world, leaving Balk,\r\nthe mother of cities, to attest the great fact; where Nature, gone back\r\nto its primeval condition, and secure in its immensities, invites the\r\nsage and the exile, with promise of safety to the one and solitude to\r\nthe other\xe2\x80\x94there I went to abide alone with God, praying, fasting,\r\nwaiting for death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain the voice fell, and the bony hands met in a fervent clasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne night I walked by the shores of the lake, and spoke to the\r\nlistening silence, \xe2\x80\x98When will God come and claim his own? Is there to\r\nbe no redemption?\xe2\x80\x99 Suddenly a light began to glow tremulously out on\r\nthe water; soon a star arose, and moved towards me, and stood overhead.\r\nThe brightness stunned me. While I lay upon the ground, I heard a voice\r\nof infinite sweetness say, \xe2\x80\x98Thy love hath conquered. Blessed art thou,\r\nO son of India! The redemption is at hand. With two others, from far\r\nquarters of the earth, thou shalt see the Redeemer, and be a witness\r\nthat he hath come. In the morning arise, and go meet them; and put all\r\nthy trust in the Spirit which shall guide thee.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd from that time the light has stayed with me; so I knew it was the\r\nvisible presence of the Spirit. In the morning I started to the world\r\nby the way I had come. In a cleft of the mountain I found a stone of\r\nvast worth, which I sold in Hurdwar. By Lahore, and Cabool, and Yezd, I\r\ncame to Ispahan. There I bought the camel, and thence was led to\r\nBagdad, not waiting for caravans. Alone I traveled, fearless, for the\r\nSpirit was with me, and is with me yet. What glory is ours, O brethren!\r\nWe are to see the Redeemer\xe2\x80\x94to speak to him\xe2\x80\x94to worship him! I am done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nThe vivacious Greek broke forth in expressions of joy and\r\ncongratulations; after which the Egyptian said, with characteristic\r\ngravity:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI salute you, my brother. You have suffered much, and I rejoice in\r\nyour triumph. If you are both pleased to hear me, I will now tell you\r\nwho I am, and how I came to be called. Wait for me a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went out and tended the camels; coming back, he resumed his seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour words, brethren, were of the Spirit,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in commencement;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand the Spirit gives me to understand them. You each spoke\r\nparticularly of your countries; in that there was a great object, which\r\nI will explain; but to make the interpretation complete, let me first\r\nspeak of myself and my people. I am Balthasar the Egyptian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last words were spoken quietly, but with so much dignity that both\r\nlisteners bowed to the speaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are many distinctions I might claim for my race,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I will content myself with one. History began with us. We were the\r\nfirst to perpetuate events by records kept. So we have no traditions;\r\nand instead of poetry, we offer you certainty. On the facades of\r\npalaces and temples, on obelisks, on the inner walls of tombs, we wrote\r\nthe names of our kings, and what they did; and to the delicate papyri\r\nwe intrusted the wisdom of our philosophers and the secrets of our\r\nreligion\xe2\x80\x94all the secrets but one, whereof I will presently speak. Older\r\nthan the Vedas of Para-Brahm or the Up-Angas of Vyasa, O Melchior;\r\nolder than the songs of Homer or the metaphysics of Plato, O my Gaspar;\r\nolder than the sacred books or kings of the people of China, or those\r\nof Siddartha, son of the beautiful Maya; older than the Genesis of\r\nMosche the Hebrew\xe2\x80\x94oldest of human records are the writings of Menes,\r\nour first king.\xe2\x80\x9d Pausing an instant, he fixed his large eves kindly\r\nupon the Greek, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the youth of Hellas, who, O Gaspar, were\r\nthe teachers of her teachers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Greek bowed, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy those records,\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe know that when the fathers\r\ncame from the far East, from the region of the birth of the three\r\nsacred rivers, from the centre of the earth\xe2\x80\x94the Old Iran of which you\r\nspoke, O Melchior\xe2\x80\x94came bringing with them the history of the world\r\nbefore the Flood, and of the Flood itself, as given to the Aryans by\r\nthe sons of Noah, they taught God, the Creator and the Beginning, and\r\nthe Soul, deathless as God. When the duty which calls us now is happily\r\ndone, if you choose to go with me, I will show you the sacred library\r\nof our priesthood; among others, the Book of the Dead, in which is the\r\nritual to be observed by the soul after Death has despatched it on its\r\njourney to judgment. The ideas\xe2\x80\x94God and the Immortal Soul\xe2\x80\x94were borne to\r\nMizraim over the desert, and by him to the banks of the Nile. They were\r\nthen in their purity, easy of understanding, as what God intends for\r\nour happiness always is; so, also, was the first worship\xe2\x80\x94a song and a\r\nprayer natural to a soul joyous, hopeful, and in love with its Maker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the Greek threw up his hands, exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cOh! the light deepens\r\nwithin me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Hindoo, with equal fervor.\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian regarded them benignantly, then went on, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cReligion\r\nis merely the law which binds man to his Creator: in purity it has but\r\nthese elements\xe2\x80\x94God, the Soul, and their Mutual Recognition; out of\r\nwhich, when put in practise, spring Worship, Love, and Reward. This\r\nlaw, like all others of divine origin\xe2\x80\x94like that, for instance, which\r\nbinds the earth to the sun\xe2\x80\x94was perfected in the beginning by its\r\nAuthor. Such, my brothers, was the religion of the first family; such\r\nwas the religion of our father Mizraim, who could not have been blind\r\nto the formula of creation, nowhere so discernible as in the first\r\nfaith and the earliest worship. Perfection is God; simplicity is\r\nperfection. The curse of curses is that men will not let truths like\r\nthese alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped, as if considering in what manner to continue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMany nations have loved the sweet waters of the Nile,\xe2\x80\x9d he said next;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe Ethiopian, the Pali-Putra, the Hebrew, the Assyrian, the Persian,\r\nthe Macedonian, the Roman\xe2\x80\x94of whom all, except the Hebrew, have at one\r\ntime or another been its masters. So much coming and going of peoples\r\ncorrupted the old Mizraimic faith. The Valley of Palms became a Valley\r\nof Gods. The Supreme One was divided into eight, each personating a\r\ncreative principle in nature, with Ammon-Re at the head. Then Isis and\r\nOsiris, and their circle, representing water, fire, air, and other\r\nforces, were invented. Still the multiplication went on until we had\r\nanother order, suggested by human qualities, such as strength,\r\nknowledge, love, and the like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn all which there was the old folly!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Greek, impulsively.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly the things out of reach remain as they came to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian bowed, and proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet a little further, O my brethren, a little further, before I come\r\nto myself. What we go to will seem all the holier of comparison with\r\nwhat is and has been. The records show that Mizraim found the Nile in\r\npossession of the Ethiopians, who were spread thence through the\r\nAfrican desert; a people of rich, fantastic genius, wholly given to the\r\nworship of nature. The Poetic Persian sacrificed to the sun, as the\r\ncompletest image of Ormuzd, his God; the devout children of the far\r\nEast carved their deities out of wood and ivory; but the Ethiopian,\r\nwithout writing, without books, without mechanical faculty of any kind,\r\nquieted his soul by the worship of animals, birds, and insects, holding\r\nthe cat sacred to Re, the bull to Isis, the beetle to Pthah. A long\r\nstruggle against their rude faith ended in its adoption as the religion\r\nof the new empire. Then rose the mighty monuments that cumber the\r\nriver-bank and the desert\xe2\x80\x94obelisk, labyrinth, pyramid, and tomb of\r\nking, blent with tomb of crocodile. Into such deep debasement, O\r\nbrethren, the sons of the Aryan fell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere, for the first time, the calmness of the Egyptian forsook him:\r\nthough his countenance remained impassive, his voice gave way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not too much despise my countrymen,\xe2\x80\x9d he began again. \xe2\x80\x9cThey did not\r\nall forget God. I said awhile ago, you may remember, that to papyri we\r\nintrusted all the secrets of our religion except one; of that I will\r\nnow tell you. We had as king once a certain Pharaoh, who lent himself\r\nto all manner of changes and additions. To establish the new system, he\r\nstrove to drive the old entirely out of mind. The Hebrews then dwelt\r\nwith us as slaves. They clung to their God; and when the persecution\r\nbecame intolerable, they were delivered in a manner never to be\r\nforgotten. I speak from the records now. Mosche, himself a Hebrew, came\r\nto the palace, and demanded permission for the slaves, then millions in\r\nnumber, to leave the country. The demand was in the name of the Lord\r\nGod of Israel. Pharaoh refused. Hear what followed. First, all the\r\nwater, that in the lakes and rivers, like that in the wells and\r\nvessels, turned to blood. Yet the monarch refused. Then frogs came up\r\nand covered all the land. Still he was firm. Then Mosche threw ashes in\r\nthe air, and a plague attacked the Egyptians. Next, all the cattle,\r\nexcept of the Hebrews, were struck dead. Locusts devoured the green\r\nthings of the valley. At noon the day was turned into a darkness so\r\nthick that lamps would not burn. Finally, in the night all the\r\nfirst-born of the Egyptians died; not even Pharaoh\xe2\x80\x99s escaped. Then he\r\nyielded. But when the Hebrews were gone he followed them with his army.\r\nAt the last moment the sea was divided, so that the fugitives passed it\r\ndry-shod. When the pursuers drove in after them, the waves rushed back\r\nand drowned horse, foot, charioteers, and king. You spoke of\r\nrevelation, my Gaspar\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe blue eyes of the Greek sparkled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had the story from the Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cYou confirm it, O\r\nBalthasar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but through me Egypt speaks, not Mosche. I interpret the marbles.\r\nThe priests of that time wrote in their way what they witnessed, and\r\nthe revelation has lived. So I come to the one unrecorded secret. In my\r\ncountry, brethren, we have, from the day of the unfortunate Pharaoh,\r\nalways had two religions\xe2\x80\x94one private, the other public; one of many\r\ngods, practised by the people; the other of one God, cherished only by\r\nthe priesthood. Rejoice with me, O brothers! All the trampling by the\r\nmany nations, all the harrowing by kings, all the inventions of\r\nenemies, all the changes of time, have been in vain. Like a seed under\r\nthe mountains waiting its hour, the glorious Truth has lived; and\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94this is its day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe wasted frame of the Hindoo trembled with delight, and the Greek\r\ncried aloud,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me the very desert is singing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom a gurglet of water near-by the Egyptian took a draught, and\r\nproceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was born at Alexandria, a prince and a priest, and had the education\r\nusual to my class. But very early I became discontented. Part of the\r\nfaith imposed was that after death upon the destruction of the body,\r\nthe soul at once began its former progression from the lowest up to\r\nhumanity, the highest and last existence; and that without reference to\r\nconduct in the mortal life. When I heard of the Persian\xe2\x80\x99s Realm of\r\nLight, his Paradise across the bridge Chinevat, where only the good go,\r\nthe thought haunted me; insomuch that in the day, as in the night, I\r\nbrooded over the comparative ideas Eternal Transmigration and Eternal\r\nLife in Heaven. If, as my teacher taught, God was just, why was there\r\nno distinction between the good and the bad? At length it became clear\r\nto me, a certainty, a corollary of the law to which I reduced pure\r\nreligion, that death was only the point of separation at which the\r\nwicked are left or lost, and the faithful rise to a higher life; not\r\nthe nirvana of Buddha, or the negative rest of Brahma, O Melchior; nor\r\nthe better condition in hell, which is all of Heaven allowed by the\r\nOlympic faith, O Gaspar; but life\xe2\x80\x94life active, joyous, everlasting\xe2\x80\x94LIFE\r\nWITH GOD! The discovery led to another inquiry. Why should the Truth be\r\nlonger kept a secret for the selfish solace of the priesthood? The\r\nreason for the suppression was gone. Philosophy had at least brought us\r\ntoleration. In Egypt we had Rome instead of Rameses. One day, in the\r\nBrucheium, the most splendid and crowded quarter of Alexandria, I arose\r\nand preached. The East and West contributed to my audience. Students\r\ngoing to the Library, priests from the Serapeion, idlers from the\r\nMuseum, patrons of the race-course, countrymen from the Rhacotis\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nmultitude\xe2\x80\x94stopped to hear me. I preached God, the Soul, Right and\r\nWrong, and Heaven, the reward of a virtuous life. You, O Melchior, were\r\nstoned; my auditors first wondered, then laughed. I tried again; they\r\npelted me with epigrams, covered my God with ridicule, and darkened my\r\nHeaven with mockery. Not to linger needlessly, I fell before them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Hindoo here drew a long sigh, as he said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe enemy of man is man,\r\nmy brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar lapsed into silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gave much thought to finding the cause of my failure, and at last\r\nsucceeded,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, upon beginning again. \xe2\x80\x9cUp the river, a day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njourney from the city, there is a village of herdsmen and gardeners. I\r\ntook a boat and went there. In the evening I called the people\r\ntogether, men and women, the poorest of the poor. I preached to them\r\nexactly as I had preached in the Brucheium. They did not laugh. Next\r\nevening I spoke again, and they believed and rejoiced, and carried the\r\nnews abroad. At the third meeting a society was formed for prayer. I\r\nreturned to the city then. Drifting down the river, under the stars,\r\nwhich never seemed so bright and so near, I evolved this lesson: To\r\nbegin a reform, go not into the places of the great and rich; go rather\r\nto those whose cups of happiness are empty\xe2\x80\x94to the poor and humble. And\r\nthen I laid a plan and devoted my life. As a first step, I secured my\r\nvast property, so that the income would be certain, and always at call\r\nfor the relief of the suffering. From that day, O brethren, I travelled\r\nup and down the Nile, in the villages, and to all the tribes, preaching\r\nOne God, a righteous life, and reward in Heaven. I have done good\xe2\x80\x94it\r\ndoes not become me to say how much. I also know that part of the world\r\nto be ripe for the reception of Him we go to find.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA flush suffused the swarthy cheek of the speaker; but he overcame the\r\nfeeling, and continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe years so given, O my brothers, were troubled by one thought\xe2\x80\x94When I\r\nwas gone, what would become of the cause I had started? Was it to end\r\nwith me? I had dreamed many times of organization as a fitting crown\r\nfor my work. To hide nothing from you, I had tried to effect it, and\r\nfailed. Brethren, the world is now in the condition that, to restore\r\nthe old Mizraimic faith, the reformer must have a more than human\r\nsanction; he must not merely come in God\xe2\x80\x99s name, he must have the\r\nproofs subject to his word; he must demonstrate all he says, even God.\r\nSo preoccupied is the mind with myths and systems; so much do false\r\ndeities crowd every place\xe2\x80\x94earth, air, sky; so have they become of\r\neverything a part, that return to the first religion can only be along\r\nbloody paths, through fields of persecution; that is to say, the\r\nconverts must be willing to die rather than recant. And who in this age\r\ncan carry the faith of men to such a point but God himself? To redeem\r\nthe race\xe2\x80\x94I do not mean to destroy it\xe2\x80\x94to REDEEM the race, he must make\r\nhimself once more manifest; HE MUST COME IN PERSON.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIntense emotion seized the three.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we not going to find him?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Greek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand why I failed in the attempt to organize,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nEgyptian, when the spell was past. \xe2\x80\x9cI had not the sanction. To know\r\nthat my work must be lost made me intolerably wretched. I believed in\r\nprayer, and to make my appeals pure and strong, like you, my brethren,\r\nI went out of the beaten ways, I went where man had not been, where\r\nonly God was. Above the fifth cataract, above the meeting of rivers in\r\nSennar, up the Bahr el Abiad, into the far unknown of Africa, I went.\r\nThere, in the morning, a mountain blue as the sky flings a cooling\r\nshadow wide over the western desert, and, with its cascades of melted\r\nsnow, feeds a broad lake nestling at its base on the east. The lake is\r\nthe mother of the great river. For a year and more the mountain gave me\r\na home. The fruit of the palm fed my body, prayer my spirit. One night\r\nI walked in the orchard close by the little sea. \xe2\x80\x98The world is dying.\r\nWhen wilt thou come? Why may I not see the redemption, O God?\xe2\x80\x99 So I\r\nprayed. The glassy water was sparkling with stars. One of them seemed\r\nto leave its place, and rise to the surface, where it became a\r\nbrilliancy burning to the eyes. Then it moved towards me, and stood\r\nover my head, apparently in hand\xe2\x80\x99s reach. I fell down and hid my face.\r\nA voice, not of the earth, said, \xe2\x80\x98Thy good works have conquered.\r\nBlessed art thou, O son of Mizraim! The redemption cometh. With two\r\nothers, from the remotenesses of the world, thou shalt see the Saviour,\r\nand testify for him. In the morning arise, and go meet them. And when\r\nye have all come to the holy city of Jerusalem, ask of the people,\r\nWhere is he that is born King of the Jews? for we have seen his star in\r\nthe East and are sent to worship him. Put all thy trust in the Spirit\r\nwhich will guide thee.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the light became an inward illumination not to be doubted, and has\r\nstayed with me, a governor and a guide. It led me down the river to\r\nMemphis, where I made ready for the desert. I bought my camel, and came\r\nhither without rest, by way of Suez and Kufileh, and up through the\r\nlands of Moab and Ammon. God is with us, O my brethren!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused, and thereupon, with a prompting not their own, they all\r\narose, and looked at each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said there was a purpose in the particularity with which we\r\ndescribed our people and their histories,\xe2\x80\x9d so the Egyptian proceeded.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe we go to find was called \xe2\x80\x98King of the Jews;\xe2\x80\x99 by that name we are\r\nbidden to ask for him. But, now that we have met, and heard from each\r\nother, we may know him to be the Redeemer, not of the Jews alone, but\r\nof all the nations of the earth. The patriarch who survived the Flood\r\nhad with him three sons, and their families, by whom the world was\r\nrepeopled. From the old Aryana-Vaejo, the well-remembered Region of\r\nDelight in the heart of Asia, they parted. India and the far East\r\nreceived the children of the first; the descendant of the youngest,\r\nthrough the North, streamed into Europe; those of the second overflowed\r\nthe deserts about the Red Sea, passing into Africa; and though most of\r\nthe latter are yet dwellers in shifting tents, some of them became\r\nbuilders along the Nile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy a simultaneous impulse the three joined hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould anything be more divinely ordered?\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar continued. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen\r\nwe have found the Lord, the brothers, and all the generations that have\r\nsucceeded them, will kneel to him in homage with us. And when we part\r\nto go our separate ways, the world will have learned a new lesson\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nHeaven may be won, not by the sword, not by human wisdom, but by Faith,\r\nLove, and Good Works.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was silence, broken by sighs and sanctified with tears; for the\r\njoy that filled them might not be stayed. It was the unspeakable joy of\r\nsouls on the shores of the River of Life, resting with the Redeemed in\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s presence.\r\n\r\nPresently their hands fell apart, and together they went out of the\r\ntent. The desert was still as the sky. The sun was sinking fast. The\r\ncamels slept.\r\n\r\nA little while after, the tent was struck, and, with the remains of the\r\nrepast, restored to the cot; then the friends mounted, and set out\r\nsingle file, led by the Egyptian. Their course was due west, into the\r\nchilly night. The camels swung forward in steady trot, keeping the line\r\nand the intervals so exactly that those following seemed to tread in\r\nthe tracks of the leader. The riders spoke not once.\r\n\r\nBy-and-by the moon came up. And as the three tall white figures sped,\r\nwith soundless tread, through the opalescent light, they appeared like\r\nspecters flying from hateful shadows. Suddenly, in the air before them,\r\nnot farther up than a low hill-top flared a lambent flame; as they\r\nlooked at it, the apparition contracted into a focus of dazzling\r\nlustre. Their hearts beat fast; their souls thrilled; and they shouted\r\nas with one voice, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Star! the Star! God is with us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nIn an aperture of the western wall of Jerusalem hang the \xe2\x80\x9coaken valves\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncalled the Bethlehem or Joppa Gate. The area outside of them is one of\r\nthe notable places of the city. Long before David coveted Zion there\r\nwas a citadel there. When at last the son of Jesse ousted the Jebusite,\r\nand began to build, the site of the citadel became the northwest corner\r\nof the new wall, defended by a tower much more imposing than the old\r\none. The location of the gate, however, was not disturbed, for the\r\nreasons, most likely, that the roads which met and merged in front of\r\nit could not well be transferred to any other point, while the area\r\noutside had become a recognized market-place. In Solomon\xe2\x80\x99s day there\r\nwas great traffic at the locality, shared in by traders from Egypt and\r\nthe rich dealers from Tyre and Sidon. Nearly three thousand years have\r\npassed, and yet a kind of commerce clings to the spot. A pilgrim\r\nwanting a pin or a pistol, a cucumber or a camel, a house or a horse, a\r\nloan or a lentil, a date or a dragoman, a melon or a man, a dove or a\r\ndonkey, has only to inquire for the article at the Joppa Gate.\r\nSometimes the scene is quite animated, and then it suggests, What a\r\nplace the old market must have been in the days of Herod the Builder!\r\nAnd to that period and that market the reader is now to be transferred.\r\n\r\nFollowing the Hebrew system, the meeting of the wise men described in\r\nthe preceding chapters took place in the afternoon of the twenty-fifth\r\nday of the third month of the year; that is to say, on the twenty-fifth\r\nday of December. The year was the second of the 193d Olympiad, or the\r\n747th of Rome; the sixty-seventh of Herod the Great, and the\r\nthirty-fifth of his reign; the fourth before the beginning of the\r\nChristian era. The hours of the day, by Judean custom, begin with the\r\nsun, the first hour being the first after sunrise; so, to be precise;\r\nthe market at the Joppa Gate during the first hour of the day stated\r\nwas in full session, and very lively. The massive valves had been wide\r\nopen since dawn. Business, always aggressive, had pushed through the\r\narched entrance into a narrow lane and court, which, passing by the\r\nwalls of the great tower, conducted on into the city. As Jerusalem is\r\nin the hill country, the morning air on this occasion was not a little\r\ncrisp. The rays of the sun, with their promise of warmth, lingered\r\nprovokingly far up on the battlements and turrets of the great piles\r\nabout, down from which fell the crooning of pigeons and the whir of the\r\nflocks coming and going.\r\n\r\nAs a passing acquaintance with the people of the Holy City, strangers\r\nas well as residents, will be necessary to an understanding of some of\r\nthe pages which follow, it will be well to stop at the gate and pass\r\nthe scene in review. Better opportunity will not offer to get sight of\r\nthe populace who will afterwhile go forward in a mood very different\r\nfrom that which now possesses them.\r\n\r\nThe scene is at first one of utter confusion\xe2\x80\x94confusion of action,\r\nsounds, colors, and things. It is especially so in the lane and court.\r\nThe ground there is paved with broad unshaped flags, from which each\r\ncry and jar and hoof-stamp arises to swell the medley that rings and\r\nroars up between the solid impending walls. A little mixing with the\r\nthrong, however, a little familiarity with the business going on, will\r\nmake analysis possible.\r\n\r\nHere stands a donkey, dozing under panniers full of lentils, beans,\r\nonions, and cucumbers, brought fresh from the gardens and terraces of\r\nGalilee. When not engaged in serving customers, the master, in a voice\r\nwhich only the initiated can understand, cries his stock. Nothing can\r\nbe simpler than his costume\xe2\x80\x94sandals, and an unbleached, undyed blanket,\r\ncrossed over one shoulder and girt round the waist. Near-by, and far\r\nmore imposing and grotesque, though scarcely as patient as the donkey,\r\nkneels a camel, raw-boned, rough, and gray, with long shaggy tufts of\r\nfox-colored hair under its throat, neck, and body, and a load of boxes\r\nand baskets curiously arranged upon an enormous saddle. The owner is an\r\nEgyptian, small, lithe, and of a complexion which has borrowed a good\r\ndeal from the dust of the roads and the sands of the desert. He wears a\r\nfaded tarbooshe, a loose gown, sleeveless, unbelted, and dropping from\r\nthe neck to the knee. His feet are bare. The camel, restless under the\r\nload, groans and occasionally shows his teeth; but the man paces\r\nindifferently to and fro, holding the driving-strap, and all the time\r\nadvertising his fruits fresh from the orchards of the Kedron\xe2\x80\x94grapes,\r\ndates, figs, apples, and pomegranates.\r\n\r\nAt the corner where the lane opens out into the court, some women sit\r\nwith their backs against the gray stones of the wall. Their dress is\r\nthat common to the humbler classes of the country\xe2\x80\x94a linen frock\r\nextending the full length of the person, loosely gathered at the waist,\r\nand a veil or wimple broad enough, after covering the head, to wrap the\r\nshoulders. Their merchandise is contained in a number of earthen jars,\r\nsuch as are still used in the East for bringing water from the wells,\r\nand some leathern bottles. Among the jars and bottles, rolling upon the\r\nstony floor, regardless of the crowd and cold, often in danger but\r\nnever hurt, play half a dozen half-naked children, their brown bodies,\r\njetty eyes, and thick black hair attesting the blood of Israel.\r\nSometimes, from under the wimples, the mothers look up, and in the\r\nvernacular modestly bespeak their trade: in the bottles \xe2\x80\x9choney of\r\ngrapes,\xe2\x80\x9d in the jars \xe2\x80\x9cstrong drink.\xe2\x80\x9d Their entreaties are usually lost\r\nin the general uproar, and they fare illy against the many competitors:\r\nbrawny fellows with bare legs, dirty tunics, and long beards, going\r\nabout with bottles lashed to their backs, and shouting \xe2\x80\x9cHoney of wine!\r\nGrapes of En-Gedi!\xe2\x80\x9d When a customer halts one of them, round comes the\r\nbottle, and, upon lifting the thumb from the nozzle, out into the ready\r\ncup gushes the deep-red blood of the luscious berry.\r\n\r\nScarcely less blatant are the dealers in birds\xe2\x80\x94doves, ducks, and\r\nfrequently the singing bulbul, or nightingale, most frequently pigeons;\r\nand buyers, receiving them from the nets, seldom fail to think of the\r\nperilous life of the catchers, bold climbers of the cliffs; now hanging\r\nwith hand and foot to the face of the crag, now swinging in a basket\r\nfar down the mountain fissure.\r\n\r\nBlent with peddlers of jewelry\xe2\x80\x94sharp men cloaked in scarlet and blue,\r\ntop-heavy under prodigious white turbans, and fully conscious of the\r\npower there is in the lustre of a ribbon and the incisive gleam of\r\ngold, whether in bracelet or necklace, or in rings for the finger or\r\nthe nose\xe2\x80\x94and with peddlers of household utensils, and with dealers in\r\nwearing-apparel, and with retailers of unguents for anointing the\r\nperson, and with hucksters of all articles, fanciful as well as of\r\nneed, hither and thither, tugging at halters and ropes, now screaming,\r\nnow coaxing, toil the venders of animals\xe2\x80\x94donkeys, horses, calves,\r\nsheep, bleating kids, and awkward camels; animals of every kind except\r\nthe outlawed swine. All these are there; not singly, as described, but\r\nmany times repeated; not in one place, but everywhere in the market.\r\n\r\nTurning from this scene in the lane and court, this glance at the\r\nsellers and their commodities, the reader has need to give attention,\r\nin the next place, to visitors and buyers, for which the best studies\r\nwill be found outside the gates, where the spectacle is quite as varied\r\nand animated; indeed, it may be more so, for there are superadded the\r\neffects of tent, booth, and sook, greater space, larger crowd, more\r\nunqualified freedom, and the glory of the Eastern sunshine.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nLet us take our stand by the gate, just out of the edge of the\r\ncurrents\xe2\x80\x94one flowing in, the other out\xe2\x80\x94and use our eyes and ears\r\nawhile.\r\n\r\nIn good time! Here come two men of a most noteworthy class.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGods! How cold it is!\xe2\x80\x9d says one of them, a powerful figure in armor;\r\non his head a brazen helmet, on his body a shining breastplate and\r\nskirts of mail. \xe2\x80\x9cHow cold it is! Dost thou remember, my Caius, that\r\nvault in the Comitium at home which the flamens say is the entrance to\r\nthe lower world? By Pluto! I could stand there this morning, long\r\nenough at least to get warm again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe party addressed drops the hood of his military cloak, leaving bare\r\nhis head and face, and replies, with an ironic smile, \xe2\x80\x9cThe helmets of\r\nthe legions which conquered Mark Antony were full of Gallic snow; but\r\nthou\xe2\x80\x94ah, my poor friend!\xe2\x80\x94thou hast just come from Egypt, bringing its\r\nsummer in thy blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd with the last word they disappear through the entrance. Though they\r\nhad been silent, the armor and the sturdy step would have published\r\nthem Roman soldiers.\r\n\r\nFrom the throng a Jew comes next, meager of frame, round-shouldered,\r\nand wearing a coarse brown robe; over his eyes and face, and down his\r\nback, hangs a mat of long, uncombed hair. He is alone. Those who meet\r\nhim laugh, if they do not worse; for he is a Nazarite, one of a\r\ndespised sect which rejects the books of Moses, devotes itself to\r\nabhorred vows, and goes unshorn while the vows endure.\r\n\r\nAs we watch his retiring figure, suddenly there is a commotion in the\r\ncrowd, a parting quickly to the right and left, with exclamations sharp\r\nand decisive. Then the cause comes\xe2\x80\x94a man, Hebrew in feature and dress.\r\nThe mantle of snow-white linen, held to his head by cords of yellow\r\nsilk, flows free over his shoulders; his robe is richly embroidered, a\r\nred sash with fringes of gold wraps his waist several times. His\r\ndemeanor is calm; he even smiles upon those who, with such rude haste,\r\nmake room for him. A leper? No, he is only a Samaritan. The shrinking\r\ncrowd, if asked, would say he is a mongrel\xe2\x80\x94an Assyrian\xe2\x80\x94whose touch of\r\nthe robe is pollution; from whom, consequently, an Israelite, though\r\ndying, might not accept life. In fact, the feud is not of blood. When\r\nDavid set his throne here on Mount Zion, with only Judah to support\r\nhim, the ten tribes betook themselves to Shechem, a city much older,\r\nand, at that date, infinitely richer in holy memories. The final union\r\nof the tribes did not settle the dispute thus begun. The Samaritans\r\nclung to their tabernacle on Gerizim, and, while maintaining its\r\nsuperior sanctity, laughed at the irate doctors in Jerusalem. Time\r\nbrought no assuagement of the hate. Under Herod, conversion to the\r\nfaith was open to all the world except the Samaritans; they alone were\r\nabsolutely and forever shut out from communion with Jews.\r\n\r\nAs the Samaritan goes in under the arch of the gate, out come three men\r\nso unlike all whom we have yet seen that they fix our gaze, whether we\r\nwill or not. They are of unusual stature and immense brawn; their eyes\r\nare blue, and so fair is their complexion that the blood shines through\r\nthe skin like blue pencilling; their hair is light and short; their\r\nheads, small and round, rest squarely upon necks columnar as the trunks\r\nof trees. Woollen tunics, open at the breast, sleeveless and loosely\r\ngirt, drape their bodies, leaving bare arms and legs of such\r\ndevelopment that they at once suggest the arena; and when thereto we\r\nadd their careless, confident, insolent manner, we cease to wonder that\r\nthe people give them way, and stop after they have passed to look at\r\nthem again. They are gladiators\xe2\x80\x94wrestlers, runners, boxers, swordsmen;\r\nprofessionals unknown in Judea before the coming of the Roman; fellows\r\nwho, what time they are not in training, may be seen strolling through\r\nthe king\xe2\x80\x99s gardens or sitting with the guards at the palace gates; or\r\npossibly they are visitors from Caesarea, Sebaste, or Jericho; in which\r\nHerod, more Greek than Jew, and with all a Roman\xe2\x80\x99s love of games and\r\nbloody spectacles, has built vast theaters, and now keeps schools of\r\nfighting-men, drawn, as is the custom, from the Gallic provinces or the\r\nSlavic tribes on the Danube.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Bacchus!\xe2\x80\x9d says one of them, drawing his clenched hand to his\r\nshoulder, \xe2\x80\x9ctheir skulls are not thicker than eggshells.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe brutal look which goes with the gesture disgusts us, and we turn\r\nhappily to something more pleasant.\r\n\r\nOpposite us is a fruit-stand. The proprietor has a bald head, a long\r\nface, and a nose like the beak of a hawk. He sits upon a carpet spread\r\nupon the dust; the wall is at his back; overhead hangs a scant curtain,\r\naround him, within hand\xe2\x80\x99s reach and arranged upon little stools, lie\r\nosier boxes full of almonds, grapes, figs, and pomegranates. To him now\r\ncomes one at whom we cannot help looking, though for another reason\r\nthan that which fixed our eyes upon the gladiators; he is really\r\nbeautiful\xe2\x80\x94a beautiful Greek. Around his temples, holding the waving\r\nhair, is a crown of myrtle, to which still cling the pale flowers and\r\nhalf ripe berries. His tunic, scarlet in color, is of the softest\r\nwoollen fabric; below the girdle of buff leather, which is clasped in\r\nfront by a fantastic device of shining gold, the skirt drops to the\r\nknee in folds heavy with embroidery of the same royal metal; a scarf,\r\nalso woollen, and of mixed white and yellow, crosses his throat and\r\nfalls trailing at his back; his arms and legs, where exposed, are white\r\nas ivory, and of the polish impossible except by perfect treatment with\r\nbath, oil, brushes, and pincers.\r\n\r\nThe dealer, keeping his seat, bends forward, and throws his hands up\r\nuntil they meet in front of him, palm downwards and fingers extended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat hast thou, this morning, O son of Paphos?\xe2\x80\x9d says the young Greek,\r\nlooking at the boxes rather than at the Cypriote. \xe2\x80\x9cI am hungry. What\r\nhast thou for breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFruits from the Pedius\xe2\x80\x94genuine\xe2\x80\x94such as the singers of Antioch take of\r\nmornings to restore the waste of their voices,\xe2\x80\x9d the dealer answers, in\r\na querulous nasal tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fig, but not one of thy best, for the singers of Antioch!\xe2\x80\x9d says the\r\nGreek. \xe2\x80\x9cThou art a worshiper of Aphrodite, and so am I, as the myrtle I\r\nwear proves; therefore I tell thee their voices have the chill of a\r\nCaspian wind. Seest thou this girdle?\xe2\x80\x94a gift of the mighty Salome\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king\xe2\x80\x99s sister!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaims the Cypriote, with another salaam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd of royal taste and divine judgment. And why not? She is more Greek\r\nthan the king. But\xe2\x80\x94my breakfast! Here is thy money\xe2\x80\x94red coppers of\r\nCyprus. Give me grapes, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilt thou not take the dates also?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am not an Arab.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor figs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be to make me a Jew. No, nothing but the grapes. Never\r\nwaters mixed so sweetly as the blood of the Greek and the blood of the\r\ngrape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe singer in the grimed and seething market, with all his airs of the\r\ncourt, is a vision not easily shut out of mind by such as see him; as\r\nif for the purpose, however, a person follows him challenging all our\r\nwonder. He comes up the road slowly, his face towards the ground; at\r\nintervals he stops, crosses his hands upon his breast, lengthens his\r\ncountenance, and turns his eyes towards heaven, as if about to break\r\ninto prayer. Nowhere, except in Jerusalem, can such a character be\r\nfound. On his forehead, attached to the band which keeps the mantle in\r\nplace, projects a leathern case, square in form; another similar case\r\nis tied by a thong to the left arm; the borders of his robe are\r\ndecorated with deep fringe; and by such signs\xe2\x80\x94the phylacteries, the\r\nenlarged borders of the garment, and the savor of intense holiness\r\npervading the whole man\xe2\x80\x94we know him to be a Pharisee, one of an\r\norganization (in religion a sect, in politics a party) whose bigotry\r\nand power will shortly bring the world to grief.\r\n\r\nThe densest of the throng outside the gate covers the road leading off\r\nto Joppa. Turning from the Pharisee, we are attracted by some parties\r\nwho, as subjects of study, opportunely separate themselves from the\r\nmotley crowd. First among them a man of very noble appearance\xe2\x80\x94clear,\r\nhealthful complexion; bright black eyes; beard long and flowing, and\r\nrich with unguents; apparel well-fitting, costly, and suitable for the\r\nseason. He carries a staff, and wears, suspended by a cord from his\r\nneck, a large golden seal. Several servants attend him, some of them\r\nwith short swords stuck through their sashes; when they address him, it\r\nis with the utmost deference. The rest of the party consists of two\r\nArabs of the pure desert stock; thin, wiry men, deeply bronzed, and\r\nwith hollow cheeks, and eyes of almost evil brightness; on their heads\r\nred tarbooshes; over their abas, and wrapping the left shoulder and the\r\nbody so as to leave the right arm free, brown woollen haicks, or\r\nblankets. There is loud chaffering, for the Arabs are leading horses\r\nand trying to sell them; and, in their eagerness, they speak in high,\r\nshrill voices. The courtly person leaves the talking mostly to his\r\nservants; occasionally he answers with much dignity; directly, seeing\r\nthe Cypriote, he stops and buys some figs. And when the whole party has\r\npassed the portal, close after the Pharisee, if we betake ourselves to\r\nthe dealer in fruits, he will tell, with a wonderful salaam, that the\r\nstranger is a Jew, one of the princes of the city, who has travelled,\r\nand learned the difference between the common grapes of Syria and those\r\nof Cyprus, so surpassingly rich with the dews of the sea.\r\n\r\nAnd so, till towards noon, sometimes later, the steady currents of\r\nbusiness habitually flow in and out of the Joppa Gate, carrying with\r\nthem every variety of character; including representatives of all the\r\ntribes of Israel, all the sects among whom the ancient faith has been\r\nparcelled and refined away, all the religious and social divisions, all\r\nthe adventurous rabble who, as children of art and ministers of\r\npleasure, riot in the prodigalities of Herod, and all the peoples of\r\nnote at any time compassed by the Caesars and their predecessors,\r\nespecially those dwelling within the circuit of the Mediterranean.\r\n\r\nIn other words, Jerusalem, rich in sacred history, richer in connection\r\nwith sacred prophecies\xe2\x80\x94the Jerusalem of Solomon, in which silver was as\r\nstones, and cedars as the sycamores of the vale\xe2\x80\x94had come to be but a\r\ncopy of Rome, a center of unholy practises, a seat of pagan power. A\r\nJewish king one day put on priestly garments, and went into the Holy of\r\nHolies of the first temple to offer incense, and he came out a leper;\r\nbut in the time of which we are reading, Pompey entered Herod\xe2\x80\x99s temple\r\nand the same Holy of Holies, and came out without harm, finding but an\r\nempty chamber, and of God not a sign.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe reader is now besought to return to the court described as part of\r\nthe market at the Joppa Gate.
