It was the third hour of the day, and\r\nmany of the people had gone away; yet the press continued without\r\napparent abatement. Of the new-comers, there was a group over by the\r\nsouth wall, consisting of a man, a woman, and a donkey, which requires\r\nextended notice.\r\n\r\nThe man stood by the animal\xe2\x80\x99s head, holding a leading-strap, and\r\nleaning upon a stick which seemed to have been chosen for the double\r\npurpose of goad and staff. His dress was like that of the ordinary Jews\r\naround him, except that it had an appearance of newness. The mantle\r\ndropping from his head, and the robe or frock which clothed his person\r\nfrom neck to heel, were probably the garments he was accustomed to wear\r\nto the synagogue on Sabbath days. His features were exposed, and they\r\ntold of fifty years of life, a surmise confirmed by the gray that\r\nstreaked his otherwise black beard. He looked around him with the\r\nhalf-curious, half-vacant stare of a stranger and provincial.\r\n\r\nThe donkey ate leisurely from an armful of green grass, of which there\r\nwas an abundance in the market. In its sleepy content, the brute did\r\nnot admit of disturbance from the bustle and clamor about; no more was\r\nit mindful of the woman sitting upon its back in a cushioned pillion.\r\nAn outer robe of dull woollen stuff completely covered her person,\r\nwhile a white wimple veiled her head and neck. Once in a while,\r\nimpelled by curiosity to see or hear something passing, she drew the\r\nwimple aside, but so slightly that the face remained invisible.\r\n\r\nAt length the man was accosted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not Joseph of Nazareth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe speaker was standing close by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so called,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Joseph, turning gravely around; \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x94ah,\r\npeace be unto you! my friend, Rabbi Samuel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same give I back to you.\xe2\x80\x9d The Rabbi paused, looking at the woman,\r\nthen added, \xe2\x80\x9cTo you, and unto your house and all your helpers, be\r\npeace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the last word, he placed one hand upon his breast, and inclined\r\nhis head to the woman, who, to see him, had by this time withdrawn the\r\nwimple enough to show the face of one but a short time out of girlhood.\r\nThereupon the acquaintances grasped right hands, as if to carry them to\r\ntheir lips; at the last moment, however, the clasp was let go, and each\r\nkissed his own hand, then put its palm upon his forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is so little dust upon your garments,\xe2\x80\x9d the Rabbi said,\r\nfamiliarly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I infer you passed the night in this city of our\r\nfathers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph replied, \xe2\x80\x9cas we could only make Bethany before the night\r\ncame, we stayed in the khan there, and took the road again at\r\ndaybreak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe journey before you is long, then\xe2\x80\x94not to Joppa, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly to Bethlehem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countenance of the Rabbi, theretofore open and friendly, became\r\nlowering and sinister, and he cleared his throat with a growl instead\r\nof a cough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes\xe2\x80\x94I see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou were born in Bethlehem, and wend\r\nthither now, with your daughter, to be counted for taxation, as ordered\r\nby Caesar. The children of Jacob are as the tribes in Egypt were\xe2\x80\x94only\r\nthey have neither a Moses nor a Joshua. How are the mighty fallen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph answered, without change of posture or countenance,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe woman is not my daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the Rabbi clung to the political idea; and he went on, without\r\nnoticing the explanation, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are the Zealots doing down in Galilee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a carpenter, and Nazareth is a village,\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph, cautiously.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe street on which my bench stands is not a road leading to any city.\r\nHewing wood and sawing plank leave me no time to take part in the\r\ndisputes of parties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are a Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rabbi, earnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are a Jew, and of\r\nthe line of David. It is not possible you can find pleasure in the\r\npayment of any tax except the shekel given by ancient custom to\r\nJehovah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph held his peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not complain,\xe2\x80\x9d his friend continued, \xe2\x80\x9cof the amount of the tax\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndenarius is a trifle. Oh no! The imposition of the tax is the offense.\r\nAnd, besides, what is paying it but submission to tyranny? Tell me, is\r\nit true that Judas claims to be the Messiah? You live in the midst of\r\nhis followers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard his followers say he was the Messiah,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph replied.\r\n\r\nAt this point the wimple was drawn aside, and for an instant the whole\r\nface of the woman was exposed. The eyes of the Rabbi wandered that way,\r\nand he had time to see a countenance of rare beauty, kindled by a look\r\nof intense interest; then a blush overspread her cheeks and brow, and\r\nthe veil was returned to its place.\r\n\r\nThe politician forgot his subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour daughter is comely,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, speaking lower.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not my daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph repeated.\r\n\r\nThe curiosity of the Rabbi was aroused; seeing which, the Nazarene\r\nhastened to say further, \xe2\x80\x9cShe is the child of Joachim and Anna of\r\nBethlehem, of whom you have at least heard, for they were of great\r\nrepute\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the Rabbi, deferentially, \xe2\x80\x9cI know them. They were\r\nlineally descended from David. I knew them well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they are dead now,\xe2\x80\x9d the Nazarene proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cThey died in\r\nNazareth. Joachim was not rich, yet he left a house and garden to be\r\ndivided between his daughters Marian and Mary. This is one of them; and\r\nto save her portion of the property, the law required her to marry her\r\nnext of kin. She is now my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you were\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer uncle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! And as you were both born in Bethlehem, the Roman compels\r\nyou to take her there with you to be also counted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Rabbi clasped his hands, and looked indignantly to heaven,\r\nexclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cThe God of Israel still lives! The vengeance is his!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that he turned and abruptly departed. A stranger near by,\r\nobserving Joseph\xe2\x80\x99s amazement, said, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cRabbi Samuel is a zealot.\r\nJudas himself is not more fierce.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph, not wishing to talk with the man, appeared not to hear, and\r\nbusied himself gathering in a little heap the grass which the donkey\r\nhad tossed abroad; after which he leaned upon his staff again, and\r\nwaited.\r\n\r\nIn another hour the party passed out the gate, and, turning to the\r\nleft, took the road into Bethlehem. The descent into the valley of\r\nHinnom was quite broken, garnished here and there with straggling wild\r\nolive-trees. Carefully, tenderly, the Nazarene walked by the woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside, leading-strap in hand. On their left, reaching to the south and\r\neast round Mount Zion, rose the city wall, and on their right the steep\r\nprominences which form the western boundary of the valley.\r\n\r\nSlowly they passed the Lower Pool of Gihon, out of which the sun was\r\nfast driving the lessening shadow of the royal hill; slowly they\r\nproceeded, keeping parallel with the aqueduct from the Pools of\r\nSolomon, until near the site of the country-house on what is now called\r\nthe Hill of Evil Counsel; there they began to ascend to the plain of\r\nRephaim. The sun streamed garishly over the stony face of the famous\r\nlocality, and under its influence Mary, the daughter of Joachim,\r\ndropped the wimple entirely, and bared her head. Joseph told the story\r\nof the Philistines surprised in their camp there by David. He was\r\ntedious in the narrative, speaking with the solemn countenance and\r\nlifeless manner of a dull man. She did not always hear him.\r\n\r\nWherever on the land men go, and on the sea ships, the face and figure\r\nof the Jew are familiar. The physical type of the race has always been\r\nthe same; yet there have been some individual variations. \xe2\x80\x9cNow he was\r\nruddy, and withal of a beautiful countenance, and goodly to look to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSuch was the son of Jesse when brought before Samuel. The fancies of\r\nmen have been ever since ruled by the description. Poetic license has\r\nextended the peculiarities of the ancestor to his notable descendants.\r\nSo all our ideal Solomons have fair faces, and hair and beard chestnut\r\nin the shade, and of the tint of gold in the sun. Such, we are also\r\nmade believe, were the locks of Absalom the beloved. And, in the\r\nabsence of authentic history, tradition has dealt no less lovingly by\r\nher whom we are now following down to the native city of the ruddy\r\nking.\r\n\r\nShe was not more than fifteen. Her form, voice, and manner belonged to\r\nthe period of transition from girlhood. Her face was perfectly oval,\r\nher complexion more pale than fair. The nose was faultless; the lips,\r\nslightly parted, were full and ripe, giving to the lines of the mouth\r\nwarmth, tenderness, and trust; the eyes were blue and large, and shaded\r\nby drooping lids and long lashes; and, in harmony with all, a flood of\r\ngolden hair, in the style permitted to Jewish brides, fell unconfined\r\ndown her back to the pillion on which she sat. The throat and neck had\r\nthe downy softness sometimes seen which leaves the artist in doubt\r\nwhether it is an effect of contour or color. To these charms of feature\r\nand person were added others more indefinable\xe2\x80\x94an air of purity which\r\nonly the soul can impart, and of abstraction natural to such as think\r\nmuch of things impalpable. Often, with trembling lips, she raised her\r\neyes to heaven, itself not more deeply blue; often she crossed her\r\nhands upon her breast, as in adoration and prayer; often she raised her\r\nhead like one listening eagerly for a calling voice. Now and then,\r\nmidst his slow utterances, Joseph turned to look at her, and, catching\r\nthe expression kindling her face as with light, forgot his theme, and\r\nwith bowed head, wondering, plodded on.\r\n\r\nSo they skirted the great plain, and at length reached the elevation\r\nMar Elias; from which, across a valley, they beheld Bethlehem, the old,\r\nold House of Bread, its white walls crowning a ridge, and shining above\r\nthe brown scumbling of leafless orchards. They paused there, and\r\nrested, while Joseph pointed out the places of sacred renown; then they\r\nwent down into the valley to the well which was the scene of one of the\r\nmarvellous exploits of David\xe2\x80\x99s strong men. The narrow space was crowded\r\nwith people and animals. A fear came upon Joseph\xe2\x80\x94a fear lest, if the\r\ntown were so thronged, there might not be house-room for the gentle\r\nMary. Without delay, he hurried on, past the pillar of stone marking\r\nthe tomb of Rachel, up the gardened slope, saluting none of the many\r\npersons he met on the way, until he stopped before the portal of the\r\nkhan that then stood outside the village gates, near a junction of\r\nroads.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\nTo understand thoroughly what happened to the Nazarene at the khan, the\r\nreader must be reminded that Eastern inns were different from the inns\r\nof the Western world. They were called khans, from the Persian, and, in\r\nsimplest form, were fenced enclosures, without house or shed, often\r\nwithout a gate or entrance. Their sites were chosen with reference to\r\nshade, defence, or water. Such were the inns that sheltered Jacob when\r\nhe went to seek a wife in Padan-Aram. Their like may been seen at this\r\nday in the stopping-places of the desert. On the other hand, some of\r\nthem, especially those on the roads between great cities, like\r\nJerusalem and Alexandria, were princely establishments, monuments to\r\nthe piety of the kings who built them. In ordinary, however, they were\r\nno more than the house or possession of a sheik, in which, as in\r\nheadquarters, he swayed his tribe. Lodging the traveller was the least\r\nof their uses; they were markets, factories, forts; places of\r\nassemblage and residence for merchants and artisans quite as much as\r\nplaces of shelter for belated and wandering wayfarers. Within their\r\nwalls, all the year round, occurred the multiplied daily transactions\r\nof a town.\r\n\r\nThe singular management of these hostelries was the feature likely to\r\nstrike a Western mind with most force. There was no host or hostess; no\r\nclerk, cook, or kitchen; a steward at the gate was all the assertion of\r\ngovernment or proprietorship anywhere visible. Strangers arriving\r\nstayed at will without rendering account. A consequence of the system\r\nwas that whoever came had to bring his food and culinary outfit with\r\nhim, or buy them of dealers in the khan. The same rule held good as to\r\nhis bed and bedding, and forage for his beasts. Water, rest, shelter,\r\nand protection were all he looked for from the proprietor, and they\r\nwere gratuities. The peace of synagogues was sometimes broken by\r\nbrawling disputants, but that of the khans never. The houses and all\r\ntheir appurtenances were sacred: a well was not more so.\r\n\r\nThe khan at Bethlehem, before which Joseph and his wife stopped, was a\r\ngood specimen of its class, being neither very primitive nor very\r\nprincely. The building was purely Oriental; that is to say, a\r\nquadrangular block of rough stones, one story high, flat-roofed,\r\nexternally unbroken by a window, and with but one principal entrance\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ndoorway, which was also a gateway, on the eastern side, or front. The\r\nroad ran by the door so near that the chalk dust half covered the\r\nlintel. A fence of flat rocks, beginning at the northeastern corner of\r\nthe pile, extended many yards down the slope to a point from whence it\r\nswept westwardly to a limestone bluff; making what was in the highest\r\ndegree essential to a respectable khan\xe2\x80\x94a safe enclosure for animals.\r\n\r\nIn a village like Bethlehem, as there was but one sheik, there could\r\nnot well be more than one khan; and, though born in the place, the\r\nNazarene, from long residence elsewhere, had no claim to hospitality in\r\nthe town. Moreover, the enumeration for which he was coming might be\r\nthe work of weeks or months; Roman deputies in the provinces were\r\nproverbially slow; and to impose himself and wife for a period so\r\nuncertain upon acquaintances or relations was out of the question. So,\r\nbefore he drew nigh the great house, while he was yet climbing the\r\nslope, in the steep places toiling to hasten the donkey, the fear that\r\nhe might not find accommodations in the khan became a painful anxiety;\r\nfor he found the road thronged with men and boys who, with great ado,\r\nwere taking their cattle, horses, and camels to and from the valley,\r\nsome to water, some to the neighboring caves. And when he was come\r\nclose by, his alarm was not allayed by the discovery of a crowd\r\ninvesting the door of the establishment, while the enclosure adjoining,\r\nbroad as it was, seemed already full.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe cannot reach the door,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph said, in his slow way. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us stop\r\nhere, and learn, if we can, what has happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe wife, without answering, quietly drew the wimple aside. The look of\r\nfatigue at first upon her face changed to one of interest. She found\r\nherself at the edge of an assemblage that could not be other than a\r\nmatter of curiosity to her, although it was common enough at the khans\r\non any of the highways which the great caravans were accustomed to\r\ntraverse. There were men on foot, running hither and thither, talking\r\nshrilly and in all the tongues of Syria; men on horseback screaming to\r\nmen on camels; men struggling doubtfully with fractious cows and\r\nfrightened sheep; men peddling bread and wine; and among the mass a\r\nherd of boys apparently in chase of a herd of dogs. Everybody and\r\neverything seemed to be in motion at the same time. Possibly the fair\r\nspectator was too weary to be long attracted by the scene; in a little\r\nwhile she sighed, and settled down on the pillion, and, as if in search\r\nof peace and rest, or in expectation of some one, looked off to the\r\nsouth, and up to the tall cliffs of the Mount of Paradise, then faintly\r\nreddening under the setting sun.\r\n\r\nWhile she was thus looking, a man pushed his way out of the press, and,\r\nstopping close by the donkey, faced about with an angry brow. The\r\nNazarene spoke to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I am what I take you to be, good friend\xe2\x80\x94a son of Judah\xe2\x80\x94may I ask\r\nthe cause of this multitude?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger turned fiercely; but, seeing the solemn countenance of\r\nJoseph, so in keeping with his deep, slow voice and speech, he raised\r\nhis hand in half-salutation, and replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace be to you, Rabbi! I am a son of Judah, and will answer you. I\r\ndwell in Beth-Dagon, which, you know, is in what used to be the land of\r\nthe tribe of Dan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the road to Joppa from Modin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you have been in Beth-Dagon,\xe2\x80\x9d the man said, his face softening yet\r\nmore. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat wanderers we of Judah are! I have been away from the\r\nridge\xe2\x80\x94old Ephrath, as our father Jacob called it\xe2\x80\x94for many years. When\r\nthe proclamation went abroad requiring all Hebrews to be numbered at\r\nthe cities of their birth\xe2\x80\x94 That is my business here, Rabbi.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph\xe2\x80\x99s face remained stolid as a mask, while he remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\ncome for that also\xe2\x80\x94I and my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger glanced at Mary and kept silence. She was looking up at\r\nthe bald top of Gedor. The sun touched her upturned face, and filled\r\nthe violet depths of her eyes, and upon her parted lips trembled an\r\naspiration which could not have been to a mortal. For the moment, all\r\nthe humanity of her beauty seemed refined away: she was as we fancy\r\nthey are who sit close by the gate in the transfiguring light of\r\nHeaven. The Beth-Dagonite saw the original of what, centuries after,\r\ncame as a vision of genius to Sanzio the divine, and left him immortal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what was I speaking? Ah! I remember. I was about to say that when I\r\nheard of the order to come here, I was angry. Then I thought of the old\r\nhill, and the town, and the valley falling away into the depths of\r\nCedron; of the vines and orchards, and fields of grain, unfailing since\r\nthe days of Boaz and Ruth, of the familiar mountains\xe2\x80\x94Gedor here, Gibeah\r\nyonder, Mar Elias there\xe2\x80\x94which, when I was a boy, were the walls of the\r\nworld to me; and I forgave the tyrants and came\xe2\x80\x94I, and Rachel, my wife,\r\nand Deborah and Michal, our roses of Sharon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man paused again, looking abruptly at Mary, who was now looking at\r\nhim and listening. Then he said, \xe2\x80\x9cRabbi, will not your wife go to mine?\r\nYou may see her yonder with the children, under the leaning olive-tree\r\nat the bend of the road. I tell you\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he turned to Joseph and spoke\r\npositively\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you the khan is full. It is useless to ask at the\r\ngate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph\xe2\x80\x99s will was slow, like his mind; he hesitated, but at length\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cThe offer is kind. Whether there be room for us or not in the\r\nhouse, we will go see your people. Let me speak to the gate-keeper\r\nmyself. I will return quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, putting the leading-strap in the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s hand, he pushed into\r\nthe stirring crowd.\r\n\r\nThe keeper sat on a great cedar block outside the gate. Against the\r\nwall behind him leaned a javelin. A dog squatted on the block by his\r\nside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peace of Jehovah be with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph, at last confronting\r\nthe keeper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you give, may you find again; and, when found, be it many times\r\nmultiplied to you and yours,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the watchman, gravely, though\r\nwithout moving.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a Bethlehemite,\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph, in his most deliberate way. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nthere not room for\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may have heard of me\xe2\x80\x94Joseph of Nazareth. This is the house of my\r\nfathers. I am of the line of David.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words held the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s hope. If they failed him, further\r\nappeal was idle, even that of the offer of many shekels. To be a son of\r\nJudah was one thing\xe2\x80\x94in the tribal opinion a great thing; to be of the\r\nhouse of David was yet another; on the tongue of a Hebrew there could\r\nbe no higher boast. A thousand years and more had passed since the\r\nboyish shepherd became the successor of Saul and founded a royal\r\nfamily. Wars, calamities, other kings, and the countless obscuring\r\nprocesses of time had, as respects fortune, lowered his descendants to\r\nthe common Jewish level; the bread they ate came to them of toil never\r\nmore humble; yet they had the benefit of history sacredly kept, of\r\nwhich genealogy was the first chapter and the last; they could not\r\nbecome unknown, while, wherever they went In Israel, acquaintance drew\r\nafter it a respect amounting to reverence.\r\n\r\nIf this were so in Jerusalem and elsewhere, certainly one of the sacred\r\nline might reasonably rely upon it at the door of the khan of\r\nBethlehem. To say, as Joseph said, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the house of my fathers,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwas to say the truth most simply and literally; for it was the very\r\nhouse Ruth ruled as the wife of Boaz, the very house in which Jesse and\r\nhis ten sons, David the youngest, were born, the very house in which\r\nSamuel came seeking a king, and found him; the very house which David\r\ngave to the son of Barzillai, the friendly Gileadite; the very house in\r\nwhich Jeremiah, by prayer, rescued the remnant of his race flying\r\nbefore the Babylonians.\r\n\r\nThe appeal was not without effect. The keeper of the gate slid down\r\nfrom the cedar block, and, laying his hand upon his beard, said,\r\nrespectfully, \xe2\x80\x9cRabbi, I cannot tell you when this door first opened in\r\nwelcome to the traveller, but it was more than a thousand years ago;\r\nand in all that time there is no known instance of a good man turned\r\naway, save when there was no room to rest him in. If it has been so\r\nwith the stranger, just cause must the steward have who says no to one\r\nof the line of David. Wherefore, I salute you again; and, if you care\r\nto go with me, I will show you that there is not a lodging-place left\r\nin the house; neither in the chambers, nor in the lewens, nor in the\r\ncourt\xe2\x80\x94not even on the roof. May I ask when you came?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe keeper smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The stranger that dwelleth with you shall be as one born among you,\r\nand thou shalt love him as thyself.\xe2\x80\x99 Is not that the law, Rabbi?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it be the law, can I say to one a long time come, \xe2\x80\x98Go thy way;\r\nanother is here to take thy place?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYet Joseph held his peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, if I said so, to whom would the place belong? See the many that\r\nhave been waiting, some of them since noon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are all these people?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Joseph, turning to the crowd. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nwhy are they here at this time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat which doubtless brought you, Rabbi\xe2\x80\x94the decree of the Caesar\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nkeeper threw an interrogative glance at the Nazarene, then\r\ncontinued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbrought most of those who have lodging in the house. And\r\nyesterday the caravan passing from Damascus to Arabia and Lower Egypt\r\narrived. These you see here belong to it\xe2\x80\x94men and camels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill Joseph persisted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe court is large,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but it is heaped with cargoes\xe2\x80\x94with bales of silk, and pockets of\r\nspices, and goods of every kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen for a moment the face of the applicant lost its stolidity; the\r\nlustreless, staring eyes dropped. With some warmth he next said, \xe2\x80\x9cI do\r\nnot care for myself, but I have with me my wife, and the night is\r\ncold\xe2\x80\x94colder on these heights than in Nazareth. She cannot live in the\r\nopen air. Is there not room in the town?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese people\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the keeper waved his hand to the throng before the\r\ndoor\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chave all besought the town, and they report its accommodations\r\nall engaged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain Joseph studied the ground, saying, half to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cShe is so\r\nyoung! if I make her bed on the hill, the frosts will kill her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he spoke to the keeper again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be you knew her parents, Joachim and Anna, once of Bethlehem,\r\nand, like myself, of the line of David.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I knew them. They were good people. That was in my youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s eyes sought the ground in thought. Suddenly he\r\nraised his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I cannot make room for you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot turn you away.\r\nRabbi, I will do the best I can for you. How many are of your party?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoseph reflected, then replied, \xe2\x80\x9cMy wife and a friend with his family,\r\nfrom Beth-Dagon, a little town over by Joppa; in all, six of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. You shall not lie out on the ridge. Bring your people, and\r\nhasten; for, when the sun goes down behind the mountain, you know the\r\nnight comes quickly, and it is nearly there now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you the blessing of the houseless traveller; that of the\r\nsojourner will follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the Nazarene went back joyfully to Mary and the\r\nBeth-Dagonite. In a little while the latter brought up his family, the\r\nwomen mounted on donkeys. The wife was matronly, the daughters were\r\nimages of what she must have been in youth; and as they drew nigh the\r\ndoor, the keeper knew them to be of the humble class.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is she of whom I spoke,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Nazarene; \xe2\x80\x9cand these are our\r\nfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMary\xe2\x80\x99s veil was raised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlue eyes and hair of gold,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the steward to himself, seeing\r\nbut her. \xe2\x80\x9cSo looked the young king when he went to sing before Saul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he took the leading-strap from Joseph, and said to Mary, \xe2\x80\x9cPeace to\r\nyou, O daughter of David!\xe2\x80\x9d Then to the others, \xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you all!\xe2\x80\x9d Then\r\nto Joseph, \xe2\x80\x9cRabbi, follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe party were conducted into a wide passage paved with stone, from\r\nwhich they entered the court of the khan. To a stranger the scene would\r\nhave been curious; but they noticed the lewens that yawned darkly upon\r\nthem from all sides, and the court itself, only to remark how crowded\r\nthey were. By a lane reserved in the stowage of the cargoes, and thence\r\nby a passage similar to the one at the entrance, they emerged into the\r\nenclosure adjoining the house, and came upon camels, horses, and\r\ndonkeys, tethered and dozing in close groups; among them were the\r\nkeepers, men of many lands; and they, too, slept or kept silent watch.\r\nThey went down the slope of the crowded yard slowly, for the dull\r\ncarriers of the women had wills of their own. At length they turned\r\ninto a path running towards the gray limestone bluff overlooking the\r\nkhan on the west.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are going to the cave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph, laconically.\r\n\r\nThe guide lingered till Mary came to his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cave to which we are going,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to her, \xe2\x80\x9cmust have been a\r\nresort of your ancestor David. From the field below us, and from the\r\nwell down in the valley, he used to drive his flocks to it for safety;\r\nand afterwards, when he was king, he came back to the old house here\r\nfor rest and health, bringing great trains of animals. The mangers yet\r\nremain as they were in his day. Better a bed on the floor where he has\r\nslept than one in the court-yard or out by the roadside. Ah, here is\r\nthe house before the cave!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis speech must not be taken as an apology for the lodging offered.\r\nThere was no need of apology. The place was the best then at disposal.\r\nThe guests were simple folks, by habits of life easily satisfied. To\r\nthe Jew of that period, moreover, abode in caverns was a familiar idea,\r\nmade so by every-day occurrences, and by what he heard of Sabbaths in\r\nthe synagogues. How much of Jewish history, how many of the many\r\nexciting incidents in that history, had transpired in caves! Yet\r\nfurther, these people were Jews of Bethlehem, with whom the idea was\r\nespecially commonplace; for their locality abounded with caves great\r\nand small, some of which had been dwelling-places from the time of the\r\nEmim and Horites. No more was there offence to them in the fact that\r\nthe cavern to which they were being taken had been, or was, a stable.\r\nThey were the descendants of a race of herdsmen, whose flocks\r\nhabitually shared both their habitations and wanderings. In keeping\r\nwith a custom derived from Abraham, the tent of the Bedawin yet\r\nshelters his horses and children alike. So they obeyed the keeper\r\ncheerfully, and gazed at the house, feeling only a natural curiosity.\r\nEverything associated with the history of David was interesting to\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nThe building was low and narrow, projecting but a little from the rock\r\nto which it was joined at the rear, and wholly without a window. In its\r\nblank front there was a door, swung on enormous hinges, and thickly\r\ndaubed with ochreous clay. While the wooden bolt of the lock was being\r\npushed back, the women were assisted from their pillions. Upon the\r\nopening of the door, the keeper called out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe guests entered, and stared about them. It became apparent\r\nimmediately that the house was but a mask or covering for the mouth of\r\na natural cave or grotto, probably forty feet long, nine or ten high,\r\nand twelve or fifteen in width. The light streamed through the doorway,\r\nover an uneven floor, falling upon piles of grain and fodder, and\r\nearthenware and household property, occupying the centre of the\r\nchamber. Along the sides were mangers, low enough for sheep, and built\r\nof stones laid in cement. There were no stalls or partitions of any\r\nkind. Dust and chaff yellowed the floor, filled all the crevices and\r\nhollows, and thickened the spider-webs, which dropped from the ceiling\r\nlike bits of dirty linen; otherwise the place was cleanly, and, to\r\nappearance, as comfortable as any of the arched lewens of the khan\r\nproper. In fact, a cave was the model and first suggestion of the\r\nlewen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in!\xe2\x80\x9d said the guide. \xe2\x80\x9cThese piles upon the floor are for\r\ntravellers like yourselves. Take what of them you need.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he spoke to Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you rest here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe place is sanctified,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI leave you then. Peace be with you all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he was gone, they busied themselves making the cave habitable.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt a certain hour in the evening the shouting and stir of the people in\r\nand about the khan ceased; at the same time, every Israelite, if not\r\nalready upon his feet, arose, solemnized his face, looked towards\r\nJerusalem, crossed his hands upon his breast, and prayed; for it was\r\nthe sacred ninth hour, when sacrifices were offered in the temple on\r\nMoriah, and God was supposed to be there. When the hands of the\r\nworshippers fell down, the commotion broke forth again; everybody\r\nhastened to bread, or to make his pallet. A little later, the lights\r\nwere put out, and there was silence, and then sleep.\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout midnight some one on the roof cried out, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat light is that in\r\nthe sky? Awake, brethren, awake and see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people, half asleep, sat up and looked; then they became\r\nwide-awake, though wonder-struck. And the stir spread to the court\r\nbelow, and into the lewens; soon the entire tenantry of the house and\r\ncourt and enclosure were out gazing at the sky.\r\n\r\nAnd this was what they saw. A ray of light, beginning at a height\r\nimmeasurably beyond the nearest stars, and dropping obliquely to the\r\nearth; at its top, a diminishing point; at its base, many furlongs in\r\nwidth; its sides blending softly with the darkness of the night, its\r\ncore a roseate electrical splendor. The apparition seemed to rest on\r\nthe nearest mountain southeast of the town, making a pale corona along\r\nthe line of the summit. The khan was touched luminously, so that those\r\nupon the roof saw each other\xe2\x80\x99s faces, all filled with wonder.\r\n\r\nSteadily, through minutes, the ray lingered, and then the wonder\r\nchanged to awe and fear; the timid trembled; the boldest spoke in\r\nwhispers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaw you ever the like?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems just over the mountain there. I cannot tell what it is, nor\r\ndid I ever see anything like it,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be that a star has burst and fallen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked another, his tongue\r\nfaltering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen a star falls, its light goes out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one, confidently. \xe2\x80\x9cThe shepherds have seen a lion,\r\nand made fires to keep him from the flocks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men next the speaker drew a breath of relief, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\r\nis it! The flocks were grazing in the valley over there to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA bystander dispelled the comfort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no! Though all the wood in all the valleys of Judah was brought\r\ntogether in one pile and fired, the blaze would not throw a light so\r\nstrong and high.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter that there was silence on the house-top, broken but once again\r\nwhile the mystery continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrethren!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a Jew of venerable mien, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat we see is the\r\nladder our father Jacob saw in his dream. Blessed be the Lord God of\r\nour fathers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\n\r\nA mile and a half, it may be two miles, southeast of Bethlehem, there\r\nis a plain separated from the town by an intervening swell of the\r\nmountain. Besides being well sheltered from the north winds, the vale\r\nwas covered with a growth of sycamore, dwarf-oak, and pine trees, while\r\nin the glens and ravines adjoining there were thickets of olive and\r\nmulberry; all at this season of the year invaluable for the support of\r\nsheep, goats, and cattle, of which the wandering flocks consisted.\r\n\r\nAt the side farthest from the town, close under a bluff, there was an\r\nextensive marah, or sheepcot, ages old. In some long-forgotten foray,\r\nthe building had been unroofed and almost demolished. The enclosure\r\nattached to it remained intact, however, and that was of more\r\nimportance to the shepherds who drove their charges thither than the\r\nhouse itself. The stone wall around the lot was high as a man\xe2\x80\x99s head,\r\nyet not so high but that sometimes a panther or a lion, hungering from\r\nthe wilderness, leaped boldly in. On the inner side of the wall, and as\r\nan additional security against the constant danger, a hedge of the\r\nrhamnus had been planted, an invention so successful that now a sparrow\r\ncould hardly penetrate the overtopping branches, armed as they were\r\nwith great clusters of thorns hard as spikes.\r\n\r\nThe day of the occurrences which occupy the preceding chapters, a\r\nnumber of shepherds, seeking fresh walks for their flocks, led them up\r\nto this plain; and from early morning the groves had been made ring\r\nwith calls, and the blows of axes, the bleating of sheep and goats, the\r\ntinkling of bells, the lowing of cattle, and the barking of dogs. When\r\nthe sun went down, they led the way to the marah, and by nightfall had\r\neverything safe in the field; then they kindled a fire down by the\r\ngate, partook of their humble supper, and sat down to rest and talk,\r\nleaving one on watch.\r\n\r\nThere were six of these men, omitting the watchman; and afterwhile they\r\nassembled in a group near the fire, some sitting, some lying prone. As\r\nthey went bareheaded habitually, their hair stood out in thick, coarse,\r\nsunburnt shocks; their beard covered their throats, and fell in mats\r\ndown the breast; mantles of the skin of kids and lambs, with the fleece\r\non, wrapped them from neck to knee, leaving the arms exposed; broad\r\nbelts girthed the rude garments to their waists; their sandals were of\r\nthe coarsest quality; from their right shoulders hung scrips containing\r\nfood and selected stones for slings, with which they were armed; on the\r\nground near each one lay his crook, a symbol of his calling and a\r\nweapon of offence.\r\n\r\nSuch were the shepherds of Judea! In appearance, rough and savage as\r\nthe gaunt dogs sitting with them around the blaze; in fact,\r\nsimple-minded, tender-hearted; effects due, in part, to the primitive\r\nlife they led, but chiefly to their constant care of things lovable and\r\nhelpless.\r\n\r\nThey rested and talked, and their talk was all about their flocks, a\r\ndull theme to the world, yet a theme which was all the world to them.\r\nIf in narrative they dwelt long upon affairs of trifling moment; if one\r\nof them omitted nothing of detail in recounting the loss of a lamb, the\r\nrelation between him and the unfortunate should be remembered: at birth\r\nit became his charge, his to keep all its days, to help over the\r\nfloods, to carry down the hollows, to name and train; it was to be his\r\ncompanion, his object of thought and interest, the subject of his will;\r\nit was to enliven and share his wanderings; in its defense he might be\r\ncalled on to face the lion or robber\xe2\x80\x94to die.\r\n\r\nThe great events, such as blotted out nations and changed the mastery\r\nof the world, were trifles to them, if perchance they came to their\r\nknowledge. Of what Herod was doing in this city or that, building\r\npalaces and gymnasia, and indulging forbidden practises, they\r\noccasionally heard. As was her habit in those days, Rome did not wait\r\nfor people slow to inquire about her; she came to them. Over the hills\r\nalong which he was leading his lagging herd, or in the fastnesses in\r\nwhich he was hiding them, not unfrequently the shepherd was startled by\r\nthe blare of trumpets, and, peering out, beheld a cohort, sometimes a\r\nlegion, in march; and when the glittering crests were gone, and the\r\nexcitement incident to the intrusion over, he bent himself to evolve\r\nthe meaning of the eagles and gilded globes of the soldiery, and the\r\ncharm of a life so the opposite of his own.\r\n\r\nYet these men, rude and simple as they were, had a knowledge and a\r\nwisdom of their own. On Sabbaths they were accustomed to purify\r\nthemselves, and go up into the synagogues, and sit on the benches\r\nfarthest from the ark. When the chazzan bore the Torah round, none\r\nkissed it with greater zest; when the sheliach read the text, none\r\nlistened to the interpreter with more absolute faith; and none took\r\naway with them more of the elder\xe2\x80\x99s sermon, or gave it more thought\r\nafterwards. In a verse of the Shema they found all the learning and all\r\nthe law of their simple lives\xe2\x80\x94that their Lord was One God, and that\r\nthey must love him with all their souls. And they loved him, and such\r\nwas their wisdom, surpassing that of kings.\r\n\r\nWhile they talked, and before the first watch was over, one by one the\r\nshepherds went to sleep, each lying where he had sat.\r\n\r\nThe night, like most nights of the winter season in the hill country,\r\nwas clear, crisp, and sparkling with stars. There was no wind. The\r\natmosphere seemed never so pure, and the stillness was more than\r\nsilence; it was a holy hush, a warning that heaven was stooping low to\r\nwhisper some good thing to the listening earth.\r\n\r\nBy the gate, hugging his mantle close, the watchman walked; at times he\r\nstopped, attracted by a stir among the sleeping herds, or by a jackal\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncry off on the mountain-side. The midnight was slow coming to him; but\r\nat last it came. His task was done; now for the dreamless sleep with\r\nwhich labor blesses its wearied children! He moved towards the fire,\r\nbut paused; a light was breaking around him, soft and white, like the\r\nmoon\xe2\x80\x99s. He waited breathlessly. The light deepened; things before\r\ninvisible came to view; he saw the whole field, and all it sheltered. A\r\nchill sharper than that of the frosty air\xe2\x80\x94a chill of fear\xe2\x80\x94smote him. He\r\nlooked up; the stars were gone; the light was dropping as from a window\r\nin the sky; as he looked, it became a splendor; then, in terror, he\r\ncried,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAwake, awake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUp sprang the dogs, and, howling, ran away.\r\n\r\nThe herds rushed together bewildered.\r\n\r\nThe men clambered to their feet, weapons in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d they asked, in one voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the watchman, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sky is on fire!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly the light became intolerably bright, and they covered their\r\neyes, and dropped upon their knees; then, as their souls shrank with\r\nfear, they fell upon their faces blind and fainting, and would have\r\ndied had not a voice said to them,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they listened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not: for behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which\r\nshall be to all people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice, in sweetness and soothing more than human, and low and\r\nclear, penetrated all their being, and filled them with assurance. They\r\nrose upon their knees, and, looking worshipfully, beheld in the centre\r\nof a great glory the appearance of a man, clad in a robe intensely\r\nwhite; above its shoulders towered the tops of wings shining and\r\nfolded; a star over its forehead glowed with steady lustre, brilliant\r\nas Hesperus; its hands were stretched towards them in blessing; its\r\nface was serene and divinely beautiful.\r\n\r\nThey had often heard, and, in their simple way, talked, of angels; and\r\nthey doubted not now, but said, in their hearts, The glory of God is\r\nabout us, and this is he who of old came to the prophet by the river of\r\nUlai.\r\n\r\nDirectly the angel continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor unto you is born this day, in the city of David, a Savior, which\r\nis Christ the Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain there was a rest, while the words sank into their minds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this shall be a sign unto you,\xe2\x80\x9d the annunciator said next. \xe2\x80\x9cYe\r\nshall find the babe, wrapped in swaddling-clothes, lying in a manger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe herald spoke not again; his good tidings were told; yet he stayed\r\nawhile. Suddenly the light, of which he seemed the centre, turned\r\nroseate and began to tremble; then up, far as the men could see, there\r\nwas flashing of white wings, and coming and going of radiant forms, and\r\nvoices as of a multitude chanting in unison,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good-will towards\r\nmen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot once the praise, but many times.\r\n\r\nThen the herald raised his eyes as seeking approval of one far off; his\r\nwings stirred, and spread slowly and majestically, on their upper side\r\nwhite as snow, in the shadow vari-tinted, like mother-of-pearl; when\r\nthey were expanded many cubits beyond his stature, he arose lightly,\r\nand, without effort, floated out of view, taking the light up with him.\r\nLong after he was gone, down from the sky fell the refrain in measure\r\nmellowed by distance, \xe2\x80\x9cGlory to God in the highest, and on earth peace,\r\ngood-will towards men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the shepherds came fully to their senses, they stared at each\r\nother stupidly, until one of them said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt was Gabriel, the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmessenger unto men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNone answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChrist the Lord is born; said he not so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen another recovered his voice, and replied, \xe2\x80\x9cThat is what he said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did he not also say, in the city of David, which is our Bethlehem\r\nyonder. And that we should find him a babe in swaddling-clothes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd lying in a manger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe first speaker gazed into the fire thoughtfully, but at length said,\r\nlike one possessed of a sudden resolve, \xe2\x80\x9cThere is but one place in\r\nBethlehem where there are mangers; but one, and that is in the cave\r\nnear the old khan. Brethren, let us go see this thing which has come to\r\npass. The priests and doctors have been a long time looking for the\r\nChrist. Now he is born, and the Lord has given us a sign by which to\r\nknow him. Let us go up and worship him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the flocks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord will take care of them. Let us make haste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen they all arose and left the marah.\r\n\r\n\r\nAround the mountain and through the town they passed, and came to the\r\ngate of the khan, where there was a man on watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have seen and heard great things to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d they replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we, too, have seen great things, but heard nothing. What did you\r\nhear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go down to the cave in the enclosure, that we may be sure; then\r\nwe will tell you all. Come with us, and see for yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a fool\xe2\x80\x99s errand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the Christ is born.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Christ! How do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go and see first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man laughed scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Christ indeed! How are you to know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was born this night, and is now lying in a manger, so we were told;\r\nand there is but one place in Bethlehem with mangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Come with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went through the court-yard without notice, although there were\r\nsome up even then talking about the wonderful light. The door of the\r\ncavern was open. A lantern was burning within, and they entered\r\nunceremoniously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you peace,\xe2\x80\x9d the watchman said to Joseph and the Beth Dagonite.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are people looking for a child born this night, whom they are to\r\nknow by finding him in swaddling-clothes and lying in a manger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment the face of the stolid Nazarene was moved; turning away,\r\nhe said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe child is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were led to one of the mangers, and there the child was. The\r\nlantern was brought, and the shepherds stood by mute. The little one\r\nmade no sign; it was as others just born.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the mother?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the watchman.\r\n\r\nOne of the women took the baby, and went to Mary, lying near, and put\r\nit in her arms. Then the bystanders collected about the two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d said a shepherd, at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d they all repeated, falling upon their knees in worship.\r\nOne of them repeated several times over,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the Lord, and his glory is above the earth and heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the simple men, never doubting, kissed the hem of the mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrobe, and with joyful faces departed. In the khan, to all the people\r\naroused and pressing about them, they told their story; and through the\r\ntown, and all the way back to the marah, they chanted the refrain of\r\nthe angels, \xe2\x80\x9cGlory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good-will\r\ntowards men!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe story went abroad, confirmed by the light so generally seen; and\r\nthe next day, and for days thereafter, the cave was visited by curious\r\ncrowds, of whom some believed, though the greater part laughed and\r\nmocked.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe eleventh day after the birth of the child in the cave, about\r\nmid-afternoon, the three wise men approached Jerusalem by the road from\r\nShechem. After crossing Brook Cedron, they met many people, of whom\r\nnone failed to stop and look after them curiously.\r\n\r\nJudea was of necessity an international thoroughfare; a narrow ridge,\r\nraised, apparently, by the pressure of the desert on the east, and the\r\nsea on the west, was all she could claim to be; over the ridge,\r\nhowever, nature had stretched the line of trade between the east and\r\nthe south; and that was her wealth. In other words, the riches of\r\nJerusalem were the tolls she levied on passing commerce. Nowhere else,\r\nconsequently, unless in Rome, was there such constant assemblage of so\r\nmany people of so many different nations; in no other city was a\r\nstranger less strange to the residents than within her walls and\r\npurlieus. And yet these three men excited the wonder of all whom they\r\nmet on the way to the gates.\r\n\r\nA child belonging to some women sitting by the roadside opposite the\r\nTombs of the Kings saw the party coming; immediately it clapped its\r\nhands, and cried, \xe2\x80\x9cLook, look! What pretty bells! What big camels!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bells were silver; the camels, as we have seen, were of unusual\r\nsize and whiteness, and moved with singular stateliness; the trappings\r\ntold of the desert and of long journeys thereon, and also of ample\r\nmeans in possession of the owners, who sat under the little canopies\r\nexactly as they appeared at the rendezvous beyond the Jebel. Yet it was\r\nnot the bells or the camels, or their furniture, or the demeanor of the\r\nriders, that were so wonderful; it was the question put by the man who\r\nrode foremost of the three.\r\n\r\nThe approach to Jerusalem from the north is across a plain which dips\r\nsouthward, leaving the Damascus Gate in a vale or hollow. The road is\r\nnarrow, but deeply cut by long use, and in places difficult on account\r\nof the cobbles left loose and dry by the washing of the rains. On\r\neither side, however, there stretched, in the old time, rich fields and\r\nhandsome olive-groves, which must, in luxurious growth, have been\r\nbeautiful, especially to travellers fresh from the wastes of the\r\ndesert. In this road, the three stopped before the party in front of\r\nthe Tombs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, stroking his plaited beard, and bending\r\nfrom his cot, \xe2\x80\x9cis not Jerusalem close by?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the woman into whose arms the child had shrunk. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the\r\ntrees on yon swell were a little lower you could see the towers on the\r\nmarket-place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar gave the Greek and the Hindoo a look, then asked,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he that is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe women gazed at each other without reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not heard of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, tell everybody that we have seen his star in the east, and are\r\ncome to worship him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon the friends rode on. Of others they asked the same question,\r\nwith like result. A large company whom they met going to the Grotto of\r\nJeremiah were so astonished by the inquiry and the appearance of the\r\ntravellers that they turned about and followed them into the city.\r\n\r\nSo much were the three occupied with the idea of their mission that\r\nthey did not care for the view which presently rose before them in the\r\nutmost magnificence: for the village first to receive them on Bezetha;\r\nfor Mizpah and Olivet, over on their left; for the wall behind the\r\nvillage, with its forty tall and solid towers, superadded partly for\r\nstrength, partly to gratify the critical taste of the kingly builder;\r\nfor the same towered wall bending off to the right, with many an angle,\r\nand here and there an embattled gate, up to the three great white piles\r\nPhasaelus, Mariamne, and Hippicus; for Zion, tallest of the hills,\r\ncrowned with marble palaces, and never so beautiful; for the glittering\r\nterraces of the temple on Moriah, admittedly one of the wonders of the\r\nearth; for the regal mountains rimming the sacred city round about\r\nuntil it seemed in the hollow of a mighty bowl.\r\n\r\nThey came, at length, to a tower of great height and strength,\r\noverlooking the gate which, at that time, answered to the present\r\nDamascus Gate, and marked the meeting-place of the three roads from\r\nShechem, Jericho, and Gibeon. A Roman guard kept the passage-way. By\r\nthis time the people following the camels formed a train sufficient to\r\ndraw the idlers hanging about the portal; so that when Balthasar\r\nstopped to speak to the sentinel, the three became instantly the centre\r\nof a close circle eager to hear all that passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you peace,\xe2\x80\x9d the Egyptian said, in a clear voice.\r\n\r\nThe sentinel made no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have come great distances in search of one who is born King of the\r\nJews. Can you tell us where he is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe soldier raised the visor of his helmet, and called loudly. From an\r\napartment at the right of the passage an officer appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive way,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, to the crowd which now pressed closer in; and as\r\nthey seemed slow to obey, he advanced twirling his javelin vigorously,\r\nnow right, now left; and so he gained room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of Balthasar, speaking in the idiom of the\r\ncity.\r\n\r\nAnd Balthasar answered in the same,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he that is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerod?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the officer, confounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerod\xe2\x80\x99s kingship is from Caesar; not Herod.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no other King of the Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we have seen the star of him we seek, and come to worship him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Roman was perplexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo farther,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, at last. \xe2\x80\x9cGo farther. I am not a Jew. Carry the\r\nquestion to the doctors in the Temple, or to Hannas the priest, or,\r\nbetter still, to Herod himself. If there be another King of the Jews,\r\nhe will find him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon he made way for the strangers, and they passed the gate. But,\r\nbefore entering the narrow street, Balthasar lingered to say to his\r\nfriends, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are sufficiently proclaimed. By midnight the whole city\r\nwill have heard of us and of our mission. Let us to the khan now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\n\r\n\r\nThat evening, before sunset, some women were washing clothes on the\r\nupper step of the flight that led down into the basin of the Pool of\r\nSiloam. They knelt each before a broad bowl of earthenware. A girl at\r\nthe foot of the steps kept them supplied with water, and sang while she\r\nfilled the jar. The song was cheerful, and no doubt lightened their\r\nlabor. Occasionally they would sit upon their heels, and look up the\r\nslope of Ophel, and round to the summit of what is now the Mount of\r\nOffence, then faintly glorified by the dying sun.\r\n\r\nWhile they plied their hands, rubbing and wringing the clothes in the\r\nbowls, two other women came to them, each with an empty jar upon her\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you,\xe2\x80\x9d one of the new-comers said.\r\n\r\nThe laborers paused, sat up, wrung the water from their hands, and\r\nreturned the salutation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nearly night\xe2\x80\x94time to quit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no end to work,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut there is a time to rest, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo hear what may be passing,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat news have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have not heard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say the Christ is born,\xe2\x80\x9d said the newsmonger, plunging into her\r\nstory.\r\n\r\nIt was curious to see the faces of the laborers brighten with interest;\r\non the other side down came the jars, which, in a moment, were turned\r\ninto seats for their owners.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Christ!\xe2\x80\x9d the listeners cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo they say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody; it is common talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes anybody believe it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis afternoon three men came across Brook Cedron on the road from\r\nShechem,\xe2\x80\x9d the speaker replied, circumstantially, intending to smother\r\ndoubt. \xe2\x80\x9cEach one of them rode a camel spotless white, and larger than\r\nany ever before seen in Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eyes and mouths of the auditors opened wide.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo prove how great and rich the men were,\xe2\x80\x9d the narrator continued,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthey sat under awnings of silk; the buckles of their saddles were of\r\ngold, as was the fringe of their bridles; the bells were of silver, and\r\nmade real music. Nobody knew them; they looked as if they had come from\r\nthe ends of the world. Only one of them spoke, and of everybody on the\r\nroad, even the women and children, he asked this question\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Where is he\r\nthat is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99 No one gave them answer\xe2\x80\x94no one\r\nunderstood what they meant; so they passed on, leaving behind them this\r\nsaying: \xe2\x80\x98For we have seen his star in the east, and are come to worship\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99 They put the question to the Roman at the gate; and he, no wiser\r\nthan the simple people on the road, sent them up to Herod.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are they now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the khan. Hundreds have been to look at them already, and hundreds\r\nmore are going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody knows. They are said to be Persians\xe2\x80\x94wise men who talk with the\r\nstars\xe2\x80\x94prophets, it may be, like Elijah and Jeremiah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do they mean by King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Christ, and that he is just born.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the women laughed, and resumed her work, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, when I\r\nsee him I will believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother followed her example: \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x94well, when I see him raise the\r\ndead, I will believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA third said, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cHe has been a long time promised. It will be\r\nenough for me to see him heal one leper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the party sat talking until the night came, and, with the help of\r\nthe frosty air, drove them home.\r\n\r\n\r\nLater in the evening, about the beginning of the first watch, there was\r\nan assemblage in the palace on Mount Zion, of probably fifty persons,\r\nwho never came together except by order of Herod, and then only when he\r\nhad demanded to know some one or more of the deeper mysteries of the\r\nJewish law and history. It was, in short, a meeting of the teachers of\r\nthe colleges, of the chief priests, and of the doctors most noted in\r\nthe city for learning\xe2\x80\x94the leaders of opinion, expounders of the\r\ndifferent creeds; princes of the Sadducees; Pharisaic debaters; calm,\r\nsoft-spoken, stoical philosophers of the Essene socialists.\r\n\r\nThe chamber in which the session was held belonged to one of the\r\ninterior court-yards of the palace, and was quite large and Romanesque.\r\nThe floor was tessellated with marble blocks; the walls, unbroken by a\r\nwindow, were frescoed in panels of saffron yellow; a divan occupied the\r\ncentre of the apartment, covered with cushions of bright-yellow cloth,\r\nand fashioned in form of the letter U, the opening towards the doorway;\r\nin the arch of the divan, or, as it were, in the bend of the letter,\r\nthere was an immense bronze tripod, curiously inlaid with gold and\r\nsilver, over which a chandelier dropped from the ceiling, having seven\r\narms, each holding a lighted lamp. The divan and the lamp were purely\r\nJewish.\r\n\r\nThe company sat upon the divan after the style of Orientals, in costume\r\nsingularly uniform, except as to color. They were mostly men advanced\r\nin years; immense beards covered their faces; to their large noses were\r\nadded the effects of large black eyes, deeply shaded by bold brows;\r\ntheir demeanor was grave, dignified, even patriarchal. In brief, their\r\nsession was that of the Sanhedrim.\r\n\r\nHe who sat before the tripod, however, in the place which may be called\r\nthe head of the divan, having all the rest of his associates on his\r\nright and left, and, at the same time, before him, evidently president\r\nof the meeting, would have instantly absorbed the attention of a\r\nspectator. He had been cast in large mould, but was now shrunken and\r\nstooped to ghastliness; his white robe dropped from his shoulders in\r\nfolds that gave no hint of muscle or anything but an angular skeleton.\r\nHis hands, half concealed by sleeves of silk, white and crimson\r\nstriped, were clasped upon his knees. When he spoke, sometimes the\r\nfirst finger of the right hand extended tremulously; he seemed\r\nincapable of other gesture. But his head was a splendid dome. A few\r\nhairs, whiter than fine-drawn silver, fringed the base; over a broad,\r\nfull-sphered skull the skin was drawn close, and shone in the light\r\nwith positive brilliance; the temples were deep hollows, from which the\r\nforehead beetled like a wrinkled crag; the eyes were wan and dim; the\r\nnose was pinched; and all the lower face was muffed in a beard flowing\r\nand venerable as Aaron\xe2\x80\x99s. Such was Hillel the Babylonian! The line of\r\nprophets, long extinct in Israel, was now succeeded by a line of\r\nscholars, of whom he was first in learning\xe2\x80\x94a prophet in all but the\r\ndivine inspiration! At the age of one hundred and six, he was still\r\nRector of the Great College.\r\n\r\nOn the table before him lay outspread a roll or volume of parchment\r\ninscribed with Hebrew characters; behind him, in waiting, stood a page\r\nrichly habited.\r\n\r\nThere had been discussion, but at this moment of introduction the\r\ncompany had reached a conclusion; each one was in an attitude of rest,\r\nand the venerable Hillel, without moving, called the page.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHist!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe youth advanced respectfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo tell the king we are ready to give him answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boy hurried away.\r\n\r\nAfter a time two officers entered and stopped, one on each side the\r\ndoor; after them slowly followed a most striking personage\xe2\x80\x94an old man\r\nclad in a purple robe bordered with scarlet, and girt to his waist by a\r\nband of gold linked so fine that it was pliable as leather; the\r\nlatchets of his shoes sparkled with precious stones; a narrow crown\r\nwrought in filigree shone outside a tarbooshe of softest crimson plush,\r\nwhich, encasing his head, fell down the neck and shoulders, leaving the\r\nthroat and neck exposed. Instead of a seal, a dagger dangled from his\r\nbelt. He walked with a halting step, leaning heavily upon a staff. Not\r\nuntil he reached the opening of the divan, did he pause or look up from\r\nthe floor; then, as for the first time conscious of the company, and\r\nroused by their presence, he raised himself, and looked haughtily\r\nround, like one startled and searching for an enemy\xe2\x80\x94so dark,\r\nsuspicious, and threatening was the glance. Such was Herod the Great\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nbody broken by diseases, a conscience seared with crimes, a mind\r\nmagnificently capable, a soul fit for brotherhood with the Caesars; now\r\nseven-and-sixty years old, but guarding his throne with a jealousy\r\nnever so vigilant, a power never so despotic, and a cruelty never so\r\ninexorable.\r\n\r\nThere was a general movement on the part of the assemblage\xe2\x80\x94a bending\r\nforward in salaam by the more aged, a rising-up by the more courtierly,\r\nfollowed by low genuflections, hands upon the beard or breast.\r\n\r\nHis observations taken, Herod moved on until at the tripod opposite the\r\nvenerable Hillel, who met his cold glance with an inclination of the\r\nhead, and a slight lifting of the hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe answer!\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, with imperious simplicity, addressing\r\nHillel, and planting his staff before him with both hands. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nanswer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eyes of the patriarch glowed mildly, and, raising his head, and\r\nlooking the inquisitor full in the face, he answered, his associates\r\ngiving him closest attention,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith thee, O king, be the peace of God, of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis manner was that of invocation; changing it, he resumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast demanded of us where the Christ should be born.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king bowed, though the evil eyes remained fixed upon the sage\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, O king, speaking for myself, and all my brethren here, not one\r\ndissenting, I say, in Bethlehem of Judea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHillel glanced at the parchment on the tripod; and, pointing with his\r\ntremulous finger, continued, \xe2\x80\x9cIn Bethlehem of Judea, for thus it is\r\nwritten by the prophet, \xe2\x80\x98And thou, Bethlehem, in the land of Judea, art\r\nnot the least among the princes of Judah; for out of thee shall come a\r\ngovernor that shall rule my people Israel.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHerod\xe2\x80\x99s face was troubled, and his eyes fell upon the parchment while\r\nhe thought. Those beholding him scarcely breathed; they spoke not, nor\r\ndid he. At length he turned about and left the chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrethren,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hillel, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are dismissed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe company then arose, and in groups departed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimeon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hillel again.\r\n\r\nA man, quite fifty years old, but in the hearty prime of life, answered\r\nand came to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake up the sacred parchment, my son; roll it tenderly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe order was obeyed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow lend me thy arm; I will to the litter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe strong man stooped; with his withered hands the old one took the\r\noffered support, and, rising, moved feebly to the door.\r\n\r\nSo departed the famous Rector, and Simeon, his son, who was to be his\r\nsuccessor in wisdom, learning, and office.\r\n\r\n\r\nYet later in the evening the wise men were lying in a lewen of the khan\r\nawake. The stones which served them as pillows raised their heads so\r\nthey could look out of the open arch into the depths of the sky; and as\r\nthey watched the twinkling of the stars, they thought of the next\r\nmanifestation. How would it come? What would it be? They were in\r\nJerusalem at last; they had asked at the gate for Him they sought; they\r\nhad borne witness of his birth; it remained only to find him; and as to\r\nthat, they placed all trust in the Spirit. Men listening for the voice\r\nof God, or waiting a sign from Heaven, cannot sleep.\r\n\r\nWhile they were in this condition, a man stepped in under the arch,\r\ndarkening the lewen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAwake!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to them; \xe2\x80\x9cI bring you a message which will not be put\r\noff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey all sat up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Egyptian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerod the king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEach one felt his spirit thrill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not the steward of the khan?\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar asked next.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would the king with us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis messenger is without; let him answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him, then, to abide our coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were right, O my brother!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Greek, when the steward was\r\ngone. \xe2\x80\x9cThe question put to the people on the road, and to the guard at\r\nthe gate, has given us quick notoriety. I am impatient; let us up\r\nquickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey arose, put on their sandals, girt their mantles about them, and\r\nwent out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI salute you, and give you peace, and pray your pardon; but my master,\r\nthe king, has sent me to invite you to the palace, where he would have\r\nspeech with you privately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus the messenger discharged his duty.\r\n\r\nA lamp hung in the entrance, and by its light they looked at each\r\nother, and knew the Spirit was upon them. Then the Egyptian stepped to\r\nthe steward, and said, so as not to be heard by the others, \xe2\x80\x9cYou know\r\nwhere our goods are stored in the court, and where our camels are\r\nresting. While we are gone, make all things ready for our departure, if\r\nit should be needful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo your way assured; trust me,\xe2\x80\x9d the steward replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king\xe2\x80\x99s will is our will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar to the messenger. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nwill follow you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe streets of the Holy City were narrow then as now, but not so rough\r\nand foul; for the great builder, not content with beauty, enforced\r\ncleanliness and convenience also. Following their guide, the brethren\r\nproceeded without a word. Through the dim starlight, made dimmer by the\r\nwalls on both sides, sometimes almost lost under bridges connecting the\r\nhouse-tops, out of a low ground they ascended a hill. At last they came\r\nto a portal reared across the way. In the light of fires blazing before\r\nit in two great braziers, they caught a glimpse of the structure, and\r\nalso of some guards leaning motionlessly upon their arms. They passed\r\ninto a building unchallenged. Then by passages and arched halls;\r\nthrough courts, and under colonnades not always lighted; up long\r\nflights of stairs, past innumerable cloisters and chambers, they were\r\nconducted into a tower of great height. Suddenly the guide halted, and,\r\npointing through an open door, said to them,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnter. The king is there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe air of the chamber was heavy with the perfume of sandal-wood, and\r\nall the appointments within were effeminately rich. Upon the floor,\r\ncovering the central space, a tufted rug was spread, and upon that a\r\nthrone was set. The visitors had but time, however, to catch a confused\r\nidea of the place\xe2\x80\x94of carved and gilt ottomans and couches; of fans and\r\njars and musical instruments; of golden candlesticks glittering in\r\ntheir own lights; of walls painted in the style of the voluptuous\r\nGrecian school, one look at which had made a Pharisee hide his head\r\nwith holy horror. Herod, sitting upon the throne to receive them, clad\r\nas when at the conference with the doctors and lawyers, claimed all\r\ntheir minds.\r\n\r\nAt the edge of the rug, to which they advanced uninvited, they\r\nprostrated themselves. The king touched a bell. An attendant came in,\r\nand placed three stools before the throne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeat yourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d said the monarch, graciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the North Gate,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, when they were at rest, \xe2\x80\x9cI had\r\nthis afternoon report of the arrival of three strangers, curiously\r\nmounted, and appearing as if from far countries. Are you the men?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian took the sign from the Greek and the Hindoo, and answered,\r\nwith the profoundest salaam, \xe2\x80\x9cWere we other than we are, the mighty\r\nHerod, whose fame is as incense to the whole world, would not have sent\r\nfor us. We may not doubt that we are the strangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHerod acknowledged the speech with a wave of the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you? Whence do you come?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, adding significantly, \xe2\x80\x9cLet\r\neach speak for himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn turn they gave him account, referring simply to the cities and lands\r\nof their birth, and the routes by which they came to Jerusalem.\r\nSomewhat disappointed, Herod plied them more directly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the question you put to the officer at the gate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe asked him, Where is he that is born King of the Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see now why the people were so curious. You excite me no less. Is\r\nthere another King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian did not blanch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one newly born.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn expression of pain knit the dark face of the monarch, as if his mind\r\nwere swept by a harrowing recollection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to me, not to me!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n\r\nPossibly the accusing images of his murdered children flitted before\r\nhim; recovering from the emotion, whatever it was, he asked, steadily,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the new king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, O king, is what we would ask.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou bring me a wonder\xe2\x80\x94a riddle surpassing any of Solomon\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\ninquisitor said next. \xe2\x80\x9cAs you see, I am in the time of life when\r\ncuriosity is as ungovernable as it was in childhood, when to trifle\r\nwith it is cruelty. Tell me further, and I will honor you as kings\r\nhonor each other. Give me all you know about the newly born, and I will\r\njoin you in the search for him; and when we have found him, I will do\r\nwhat you wish; I will bring him to Jerusalem, and train him in\r\nkingcraft; I will use my grace with Caesar for his promotion and glory.\r\nJealousy shall not come between us, so I swear. But tell me first how,\r\nso widely separated by seas and deserts, you all came to hear of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you truly, O king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herod.\r\n\r\nBalthasar raised himself erect, and said, solemnly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is an Almighty God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHerod was visibly startled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe bade us come hither, promising that we should find the Redeemer of\r\nthe World; that we should see and worship him, and bear witness that he\r\nwas come; and, as a sign, we were each given to see a star. His Spirit\r\nstayed with us. O king, his Spirit is with us now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn overpowering feeling seized the three. The Greek with difficulty\r\nrestrained an outcry. Herod\xe2\x80\x99s gaze darted quickly from one to the\r\nother; he was more suspicious and dissatisfied than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mocking me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf not, tell me more. What is to follow\r\nthe coming of the new king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe salvation of men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheir wickedness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the divine agencies\xe2\x80\x94Faith, Love, and Good Works.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Herod paused, and from his look no man could have said with what\r\nfeeling he continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou are the heralds of the Christ. Is that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar bowed low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are your servants, O king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe monarch touched a bell, and the attendant appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring the gifts,\xe2\x80\x9d the master said.\r\n\r\nThe attendant went out, but in a little while returned, and, kneeling\r\nbefore the guests, gave to each one an outer robe or mantle of scarlet\r\nand blue, and a girdle of gold. They acknowledged the honors with\r\nEastern prostrations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA word further,\xe2\x80\x9d said Herod, when the ceremony was ended. \xe2\x80\x9cTo the\r\nofficer of the gate, and but now to me, you spoke of seeing a star in\r\nthe east.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, \xe2\x80\x9chis star, the star of the newly born.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat time did it appear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen we were bidden come hither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHerod arose, signifying the audience was over. Stepping from the throne\r\ntowards them, he said, with all graciousness,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf, as I believe, O illustrious men, you are indeed the heralds of the\r\nChrist just born, know that I have this night consulted those wisest in\r\nthings Jewish, and they say with one voice he should be born in\r\nBethlehem of Judea. I say to you, go thither; go and search diligently\r\nfor the young child; and when you have found him bring me word again,\r\nthat I may come and worship him. To your going there shall be no let or\r\nhindrance.
