Peace be with you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, folding his robe about him, he left the chamber.\r\n\r\nDirectly the guide came, and led them back to the street, and thence to\r\nthe khan, at the portal of which the Greek said, impulsively, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us\r\nto Bethlehem, O brethren, as the king has advised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Hindoo. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Spirit burns within me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, with equal warmth. \xe2\x80\x9cThe camels are ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey gave gifts to the steward, mounted into their saddles, received\r\ndirections to the Joppa Gate, and departed. At their approach the great\r\nvalves were unbarred, and they passed out into the open country, taking\r\nthe road so lately travelled by Joseph and Mary. As they came up out of\r\nHinnom, on the plain of Rephaim, a light appeared, at first wide-spread\r\nand faint. Their pulses fluttered fast. The light intensified rapidly;\r\nthey closed their eyes against its burning brilliance: when they dared\r\nlook again, lo! the star, perfect as any in the heavens, but low down\r\nand moving slowly before them. And they folded their hands, and\r\nshouted, and rejoiced with exceeding great joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is with us! God is with us!\xe2\x80\x9d they repeated, in frequent cheer, all\r\nthe way, until the star, rising out of the valley beyond Mar Elias,\r\nstood still over a house up on the slope of the hill near the town.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was now the beginning of the third watch, and at Bethlehem the\r\nmorning was breaking over the mountains in the east, but so feebly that\r\nit was yet night in the valley. The watchman on the roof of the old\r\nkhan, shivering in the chilly air, was listening for the first\r\ndistinguishable sounds with which life, awakening, greets the dawn,\r\nwhen a light came moving up the hill towards the house. He thought it a\r\ntorch in some one\xe2\x80\x99s hand; next moment he thought it a meteor; the\r\nbrilliance grew, however, until it became a star. Sore afraid, he cried\r\nout, and brought everybody within the walls to the roof. The\r\nphenomenon, in eccentric motion, continued to approach; the rocks,\r\ntrees, and roadway under it shone as in a glare of lightning; directly\r\nits brightness became blinding. The more timid of the beholders fell\r\nupon their knees, and prayed, with their faces hidden; the boldest,\r\ncovering their eyes, crouched, and now and then snatched glances\r\nfearfully. Afterwhile the khan and everything thereabout lay under the\r\nintolerable radiance. Such as dared look beheld the star standing still\r\ndirectly over the house in front of the cave where the Child had been\r\nborn.\r\n\r\nIn the height of this scene, the wise men came up, and at the gate\r\ndismounted from their camels, and shouted for admission. When the\r\nsteward so far mastered his terror as to give them heed, he drew the\r\nbars and opened to them. The camels looked spectral in the unnatural\r\nlight, and, besides their outlandishness, there were in the faces and\r\nmanner of the three visitors an eagerness and exaltation which still\r\nfurther excited the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s fears and fancy; he fell back, and for a\r\ntime could not answer the question they put to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs not this Bethlehem of Judea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut others came, and by their presence gave him assurance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, this is but the khan; the town lies farther on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there not here a child newly born?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bystanders turned to each other marvelling, though some of them\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow us to him!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Greek, impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow us to him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Balthasar, breaking through his gravity; \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nwe have seen his star, even that which ye behold over the house, and\r\nare come to worship him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Hindoo clasped his hands, exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cGod indeed lives! Make\r\nhaste, make haste! The Savior is found. Blessed, blessed are we above\r\nmen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people from the roof came down and followed the strangers as they\r\nwere taken through the court and out into the enclosure; at sight of\r\nthe star yet above the cave, though less candescent than before, some\r\nturned back afraid; the greater part went on. As the strangers neared\r\nthe house, the orb arose; when they were at the door, it was high up\r\noverhead vanishing; when they entered, it went out lost to sight. And\r\nto the witnesses of what then took place came a conviction that there\r\nwas a divine relation between the star and the strangers, which\r\nextended also to at least some of the occupants of the cave. When the\r\ndoor was opened, they crowded in.\r\n\r\nThe apartment was lighted by a lantern enough to enable the strangers\r\nto find the mother, and the child awake in her lap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the child thine?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Balthasar of Mary.\r\n\r\nAnd she who had kept all the things in the least affecting the little\r\none, and pondered them in her heart, held it up in the light, saying,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is my son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they fell down and worshipped him.\r\n\r\nThey saw the child was as other children: about its head was neither\r\nnimbus nor material crown; its lips opened not in speech; if it heard\r\ntheir expressions of joy, their invocations, their prayers, it made no\r\nsign whatever, but, baby-like, looked longer at the flame in the\r\nlantern than at them.\r\n\r\nIn a little while they arose, and, returning to the camels, brought\r\ngifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh, and laid them before the child,\r\nabating nothing of their worshipful speeches; of which no part is\r\ngiven, for the thoughtful know that the pure worship of the pure heart\r\nwas then what it is now, and has always been, an inspired song.\r\n\r\nAnd this was the Savior they had come so far to find!\r\n\r\nYet they worshipped without a doubt.\r\n\r\nWhy?\r\n\r\nTheir faith rested upon the signs sent them by him whom we have since\r\ncome to know as the Father; and they were of the kind to whom his\r\npromises were so all-sufficient that they asked nothing about his ways.\r\nFew there were who had seen the signs and heard the promises\xe2\x80\x94the Mother\r\nand Joseph, the shepherds, and the Three\xe2\x80\x94yet they all believed alike;\r\nthat is to say, in this period of the plan of salvation, God was all\r\nand the Child nothing. But look forward, O reader! A time will come\r\nwhen the signs will all proceed from the Son. Happy they who then\r\nbelieve in him!\r\n\r\nLet us wait that period.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SECOND\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a fire\r\nAnd motion of the soul which will not dwell\r\nIn its own narrow being, but aspire\r\nBeyond the fitting medium of desire;\r\nAnd, but once kindled, quenchless evermore,\r\nPreys upon high adventure, nor can tire\r\nOf aught but rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nChilde Harold.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is necessary now to carry the reader forward twenty-one years, to\r\nthe beginning of the administration of Valerius Gratus, the fourth\r\nimperial governor of Judea\xe2\x80\x94a period which will be remembered as rent by\r\npolitical agitations in Jerusalem, if, indeed, it be not the precise\r\ntime of the opening of the final quarrel between the Jew and the Roman.\r\n\r\nIn the interval Judea had been subjected to changes affecting her in\r\nmany ways, but in nothing so much as her political status. Herod the\r\nGreat died within one year after the birth of the Child\xe2\x80\x94died so\r\nmiserably that the Christian world had reason to believe him overtaken\r\nby the Divine wrath. Like all great rulers who spend their lives in\r\nperfecting the power they create, he dreamed of transmitting his throne\r\nand crown\xe2\x80\x94of being the founder of a dynasty. With that intent, he left\r\na will dividing his territories between his three sons, Antipas,\r\nPhilip, and Archelaus, of whom the last was appointed to succeed to the\r\ntitle. The testament was necessarily referred to Augustus, the emperor,\r\nwho ratified all its provisions with one exception: he withheld from\r\nArchelaus the title of king until he proved his capacity and loyalty;\r\nin lieu thereof, he created him ethnarch, and as such permitted him to\r\ngovern nine years, when, for misconduct and inability to stay the\r\nturbulent elements that grew and strengthened around him, he was sent\r\ninto Gaul as an exile.\r\n\r\nCaesar was not content with deposing Archelaus; he struck the people of\r\nJerusalem in a manner that touched their pride, and keenly wounded the\r\nsensibilities of the haughty habitues of the Temple. He reduced Judea\r\nto a Roman province, and annexed it to the prefecture of Syria. So,\r\ninstead of a king ruling royally from the palace left by Herod on Mount\r\nZion, the city fell into the hands of an officer of the second grade,\r\nan appointee called procurator, who communicated with the court in Rome\r\nthrough the Legate of Syria, residing in Antioch. To make the hurt more\r\npainful, the procurator was not permitted to establish himself in\r\nJerusalem; Caesarea was his seat of government. Most humiliating,\r\nhowever, most exasperating, most studied, Samaria, of all the world the\r\nmost despised\xe2\x80\x94Samaria was joined to Judea as a part of the same\r\nprovince! What ineffable misery the bigoted Separatists or Pharisees\r\nendured at finding themselves elbowed and laughed at in the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s presence in Caesarea by the devotees of Gerizim!\r\n\r\nIn this rain of sorrows, one consolation, and one only, remained to the\r\nfallen people: the high-priest occupied the Herodian palace in the\r\nmarket-place, and kept the semblance of a court there. What his\r\nauthority really was is a matter of easy estimate. Judgment of life and\r\ndeath was retained by the procurator. Justice was administered in the\r\nname and according to the decretals of Rome. Yet more significant, the\r\nroyal house was jointly occupied by the imperial exciseman, and all his\r\ncorps of assistants, registrars, collectors, publicans, informers, and\r\nspies. Still, to the dreamers of liberty to come, there was a certain\r\nsatisfaction in the fact that the chief ruler in the palace was a Jew.\r\nHis mere presence there day after day kept them reminded of the\r\ncovenants and promises of the prophets, and the ages when Jehovah\r\ngoverned the tribes through the sons of Aaron; it was to them a certain\r\nsign that he had not abandoned them: so their hopes lived, and served\r\ntheir patience, and helped them wait grimly the son of Judah who was to\r\nrule Israel.\r\n\r\nJudea had been a Roman province eighty years and more\xe2\x80\x94ample time for\r\nthe Caesars to study the idiosyncrasies of the people\xe2\x80\x94time enough, at\r\nleast, to learn that the Jew, with all his pride, could be quietly\r\ngoverned if his religion were respected. Proceeding upon that policy,\r\nthe predecessors of Gratus had carefully abstained from interfering\r\nwith any of the sacred observances of their subjects. But he chose a\r\ndifferent course: almost his first official act was to expel Hannas\r\nfrom the high-priesthood, and give the place to Ishmael, son of Fabus.\r\n\r\nWhether the act was directed by Augustus, or proceeded from Gratus\r\nhimself, its impolicy became speedily apparent. The reader shall be\r\nspared a chapter on Jewish politics; a few words upon the subject,\r\nhowever, are essential to such as may follow the succeeding narration\r\ncritically. At this time, leaving origin out of view, there were in\r\nJudea the party of the nobles and the Separatist or popular party. Upon\r\nHerod\xe2\x80\x99s death, the two united against Archelaus; from temple to palace,\r\nfrom Jerusalem to Rome, they fought him; sometimes with intrigue,\r\nsometimes with the actual weapons of war. More than once the holy\r\ncloisters on Moriah resounded with the cries of fighting-men. Finally,\r\nthey drove him into exile. Meantime throughout this struggle the allies\r\nhad their diverse objects in view. The nobles hated Joazar, the\r\nhigh-priest; the Separatists, on the other hand, were his zealous\r\nadherents. When Herod\xe2\x80\x99s settlement went down with Archelaus, Joazar\r\nshared the fall. Hannas, the son of Seth, was selected by the nobles to\r\nfill the great office; thereupon the allies divided. The induction of\r\nthe Sethian brought them face to face in fierce hostility.\r\n\r\nIn the course of the struggle with the unfortunate ethnarch, the nobles\r\nhad found it expedient to attach themselves to Rome. Discerning that\r\nwhen the existing settlement was broken up some form of government must\r\nneeds follow, they suggested the conversion of Judea into a province.\r\nThe fact furnished the Separatists an additional cause for attack; and,\r\nwhen Samaria was made part of the province, the nobles sank into a\r\nminority, with nothing to support them but the imperial court and the\r\nprestige of their rank and wealth; yet for fifteen years\xe2\x80\x94down, indeed,\r\nto the coming of Valerius Gratus\xe2\x80\x94they managed to maintain themselves in\r\nboth palace and Temple.\r\n\r\nHannas, the idol of his party, had used his power faithfully in the\r\ninterest of his imperial patron. A Roman garrison held the Tower of\r\nAntonia; a Roman guard kept the gates of the palace; a Roman judge\r\ndispensed justice civil and criminal; a Roman system of taxation,\r\nmercilessly executed, crushed both city and country; daily, hourly, and\r\nin a thousand ways, the people were bruised and galled, and taught the\r\ndifference between a life of independence and a life of subjection; yet\r\nHannas kept them in comparative quiet. Rome had no truer friend; and he\r\nmade his loss instantly felt. Delivering his vestments to Ishmael, the\r\nnew appointee, he walked from the courts of the Temple into the\r\ncouncils of the Separatists, and became the head of a new combination,\r\nBethusian and Sethian.\r\n\r\nGratus, the procurator, left thus without a party, saw the fires which,\r\nin the fifteen years, had sunk into sodden smoke begin to glow with\r\nreturning life. A month after Ishmael took the office, the Roman found\r\nit necessary to visit him in Jerusalem. When from the walls, hooting\r\nand hissing him, the Jews beheld his guard enter the north gate of the\r\ncity and march to the Tower of Antonia, they understood the real\r\npurpose of the visit\xe2\x80\x94a full cohort of legionaries was added to the\r\nformer garrison, and the keys of their yoke could now be tightened with\r\nimpunity. If the procurator deemed it important to make an example,\r\nalas for the first offender!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nWith the foregoing explanation in mind, the reader is invited to look\r\ninto one of the gardens of the palace on Mount Zion. The time was\r\nnoonday in the middle of July, when the heat of summer was at its\r\nhighest.\r\n\r\nThe garden was bounded on every side by buildings, which in places\r\narose two stories, with verandas shading the doors and windows of the\r\nlower story, while retreating galleries, guarded by strong balustrades,\r\nadorned and protected the upper. Here and there, moreover, the\r\nstructures fell into what appeared low colonnades, permitting the\r\npassage of such winds as chanced to blow, and allowing other parts of\r\nthe house to be seen, the better to realize its magnitude and beauty.\r\nThe arrangement of the ground was equally pleasant to the eye. There\r\nwere walks, and patches of grass and shrubbery, and a few large trees,\r\nrare specimens of the palm, grouped with the carob, apricot, and\r\nwalnut. In all directions the grade sloped gently from the centre,\r\nwhere there was a reservoir, or deep marble basin, broken at intervals\r\nby little gates which, when raised, emptied the water into sluices\r\nbordering the walks\xe2\x80\x94a cunning device for the rescue of the place from\r\nthe aridity too prevalent elsewhere in the region.\r\n\r\nNot far from the fountain, there was a small pool of clear water\r\nnourishing a clump of cane and oleander, such as grow on the Jordan and\r\ndown by the Dead Sea. Between the clump and the pool, unmindful of the\r\nsun shining full upon them in the breathless air, two boys, one about\r\nnineteen, the other seventeen, sat engaged in earnest conversation.\r\n\r\nThey were both handsome, and, at first glance, would have been\r\npronounced brothers. Both had hair and eyes black; their faces were\r\ndeeply browned; and, sitting, they seemed of a size proper for the\r\ndifference in their ages.\r\n\r\nThe elder was bareheaded. A loose tunic, dropping to the knees, was his\r\nattire complete, except sandals and a light-blue mantle spread under\r\nhim on the seat. The costume left his arms and legs exposed, and they\r\nwere brown as the face; nevertheless, a certain grace of manner,\r\nrefinement of features, and culture of voice decided his rank. The\r\ntunic, of softest woollen, gray-tinted, at the neck, sleeves, and edge\r\nof the skirt bordered with red, and bound to the waist by a tasselled\r\nsilken cord, certified him the Roman he was. And if in speech he now\r\nand then gazed haughtily at his companion and addressed him as an\r\ninferior, he might almost be excused, for he was of a family noble even\r\nin Rome\xe2\x80\x94a circumstance which in that age justified any assumption. In\r\nthe terrible wars between the first Caesar and his great enemies, a\r\nMessala had been the friend of Brutus. After Philippi, without\r\nsacrifice of his honor, he and the conqueror became reconciled. Yet\r\nlater, when Octavius disputed for the empire, Messala supported him.\r\nOctavius, as the Emperor Augustus, remembered the service, and showered\r\nthe family with honors. Among other things, Judea being reduced to a\r\nprovince, he sent the son of his old client or retainer to Jerusalem,\r\ncharged with the receipt and management of the taxes levied in that\r\nregion; and in that service the son had since remained, sharing the\r\npalace with the high-priest. The youth just described was his son,\r\nwhose habit it was to carry about with him all too faithfully a\r\nremembrance of the relation between his grandfather and the great\r\nRomans of his day.\r\n\r\nThe associate of the Messala was slighter in form, and his garments\r\nwere of fine white linen and of the prevalent style in Jerusalem; a\r\ncloth covered his head, held by a yellow cord, and arranged so as to\r\nfall away from the forehead down low over the back of the neck. An\r\nobserver skilled in the distinctions of race, and studying his features\r\nmore than his costume, would have soon discovered him to be of Jewish\r\ndescent. The forehead of the Roman was high and narrow, his nose sharp\r\nand aquiline, while his lips were thin and straight, and his eyes cold\r\nand close under the brows. The front of the Israelite, on the other\r\nhand, was low and broad; his nose long, with expanded nostrils; his\r\nupper lip, slightly shading the lower one, short and curving to the\r\ndimpled corners, like a Cupid\xe2\x80\x99s bow; points which, in connection with\r\nthe round chin, full eyes, and oval cheeks reddened with a wine-like\r\nglow, gave his face the softness, strength, and beauty peculiar to his\r\nrace. The comeliness of the Roman was severe and chaste, that of the\r\nJew rich and voluptuous.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you not say the new procurator is to arrive to-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question proceeded from the younger of the friends, and was couched\r\nin Greek, at the time, singularly enough, the language everywhere\r\nprevalent in the politer circles of Judea; having passed from the\r\npalace into the camp and college; thence, nobody knew exactly when or\r\nhow, into the Temple itself, and, for that matter, into precincts of\r\nthe Temple far beyond the gates and cloisters\xe2\x80\x94precincts of a sanctity\r\nintolerable for a Gentile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d Messala answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard Ishmael, the new governor in the palace\xe2\x80\x94you call him high\r\npriest\xe2\x80\x94tell my father so last night. The news had been more credible, I\r\ngrant you, coming from an Egyptian, who is of a race that has forgotten\r\nwhat truth is, or even from an Idumaean, whose people never knew what\r\ntruth was; but, to make quite certain, I saw a centurion from the Tower\r\nthis morning, and he told me preparations were going on for the\r\nreception; that the armorers were furbishing the helmets and shields,\r\nand regilding the eagles and globes; and that apartments long unused\r\nwere being cleansed and aired as if for an addition to the garrison\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nbody-guard, probably, of the great man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA perfect idea of the manner in which the answer was given cannot be\r\nconveyed, as its fine points continually escape the power behind the\r\npen. The reader\xe2\x80\x99s fancy must come to his aid; and for that he must be\r\nreminded that reverence as a quality of the Roman mind was fast\r\nbreaking down, or, rather, it was becoming unfashionable. The old\r\nreligion had nearly ceased to be a faith; at most it was a mere habit\r\nof thought and expression, cherished principally by the priests who\r\nfound service in the Temple profitable, and the poets who, in the turn\r\nof their verses, could not dispense with the familiar deities: there\r\nare singers of this age who are similarly given. As philosophy was\r\ntaking the place of religion, satire was fast substituting reverence;\r\ninsomuch that in Latin opinion it was to every speech, even to the\r\nlittle diatribes of conversation, as salt to viands, and aroma to wine.\r\nThe young Messala, educated in Rome, but lately returned, had caught\r\nthe habit and manner; the scarce perceptible movement of the outer\r\ncorner of the lower eyelid, the decided curl of the corresponding\r\nnostril, and a languid utterance affected as the best vehicle to convey\r\nthe idea of general indifference, but more particularly because of the\r\nopportunities it afforded for certain rhetorical pauses thought to be\r\nof prime importance to enable the listener to take the happy conceit or\r\nreceive the virus of the stinging epigram. Such a stop occurred in the\r\nanswer just given, at the end of the allusion to the Egyptian and\r\nIdumaean. The color in the Jewish lad\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks deepened, and he may not\r\nhave heard the rest of the speech, for he remained silent, looking\r\nabsently into the depths of the pool.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur farewell took place in this garden. \xe2\x80\x98The peace of the Lord go with\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94your last words. \xe2\x80\x98The gods keep you!\xe2\x80\x99 I said. Do you remember?\r\nHow many years have passed since then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jew, gazing into the water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you have reason to be thankful to\xe2\x80\x94whom shall I say? The gods? No\r\nmatter. You have grown handsome; the Greeks would call you\r\nbeautiful\xe2\x80\x94happy achievement of the years! If Jupiter would stay content\r\nwith one Ganymede, what a cup-bearer you would make for the emperor!\r\nTell me, my Judah, how the coming of the procurator is of such interest\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah bent his large eyes upon the questioner; the gaze was grave and\r\nthoughtful, and caught the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s, and held it while he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\r\nfive years. I remember the parting; you went to Rome; I saw you start,\r\nand cried, for I love you. The years are gone, and you have come back\r\nto me accomplished and princely\xe2\x80\x94I do not jest; and yet\xe2\x80\x94yet\xe2\x80\x94I do wish\r\nyou were the Messala you went away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fine nostril of the satirist stirred, and he put on a longer drawl\r\nas he said, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; not a Ganymede\xe2\x80\x94an oracle, my Judah. A few lessons\r\nfrom my teacher of rhetoric hard by the Forum\xe2\x80\x94I will give you a letter\r\nto him when you become wise enough to accept a suggestion which I am\r\nreminded to make you\xe2\x80\x94a little practise of the art of mystery, and\r\nDelphi will receive you as Apollo himself. At the sound of your solemn\r\nvoice, the Pythia will come down to you with her crown. Seriously, O my\r\nfriend, in what am I not the Messala I went away? I once heard the\r\ngreatest logician in the world. His subject was Disputation. One saying\r\nI remember\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Understand your antagonist before you answer him.\xe2\x80\x99 Let me\r\nunderstand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe lad reddened under the cynical look to which he was subjected; yet\r\nhe replied, firmly, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have availed yourself, I see, of your\r\nopportunities; from your teachers you have brought away much knowledge\r\nand many graces. You talk with the ease of a master, yet your speech\r\ncarries a sting. My Messala, when he went away, had no poison in his\r\nnature; not for the world would he have hurt the feelings of a friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Roman smiled as if complimented, and raised his patrician head a\r\ntoss higher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my solemn Judah, we are not at Dodona or Pytho. Drop the oracular,\r\nand be plain. Wherein have I hurt you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other drew a long breath, and said, pulling at the cord about his\r\nwaist, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the five years, I, too, have learned somewhat. Hillel may\r\nnot be the equal of the logician you heard, and Simeon and Shammai are,\r\nno doubt, inferior to your master hard by the Forum. Their learning\r\ngoes not out into forbidden paths; those who sit at their feet arise\r\nenriched simply with knowledge of God, the law, and Israel; and the\r\neffect is love and reverence for everything that pertains to them.\r\nAttendance at the Great College, and study of what I heard there, have\r\ntaught me that Judea is not as she used to be. I know the space that\r\nlies between an independent kingdom and the petty province Judea is. I\r\nwere meaner, viler, than a Samaritan not to resent the degradation of\r\nmy country. Ishmael is not lawfully high-priest, and he cannot be while\r\nthe noble Hannas lives; yet he is a Levite; one of the devoted who for\r\nthousands of years have acceptably served the Lord God of our faith and\r\nworship. His\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala broke in upon him with a biting laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I understand you now. Ishmael, you say, is a usurper, yet to\r\nbelieve an Idumaean sooner than Ishmael is to sting like an adder. By\r\nthe drunken son of Semele, what it is to be a Jew! All men and things,\r\neven heaven and earth, change; but a Jew never. To him there is no\r\nbackward, no forward; he is what his ancestor was in the beginning. In\r\nthis sand I draw you a circle\xe2\x80\x94there! Now tell me what more a Jew\xe2\x80\x99s life\r\nis? Round and round, Abraham here, Isaac and Jacob yonder, God in the\r\nmiddle. And the circle\xe2\x80\x94by the master of all thunders! the circle is too\r\nlarge. I draw it again\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped, put his thumb upon the ground, and\r\nswept the fingers about it. \xe2\x80\x9cSee, the thumb spot is the Temple, the\r\nfinger-lines Judea. Outside the little space is there nothing of value?\r\nThe arts! Herod was a builder; therefore he is accursed. Painting,\r\nsculpture! to look upon them is sin. Poetry you make fast to your\r\naltars. Except in the synagogue, who of you attempts eloquence? In war\r\nall you conquer in the six days you lose on the seventh. Such your life\r\nand limit; who shall say no if I laugh at you? Satisfied with the\r\nworship of such a people, what is your God to our Roman Jove, who lends\r\nus his eagles that we may compass the universe with our arms? Hillel,\r\nSimeon, Shammai, Abtalion\xe2\x80\x94what are they to the masters who teach that\r\neverything is worth knowing that can be known?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew arose, his face much flushed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; keep your place, my Judah, keep your place,\xe2\x80\x9d Messala cried,\r\nextending his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mock me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen a little further. Directly\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the Roman smiled\r\nderisively\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cdirectly Jupiter and his whole family, Greek and Latin,\r\nwill come to me, as is their habit, and make an end of serious speech.\r\nI am mindful of your goodness in walking from the old house of your\r\nfathers to welcome me back and renew the love of our childhood\xe2\x80\x94if we\r\ncan. \xe2\x80\x98Go,\xe2\x80\x99 said my teacher, in his last lecture\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Go, and, to make your\r\nlives great, remember Mars reigns and Eros has found his eyes.\xe2\x80\x99 He\r\nmeant love is nothing, war everything. It is so in Rome. Marriage is\r\nthe first step to divorce. Virtue is a tradesman\xe2\x80\x99s jewel. Cleopatra,\r\ndying, bequeathed her arts, and is avenged; she has a successor in\r\nevery Roman\xe2\x80\x99s house. The world is going the same way; so, as to our\r\nfuture, down Eros, up Mars! I am to be a soldier; and you, O my Judah,\r\nI pity you; what can you be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew moved nearer the pool; Messala\xe2\x80\x99s drawl deepened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I pity you, my fine Judah. From the college to the synagogue;\r\nthen to the Temple; then\xe2\x80\x94oh, a crowning glory!\xe2\x80\x94the seat in the\r\nSanhedrim. A life without opportunities; the gods help you! But I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah looked at him in time to see the flush of pride that kindled in\r\nhis haughty face as he went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x94ah, the world is not all conquered. The sea has islands unseen.\r\nIn the north there are nations yet unvisited. The glory of completing\r\nAlexander\xe2\x80\x99s march to the Far East remains to some one. See what\r\npossibilities lie before a Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNext instant he resumed his drawl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA campaign into Africa; another after the Scythian; then\xe2\x80\x94a legion!\r\nMost careers end there; but not mine. I\xe2\x80\x94by Jupiter! what a\r\nconception!\xe2\x80\x94I will give up my legion for a prefecture. Think of life in\r\nRome with money\xe2\x80\x94money, wine, women, games\xe2\x80\x94poets at the banquet,\r\nintrigues in the court, dice all the year round. Such a rounding of\r\nlife may be\xe2\x80\x94a fat prefecture, and it is mine. O my Judah, here is\r\nSyria! Judea is rich; Antioch a capital for the gods. I will succeed\r\nCyrenius, and you\xe2\x80\x94shall share my fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sophists and rhetoricians who thronged the public resorts of Rome,\r\nalmost monopolizing the business of teaching her patrician youth, might\r\nhave approved these sayings of Messala, for they were all in the\r\npopular vein; to the young Jew, however, they were new, and unlike the\r\nsolemn style of discourse and conversation to which he was accustomed.\r\nHe belonged, moreover, to a race whose laws, modes, and habits of\r\nthought forbade satire and humor; very naturally, therefore, he\r\nlistened to his friend with varying feelings; one moment indignant,\r\nthen uncertain how to take him. The superior airs assumed had been\r\noffensive to him in the beginning; soon they became irritating, and at\r\nlast an acute smart. Anger lies close by this point in all of us; and\r\nthat the satirist evoked in another way. To the Jew of the Herodian\r\nperiod patriotism was a savage passion scarcely hidden under his common\r\nhumor, and so related to his history, religion, and God that it\r\nresponded instantly to derision of them. Wherefore it is not speaking\r\ntoo strongly to say that Messala\xe2\x80\x99s progress down to the last pause was\r\nexquisite torture to his hearer; at that point the latter said, with a\r\nforced smile,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are a few, I have heard, who can afford to make a jest of their\r\nfuture; you convince me, O my Messala, that I am not one of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Roman studied him; then replied, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not the truth in a jest as\r\nwell as a parable? The great Fulvia went fishing the other day; she\r\ncaught more than all the company besides. They said it was because the\r\nbarb of her hook was covered with gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you were not merely jesting?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Judah, I see I did not offer you enough,\xe2\x80\x9d the Roman answered,\r\nquickly, his eyes sparkling. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I am prefect, with Judea to enrich\r\nme, I\xe2\x80\x94will make you high-priest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew turned off angrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not leave me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Messala.\r\n\r\nThe other stopped irresolute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGods, Judah, how hot the sun shines!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the patrician, observing\r\nhis perplexity. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us seek a shade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah answered, coldly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had better part. I wish I had not come. I sought a friend and find\r\na\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRoman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Messala, quickly.\r\n\r\nThe hands of the Jew clenched, but controlling himself again, he\r\nstarted off. Messala arose, and, taking the mantle from the bench,\r\nflung it over his shoulder, and followed after; when he gained his\r\nside, he put his hand upon his shoulder and walked with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the way\xe2\x80\x94my hand thus\xe2\x80\x94we used to walk when we were children.\r\nLet us keep it as far as the gate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nApparently Messala was trying to be serious and kind, though he could\r\nnot rid his countenance of the habitual satirical expression. Judah\r\npermitted the familiarity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a boy; I am a man; let me talk like one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe complacency of the Roman was superb. Mentor lecturing the young\r\nTelemachus could not have been more at ease.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe in the Parcae? Ah, I forgot, you are a Sadducee: the\r\nEssenes are your sensible people; they believe in the sisters. So do I.\r\nHow everlastingly the three are in the way of our doing what we please!\r\nI sit down scheming. I run paths here and there. Perpol! Just when I am\r\nreaching to take the world in hand, I hear behind me the grinding of\r\nscissors. I look, and there she is, the accursed Atropos! But, my\r\nJudah, why did you get mad when I spoke of succeeding old Cyrenius? You\r\nthought I meant to enrich myself plundering your Judea. Suppose so; it\r\nis what some Roman will do. Why not I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah shortened his step.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere have been strangers in mastery of Judea before the Roman,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, with lifted hand. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are they, Messala? She has outlived them\r\nall. What has been will be again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala put on his drawl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Parcae have believers outside the Essenes. Welcome, Judah, welcome\r\nto the faith!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Messala, count me not with them. My faith rests on the rock which\r\nwas the foundation of the faith of my fathers back further than\r\nAbraham; on the covenants of the Lord God of Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToo much passion, my Judah. How my master would have been shocked had\r\nI been guilty of so much heat in his presence! There were other things\r\nI had to tell you, but I fear to now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen they had gone a few yards, the Roman spoke again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you can hear me now, especially as what I have to say concerns\r\nyourself. I would serve you, O handsome as Ganymede; I would serve you\r\nwith real good-will. I love you\xe2\x80\x94all I can. I told you I meant to be a\r\nsoldier. Why not you also? Why not you step out of the narrow circle\r\nwhich, as I have shown, is all of noble life your laws and customs\r\nallow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah made no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are the wise men of our day?\xe2\x80\x9d Messala continued. \xe2\x80\x9cNot they who\r\nexhaust their years quarrelling about dead things; about Baals, Joves,\r\nand Jehovahs; about philosophies and religions. Give me one great name,\r\nO Judah; I care not where you go to find it\xe2\x80\x94to Rome, Egypt, the East,\r\nor here in Jerusalem\xe2\x80\x94Pluto take me if it belong not to a man who\r\nwrought his fame out of the material furnished him by the present;\r\nholding nothing sacred that did not contribute to the end, scorning\r\nnothing that did! How was it with Herod? How with the Maccabees? How\r\nwith the first and second Caesars? Imitate them. Begin now. At hand\r\nsee\xe2\x80\x94Rome, as ready to help you as she was the Idumaean Antipater.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jewish lad trembled with rage; and, as the garden gate was close\r\nby, he quickened his steps, eager to escape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Rome, Rome!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe wise,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Messala. \xe2\x80\x9cGive up the follies of Moses and the\r\ntraditions; see the situation as it is. Dare look the Parcae in the\r\nface, and they will tell you, Rome is the world. Ask them of Judea, and\r\nthey will answer, She is what Rome wills.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were now at the gate. Judah stopped, and took the hand gently from\r\nhis shoulder, and confronted Messala, tears trembling in his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand you, because you are a Roman; you cannot understand me\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nam an Israelite. You have given me suffering to-day by convincing me\r\nthat we can never be the friends we have been\xe2\x80\x94never! Here we part. The\r\npeace of the God of my fathers abide with you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala offered him his hand; the Jew walked on through the gateway.\r\nWhen he was gone, the Roman was silent awhile; then he, too, passed\r\nthrough, saying to himself, with a toss of the head,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so. Eros is dead, Mars reigns!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nFrom the entrance to the Holy City, equivalent to what is now called\r\nSt. Stephen\xe2\x80\x99s Gate, a street extended westwardly, on a line parallel\r\nwith the northern front of the Tower of Antonia, though a square from\r\nthat famous castle. Keeping the course as far as the Tyropoeon Valley,\r\nwhich it followed a little way south, it turned and again ran west\r\nuntil a short distance beyond what tradition tells us was the Judgment\r\nGate, from whence it broke abruptly south. The traveller or the student\r\nfamiliar with the sacred locality will recognize the thoroughfare\r\ndescribed as part of the Via Dolorosa\xe2\x80\x94with Christians of more interest,\r\nthough of a melancholy kind, than any street in the world. As the\r\npurpose in view does not at present require dealing with the whole\r\nstreet, it will be sufficient to point out a house standing in the\r\nangle last mentioned as marking the change of direction south, and\r\nwhich, as an important centre of interest, needs somewhat particular\r\ndescription.\r\n\r\nThe building fronted north and west, probably four hundred feet each\r\nway, and, like most pretentious Eastern structures, was two stories in\r\nheight, and perfectly quadrangular. The street on the west side was\r\nabout twelve feet wide, that on the north not more than ten; so that\r\none walking close to the walls, and looking up at them, would have been\r\nstruck by the rude, unfinished, uninviting, but strong and imposing,\r\nappearance they presented; for they were of stone laid in large blocks,\r\nundressed\xe2\x80\x94on the outer side, in fact, just as they were taken from the\r\nquarry. A critic of this age would have pronounced the house\r\nfortelesque in style, except for the windows, with which it was\r\nunusually garnished, and the ornate finish of the doorways or gates.\r\nThe western windows were four in number, the northern only two, all set\r\non the line of the second story in such manner as to overhang the\r\nthoroughfares below. The gates were the only breaks of wall externally\r\nvisible in the first story; and, besides being so thickly riven with\r\niron bolts as to suggest resistance to battering-rams, they were\r\nprotected by cornices of marble, handsomely executed, and of such bold\r\nprojection as to assure visitors well informed of the people that the\r\nrich man who resided there was a Sadducee in politics and creed.\r\n\r\nNot long after the young Jew parted from the Roman at the palace up on\r\nthe Market-place, he stopped before the western gate of the house\r\ndescribed, and knocked. The wicket (a door hung in one of the valves of\r\nthe gate) was opened to admit him. He stepped in hastily, and failed to\r\nacknowledge the low salaam of the porter.\r\n\r\nTo get an idea of the interior arrangement of the structure, as well as\r\nto see what more befell the youth, we will follow him.\r\n\r\nThe passage into which he was admitted appeared not unlike a narrow\r\ntunnel with panelled walls and pitted ceiling. There were benches of\r\nstone on both sides, stained and polished by long use. Twelve or\r\nfifteen steps carried him into a court-yard, oblong north and south,\r\nand in every quarter, except the east, bounded by what seemed the\r\nfronts of two-story houses; of which the lower floor was divided into\r\nlewens, while the upper was terraced and defended by strong\r\nbalustrading. The servants coming and going along the terraces; the\r\nnoise of millstones grinding; the garments fluttering from ropes\r\nstretched from point to point; the chickens and pigeons in full\r\nenjoyment of the place; the goats, cows, donkeys, and horses stabled in\r\nthe lewens; a massive trough of water, apparently for the common use,\r\ndeclared this court appurtenant to the domestic management of the\r\nowner. Eastwardly there was a division wall broken by another\r\npassage-way in all respects like the first one.\r\n\r\nClearing the second passage, the young man entered a second court,\r\nspacious, square, and set with shrubbery and vines, kept fresh and\r\nbeautiful by water from a basin erected near a porch on the north side.\r\nThe lewens here were high, airy, and shaded by curtains striped\r\nalternate white and red. The arches of the lewens rested on clustered\r\ncolumns. A flight of steps on the south ascended to the terraces of the\r\nupper story, over which great awnings were stretched as a defence\r\nagainst the sun. Another stairway reached from the terraces to the\r\nroof, the edge of which, all around the square, was defined by a\r\nsculptured cornice, and a parapet of burned-clay tiling, sexangular and\r\nbright red. In this quarter, moreover, there was everywhere observable\r\na scrupulous neatness, which, allowing no dust in the angles, not even\r\na yellow leaf upon a shrub, contributed quite as much as anything else\r\nto the delightful general effect; insomuch that a visitor, breathing\r\nthe sweet air, knew, in advance of introduction, the refinement of the\r\nfamily he was about calling upon.\r\n\r\nA few steps within the second court, the lad turned to the right, and,\r\nchoosing a walk through the shrubbery, part of which was in flower,\r\npassed to the stairway, and ascended to the terrace\xe2\x80\x94a broad pavement of\r\nwhite and brown flags closely laid, and much worn. Making way under the\r\nawning to a doorway on the north side, he entered an apartment which\r\nthe dropping of the screen behind him returned to darkness.\r\nNevertheless, he proceeded, moving over a tiled floor to a divan, upon\r\nwhich he flung himself, face downwards, and lay at rest, his forehead\r\nupon his crossed arms.\r\n\r\nAbout nightfall a woman came to the door and called; he answered, and\r\nshe went in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupper is over, and it is night. Is not my son hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sick?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sleepy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour mother has asked for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the summer-house on the roof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stirred himself, and sat up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. Bring me something to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you please, Amrah. I am not sick, but indifferent. Life does not\r\nseem as pleasant as it did this morning. A new ailment, O my Amrah; and\r\nyou who know me so well, who never failed me, may think of the things\r\nnow that answer for food and medicine. Bring me what you choose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah\xe2\x80\x99s questions, and the voice in which she put them\xe2\x80\x94low,\r\nsympathetic, and solicitous\xe2\x80\x94were significant of an endeared relation\r\nbetween the two. She laid her hand upon his forehead; then, as\r\nsatisfied, went out, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a while she returned, bearing on a wooden platter a bowl of milk,\r\nsome thin cakes of white bread broken, a delicate paste of brayed\r\nwheat, a bird broiled, and honey and salt. On one end of the platter\r\nthere was a silver goblet full of wine, on the other a brazen hand-lamp\r\nlighted.\r\n\r\nThe room was then revealed: its walls smoothly plastered; the ceiling\r\nbroken by great oaken rafters, brown with rain stains and time; the\r\nfloor of small diamond-shaped white and blue tiles, very firm and\r\nenduring; a few stools with legs carved in imitation of the legs of\r\nlions; a divan raised a little above the floor, trimmed with blue\r\ncloth, and partially covered by an immense striped woollen blanket or\r\nshawl\xe2\x80\x94in brief, a Hebrew bedroom.\r\n\r\nThe same light also gave the woman to view. Drawing a stool to the\r\ndivan, she placed the platter upon it, then knelt close by ready to\r\nserve him. Her face was that of a woman of fifty, dark-skinned,\r\ndark-eyed, and at the moment softened by a look of tenderness almost\r\nmaternal. A white turban covered her head, leaving the lobes of the ear\r\nexposed, and in them the sign that settled her condition\xe2\x80\x94an orifice\r\nbored by a thick awl. She was a slave, of Egyptian origin, to whom not\r\neven the sacred fiftieth year could have brought freedom; nor would she\r\nhave accepted it, for the boy she was attending was her life. She had\r\nnursed him through babyhood, tended him as a child, and could not break\r\nthe service. To her love he could never be a man.\r\n\r\nHe spoke but once during the meal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember, O my Amrah,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Messala who used to visit me\r\nhere days at a time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe went to Rome some years ago, and is now back. I called upon him\r\nto-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA shudder of disgust seized the lad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew something had happened,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, deeply interested. \xe2\x80\x9cI never\r\nliked the Messala. Tell me all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he fell into musing, and to her repeated inquiries only said, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nis much changed, and I shall have nothing more to do with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Amrah took the platter away, he also went out, and up from the\r\nterrace to the roof.\r\n\r\nThe reader is presumed to know somewhat of the uses of the house-top in\r\nthe East. In the matter of customs, climate is a lawgiver everywhere.\r\nThe Syrian summer day drives the seeker of comfort into the darkened\r\nlewen; night, however, calls him forth early, and the shadows deepening\r\nover the mountain-sides seem veils dimly covering Circean singers; but\r\nthey are far off, while the roof is close by, and raised above the\r\nlevel of the shimmering plain enough for the visitation of cool airs,\r\nand sufficiently above the trees to allure the stars down closer, down\r\nat least into brighter shining. So the roof became a resort\xe2\x80\x94became\r\nplayground, sleeping-chamber, boudoir, rendezvous for the family, place\r\nof music, dance, conversation, reverie, and prayer.\r\n\r\nThe motive that prompts the decoration, at whatever cost, of interiors\r\nin colder climes suggested to the Oriental the embellishment of his\r\nhouse-top. The parapet ordered by Moses became a potter\xe2\x80\x99s triumph;\r\nabove that, later, arose towers, plain and fantastic; still later,\r\nkings and princes crowned their roofs with summer-houses of marble and\r\ngold. When the Babylonian hung gardens in the air, extravagance could\r\npush the idea no further.\r\n\r\nThe lad whom we are following walked slowly across the house-top to a\r\ntower built over the northwest corner of the palace. Had he been a\r\nstranger, he might have bestowed a glance upon the structure as he drew\r\nnigh it, and seen all the dimness permitted\xe2\x80\x94a darkened mass, low,\r\nlatticed, pillared, and domed. He entered, passing under a half-raised\r\ncurtain. The interior was all darkness, except that on four sides there\r\nwere arched openings like doorways, through which the sky, lighted with\r\nstars, was visible. In one of the openings, reclining against a cushion\r\nfrom a divan, he saw the figure of a woman, indistinct even in white\r\nfloating drapery. At the sound of his steps upon the floor, the fan in\r\nher hand stopped, glistening where the starlight struck the jewels with\r\nwhich it was sprinkled, and she sat up, and called his name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudah, my son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is I, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, quickening his approach.\r\n\r\nGoing to her, he knelt, and she put her arms around him, and with\r\nkisses pressed him to her bosom.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nThe mother resumed her easy position against the cushion, while the son\r\ntook place on the divan, his head in her lap. Both of them, looking out\r\nof the opening, could see a stretch of lower house-tops in the\r\nvicinity, a bank of blue-blackness over in the west which they knew to\r\nbe mountains, and the sky, its shadowy depths brilliant with stars. The\r\ncity was still. Only the winds stirred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah tells me something has happened to you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, caressing his\r\ncheek. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen my Judah was a child, I allowed small things to trouble\r\nhim, but he is now a man. He must not forget\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94her voice became very\r\nsoft\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat one day he is to be my hero.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe spoke in the language almost lost in the land, but which a few\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthey were always as rich in blood as in possessions\xe2\x80\x94cherished in its\r\npurity, that they might be more certainly distinguished from Gentile\r\npeoples\xe2\x80\x94the language in which the loved Rebekah and Rachel sang to\r\nBenjamin.\r\n\r\nThe words appeared to set him thinking anew; after a while, however, he\r\ncaught the hand with which she fanned him, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cToday, O my\r\nmother, I have been made to think of many things that never had place\r\nin my mind before. Tell me, first, what am I to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I not told you? You are to be my hero.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe could not see her face, yet he knew she was in play. He became more\r\nserious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very good, very kind, O my mother. No one will ever love me as\r\nyou do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe kissed the hand over and over again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I understand why you would have me put off the question,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncontinued. \xe2\x80\x9cThus far my life has belonged to you. How gentle, how sweet\r\nyour control has been! I wish it could last forever. But that may not\r\nbe. It is the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s will that I shall one day become owner of myself\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nday of separation, and therefore a dreadful day to you. Let us be brave\r\nand serious. I will be your hero, but you must put me in the way. You\r\nknow the law\xe2\x80\x94every son of Israel must have some occupation. I am not\r\nexempt, and ask now, shall I tend the herds? or till the soil? or drive\r\nthe saw? or be a clerk or lawyer? What shall I be? Dear, good mother,\r\nhelp me to an answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGamaliel has been lecturing today,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf so, I did not hear him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have been walking with Simeon, who, they tell me, inherits\r\nthe genius of his family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have not seen him. I have been up on the Market-place, not to\r\nthe Temple. I visited the young Messala.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA certain change in his voice attracted the mother\xe2\x80\x99s attention. A\r\npresentiment quickened the beating of her heart; the fan became\r\nmotionless again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messala!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat could he say to so trouble you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very much changed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean he has come back a Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRoman!\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, half to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cTo all the world the word\r\nmeans master. How long has he been away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe raised her head, and looked off into the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe airs of the Via Sacra are well enough in the streets of the\r\nEgyptian and in Babylon; but in Jerusalem\xe2\x80\x94our Jerusalem\xe2\x80\x94the covenant\r\nabides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, full of the thought, she settled back into her easy place. He was\r\nfirst to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat Messala said, my mother, was sharp enough in itself; but, taken\r\nwith the manner, some of the sayings were intolerable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I understand you. Rome, her poets, orators, senators,\r\ncourtiers, are mad with affectation of what they call satire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose all great peoples are proud,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, scarcely noticing\r\nthe interruption; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the pride of that people is unlike all others;\r\nin these latter days it is so grown the gods barely escape it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gods escape!\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cMore than one Roman has\r\naccepted worship as his divine right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Messala always had his share of the disagreeable quality. When\r\nhe was a child, I have seen him mock strangers whom even Herod\r\ncondescended to receive with honors; yet he always spared Judea. For\r\nthe first time, in conversation with me to-day, he trifled with our\r\ncustoms and God. As you would have had me do, I parted with him\r\nfinally. And now, O my dear mother, I would know with more certainty if\r\nthere be just ground for the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s contempt. In what am I his\r\ninferior? Is ours a lower order of people? Why should I, even in\r\nCaesar\xe2\x80\x99s presence; feel the shrinking of a slave? Tell me especially\r\nwhy, if I have the soul, and so choose, I may not hunt the honors of\r\nthe world in all its fields? Why may not I take sword and indulge the\r\npassion of war? As a poet, why may not I sing of all themes? I can be a\r\nworker in metals, a keeper of flocks, a merchant, why not an artist\r\nlike the Greek? Tell me, O my mother\xe2\x80\x94and this is the sum of my\r\ntrouble\xe2\x80\x94why may not a son of Israel do all a Roman may?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe reader will refer these questions back to the conversation in the\r\nMarket-place; the mother, listening with all her faculties awake, from\r\nsomething which would have been lost upon one less interested in\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94from the connections of the subject, the pointing of the questions,\r\npossibly his accent and tone\xe2\x80\x94was not less swift in making the same\r\nreference. She sat up, and in a voice quick and sharp as his own,\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cI see, I see! From association Messala, in boyhood, was\r\nalmost a Jew; had he remained here, he might have become a proselyte,\r\nso much do we all borrow from the influences that ripen our lives; but\r\nthe years in Rome have been too much for him. I do not wonder at the\r\nchange; yet\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94her voice fell\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9che might have dealt tenderly at least with\r\nyou. It is a hard, cruel nature which in youth can forget its first\r\nloves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer hand dropped lightly upon his forehead, and the fingers caught in\r\nhis hair and lingered there lovingly, while her eyes sought the highest\r\nstars in view. Her pride responded to his, not merely in echo, but in\r\nthe unison of perfect sympathy. She would answer him; at the same time,\r\nnot for the world would she have had the answer unsatisfactory: an\r\nadmission of inferiority might weaken his spirit for life. She faltered\r\nwith misgivings of her own powers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you propose, O my Judah, is not a subject for treatment by a\r\nwoman. Let me put its consideration off till to-morrow, and I will have\r\nthe wise Simeon\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not send me to the Rector,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, abruptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will have him come to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I seek more than information; while he might give me that better\r\nthan you, O my mother, you can do better by giving me what he\r\ncannot\xe2\x80\x94the resolution which is the soul of a man\xe2\x80\x99s soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe swept the heavens with a rapid glance, trying to compass all the\r\nmeaning of his questions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile craving justice for ourselves, it is never wise to be unjust to\r\nothers. To deny valor in the enemy we have conquered is to underrate\r\nour victory; and if the enemy be strong enough to hold us at bay, much\r\nmore to conquer us\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she hesitated\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cself-respect bids us seek some other\r\nexplanation of our misfortunes than accusing him of qualities inferior\r\nto our own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus, speaking to herself rather than to him, she began:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake heart, O my son. The Messala is nobly descended; his family has\r\nbeen illustrious through many generations. In the days of Republican\r\nRome\xe2\x80\x94how far back I cannot tell\xe2\x80\x94they were famous, some as soldiers,\r\nsome as civilians. I can recall but one consul of the name; their rank\r\nwas senatorial, and their patronage always sought because they were\r\nalways rich. Yet if to-day your friend boasted of his ancestry, you\r\nmight have shamed him by recounting yours. If he referred to the ages\r\nthrough which the line is traceable, or to deeds, rank, or wealth\xe2\x80\x94such\r\nallusions, except when great occasion demands them, are tokens of small\r\nminds\xe2\x80\x94if he mentioned them in proof of his superiority, then without\r\ndread, and standing on each particular, you might have challenged him\r\nto a comparison of records.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTaking a moment\xe2\x80\x99s thought, the mother proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the ideas of fast hold now is that time has much to do with the\r\nnobility of races and families. A Roman boasting his superiority on\r\nthat account over a son of Israel will always fail when put to the\r\nproof. The founding of Rome was his beginning; the very best of them\r\ncannot trace their descent beyond that period; few of them pretend to\r\ndo so; and of such as do, I say not one could make good his claim\r\nexcept by resort to tradition. Messala certainly could not. Let us look\r\nnow to ourselves. Could we better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA little more light would have enabled him to see the pride that\r\ndiffused itself over her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us imagine the Roman putting us to the challenge. I would answer\r\nhim, neither doubting nor boastful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer voice faltered; a tender thought changed the form of the argument.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour father, O my Judah, is at rest with his fathers; yet I remember,\r\nas though it were this evening, the day he and I, with many rejoicing\r\nfriends, went up into the Temple to present you to the Lord. We\r\nsacrificed the doves, and to the priest I gave your name, which he\r\nwrote in my presence\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Judah, son of Ithamar, of the House of Hur.\xe2\x80\x99 The\r\nname was then carried away, and written in a book of the division of\r\nrecords devoted to the saintly family.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you when the custom of registration in this mode began.\r\nWe know it prevailed before the flight from Egypt. I have heard Hillel\r\nsay Abraham caused the record to be first opened with his own name, and\r\nthe names of his sons, moved by the promises of the Lord which\r\nseparated him and them from all other races, and made them the highest\r\nand noblest, the very chosen of the earth. The covenant with Jacob was\r\nof like effect. \xe2\x80\x98In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be\r\nblessed\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94so said the angel to Abraham in the place Jehovah-jireh. \xe2\x80\x98And\r\nthe land whereon thou liest, to thee will I give it, and to thy\r\nseed\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94so the Lord himself said to Jacob asleep at Bethel on the way to\r\nHaran. Afterwards the wise men looked forward to a just division of the\r\nland of promise; and, that it might be known in the day of partition\r\nwho were entitled to portions, the Book of Generations was begun. But\r\nnot for that alone. The promise of a blessing to all the earth through\r\nthe patriarch reached far into the future. One name was mentioned in\r\nconnection with the blessing\xe2\x80\x94the benefactor might be the humblest of\r\nthe chosen family, for the Lord our God knows no distinctions of rank\r\nor riches. So, to make the performance clear to men of the generation\r\nwho were to witness it, and that they might give the glory to whom it\r\nbelonged, the record was required to be kept with absolute certainty.\r\nHas it been so kept?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fan played to and fro, until, becoming impatient, he repeated the\r\nquestion, \xe2\x80\x9cIs the record absolutely true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHillel said it was, and of all who have lived no one was so\r\nwell-informed upon the subject. Our people have at times been heedless\r\nof some parts of the law, but never of this part. The good rector\r\nhimself has followed the Books of Generations through three\r\nperiods\xe2\x80\x94from the promises to the opening of the Temple; thence to the\r\nCaptivity; thence, again, to the present. Once only were the records\r\ndisturbed, and that was at the end of the second period; but when the\r\nnation returned from the long exile, as a first duty to God, Zerubbabel\r\nrestored the Books, enabling us once more to carry the lines of Jewish\r\ndescent back unbroken fully two thousand years. And now\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe paused as if to allow the hearer to measure the time comprehended\r\nin the statement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat becomes of the Roman boast of blood\r\nenriched by ages? By that test, the sons of Israel watching the herds\r\non old Rephaim yonder are nobler than the noblest of the Marcii.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, mother\xe2\x80\x94by the Books, who am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I have said thus far, my son, had reference to your question. I\r\nwill answer you. If Messala were here, he might say, as others have\r\nsaid, that the exact trace of your lineage stopped when the Assyrian\r\ntook Jerusalem, and razed the Temple, with all its precious stores; but\r\nyou might plead the pious action of Zerubbabel, and retort that all\r\nverity in Roman genealogy ended when the barbarians from the West took\r\nRome, and camped six months upon her desolated site. Did the government\r\nkeep family histories? If so, what became of them in those dreadful\r\ndays? No, no; there is verity in our Books of Generations; and,\r\nfollowing them back to the Captivity, back to the foundation of the\r\nfirst Temple, back to the march from Egypt, we have absolute assurance\r\nthat you are lineally sprung from Hur, the associate of Joshua. In the\r\nmatter of descent sanctified by time, is not the honor perfect? Do you\r\ncare to pursue further? if so, take the Torah, and search the Book of\r\nNumbers, and of the seventy-two generations after Adam, you can find\r\nthe very progenitor of your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was silence for a time in the chamber on the roof.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, O my mother,\xe2\x80\x9d Judah next said, clasping both her hands in\r\nhis; \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you with all my heart. I was right in not having the good\r\nrector called in; he could not have satisfied me more than you have.\r\nYet to make a family truly noble, is time alone sufficient?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you forget, you forget; our claim rests not merely upon time; the\r\nLord\xe2\x80\x99s preference is our especial glory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are speaking of the race, and I, mother, of the family\xe2\x80\x94our family.\r\nIn the years since Father Abraham, what have they achieved? What have\r\nthey done? What great things to lift them above the level of their\r\nfellows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hesitated, thinking she might all this time have mistaken his\r\nobject. The information he sought might have been for more than\r\nsatisfaction of wounded vanity. Youth is but the painted shell within\r\nwhich, continually growing, lives that wondrous thing the spirit of\r\nman, biding its moment of apparition, earlier in some than in others.\r\nShe trembled under a perception that this might be the supreme moment\r\ncome to him; that as children at birth reach out their untried hands\r\ngrasping for shadows, and crying the while, so his spirit might, in\r\ntemporary blindness, be struggling to take hold of its impalpable\r\nfuture. They to whom a boy comes asking, Who am I, and what am I to be?\r\nhave need of ever so much care. Each word in answer may prove to the\r\nafter-life what each finger-touch of the artist is to the clay he is\r\nmodelling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a feeling, O my Judah,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, patting his cheek with the\r\nhand he had been caressing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have the feeling that all I have said has\r\nbeen in strife with an antagonist more real than imaginary. If Messala\r\nis the enemy, do not leave me to fight him in the dark. Tell me all he\r\nsaid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nThe young Israelite proceeded then, and rehearsed his conversation with\r\nMessala, dwelling with particularity upon the latter\xe2\x80\x99s speeches in\r\ncontempt of the Jews, their customs, and much pent round of life.\r\n\r\nAfraid to speak the while, the mother listened, discerning the matter\r\nplainly. Judah had gone to the palace on the Market-place, allured by\r\nlove of a playmate whom he thought to find exactly as he had been at\r\nthe parting years before; a man met him, and, in place of laughter and\r\nreferences to the sports of the past, the man had been full of the\r\nfuture, and talked of glory to be won, and of riches and power.\r\nUnconscious of the effect, the visitor had come away hurt in pride, yet\r\ntouched with a natural ambition; but she, the jealous mother, saw it,\r\nand, not knowing the turn the aspiration might take, became at once\r\nJewish in her fear. What if it lured him away from the patriarchal\r\nfaith? In her view, that consequence was more dreadful than any or all\r\nothers. She could discover but one way to avert it, and she set about\r\nthe task, her native power reinforced by love to such degree that her\r\nspeech took a masculine strength and at times a poet\xe2\x80\x99s fervor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere never has been a people,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, \xe2\x80\x9cwho did not think\r\nthemselves at least equal to any other; never a great nation, my son,\r\nthat did not believe itself the very superior. When the Roman looks\r\ndown upon Israel and laughs, he merely repeats the folly of the\r\nEgyptian, the Assyrian, and the Macedonian; and as the laugh is against\r\nGod, the result will be the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer voice became firmer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no law by which to determine the superiority of nations;\r\nhence the vanity of the claim, and the idleness of disputes about it. A\r\npeople risen, run their race, and die either of themselves or at the\r\nhands of another, who, succeeding to their power, take possession of\r\ntheir place, and upon their monuments write new names; such is history.\r\nIf I were called upon to symbolize God and man in the simplest form, I\r\nwould draw a straight line and a circle, and of the line I would say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is God, for he alone moves forever straightforward,\xe2\x80\x99 and of the\r\ncircle, \xe2\x80\x98This is man\xe2\x80\x94such is his progress.\xe2\x80\x99 I do not mean that there is\r\nno difference between the careers of nations; no two are alike. The\r\ndifference, however, is not, as some say, in the extent of the circle\r\nthey describe or the space of earth they cover, but in the sphere of\r\ntheir movement, the highest being nearest God.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo stop here, my son, would be to leave the subject where we began.\r\nLet us go on. There are signs by which to measure the height of the\r\ncircle each nation runs while in its course. By them let us compare the\r\nHebrew and the Roman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe simplest of all the signs is the daily life of the people. Of this\r\nI will only say, Israel has at times forgotten God, while the Roman\r\nnever knew him; consequently comparison is not possible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour friend\xe2\x80\x94or your former friend\xe2\x80\x94charged, if I understood you\r\nrightly, that we have had no poets, artists, or warriors; by which he\r\nmeant, I suppose, to deny that we have had great men, the next most\r\ncertain of the signs. A just consideration of this charge requires a\r\ndefinition at the commencement. A great man, O my boy, is one whose\r\nlife proves him to have been recognized, if not called, by God. A\r\nPersian was used to punish our recreant fathers, and he carried them\r\ninto captivity; another Persian was selected to restore their children\r\nto the Holy Land; greater than either of them, however, was the\r\nMacedonian through whom the desolation of Judea and the Temple was\r\navenged. The special distinction of the men was that they were chosen\r\nby the Lord, each for a divine purpose; and that they were Gentiles\r\ndoes not lessen their glory. Do not lose sight of this definition while\r\nI proceed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is an idea that war is the most noble occupation of men, and\r\nthat the most exalted greatness is the growth of battle-fields. Because\r\nthe world has adopted the idea, be not you deceived. That we must\r\nworship something is a law which will continue as long as there is\r\nanything we cannot understand. The prayer of the barbarian is a wail of\r\nfear addressed to Strength, the only divine quality he can clearly\r\nconceive; hence his faith in heroes. What is Jove but a Roman hero? The\r\nGreeks have their great glory because they were the first to set Mind\r\nabove Strength. In Athens the orator and philosopher were more revered\r\nthan the warrior. The charioteer and the swiftest runner are still\r\nidols of the arena; yet the immortelles are reserved for the sweetest\r\nsinger. The birthplace of one poet was contested by seven cities. But\r\nwas the Hellene the first to deny the old barbaric faith? No. My son,\r\nthat glory is ours; against brutalism our fathers erected God; in our\r\nworship, the wail of fear gave place to the Hosanna and the Psalm. So\r\nthe Hebrew and the Greek would have carried all humanity forward and\r\nupward. But, alas! the government of the world presumes war as an\r\neternal condition; wherefore, over Mind and above God, the Roman has\r\nenthroned his Caesar, the absorbent of all attainable power, the\r\nprohibition of any other greatness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sway of the Greek was a flowering time for genius. In return for\r\nthe liberty it then enjoyed, what a company of thinkers the Mind led\r\nforth? There was a glory for every excellence, and a perfection so\r\nabsolute that in everything but war even the Roman has stooped to\r\nimitation. A Greek is now the model of the orators in the Forum;\r\nlisten, and in every Roman song you will hear the rhythm of the Greek;\r\nif a Roman opens his mouth speaking wisely of moralities, or\r\nabstractions, or of the mysteries of nature, he is either a plagiarist\r\nor the disciple of some school which had a Greek for its founder. In\r\nnothing but war, I say again, has Rome a claim to originality. Her\r\ngames and spectacles are Greek inventions, dashed with blood to gratify\r\nthe ferocity of her rabble; her religion, if such it may be called, is\r\nmade up of contributions from the faiths of all other peoples; her most\r\nvenerated gods are from Olympus\xe2\x80\x94even her Mars, and, for that matter,\r\nthe Jove she much magnifies. So it happens, O my son, that of the whole\r\nworld our Israel alone can dispute the superiority of the Greek, and\r\nwith him contest the palm of original genius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the excellences of other peoples the egotism of a Roman is a\r\nblindfold, impenetrable as his breastplate. Oh, the ruthless robbers!\r\nUnder their trampling the earth trembles like a floor beaten with\r\nflails. Along with the rest we are fallen\xe2\x80\x94alas that I should say it to\r\nyou, my son! They have our highest places, and the holiest, and the end\r\nno man can tell; but this I know\xe2\x80\x94they may reduce Judea as an almond\r\nbroken with hammers, and devour Jerusalem, which is the oil and\r\nsweetness thereof; yet the glory of the men of Israel will remain a\r\nlight in the heavens overhead out of reach: for their history is the\r\nhistory of God, who wrote with their hands, spake with their tongues,\r\nand was himself in all the good they did, even the least; who dwelt\r\nwith them, a Lawgiver on Sinai, a Guide in the wilderness, in war a\r\nCaptain, in government a King; who once and again pushed back the\r\ncurtains of the pavilion which is his resting-place, intolerably\r\nbright, and, as a man speaking to men, showed them the right, and the\r\nway to happiness, and how they should live, and made them promises\r\nbinding the strength of his Almightiness with covenants sworn to\r\neverlastingly. O my son, could it be that they with whom Jehovah thus\r\ndwelt, an awful familiar, derived nothing from him?\xe2\x80\x94that in their lives\r\nand deeds the common human qualities should not in some degree have\r\nbeen mixed and colored with the divine? that their genius should not\r\nhave in it, even after the lapse of ages, some little of heaven?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a time the rustling of the fan was all the sound heard in the\r\nchamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the sense which limits art to sculpture and painting, it is true,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe next said, \xe2\x80\x9cIsrael has had no artists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe admission was made regretfully, for it must be remembered she was a\r\nSadducee, whose faith, unlike that of the Pharisees, permitted a love\r\nof the beautiful in every form, and without reference to its origin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill he who would do justice,\xe2\x80\x9d she proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cwill not forget that\r\nthe cunning of our hands was bound by the prohibition, \xe2\x80\x98Thou shalt not\r\nmake unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of anything;\xe2\x80\x99 which\r\nthe Sopherim wickedly extended beyond its purpose and time. Nor should\r\nit be forgotten that long before Daedalus appeared in Attica and with\r\nhis wooden statues so transformed sculpture as to make possible the\r\nschools of Corinth and \xc3\x86gina, and their ultimate triumphs the Poecile\r\nand Capitolium\xe2\x80\x94long before the age of Daedalus, I say, two Israelites,\r\nBezaleel and Aholiab, the master-builders of the first tabernacle, said\r\nto have been skilled \xe2\x80\x98in all manner of workmanship,\xe2\x80\x99 wrought the\r\ncherubim of the mercy-seat above the ark. Of gold beaten, not chiseled,\r\nwere they; and they were statues in form both human and divine. \xe2\x80\x98And\r\nthey shall stretch forth their wings on high, .... and their faces\r\nshall look one to another.\xe2\x80\x99 Who will say they were not beautiful? or\r\nthat they were not the first statues?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I see now why the Greek outstripped us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Judah, intensely\r\ninterested. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the ark; accursed be the Babylonians who destroyed\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, Judah, be of faith. It was not destroyed, only lost, hidden away\r\ntoo safely in some cavern of the mountains. One day\xe2\x80\x94Hillel and Shammai\r\nboth say so\xe2\x80\x94one day, in the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s good time, it will be found and\r\nbrought forth, and Israel dance before it, singing as of old. And they\r\nwho look upon the faces of the cherubim then, though they have seen the\r\nface of the ivory Minerva, will be ready to kiss the hand of the Jew\r\nfrom love of his genius, asleep through all the thousands of years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother, in her eagerness, had risen into something like the\r\nrapidity and vehemence of a speech-maker; but now, to recover herself,\r\nor to pick up the thread of her thought, she rested awhile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are so good, my mother,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a grateful way. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will\r\nnever be done saying so. Shammai could not have talked better, nor\r\nHillel. I am a true son of Israel again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlatterer!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know that I am but repeating what I\r\nheard Hillel say in an argument he had one day in my presence with a\r\nsophist from Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the hearty words are yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDirectly all her earnestness returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was I? Oh yes, I was claiming for our Hebrew fathers the first\r\nstatues. The trick of the sculptor, Judah, is not all there is of art,\r\nany more than art is all there is of greatness. I always think of great\r\nmen marching down the centuries in groups and goodly companies,\r\nseparable according to nationalities; here the Indian, there the\r\nEgyptian, yonder the Assyrian; above them the music of trumpets and the\r\nbeauty of banners; and on their right hand and left, as reverent\r\nspectators, the generations from the beginning, numberless. As they go,\r\nI think of the Greek, saying, \xe2\x80\x98Lo! The Hellene leads the way.\xe2\x80\x99 Then the\r\nRoman replies, \xe2\x80\x98Silence! what was your place is ours now; we have left\r\nyou behind as dust trodden on.\xe2\x80\x99 And all the time, from the far front\r\nback over the line of march, as well as forward into the farthest\r\nfuture, streams a light of which the wranglers know nothing, except\r\nthat it is forever leading them on\xe2\x80\x94the Light of Revelation!
