Who are\r\nthey that carry it? Ah, the old Judean blood! How it leaps at the\r\nthought! By the light we know them. Thrice blessed, O our fathers,\r\nservants of God, keepers of the covenants! Ye are the leaders of men,\r\nthe living and the dead. The front is thine; and though every Roman\r\nwere a Caesar, ye shall not lose it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah was deeply stirred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not stop, I pray you,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cYou give me to hear the sound of\r\ntimbrels. I wait for Miriam and the women who went after her dancing\r\nand singing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe caught his feeling, and, with ready wit, wove it into her speech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, my son. If you can hear the timbrel of the prophetess, you\r\ncan do what I was about to ask; you can use your fancy, and stand with\r\nme, as if by the wayside, while the chosen of Israel pass us at the\r\nhead of the procession. Now they come\xe2\x80\x94the patriarchs first; next the\r\nfathers of the tribes. I almost hear the bells of their camels and the\r\nlowing of their herds. Who is he that walks alone between the\r\ncompanies? An old man, yet his eye is not dim, nor his natural force\r\nabated. He knew the Lord face to face! Warrior, poet, orator, lawgiver,\r\nprophet, his greatness is as the sun at morning, its flood of splendor\r\nquenching all other lights, even that of the first and noblest of the\r\nCaesars. After him the judges. And then the kings\xe2\x80\x94the son of Jesse, a\r\nhero in war, and a singer of songs eternal as that of the sea; and his\r\nson, who, passing all other kings in riches and wisdom, and while\r\nmaking the Desert habitable, and in its waste places planting cities,\r\nforgot not Jerusalem which the Lord had chosen for his seat on earth.\r\nBend lower, my son! These that come next are the first of their kind,\r\nand the last. Their faces are raised, as if they heard a voice in the\r\nsky and were listening. Their lives were full of sorrows. Their\r\ngarments smell of tombs and caverns. Hearken to a woman among\r\nthem\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Sing ye to the Lord, for he hath triumphed gloriously!\xe2\x80\x99 Nay, put\r\nyour forehead in the dust before them! They were tongues of God, his\r\nservants, who looked through heaven, and, seeing all the future, wrote\r\nwhat they saw, and left the writing to be proven by time. Kings turned\r\npale as they approached them, and nations trembled at the sound of\r\ntheir voices. The elements waited upon them. In their hands they\r\ncarried every bounty and every plague. See the Tishbite and his servant\r\nElisha! See the sad son of Hilkiah, and him, the seer of visions, by\r\nthe river of Chebar! And of the three children of Judah who refused the\r\nimage of the Babylonian, lo! that one who, in the feast to the thousand\r\nlords, so confounded the astrologers. And yonder\xe2\x80\x94O my son, kiss the\r\ndust again!\xe2\x80\x94yonder the gentle son of Amoz, from whom the world has its\r\npromise of the Messiah to come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn this passage the fan had been kept in rapid play; it stopped now,\r\nand her voice sank low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are tired,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI was listening to a new song of Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother was still intent upon her purpose, and passed the pleasant\r\nspeech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn such light as I could, my Judah, I have set our great men before\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94patriarchs, legislators, warriors, singers, prophets. Turn we to\r\nthe best of Rome. Against Moses place Caesar, and Tarquin against\r\nDavid; Sylla against either of the Maccabees; the best of the consuls\r\nagainst the judges; Augustus against Solomon, and you are done:\r\ncomparison ends there. But think then of the prophets\xe2\x80\x94greatest of the\r\ngreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe laughed scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me. I was thinking of the soothsayer who warned Caius Julius\r\nagainst the Ides of March, and fancied him looking for the omens of\r\nevil which his master despised in the entrails of a chicken. From that\r\npicture turn to Elijah sitting on the hill-top on the way to Samaria,\r\namid the smoking bodies of the captains and their fifties, warning the\r\nson of Ahab of the wrath of our God. Finally, O my Judah\xe2\x80\x94if such speech\r\nbe reverent\xe2\x80\x94how shall we judge Jehovah and Jupiter unless it be by what\r\ntheir servants have done in their names? And as for what you shall do\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe spoke the latter words slowly, and with a tremulous utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for what you shall do, my boy\xe2\x80\x94serve the Lord, the Lord God of\r\nIsrael, not Rome. For a child of Abraham there is no glory except in\r\nthe Lord\xe2\x80\x99s ways, and in them there is much glory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may be a soldier then?\xe2\x80\x9d Judah asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? Did not Moses call God a man of war?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was then a long silence in the summer chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have my permission,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, finally; \xe2\x80\x9cif only you serve the\r\nLord instead of Caesar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was content with the condition, and by-and-by fell asleep. She arose\r\nthen, and put the cushion under his head, and, throwing a shawl over\r\nhim and kissing him tenderly, went away.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe good man, like the bad, must die; but, remembering the lesson of\r\nour faith, we say of him and the event, \xe2\x80\x9cNo matter, he will open his\r\neyes in heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d Nearest this in life is the waking from healthful\r\nsleep to a quick consciousness of happy sights and sounds.\r\n\r\nWhen Judah awoke, the sun was up over the mountains; the pigeons were\r\nabroad in flocks, filling the air with the gleams of their white wings;\r\nand off southeast he beheld the Temple, an apparition of gold in the\r\nblue of the sky. These, however, were familiar objects, and they\r\nreceived but a glance; upon the edge of the divan, close by him, a girl\r\nscarcely fifteen sat singing to the accompaniment of a nebel, which she\r\nrested upon her knee, and touched gracefully. To her he turned\r\nlistening; and this was what she sang:\r\n\r\nTHE SONG.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWake not, but hear me, love!\r\n     Adrift, adrift on slumber\xe2\x80\x99s sea,\r\n     Thy spirit call to list to me.\r\nWake not, but hear me, love!\r\n     A gift from Sleep, the restful king,\r\n     All happy, happy dreams I bring.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWake not, but hear me, love!\r\n     Of all the world of dreams \xe2\x80\x99tis thine\r\n     This once to choose the most divine.\r\nSo choose, and sleep, my love!\r\n     But ne\xe2\x80\x99er again in choice be free,\r\n     Unless, unless\xe2\x80\x94thou dream\xe2\x80\x99st of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nShe put the instrument down, and, resting her hands in her lap, waited\r\nfor him to speak. And as it has become necessary to tell somewhat of\r\nher, we will avail ourselves of the chance, and add such particulars of\r\nthe family into whose privacy we are brought as the reader may wish to\r\nknow.\r\n\r\nThe favors of Herod had left surviving him many persons of vast estate.\r\nWhere this fortune was joined to undoubted lineal descent from some\r\nfamous son of one of the tribes, especially Judah, the happy individual\r\nwas accounted a Prince of Jerusalem\xe2\x80\x94a distinction which sufficed to\r\nbring him the homage of his less favored countrymen, and the respect,\r\nif nothing more, of the Gentiles with whom business and social\r\ncircumstance brought him into dealing. Of this class none had won in\r\nprivate or public life a higher regard than the father of the lad whom\r\nwe have been following. With a remembrance of his nationality which\r\nnever failed him, he had yet been true to the king, and served him\r\nfaithfully at home and abroad. Some offices had taken him to Rome,\r\nwhere his conduct attracted the notice of Augustus, who strove without\r\nreserve to engage his friendship. In his house, accordingly, were many\r\npresents, such as had gratified the vanity of kings\xe2\x80\x94purple togas, ivory\r\nchairs, golden pateroe\xe2\x80\x94chiefly valuable on account of the imperial hand\r\nwhich had honorably conferred them. Such a man could not fail to be\r\nrich; yet his wealth was not altogether the largess of royal patrons.\r\nHe had welcomed the law that bound him to some pursuit; and, instead of\r\none, he entered into many. Of the herdsmen watching flocks on the\r\nplains and hill-sides, far as old Lebanon, numbers reported to him as\r\ntheir employer; in the cities by the sea, and in those inland, he\r\nfounded houses of traffic; his ships brought him silver from Spain,\r\nwhose mines were then the richest known; while his caravans came twice\r\na year from the East, laden with silks and spices. In faith he was a\r\nHebrew, observant of the law and every essential rite; his place in the\r\nsynagogue and Temple knew him well; he was thoroughly learned in the\r\nScriptures; he delighted in the society of the college-masters, and\r\ncarried his reverence for Hillel almost to the point of worship. Yet he\r\nwas in no sense a Separatist; his hospitality took in strangers from\r\nevery land; the carping Pharisees even accused him of having more than\r\nonce entertained Samaritans at his table. Had he been a Gentile, and\r\nlived, the world might have heard of him as the rival of Herodes\r\nAtticus: as it was, he perished at sea some ten years before this\r\nsecond period of our story, in the prime of life, and lamented\r\neverywhere in Judea. We are already acquainted with two members of his\r\nfamily\xe2\x80\x94his widow and son; the only other was a daughter\xe2\x80\x94she whom we\r\nhave seen singing to her brother.\r\n\r\nTirzah was her name, and as the two looked at each other, their\r\nresemblance was plain. Her features had the regularity of his, and were\r\nof the same Jewish type; they had also the charm of childish innocency\r\nof expression. Home-life and its trustful love permitted the negligent\r\nattire in which she appeared. A chemise buttoned upon the right\r\nshoulder, and passing loosely over the breast and back and under the\r\nleft arm, but half concealed her person above the waist, while it left\r\nthe arms entirely nude. A girdle caught the folds of the garment,\r\nmarking the commencement of the skirt. The coiffure was very simple and\r\nbecoming\xe2\x80\x94a silken cap, Tyrian-dyed; and over that a striped scarf of\r\nthe same material, beautifully embroidered, and wound about in thin\r\nfolds so as to show the shape of the head without enlarging it; the\r\nwhole finished by a tassel dropping from the crown point of the cap.\r\nShe had rings, ear and finger; anklets and bracelets, all of gold; and\r\naround her neck there was a collar of gold, curiously garnished with a\r\nnetwork of delicate chains, to which were pendants of pearl. The edges\r\nof her eyelids were painted, and the tips of her fingers stained. Her\r\nhair fell in two long plaits down her back. A curled lock rested upon\r\neach cheek in front of the ear. Altogether it would have been\r\nimpossible to deny her grace, refinement, and beauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery pretty, my Tirzah, very pretty!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with animation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe song?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94and the singer, too. It has the conceit of a Greek. Where did you\r\nget it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember the Greek who sang in the theatre last month? They said\r\nhe used to be a singer at the court for Herod and his sister Salome. He\r\ncame out just after an exhibition of wrestlers, when the house was full\r\nof noise. At his first note everything became so quiet that I heard\r\nevery word. I got the song from him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he sang in Greek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I in Hebrew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes. I am proud of my little sister. Have you another as good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery many. But let them go now. Amrah sent me to tell you she will\r\nbring you your breakfast, and that you need not come down. She should\r\nbe here by this time. She thinks you sick\xe2\x80\x94that a dreadful accident\r\nhappened you yesterday. What was it? Tell me, and I will help Amrah\r\ndoctor you. She knows the cures of the Egyptians, who were always a\r\nstupid set; but I have a great many recipes of the Arabs who\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre even more stupid than the Egyptians,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, shaking his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so? Very well, then,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, almost without pause,\r\nand putting her hands to her left ear. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will have nothing to do with\r\nany of them. I have here what is much surer and better\xe2\x80\x94the amulet which\r\nwas given to some of our people\xe2\x80\x94I cannot tell when, it was so far\r\nback\xe2\x80\x94by a Persian magician. See, the inscription is almost worn out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe offered him the earring, which he took, looked at, and handed back,\r\nlaughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were dying, Tirzah, I could not use the charm. It is a relic of\r\nidolatry, forbidden every believing son and daughter of Abraham. Take\r\nit, but do not wear it any more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForbidden! Not so,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cOur father\xe2\x80\x99s mother wore it I do not\r\nknow how many Sabbaths in her life. It has cured I do not know how many\r\npeople\xe2\x80\x94more than three anyhow. It is approved\xe2\x80\x94look, here is the mark of\r\nthe rabbis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no faith in amulets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe raised her eyes to his in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would Amrah say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah\xe2\x80\x99s father and mother tended sakiyeh for a garden on the Nile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Gamaliel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe says they are godless inventions of unbelievers and Shechemites.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah looked at the ring doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall I do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWear it, my little sister. It becomes you\xe2\x80\x94it helps make you beautiful,\r\nthough I think you that without help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSatisfied, she returned the amulet to her ear just as Amrah entered the\r\nsummer chamber, bearing a platter, with wash-bowl, water, and napkins.\r\n\r\nNot being a Pharisee, the ablution was short and simple with Judah. The\r\nservant then went out, leaving Tirzah to dress his hair. When a lock\r\nwas disposed to her satisfaction, she would unloose the small metallic\r\nmirror which, as was the fashion among her fair countrywomen, she wore\r\nat her girdle, and gave it to him, that he might see the triumph, and\r\nhow handsome it made him. Meanwhile they kept up their conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think, Tirzah?\xe2\x80\x94I am going away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe dropped her hands with amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing away! When? Where? For what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree questions, all in a breath! What a body you are!\xe2\x80\x9d Next instant\r\nhe became serious. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know the law requires me to follow some\r\noccupation. Our good father set me an example. Even you would despise\r\nme if I spent in idleness the results of his industry and knowledge. I\r\nam going to Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I will go with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must stay with mother. If both of us leave her she will die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe brightness faded from her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, yes! But\xe2\x80\x94must you go? Here in Jerusalem you can learn all\r\nthat is needed to be a merchant\xe2\x80\x94if that is what you are thinking of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not what I am thinking of. The law does not require the\r\nson to be what the father was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else can you be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA soldier,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, with a certain pride of voice.\r\n\r\nTears came into her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be killed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf God\xe2\x80\x99s will, be it so. But, Tirzah, the soldiers are not all\r\nkilled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe threw her arms around his neck, as if to hold him back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are so happy! Stay at home, my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHome cannot always be what it is. You yourself will be going away\r\nbefore long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe smiled at her earnestness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA prince of Judah, or some other of one of the tribes, will come soon\r\nand claim my Tirzah, and ride away with her, to be the light of another\r\nhouse. What will then become of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe answered with sobs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWar is a trade,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, more soberly. \xe2\x80\x9cTo learn it thoroughly,\r\none must go to school, and there is no school like a Roman camp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would not fight for Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, holding her breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x94even you hate her. The whole world hates her. In that, O\r\nTirzah, find the reason of the answer I give you\xe2\x80\x94 Yes, I will fight for\r\nher, if, in return, she will teach me how one day to fight against\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will you go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah\xe2\x80\x99s steps were then heard returning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHist!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDo not let her know of what I am thinking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe faithful slave came in with breakfast, and placed the waiter\r\nholding it upon a stool before them; then, with white napkins upon her\r\narm, she remained to serve them. They dipped their fingers in a bowl of\r\nwater, and were rinsing them, when a noise arrested their attention.\r\nThey listened, and distinguished martial music in the street on the\r\nnorth side of the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoldiers from the Praetorium! I must see them,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, springing\r\nfrom the divan, and running out.\r\n\r\nIn a moment more he was leaning over the parapet of tiles which guarded\r\nthe roof at the extreme northeast corner, so absorbed that he did not\r\nnotice Tirzah by his side, resting one hand upon his shoulder.\r\n\r\nTheir position\xe2\x80\x94the roof being the highest one in the locality\xe2\x80\x94commanded\r\nthe house-tops eastward as far as the huge irregular Tower of Antonia,\r\nwhich has been already mentioned as a citadel for the garrison and\r\nmilitary headquarters for the governor. The street, not more than ten\r\nfeet wide, was spanned here and there by bridges, open and covered,\r\nwhich, like the roofs along the way, were beginning to be occupied by\r\nmen, women, and children, called out by the music. The word is used,\r\nthough it is hardly fitting; what the people heard when they came forth\r\nwas rather an uproar of trumpets and the shriller litui so delightful\r\nto the soldiers.\r\n\r\nThe array after a while came into view of the two upon the house of the\r\nHurs. First, a vanguard of the light-armed\xe2\x80\x94mostly slingers and\r\nbowmen\xe2\x80\x94marching with wide intervals between their ranks and files; next\r\na body of heavy-armed infantry, bearing large shields, and hastoe\r\nlongoe, or spears identical with those used in the duels before Ilium;\r\nthen the musicians; and then an officer riding alone, but followed\r\nclosely by a guard of cavalry; after them again, a column of infantry\r\nalso heavy-armed, which, moving in close order, crowded the streets\r\nfrom wall to wall, and appeared to be without end.\r\n\r\nThe brawny limbs of the men; the cadenced motion from right to left of\r\nthe shields; the sparkle of scales, buckles, and breastplates and\r\nhelms, all perfectly burnished; the plumes nodding above the tall\r\ncrests; the sway of ensigns and iron-shod spears; the bold, confident\r\nstep, exactly timed and measured; the demeanor, so grave, yet so\r\nwatchful; the machine-like unity of the whole moving mass\xe2\x80\x94made an\r\nimpression upon Judah, but as something felt rather than seen. Two\r\nobjects fixed his attention\xe2\x80\x94the eagle of the legion first\xe2\x80\x94a gilded\r\neffigy perched on a tall shaft, with wings outspread until they met\r\nabove its head. He knew that, when brought from its chamber in the\r\nTower, it had been received with divine honors.\r\n\r\nThe officer riding alone in the midst of the column was the other\r\nattraction. His head was bare; otherwise he was in full armor. At his\r\nleft hip he wore a short sword; in his hand, however, he carried a\r\ntruncheon, which looked like a roll of white paper. He sat upon a\r\npurple cloth instead of a saddle, and that, and a bridle with a\r\nforestall of gold and reins of yellow silk broadly fringed at the lower\r\nedge, completed the housings of the horse.\r\n\r\nWhile the man was yet in the distance, Judah observed that his presence\r\nwas sufficient to throw the people looking at him into angry\r\nexcitement. They would lean over the parapets or stand boldly out, and\r\nshake their fists at him; they followed him with loud cries, and spit\r\nat him as he passed under the bridges; the women even flung their\r\nsandals, sometimes with such good effect as to hit him. When he was\r\nnearer, the yells became distinguishable\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRobber, tyrant, dog of a\r\nRoman! Away with Ishmael! Give us back our Hannas!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen quite near, Judah could see that, as was but natural, the man did\r\nnot share the indifference so superbly shown by the soldiers; his face\r\nwas dark and sullen, and the glances he occasionally cast at his\r\npersecutors were full of menace; the very timid shrank from them.\r\n\r\nNow the lad had heard of the custom, borrowed from a habit of the first\r\nCaesar, by which chief commanders, to indicate their rank, appeared in\r\npublic with only a laurel vine upon their heads. By that sign he knew\r\nthis officer\xe2\x80\x94VALERIUS GRATUS, THE NEW PROCURATOR OF JUDEA!\r\n\r\nTo say truth now, the Roman under the unprovoked storm had the young\r\nJew\xe2\x80\x99s sympathy; so that when he reached the corner of the house, the\r\nlatter leaned yet farther over the parapet to see him go by, and in the\r\nact rested a hand upon a tile which had been a long time cracked and\r\nallowed to go unnoticed. The pressure was strong enough to displace the\r\nouter piece, which started to fall. A thrill of horror shot through the\r\nyouth. He reached out to catch the missile. In appearance the motion\r\nwas exactly that of one pitching something from him. The effort\r\nfailed\xe2\x80\x94nay, it served to push the descending fragment farther out over\r\nthe wall. He shouted with all his might. The soldiers of the guard\r\nlooked up; so did the great man, and that moment the missile struck\r\nhim, and he fell from his seat as dead.\r\n\r\nThe cohort halted; the guards leaped from their horses, and hastened to\r\ncover the chief with their shields. On the other hand, the people who\r\nwitnessed the affair, never doubting that the blow had been purposely\r\ndealt, cheered the lad as he yet stooped in full view over the parapet,\r\ntransfixed by what he beheld, and by anticipation of the consequences\r\nflashed all too plainly upon him.\r\n\r\nA mischievous spirit flew with incredible speed from roof to roof along\r\nthe line of march, seizing the people, and urging them all alike. They\r\nlaid hands upon the parapets and tore up the tiling and the sunburnt\r\nmud of which the house-tops were for the most part made, and with blind\r\nfury began to fling them upon the legionaries halted below. A battle\r\nthen ensued. Discipline, of course, prevailed. The struggle, the\r\nslaughter, the skill of one side, the desperation of the other, are\r\nalike unnecessary to our story. Let us look rather to the wretched\r\nauthor of it all.\r\n\r\nHe arose from the parapet, his face very pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Tirzah, Tirzah! What will become of us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe had not seen the occurrence below, but was listening to the\r\nshouting and watching the mad activity of the people in view on the\r\nhouses. Something terrible was going on, she knew; but what it was, or\r\nthe cause, or that she or any of those dear to her were in danger, she\r\ndid not know.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened? What does it all mean?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, in sudden alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have killed the Roman governor. The tile fell upon him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn unseen hand appeared to sprinkle her face with the dust of ashes\xe2\x80\x94it\r\ngrew white so instantly. She put her arm around him, and looked\r\nwistfully, but without a word, into his eyes. His fears had passed to\r\nher, and the sight of them gave him strength.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not do it purposely, Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94it was an accident,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, more\r\ncalmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will they do?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\nHe looked off over the tumult momentarily deepening in the street and\r\non the roofs, and thought of the sullen countenance of Gratus. If he\r\nwere not dead, where would his vengeance stop? And if he were dead, to\r\nwhat height of fury would not the violence of the people lash the\r\nlegionaries? To evade an answer, he peered over the parapet again, just\r\nas the guard were assisting the Roman to remount his horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives, he lives, Tirzah! Blessed be the Lord God of our fathers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that outcry, and a brightened countenance, he drew back and\r\nreplied to her question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe not afraid, Tirzah. I will explain how it happened, and they will\r\nremember our father and his services, and not hurt us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was leading her to the summer-house, when the roof jarred under\r\ntheir feet, and a crash of strong timbers being burst away, followed by\r\na cry of surprise and agony, arose apparently from the court-yard\r\nbelow. He stopped and listened. The cry was repeated; then came a rush\r\nof many feet, and voices lifted in rage blent with voices in prayer;\r\nand then the screams of women in mortal terror. The soldiers had beaten\r\nin the north gate, and were in possession of the house. The terrible\r\nsense of being hunted smote him. His first impulse was to fly; but\r\nwhere? Nothing but wings would serve him. Tirzah, her eyes wild with\r\nfear, caught his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Judah, what does it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servants were being butchered\xe2\x80\x94and his mother! Was not one of the\r\nvoices he heard hers? With all the will left him, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cStay here,\r\nand wait for me, Tirzah. I will go down and see what is the matter, and\r\ncome back to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis voice was not steady as he wished. She clung closer to him.\r\n\r\nClearer, shriller, no longer a fancy, his mother\xe2\x80\x99s cry arose. He\r\nhesitated no longer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then, let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe terrace or gallery at the foot of the steps was crowded with\r\nsoldiers. Other soldiers with drawn swords ran in and out of the\r\nchambers. At one place a number of women on their knees clung to each\r\nother or prayed for mercy. Apart from them, one with torn garments, and\r\nlong hair streaming over her face, struggled to tear loose from a man\r\nall whose strength was tasked to keep his hold. Her cries were\r\nshrillest of all; cutting through the clamor, they had risen\r\ndistinguishably to the roof. To her Judah sprang\xe2\x80\x94his steps were long\r\nand swift, almost a winged flight\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMother, mother!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted. She\r\nstretched her hands towards him; but when almost touching them he was\r\nseized and forced aside. Then he heard some one say, speaking loudly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah looked, and saw\xe2\x80\x94Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, the assassin\xe2\x80\x94that?\xe2\x80\x9d said a tall man, in legionary armor of\r\nbeautiful finish. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, he is but a boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGods!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Messala, not forgetting his drawl. \xe2\x80\x9cA new philosophy!\r\nWhat would Seneca say to the proposition that a man must be old before\r\nhe can hate enough to kill? You have him; and that is his mother;\r\nyonder his sister. You have the whole family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor love of them, Judah forgot his quarrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp them, O my Messala! Remember our childhood and help them.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x94Judah\xe2\x80\x94pray you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala affected not to hear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot be of further use to you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the officer. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is\r\nricher entertainment in the street. Down Eros, up Mars!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the last words he disappeared. Judah understood him, and, in the\r\nbitterness of his soul, prayed to Heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the hour of thy vengeance, O Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbe mine the hand to\r\nput it upon him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy great exertion, he drew nearer the officer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO sir, the woman you hear is my mother. Spare her, spare my sister\r\nyonder. God is just, he will give you mercy for mercy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man appeared to be moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Tower with the women!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cbut do them no harm. I will\r\ndemand them of you.\xe2\x80\x9d Then to those holding Judah, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cGet cords,\r\nand bind his hands, and take him to the street. His punishment is\r\nreserved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother was carried away. The little Tirzah, in her home attire,\r\nstupefied with fear, went passively with her keepers. Judah gave each\r\nof them a last look, and covered his face with his hands, as if to\r\npossess himself of the scene fadelessly. He may have shed tears, though\r\nno one saw them.\r\n\r\nThere took place in him then what may be justly called the wonder of\r\nlife. The thoughtful reader of these pages has ere this discerned\r\nenough to know that the young Jew in disposition was gentle even to\r\nwomanliness\xe2\x80\x94a result that seldom fails the habit of loving and being\r\nloved. The circumstances through which he had come had made no call\r\nupon the harsher elements of his nature, if such he had. At times he\r\nhad felt the stir and impulses of ambition, but they had been like the\r\nformless dreams of a child walking by the sea and gazing at the coming\r\nand going of stately ships. But now, if we can imagine an idol,\r\nsensible of the worship it was accustomed to, dashed suddenly from its\r\naltar, and lying amidst the wreck of its little world of love, an idea\r\nmay be had of what had befallen the young Ben-Hur, and of its effect\r\nupon his being. Yet there was no sign, nothing to indicate that he had\r\nundergone a change, except that when he raised his head, and held his\r\narms out to be bound, the bend of the Cupid\xe2\x80\x99s bow had vanished from his\r\nlips. In that instant he had put off childhood and become a man.\r\n\r\nA trumpet sounded in the court-yard. With the cessation of the call,\r\nthe gallery was cleared of the soldiery; many of whom, as they dared\r\nnot appear in the ranks with visible plunder in their hands, flung what\r\nthey had upon the floor, until it was strewn with articles of richest\r\nvirtu. When Judah descended, the formation was complete, and the\r\nofficer waiting to see his last order executed.\r\n\r\nThe mother, daughter, and entire household were led out of the north\r\ngate, the ruins of which choked the passageway. The cries of the\r\ndomestics, some of whom had been born in the house, were most pitiable.\r\nWhen, finally, the horses and all the dumb tenantry of the place were\r\ndriven past him, Judah began to comprehend the scope of the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s vengeance. The very structure was devoted. Far as the\r\norder was possible of execution, nothing living was to be left within\r\nits walls. If in Judea there were others desperate enough to think of\r\nassassinating a Roman governor, the story of what befell the princely\r\nfamily of Hur would be a warning to them, while the ruin of the\r\nhabitation would keep the story alive.\r\n\r\nThe officer waited outside while a detail of men temporarily restored\r\nthe gate.\r\n\r\nIn the street the fighting had almost ceased. Upon the houses here and\r\nthere clouds of dust told where the struggle was yet prolonged. The\r\ncohort was, for the most part, standing at rest, its splendor, like its\r\nranks, in nowise diminished. Borne past the point of care for himself,\r\nJudah had heart for nothing in view but the prisoners, among whom he\r\nlooked in vain for his mother and Tirzah.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, from the earth where she had been lying, a woman arose and\r\nstarted swiftly back to the gate. Some of the guards reached out to\r\nseize her, and a great shout followed their failure. She ran to Judah,\r\nand, dropping down, clasped his knees, the coarse black hair powdered\r\nwith dust veiling her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Amrah, good Amrah,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to her, \xe2\x80\x9cGod help you; I cannot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe could not speak.\r\n\r\nHe bent down, and whispered, \xe2\x80\x9cLive, Amrah, for Tirzah and my mother.\r\nThey will come back, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA soldier drew her away; whereupon she sprang up and rushed through the\r\ngateway and passage into the vacant court-yard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her go,\xe2\x80\x9d the officer shouted. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will seal the house, and she\r\nwill starve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men resumed their work, and, when it was finished there, passed\r\nround to the west side. That gate was also secured, after which the\r\npalace of the Hurs was lost to use.\r\n\r\nThe cohort at length marched back to the Tower, where the procurator\r\nstayed to recover from his hurts and dispose of his prisoners. On the\r\ntenth day following, he visited the Market-place.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nNext day a detachment of legionaries went to the desolated palace, and,\r\nclosing the gates permanently, plastered the corners with wax, and at\r\nthe sides nailed a notice in Latin:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTHIS IS THE PROPERTY OF THE EMPEROR.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the haughty Roman idea, the sententious announcement was thought\r\nsufficient for the purpose\xe2\x80\x94and it was.\r\n\r\nThe day after that again, about noon, a decurion with his command of\r\nten horsemen approached Nazareth from the south\xe2\x80\x94that is, from the\r\ndirection of Jerusalem. The place was then a straggling village,\r\nperched on a hill-side, and so insignificant that its one street was\r\nlittle more than a path well beaten by the coming and going of flocks\r\nand herds. The great plain of Esdraelon crept close to it on the south,\r\nand from the height on the west a view could be had of the shores of\r\nthe Mediterranean, the region beyond the Jordan, and Hermon. The valley\r\nbelow, and the country on every side, were given to gardens, vineyards,\r\norchards, and pasturage. Groves of palm-trees Orientalized the\r\nlandscape. The houses, in irregular assemblage, were of the humbler\r\nclass\xe2\x80\x94square, one-story, flat-roofed, and covered with bright-green\r\nvines. The drought that had burned the hills of Judea to a crisp, brown\r\nand lifeless, stopped at the boundary-line of Galilee.\r\n\r\nA trumpet, sounded when the cavalcade drew near the village, had a\r\nmagical effect upon the inhabitants. The gates and front doors cast\r\nforth groups eager to be the first to catch the meaning of a visitation\r\nso unusual.\r\n\r\nNazareth, it must be remembered, was not only aside from any great\r\nhighway, but within the sway of Judas of Gamala; wherefore it should\r\nnot be hard to imagine the feelings with which the legionaries were\r\nreceived. But when they were up and traversing the street, the duty\r\nthat occupied them became apparent, and then fear and hatred were lost\r\nin curiosity, under the impulse of which the people, knowing there must\r\nbe a halt at the well in the northeastern part of the town, quit their\r\ngates and doors, and closed in after the procession.\r\n\r\nA prisoner whom the horsemen were guarding was the object of curiosity.\r\nHe was afoot, bareheaded, half naked, his hands bound behind him. A\r\nthong fixed to his wrists was looped over the neck of a horse. The dust\r\nwent with the party when in movement, wrapping him in yellow fog,\r\nsometimes in a dense cloud. He drooped forward, footsore and faint. The\r\nvillagers could see he was young.\r\n\r\nAt the well the decurion halted, and, with most of the men, dismounted.\r\nThe prisoner sank down in the dust of the road, stupefied, and asking\r\nnothing: apparently he was in the last stage of exhaustion. Seeing,\r\nwhen they came near, that he was but a boy, the villagers would have\r\nhelped him had they dared.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of their perplexity, and while the pitchers were passing\r\namong the soldiers, a man was descried coming down the road from\r\nSepphoris. At sight of him a woman cried out, \xe2\x80\x9cLook! Yonder comes the\r\ncarpenter. Now we will hear something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe person spoken of was quite venerable in appearance. Thin white\r\nlocks fell below the edge of his full turban, and a mass of still\r\nwhiter beard flowed down the front of his coarse gray gown. He came\r\nslowly, for, in addition to his age, he carried some tools\xe2\x80\x94an axe, a\r\nsaw, and a drawing-knife, all very rude and heavy\xe2\x80\x94and had evidently\r\ntravelled some distance without rest.\r\n\r\nHe stopped close by to survey the assemblage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Rabbi, good Rabbi Joseph!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a woman, running to him. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is a\r\nprisoner; come ask the soldiers about him, that we may know who he is,\r\nand what he has done, and what they are going to do with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe rabbi\xe2\x80\x99s face remained stolid; he glanced at the prisoner, however,\r\nand presently went to the officer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peace of the Lord be with you!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with unbending gravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that of the gods with you,\xe2\x80\x9d the decurion replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you from Jerusalem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour prisoner is young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn years, yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask what he has done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is an assassin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people repeated the word in astonishment, but Rabbi Joseph pursued\r\nhis inquest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he a son of Israel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Roman, dryly.\r\n\r\nThe wavering pity of the bystanders came back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing of your tribes, but can speak of his family,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nspeaker continued. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may have heard of a prince of Jerusalem named\r\nHur\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur, they called him. He lived in Herod\xe2\x80\x99s day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have seen him,\xe2\x80\x9d Joseph said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this is his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nExclamations became general, and the decurion hastened to stop them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the streets of Jerusalem, day before yesterday, he nearly killed\r\nthe noble Gratus by flinging a tile upon his head from the roof of a\r\npalace\xe2\x80\x94his father\xe2\x80\x99s, I believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a pause in the conversation during which the Nazarenes gazed\r\nat the young Ben-Hur as at a wild beast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he kill him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the rabbi.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is under sentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94the galleys for life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord help him!\xe2\x80\x9d said Joseph, for once moved out of his stolidity.\r\n\r\nThereupon a youth who came up with Joseph, but had stood behind him\r\nunobserved, laid down an axe he had been carrying, and, going to the\r\ngreat stone standing by the well, took from it a pitcher of water. The\r\naction was so quiet that before the guard could interfere, had they\r\nbeen disposed to do so, he was stooping over the prisoner, and offering\r\nhim drink.\r\n\r\nThe hand laid kindly upon his shoulder awoke the unfortunate Judah,\r\nand, looking up, he saw a face he never forgot\xe2\x80\x94the face of a boy about\r\nhis own age, shaded by locks of yellowish bright chestnut hair; a face\r\nlighted by dark-blue eyes, at the time so soft, so appealing, so full\r\nof love and holy purpose, that they had all the power of command and\r\nwill. The spirit of the Jew, hardened though it was by days and nights\r\nof suffering, and so embittered by wrong that its dreams of revenge\r\ntook in all the world, melted under the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s look, and became as\r\na child\xe2\x80\x99s. He put his lips to the pitcher, and drank long and deep. Not\r\na word was said to him, nor did he say a word.\r\n\r\nWhen the draught was finished, the hand that had been resting upon the\r\nsufferer\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder was placed upon his head, and stayed there in the\r\ndusty locks time enough to say a blessing; the stranger then returned\r\nthe pitcher to its place on the stone, and, taking his axe again, went\r\nback to Rabbi Joseph. All eyes went with him, the decurion\xe2\x80\x99s as well as\r\nthose of the villagers.\r\n\r\nThis was the end of the scene at the well. When the men had drunk, and\r\nthe horses, the march was resumed. But the temper of the decurion was\r\nnot as it had been; he himself raised the prisoner from the dust, and\r\nhelped him on a horse behind a soldier. The Nazarenes went to their\r\nhouses\xe2\x80\x94among them Rabbi Joseph and his apprentice.\r\n\r\nAnd so, for the first time, Judah and the son of Mary met and parted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK THIRD\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCleopatra.... Our size of sorrow,\r\nProportion\xe2\x80\x99d to our cause, must be as great\r\nAs that which makes it.\xe2\x80\x94\r\n          Enter, below, DIOMEDES.\r\n                    How now? is he dead?\r\n\r\nDiomedes. His death\xe2\x80\x99s upon him, but not dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n          Antony and Cleopatra (act iv., sc. xiii.).\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThe city of Misenum gave name to the promontory which it crowned, a few\r\nmiles southwest of Naples. An account of ruins is all that remains of\r\nit now; yet in the year of our Lord 24\xe2\x80\x94to which it is desirable to\r\nadvance the reader\xe2\x80\x94the place was one of the most important on the\r\nwestern coast of Italy.[1]\r\n\r\n[1] The Roman government, it will be remembered, had two harbors in\r\nwhich great fleets were constantly kept\xe2\x80\x94Ravenna and Misenum.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the year mentioned, a traveller coming to the promontory to regale\r\nhimself with the view there offered, would have mounted a wall, and,\r\nwith the city at his back, looked over the bay of Neapolis, as charming\r\nthen as now; and then, as now, he would have seen the matchless shore,\r\nthe smoking cone, the sky and waves so softly, deeply blue, Ischia here\r\nand Capri yonder; from one to the other and back again, through the\r\npurpled air, his gaze would have sported; at last\xe2\x80\x94for the eyes do weary\r\nof the beautiful as the palate with sweets\xe2\x80\x94at last it would have\r\ndropped upon a spectacle which the modern tourist cannot see\xe2\x80\x94half the\r\nreserve navy of Rome astir or at anchor below him. Thus regarded,\r\nMisenum was a very proper place for three masters to meet, and at\r\nleisure parcel the world among them.\r\n\r\nIn the old time, moreover, there was a gateway in the wall at a certain\r\npoint fronting the sea\xe2\x80\x94an empty gateway forming the outlet of a street\r\nwhich, after the exit, stretched itself, in the form of a broad mole,\r\nout many stadia into the waves.\r\n\r\nThe watchman on the wall above the gateway was disturbed, one cool\r\nSeptember morning, by a party coming down the street in noisy\r\nconversation. He gave one look, then settled into his drowse again.\r\n\r\nThere were twenty or thirty persons in the party, of whom the greater\r\nnumber were slaves with torches, which flamed little and smoked much,\r\nleaving on the air the perfume of the Indian nard. The masters walked\r\nin advance arm-in-arm. One of them, apparently fifty years old,\r\nslightly bald, and wearing over his scant locks a crown of laurel,\r\nseemed, from the attentions paid him, the central object of some\r\naffectionate ceremony. They all sported ample togas of white wool\r\nbroadly bordered with purple. A glance had sufficed the watchman. He\r\nknew, without question, they were of high rank, and escorting a friend\r\nto ship after a night of festivity. Further explanation will be found\r\nin the conversation they carried on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my Quintus,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, speaking to him with the crown, \xe2\x80\x9cit is ill\r\nof Fortune to take thee from us so soon. Only yesterday thou didst\r\nreturn from the seas beyond the Pillars. Why, thou hast not even got\r\nback thy land legs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Castor! if a man may swear a woman\xe2\x80\x99s oath,\xe2\x80\x9d said another, somewhat\r\nworse of wine, \xe2\x80\x9clet us not lament. Our Quintus is but going to find\r\nwhat he lost last night. Dice on a rolling ship is not dice on\r\nshore\xe2\x80\x94eh, Quintus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbuse not Fortune!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a third. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is not blind or fickle. At\r\nAntium, where our Arrius questions her, she answers him with nods, and\r\nat sea she abides with him holding the rudder. She takes him from us,\r\nbut does she not always give him back with a new victory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Greeks are taking him away,\xe2\x80\x9d another broke in. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us abuse them,\r\nnot the gods. In learning to trade they forgot how to fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words, the party passed the gateway, and came upon the mole,\r\nwith the bay before them beautiful in the morning light. To the veteran\r\nsailor the plash of the waves was like a greeting. He drew a long\r\nbreath, as if the perfume of the water were sweeter than that of the\r\nnard, and held his hand aloft.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy gifts were at Praeneste, not Antium\xe2\x80\x94and see! Wind from the west.\r\nThanks, O Fortune, my mother!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, earnestly.\r\n\r\nThe friends all repeated the exclamation, and the slaves waved their\r\ntorches.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe comes\xe2\x80\x94yonder!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, pointing to a galley outside the\r\nmole. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat need has a sailor for other mistress? Is your Lucrece more\r\ngraceful, my Caius?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gazed at the coming ship, and justified his pride. A white sail was\r\nbent to the low mast, and the oars dipped, arose, poised a moment, then\r\ndipped again, with wing-like action, and in perfect time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, spare the gods,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, soberly, his eyes fixed upon the\r\nvessel. \xe2\x80\x9cThey send us opportunities. Ours the fault if we fail. And as\r\nfor the Greeks, you forget, O my Lentulus, the pirates I am going to\r\npunish are Greeks. One victory over them is of more account than a\r\nhundred over the Africans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen thy way is to the Aegean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sailor\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were full of his ship.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat grace, what freedom! A bird hath not less care for the fretting\r\nof the waves. See!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, but almost immediately added, \xe2\x80\x9cThy pardon,\r\nmy Lentulus. I am going to the Aegean; and as my departure is so near,\r\nI will tell the occasion\xe2\x80\x94only keep it under the rose. I would not that\r\nyou abuse the duumvir when next you meet him. He is my friend. The\r\ntrade between Greece and Alexandria, as ye may have heard, is hardly\r\ninferior to that between Alexandria and Rome. The people in that part\r\nof the world forgot to celebrate the Cerealia, and Triptolemus paid\r\nthem with a harvest not worth the gathering. At all events, the trade\r\nis so grown that it will not brook interruption a day. Ye may also have\r\nheard of the Chersonesan pirates, nested up in the Euxine; none bolder,\r\nby the Bacchae! Yesterday word came to Rome that, with a fleet, they\r\nhad rowed down the Bosphorus, sunk the galleys off Byzantium and\r\nChalcedon, swept the Propontis, and, still unsated, burst through into\r\nthe Aegean. The corn-merchants who have ships in the East Mediterranean\r\nare frightened. They had audience with the Emperor himself, and from\r\nRavenna there go to-day a hundred galleys, and from Misenum\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he paused\r\nas if to pique the curiosity of his friends, and ended with an\r\nemphatic\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy Quintus! We congratulate thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe preferment forerunneth promotion. We salute thee duumvir; nothing\r\nless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuintus Arrius, the duumvir, hath a better sound than Quintus Arrius,\r\nthe tribune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn such manner they showered him with congratulations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad with the rest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the bibulous friend, \xe2\x80\x9cvery glad; but I\r\nmust be practical, O my duumvir; and not until I know if promotion will\r\nhelp thee to knowledge of the tesserae will I have an opinion as to\r\nwhether the gods mean thee ill or good in this\xe2\x80\x94this business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, many thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius replied, speaking to them collectively.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad ye but lanterns, I would say ye were augurs. Perpol! I will go\r\nfurther, and show what master diviners ye are! See\xe2\x80\x94and read.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the folds of his toga he drew a roll of paper, and passed it to\r\nthem, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cReceived while at table last night from\xe2\x80\x94Sejanus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe name was already a great one in the Roman world; great, and not so\r\ninfamous as it afterwards became.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSejanus!\xe2\x80\x9d they exclaimed, with one voice, closing in to read what the\r\nminister had written.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSejanus to C. Caecilius Rufus, Duumvir.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cROME, XIX. Kal. Sept.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaesar hath good report of Quintus Arrius, the tribune. In particular\r\nhe hath heard of his valor, manifested in the western seas, insomuch\r\nthat it is his will that the said Quintus be transferred instantly to\r\nthe East.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is our Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s will, further, that you cause a hundred triremes,\r\nof the first class, and full appointment, to be despatched without\r\ndelay against the pirates who have appeared in the Aegean, and that\r\nQuintus be sent to command the fleet so despatched.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDetails are thine, my Caecilius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe necessity is urgent, as thou will be advised by the reports\r\nenclosed for thy perusal and the information of the said Quintus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSEJANUS.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius gave little heed to the reading. As the ship drew more plainly\r\nout of the perspective, she became more and more an attraction to him.\r\nThe look with which he watched her was that of an enthusiast. At length\r\nhe tossed the loosened folds of his toga in the air; in reply to the\r\nsignal, over the aplustre, or fan-like fixture at the stern of the\r\nvessel, a scarlet flag was displayed; while several sailors appeared\r\nupon the bulwarks, and swung themselves hand over hand up the ropes to\r\nthe antenna, or yard, and furled the sail. The bow was put round, and\r\nthe time of the oars increased one half; so that at racing speed she\r\nbore down directly towards him and his friends. He observed the\r\nmanoeuvring with a perceptible brightening of the eyes. Her instant\r\nanswer to the rudder, and the steadiness with which she kept her\r\ncourse, were especially noticeable as virtues to be relied upon in\r\naction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the Nymphae!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the friends, giving back the roll, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\nmay not longer say our friend will be great; he is already great. Our\r\nlove will now have famous things to feed upon. What more hast thou for\r\nus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more,\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius replied. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat ye have of the affair is by this\r\ntime old news in Rome, especially between the palace and the Forum. The\r\nduumvir is discreet; what I am to do, where go to find my fleet, he\r\nwill tell on the ship, where a sealed package is waiting me. If,\r\nhowever, ye have offerings for any of the altars to-day, pray the gods\r\nfor a friend plying oar and sail somewhere in the direction of Sicily.\r\nBut she is here, and will come to,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, reverting to the vessel.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have interest in her masters; they will sail and fight with me. It\r\nis not an easy thing to lay ship side on a shore like this; so let us\r\njudge their training and skill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, is she new to thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never saw her before; and, as yet, I know not if she will bring me\r\none acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt matters but little. We of the sea come to know each other quickly;\r\nour loves, like our hates, are born of sudden dangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe vessel was of the class called naves liburnicae\xe2\x80\x94long, narrow, low\r\nin the water, and modelled for speed and quick manoeuvre. The bow was\r\nbeautiful. A jet of water spun from its foot as she came on, sprinkling\r\nall the prow, which rose in graceful curvature twice a man\xe2\x80\x99s stature\r\nabove the plane of the deck. Upon the bending of the sides were figures\r\nof Triton blowing shells. Below the bow, fixed to the keel, and\r\nprojecting forward under the water-line, was the rostrum, or beak, a\r\ndevice of solid wood, reinforced and armed with iron, in action used as\r\na ram. A stout molding extended from the bow the full length of the\r\nship\xe2\x80\x99s sides, defining the bulwarks, which were tastefully crenelated;\r\nbelow the molding, in three rows, each covered with a cap or shield of\r\nbull-hide, were the holes in which the oars were worked\xe2\x80\x94sixty on the\r\nright, sixty on the left. In further ornamentation, caducei leaned\r\nagainst the lofty prow. Two immense ropes passing across the bow marked\r\nthe number of anchors stowed on the foredeck.\r\n\r\nThe simplicity of the upper works declared the oars the chief\r\ndependence of the crew. A mast, set a little forward of midship, was\r\nheld by fore and back stays and shrouds fixed to rings on the inner\r\nside of the bulwarks. The tackle was that required for the management\r\nof one great square sail and the yard to which it was hung. Above the\r\nbulwarks the deck was visible.\r\n\r\nSave the sailors who had reefed the sail, and yet lingered on the yard,\r\nbut one man was to be seen by the party on the mole, and he stood by\r\nthe prow helmeted and with a shield.\r\n\r\nThe hundred and twenty oaken blades, kept white and shining by pumice\r\nand the constant wash of the waves, rose and fell as if operated by the\r\nsame hand, and drove the galley forward with a speed rivalling that of\r\na modern steamer.\r\n\r\nSo rapidly, and apparently, so rashly, did she come that the landsmen\r\nof the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s party were alarmed. Suddenly the man by the prow\r\nraised his hand with a peculiar gesture; whereupon all the oars flew\r\nup, poised a moment in air, then fell straight down. The water boiled\r\nand bubbled about them; the galley shook in every timber, and stopped\r\nas if scared. Another gesture of the hand, and again the oars arose,\r\nfeathered, and fell; but this time those on the right, dropping towards\r\nthe stern, pushed forward; while those on the left, dropping towards\r\nthe bow, pulled backwards. Three times the oars thus pushed and pulled\r\nagainst each other. Round to the right the ship swung as upon a pivot;\r\nthen, caught by the wind, she settled gently broadside to the mole.\r\n\r\nThe movement brought the stern to view, with all its garniture\xe2\x80\x94Tritons\r\nlike those at the bow; name in large raised letters; the rudder at the\r\nside; the elevated platform upon which the helmsman sat, a stately\r\nfigure in full armor, his hand upon the rudder-rope; and the aplustre,\r\nhigh, gilt, carved, and bent over the helmsman like a great runcinate\r\nleaf.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the rounding-to, a trumpet was blown brief and shrill,\r\nand from the hatchways out poured the marines, all in superb equipment,\r\nbrazen helms, burnished shields and javelins. While the fighting-men\r\nthus went to quarters as for action, the sailors proper climbed the\r\nshrouds and perched themselves along the yard. The officers and\r\nmusicians took their posts. There was no shouting or needless noise.\r\nWhen the oars touched the mole, a bridge was sent out from the\r\nhelmsman\xe2\x80\x99s deck. Then the tribune turned to his party and said, with a\r\ngravity he had not before shown:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuty now, O my friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the chaplet from his head and gave it to the dice-player.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake thou the myrtle, O favorite of the tesserae!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I\r\nreturn, I will seek my sestertii again; if I am not victor, I will not\r\nreturn. Hang the crown in thy atrium.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo the company he opened his arms, and they came one by one and\r\nreceived his parting embrace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gods go with thee, O Quintus!\xe2\x80\x9d they said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\nTo the slaves waving their torches he waved his hand; then he turned to\r\nthe waiting ship, beautiful with ordered ranks and crested helms, and\r\nshields and javelins. As he stepped upon the bridge, the trumpets\r\nsounded, and over the aplustre rose the vexillum purpureum, or pennant\r\nof a commander of a fleet.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nThe tribune, standing upon the helmsman\xe2\x80\x99s deck with the order of the\r\nduumvir open in his hand, spoke to the chief of the rowers.[1]\r\n\r\n[1] Called hortator.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat force hast thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf oarsmen, two hundred and fifty-two; ten supernumeraries.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaking reliefs of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEighty-four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thy habit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt has been to take off and put on every two hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune mused a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe division is hard, and I will reform it, but not now. The oars may\r\nnot rest day or night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen to the sailing-master he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wind is fair. Let the sail help the oars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the two thus addressed were gone, he turned to the chief pilot.[2]\r\n\r\n[2] Called rector.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat service hast thou had?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo-and-thirty years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what seas chiefly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetween our Rome and the East.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art the man I would have chosen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune looked at his orders again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPast the Camponellan cape, the course will be to Messina. Beyond that,\r\nfollow the bend of the Calabrian shore till Melito is on thy left,\r\nthen\xe2\x80\x94 Knowest thou the stars that govern in the Ionian Sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know them well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen from Melito course eastward for Cythera. The gods willing, I will\r\nnot anchor until in the Bay of Antemona. The duty is urgent. I rely\r\nupon thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA prudent man was Arrius\xe2\x80\x94prudent, and of the class which, while\r\nenriching the altars at Praeneste and Antium, was of opinion,\r\nnevertheless, that the favor of the blind goddess depended more upon\r\nthe votary\xe2\x80\x99s care and judgment than upon his gifts and vows. All night\r\nas master of the feast he had sat at table drinking and playing; yet\r\nthe odor of the sea returned him to the mood of the sailor, and he\r\nwould not rest until he knew his ship. Knowledge leaves no room for\r\nchances. Having begun with the chief of the rowers, the sailing-master,\r\nand the pilot, in company with the other officers\xe2\x80\x94the commander of the\r\nmarines, the keeper of the stores, the master of the machines, the\r\noverseer of the kitchen or fires\xe2\x80\x94he passed through the several\r\nquarters. Nothing escaped his inspection. When he was through, of the\r\ncommunity crowded within the narrow walls he alone knew perfectly all\r\nthere was of material preparation for the voyage and its possible\r\nincidents; and, finding the preparation complete, there was left him\r\nbut one thing further\xe2\x80\x94thorough knowledge of the personnel of his\r\ncommand. As this was the most delicate and difficult part of his task,\r\nrequiring much time, he set about it his own way.\r\n\r\nAt noon that day the galley was skimming the sea off Paestum. The wind\r\nwas yet from the west, filling the sail to the master\xe2\x80\x99s content. The\r\nwatches had been established. On the foredeck the altar had been set\r\nand sprinkled with salt and barley, and before it the tribune had\r\noffered solemn prayers to Jove and to Neptune and all the Oceanidae,\r\nand, with vows, poured the wine and burned the incense. And now, the\r\nbetter to study his men, he was seated in the great cabin, a very\r\nmartial figure.\r\n\r\nThe cabin, it should be stated, was the central compartment of the\r\ngalley, in extent quite sixty-five by thirty feet, and lighted by three\r\nbroad hatchways. A row of stanchions ran from end to end, supporting\r\nthe roof, and near the centre the mast was visible, all bristling with\r\naxes and spears and javelins. To each hatchway there were double stairs\r\ndescending right and left, with a pivotal arrangement at the top to\r\nallow the lower ends to be hitched to the ceiling; and, as these were\r\nnow raised, the compartment had the appearance of a skylighted hall.\r\n\r\nThe reader will understand readily that this was the heart of the ship,\r\nthe home of all aboard\xe2\x80\x94eating-room, sleeping-chamber, field of\r\nexercise, lounging-place off duty\xe2\x80\x94uses made possible by the laws which\r\nreduced life there to minute details and a routine relentless as death.\r\n\r\nAt the after-end of the cabin there was a platform, reached by several\r\nsteps. Upon it the chief of the rowers sat; in front of him a\r\nsounding-table, upon which, with a gavel, he beat time for the oarsmen;\r\nat his right a clepsydra, or water-clock, to measure the reliefs and\r\nwatches. Above him, on a higher platform, well guarded by gilded\r\nrailing, the tribune had his quarters, overlooking everything, and\r\nfurnished with a couch, a table, and a cathedra, or chair, cushioned,\r\nand with arms and high back\xe2\x80\x94articles which the imperial dispensation\r\npermitted of the utmost elegance.\r\n\r\nThus at ease, lounging in the great chair, swaying with the motion of\r\nthe vessel, the military cloak half draping his tunic, sword in belt,\r\nArrius kept watchful eye over his command, and was as closely watched\r\nby them. He saw critically everything in view, but dwelt longest upon\r\nthe rowers. The reader would doubtless have done the same: only he\r\nwould have looked with much sympathy, while, as is the habit with\r\nmasters, the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s mind ran forward of what he saw, inquiring for\r\nresults.\r\n\r\nThe spectacle was simple enough of itself. Along the sides of the\r\ncabin, fixed to the ship\xe2\x80\x99s timbers, were what at first appeared to be\r\nthree rows of benches; a closer view, however, showed them a succession\r\nof rising banks, in each of which the second bench was behind and above\r\nthe first one, and the third above and behind the second. To\r\naccommodate the sixty rowers on a side, the space devoted to them\r\npermitted nineteen banks separated by intervals of one yard, with a\r\ntwentieth bank divided so that what would have been its upper seat or\r\nbench was directly above the lower seat of the first bank. The\r\narrangement gave each rower when at work ample room, if he timed his\r\nmovements with those of his associates, the principle being that of\r\nsoldiers marching with cadenced step in close order. The arrangement\r\nalso allowed a multiplication of banks, limited only by the length of\r\nthe galley.\r\n\r\nAs to the rowers, those upon the first and second benches sat, while\r\nthose upon the third, having longer oars to work, were suffered to\r\nstand. The oars were loaded with lead in the handles, and near the\r\npoint of balance hung to pliable thongs, making possible the delicate\r\ntouch called feathering, but, at the same time, increasing the need of\r\nskill, since an eccentric wave might at any moment catch a heedless\r\nfellow and hurl him from his seat. Each oar-hole was a vent through\r\nwhich the laborer opposite it had his plenty of sweet air. Light\r\nstreamed down upon him from the grating which formed the floor of the\r\npassage between the deck and the bulwark over his head. In some\r\nrespects, therefore, the condition of the men might have been much\r\nworse. Still, it must not be imagined that there was any pleasantness\r\nin their lives. Communication between them was not allowed. Day after\r\nday they filled their places without speech; in hours of labor they\r\ncould not see each other\xe2\x80\x99s faces; their short respites were given to\r\nsleep and the snatching of food. They never laughed; no one ever heard\r\none of them sing. What is the use of tongues when a sigh or a groan\r\nwill tell all men feel while, perforce, they think in silence?\r\nExistence with the poor wretches was like a stream under ground\r\nsweeping slowly, laboriously on to its outlet, wherever that might\r\nchance to be.\r\n\r\nO Son of Mary! The sword has now a heart\xe2\x80\x94and thine the glory! So now;\r\nbut, in the days of which we are writing, for captivity there was\r\ndrudgery on walls, and in the streets and mines, and the galleys both\r\nof war and commerce were insatiable. When Druilius won the first\r\nsea-fight for his country, Romans plied the oars, and the glory was to\r\nthe rower not less than the marine. These benches which now we are\r\ntrying to see as they were testified to the change come with conquest,\r\nand illustrated both the policy and the prowess of Rome. Nearly all the\r\nnations had sons there, mostly prisoners of war, chosen for their brawn\r\nand endurance. In one place a Briton; before him a Libyan; behind him a\r\nCrimean. Elsewhere a Scythian, a Gaul, and a Thebasite. Roman convicts\r\ncast down to consort with Goths and Longobardi, Jews, Ethiopians, and\r\nbarbarians from the shores of Maeotis. Here an Athenian, there a\r\nred-haired savage from Hibernia, yonder blue-eyed giants of the Cimbri.\r\n\r\nIn the labor of the rowers there was not enough art to give occupation\r\nto their minds, rude and simple as they were. The reach forward, the\r\npull, the feathering the blade, the dip, were all there was of it;\r\nmotions most perfect when most automatic. Even the care forced upon\r\nthem by the sea outside grew in time to be a thing instinctive rather\r\nthan of thought. So, as the result of long service, the poor wretches\r\nbecame imbruted\xe2\x80\x94patient, spiritless, obedient\xe2\x80\x94creatures of vast muscle\r\nand exhausted intellects, who lived upon recollections generally few\r\nbut dear, and at last lowered into the semi-conscious alchemic state\r\nwherein misery turns to habit, and the soul takes on incredible\r\nendurance.\r\n\r\nFrom right to left, hour after hour, the tribune, swaying in his\r\neasy-chair, turned with thought of everything rather than the\r\nwretchedness of the slaves upon the benches. Their motions, precise,\r\nand exactly the same on both sides of the vessel, after a while became\r\nmonotonous; and then he amused himself singling out individuals. With\r\nhis stylus he made note of objections, thinking, if all went well, he\r\nwould find among the pirates of whom he was in search better men for\r\nthe places.\r\n\r\nThere was no need of keeping the proper names of the slaves brought to\r\nthe galleys as to their graves; so, for convenience, they were usually\r\nidentified by the numerals painted upon the benches to which they were\r\nassigned. As the sharp eyes of the great man moved from seat to seat on\r\neither hand, they came at last to number sixty, which, as has been\r\nsaid, belonged properly to the last bank on the left-hand side, but,\r\nwanting room aft, had been fixed above the first bench of the first\r\nbank. There they rested.\r\n\r\nThe bench of number sixty was slightly above the level of the platform,\r\nand but a few feet away. The light glinting through the grating over\r\nhis head gave the rower fairly to the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s view\xe2\x80\x94erect, and, like\r\nall his fellows, naked, except a cincture about the loins. There were,\r\nhowever, some points in his favor. He was very young, not more than\r\ntwenty. Furthermore, Arrius was not merely given to dice; he was a\r\nconnoisseur of men physically, and when ashore indulged a habit of\r\nvisiting the gymnasia to see and admire the most famous athletae. From\r\nsome professor, doubtless, he had caught the idea that strength was as\r\nmuch of the quality as the quantity of the muscle, while superiority in\r\nperformance required a certain mind as well as strength. Having adopted\r\nthe doctrine, like most men with a hobby, he was always looking for\r\nillustrations to support it.\r\n\r\nThe reader may well believe that while the tribune, in the search for\r\nthe perfect, was often called upon to stop and study, he was seldom\r\nperfectly satisfied\xe2\x80\x94in fact, very seldom held as long as on this\r\noccasion.\r\n\r\nIn the beginning of each movement of the oar, the rower\xe2\x80\x99s body and face\r\nwere brought into profile view from the platform; the movement ended\r\nwith the body reversed, and in a pushing posture. The grace and ease of\r\nthe action at first suggested a doubt of the honesty of the effort put\r\nforth; but it was speedily dismissed; the firmness with which the oar\r\nwas held while in the reach forward, its bending under the push, were\r\nproofs of the force applied; not that only, they as certainly proved\r\nthe rower\xe2\x80\x99s art, and put the critic in the great arm-chair in search of\r\nthe combination of strength and cleverness which was the central idea\r\nof his theory.\r\n\r\nIn course of the study, Arrius observed the subject\xe2\x80\x99s youth; wholly\r\nunconscious of tenderness on that account, he also observed that he\r\nseemed of good height, and that his limbs, upper and nether, were\r\nsingularly perfect. The arms, perhaps, were too long, but the objection\r\nwas well hidden under a mass of muscle, which, in some movements,\r\nswelled and knotted like kinking cords. Every rib in the round body was\r\ndiscernible; yet the leanness was the healthful reduction so strained\r\nafter in the palaestrae. And altogether there was in the rower\xe2\x80\x99s action\r\na certain harmony which, besides addressing itself to the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntheory, stimulated both his curiosity and general interest.\r\n\r\nVery soon he found himself waiting to catch a view of the man\xe2\x80\x99s face in\r\nfull. The head was shapely, and balanced upon a neck broad at the base,\r\nbut of exceeding pliancy and grace. The features in profile were of\r\nOriental outline, and of that delicacy of expression which has always\r\nbeen thought a sign of blood and sensitive spirit. With these\r\nobservations, the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s interest in the subject deepened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the gods,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthe fellow impresses me! He\r\npromises well. I will know more of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDirectly the tribune caught the view he wished\xe2\x80\x94the rower turned and\r\nlooked at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Jew! and a boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnder the gaze then fixed steadily upon him, the large eyes of the\r\nslave grew larger\xe2\x80\x94the blood surged to his very brows\xe2\x80\x94the blade lingered\r\nin his hands. But instantly, with an angry crash, down fell the gavel\r\nof the hortator. The rower started, withdrew his face from the\r\ninquisitor, and, as if personally chidden, dropped the oar half\r\nfeathered. When he glanced again at the tribune, he was vastly more\r\nastonished\xe2\x80\x94he was met with a kindly smile.\r\n\r\nMeantime the galley entered the Straits of Messina, and, skimming past\r\nthe city of that name, was after a while turned eastward, leaving the\r\ncloud over \xc3\x86tna in the sky astern.\r\n\r\nOften as Arrius resumed to his platform in the cabin he returned to\r\nstudy the rower, and he kept saying to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cThe fellow hath a\r\nspirit. A Jew is not a barbarian. I will know more of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nThe fourth day out, and the Astroea\xe2\x80\x94so the galley was named\xe2\x80\x94speeding\r\nthrough the Ionian Sea. The sky was clear, and the wind blew as if\r\nbearing the good-will of all the gods.\r\n\r\nAs it was possible to overtake the fleet before reaching the bay east\r\nof the island of Cythera, designated for assemblage, Arrius, somewhat\r\nimpatient, spent much time on deck. He took note diligently of matters\r\npertaining to his ship, and as a rule was well pleased. In the cabin,\r\nswinging in the great chair, his thought continually reverted to the\r\nrower on number sixty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnowest thou the man just come from yon bench?\xe2\x80\x9d he at length asked of\r\nthe hortator.\r\n\r\nA relief was going on at the moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom number sixty?\xe2\x80\x9d returned the chief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chief looked sharply at the rower then going forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs thou knowest,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied \xe2\x80\x9cthe ship is but a month from the maker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, and the men are as new to me as the ship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius remarked, thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe noble Quintus is shrewd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very young,\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut our best rower,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen his oar bend almost\r\nto breaking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what disposition is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is obedient; further I know not. Once he made request of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wished me to change him alternately from the right to the left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he give a reason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had observed that the men who are confined to one side become\r\nmisshapen. He also said that some day of storm or battle there might be\r\nsudden need to change him, and he might then be unserviceable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerpol! The idea is new. What else hast thou observed of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is cleanly above his companions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that he is Roman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arrius, approvingly. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you nothing of\r\nhis history?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune reflected awhile, and turned to go to his own seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I should be on deck when his time is up,\xe2\x80\x9d he paused to say, \xe2\x80\x9csend\r\nhim to me. Let him come alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAbout two hours later Arrius stood under the aplustre of the galley; in\r\nthe mood of one who, seeing himself carried swiftly towards an event of\r\nmighty import, has nothing to do but wait\xe2\x80\x94the mood in which philosophy\r\nvests an even-minded man with the utmost calm, and is ever so\r\nserviceable. The pilot sat with a hand upon the rope by which the\r\nrudder paddles, one on each side of the vessel, were managed. In the\r\nshade of the sail some sailors lay asleep, and up on the yard there was\r\na lookout. Lifting his eyes from the solarium set under the aplustre\r\nfor reference in keeping the course, Arrius beheld the rower\r\napproaching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe chief called thee the noble Arrius, and said it was thy will that\r\nI should seek thee here. I have come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius surveyed the figure, tall, sinewy, glistening in the sun, and\r\ntinted by the rich red blood within\xe2\x80\x94surveyed it admiringly, and with a\r\nthought of the arena; yet the manner was not without effect upon him:\r\nthere was in the voice a suggestion of life at least partly spent under\r\nrefining influences; the eyes were clear and open, and more curious\r\nthan defiant. To the shrewd, demanding, masterful glance bent upon it,\r\nthe face gave back nothing to mar its youthful comeliness\xe2\x80\x94nothing of\r\naccusation or sullenness or menace, only the signs which a great sorrow\r\nlong borne imprints, as time mellows the surface of pictures. In tacit\r\nacknowledgment of the effect, the Roman spoke as an older man to a\r\nyounger, not as a master to a slave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hortator tells me thou art his best rower.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hortator is very kind,\xe2\x80\x9d the rower answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast thou seen much service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout three years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the oars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot recall a day of rest from them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe labor is hard; few men bear it a year without breaking, and\r\nthou\xe2\x80\x94thou art but a boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe noble Arrius forgets that the spirit hath much to do with\r\nendurance. By its help the weak sometimes thrive, when the strong\r\nperish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom thy speech, thou art a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy ancestors further back than the first Roman were Hebrews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stubborn pride of thy race is not lost in thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arrius,\r\nobserving a flush upon the rower\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPride is never so loud as when in chains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat cause hast thou for pride?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I am a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not been to Jerusalem,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have heard of its\r\nprinces. I knew one of them. He was a merchant, and sailed the seas. He\r\nwas fit to have been a king. Of what degree art thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must answer thee from the bench of a galley.
