I am of the degree of\r\nslaves. My father was a prince of Jerusalem, and, as a merchant, he\r\nsailed the seas. He was known and honored in the guest-chamber of the\r\ngreat Augustus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIthamar, of the house of Hur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune raised his hand in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a silence, he asked,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat brought thee here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah lowered his head, and his breast labored hard. When his feelings\r\nwere sufficiently mastered, he looked the tribune in the face, and\r\nanswered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was accused of attempting to assassinate Valerius Gratus, the\r\nprocurator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Arrius, yet more amazed, and retreating a step. \xe2\x80\x9cThou\r\nthat assassin! All Rome rang with the story. It came to my ship in the\r\nriver by Lodinum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two regarded each other silently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought the family of Hur blotted from the earth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arrius,\r\nspeaking first.\r\n\r\nA flood of tender recollections carried the young man\xe2\x80\x99s pride away;\r\ntears shone upon his cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x94mother! And my little Tirzah! Where are they? O tribune, noble\r\ntribune, if thou knowest anything of them\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he clasped his hands in\r\nappeal\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctell me all thou knowest. Tell me if they are living\xe2\x80\x94if living,\r\nwhere are they? and in what condition? Oh, I pray thee, tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew nearer Arrius, so near that his hands touched the cloak where\r\nit dropped from the latter\xe2\x80\x99s folded arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe horrible day is three years gone,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthree years, O\r\ntribune, and every hour a whole lifetime of misery\xe2\x80\x94a lifetime in a\r\nbottomless pit with death, and no relief but in labor\xe2\x80\x94and in all that\r\ntime not a word from any one, not a whisper. Oh, if, in being\r\nforgotten, we could only forget! If only I could hide from that\r\nscene\xe2\x80\x94my sister torn from me, my mother\xe2\x80\x99s last look! I have felt the\r\nplague\xe2\x80\x99s breath, and the shock of ships in battle; I have heard the\r\ntempest lashing the sea, and laughed, though others prayed: death would\r\nhave been a riddance. Bend the oar\xe2\x80\x94yes, in the strain of mighty effort\r\ntrying to escape the haunting of what that day occurred. Think what\r\nlittle will help me. Tell me they are dead, if no more, for happy they\r\ncannot be while I am lost. I have heard them call me in the night; I\r\nhave seen them on the water walking. Oh, never anything so true as my\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s love! And Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94her breath was as the breath of white lilies.\r\nShe was the youngest branch of the palm\xe2\x80\x94so fresh, so tender, so\r\ngraceful, so beautiful! She made my day all morning. She came and went\r\nin music. And mine was the hand that laid them low! I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDost thou admit thy guilt?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Arrius, sternly.\r\n\r\nThe change that came upon Ben-Hur was wonderful to see, it was so\r\ninstant and extreme. The voice sharpened; the hands arose\r\ntight-clenched; every fibre thrilled; his eyes inflamed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast heard of the God of my fathers,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cof the infinite\r\nJehovah. By his truth and almightiness, and by the love with which he\r\nhath followed Israel from the beginning, I swear I am innocent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune was much moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO noble Roman!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Ben-Hur, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me a little faith, and, into\r\nmy darkness, deeper darkening every day, send a light!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius turned away, and walked the deck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidst thou not have a trial?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, stopping suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Roman raised his head, surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo trial\xe2\x80\x94no witnesses! Who passed judgment upon thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRomans, it should be remembered, were at no time such lovers of the law\r\nand its forms as in the ages of their decay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey bound me with cords, and dragged me to a vault in the Tower. I\r\nsaw no one. No one spoke to me. Next day soldiers took me to the\r\nseaside. I have been a galley-slave ever since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat couldst thou have proven?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was a boy, too young to be a conspirator. Gratus was a stranger to\r\nme. If I had meant to kill him, that was not the time or the place. He\r\nwas riding in the midst of a legion, and it was broad day. I could not\r\nhave escaped. I was of a class most friendly to Rome. My father had\r\nbeen distinguished for his services to the emperor. We had a great\r\nestate to lose. Ruin was certain to myself, my mother, my sister. I had\r\nno cause for malice, while every consideration\xe2\x80\x94property, family, life,\r\nconscience, the Law\xe2\x80\x94to a son of Israel as the breath of his\r\nnostrils\xe2\x80\x94would have stayed my hand, though the foul intent had been\r\never so strong. I was not mad. Death was preferable to shame; and,\r\nbelieve me, I pray, it is so yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was with thee when the blow was struck?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was on the house-top\xe2\x80\x94my father\xe2\x80\x99s house. Tirzah was with me\xe2\x80\x94at my\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94the soul of gentleness. Together we leaned over the parapet to see\r\nthe legion pass. A tile gave way under my hand, and fell upon Gratus. I\r\nthought I had killed him. Ah, what horror I felt!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was thy mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn her chamber below.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat became of her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur clenched his hands, and drew a breath like a gasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know. I saw them drag her away\xe2\x80\x94that is all I know. Out of the\r\nhouse they drove every living thing, even the dumb cattle, and they\r\nsealed the gates. The purpose was that she should not return. I, too,\r\nask for her. Oh for one word! She, at least, was innocent. I can\r\nforgive\xe2\x80\x94but I pray thy pardon, noble tribune! A slave like me should\r\nnot talk of forgiveness or of revenge. I am bound to an oar for life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius listened intently. He brought all his experience with slaves to\r\nhis aid. If the feeling shown in this instance were assumed, the acting\r\nwas perfect; on the other hand, if it were real, the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s innocence\r\nmight not be doubted; and if he were innocent, with what blind fury the\r\npower had been exercised! A whole family blotted out to atone an\r\naccident! The thought shocked him.\r\n\r\nThere is no wiser providence than that our occupations, however rude or\r\nbloody, cannot wear us out morally; that such qualities as justice and\r\nmercy, if they really possess us, continue to live on under them, like\r\nflowers under the snow. The tribune could be inexorable, else he had\r\nnot been fit for the usages of his calling; he could also be just; and\r\nto excite his sense of wrong was to put him in the way to right the\r\nwrong. The crews of the ships in which he served came after a time to\r\nspeak of him as the good tribune. Shrewd readers will not want a better\r\ndefinition of his character.\r\n\r\nIn this instance there were many circumstances certainly in the young\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s favor, and some to be supposed. Possibly Arrius knew Valerius\r\nGratus without loving him. Possibly he had known the elder Hur. In the\r\ncourse of his appeal, Judah had asked him of that; and, as will be\r\nnoticed, he had made no reply.\r\n\r\nFor once the tribune was at loss, and hesitated. His power was ample.\r\nHe was monarch of the ship. His prepossessions all moved him to mercy.\r\nHis faith was won. Yet, he said to himself, there was no haste\xe2\x80\x94or,\r\nrather, there was haste to Cythera; the best rower could not then be\r\nspared; he would wait; he would learn more; he would at least be sure\r\nthis was the prince Ben-Hur, and that he was of a right disposition.\r\nOrdinarily, slaves were liars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough,\xe2\x80\x9d he said aloud. \xe2\x80\x9cGo back to thy place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur bowed; looked once more into the master\xe2\x80\x99s face, but saw nothing\r\nfor hope. He turned away slowly, looked back, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou dost think of me again, O tribune, let it not be lost in thy\r\nmind that I prayed thee only for word of my people\xe2\x80\x94mother, sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe moved on.\r\n\r\nArrius followed him with admiring eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerpol!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWith teaching, what a man for the arena! What a\r\nrunner! Ye gods! what an arm for the sword or the cestus!\xe2\x80\x94Stay!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid aloud.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur stopped, and the tribune went to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou wert free, what wouldst thou do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe noble Arrius mocks me!\xe2\x80\x9d Judah said, with trembling lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; by the gods, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I will answer gladly. I would give myself to duty the first of\r\nlife. I would know no other. I would know no rest until my mother and\r\nTirzah were restored to home. I would give every day and hour to their\r\nhappiness. I would wait upon them; never a slave more faithful. They\r\nhave lost much, but, by the God of my fathers, I would find them more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer was unexpected by the Roman. For a moment he lost his\r\npurpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spoke to thy ambition,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, recovering. \xe2\x80\x9cIf thy mother and\r\nsister were dead, or not to be found, what wouldst thou do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA distinct pallor overspread Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face, and he looked over the\r\nsea. There was a struggle with some strong feeling; when it was\r\nconquered, he turned to the tribune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat pursuit would I follow?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTribune, I will tell thee truly. Only the night before the dreadful\r\nday of which I have spoken, I obtained permission to be a soldier. I am\r\nof the same mind yet; and, as in all the earth there is but one school\r\nof war, thither I would go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe palaestra!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Arrius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; a Roman camp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut thou must first acquaint thyself with the use of arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow a master may never safely advise a slave. Arrius saw his\r\nindiscretion, and, in a breath, chilled his voice and manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand do not build upon what has passed between us.\r\nPerhaps I do but play with thee. Or\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he looked away musingly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cor, if\r\nthou dost think of it with any hope, choose between the renown of a\r\ngladiator and the service of a soldier. The former may come of the\r\nfavor of the emperor; there is no reward for thee in the latter. Thou\r\nart not a Roman. Go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA short while after Ben-Hur was upon his bench again.\r\n\r\nA man\xe2\x80\x99s task is always light if his heart is light. Handling the oar\r\ndid not seem so toilsome to Judah. A hope had come to him, like a\r\nsinging bird. He could hardly see the visitor or hear its song; that it\r\nwas there, though, he knew; his feelings told him so. The caution of\r\nthe tribune\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I do but play with thee\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94was dismissed often as it\r\nrecurred to his mind. That he had been called by the great man and\r\nasked his story was the bread upon which he fed his hungry spirit.\r\nSurely something good would come of it. The light about his bench was\r\nclear and bright with promises, and he prayed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO God! I am a true son of the Israel thou hast so loved! Help me, I\r\npray thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the Bay of Antemona, east of Cythera the island, the hundred galleys\r\nassembled. There the tribune gave one day to inspection. He sailed then\r\nto Naxos, the largest of the Cyclades, midway the coasts of Greece and\r\nAsia, like a great stone planted in the centre of a highway, from which\r\nhe could challenge everything that passed; at the same time, he would\r\nbe in position to go after the pirates instantly, whether they were in\r\nthe \xc3\x86gean or out on the Mediterranean.\r\n\r\nAs the fleet, in order, rowed in towards the mountain shores of the\r\nisland, a galley was descried coming from the north. Arrius went to\r\nmeet it. She proved to be a transport just from Byzantium, and from her\r\ncommander he learned the particulars of which he stood in most need.\r\n\r\nThe pirates were from all the farther shores of the Euxine. Even\r\nTanais, at the mouth of the river which was supposed to feed Palus\r\nMaeotis, was represented among them. Their preparations had been with\r\nthe greatest secrecy. The first known of them was their appearance off\r\nthe entrance to the Thracian Bosphorus, followed by the destruction of\r\nthe fleet in station there. Thence to the outlet of the Hellespont\r\neverything afloat had fallen their prey. There were quite sixty galleys\r\nin the squadron, all well manned and supplied. A few were biremes, the\r\nrest stout triremes. A Greek was in command, and the pilots, said to be\r\nfamiliar with all the Eastern seas, were Greek. The plunder had been\r\nincalculable. The panic, consequently, was not on the sea alone;\r\ncities, with closed gates, sent their people nightly to the walls.\r\nTraffic had almost ceased.\r\n\r\nWhere were the pirates now?\r\n\r\nTo this question, of most interest to Arrius, he received answer.\r\n\r\nAfter sacking Hephaestia, on the island of Lemnos, the enemy had\r\ncoursed across to the Thessalian group, and, by last account,\r\ndisappeared in the gulfs between Euboea and Hellas.\r\n\r\nSuch were the tidings.\r\n\r\nThen the people of the island, drawn to the hill-tops by the rare\r\nspectacle of a hundred ships careering in united squadron, beheld the\r\nadvance division suddenly turn to the north, and the others follow,\r\nwheeling upon the same point like cavalry in a column. News of the\r\npiratical descent had reached them, and now, watching the white sails\r\nuntil they faded from sight up between Rhene and Syros, the thoughtful\r\namong them took comfort, and were grateful. What Rome seized with\r\nstrong hand she always defended: in return for their taxes, she gave\r\nthem safety.\r\n\r\nThe tribune was more than pleased with the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s movements; he was\r\ndoubly thankful to Fortune. She had brought swift and sure\r\nintelligence, and had lured his foes into the waters where, of all\r\nothers, destruction was most assured. He knew the havoc one galley\r\ncould play in a broad sea like the Mediterranean, and the difficulty of\r\nfinding and overhauling her; he knew, also, how those very\r\ncircumstances would enhance the service and glory if, at one blow, he\r\ncould put a finish to the whole piratical array.\r\n\r\nIf the reader will take a map of Greece and the \xc3\x86gean, he will notice\r\nthe island of Euboea lying along the classic coast like a rampart\r\nagainst Asia, leaving a channel between it and the continent quite a\r\nhundred and twenty miles in length, and scarcely an average of eight in\r\nwidth. The inlet on the north had admitted the fleet of Xerxes, and now\r\nit received the bold raiders from the Euxine. The towns along the\r\nPelasgic and Meliac gulfs were rich and their plunder seductive. All\r\nthings considered, therefore, Arrius judged that the robbers might be\r\nfound somewhere below Thermopylae. Welcoming the chance, he resolved to\r\nenclose them north and south, to do which not an hour could be lost;\r\neven the fruits and wines and women of Naxos must be left behind. So he\r\nsailed away without stop or tack until, a little before nightfall,\r\nMount Ocha was seen upreared against the sky, and the pilot reported\r\nthe Euboean coast.\r\n\r\nAt a signal the fleet rested upon its oars. When the movement was\r\nresumed, Arrius led a division of fifty of the galleys, intending to\r\ntake them up the channel, while another division, equally strong,\r\nturned their prows to the outer or seaward side of the island, with\r\norders to make all haste to the upper inlet, and descend sweeping the\r\nwaters.\r\n\r\nTo be sure, neither division was equal in number to the pirates; but\r\neach had advantages in compensation, among them, by no means least, a\r\ndiscipline impossible to a lawless horde, however brave. Besides, it\r\nwas a shrewd count on the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s side, if, peradventure, one should\r\nbe defeated, the other would find the enemy shattered by his victory,\r\nand in condition to be easily overwhelmed.\r\n\r\nMeantime Ben-Hur kept his bench, relieved every six hours. The rest in\r\nthe Bay of Antemona had freshened him, so that the oar was not\r\ntroublesome, and the chief on the platform found no fault.\r\n\r\nPeople, generally, are not aware of the ease of mind there is in\r\nknowing where they are, and where they are going. The sensation of\r\nbeing lost is a keen distress; still worse is the feeling one has in\r\ndriving blindly into unknown places. Custom had dulled the feeling with\r\nBen-Hur, but only measurably. Pulling away hour after hour, sometimes\r\ndays and nights together, sensible all the time that the galley was\r\ngliding swiftly along some of the many tracks of the broad sea, the\r\nlonging to know where he was, and whither going, was always present\r\nwith him; but now it seemed quickened by the hope which had come to new\r\nlife in his breast since the interview with the tribune. The narrower\r\nthe abiding-place happens to be, the more intense is the longing; and\r\nso he found. He seemed to hear every sound of the ship in labor, and\r\nlistened to each one as if it were a voice come to tell him something;\r\nhe looked to the grating overhead, and through it into the light of\r\nwhich so small a portion was his, expecting, he knew not what; and many\r\ntimes he caught himself on the point of yielding to the impulse to\r\nspeak to the chief on the platform, than which no circumstance of\r\nbattle would have astonished that dignitary more.\r\n\r\nIn his long service, by watching the shifting of the meager sunbeams\r\nupon the cabin floor when the ship was under way, he had come to know,\r\ngenerally, the quarter into which she was sailing. This, of course, was\r\nonly of clear days like those good-fortune was sending the tribune. The\r\nexperience had not failed him in the period succeeding the departure\r\nfrom Cythera. Thinking they were tending towards the old Judean\r\ncountry, he was sensitive to every variation from the course. With a\r\npang, he had observed the sudden change northward which, as has been\r\nnoticed, took place near Naxos: the cause, however, he could not even\r\nconjecture; for it must be remembered that, in common with his\r\nfellow-slaves, he knew nothing of the situation, and had no interest in\r\nthe voyage. His place was at the oar, and he was held there inexorably,\r\nwhether at anchor or under sail. Once only in three years had he been\r\npermitted an outlook from the deck. The occasion we have seen. He had\r\nno idea that, following the vessel he was helping drive, there was a\r\ngreat squadron close at hand and in beautiful order; no more did he\r\nknow the object of which it was in pursuit.\r\n\r\nWhen the sun, going down, withdrew his last ray from the cabin, the\r\ngalley still held northward. Night fell, yet Ben-Hur could discern no\r\nchange. About that time the smell of incense floated down the gangways\r\nfrom the deck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe tribune is at the altar,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cCan it be we are going into\r\nbattle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe became observant.\r\n\r\nNow he had been in many battles without having seen one. From his bench\r\nhe had heard them above and about him, until he was familiar with all\r\ntheir notes, almost as a singer with a song. So, too, he had become\r\nacquainted with many of the preliminaries of an engagement, of which,\r\nwith a Roman as well as a Greek, the most invariable was the sacrifice\r\nto the gods. The rites were the same as those performed at the\r\nbeginning of a voyage, and to him, when noticed, they were always an\r\nadmonition.\r\n\r\nA battle, it should be observed, possessed for him and his\r\nfellow-slaves of the oar an interest unlike that of the sailor and\r\nmarine; it came, not of the danger encountered but of the fact that\r\ndefeat, if survived, might bring an alteration of condition\xe2\x80\x94possibly\r\nfreedom\xe2\x80\x94at least a change of masters, which might be for the better.\r\n\r\nIn good time the lanterns were lighted and hung by the stairs, and the\r\ntribune came down from the deck. At his word the marines put on their\r\narmor. At his word again, the machines were looked to, and spears,\r\njavelins, and arrows, in great sheaves, brought and laid upon the\r\nfloor, together with jars of inflammable oil, and baskets of cotton\r\nballs wound loose like the wicking of candles. And when, finally,\r\nBen-Hur saw the tribune mount his platform and don his armor, and get\r\nhis helmet and shield out, the meaning of the preparations might not be\r\nany longer doubted, and he made ready for the last ignominy of his\r\nservice.\r\n\r\nTo every bench, as a fixture, there was a chain with heavy anklets.\r\nThese the hortator proceeded to lock upon the oarsmen, going from\r\nnumber to number, leaving no choice but to obey, and, in event of\r\ndisaster, no possibility of escape.\r\n\r\nIn the cabin, then, a silence fell, broken, at first, only by the sough\r\nof the oars turning in the leathern cases. Every man upon the benches\r\nfelt the shame, Ben-Hur more keenly than his companions. He would have\r\nput it away at any price. Soon the clanking of the fetters notified him\r\nof the progress the chief was making in his round. He would come to him\r\nin turn; but would not the tribune interpose for him?\r\n\r\nThe thought may be set down to vanity or selfishness, as the reader\r\npleases; it certainly, at that moment, took possession of Ben-Hur. He\r\nbelieved the Roman would interpose; anyhow, the circumstance would test\r\nthe man\xe2\x80\x99s feelings. If, intent upon the battle, he would but think of\r\nhim, it would be proof of his opinion formed\xe2\x80\x94proof that he had been\r\ntacitly promoted above his associates in misery\xe2\x80\x94such proof as would\r\njustify hope.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur waited anxiously. The interval seemed like an age. At every\r\nturn of the oar he looked towards the tribune, who, his simple\r\npreparations made, lay down upon the couch and composed himself to\r\nrest; whereupon number sixty chid himself, and laughed grimly, and\r\nresolved not to look that way again.\r\n\r\nThe hortator approached. Now he was at number one\xe2\x80\x94the rattle of the\r\niron links sounded horribly. At last number sixty! Calm from despair,\r\nBen-Hur held his oar at poise, and gave his foot to the officer. Then\r\nthe tribune stirred\xe2\x80\x94sat up\xe2\x80\x94beckoned to the chief.\r\n\r\nA strong revulsion seized the Jew. From the hortator, the great man\r\nglanced at him; and when he dropped his oar all the section of the ship\r\non his side seemed aglow. He heard nothing of what was said; enough\r\nthat the chain hung idly from its staple in the bench, and that the\r\nchief, going to his seat, began to beat the sounding-board. The notes\r\nof the gavel were never so like music. With his breast against the\r\nleaded handle, he pushed with all his might\xe2\x80\x94pushed until the shaft bent\r\nas if about to break.\r\n\r\nThe chief went to the tribune, and, smiling, pointed to number sixty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat strength!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what spirit!\xe2\x80\x9d the tribune answered. \xe2\x80\x9cPerpol! He is better without\r\nthe irons. Put them on him no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he stretched himself upon the couch again.\r\n\r\nThe ship sailed on hour after hour under the oars in water scarcely\r\nrippled by the wind. And the people not on duty slept, Arrius in his\r\nplace, the marines on the floor.\r\n\r\nOnce\xe2\x80\x94twice\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur was relieved; but he could not sleep. Three years of\r\nnight, and through the darkness a sunbeam at last! At sea adrift and\r\nlost, and now land! Dead so long, and, lo! the thrill and stir of\r\nresurrection. Sleep was not for such an hour. Hope deals with the\r\nfuture; now and the past are but servants that wait on her with impulse\r\nand suggestive circumstance. Starting from the favor of the tribune,\r\nshe carried him forward indefinitely. The wonder is, not that things so\r\npurely imaginative as the results she points us to can make us so\r\nhappy, but that we can receive them as so real. They must be as\r\ngorgeous poppies under the influence of which, under the crimson and\r\npurple and gold, reason lies down the while, and is not. Sorrows\r\nassuaged, home and the fortunes of his house restored; mother and\r\nsister in his arms once more\xe2\x80\x94such were the central ideas which made him\r\nhappier that moment than he had ever been. That he was rushing, as on\r\nwings, into horrible battle had, for the time, nothing to do with his\r\nthoughts. The things thus in hope were unmixed with doubts\xe2\x80\x94they WERE.\r\nHence his joy so full, so perfect, there was no room in his heart for\r\nrevenge. Messala, Gratus, Rome, and all the bitter, passionate memories\r\nconnected with them, were as dead plagues\xe2\x80\x94miasms of the earth above\r\nwhich he floated, far and safe, listening to singing stars.\r\n\r\nThe deeper darkness before the dawn was upon the waters, and all things\r\ngoing well with the Astroea, when a man, descending from the deck,\r\nwalked swiftly to the platform where the tribune slept, and awoke him.\r\nArrius arose, put on his helmet, sword, and shield, and went to the\r\ncommander of the marines.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe pirates are close by. Up and ready!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and passed to the\r\nstairs, calm, confident, insomuch that one might have thought, \xe2\x80\x9cHappy\r\nfellow! Apicius has set a feast for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nEvery soul aboard, even the ship, awoke. Officers went to their\r\nquarters. The marines took arms, and were led out, looking in all\r\nrespects like legionaries. Sheaves of arrows and armfuls of javelins\r\nwere carried on deck. By the central stairs the oil-tanks and\r\nfire-balls were set ready for use. Additional lanterns were lighted.\r\nBuckets were filled with water. The rowers in relief assembled under\r\nguard in front of the chief. As Providence would have it, Ben-Hur was\r\none of the latter. Overhead he heard the muffled noises of the final\r\npreparations\xe2\x80\x94of the sailors furling sail, spreading the nettings,\r\nunslinging the machines, and hanging the armor of bull-hide over the\r\nside. Presently quiet settled about the galley again; quiet full of\r\nvague dread and expectation, which, interpreted, means READY.\r\n\r\nAt a signal passed down from the deck, and communicated to the hortator\r\nby a petty officer stationed on the stairs, all at once the oars\r\nstopped.\r\n\r\nWhat did it mean?\r\n\r\nOf the hundred and twenty slaves chained to the benches, not one but\r\nasked himself the question. They were without incentive. Patriotism,\r\nlove of honor, sense of duty, brought them no inspiration. They felt\r\nthe thrill common to men rushed helpless and blind into danger. It may\r\nbe supposed the dullest of them, poising his oar, thought of all that\r\nmight happen, yet could promise himself nothing; for victory would but\r\nrivet his chains the firmer, while the chances of the ship were his;\r\nsinking or on fire, he was doomed to her fate.\r\n\r\nOf the situation without they might not ask. And who were the enemy?\r\nAnd what if they were friends, brethren, countrymen? The reader,\r\ncarrying the suggestion forward, will see the necessity which governed\r\nthe Roman when, in such emergencies, he locked the hapless wretches to\r\ntheir seats.\r\n\r\nThere was little time, however, for such thought with them. A sound\r\nlike the rowing of galleys astern attracted Ben-Hur, and the Astroea\r\nrocked as if in the midst of countering waves. The idea of a fleet at\r\nhand broke upon him\xe2\x80\x94a fleet in manoeuvre\xe2\x80\x94forming probably for attack.\r\nHis blood started with the fancy.\r\n\r\nAnother signal came down from the deck. The oars dipped, and the galley\r\nstarted imperceptibly. No sound from without, none from within, yet\r\neach man in the cabin instinctively poised himself for a shock; the\r\nvery ship seemed to catch the sense, and hold its breath, and go\r\ncrouched tiger-like.\r\n\r\nIn such a situation time is inappreciable; so that Ben-Hur could form\r\nno judgment of distance gone. At last there was a sound of trumpets on\r\ndeck, full, clear, long blown. The chief beat the sounding-board until\r\nit rang; the rowers reached forward full length, and, deepening the dip\r\nof their oars, pulled suddenly with all their united force. The galley,\r\nquivering in every timber, answered with a leap. Other trumpets joined\r\nin the clamor\xe2\x80\x94all from the rear, none forward\xe2\x80\x94from the latter quarter\r\nonly a rising sound of voices in tumult heard briefly. There was a\r\nmighty blow; the rowers in front of the chief\xe2\x80\x99s platform reeled, some\r\nof them fell; the ship bounded back, recovered, and rushed on more\r\nirresistibly than before. Shrill and high arose the shrieks of men in\r\nterror; over the blare of trumpets, and the grind and crash of the\r\ncollision, they arose; then under his feet, under the keel, pounding,\r\nrumbling, breaking to pieces, drowning, Ben-Hur felt something\r\noverridden. The men about him looked at each other afraid. A shout of\r\ntriumph from the deck\xe2\x80\x94the beak of the Roman had won! But who were they\r\nwhom the sea had drunk? Of what tongue, from what land were they?\r\n\r\nNo pause, no stay! Forward rushed the Astroea; and, as it went, some\r\nsailors ran down, and plunging the cotton balls into the oil-tanks,\r\ntossed them dripping to comrades at the head of the stairs: fire was to\r\nbe added to other horrors of the combat.\r\n\r\nDirectly the galley heeled over so far that the oarsmen on the\r\nuppermost side with difficulty kept their benches. Again the hearty\r\nRoman cheer, and with it despairing shrieks. An opposing vessel, caught\r\nby the grappling-hooks of the great crane swinging from the prow, was\r\nbeing lifted into the air that it might be dropped and sunk.\r\n\r\nThe shouting increased on the right hand and on the left; before,\r\nbehind, swelled an indescribable clamor. Occasionally there was a\r\ncrash, followed by sudden peals of fright, telling of other ships\r\nridden down, and their crews drowned in the vortexes.\r\n\r\nNor was the fight all on one side. Now and then a Roman in armor was\r\nborne down the hatchway, and laid bleeding, sometimes dying, on the\r\nfloor.\r\n\r\nSometimes, also, puffs of smoke, blended with steam, and foul with the\r\nscent of roasting human flesh, poured into the cabin, turning the\r\ndimming light into yellow murk. Gasping for breath the while, Ben-Hur\r\nknew they were passing through the cloud of a ship on fire, and burning\r\nup with the rowers chained to the benches.\r\n\r\nThe Astroea all this time was in motion. Suddenly she stopped. The oars\r\nforward were dashed from the hands of the rowers, and the rowers from\r\ntheir benches. On deck, then, a furious trampling, and on the sides a\r\ngrinding of ships afoul of each other. For the first time the beating\r\nof the gavel was lost in the uproar. Men sank on the floor in fear or\r\nlooked about seeking a hiding-place. In the midst of the panic a body\r\nplunged or was pitched headlong down the hatchway, falling near\r\nBen-Hur. He beheld the half-naked carcass, a mass of hair blackening\r\nthe face, and under it a shield of bull-hide and wicker-work\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nbarbarian from the white-skinned nations of the North whom death had\r\nrobbed of plunder and revenge. How came he there? An iron hand had\r\nsnatched him from the opposing deck\xe2\x80\x94no, the Astroea had been boarded!\r\nThe Romans were fighting on their own deck? A chill smote the young\r\nJew: Arrius was hard pressed\xe2\x80\x94he might be defending his own life. If he\r\nshould be slain! God of Abraham forefend! The hopes and dreams so\r\nlately come, were they only hopes and dreams? Mother and\r\nsister\xe2\x80\x94house\xe2\x80\x94home\xe2\x80\x94Holy Land\xe2\x80\x94was he not to see them, after all? The\r\ntumult thundered above him; he looked around; in the cabin all was\r\nconfusion\xe2\x80\x94the rowers on the benches paralyzed; men running blindly\r\nhither and thither; only the chief on his seat imperturbable, vainly\r\nbeating the sounding-board, and waiting the orders of the tribune\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nthe red murk illustrating the matchless discipline which had won the\r\nworld.\r\n\r\nThe example had a good effect upon Ben-Hur. He controlled himself\r\nenough to think. Honor and duty bound the Roman to the platform; but\r\nwhat had he to do with such motives then? The bench was a thing to run\r\nfrom; while, if he were to die a slave, who would be the better of the\r\nsacrifice? With him living was duty, if not honor. His life belonged to\r\nhis people. They arose before him never more real: he saw them, their\r\narms outstretched; he heard them imploring him. And he would go to\r\nthem. He started\xe2\x80\x94stopped. Alas! a Roman judgment held him in doom.\r\nWhile it endured, escape would be profitless. In the wide, wide earth\r\nthere was no place in which he would be safe from the imperial demand;\r\nupon the land none, nor upon the sea. Whereas he required freedom\r\naccording to the forms of law, so only could he abide in Judea and\r\nexecute the filial purpose to which he would devote himself: in other\r\nland he would not live. Dear God! How he had waited and watched and\r\nprayed for such a release! And how it had been delayed! But at last he\r\nhad seen it in the promise of the tribune. What else the great man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmeaning? And if the benefactor so belated should now be slain! The dead\r\ncome not back to redeem the pledges of the living. It should not\r\nbe\xe2\x80\x94Arrius should not die. At least, better perish with him than survive\r\na galley-slave.\r\n\r\nOnce more Ben-Hur looked around. Upon the roof of the cabin the battle\r\nyet beat; against the sides the hostile vessels yet crushed and grided.\r\nOn the benches, the slaves struggled to tear loose from their chains,\r\nand, finding their efforts vain, howled like madmen; the guards had\r\ngone upstairs; discipline was out, panic in. No, the chief kept his\r\nchair, unchanged, calm as ever\xe2\x80\x94except the gavel, weaponless. Vainly\r\nwith his clangor he filled the lulls in the din. Ben-Hur gave him a\r\nlast look, then broke away\xe2\x80\x94not in flight, but to seek the tribune.\r\n\r\nA very short space lay between him and the stairs of the hatchway aft.\r\nHe took it with a leap, and was half-way up the steps\xe2\x80\x94up far enough to\r\ncatch a glimpse of the sky blood-red with fire, of the ships alongside,\r\nof the sea covered with ships and wrecks, of the fight closed in about\r\nthe pilot\xe2\x80\x99s quarter, the assailants many, the defenders few\xe2\x80\x94when\r\nsuddenly his foothold was knocked away, and he pitched backward. The\r\nfloor, when he reached it, seemed to be lifting itself and breaking to\r\npieces; then, in a twinkling, the whole after-part of the hull broke\r\nasunder, and, as if it had all the time been lying in wait, the sea,\r\nhissing and foaming, leaped in, and all became darkness and surging\r\nwater to Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nIt cannot be said that the young Jew helped himself in this stress.\r\nBesides his usual strength, he had the indefinite extra force which\r\nnature keeps in reserve for just such perils to life; yet the darkness,\r\nand the whirl and roar of water, stupefied him. Even the holding his\r\nbreath was involuntary.\r\n\r\nThe influx of the flood tossed him like a log forward into the cabin,\r\nwhere he would have drowned but for the refluence of the sinking\r\nmotion. As it was, fathoms under the surface the hollow mass vomited\r\nhim forth, and he arose along with the loosed debris. In the act of\r\nrising, he clutched something, and held to it. The time he was under\r\nseemed an age longer than it really was; at last he gained the top;\r\nwith a great gasp he filled his lungs afresh, and, tossing the water\r\nfrom his hair and eyes, climbed higher upon the plank he held, and\r\nlooked about him.\r\n\r\nDeath had pursued him closely under the waves; he found it waiting for\r\nhim when he was risen\xe2\x80\x94waiting multiform.\r\n\r\nSmoke lay upon the sea like a semitransparent fog, through which here\r\nand there shone cores of intense brilliance. A quick intelligence told\r\nhim that they were ships on fire. The battle was yet on; nor could he\r\nsay who was victor. Within the radius of his vision now and then ships\r\npassed, shooting shadows athwart lights. Out of the dun clouds farther\r\non he caught the crash of other ships colliding. The danger, however,\r\nwas closer at hand. When the Astroea went down, her deck, it will be\r\nrecollected, held her own crew, and the crews of the two galleys which\r\nhad attacked her at the same time, all of whom were ingulfed. Many of\r\nthem came to the surface together, and on the same plank or support of\r\nwhatever kind continued the combat, begun possibly in the vortex\r\nfathoms down. Writhing and twisting in deadly embrace, sometimes\r\nstriking with sword or javelin, they kept the sea around them in\r\nagitation, at one place inky-black, at another aflame with fiery\r\nreflections. With their struggles he had nothing to do; they were all\r\nhis enemies: not one of them but would kill him for the plank upon\r\nwhich he floated. He made haste to get away.\r\n\r\nAbout that time he heard oars in quickest movement, and beheld a galley\r\ncoming down upon him. The tall prow seemed doubly tall, and the red\r\nlight playing upon its gilt and carving gave it an appearance of snaky\r\nlife. Under its foot the water churned to flying foam.\r\n\r\nHe struck out, pushing the plank, which was very broad and\r\nunmanageable. Seconds were precious\xe2\x80\x94half a second might save or lose\r\nhim. In the crisis of the effort, up from the sea, within arm\xe2\x80\x99s reach,\r\na helmet shot like a gleam of gold. Next came two hands with fingers\r\nextended\xe2\x80\x94large hands were they, and strong\xe2\x80\x94their hold once fixed, might\r\nnot be loosed. Ben-Hur swerved from them appalled. Up rose the helmet\r\nand the head it encased\xe2\x80\x94then two arms, which began to beat the water\r\nwildly\xe2\x80\x94the head turned back, and gave the face to the light. The mouth\r\ngaping wide; the eyes open, but sightless, and the bloodless pallor of\r\na drowning man\xe2\x80\x94never anything more ghastly! Yet he gave a cry of joy at\r\nthe sight, and as the face was going under again, he caught the\r\nsufferer by the chain which passed from the helmet beneath the chin,\r\nand drew him to the plank.\r\n\r\nThe man was Arrius, the tribune.\r\n\r\nFor a while the water foamed and eddied violently about Ben-Hur, taxing\r\nall his strength to hold to the support and at the same time keep the\r\nRoman\xe2\x80\x99s head above the surface. The galley had passed, leaving the two\r\nbarely outside the stroke of its oars. Right through the floating men,\r\nover heads helmeted as well as heads bare, she drove, in her wake\r\nnothing but the sea sparkling with fire. A muffled crash, succeeded by\r\na great outcry, made the rescuer look again from his charge. A certain\r\nsavage pleasure touched his heart\xe2\x80\x94the Astroea was avenged.\r\n\r\nAfter that the battle moved on. Resistance turned to flight. But who\r\nwere the victors? Ben-Hur was sensible how much his freedom and the\r\nlife of the tribune depended upon that event. He pushed the plank under\r\nthe latter until it floated him, after which all his care was to keep\r\nhim there. The dawn came slowly. He watched its growing hopefully, yet\r\nsometimes afraid. Would it bring the Romans or the pirates? If the\r\npirates, his charge was lost.\r\n\r\nAt last morning broke in full, the air without a breath. Off to the\r\nleft he saw the land, too far to think of attempting to make it. Here\r\nand there men were adrift like himself. In spots the sea was blackened\r\nby charred and sometimes smoking fragments. A galley up a long way was\r\nlying to with a torn sail hanging from the tilted yard, and the oars\r\nall idle. Still farther away he could discern moving specks, which he\r\nthought might be ships in flight or pursuit, or they might be white\r\nbirds a-wing.\r\n\r\nAn hour passed thus. His anxiety increased. If relief came not\r\nspeedily, Arrius would die. Sometimes he seemed already dead, he lay so\r\nstill. He took the helmet off, and then, with greater difficulty, the\r\ncuirass; the heart he found fluttering. He took hope at the sign, and\r\nheld on. There was nothing to do but wait, and, after the manner of his\r\npeople, pray.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe throes of recovery from drowning are more painful than the\r\ndrowning. These Arrius passed through, and, at length, to Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndelight, reached the point of speech.\r\n\r\nGradually, from incoherent questions as to where he was, and by whom\r\nand how he had been saved, he reverted to the battle. The doubt of the\r\nvictory stimulated his faculties to full return, a result aided not a\r\nlittle by a long rest\xe2\x80\x94such as could be had on their frail support.\r\nAfter a while he became talkative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur rescue, I see, depends upon the result of the fight. I see also\r\nwhat thou hast done for me. To speak fairly, thou hast saved my life at\r\nthe risk of thy own. I make the acknowledgment broadly; and, whatever\r\ncometh, thou hast my thanks. More than that, if fortune doth but serve\r\nme kindly, and we get well out of this peril, I will do thee such favor\r\nas becometh a Roman who hath power and opportunity to prove his\r\ngratitude. Yet, yet it is to be seen if, with thy good intent, thou\r\nhast really done me a kindness; or, rather, speaking to thy\r\ngood-will\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he hesitated\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI would exact of thee a promise to do me, in a\r\ncertain event, the greatest favor one man can do another\xe2\x80\x94and of that\r\nlet me have thy pledge now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the thing be not forbidden, I will do it,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied.\r\n\r\nArrius rested again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou, indeed, a son of Hur, the Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d he next asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as I have said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew thy father\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah drew himself nearer, for the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s voice was weak\xe2\x80\x94he drew\r\nnearer, and listened eagerly\xe2\x80\x94at last he thought to hear of home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew him, and loved him,\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius continued.\r\n\r\nThere was another pause, during which something diverted the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt cannot be,\xe2\x80\x9d he proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cthat thou, a son of his, hast not heard\r\nof Cato and Brutus. They were very great men, and never as great as in\r\ndeath. In their dying, they left this law\xe2\x80\x94A Roman may not survive his\r\ngood-fortune. Art thou listening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a custom of gentlemen in Rome to wear a ring. There is one on my\r\nhand. Take it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe held the hand to Judah, who did as he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow put it on thine own hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe trinket hath its uses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arrius next. \xe2\x80\x9cI have property and\r\nmoney. I am accounted rich even in Rome. I have no family. Show the\r\nring to my freedman, who hath control in my absence; you will find him\r\nin a villa near Misenum. Tell him how it came to thee, and ask\r\nanything, or all he may have; he will not refuse the demand. If I live,\r\nI will do better by thee. I will make thee free, and restore thee to\r\nthy home and people; or thou mayst give thyself to the pursuit that\r\npleaseth thee most. Dost thou hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could not choose but hear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen pledge me. By the gods\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, good tribune, I am a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy thy God, then, or in the form most sacred to those of thy\r\nfaith\xe2\x80\x94pledge me to do what I tell thee now, and as I tell thee; I am\r\nwaiting, let me have thy promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoble Arrius, I am warned by thy manner to expect something of gravest\r\nconcern. Tell me thy wish first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilt thou promise then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat were to give the pledge, and\xe2\x80\x94 Blessed be the God of my fathers!\r\nyonder cometh a ship!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what direction?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the north.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCanst thou tell her nationality by outward signs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. My service hath been at the oars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHath she a flag?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot see one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius remained quiet some time, apparently in deep reflection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes the ship hold this way yet?\xe2\x80\x9d he at length asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook for the flag now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe hath none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor any other sign?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe hath a sail set, and is of three banks, and cometh swiftly\xe2\x80\x94that is\r\nall I can say of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Roman in triumph would have out many flags. She must be an enemy.\r\nHear now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Arrius, becoming grave again, \xe2\x80\x9chear, while yet I may\r\nspeak. If the galley be a pirate, thy life is safe; they may not give\r\nthee freedom; they may put thee to the oar again; but they will not\r\nkill thee. On the other hand, I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune faltered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerpol!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, resolutely. \xe2\x80\x9cI am too old to submit to\r\ndishonor. In Rome, let them tell how Quintus Arrius, as became a Roman\r\ntribune, went down with his ship in the midst of the foe. This is what\r\nI would have thee do. If the galley prove a pirate, push me from the\r\nplank and drown me. Dost thou hear? Swear thou wilt do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not swear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, firmly; \xe2\x80\x9cneither will I do the deed.\r\nThe Law, which is to me most binding, O tribune, would make me\r\nanswerable for thy life. Take back the ring\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he took the seal from his\r\nfinger\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctake it back, and all thy promises of favor in the event of\r\ndelivery from this peril. The judgment which sent me to the oar for\r\nlife made me a slave, yet I am not a slave; no more am I thy freedman.\r\nI am a son of Israel, and this moment, at least, my own master. Take\r\nback the ring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nArrius remained passive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou wilt not?\xe2\x80\x9d Judah continued. \xe2\x80\x9cNot in anger, then, nor in any\r\ndespite, but to free myself from a hateful obligation, I will give thy\r\ngift to the sea. See, O tribune!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tossed the ring away. Arrius heard the splash where it struck and\r\nsank, though he did not look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast done a foolish thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cfoolish for one placed as\r\nthou art. I am not dependent upon thee for death. Life is a thread I\r\ncan break without thy help; and, if I do, what will become of thee? Men\r\ndetermined on death prefer it at the hands of others, for the reason\r\nthat the soul which Plato giveth us is rebellious at the thought of\r\nself-destruction; that is all. If the ship be a pirate, I will escape\r\nfrom the world. My mind is fixed. I am a Roman. Success and honor are\r\nall in all. Yet I would have served thee; thou wouldst not. The ring\r\nwas the only witness of my will available in this situation. We are\r\nboth lost. I will die regretting the victory and glory wrested from me;\r\nthou wilt live to die a little later, mourning the pious duties undone\r\nbecause of this folly. I pity thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur saw the consequences of his act more distinctly than before,\r\nyet he did not falter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the three years of my servitude, O tribune, thou wert the first to\r\nlook upon me kindly. No, no! There was another.\xe2\x80\x9d The voice dropped, the\r\neyes became humid, and he saw plainly as if it were then before him the\r\nface of the boy who helped him to a drink by the old well at Nazareth.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least,\xe2\x80\x9d he proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cthou wert the first to ask me who I was; and\r\nif, when I reached out and caught thee, blind and sinking the last\r\ntime, I, too, had thought of the many ways in which thou couldst be\r\nuseful to me in my wretchedness, still the act was not all selfish;\r\nthis I pray you to believe. Moreover, seeing as God giveth me to know,\r\nthe ends I dream of are to be wrought by fair means alone. As a thing\r\nof conscience, I would rather die with thee than be thy slayer. My mind\r\nis firmly set as thine; though thou wert to offer me all Rome, O\r\ntribune, and it belonged to thee to make the gift good, I would not\r\nkill thee. Thy Cato and Brutus were as little children compared to the\r\nHebrew whose law a Jew must obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut my request. Hast\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy command would be of more weight, and that would not move me. I\r\nhave said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth became silent, waiting.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked often at the coming ship. Arrius rested with closed\r\neyes, indifferent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou sure she is an enemy?\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe stops, and puts a boat over the side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDost thou see her flag?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there no other sign by which she may be known if Roman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Roman, she hath a helmet over the mast\xe2\x80\x99s top.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen be of cheer. I see the helmet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill Arrius was not assured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe men in the small boat are taking in the people afloat. Pirates are\r\nnot humane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may need rowers,\xe2\x80\x9d Arrius replied, recurring, possibly, to times\r\nwhen he had made rescues for the purpose.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was very watchful of the actions of the strangers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ship moves off,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver on our right there is a galley which I take to be deserted. The\r\nnew-comer heads towards it. Now she is alongside. Now she is sending\r\nmen aboard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Arrius opened his eyes and threw off his calm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank thou thy God,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Ben-Hur, after a look at the galleys,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthank thou thy God, as I do my many gods. A pirate would sink, not\r\nsave, yon ship. By the act and the helmet on the mast I know a Roman.\r\nThe victory is mine. Fortune hath not deserted me. We are saved. Wave\r\nthy hand\xe2\x80\x94call to them\xe2\x80\x94bring them quickly. I shall be duumvir, and thou!\r\nI knew thy father, and loved him. He was a prince indeed. He taught me\r\na Jew was not a barbarian. I will take thee with me. I will make thee\r\nmy son. Give thy God thanks, and call the sailors. Haste! The pursuit\r\nmust be kept. Not a robber shall escape. Hasten them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah raised himself upon the plank, and waved his hand, and called\r\nwith all his might; at last he drew the attention of the sailors in the\r\nsmall boat, and they were speedily taken up.\r\n\r\nArrius was received on the galley with all the honors due a hero so the\r\nfavorite of Fortune. Upon a couch on the deck he heard the particulars\r\nof the conclusion of the fight. When the survivors afloat upon the\r\nwater were all saved and the prize secured, he spread his flag of\r\ncommandant anew, and hurried northward to rejoin the fleet and perfect\r\nthe victory. In due time the fifty vessels coming down the channel\r\nclosed in upon the fugitive pirates, and crushed them utterly; not one\r\nescaped. To swell the tribune\xe2\x80\x99s glory, twenty galleys of the enemy were\r\ncaptured.\r\n\r\nUpon his return from the cruise, Arrius had warm welcome on the mole at\r\nMisenum. The young man attending him very early attracted the attention\r\nof his friends there; and to their questions as to who he was the\r\ntribune proceeded in the most affectionate manner to tell the story of\r\nhis rescue and introduce the stranger, omitting carefully all that\r\npertained to the latter\xe2\x80\x99s previous history. At the end of the\r\nnarrative, he called Ben-Hur to him, and said, with a hand resting\r\naffectionately upon his shoulder,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood friends, this is my son and heir, who, as he is to take my\r\nproperty\xe2\x80\x94if it be the will of the gods that I leave any\xe2\x80\x94shall be known\r\nto you by my name. I pray you all to love him as you love me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSpeedily as opportunity permitted, the adoption was formally perfected.\r\nAnd in such manner the brave Roman kept his faith with Ben-Hur, giving\r\nhim happy introduction into the imperial world. The month succeeding\r\nArrius\xe2\x80\x99s return, the armilustrium was celebrated with the utmost\r\nmagnificence in the theater of Scaurus. One side of the structure was\r\ntaken up with military trophies; among which by far the most\r\nconspicuous and most admired were twenty prows, complemented by their\r\ncorresponding aplustra, cut bodily from as many galleys; and over them,\r\nso as to be legible to the eighty thousand spectators in the seats, was\r\nthis inscription:\r\n\r\nTAKEN FROM THE PIRATES IN THE GULF OF EURIPUS,\r\nBY\r\nQUINTUS ARRIUS,\r\nDUUMVIR.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK FOURTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlva. Should the monarch prove unjust\xe2\x80\x94\r\nAnd, at this time\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nQueen. Then I must wait for justice\r\nUntil it come; and they are happiest far\r\nWhose consciences may calmly wait their right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                    Schiller, Don Carlos (act iv., sc. xv.)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThe month to which we now come is July, the year that of our Lord 29,\r\nand the place Antioch, then Queen of the East, and next to Rome the\r\nstrongest, if not the most populous, city in the world.\r\n\r\nThere is an opinion that the extravagance and dissoluteness of the age\r\nhad their origin in Rome, and spread thence throughout the empire; that\r\nthe great cities but reflected the manners of their mistress on the\r\nTiber. This may be doubted. The reaction of the conquest would seem to\r\nhave been upon the morals of the conqueror. In Greece she found a\r\nspring of corruption; so also in Egypt; and the student, having\r\nexhausted the subject, will close the books assured that the flow of\r\nthe demoralizing river was from the East westwardly, and that this very\r\ncity of Antioch, one of the oldest seats of Assyrian power and\r\nsplendor, was a principal source of the deadly stream.\r\n\r\nA transport galley entered the mouth of the river Orontes from the blue\r\nwaters of the sea. It was in the forenoon. The heat was great, yet all\r\non board who could avail themselves of the privilege were on\r\ndeck\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur among others.\r\n\r\nThe five years had brought the young Jew to perfect manhood. Though the\r\nrobe of white linen in which he was attired somewhat masked his form,\r\nhis appearance was unusually attractive. For an hour and more he had\r\noccupied a seat in the shade of the sail, and in that time several\r\nfellow-passengers of his own nationality had tried to engage him in\r\nconversation, but without avail. His replies to their questions had\r\nbeen brief, though gravely courteous, and in the Latin tongue. The\r\npurity of his speech, his cultivated manners, his reticence, served to\r\nstimulate their curiosity the more. Such as observed him closely were\r\nstruck by an incongruity between his demeanor, which had the ease and\r\ngrace of a patrician, and certain points of his person. Thus his arms\r\nwere disproportionately long; and when, to steady himself against the\r\nmotion of the vessel, he took hold of anything near by, the size of his\r\nhands and their evident power compelled remark; so the wonder who and\r\nwhat he was mixed continually with a wish to know the particulars of\r\nhis life. In other words, his air cannot be better described than as a\r\nnotice\xe2\x80\x94This man has a story to tell.\r\n\r\nThe galley, in coming, had stopped at one of the ports of Cyprus, and\r\npicked up a Hebrew of most respectable appearance, quiet, reserved,\r\npaternal. Ben-Hur ventured to ask him some questions; the replies won\r\nhis confidence, and resulted finally in an extended conversation.\r\n\r\nIt chanced also that as the galley from Cyprus entered the receiving\r\nbay of the Orontes, two other vessels which had been sighted out in the\r\nsea met it and passed into the river at the same time; and as they did\r\nso both the strangers threw out small flags of brightest yellow. There\r\nwas much conjecture as to the meaning of the signals. At length a\r\npassenger addressed himself to the respectable Hebrew for information\r\nupon the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know the meaning of the flags,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied; \xe2\x80\x9cthey do not\r\nsignify nationality\xe2\x80\x94they are merely marks of ownership.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas the owner many ships?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have dealt with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe passengers looked at the speaker as if requesting him to go on.\r\nBen-Hur listened with interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives in Antioch,\xe2\x80\x9d the Hebrew continued, in his quiet way. \xe2\x80\x9cThat he\r\nis vastly rich has brought him into notice, and the talk about him is\r\nnot always kind. There used to be in Jerusalem a prince of very ancient\r\nfamily named Hur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah strove to be composed, yet his heart beat quicker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe prince was a merchant, with a genius for business. He set on foot\r\nmany enterprises, some reaching far East, others West. In the great\r\ncities he had branch houses. The one in Antioch was in charge of a man\r\nsaid by some to have been a family servant called Simonides, Greek in\r\nname, yet an Israelite. The master was drowned at sea. His business,\r\nhowever, went on, and was scarcely less prosperous. After a while\r\nmisfortune overtook the family. The prince\xe2\x80\x99s only son, nearly grown,\r\ntried to kill the procurator Gratus in one of the streets of Jerusalem.\r\nHe failed by a narrow chance, and has not since been heard of. In fact,\r\nthe Roman\xe2\x80\x99s rage took in the whole house\xe2\x80\x94not one of the name was left\r\nalive. Their palace was sealed up, and is now a rookery for pigeons;\r\nthe estate was confiscated; everything that could be traced to the\r\nownership of the Hurs was confiscated. The procurator cured his hurt\r\nwith a golden salve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe passengers laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean he kept the property,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say so,\xe2\x80\x9d the Hebrew replied; \xe2\x80\x9cI am only telling a story as I\r\nreceived it. And, to go on, Simonides, who had been the prince\xe2\x80\x99s agent\r\nhere in Antioch, opened trade in a short time on his own account, and\r\nin a space incredibly brief became the master merchant of the city. In\r\nimitation of his master, he sent caravans to India; and on the sea at\r\npresent he has galleys enough to make a royal fleet. They say nothing\r\ngoes amiss with him. His camels do not die, except of old age; his\r\nships never founder; if he throw a chip into the river, it will come\r\nback to him gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long has he been going on thus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot ten years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must have had a good start.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, they say the procurator took only the prince\xe2\x80\x99s property ready at\r\nhand\xe2\x80\x94his horses, cattle, houses, land, vessels, goods. The money could\r\nnot be found, though there must have been vast sums of it. What became\r\nof it has been an unsolved mystery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said a passenger, with a sneer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand you,\xe2\x80\x9d the Hebrew answered. \xe2\x80\x9cOthers have had your idea.\r\nThat it furnished old Simonides his start is a common belief. The\r\nprocurator is of that opinion\xe2\x80\x94or he has been\xe2\x80\x94for twice in five years he\r\nhas caught the merchant, and put him to torture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah gripped the rope he was holding with crushing force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is said,\xe2\x80\x9d the narrator continued, \xe2\x80\x9cthat there is not a sound bone\r\nin the man\xe2\x80\x99s body. The last time I saw him he sat in a chair, a\r\nshapeless cripple, propped against cushions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo tortured!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed several listeners in a breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDisease could not have produced such a deformity. Still the suffering\r\nmade no impression upon him. All he had was his lawfully, and he was\r\nmaking lawful use of it\xe2\x80\x94that was the most they wrung from him. Now,\r\nhowever, he is past persecution. He has a license to trade signed by\r\nTiberius himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe paid roundly for it, I warrant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese ships are his,\xe2\x80\x9d the Hebrew continued, passing the remark. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\na custom among his sailors to salute each other upon meeting by\r\nthrowing out yellow flags, sight of which is as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x98We\r\nhave had a fortunate voyage.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe story ended there.\r\n\r\nWhen the transport was fairly in the channel of the river, Judah spoke\r\nto the Hebrew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the name of the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBen-Hur, Prince of Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat became of the prince\xe2\x80\x99s family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe boy was sent to the galleys. I may say he is dead. One year is the\r\nordinary limit of life under that sentence. The widow and daughter have\r\nnot been heard of; those who know what became of them will not speak.\r\nThey died doubtless in the cells of one of the castles which spot the\r\nwaysides of Judea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJudah walked to the pilot\xe2\x80\x99s quarter. So absorbed was he in thought that\r\nhe scarcely noticed the shores of the river, which from sea to city\r\nwere surpassingly beautiful with orchards of all the Syrian fruits and\r\nvines, clustered about villas rich as those of Neapolis. No more did he\r\nobserve the vessels passing in an endless fleet, nor hear the singing\r\nand shouting of the sailors, some in labor, some in merriment. The sky\r\nwas full of sunlight, lying in hazy warmth upon the land and the water;\r\nnowhere except over his life was there a shadow.\r\n\r\nOnce only he awoke to a momentary interest, and that was when some one\r\npointed out the Grove of Daphne, discernible from a bend in the river.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the city came into view, the passengers were on deck, eager that\r\nnothing of the scene might escape them. The respectable Jew already\r\nintroduced to the reader was the principal spokesman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe river here runs to the west,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in the way of general\r\nanswer. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember when it washed the base of the walls; but as Roman\r\nsubjects we have lived in peace, and, as always happens in such times,\r\ntrade has had its will; now the whole river front is taken up with\r\nwharves and docks. Yonder\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the speaker pointed southward\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cis Mount\r\nCasius, or, as these people love to call it, the Mountains of Orontes,\r\nlooking across to its brother Amnus in the north; and between them lies\r\nthe Plain of Antioch. Farther on are the Black Mountains, whence the\r\nDucts of the Kings bring the purest water to wash the thirsty streets\r\nand people; yet they are forests in wilderness state, dense, and full\r\nof birds and beasts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the lake?\xe2\x80\x9d one asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver north there. You can take horse, if you wish to see it\xe2\x80\x94or,\r\nbetter, a boat, for a tributary connects it with the river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Grove of Daphne!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, to a third inquirer. \xe2\x80\x9cNobody can\r\ndescribe it; only beware! It was begun by Apollo, and completed by him.\r\nHe prefers it to Olympus. People go there for one look\xe2\x80\x94just one\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnever come away. They have a saying which tells it all\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Better be a\r\nworm and feed on the mulberries of Daphne than a king\xe2\x80\x99s guest.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you advise me to stay away from it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I! Go you will. Everybody goes, cynic philosopher, virile boy,\r\nwomen, and priests\xe2\x80\x94all go. So sure am I of what you will do that I\r\nassume to advise you. Do not take quarters in the city\xe2\x80\x94that will be\r\nloss of time; but go at once to the village in the edge of the grove.\r\nThe way is through a garden, under the spray of fountains. The lovers\r\nof the god and his Penaean maid built the town; and in its porticos and\r\npaths and thousand retreats you will find characters and habits and\r\nsweets and kinds elsewhere impossible. But the wall of the city! there\r\nit is, the masterpiece of Xeraeus, the master of mural architecture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll eyes followed his pointing finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis part was raised by order of the first of the Seleucidae. Three\r\nhundred years have made it part of the rock it rests upon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe defense justified the encomium. High, solid, and with many bold\r\nangles, it curved southwardly out of view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the top there are four hundred towers, each a reservoir of water,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe Hebrew continued. \xe2\x80\x9cLook now! Over the wall, tall as it is, see in\r\nthe distance two hills, which you may know as the rival crests of\r\nSulpius. The structure on the farthest one is the citadel, garrisoned\r\nall the year round by a Roman legion. Opposite it this way rises the\r\nTemple of Jupiter, and under that the front of the legate\xe2\x80\x99s residence\xe2\x80\x94a\r\npalace full of offices, and yet a fortress against which a mob would\r\ndash harmlessly as a south wind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point the sailors began taking in sail, whereupon the Hebrew\r\nexclaimed, heartily, \xe2\x80\x9cSee! you who hate the sea, and you who have vows,\r\nget ready your curses and your prayers. The bridge yonder, over which\r\nthe road to Seleucia is carried, marks the limit of navigation. What\r\nthe ship unloads for further transit, the camel takes up there. Above\r\nthe bridge begins the island upon which Calinicus built his new city,\r\nconnecting it with five great viaducts so solid time has made no\r\nimpression upon them, nor floods nor earthquakes. Of the main town, my\r\nfriends, I have only to say you will be happier all your lives for\r\nhaving seen it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he concluded, the ship turned and made slowly for her wharf under\r\nthe wall, bringing even more fairly to view the life with which the\r\nriver at that point was possessed. Finally, the lines were thrown, the\r\noars shipped, and the voyage was done. Then Ben-Hur sought the\r\nrespectable Hebrew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me trouble you a moment before saying farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man bowed assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour story of the merchant has made me curious to see him. You called\r\nhim Simonides?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. He is a Jew with a Greek name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he to be found?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe acquaintance gave a sharp look before he answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may save you mortification. He is not a money-lender.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor am I a money-borrower,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, smiling at the other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshrewdness.\r\n\r\nThe man raised his head and considered an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne would think,\xe2\x80\x9d he then replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the richest merchant in\r\nAntioch would have a house for business corresponding to his wealth;\r\nbut if you would find him in the day, follow the river to yon bridge,\r\nunder which he quarters in a building that looks like a buttress of the\r\nwall. Before the door there is an immense landing, always covered with\r\ncargoes come and to go. The fleet that lies moored there is his. You\r\ncannot fail to find him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you thanks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peace of our fathers go with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that they separated.\r\n\r\nTwo street-porters, loaded with his baggage, received Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s orders\r\nupon the wharf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the citadel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; a direction which implied an official\r\nmilitary connection.\r\n\r\nTwo great streets, cutting each other at right angles, divided the city\r\ninto quarters. A curious and immense structure, called the Nymphaeum,\r\narose at the foot of the one running north and south. When the porters\r\nturned south there, the new-comer, though fresh from Rome, was amazed\r\nat the magnificence of the avenue. On the right and left there were\r\npalaces, and between them extended indefinitely double colonnades of\r\nmarble, leaving separate ways for footmen, beasts, and chariots; the\r\nwhole under shade, and cooled by fountains of incessant flow.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was not in mood to enjoy the spectacle. The story of Simonides\r\nhaunted him. Arrived at the Omphalus\xe2\x80\x94a monument of four arches wide as\r\nthe streets, superbly illustrated, and erected to himself by Epiphanes,\r\nthe eighth of the Seleucidae\xe2\x80\x94he suddenly changed his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not go to the citadel to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the porters. \xe2\x80\x9cTake\r\nme to the khan nearest the bridge on the road to Seleucia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe party faced about, and in good time he was deposited in a public\r\nhouse of primitive but ample construction, within stone\xe2\x80\x99s-throw of the\r\nbridge under which old Simonides had his quarters. He lay upon the\r\nhouse-top through the night. In his inner mind lived the thought,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow\xe2\x80\x94now I will hear of home\xe2\x80\x94and mother\xe2\x80\x94and the dear little Tirzah. If\r\nthey are on earth, I will find them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nNext day early, to the neglect of the city, Ben-Hur sought the house of\r\nSimonides. Through an embattled gateway he passed to a continuity of\r\nwharves; thence up the river midst a busy press, to the Seleucian\r\nBridge, under which he paused to take in the scene.\r\n\r\nThere, directly under the bridge, was the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s house, a mass of\r\ngray stone, unhewn, referable to no style, looking, as the voyager had\r\ndescribed it, like a buttress of the wall against which it leaned. Two\r\nimmense doors in front communicated with the wharf. Some holes near the\r\ntop, heavily barred, served as windows. Weeds waved from the crevices,\r\nand in places black moss splotched the otherwise bald stones.\r\n\r\nThe doors were open. Through one of them business went in; through the\r\nother it came out; and there was hurry, hurry in all its movements.\r\n\r\nOn the wharf there were piles of goods in every kind of package, and\r\ngroups of slaves, stripped to the waist, going about in the abandon of\r\nlabor.\r\n\r\nBelow the bridge lay a fleet of galleys, some loading, others\r\nunloading. A yellow flag blew out from each masthead. From fleet and\r\nwharf, and from ship to ship, the bondmen of traffic passed in\r\nclamorous counter-currents.\r\n\r\nAbove the bridge, across the river, a wall rose from the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge,\r\nover which towered the fanciful cornices and turrets of an imperial\r\npalace, covering every foot of the island spoken of in the Hebrew\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndescription. But, with all its suggestions, Ben-Hur scarcely noticed\r\nit. Now, at last, he thought to hear of his people\xe2\x80\x94this, certainly, if\r\nSimonides had indeed been his father\xe2\x80\x99s slave. But would the man\r\nacknowledge the relation? That would be to give up his riches and the\r\nsovereignty of trade so royally witnessed on the wharf and river. And\r\nwhat was of still greater consequence to the merchant, it would be to\r\nforego his career in the midst of amazing success, and yield himself\r\nvoluntarily once more a slave. Simple thought of the demand seemed a\r\nmonstrous audacity. Stripped of diplomatic address, it was to say, You\r\nare my slave; give me all you have, and\xe2\x80\x94yourself.\r\n\r\nYet Ben-Hur derived strength for the interview from faith in his rights\r\nand the hope uppermost in his heart. If the story to which he was\r\nyielding were true, Simonides belonged to him, with all he had. For the\r\nwealth, be it said in justice, he cared nothing. When he started to the\r\ndoor determined in mind, it was with a promise to himself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLet him tell\r\nme of mother and Tirzah, and I will give him his freedom without\r\naccount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe passed boldly into the house.\r\n\r\nThe interior was that of a vast depot where, in ordered spaces, and\r\nunder careful arrangement, goods of every kind were heaped and pent.\r\nThough the light was murky and the air stifling, men moved about\r\nbriskly; and in places he saw workmen with saws and hammers making\r\npackages for shipments. Down a path between the piles he walked slowly,\r\nwondering if the man of whose genius there were here such abounding\r\nproofs could have been his father\xe2\x80\x99s slave? If so, to what class had he\r\nbelonged? If a Jew, was he the son of a servant? Or was he a debtor or\r\na debtor\xe2\x80\x99s son? Or had he been sentenced and sold for theft? These\r\nthoughts, as they passed, in nowise disturbed the growing respect for\r\nthe merchant of which he was each instant more and more conscious. A\r\npeculiarity of our admiration for another is that it is always looking\r\nfor circumstances to justify itself.\r\n\r\nAt length a man approached and spoke to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would see Simonides, the merchant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you come this way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy a number of paths left in the stowage, they finally came to a flight\r\nof steps; ascending which, he found himself on the roof of the depot,\r\nand in front of a structure which cannot be better described than as a\r\nlesser stone house built upon another, invisible from the landing\r\nbelow, and out west of the bridge under the open sky. The roof, hemmed\r\nin by a low wall, seemed like a terrace, which, to his astonishment,\r\nwas brilliant with flowers; in the rich surrounding, the house sat\r\nsquat, a plain square block, unbroken except by a doorway in front. A\r\ndustless path led to the door, through a bordering of shrubs of Persian\r\nrose in perfect bloom. Breathing a sweet attar-perfume, he followed the\r\nguide.\r\n\r\nAt the end of a darkened passage within, they stopped before a curtain\r\nhalf parted. The man called out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA stranger to see the master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA clear voice replied, \xe2\x80\x9cIn God\xe2\x80\x99s name, let him enter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA Roman might have called the apartment into which the visitor was\r\nushered his atrium. The walls were paneled; each panel was comparted\r\nlike a modern office-desk, and each compartment crowded with labelled\r\nfolios all filemot with age and use. Between the panels, and above and\r\nbelow them, were borders of wood once white, now tinted like cream, and\r\ncarved with marvellous intricacy of design. Above a cornice of gilded\r\nballs, the ceiling rose in pavilion style until it broke into a shallow\r\ndome set with hundreds of panes of violet mica, permitting a flood of\r\nlight deliciously reposeful. The floor was carpeted with gray rugs so\r\nthick that an invading foot fell half buried and soundless.\r\n\r\nIn the midlight of the room were two persons\xe2\x80\x94a man resting in a chair\r\nhigh-backed, broad-armed, and lined with pliant cushions; and at his\r\nleft, leaning against the back of the chair, a girl well forward into\r\nwomanhood. At sight of them Ben-Hur felt the blood redden his forehead;\r\nbowing, as much to recover himself as in respect, he lost the lifting\r\nof the hands, and the shiver and shrink with which the sitter caught\r\nsight of him\xe2\x80\x94an emotion as swift to go as it had been to come.
