When he\r\nraised his eyes the two were in the same position, except the girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand had fallen and was resting lightly upon the elder\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder; both\r\nof them were regarding him fixedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are Simonides, the merchant, and a Jew\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur stopped an\r\ninstant\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthen the peace of the God of our father Abraham upon you\r\nand\xe2\x80\x94yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last word was addressed to the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the Simonides of whom you speak, by birthright a Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d the man\r\nmade answer, in a voice singularly clear. \xe2\x80\x9cI am Simonides, and a Jew;\r\nand I return you your salutation, with prayer to know who calls upon\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked as he listened, and where the figure of the man should\r\nhave been in healthful roundness, there was only a formless heap sunk\r\nin the depths of the cushions, and covered by a quilted robe of sombre\r\nsilk. Over the heap shone a head royally proportioned\xe2\x80\x94the ideal head of\r\na statesman and conqueror\xe2\x80\x94a head broad of base and domelike in front,\r\nsuch as Angelo would have modelled for Caesar. White hair dropped in\r\nthin locks over the white brows, deepening the blackness of the eyes\r\nshining through them like sullen lights. The face was bloodless, and\r\nmuch puffed with folds, especially under the chin. In other words, the\r\nhead and face were those of a man who might move the world more readily\r\nthan the world could move him\xe2\x80\x94a man to be twice twelve times tortured\r\ninto the shapeless cripple he was, without a groan, much less a\r\nconfession; a man to yield his life, but never a purpose or a point; a\r\nman born in armor, and assailable only through his loves. To him\r\nBen-Hur stretched his hands, open and palm up, as he would offer peace\r\nat the same time he asked it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Judah, son of Ithamar, late head of the House of Hur, and a\r\nprince of Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merchant\xe2\x80\x99s right hand lay outside the robe\xe2\x80\x94a long, thin hand,\r\narticulate to deformity with suffering. It closed tightly; otherwise\r\nthere was not the slightest expression of feeling of any kind on his\r\npart; nothing to warrant an inference of surprise or interest; nothing\r\nbut this calm answer,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe princes of Jerusalem, of the pure blood, are always welcome in my\r\nhouse; you are welcome. Give the young man a seat, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl took an ottoman near by, and carried it to Ben-Hur. As she\r\narose from placing the seat, their eyes met.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peace of our Lord with you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, modestly. \xe2\x80\x9cBe seated and at\r\nrest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen she resumed her place by the chair, she had not divined his\r\npurpose. The powers of woman go not so far: if the matter is of finer\r\nfeeling, such as pity, mercy, sympathy, that she detects; and therein\r\nis a difference between her and man which will endure as long as she\r\nremains, by nature, alive to such feelings. She was simply sure he\r\nbrought some wound of life for healing.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur did not take the offered seat, but said, deferentially, \xe2\x80\x9cI pray\r\nthe good master Simonides that he will not hold me an intruder. Coming\r\nup the river yesterday, I heard he knew my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew the Prince Hur. We were associated in some enterprises lawful\r\nto merchants who find profit in lands beyond the sea and the desert.\r\nBut sit, I pray you\xe2\x80\x94and, Esther, some wine for the young man. Nehemiah\r\nspeaks of a son of Hur who once ruled the half part of Jerusalem; an\r\nold house; very old, by the faith! In the days of Moses and Joshua even\r\nsome of them found favor in the sight of the Lord, and divided honors\r\nwith those princes among men. It can hardly be that their descendant,\r\nlineally come to us, will refuse a cup of wine-fat of the genuine vine\r\nof Sorek, grown on the south hill-sides of Hebron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy the time of the conclusion of this speech, Esther was before Ben-Hur\r\nwith a silver cup filled from a vase upon a table a little removed from\r\nthe chair. She offered the drink with downcast face. He touched her\r\nhand gently to put it away. Again their eyes met; whereat he noticed\r\nthat she was small, not nearly to his shoulder in height; but very\r\ngraceful, and fair and sweet of face, with eyes black and inexpressibly\r\nsoft. She is kind and pretty, he thought, and looks as Tirzah would\r\nwere she living. Poor Tirzah! Then he said aloud,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thy father\xe2\x80\x94if he is thy father?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Esther, the daughter of Simonides,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, fair Esther, thy father, when he has heard my further speech,\r\nwill not think worse of me if yet I am slow to take his wine of famous\r\nextract; nor less I hope not to lose grace in thy sight. Stand thou\r\nhere with me a moment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth of them, as in common cause, turned to the merchant. \xe2\x80\x9cSimonides!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, firmly, \xe2\x80\x9cmy father, at his death, had a trusted servant of thy\r\nname, and it has been told me that thou art the man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a sudden start of the wrenched limbs under the robe, and the\r\nthin hand clenched.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther, Esther!\xe2\x80\x9d the man called, sternly; \xe2\x80\x9chere, not there, as thou\r\nart thy mother\xe2\x80\x99s child and mine\xe2\x80\x94here, not there, I say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl looked once from father to visitor; then she replaced the cup\r\nupon the table, and went dutifully to the chair. Her countenance\r\nsufficiently expressed her wonder and alarm.\r\n\r\nSimonides lifted his left hand, and gave it into hers, lying lovingly\r\nupon his shoulder, and said, dispassionately, \xe2\x80\x9cI have grown old in\r\ndealing with men\xe2\x80\x94old before my time. If he who told thee that whereof\r\nthou speakest was a friend acquainted with my history, and spoke of it\r\nnot harshly, he must have persuaded thee that I could not be else than\r\na man distrustful of my kind. The God of Israel help him who, at the\r\nend of life, is constrained to acknowledge so much! My loves are few,\r\nbut they are. One of them is a soul which\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he carried the hand holding\r\nhis to his lips, in manner unmistakable\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca soul which to this time has\r\nbeen unselfishly mine, and such sweet comfort that, were it taken from\r\nme, I would die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther\xe2\x80\x99s head drooped until her cheek touched his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe other love is but a memory; of which I will say further that, like\r\na benison of the Lord, it hath a compass to contain a whole family, if\r\nonly\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94his voice lowered and trembled\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif only I knew where they were.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face suffused, and, advancing a step, he cried, impulsively,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother and sister! Oh, it is of them you speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther, as if spoken to, raised her head; but Simonides returned to his\r\ncalm, and answered, coldly, \xe2\x80\x9cHear me to the end. Because I am that I\r\nam, and because of the loves of which I have spoken, before I make\r\nreturn to thy demand touching my relations to the Prince Hur, and as\r\nsomething which of right should come first, do thou show me proofs of\r\nwho thou art. Is thy witness in writing? Or cometh it in person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe demand was plain, and the right of it indisputable. Ben-Hur\r\nblushed, clasped his hands, stammered, and turned away at loss.\r\nSimonides pressed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe proofs, the proofs, I say! Set them before me\xe2\x80\x94lay them in my\r\nhands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYet Ben-Hur had no answer. He had not anticipated the requirement; and,\r\nnow that it was made, to him as never before came the awful fact that\r\nthe three years in the galley had carried away all the proofs of his\r\nidentity; mother and sister gone, he did not live in the knowledge of\r\nany human being. Many there were acquainted with him, but that was all.\r\nHad Quintus Arrius been present, what could he have said more than\r\nwhere he found him, and that he believed the pretender to be the son of\r\nHur? But, as will presently appear in full, the brave Roman sailor was\r\ndead. Judah had felt the loneliness before; to the core of life the\r\nsense struck him now. He stood, hands clasped, face averted, in\r\nstupefaction. Simonides respected his suffering, and waited in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster Simonides,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, at length, \xe2\x80\x9cI can only tell my story; and\r\nI will not that unless you stay judgment so long, and with good-will\r\ndeign to hear me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, now, indeed, master of the situation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cspeak,\r\nand I will listen the more willingly that I have not denied you to be\r\nthe very person you claim yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur proceeded then, and told his life hurriedly, yet with the\r\nfeeling which is the source of all eloquence; but as we are familiar\r\nwith it down to his landing at Misenum, in company with Arrius,\r\nreturned victorious from the \xc3\x86gean, at that point we will take up the\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy benefactor was loved and trusted by the emperor, who heaped him\r\nwith honorable rewards. The merchants of the East contributed\r\nmagnificent presents, and he became doubly rich among the rich of Rome.\r\nMay a Jew forget his religion? or his birthplace, if it were the Holy\r\nLand of our fathers? The good man adopted me his son by formal rites of\r\nlaw; and I strove to make him just return: no child was ever more\r\ndutiful to father than I to him. He would have had me a scholar; in\r\nart, philosophy, rhetoric, oratory, he would have furnished me the most\r\nfamous teacher. I declined his insistence, because I was a Jew, and\r\ncould not forget the Lord God, or the glory of the prophets, or the\r\ncity set on the hills by David and Solomon. Oh, ask you why I accepted\r\nany of the benefactions of the Roman? I loved him; next place, I\r\nthought with his help, array influences which would enable me one day\r\nto unseal the mystery close-locking the fate of my mother and sister;\r\nand to these there was yet another motive of which I shall not speak\r\nexcept to say it controlled me so far that I devoted myself to arms,\r\nand the acquisition of everything deemed essential to thorough\r\nknowledge of the art of war. In the palaestrae and circuses of the city\r\nI toiled, and in the camps no less; and in all of them I have a name,\r\nbut not that of my fathers. The crowns I won\xe2\x80\x94and on the walls of the\r\nvilla by Misenum there are many of them\xe2\x80\x94all came to me as the son of\r\nArrius, the duumvir. In that relation only am I known among Romans....\r\nIn steadfast pursuit of my secret aim, I left Rome for Antioch,\r\nintending to accompany the Consul Maxentius in the campaign he is\r\norganizing against the Parthians. Master of personal skill in all arms,\r\nI seek now the higher knowledge pertaining to the conduct of bodies of\r\nmen in the field. The consul has admitted me one of his military\r\nfamily. But yesterday, as our ship entered the Orontes, two other ships\r\nsailed in with us flying yellow flags. A fellow-passenger and\r\ncountryman from Cyprus explained that the vessels belonged to\r\nSimonides, the master-merchant of Antioch; he told us, also, who the\r\nmerchant was; his marvellous success in commerce; of his fleets and\r\ncaravans, and their coming and going; and, not knowing I had interest\r\nin the theme beyond my associate listeners, he said Simonides was a\r\nJew, once the servant of the Prince Hur; nor did he conceal the\r\ncruelties of Gratus, or the purpose of their infliction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this allusion Simonides bowed his head, and, as if to help him\r\nconceal his feelings and her own deep sympathy, the daughter hid her\r\nface on his neck. Directly he raised his eyes, and said, in a clear\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cI am listening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO good Simonides!\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur then said, advancing a step, his whole soul\r\nseeking expression, \xe2\x80\x9cI see thou art not convinced, and that yet I stand\r\nin the shadow of thy distrust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merchant held his features fixed as marble, and his tongue as\r\nstill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd not less clearly, I see the difficulties of my position,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur\r\ncontinued. \xe2\x80\x9cAll my Roman connection I can prove; I have only to call\r\nupon the consul, now the guest of the governor of the city; but I\r\ncannot prove the particulars of thy demand upon me. I cannot prove I am\r\nmy father\xe2\x80\x99s son. They who could serve me in that\xe2\x80\x94alas! they are dead or\r\nlost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe covered his face with his hands; whereupon Esther arose, and, taking\r\nthe rejected cup to him, said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe wine is of the country we all so\r\nlove. Drink, I pray thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice was sweet as that of Rebekah offering drink at the well near\r\nNahor the city; he saw there were tears in her eyes, and he drank,\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x9cDaughter of Simonides, thy heart is full of goodness; and\r\nmerciful art thou to let the stranger share it with thy father. Be thou\r\nblessed of our God! I thank thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he addressed himself to the merchant again:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I have no proof that I am my father\xe2\x80\x99s son, I will withdraw that I\r\ndemanded of thee, O Simonides, and go hence to trouble you no more;\r\nonly let me say I did not seek thy return to servitude nor account of\r\nthy fortune; in any event, I would have said, as now I say, that all\r\nwhich is product of thy labor and genius is thine; keep it in welcome.\r\nI have no need of any part thereof. When the good Quintus, my second\r\nfather, sailed on the voyage which was his last, he left me his heir,\r\nprincely rich. If, therefore, thou dost think of me again, be it with\r\nremembrance of this question, which, as I do swear by the prophets and\r\nJehovah, thy God and mine, was the chief purpose of my coming here:\r\nWhat dost thou know\xe2\x80\x94what canst thou tell me\xe2\x80\x94of my mother and Tirzah, my\r\nsister\xe2\x80\x94she who should be in beauty and grace even as this one, thy\r\nsweetness of life, if not thy very life? Oh! what canst thou tell me of\r\nthem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tears ran down Esther\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks; but the man was wilful: in a clear\r\nvoice, he replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have said I knew the Prince Ben-Hur. I remember hearing of the\r\nmisfortune which overtook his family. I remember the bitterness with\r\nwhich I heard it. He who wrought such misery to the widow of my friend\r\nis the same who, in the same spirit, hath since wrought upon me. I will\r\ngo further, and say to you, I have made diligent quest concerning the\r\nfamily, but\xe2\x80\x94I have nothing to tell you of them. They are lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur uttered a great groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen\xe2\x80\x94then it is another hope broken!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, struggling with his\r\nfeelings. \xe2\x80\x9cI am used to disappointments. I pray you pardon my\r\nintrusion; and if I have occasioned you annoyance, forgive it because\r\nof my sorrow. I have nothing now to live for but vengeance. Farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the curtain he turned, and said, simply, \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace go with you,\xe2\x80\x9d the merchant said.\r\n\r\nEsther could not speak for sobbing.\r\n\r\nAnd so he departed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nScarcely was Ben-Hur gone, when Simonides seemed to wake as from sleep:\r\nhis countenance flushed; the sullen light of his eyes changed to\r\nbrightness; and he said, cheerily,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther, ring\xe2\x80\x94quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went to the table, and rang a service-bell.\r\n\r\nOne of the panels in the wall swung back, exposing a doorway which gave\r\nadmittance to a man who passed round to the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s front, and\r\nsaluted him with a half-salaam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalluch, here\xe2\x80\x94nearer\xe2\x80\x94to the chair,\xe2\x80\x9d the master said, imperiously. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave a mission which shall not fail though the sun should. Hearken! A\r\nyoung man is now descending to the store-room\xe2\x80\x94tall, comely, and in the\r\ngarb of Israel; follow him, his shadow not more faithful; and every\r\nnight send me report of where he is, what he does, and the company he\r\nkeeps; and if, without discovery, you overhear his conversations,\r\nreport them word for word, together with whatever will serve to expose\r\nhim, his habits, motives, life. Understand you? Go quickly! Stay,\r\nMalluch: if he leave the city, go after him\xe2\x80\x94and, mark you, Malluch, be\r\nas a friend. If he bespeak you, tell him what you will to the occasion\r\nmost suited, except that you are in my service, of that, not a word.\r\nHaste\xe2\x80\x94make haste!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man saluted as before, and was gone.\r\n\r\nThen Simonides rubbed his wan hands together, and laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the day, daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in the midst of the mood. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nis the day? I wish to remember it for happiness come. See, and look for\r\nit laughing, and laughing tell me, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merriment seemed unnatural to her; and, as if to entreat him from\r\nit, she answered, sorrowfully, \xe2\x80\x9cWoe\xe2\x80\x99s me, father, that I should ever\r\nforget this day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis hands fell down the instant, and his chin, dropping upon his\r\nbreast, lost itself in the muffling folds of flesh composing his lower\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, most true, my daughter!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, without looking up. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is\r\nthe twentieth day of the fourth month. To-day, five years ago, my\r\nRachel, thy mother, fell down and died. They brought me home broken as\r\nthou seest me, and we found her dead of grief. Oh, to me she was a\r\ncluster of camphire in the vineyards of En-Gedi! I have gathered my\r\nmyrrh with my spice. I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey. We laid\r\nher away in a lonely place\xe2\x80\x94in a tomb cut in the mountain; no one near\r\nher. Yet in the darkness she left me a little light, which the years\r\nhave increased to a brightness of morning.\xe2\x80\x9d He raised his hand and\r\nrested it upon his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s head. \xe2\x80\x9cDear Lord, I thank thee that now\r\nin my Esther my lost Rachel liveth again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDirectly he lifted his head, and said, as with a sudden thought, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it\r\nnot clear day outside?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was, when the young man came in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let Abimelech come and take me to the garden, where I can see the\r\nriver and the ships, and I will tell thee, dear Esther, why but now my\r\nmouth filled with laughter, and my tongue with singing, and my spirit\r\nwas like to a roe or to a young hart upon the mountains of spices.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn answer to the bell a servant came, and at her bidding pushed the\r\nchair, set on little wheels for the purpose, out of the room to the\r\nroof of the lower house, called by him his garden. Out through the\r\nroses, and by beds of lesser flowers, all triumphs of careful\r\nattendance, but now unnoticed, he was rolled to a position from which\r\nhe could view the palace-tops over against him on the island, the\r\nbridge in lessening perspective to the farther shore, and the river\r\nbelow the bridge crowded with vessels, all swimming amidst the dancing\r\nsplendors of the early sun upon the rippling water. There the servant\r\nleft him with Esther.\r\n\r\nThe much shouting of laborers, and their beating and pounding, did not\r\ndisturb him any more than the tramping of people on the bridge floor\r\nalmost overhead, being as familiar to his ear as the view before him to\r\nhis eye, and therefore unnoticeable, except as suggestions of profits\r\nin promise.\r\n\r\nEsther sat on the arm of the chair nursing his hand, and waiting his\r\nspeech, which came at length in the calm way, the mighty will having\r\ncarried him back to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen the young man was speaking, Esther, I observed thee, and thought\r\nthou wert won by him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer eyes fell as she replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak you of faith, father, I believed him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn thy eyes, then, he is the lost son of the Prince Hur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d She hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if he is not, Esther?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been thy handmaiden, father, since my mother answered the call\r\nof the Lord God; by thy side I have heard and seen thee deal in wise\r\nways with all manner of men seeking profit, holy and unholy; and now I\r\nsay, if indeed the young man be not the prince he claims to be, then\r\nbefore me falsehood never played so well the part of righteous truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the glory of Solomon, daughter, thou speakest earnestly. Dost thou\r\nbelieve thy father his father\xe2\x80\x99s servant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understood him to ask of that as something he had but heard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a time Simonides\xe2\x80\x99 gaze swam among his swimming ships, though they\r\nhad no place in his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, thou art a good child, Esther, of genuine Jewish shrewdness, and\r\nof years and strength to hear a sorrowful tale. Wherefore give me heed,\r\nand I will tell you of myself, and of thy mother, and of many things\r\npertaining to the past not in thy knowledge or thy dreams\xe2\x80\x94things\r\nwithheld from the persecuting Romans for a hope\xe2\x80\x99s sake, and from thee\r\nthat thy nature should grow towards the Lord straight as the reed to\r\nthe sun.... I was born in a tomb in the valley of Hinnom, on the south\r\nside of Zion. My father and mother were Hebrew bond-servants, tenders\r\nof the fig and olive trees growing, with many vines, in the King\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGarden hard by Siloam; and in my boyhood I helped them. They were of\r\nthe class bound to serve forever. They sold me to the Prince Hur, then,\r\nnext to Herod the King, the richest man in Jerusalem. From the garden\r\nhe transferred me to his storehouse in Alexandria of Egypt, where I\r\ncame of age. I served him six years, and in the seventh, by the law of\r\nMoses, I went free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther clapped her hands lightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then, thou art not his father\xe2\x80\x99s servant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, daughter, hear. Now, in those days there were lawyers in the\r\ncloisters of the Temple who disputed vehemently, saying the children of\r\nservants bound forever took the condition of their parents; but the\r\nPrince Hur was a man righteous in all things, and an interpreter of the\r\nlaw after the straitest sect, though not of them. He said I was a\r\nHebrew servant bought, in the true meaning of the great lawgiver, and,\r\nby sealed writings, which I yet have, he set me free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd my mother?\xe2\x80\x9d Esther asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt hear all, Esther; be patient. Before I am through thou\r\nshalt see it were easier for me to forget myself than thy mother.... At\r\nthe end of my service, I came up to Jerusalem to the Passover. My\r\nmaster entertained me. I was in love with him already, and I prayed to\r\nbe continued in his service. He consented, and I served him yet another\r\nseven years, but as a hired son of Israel. In his behalf I had charge\r\nof ventures on the sea by ships, and of ventures on land by caravans\r\neastward to Susa and Persepolis, and the lands of silk beyond them.\r\nPerilous passages were they, my daughter; but the Lord blessed all I\r\nundertook. I brought home vast gains for the prince, and richer\r\nknowledge for myself, without which I could not have mastered the\r\ncharges since fallen to me.... One day I was a guest in his house in\r\nJerusalem. A servant entered with some sliced bread on a platter. She\r\ncame to me first. It was then I saw thy mother, and loved her, and took\r\nher away in my secret heart. After a while a time came when I sought\r\nthe prince to make her my wife. He told me she was bond-servant\r\nforever; but if she wished, he would set her free that I might be\r\ngratified. She gave me love for love, but was happy where she was, and\r\nrefused her freedom. I prayed and besought, going again and again after\r\nlong intervals. She would be my wife, she all the time said, if I would\r\nbecome her fellow in servitude. Our father Jacob served yet other seven\r\nyears for his Rachel. Could I not as much for mine? But thy mother said\r\nI must become as she, to serve forever. I came away, but went back.\r\nLook, Esther, look here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pulled out the lobe of his left ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee you not the scar of the awl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cand, oh, I see how thou didst love my mother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove her, Esther! She was to me more than the Shulamite to the singing\r\nking, fairer, more spotless; a fountain of gardens, a well of living\r\nwaters, and streams from Lebanon. The master, even as I required him,\r\ntook me to the judges, and back to his door, and thrust the awl through\r\nmy ear into the door, and I was his servant forever. So I won my\r\nRachel. And was ever love like mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther stooped and kissed him, and they were silent, thinking of the\r\ndead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master was drowned at sea, the first sorrow that ever fell upon\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d the merchant continued. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was mourning in his house, and in\r\nmine here in Antioch, my abiding-place at the time. Now, Esther, mark\r\nyou! When the good prince was lost, I had risen to be his chief\r\nsteward, with everything of property belonging to him in my management\r\nand control. Judge you how much he loved and trusted me! I hastened to\r\nJerusalem to render account to the widow. She continued me in the\r\nstewardship. I applied myself with greater diligence. The business\r\nprospered, and grew year by year. Ten years passed; then came the blow\r\nwhich you heard the young man tell about\xe2\x80\x94the accident, as he called it,\r\nto the Procurator Gratus. The Roman gave it out an attempt to\r\nassassinate him. Under that pretext, by leave from Rome, he confiscated\r\nto his own use the immense fortune of the widow and children. Nor\r\nstopped he there. That there might be no reversal of the judgment, he\r\nremoved all the parties interested. From that dreadful day to this the\r\nfamily of Hur have been lost. The son, whom I had seen as a child, was\r\nsentenced to the galleys. The widow and daughter are supposed to have\r\nbeen buried in some of the many dungeons of Judea, which, once closed\r\nupon the doomed, are like sepulchers sealed and locked. They passed\r\nfrom the knowledge of men as utterly as if the sea had swallowed them\r\nunseen. We could not hear how they died\xe2\x80\x94nay, not even that they were\r\ndead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were dewy with tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy heart is good, Esther, good as thy mother\xe2\x80\x99s was; and I pray it\r\nhave not the fate of most good hearts\xe2\x80\x94to be trampled upon by the\r\nunmerciful and blind. But hearken further. I went up to Jerusalem to\r\ngive help to my benefactress, and was seized at the gate of the city\r\nand carried to the sunken cells of the Tower of Antonia; why, I knew\r\nnot, until Gratus himself came and demanded of me the moneys of the\r\nHouse of Hur, which he knew, after our Jewish custom of exchange, were\r\nsubject to my draft in the different marts of the world. He required me\r\nto sign to his order. I refused. He had the houses, lands, goods,\r\nships, and movable property of those I served; he had not their moneys.\r\nI saw, if I kept favor in the sight of the Lord, I could rebuild their\r\nbroken fortunes. I refused the tyrant\xe2\x80\x99s demands. He put me to torture;\r\nmy will held good, and he set me free, nothing gained. I came home and\r\nbegan again, in the name of Simonides of Antioch, instead of the Prince\r\nHur of Jerusalem. Thou knowest, Esther, how I have prospered; that the\r\nincrease of the millions of the prince in my hands was miraculous; thou\r\nknowest how, at the end of three years, while going up to Caesarea, I\r\nwas taken and a second time tortured by Gratus to compel a confession\r\nthat my goods and moneys were subject to his order of confiscation;\r\nthou knowest he failed as before. Broken in body, I came home and found\r\nmy Rachel dead of fear and grief for me. The Lord our God reigned, and\r\nI lived. From the emperor himself I bought immunity and license to\r\ntrade throughout the world. To-day\xe2\x80\x94praised be He who maketh the clouds\r\nhis chariot and walketh upon the winds!\xe2\x80\x94to-day, Esther, that which was\r\nin my hands for stewardship is multiplied into talents sufficient to\r\nenrich a Caesar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe lifted his head proudly; their eyes met; each read the other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthought. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall I with the treasure, Esther?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, without\r\nlowering his gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cdid not the rightful owner\r\ncall for it but now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill his look did not fail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, my child; shall I leave thee a beggar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, father, am not I, because I am thy child, his bond-servant? And\r\nof whom was it written, \xe2\x80\x98Strength and honor are her clothing, and she\r\nshall rejoice in time to come?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA gleam of ineffable love lighted his face as he said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord hath\r\nbeen good to me in many ways; but thou, Esther, art the sovereign\r\nexcellence of his favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew her to his breast and kissed her many times.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with clearer voice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chear now why I laughed this\r\nmorning. The young man faced me the apparition of his father in comely\r\nyouth. My spirit arose to salute him. I felt my trial-days were over\r\nand my labors ended. Hardly could I keep from crying out. I longed to\r\ntake him by the hand and show the balance I had earned, and say, \xe2\x80\x98Lo,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99tis all thine! and I am thy servant, ready now to be called away.\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nso I would have done, Esther, so I would have done, but that moment\r\nthree thoughts rushed to restrain me. I will be sure he is my master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nson\xe2\x80\x94such was the first thought; if he is my master\xe2\x80\x99s son, I will learn\r\nsomewhat of his nature. Of those born to riches, bethink you, Esther,\r\nhow many there are in whose hands riches are but breeding curses\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\r\npaused, while his hands clutched, and his voice shrilled with\r\npassion\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cEsther, consider the pains I endured at the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s hands;\r\nnay, not Gratus\xe2\x80\x99s alone: the merciless wretches who did his bidding the\r\nfirst time and the last were Romans, and they all alike laughed to hear\r\nme scream. Consider my broken body, and the years I have gone shorn of\r\nmy stature; consider thy mother yonder in her lonely tomb, crushed of\r\nsoul as I of body; consider the sorrows of my master\xe2\x80\x99s family if they\r\nare living, and the cruelty of their taking-off if they are dead;\r\nconsider all, and, with Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s love about thee, tell me, daughter,\r\nshall not a hair fall or a red drop run in expiation? Tell me not, as\r\nthe preachers sometimes do\xe2\x80\x94tell me not that vengeance is the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nDoes he not work his will harmfully as well as in love by agencies? Has\r\nhe not his men of war more numerous than his prophets? Is not his the\r\nlaw, Eye for eye, hand for hand, foot for foot? Oh, in all these years\r\nI have dreamed of vengeance, and prayed and provided for it, and\r\ngathered patience from the growing of my store, thinking and promising,\r\nas the Lord liveth, it will one day buy me punishment of the\r\nwrong-doers? And when, speaking of his practise with arms, the young\r\nman said it was for a nameless purpose, I named the purpose even as he\r\nspoke\xe2\x80\x94vengeance! and that, Esther, that it was\xe2\x80\x94the third thought which\r\nheld me still and hard while his pleading lasted, and made me laugh\r\nwhen he was gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther caressed the faded hands, and said, as if her spirit with his\r\nwere running forward to results, \xe2\x80\x9cHe is gone. Will he come again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, Malluch the faithful goes with him, and will bring him back when I\r\nam ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when will that be, father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot long, not long. He thinks all his witnesses dead. There is one\r\nliving who will not fail to know him, if he be indeed my master\xe2\x80\x99s son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, daughter, I will set the witness before him; till then let us\r\nrest the business with the Lord. I am tired. Call Abimelech.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther called the servant, and they returned into the house.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Ben-Hur sallied from the great warehouse, it was with the thought\r\nthat another failure was to be added to the many he had already met in\r\nthe quest for his people; and the idea was depressing exactly in\r\nproportion as the objects of his quest were dear to him; it curtained\r\nhim round about with a sense of utter loneliness on earth, which, more\r\nthan anything else, serves to eke from a soul cast down its remaining\r\ninterest in life.\r\n\r\nThrough the people, and the piles of goods, he made way to the edge of\r\nthe landing, and was tempted by the cool shadows darkening the river\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndepth. The lazy current seemed to stop and wait for him. In\r\ncounteraction of the spell, the saying of the voyager flashed into\r\nmemory\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBetter be a worm, and feed upon the mulberries of Daphne, than\r\na king\xe2\x80\x99s guest.\xe2\x80\x9d He turned, and walked rapidly down the landing and\r\nback to the khan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe road to Daphne!\xe2\x80\x9d the steward said, surprised at the question\r\nBen-Hur put to him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have not been here before? Well, count this\r\nthe happiest day of your life. You cannot mistake the road. The next\r\nstreet to the left, going south, leads straight to Mount Sulpius,\r\ncrowned by the altar of Jupiter and the Amphitheater; keep it to the\r\nthird cross street, known as Herod\xe2\x80\x99s Colonnade; turn to your right\r\nthere, and hold the way through the old city of Seleucus to the bronze\r\ngates of Epiphanes. There the road to Daphne begins\xe2\x80\x94and may the gods\r\nkeep you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA few directions respecting his baggage, and Ben-Hur set out.\r\n\r\nThe Colonnade of Herod was easily found; thence to the brazen gates,\r\nunder a continuous marble portico, he passed with a multitude mixed of\r\npeople from all the trading nations of the earth.\r\n\r\nIt was about the fourth hour of the day when he passed out the gate,\r\nand found himself one of a procession apparently interminable, moving\r\nto the famous Grove. The road was divided into separate ways for\r\nfootmen, for men on horses, and men in chariots; and those again into\r\nseparate ways for outgoers and incomers. The lines of division were\r\nguarded by low balustrading, broken by massive pedestals, many of which\r\nwere surmounted with statuary. Right and left of the road extended\r\nmargins of sward perfectly kept, relieved at intervals by groups of oak\r\nand sycamore trees, and vine-clad summer-houses for the accommodation\r\nof the weary, of whom, on the return side, there were always\r\nmultitudes. The ways of the footmen were paved with red stone, and\r\nthose of the riders strewn with white sand compactly rolled, but not so\r\nsolid as to give back an echo to hoof or wheel. The number and variety\r\nof fountains at play were amazing, all gifts of visiting kings, and\r\ncalled after them. Out southwest to the gates of the Grove, the\r\nmagnificent thoroughfare stretched a little over four miles from the\r\ncity.\r\n\r\nIn his wretchedness of feeling, Ben-Hur barely observed the royal\r\nliberality which marked the construction of the road. Nor more did he\r\nat first notice the crowd going with him. He treated the processional\r\ndisplays with like indifference. To say truth, besides his\r\nself-absorption, he had not a little of the complacency of a Roman\r\nvisiting the provinces fresh from the ceremonies which daily eddied\r\nround and round the golden pillar set up by Augustus as the centre of\r\nthe world. It was not possible for the provinces to offer anything new\r\nor superior. He rather availed himself of every opportunity to push\r\nforward through the companies in the way, and too slow-going for his\r\nimpatience. By the time he reached Heracleia, a suburban village\r\nintermediate the city and the Grove, he was somewhat spent with\r\nexercise, and began to be susceptible of entertainment. Once a pair of\r\ngoats led by a beautiful woman, woman and goats alike brilliant with\r\nribbons and flowers, attracted his attention. Then he stopped to look\r\nat a bull of mighty girth, and snowy white, covered with vines freshly\r\ncut, and bearing on its broad back a naked child in a basket, the image\r\nof a young Bacchus, squeezing the juice of ripened berries into a\r\ngoblet, and drinking with libational formulas. As he resumed his walk,\r\nhe wondered whose altars would be enriched by the offerings. A horse\r\nwent by with clipped mane, after the fashion of the time, his rider\r\nsuperbly dressed. He smiled to observe the harmony of pride between the\r\nman and the brute. Often after that he turned his head at hearing the\r\nrumble of wheels and the dull thud of hoofs; unconsciously he was\r\nbecoming interested in the styles of chariots and charioteers, as they\r\nrustled past him going and coming. Nor was it long until he began to\r\nmake notes of the people around him. He saw they were of all ages,\r\nsexes, and conditions, and all in holiday attire. One company was\r\nuniformed in white, another in black; some bore flags, some smoking\r\ncensers; some went slowly, singing hymns; others stepped to the music\r\nof flutes and tabrets. If such were the going to Daphne every day in\r\nthe year, what a wondrous sight Daphne must be! At last there was a\r\nclapping of hands, and a burst of joyous cries; following the pointing\r\nof many fingers, he looked and saw upon the brow of a hill the templed\r\ngate of the consecrated Grove. The hymns swelled to louder strains; the\r\nmusic quickened time; and, borne along by the impulsive current, and\r\nsharing the common eagerness, he passed in, and, Romanized in taste as\r\nhe was, fell to worshiping the place.\r\n\r\nRearward of the structure which graced the entrance-way\xe2\x80\x94a purely\r\nGrecian pile\xe2\x80\x94he stood upon a broad esplanade paved with polished stone;\r\naround him a restless exclamatory multitude, in gayest colors, relieved\r\nagainst the iridescent spray flying crystal-white from fountains;\r\nbefore him, off to the southwest, dustless paths radiated out into a\r\ngarden, and beyond that into a forest, over which rested a veil of\r\npale-blue vapor. Ben-Hur gazed wistfully, uncertain where to go. A\r\nwoman that moment exclaimed,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeautiful! But where to now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer companion, wearing a chaplet of bays, laughed and answered, \xe2\x80\x9cGo to,\r\nthou pretty barbarian! The question implies an earthly fear; and did we\r\nnot agree to leave all such behind in Antioch with the rusty earth? The\r\nwinds which blow here are respirations of the gods. Let us give\r\nourselves to waftage of the winds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if we should get lost?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO thou timid! No one was ever lost in Daphne, except those on whom her\r\ngates close forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who are they?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, still fearful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch as have yielded to the charms of the place and chosen it for life\r\nand death. Hark! Stand we here, and I will show you of whom I speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon the marble pavement there was a scurry of sandalled feet; the\r\ncrowd opened, and a party of girls rushed about the speaker and his\r\nfair friend, and began singing and dancing to the tabrets they\r\nthemselves touched. The woman, scared, clung to the man, who put an arm\r\nabout her, and, with kindled face, kept time to the music with the\r\nother hand overhead. The hair of the dancers floated free, and their\r\nlimbs blushed through the robes of gauze which scarcely draped them.\r\nWords may not be used to tell of the voluptuousness of the dance. One\r\nbrief round, and they darted off through the yielding crowd lightly as\r\nthey had come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow what think you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the man to the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevadasi\xe2\x80\x94priestesses devoted to the Temple of Apollo. There is an army\r\nof them. They make the chorus in celebrations. This is their home.\r\nSometimes they wander off to other cities, but all they make is brought\r\nhere to enrich the house of the divine musician. Shall we go now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNext minute the two were gone.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took comfort in the assurance that no one was ever lost in\r\nDaphne, and he, too, set out\xe2\x80\x94where, he knew not.\r\n\r\nA sculpture reared upon a beautiful pedestal in the garden attracted\r\nhim first. It proved to be the statue of a centaur. An inscription\r\ninformed the unlearned visitor that it exactly represented Chiron, the\r\nbeloved of Apollo and Diana, instructed by them in the mysteries of\r\nhunting, medicine, music, and prophecy. The inscription also bade the\r\nstranger look out at a certain part of the heavens, at a certain hour\r\nof the clear night, and he would behold the dead alive among the stars,\r\nwhither Jupiter had transferred the good genius.\r\n\r\nThe wisest of the centaurs continued, nevertheless, in the service of\r\nmankind. In his hand he held a scroll, on which, graven in Greek, were\r\nparagraphs of a notice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Traveller!\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou a stranger?\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI. Hearken to the singing of the brooks, and fear not the rain of the\r\nfountains; so will the Naiades learn to love thee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cII. The invited breezes of Daphne are Zephyrus and Auster; gentle\r\nministers of life, they will gather sweets for thee; when Eurus blows,\r\nDiana is elsewhere hunting; when Boreas blusters, go hide, for Apollo\r\nis angry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIII. The shades of the Grove are thine in the day; at night they\r\nbelong to Pan and his Dryades. Disturb them not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIV. Eat of the Lotus by the brooksides sparingly, unless thou wouldst\r\nhave surcease of memory, which is to become a child of Daphne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cV. Walk thou round the weaving spider\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis Arachne at work for\r\nMinerva.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVI. Wouldst thou behold the tears of Daphne, break but a bud from a\r\nlaurel bough\xe2\x80\x94and die.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeed thou!\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd stay and be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur left the interpretation of the mystic notice to others fast\r\nenclosing him, and turned away as the white bull was led by. The boy\r\nsat in the basket, followed by a procession; after them again, the\r\nwoman with the goats; and behind her the flute and tabret players, and\r\nanother procession of gift-bringers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither go they?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a bystander.\r\n\r\nAnother made answer, \xe2\x80\x9cThe bull to Father Jove; the goat\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid not Apollo once keep the flocks of Admetus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, the goat to Apollo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe goodness of the reader is again besought in favor of an\r\nexplanation. A certain facility of accommodation in the matter of\r\nreligion comes to us after much intercourse with people of a different\r\nfaith; gradually we attain the truth that every creed is illustrated by\r\ngood men who are entitled to our respect, but whom we cannot respect\r\nwithout courtesy to their creed. To this point Ben-Hur had arrived.\r\nNeither the years in Rome nor those in the galley had made any\r\nimpression upon his religious faith; he was yet a Jew. In his view,\r\nnevertheless, it was not an impiety to look for the beautiful in the\r\nGrove of Daphne.\r\n\r\nThe remark does not interdict the further saying, if his scruples had\r\nbeen ever so extreme, not improbably he would at this time have\r\nsmothered them. He was angry; not as the irritable, from chafing of a\r\ntrifle; nor was his anger like the fool\xe2\x80\x99s, pumped from the wells of\r\nnothing, to be dissipated by a reproach or a curse; it was the wrath\r\npeculiar to ardent natures rudely awakened by the sudden annihilation\r\nof a hope\xe2\x80\x94dream, if you will\xe2\x80\x94in which the choicest happinesses were\r\nthought to be certainly in reach. In such case nothing intermediate\r\nwill carry off the passion\xe2\x80\x94the quarrel is with Fate.\r\n\r\nLet us follow the philosophy a little further, and say to ourselves, it\r\nwere well in such quarrels if Fate were something tangible, to be\r\ndespatched with a look or a blow, or a speaking personage with whom\r\nhigh words were possible; then the unhappy mortal would not always end\r\nthe affair by punishing himself.\r\n\r\nIn ordinary mood, Ben-Hur would not have come to the Grove alone, or,\r\ncoming alone, he would have availed himself of his position in the\r\nconsul\xe2\x80\x99s family, and made provision against wandering idly about,\r\nunknowing and unknown; he would have had all the points of interest in\r\nmind, and gone to them under guidance, as in the despatch of business;\r\nor, wishing to squander days of leisure in the beautiful place, he\r\nwould have had in hand a letter to the master of it all, whoever he\r\nmight be. This would have made him a sightseer, like the shouting herd\r\nhe was accompanying; whereas he had no reverence for the deities of the\r\nGrove, nor curiosity; a man in the blindness of bitter disappointment,\r\nhe was adrift, not waiting for Fate, but seeking it as a desperate\r\nchallenger.\r\n\r\nEvery one has known this condition of mind, though perhaps not all in\r\nthe same degree; every one will recognize it as the condition in which\r\nhe has done brave things with apparent serenity; and every one reading\r\nwill say, Fortunate for Ben-Hur if the folly which now catches him is\r\nbut a friendly harlequin with whistle and painted cap, and not some\r\nViolence with a pointed sword pitiless.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur entered the woods with the processions. He had not interest\r\nenough at first to ask where they were going; yet, to relieve him from\r\nabsolute indifference, he had a vague impression that they were in\r\nmovement to the temples, which were the central objects of the Grove,\r\nsupreme in attractions.\r\n\r\nPresently, as singers dreamfully play with a flitting chorus, he began\r\nrepeating to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cBetter be a worm, and feed on the mulberries of\r\nDaphne, than a king\xe2\x80\x99s guest.\xe2\x80\x9d Then of the much repetition arose\r\nquestions importunate of answer. Was life in the Grove so very sweet?\r\nWherein was the charm? Did it lie in some tangled depth of philosophy?\r\nOr was it something in fact, something on the surface, discernible to\r\nevery-day wakeful senses? Every year thousands, forswearing the world,\r\ngave themselves to service here. Did they find the charm? And was it\r\nsufficient, when found, to induce forgetfulness profound enough to shut\r\nout of mind the infinitely diverse things of life? those that sweeten\r\nand those that embitter? hopes hovering in the near future as well as\r\nsorrows born of the past? If the Grove were so good for them, why\r\nshould it not be good for him? He was a Jew; could it be that the\r\nexcellences were for all the world but children of Abraham? Forthwith\r\nhe bent all his faculties to the task of discovery, unmindful of the\r\nsinging of the gift-bringers and the quips of his associates.\r\n\r\nIn the quest, the sky yielded him nothing; it was blue, very blue, and\r\nfull of twittering swallows\xe2\x80\x94so was the sky over the city.\r\n\r\nFurther on, out of the woods at his right hand, a breeze poured across\r\nthe road, splashing him with a wave of sweet smells, blent of roses and\r\nconsuming spices. He stopped, as did others, looking the way the breeze\r\ncame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA garden over there?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, to a man at his elbow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather some priestly ceremony in performance\xe2\x80\x94something to Diana, or\r\nPan, or a deity of the woods.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer was in his mother tongue. Ben-Hur gave the speaker a\r\nsurprised look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Hebrew?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked him.\r\n\r\nThe man replied with a deferential smile,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was born within a stone\xe2\x80\x99s-throw of the market-place in Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was proceeding to further speech, when the crowd surged\r\nforward, thrusting him out on the side of the walk next the woods, and\r\ncarrying the stranger away. The customary gown and staff, a brown cloth\r\non the head tied by a yellow rope, and a strong Judean face to avouch\r\nthe garments of honest right, remained in the young man\xe2\x80\x99s mind, a kind\r\nof summary of the man.\r\n\r\nThis took place at a point where a path into the woods began, offering\r\na happy escape from the noisy processions. Ben-Hur availed himself of\r\nthe offer.\r\n\r\nHe walked first into a thicket which, from the road, appeared in a\r\nstate of nature, close, impenetrable, a nesting-place for wild birds. A\r\nfew steps, however, gave him to see the master\xe2\x80\x99s hand even there. The\r\nshrubs were flowering or fruit-bearing; under the bending branches the\r\nground was pranked with brightest blooms; over them the jasmine\r\nstretched its delicate bonds. From lilac and rose, and lily and tulip,\r\nfrom oleander and strawberry-tree, all old friends in the gardens of\r\nthe valleys about the city of David, the air, lingering or in haste,\r\nloaded itself with exhalations day and night; and that nothing might be\r\nwanting to the happiness of the nymphs and naiads, down through the\r\nflower-lighted shadows of the mass a brook went its course gently, and\r\nby many winding ways.\r\n\r\nOut of the thicket, as he proceeded, on his right and left, issued the\r\ncry of the pigeon and the cooing of turtle-doves; blackbirds waited for\r\nhim, and bided his coming close; a nightingale kept its place fearless,\r\nthough he passed in arm\xe2\x80\x99s-length; a quail ran before him at his feet,\r\nwhistling to the brood she was leading, and as he paused for them to\r\nget out of his way, a figure crawled from a bed of honeyed musk\r\nbrilliant with balls of golden blossoms. Ben-Hur was startled. Had he,\r\nindeed, been permitted to see a satyr at home? The creature looked up\r\nat him, and showed in its teeth a hooked pruning-knife; he smiled at\r\nhis own scare, and, lo! the charm was evolved! Peace without fear\xe2\x80\x94peace\r\na universal condition\xe2\x80\x94that it was!\r\n\r\nHe sat upon the ground beneath a citron-tree, which spread its gray\r\nroots sprawling to receive a branch of the brook. The nest of a\r\ntitmouse hung close to the bubbling water, and the tiny creature looked\r\nout of the door of the nest into his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cVerily, the bird is\r\ninterpreting to me,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cIt says, \xe2\x80\x98I am not afraid of you, for\r\nthe law of this happy place is Love.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe charm of the Grove seemed plain to him; he was glad, and determined\r\nto render himself one of the lost in Daphne. In charge of the flowers\r\nand shrubs, and watching the growth of all the dumb excellences\r\neverywhere to be seen, could not he, like the man with the\r\npruning-knife in his mouth, forego the days of his troubled life\xe2\x80\x94forego\r\nthem forgetting and forgotten?\r\n\r\nBut by-and-by his Jewish nature began to stir within him.\r\n\r\nThe charm might be sufficient for some people. Of what kind were they?\r\n\r\nLove is delightful\xe2\x80\x94ah! how pleasant as a successor to wretchedness like\r\nhis. But was it all there was of life? All?\r\n\r\nThere was an unlikeness between him and those who buried themselves\r\ncontentedly here. They had no duties\xe2\x80\x94they could not have had; but he\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod of Israel!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried aloud, springing to his feet, with burning\r\ncheeks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMother! Tirzah! Cursed be the moment, cursed the place, in\r\nwhich I yield myself happy in your loss!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hurried away through the thicket, and came to a stream flowing with\r\nthe volume of a river between banks of masonry, broken at intervals by\r\ngated sluiceways. A bridge carried the path he was traversing across\r\nthe stream; and, standing upon it, he saw other bridges, no two of them\r\nalike. Under him the water was lying in a deep pool, clear as a shadow;\r\ndown a little way it tumbled with a roar over rocks; then there was\r\nanother pool, and another cascade; and so on, out of view; and bridges\r\nand pools and resounding cascades said, plainly as inarticulate things\r\ncan tell a story, the river was running by permission of a master,\r\nexactly as the master would have it, tractable as became a servant of\r\nthe gods.\r\n\r\nForward from the bridge he beheld a landscape of wide valleys and\r\nirregular heights, with groves and lakes and fanciful houses linked\r\ntogether by white paths and shining streams. The valleys were spread\r\nbelow, that the river might be poured upon them for refreshment in days\r\nof drought, and they were as green carpets figured with beds and fields\r\nof flowers, and flecked with flocks of sheep white as balls of snow;\r\nand the voices of shepherds following the flocks were heard afar. As if\r\nto tell him of the pious inscription of all he beheld, the altars out\r\nunder the open sky seemed countless, each with a white-gowned figure\r\nattending it, while processions in white went slowly hither and thither\r\nbetween them; and the smoke of the altars half-risen hung collected in\r\npale clouds over the devoted places.\r\n\r\nHere, there, happy in flight, intoxicated in pause, from object to\r\nobject, point to point, now in the meadow, now on the heights, now\r\nlingering to penetrate the groves and observe the processions, then\r\nlost in efforts to pursue the paths and streams which trended mazily\r\ninto dim perspectives to end finally in\xe2\x80\x94 Ah, what might be a fitting\r\nend to scene so beautiful! What adequate mysteries were hidden behind\r\nan introduction so marvellous! Here and there, the speech was\r\nbeginning, his gaze wandered, so he could not help the conviction,\r\nforced by the view, and as the sum of it all, that there was peace in\r\nthe air and on the earth, and invitation everywhere to come and lie\r\ndown here and be at rest.\r\n\r\nSuddenly a revelation dawned upon him\xe2\x80\x94the Grove was, in fact, a\r\ntemple\xe2\x80\x94one far-reaching, wall-less temple!\r\n\r\nNever anything like it!\r\n\r\nThe architect had not stopped to pother about columns and porticos,\r\nproportions or interiors, or any limitation upon the epic he sought to\r\nmaterialize; he had simply made a servant of Nature\xe2\x80\x94art can go no\r\nfurther. So the cunning son of Jupiter and Callisto built the old\r\nArcadia; and in this, as in that, the genius was Greek.\r\n\r\nFrom the bridge Ben-Hur went forward into the nearest valley.\r\n\r\nHe came to a flock of sheep. The shepherd was a girl, and she beckoned\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFarther on, the path was divided by an altar\xe2\x80\x94a pedestal of black\r\ngneiss, capped with a slab of white marble deftly foliated, and on that\r\na brazier of bronze holding a fire. Close by it, a woman, seeing him,\r\nwaved a wand of willow, and as he passed called him, \xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d And the\r\ntemptation in her smile was that of passionate youth.\r\n\r\nOn yet further, he met one of the processions; at its head a troop of\r\nlittle girls, nude except as they were covered with garlands, piped\r\ntheir shrill voices into a song; then a troop of boys, also nude, their\r\nbodies deeply sun-browned, came dancing to the song of the girls;\r\nbehind them the procession, all women, bearing baskets of spices and\r\nsweets to the altars\xe2\x80\x94women clad in simple robes, careless of exposure.\r\nAs he went by they held their hands to him, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cStay, and go\r\nwith us.\xe2\x80\x9d One, a Greek, sang a verse from Anacreon:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor to-day I take or give;\r\nFor to-day I drink and live;\r\nFor to-day I beg or borrow;\r\nWho knows about the silent morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBut he pursued his way indifferent, and came next to a grove luxuriant,\r\nin the heart of the vale at the point where it would be most attractive\r\nto the observing eye. As it came close to the path he was travelling,\r\nthere was a seduction in its shade, and through the foliage he caught\r\nthe shining of what appeared a pretentious statue; so he turned aside,\r\nand entered the cool retreat.\r\n\r\nThe grass was fresh and clean. The trees did not crowd each other; and\r\nthey were of every kind native to the East, blended well with strangers\r\nadopted from far quarters; here grouped in exclusive companionship\r\npalm-trees plumed like queens; there sycamores, overtopping laurels of\r\ndarker foliage; and evergreen oaks rising verdantly, with cedars vast\r\nenough to be kings on Lebanon; and mulberries; and terebinths so\r\nbeautiful it is not hyperbole to speak of them as blown from the\r\norchards of Paradise.\r\n\r\nThe statue proved to be a Daphne of wondrous beauty. Hardly, however,\r\nhad he time to more than glance at her face: at the base of the\r\npedestal a girl and a youth were lying upon a tiger\xe2\x80\x99s skin asleep in\r\neach other\xe2\x80\x99s arms; close by them the implements of their service\xe2\x80\x94his\r\naxe and sickle, her basket\xe2\x80\x94flung carelessly upon a heap of fading\r\nroses.\r\n\r\nThe exposure startled him. Back in the hush of the perfumed thicket he\r\ndiscovered, as he thought, that the charm of the great Grove was peace\r\nwithout fear, and almost yielded to it; now, in this sleep in the day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbroad glare\xe2\x80\x94this sleep at the feet of Daphne\xe2\x80\x94he read a further chapter\r\nto which only the vaguest allusion is sufferable. The law of the place\r\nwas Love, but Love without Law.\r\n\r\nAnd this was the sweet peace of Daphne!\r\n\r\nThis the life\xe2\x80\x99s end of her ministers!\r\n\r\nFor this kings and princes gave of their revenues!\r\n\r\nFor this a crafty priesthood subordinated nature\xe2\x80\x94her birds and brooks\r\nand lilies, the river, the labor of many hands, the sanctity of altars,\r\nthe fertile power of the sun!\r\n\r\nIt would be pleasant now to record that as Ben-Hur pursued his walk\r\nassailed by such reflections, he yielded somewhat to sorrow for the\r\nvotaries of the great outdoor temple; especially for those who, by\r\npersonal service, kept it in a state so surpassingly lovely. How they\r\ncame to the condition was not any longer a mystery; the motive, the\r\ninfluence, the inducement, were before him. Some there were, no doubt,\r\ncaught by the promise held out to their troubled spirits of endless\r\npeace in a consecrated abode, to the beauty of which, if they had not\r\nmoney, they could contribute their labor; this class implied intellect\r\npeculiarly subject to hope and fear; but the great body of the faithful\r\ncould not be classed with such. Apollo\xe2\x80\x99s nets were wide, and their\r\nmeshes small; and hardly may one tell what all his fishermen landed:\r\nthis less for that they cannot be described than because they ought not\r\nto be. Enough that the mass were of the sybarites of the world, and of\r\nthe herds in number vaster and in degree lower\xe2\x80\x94devotees of the unmixed\r\nsensualism to which the East was almost wholly given. Not to any of the\r\nexaltations\xe2\x80\x94not to the singing-god, or his unhappy mistress; not to any\r\nphilosophy requiring for its enjoyment the calm of retirement, nor to\r\nany service for the comfort there is in religion, nor to love in its\r\nholier sense\xe2\x80\x94were they abiding their vows. Good reader, why shall not\r\nthe truth be told here? Why not learn that, at this age, there were in\r\nall earth but two peoples capable of exaltations of the kind referred\r\nto\xe2\x80\x94those who lived by the law of Moses, and those who lived by the law\r\nof Brahma. They alone could have cried you, Better a law without love\r\nthan a love without law.\r\n\r\nBesides that, sympathy is in great degree a result of the mood we are\r\nin at the moment: anger forbids the emotion. On the other hand, it is\r\neasiest taken on when we are in a state of most absolute\r\nself-satisfaction. Ben-Hur walked with a quicker step, holding his head\r\nhigher; and, while not less sensitive to the delightfulness of all\r\nabout him, he made his survey with calmer spirit, though sometimes with\r\ncurling lip; that is to say, he could not so soon forget how nearly he\r\nhimself had been imposed upon.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nIn front of Ben-Hur there was a forest of cypress-trees, each a column\r\ntall and straight as a mast. Venturing into the shady precinct, he\r\nheard a trumpet gayly blown, and an instant after saw lying upon the\r\ngrass close by the countryman whom he had run upon in the road going to\r\nthe temples. The man arose, and came to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you peace again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pleasantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied, then asked, \xe2\x80\x9cGo you my way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am for the stadium, if that is your way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stadium!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. The trumpet you heard but now was a call for the competitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, frankly, \xe2\x80\x9cI admit my ignorance of the\r\nGrove; and if you will let me be your follower, I will be glad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will delight me. Hark! I hear the wheels of the chariots. They\r\nare taking the track.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur listened a moment, then completed the introduction by laying\r\nhis hand upon the man\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI am the son of Arrius, the\r\nduumvir, and thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Malluch, a merchant of Antioch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good Malluch, the trumpet, and the gride of wheels, and the\r\nprospect of diversion excite me. I have some skill in the exercises. In\r\nthe palaestrae of Rome I am not unknown. Let us to the course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch lingered to say, quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cThe duumvir was a Roman, yet I see\r\nhis son in the garments of a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe noble Arrius was my father by adoption,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I see, and beg pardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPassing through the belt of forest, they came to a field with a track\r\nlaid out upon it, in shape and extent exactly like those of the stadia.\r\nThe course, or track proper, was of soft earth, rolled and sprinkled,\r\nand on both sides defined by ropes, stretched loosely upon upright\r\njavelins. For the accommodation of spectators, and such as had\r\ninterests reaching forward of the mere practise, there were several\r\nstands shaded by substantial awnings, and provided with seats in rising\r\nrows. In one of the stands the two new-comers found places.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur counted the chariots as they went by\xe2\x80\x94nine in all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI commend the fellows,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with good-will. \xe2\x80\x9cHere in the East, I\r\nthought they aspired to nothing better than the two; but they are\r\nambitious, and play with royal fours. Let us study their performance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEight of the fours passed the stand, some walking, others on the trot,\r\nand all unexceptionably handled; then the ninth one came on the gallop.\r\nBen-Hur burst into exclamation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been in the stables of the emperor, Malluch, but, by our father\r\nAbraham of blessed memory! I never saw the like of these.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last four was then sweeping past. All at once they fell into\r\nconfusion. Some one on the stand uttered a sharp cry. Ben-Hur turned,\r\nand saw an old man half-risen from an upper seat, his hands clenched\r\nand raised, his eyes fiercely bright, his long white beard fairly\r\nquivering. Some of the spectators nearest him began to laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey should respect his beard at least. Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mighty man from the Desert, somewhere beyond Moab, and owner of\r\ncamels in herds, and horses descended, they say, from the racers of the\r\nfirst Pharaoh\xe2\x80\x94Sheik Ilderim by name and title.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus Malluch replied.\r\n\r\nThe driver meanwhile exerted himself to quiet the four, but without\r\navail. Each ineffectual effort excited the sheik the more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbaddon seize him!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled the patriarch, shrilly. \xe2\x80\x9cRun! fly! do you\r\nhear, my children?\xe2\x80\x9d The question was to his attendants, apparently of\r\nthe tribe. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear? They are Desert-born, like yourselves. Catch\r\nthem\xe2\x80\x94quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe plunging of the animals increased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccursed Roman!\xe2\x80\x9d and the sheik shook his fist at the driver. \xe2\x80\x9cDid he\r\nnot swear he could drive them\xe2\x80\x94swear it by all his brood of bastard\r\nLatin gods? Nay, hands off me\xe2\x80\x94off, I say! They should run swift as\r\neagles, and with the temper of hand-bred lambs, he swore. Cursed be\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x94cursed the mother of liars who calls him son! See them, the\r\npriceless! Let him touch one of them with a lash, and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the rest of the\r\nsentence was lost in a furious grinding of his teeth. \xe2\x80\x9cTo their heads,\r\nsome of you, and speak them\xe2\x80\x94a word, one is enough, from the tent-song\r\nyour mothers sang you. Oh, fool, fool that I was to put trust in a\r\nRoman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome of the shrewder of the old man\xe2\x80\x99s friends planted themselves\r\nbetween him and the horses. An opportune failure of breath on his part\r\nhelped the stratagem.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur, thinking he comprehended the sheik, sympathized with him. Far\r\nmore than mere pride of property\xe2\x80\x94more than anxiety for the result of\r\nthe race\xe2\x80\x94in his view it was within the possible for the patriarch,\r\naccording to his habits of thought and his ideas of the inestimable, to\r\nlove such animals with a tenderness akin to the most sensitive passion.\r\n\r\nThey were all bright bays, unspotted, perfectly matched, and so\r\nproportioned as to seem less than they really were. Delicate ears\r\npointed small heads; the faces were broad and full between the eyes;\r\nthe nostrils in expansion disclosed membrane so deeply red as to\r\nsuggest the flashing of flame; the necks were arches, overlaid with\r\nfine mane so abundant as to drape the shoulders and breast, while in\r\nhappy consonance the forelocks were like ravellings of silken veils;\r\nbetween the knees and the fetlocks the legs were flat as an open hand,\r\nbut above the knees they were rounded with mighty muscles, needful to\r\nupbear the shapely close-knit bodies; the hoofs were like cups of\r\npolished agate; and in rearing and plunging they whipped the air, and\r\nsometimes the earth, with tails glossy-black and thick and long. The\r\nsheik spoke of them as the priceless, and it was a good saying.\r\n\r\nIn this second and closer look at the horses, Ben-Hur read the story of\r\ntheir relation to their master. They had grown up under his eyes,\r\nobjects of his special care in the day, his visions of pride in the\r\nnight, with his family at home in the black tent out on the shadeless\r\nbosom of the desert, as his children beloved. That they might win him a\r\ntriumph over the haughty and hated Roman, the old man had brought his\r\nloves to the city, never doubting they would win, if only he could find\r\na trusty expert to take them in hand; not merely one with skill, but of\r\na spirit which their spirits would acknowledge. Unlike the colder\r\npeople of the West, he could not protest the driver\xe2\x80\x99s inability, and\r\ndismiss him civilly; an Arab and a sheik, he had to explode, and rive\r\nthe air about him with clamor.\r\n\r\nBefore the patriarch was done with his expletives, a dozen hands were\r\nat the bits of the horses, and their quiet assured. About that time,\r\nanother chariot appeared upon the track; and, unlike the others,\r\ndriver, vehicle, and races were precisely as they would be presented in\r\nthe Circus the day of final trial. For a reason which will presently be\r\nmore apparent, it is desirable now to give this turnout plainly to the\r\nreader.\r\n\r\nThere should be no difficulty in understanding the carriage known to us\r\nall as the chariot of classical renown. One has but to picture to\r\nhimself a dray with low wheels and broad axle, surmounted by a box open\r\nat the tail end. Such was the primitive pattern. Artistic genius came\r\nalong in time, and, touching the rude machine, raised it into a thing\r\nof beauty\xe2\x80\x94that, for instance, in which Aurora, riding in advance of the\r\ndawn, is given to our fancy.\r\n\r\nThe jockeys of the ancients, quite as shrewd and ambitious as their\r\nsuccessors of the present, called their humblest turnout a two, and\r\ntheir best in grade a four; in the latter, they contested the Olympics\r\nand the other festal shows founded in imitation of them.\r\n\r\nThe same sharp gamesters preferred to put their horses to the chariot\r\nall abreast; and for distinction they termed the two next the pole\r\nyoke-steeds, and those on the right and left outside trace-mates. It\r\nwas their judgment, also, that, by allowing the fullest freedom of\r\naction, the greatest speed was attainable; accordingly, the harness\r\nresorted to was peculiarly simple; in fact, there was nothing of it\r\nsave a collar round the animal\xe2\x80\x99s neck, and a trace fixed to the collar,\r\nunless the lines and a halter fall within the term. Wanting to hitch\r\nup, the masters pinned a narrow wooden yoke, or cross-tree, near the\r\nend of the pole, and, by straps passed through rings at the end of the\r\nyoke, buckled the latter to the collar. The traces of the yokesteeds\r\nthey hitched to the axle; those of the trace-mates to the top rim of\r\nthe chariot-bed. There remained then but the adjustment of the lines,\r\nwhich, judged by the modern devices, was not the least curious part of\r\nthe method. For this there was a large ring at the forward extremity of\r\nthe pole; securing the ends to that ring first, they parted the lines\r\nso as to give one to each horse, and proceeded to pass them to the\r\ndriver, slipping them separately through rings on the inner side of the\r\nhalters at the mouth.\r\n\r\nWith this plain generalization in mind, all further desirable knowledge\r\nupon the subject can be had by following the incidents of the scene\r\noccurring.\r\n\r\nThe other contestants had been received in silence; the last comer was\r\nmore fortunate. While moving towards the stand from which we are\r\nviewing the scene, his progress was signalized by loud demonstrations,\r\nby clapping of hands and cheers, the effect of which was to centre\r\nattention upon him exclusively. His yoke-steeds, it was observed, were\r\nblack, while the trace-mates were snow-white. In conformity to the\r\nexacting canons of Roman taste, they had all four been mutilated; that\r\nis to say, their tails had been clipped, and, to complete the\r\nbarbarity, their shorn manes were divided into knots tied with flaring\r\nred and yellow ribbons.\r\n\r\nIn advancing, the stranger at length reached a point where the chariot\r\ncame into view from the stand, and its appearance would of itself have\r\njustified the shouting. The wheels were very marvels of construction.\r\nStout bands of burnished bronze reinforced the hubs, otherwise very\r\nlight; the spokes were sections of ivory tusks, set in with the natural\r\ncurve outward to perfect the dishing, considered important then as now;\r\nbronze tires held the fellies, which were of shining ebony. The axle,\r\nin keeping with the wheels, was tipped with heads of snarling tigers\r\ndone in brass, and the bed was woven of willow wands gilded with gold.\r\n\r\nThe coming of the beautiful horses and resplendent chariot drew Ben-Hur\r\nto look at the driver with increased interest.\r\n\r\nWho was he?\r\n\r\nWhen Ben-Hur asked himself the question first, he could not see the\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s face, or even his full figure; yet the air and manner were\r\nfamiliar, and pricked him keenly with a reminder of a period long gone.\r\n\r\nWho could it be?\r\n\r\nNearer now, and the horses approaching at a trot. From the shouting and\r\nthe gorgeousness of the turnout, it was thought he might be some\r\nofficial favorite or famous prince. Such an appearance was not\r\ninconsistent with exalted rank. Kings often struggled for the crown of\r\nleaves which was the prize of victory. Nero and Commodus, it will be\r\nremembered, devoted themselves to the chariot. Ben-Hur arose and forced\r\na passage down nearly to the railing in front of the lower seat of the\r\nstand. His face was earnest, his manner eager.\r\n\r\nAnd directly the whole person of the driver was in view. A companion\r\nrode with him, in classic description a Myrtilus, permitted men of high\r\nestate indulging their passion for the race-course. Ben-Hur could see\r\nonly the driver, standing erect in the chariot, with the reins passed\r\nseveral times round his body\xe2\x80\x94a handsome figure, scantily covered by a\r\ntunic of light-red cloth; in the right hand a whip; in the other, the\r\narm raised and lightly extended, the four lines. The pose was\r\nexceedingly graceful and animated. The cheers and clapping of hands\r\nwere received with statuesque indifference. Ben-Hur stood\r\ntransfixed\xe2\x80\x94his instinct and memory had served him faithfully\xe2\x80\x94THE DRIVER\r\nWAS MESSALA.\r\n\r\nBy the selection of horses, the magnificence of the chariot, the\r\nattitude, and display of person\xe2\x80\x94above all, by the expression of the\r\ncold, sharp, eagle features, imperialized in his countrymen by sway of\r\nthe world through so many generations, Ben-Hur knew Messala unchanged,\r\nas haughty, confident, and audacious as ever, the same in ambition,\r\ncynicism, and mocking insouciance.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Ben-Hur descended the steps of the stand, an Arab arose upon the\r\nlast one at the foot, and cried out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen of the East and West\xe2\x80\x94hearken! The good Sheik Ilderim giveth\r\ngreeting. With four horses, sons of the favorites of Solomon the Wise,\r\nhe hath come up against the best. Needs he most a mighty man to drive\r\nthem. Whoso will take them to his satisfaction, to him he promiseth\r\nenrichment forever. Here\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x94in the city and in the Circuses, and\r\nwherever the strong most do congregate, tell ye this his offer. So\r\nsaith my master, Sheik Ilderim the Generous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe proclamation awakened a great buzz among the people under the\r\nawning. By night it would be repeated and discussed in all the sporting\r\ncircles of Antioch. Ben-Hur, hearing it, stopped and looked\r\nhesitatingly from the herald to the sheik. Malluch thought he was about\r\nto accept the offer, but was relieved when he presently turned to him,\r\nand asked, \xe2\x80\x9cGood Malluch, where to now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe worthy replied, with a laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cWould you liken yourself to others\r\nvisiting the Grove for the first time, you will straightway to hear\r\nyour fortune told.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy fortune, said you? Though the suggestion has in it a flavor of\r\nunbelief, let us to the goddess at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, son of Arrius, these Apollonians have a better trick than that.\r\nInstead of speech with a Pythia or a Sibyl, they will sell you a plain\r\npapyrus leaf, hardly dry from the stalk, and bid you dip it in the\r\nwater of a certain fountain, when it will show you a verse in which you\r\nmay hear of your future.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe glow of interest departed from Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are people who have no need to vex themselves about their\r\nfuture,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gloomily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you prefer to go to the temples?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe temples are Greek, are they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey call them Greek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Hellenes were masters of the beautiful in art; but in architecture\r\nthey sacrificed variety to unbending beauty. Their temples are all\r\nalike. How call you the fountain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCastalia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! it has repute throughout the world. Let us thither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch kept watch on his companion as they went, and saw that for the\r\nmoment at least his good spirits were out. To the people passing he\r\ngave no attention; over the wonders they came upon there were no\r\nexclamations; silently, even sullenly, he kept a slow pace.\r\n\r\nThe truth was, the sight of Messala had set Ben-Hur to thinking. It\r\nseemed scarce an hour ago that the strong hands had torn him from his\r\nmother, scarce an hour ago that the Roman had put seal upon the gates\r\nof his father\xe2\x80\x99s house. He recounted how, in the hopeless misery of the\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94if such it might be called\xe2\x80\x94in the galleys, he had had little else\r\nto do, aside from labor, than dream dreams of vengeance, in all of\r\nwhich Messala was the principal. There might be, he used to say to\r\nhimself, escape for Gratus, but for Messala\xe2\x80\x94never!
