And to strengthen\r\nand harden his resolution, he was accustomed to repeat over and over,\r\nWho pointed us out to the persecutors? And when I begged him for\r\nhelp\xe2\x80\x94not for myself\xe2\x80\x94who mocked me, and went away laughing? And always\r\nthe dream had the same ending. The day I meet him, help me, thou good\r\nGod of my people!\xe2\x80\x94help me to some fitting special vengeance!\r\n\r\nAnd now the meeting was at hand.\r\n\r\nPerhaps, if he had found Messala poor and suffering, Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s feeling\r\nhad been different; but it was not so. He found him more than\r\nprosperous; in the prosperity there was a dash and glitter\xe2\x80\x94gleam of sun\r\non gilt of gold.\r\n\r\nSo it happened that what Malluch accounted a passing loss of spirit was\r\npondering when the meeting should be, and in what manner he could make\r\nit most memorable.\r\n\r\nThey turned after a while into an avenue of oaks, where the people were\r\ngoing and coming in groups; footmen here, and horsemen; there women in\r\nlitters borne slaves; and now and then chariots rolled by thunderously.\r\n\r\nAt the end of the avenue the road, by an easy grade, descended into a\r\nlowland, where, on the right hand, there was a precipitous facing of\r\ngray rock, and on the left an open meadow of vernal freshness. Then\r\nthey came in view of the famous Fountain of Castalia.\r\n\r\nEdging through a company assembled at the point, Ben-Hur beheld a jet\r\nof sweet water pouring from the crest of a stone into a basin of black\r\nmarble, where, after much boiling and foaming, it disappeared as\r\nthrough a funnel.\r\n\r\nBy the basin, under a small portico cut in the solid wall, sat a\r\npriest, old, bearded, wrinkled, cowled\xe2\x80\x94never being more perfectly\r\neremitish. From the manner of the people present, hardly might one say\r\nwhich was the attraction, the fountain, forever sparkling, or the\r\npriest, forever there. He heard, saw, was seen, but never spoke.\r\nOccasionally a visitor extended a hand to him with a coin in it. With a\r\ncunning twinkle of the eyes, he took the money, and gave the party in\r\nexchange a leaf of papyrus.\r\n\r\nThe receiver made haste to plunge the papyrus into the basin; then,\r\nholding the dripping leaf in the sunlight, he would be rewarded with a\r\nversified inscription upon its face; and the fame of the fountain\r\nseldom suffered loss by poverty of merit in the poetry. Before Ben-Hur\r\ncould test the oracle, some other visitors were seen approaching across\r\nthe meadow, and their appearance piqued the curiosity of the company,\r\nhis not less than theirs.\r\n\r\nHe saw first a camel, very tall and very white, in leading of a driver\r\non horseback. A houdah on the animal, besides being unusually large,\r\nwas of crimson and gold. Two other horsemen followed the camel with\r\ntall spears in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a wonderful camel!\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA prince from afar,\xe2\x80\x9d another one suggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore likely a king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he were on an elephant, I would say he was a king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA third man had a very different opinion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA camel\xe2\x80\x94and a white camel!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, authoritatively. \xe2\x80\x9cBy Apollo,\r\nfriends, they who come yonder\xe2\x80\x94you can see there are two of them\xe2\x80\x94are\r\nneither kings nor princes; they are women!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the dispute the strangers arrived.\r\n\r\nThe camel seen at hand did not belie his appearance afar. A taller,\r\nstatelier brute of his kind no traveller at the fountain, though from\r\nthe remotest parts, had ever beheld. Such great black eyes! such\r\nexceedingly fine white hair! feet so contractile when raised, so\r\nsoundless in planting, so broad when set!\xe2\x80\x94nobody had ever seen the peer\r\nof this camel. And how well he became his housing of silk, and all its\r\nfrippery of gold in fringe and gold in tassel! The tinkling of silver\r\nbells went before him, and he moved lightly, as if unknowing of his\r\nburden.\r\n\r\nBut who were the man and woman under the houdah?\r\n\r\nEvery eye saluted them with the inquiry.\r\n\r\nIf the former were a prince or a king, the philosophers of the crowd\r\nmight not deny the impartiality of Time. When they saw the thin,\r\nshrunken face buried under an immense turban, the skin of the hue of a\r\nmummy, making it impossible to form an idea of his nationality, they\r\nwere pleased to think the limit of life was for the great as well as\r\nthe small. They saw about his person nothing so enviable as the shawl\r\nwhich draped him.\r\n\r\nThe woman was seated in the manner of the East, amidst veils and laces\r\nof surpassing fineness. Above her elbows she wore armlets fashioned\r\nlike coiled asps, and linked to bracelets at the wrists by strands of\r\ngold; otherwise the arms were bare and of singular natural grace,\r\ncomplemented with hands modelled daintily as a child\xe2\x80\x99s. One of the\r\nhands rested upon the side of the carriage, showing tapered fingers\r\nglittering with rings, and stained at the tips till they blushed like\r\nthe pink of mother-of-pearl. She wore an open caul upon her head,\r\nsprinkled with beads of coral, and strung with coin-pieces called\r\nsunlets, some of which were carried across her forehead, while others\r\nfell down her back, half-smothered in the mass of her straight\r\nblue-black hair, of itself an incomparable ornament, not needing the\r\nveil which covered it, except as a protection against sun and dust.\r\nFrom her elevated seat she looked upon the people calmly, pleasantly,\r\nand apparently so intent upon studying them as to be unconscious of the\r\ninterest she herself was exciting; and, what was unusual\xe2\x80\x94nay, in\r\nviolent contravention of the custom among women of rank in public\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nlooked at them with an open face.\r\n\r\nIt was a fair face to see; quite youthful; in form, oval: complexion\r\nnot white, like the Greek; nor brunet, like the Roman; nor blond, like\r\nthe Gaul; but rather the tinting of the sun of the Upper Nile upon a\r\nskin of such transparency that the blood shone through it on cheek and\r\nbrow with nigh the ruddiness of lamplight. The eyes, naturally large,\r\nwere touched along the lids with the black paint immemorial throughout\r\nthe East. The lips were slightly parted, disclosing, through their\r\nscarlet lake, teeth of glistening whiteness. To all these excellences\r\nof countenance the reader is finally besought to superadd the air\r\nderived from the pose of a small head, classic in shape, set upon a\r\nneck long, drooping, and graceful\xe2\x80\x94the air, we may fancy, happily\r\ndescribed by the word queenly.\r\n\r\nAs if satisfied with the survey of people and locality, the fair\r\ncreature spoke to the driver\xe2\x80\x94an Ethiopian of vast brawn, naked to the\r\nwaist\xe2\x80\x94who led the camel nearer the fountain, and caused it to kneel;\r\nafter which he received from her hand a cup, and proceeded to fill it\r\nat the basin. That instant the sound of wheels and the trampling of\r\nhorses in rapid motion broke the silence her beauty had imposed, and,\r\nwith a great outcry, the bystanders parted in every direction, hurrying\r\nto get away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Roman has a mind to ride us down. Look out!\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch shouted to\r\nBen-Hur, setting him at the same time an example of hasty flight.\r\n\r\nThe latter faced to the direction the sounds came from, and beheld\r\nMessala in his chariot pushing the four straight at the crowd. This\r\ntime the view was near and distinct.\r\n\r\nThe parting of the company uncovered the camel, which might have been\r\nmore agile than his kind generally; yet the hoofs were almost upon him,\r\nand he resting with closed eyes, chewing the endless cud with such\r\nsense of security as long favoritism may be supposed to have bred in\r\nhim. The Ethiopian wrung his hands afraid. In the houdah, the old man\r\nmoved to escape; but he was hampered with age, and could not, even in\r\nthe face of danger, forget the dignity which was plainly his habit. It\r\nwas too late for the woman to save herself. Ben-Hur stood nearest them,\r\nand he called to Messala,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold! Look where thou goest! Back, back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe patrician was laughing in hearty good-humor; and, seeing there was\r\nbut one chance of rescue, Ben-Hur stepped in, and caught the bits of\r\nthe left yoke-steed and his mate. \xe2\x80\x9cDog of a Roman! Carest thou so\r\nlittle for life?\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, putting forth all his strength. The two\r\nhorses reared, and drew the others round; the tilting of the pole\r\ntilted the chariot; Messala barely escaped a fall, while his complacent\r\nMyrtilus rolled back like a clod to the ground. Seeing the peril past,\r\nall the bystanders burst into derisive laughter.\r\n\r\nThe matchless audacity of the Roman then manifested itself. Loosing the\r\nlines from his body, he tossed them to one side, dismounted, walked\r\nround the camel, looked at Ben-Hur, and spoke partly to the old man and\r\npartly to the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, I pray you\xe2\x80\x94I pray you both. I am Messala,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand, by\r\nthe old Mother of the earth, I swear I did not see you or your camel!\r\nAs to these good people\xe2\x80\x94perhaps I trusted too much to my skill. I\r\nsought a laugh at them\xe2\x80\x94the laugh is theirs. Good may it do them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe good-natured, careless look and gesture he threw the bystanders\r\naccorded well with the speech. To hear what more he had to say, they\r\nbecame quiet. Assured of victory over the body of the offended, he\r\nsigned his companion to take the chariot to a safer distance, and\r\naddressed himself boldly to the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast interest in the good man here, whose pardon, if not granted\r\nnow, I shall seek with the greater diligence hereafter; his daughter, I\r\nshould say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made him no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Pallas, thou art beautiful! Beware Apollo mistake thee not for his\r\nlost love. I wonder what land can boast herself thy mother. Turn not\r\naway. A truce! a truce! There is the sun of India in thine eyes; in the\r\ncorners of thy mouth, Egypt hath set her love-signs. Perpol! Turn not\r\nto that slave, fair mistress, before proving merciful to this one. Tell\r\nme at least that I am pardoned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point she broke in upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilt thou come here?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, smiling, and with gracious bend of\r\nthe head to Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake the cup and fill it, I pray thee,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the latter. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nfather is thirsty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am thy most willing servant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur turned about to do the favor, and was face to face with\r\nMessala. Their glances met; the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s defiant; the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s sparkling\r\nwith humor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO stranger, beautiful as cruel!\xe2\x80\x9d Messala said, waving his hand to her.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Apollo get thee not, thou shalt see me again. Not knowing thy\r\ncountry, I cannot name a god to commend thee to; so, by all the gods, I\r\nwill commend thee to\xe2\x80\x94myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeeing that Myrtilus had the four composed and ready, he returned to\r\nthe chariot. The woman looked after him as he moved away, and whatever\r\nelse there was in her look, there was no displeasure. Presently she\r\nreceived the water; her father drank; then she raised the cup to her\r\nlips, and, leaning down, gave it to Ben-Hur; never action more graceful\r\nand gracious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep it, we pray of thee! It is full of blessings\xe2\x80\x94all thine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nImmediately the camel was aroused, and on his feet, and about to go,\r\nwhen the old man called,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand thou here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur went to him respectfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast served the stranger well to-day. There is but one God. In\r\nhis holy name I thank thee. I am Balthasar, the Egyptian. In the Great\r\nOrchard of Palms, beyond the village of Daphne, in the shade of the\r\npalms, Sheik Ilderim the Generous abideth in his tents, and we are his\r\nguests. Seek us there. Thou shalt have welcome sweet with the savor of\r\nthe grateful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was left in wonder at the old man\xe2\x80\x99s clear voice and reverend\r\nmanner. As he gazed after the two departing, he caught sight of Messala\r\ngoing as he had come, joyous, indifferent, and with a mocking laugh.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\nAs a rule, there is no surer way to the dislike of men than to behave\r\nwell where they have behaved badly. In this instance, happily, Malluch\r\nwas an exception to the rule. The affair he had just witnessed raised\r\nBen-Hur in his estimation, since he could not deny him courage and\r\naddress; could he now get some insight into the young man\xe2\x80\x99s history,\r\nthe results of the day would not be all unprofitable to good master\r\nSimonides.\r\n\r\nOn the latter point, referring to what he had as yet learned, two facts\r\ncomprehended it all\xe2\x80\x94the subject of his investigation was a Jew, and the\r\nadopted son of a famous Roman. Another conclusion which might be of\r\nimportance was beginning to formulate itself in the shrewd mind of the\r\nemissary; between Messala and the son of the duumvir there was a\r\nconnection of some kind. But what was it?\xe2\x80\x94and how could it be reduced\r\nto assurance? With all his sounding, the ways and means of solution\r\nwere not at call. In the heat of the perplexity, Ben-Hur himself came\r\nto his help. He laid his hand on Malluch\xe2\x80\x99s arm and drew him out of the\r\ncrowd, which was already going back to its interest in the gray old\r\npriest and the mystic fountain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Malluch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stopping, \xe2\x80\x9cmay a man forget his mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question was abrupt and without direction, and therefore of the\r\nkind which leaves the person addressed in a state of confusion. Malluch\r\nlooked into Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face for a hint of meaning, but saw, instead, two\r\nbright-red spots, one on each cheek, and in his eyes traces of what\r\nmight have been repressed tears; then he answered, mechanically, \xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadding, with fervor, \xe2\x80\x9cnever;\xe2\x80\x9d and a moment after, when he began to\r\nrecover himself, \xe2\x80\x9cIf he is an Israelite, never!\xe2\x80\x9d And when at length he\r\nwas completely recovered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMy first lesson in the synagogue was the\r\nShema; my next was the saying of the son of Sirach, \xe2\x80\x98Honor thy father\r\nwith thy whole soul, and forget not the sorrows of thy mother.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe red spots on Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face deepened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe words bring my childhood back again; and, Malluch, they prove you\r\na genuine Jew. I believe I can trust you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur let go the arm he was holding, and caught the folds of the gown\r\ncovering his own breast, and pressed them close, as if to smother a\r\npain, or a feeling there as sharp as a pain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbore a good name, and was not without honor in\r\nJerusalem, where he dwelt. My mother, at his death, was in the prime of\r\nwomanhood; and it is not enough to say of her she was good and\r\nbeautiful: in her tongue was the law of kindness, and her works were\r\nthe praise of all in the gates, and she smiled at days to come. I had a\r\nlittle sister, and she and I were the family, and we were so happy that\r\nI, at least, have never seen harm in the saying of the old rabbi, \xe2\x80\x98God\r\ncould not be everywhere, and, therefore, he made mothers.\xe2\x80\x99 One day an\r\naccident happened to a Roman in authority as he was riding past our\r\nhouse at the head of a cohort; the legionaries burst the gate and\r\nrushed in and seized us. I have not seen my mother or sister since. I\r\ncannot say they are dead or living. I do not know what became of them.\r\nBut, Malluch, the man in the chariot yonder was present at the\r\nseparation; he gave us over to the captors; he heard my mother\xe2\x80\x99s prayer\r\nfor her children, and he laughed when they dragged her away. Hardly may\r\none say which graves deepest in memory, love or hate. To-day I knew him\r\nafar\xe2\x80\x94and, Malluch\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe caught the listener\xe2\x80\x99s arm again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, Malluch, he knows and takes with him now the secret I would give\r\nmy life for: he could tell if she lives, and where she is, and her\r\ncondition; if she\xe2\x80\x94no, THEY\xe2\x80\x94much sorrow has made the two as one\xe2\x80\x94if they\r\nare dead, he could tell where they died, and of what, and where their\r\nbones await my finding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a Jew, and he is a Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Romans have tongues, and Jews, though ever so despised, have\r\nmethods to beguile them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor such as he? No; and, besides, the secret is one of state. All my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s property was confiscated and divided.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch nodded his head slowly, much as to admit the argument; then he\r\nasked anew, \xe2\x80\x9cDid he not recognize you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe could not. I was sent to death in life, and have been long since\r\naccounted of the dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder you did not strike him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, yielding to a touch of\r\npassion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would have been to put him past serving me forever. I would have\r\nhad to kill him, and Death, you know, keeps secrets better even than a\r\nguilty Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man who, with so much to avenge, could so calmly put such an\r\nopportunity aside must be confident of his future or have ready some\r\nbetter design, and Malluch\xe2\x80\x99s interest changed with the thought; it\r\nceased to be that of an emissary in duty bound to another. Ben-Hur was\r\nactually asserting a claim upon him for his own sake. In other words,\r\nMalluch was preparing to serve him with good heart and from downright\r\nadmiration.\r\n\r\nAfter brief pause, Ben-Hur resumed speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would not take his life, good Malluch; against that extreme the\r\npossession of the secret is for the present, at least, his safeguard;\r\nyet I may punish him, and so you give me help, I will try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Roman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, without hesitation; \xe2\x80\x9cand I am of the\r\ntribe of Judah. I will help you. If you choose, put me under oath\xe2\x80\x94under\r\nthe most solemn oath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me your hand, that will suffice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs their hands fell apart, Ben-Hur said, with lightened feeling, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\r\nI would charge you with is not difficult, good friend; neither is it\r\ndreadful to conscience. Let us move on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey took the road which led to the right across the meadow spoken of\r\nin the description of the coming to the fountain. Ben-Hur was first to\r\nbreak the silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know Sheik Ilderim the Generous?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is his Orchard of Palms? or, rather, Malluch, how far is it\r\nbeyond the village of Daphne?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch was touched by a doubt; he recalled the prettiness of the favor\r\nshown him by the woman at the fountain, and wondered if he who had the\r\nsorrows of a mother in mind was about to forget them for a lure of\r\nlove; yet he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Orchard of Palms lies beyond the village two\r\nhours by horse, and one by swift camel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you; and to your knowledge once more. Have the games of which\r\nyou told me been widely published? and when will they take place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe questions were suggestive; and if they did not restore Malluch his\r\nconfidence, they at least stimulated his curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, they will be of ample splendor. The prefect is rich, and could\r\nafford to lose his place; yet, as is the way with successful men, his\r\nlove of riches is nowise diminished; and to gain a friend at court, if\r\nnothing more, he must make ado for the Consul Maxentius, who is coming\r\nhither to make final preparations for a campaign against the Parthians.\r\nThe money there is in the preparations the citizens of Antioch know\r\nfrom experience; so they have had permission to join the prefect in the\r\nhonors intended for the great man. A month ago heralds went to the four\r\nquarters to proclaim the opening of the Circus for the celebration. The\r\nname of the prefect would be of itself good guarantee of variety and\r\nmagnificence, particularly throughout the East; but when to his\r\npromises Antioch joins hers, all the islands and the cities by the sea\r\nstand assured of the extraordinary, and will be here in person or by\r\ntheir most famous professionals. The fees offered are royal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the Circus\xe2\x80\x94I have heard it is second only to the Maximus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Rome, you mean. Well, ours seats two hundred thousand people, yours\r\nseats seventy-five thousand more; yours is of marble, so is ours; in\r\narrangement they are exactly the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre the rules the same?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Antioch dared be original, son of Arrius, Rome would not be the\r\nmistress she is. The laws of the Circus Maximus govern except in one\r\nparticular: there but four chariots may start at once, here all start\r\nwithout reference to number.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the practise of the Greeks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Antioch is more Greek than Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then, Malluch, I may choose my own chariot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour own chariot and horses. There is no restriction upon either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile replying, Malluch observed the thoughtful look on Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\ngive place to one of satisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing more now, O Malluch. When will the celebration be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d the other answered. \xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow\xe2\x80\x94and the next day,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, counting aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cthen, to speak in the Roman style, if the\r\nsea-gods be propitious, the consul arrives. Yes, the sixth day from\r\nthis we have the games.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe time is short, Malluch, but it is enough.\xe2\x80\x9d The last words were\r\nspoken decisively. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the prophets of our old Israel! I will take to\r\nthe reins again. Stay! a condition; is there assurance that Messala\r\nwill be a competitor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch saw now the plan, and all its opportunities for the humiliation\r\nof the Roman; and he had not been true descendant of Jacob if, with all\r\nhis interest wakened, he had not rushed to a consideration of the\r\nchances. His voice actually trembled as he said, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you the\r\npractise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not, my friend. The winners in the Circus Maximus have held their\r\ncrowns these three years at my will. Ask them\xe2\x80\x94ask the best of them\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthey will tell you so. In the last great games the emperor himself\r\noffered me his patronage if I would take his horses in hand and run\r\nthem against the entries of the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you did not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch spoke eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94I am a Jew\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur seemed shrinking within himself as he\r\nspoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand, though I wear a Roman name, I dared not do professionally a\r\nthing to sully my father\xe2\x80\x99s name in the cloisters and courts of the\r\nTemple. In the palaestrae I could indulge practise which, if followed\r\ninto the Circus, would become an abomination; and if I take to the\r\ncourse here, Malluch, I swear it will not be for the prize or the\r\nwinner\xe2\x80\x99s fee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold\xe2\x80\x94swear not so!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Malluch. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fee is ten thousand\r\nsestertii\xe2\x80\x94a fortune for life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for me, though the prefect trebled it fifty times. Better than\r\nthat, better than all the imperial revenues from the first year of the\r\nfirst Caesar\xe2\x80\x94I will make this race to humble my enemy. Vengeance is\r\npermitted by the law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch smiled and nodded as if saying, \xe2\x80\x9cRight, right\xe2\x80\x94trust me a Jew to\r\nunderstand a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messala will drive,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, directly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is committed to the\r\nrace in many ways\xe2\x80\x94by publication in the streets, and in the baths and\r\ntheaters, the palace and barracks; and, to fix him past retreat, his\r\nname is on the tablets of every young spendthrift in Antioch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn wager, Malluch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in wager; and every day he comes ostentatiously to practise, as\r\nyou saw him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! and that is the chariot, and those the horses, with which he will\r\nmake the race? Thank you, thank you, Malluch! You have served me well\r\nalready. I am satisfied. Now be my guide to the Orchard of Palms, and\r\ngive me introduction to Sheik Ilderim the Generous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-day. His horses may be engaged to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou like them, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur answered with animation,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw them from the stand an instant only, for Messala then drove up,\r\nand I might not look at anything else; yet I recognized them as of the\r\nblood which is the wonder as well as the glory of the deserts. I never\r\nsaw the kind before, except in the stables of Caesar; but once seen,\r\nthey are always to be known. To-morrow, upon meeting, I will know you,\r\nMalluch, though you do not so much as salute me; I will know you by\r\nyour face, by your form, by your manner; and by the same signs I will\r\nknow them, and with the same certainty. If all that is said of them be\r\ntrue, and I can bring their spirit under control of mine, I can\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWin the sestertii!\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ben-Hur, as quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cI will do what better becomes a\r\nman born to the heritage of Jacob\xe2\x80\x94I will humble mine enemy in a most\r\npublic place. But,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are losing time. How can\r\nwe most quickly reach the tents of the sheik?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch took a moment for reflection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is best we go straight to the village, which is fortunately near\r\nby; if two swift camels are to be had for hire there, we will be on the\r\nroad but an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us about it, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe village was an assemblage of palaces in beautiful gardens,\r\ninterspersed with khans of princely sort. Dromedaries were happily\r\nsecured, and upon them the journey to the famous Orchard of Palms was\r\nbegun.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\n\r\nBeyond the village the country was undulating and cultivated; in fact,\r\nit was the garden-land of Antioch, with not a foot lost to labor. The\r\nsteep faces of the hills were terraced; even the hedges were brighter\r\nof the trailing vines which, besides the lure of shade, offered\r\npassers-by sweet promises of wine to come, and grapes in clustered\r\npurple ripeness. Over melon-patches, and through apricot and fig-tree\r\ngroves, and groves of oranges and limes, the white-washed houses of the\r\nfarmers were seen; and everywhere Plenty, the smiling daughter of\r\nPeace, gave notice by her thousand signs that she was at home, making\r\nthe generous traveller merry at heart, until he was even disposed to\r\ngive Rome her dues. Occasionally, also, views were had of Taurus and\r\nLebanon, between which, a separating line of silver, the Orontes\r\nplacidly pursued its way.\r\n\r\nIn course of their journey the friends came to the river, which they\r\nfollowed with the windings of the road, now over bold bluffs, and then\r\ninto vales, all alike allotted for country-seats, and if the land was\r\nin full foliage of oak and sycamore and myrtle, and bay and arbutus,\r\nand perfuming jasmine, the river was bright with slanted sunlight,\r\nwhich would have slept where it fell but for ships in endless\r\nprocession, gliding with the current, tacking for the wind, or bounding\r\nunder the impulse of oars\xe2\x80\x94some coming, some going, and all suggestive\r\nof the sea, and distant peoples, and famous places, and things coveted\r\non account of their rarity. To the fancy there is nothing so winsome as\r\na white sail seaward blown, unless it be a white sail homeward bound,\r\nits voyage happily done. And down the shore the friends went\r\ncontinuously till they came to a lake fed by back-water from the river,\r\nclear, deep, and without current. An old palm-tree dominated the angle\r\nof the inlet; turning to the left at the foot of the tree, Malluch\r\nclapped his hands and shouted,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook, look! The Orchard of Palms!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe scene was nowhere else to be found unless in the favored oases of\r\nArabia or the Ptolemaean farms along the Nile; and to sustain a\r\nsensation new as it was delightful, Ben-Hur was admitted into a tract\r\nof land apparently without limit and level as a floor. All under foot\r\nwas fresh grass, in Syria the rarest and most beautiful production of\r\nthe soil; if he looked up, it was to see the sky paley blue through the\r\ngroinery of countless date-bearers, very patriarchs of their kind, so\r\nnumerous and old, and of such mighty girth, so tall, so serried, so\r\nwide of branch, each branch so perfect with fronds, plumy and waxlike\r\nand brilliant, they seemed enchanters enchanted. Here was the grass\r\ncoloring the very atmosphere; there the lake, cool and clear, rippling\r\nbut a few feet under the surface, and helping the trees to their long\r\nlife in old age. Did the Grove of Daphne excel this one? And the palms,\r\nas if they knew Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s thought, and would win him after a way of\r\ntheir own, seemed, as he passed under their arches, to stir and\r\nsprinkle him with dewy coolness.\r\n\r\nThe road wound in close parallelism with the shore of the lake; and\r\nwhen it carried the travellers down to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge, there was\r\nalways on that side a shining expanse limited not far off by the\r\nopposite shore, on which, as on this one, no tree but the palm was\r\npermitted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, pointing to a giant of the place. \xe2\x80\x9cEach ring\r\nupon its trunk marks a year of its life. Count them from root to\r\nbranch, and if the sheik tells you the grove was planted before the\r\nSeleucidae were heard of in Antioch, do not doubt him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne may not look at a perfect palm-tree but that, with a subtlety all\r\nits own, it assumes a presence for itself, and makes a poet of the\r\nbeholder. This is the explanation of the honors it has received,\r\nbeginning with the artists of the first kings, who could find no form\r\nin all the earth to serve them so well as a model for the pillars of\r\ntheir palaces and temples; and for the same reason Ben-Hur was moved to\r\nsay,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I saw him at the stand to-day, good Malluch, Sheik Ilderim appeared\r\nto be a very common man. The rabbis in Jerusalem would look down upon\r\nhim, I fear, as a son of a dog of Edom. How came he in possession of\r\nthe Orchard? And how has he been able to hold it against the greed of\r\nRoman governors?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf blood derives excellence from time, son of Arrius, then is old\r\nIlderim a man, though he be an uncircumcised Edomite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch spoke warmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll his fathers before him were sheiks. One of them\xe2\x80\x94I shall not say\r\nwhen he lived or did the good deed\xe2\x80\x94once helped a king who was being\r\nhunted with swords. The story says he loaned him a thousand horsemen,\r\nwho knew the paths of the wilderness and its hiding-places as shepherds\r\nknow the scant hills they inhabit with their flocks; and they carried\r\nhim here and there until the opportunity came, and then with their\r\nspears they slew the enemy, and set him upon his throne again. And the\r\nking, it is said, remembered the service, and brought the son of the\r\nDesert to this place, and bade him set up his tent and bring his family\r\nand his herds, for the lake and trees, and all the land from the river\r\nto the nearest mountains, were his and his children\xe2\x80\x99s forever. And they\r\nhave never been disturbed in the possession. The rulers succeeding have\r\nfound it policy to keep good terms with the tribe, to whom the Lord has\r\ngiven increase of men and horses, and camels and riches, making them\r\nmasters of many highways between cities; so that it is with them any\r\ntime they please to say to commerce, \xe2\x80\x98Go in peace,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 and what\r\nthey say shall be done. Even the prefect in the citadel overlooking\r\nAntioch thinks it happy day with him when Ilderim, surnamed the\r\nGenerous on account of good deeds done unto all manner of men, with his\r\nwives and children, and his trains of camels and horses, and his\r\nbelongings of sheik, moving as our fathers Abraham and Jacob moved,\r\ncomes up to exchange briefly his bitter wells for the pleasantness you\r\nsee about us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, who had been listening unmindful of\r\nthe slow gait of the dromedaries. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw the sheik tear his beard while\r\nhe cursed himself that he had put trust in a Roman. Caesar, had he\r\nheard him, might have said, \xe2\x80\x98I like not such a friend as this; put him\r\naway.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be but shrewd judgment,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch replied, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cIlderim\r\nis not a lover of Rome; he has a grievance. Three years ago the\r\nParthians rode across the road from Bozra to Damascus, and fell upon a\r\ncaravan laden, among other things, with the incoming tax-returns of a\r\ndistrict over that way. They slew every creature taken, which the\r\ncensors in Rome could have forgiven if the imperial treasure had been\r\nspared and forwarded. The farmers of the taxes, being chargeable with\r\nthe loss, complained to Caesar, and Caesar held Herod to payment, and\r\nHerod, on his part, seized property of Ilderim, whom he charged with\r\ntreasonable neglect of duty. The sheik appealed to Caesar, and Caesar\r\nhas made him such answer as might be looked for from the unwinking\r\nsphinx. The old man\xe2\x80\x99s heart has been aching sore ever since, and he\r\nnurses his wrath, and takes pleasure in its daily growth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe can do nothing, Malluch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, \xe2\x80\x9cthat involves another explanation, which I will\r\ngive you, if we can draw nearer. But see!\xe2\x80\x94the hospitality of the sheik\r\nbegins early\xe2\x80\x94the children are speaking to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dromedaries stopped, and Ben-Hur looked down upon some little girls\r\nof the Syrian peasant class, who were offering him their baskets filled\r\nwith dates. The fruit was freshly gathered, and not to be refused; he\r\nstooped and took it, and as he did so a man in the tree by which they\r\nwere halted cried, \xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, and welcome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTheir thanks said to the children, the friends moved on at such gait as\r\nthe animals chose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must know,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch continued, pausing now and then to dispose of\r\na date, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the merchant Simonides gives me his confidence, and\r\nsometimes flatters me by taking me into council; and as I attend him at\r\nhis house, I have made acquaintance with many of his friends, who,\r\nknowing my footing with the host, talk to him freely in my presence. In\r\nthat way I became somewhat intimate with Sheik Ilderim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor a moment Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s attention wandered. Before his mind\xe2\x80\x99s eye there\r\narose the image, pure, gentle, and appealing, of Esther, the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndaughter. Her dark eyes bright with the peculiar Jewish lustre met his\r\nin modest gaze; he heard her step as when she approached him with the\r\nwine, and her voice as she tendered him the cup; and he acknowledged to\r\nhimself again all the sympathy she manifested for him, and manifested\r\nso plainly that words were unnecessary, and so sweetly that words would\r\nhave been but a detraction. The vision was exceeding pleasant, but upon\r\nhis turning to Malluch, it flew away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA few weeks ago,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, continuing, \xe2\x80\x9cthe old Arab called on\r\nSimonides, and found me present. I observed he seemed much moved about\r\nsomething, and, in deference, offered to withdraw, but he himself\r\nforbade me. \xe2\x80\x98As you are an Israelite,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98stay, for I have a\r\nstrange story to tell.\xe2\x80\x99 The emphasis on the word Israelite excited my\r\ncuriosity. I remained, and this is in substance his story\xe2\x80\x94I cut it\r\nshort because we are drawing nigh the tent, and I leave the details to\r\nthe good man himself. A good many years ago, three men called at\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s tent out in the wilderness. They were all foreigners, a\r\nHindoo, a Greek, and an Egyptian; and they had come on camels, the\r\nlargest he had ever seen, and all white. He welcomed them, and gave\r\nthem rest. Next morning they arose and prayed a prayer new to the\r\nsheik\xe2\x80\x94a prayer addressed to God and his son\xe2\x80\x94this with much mystery\r\nbesides. After breaking fast with him, the Egyptian told who they were,\r\nand whence they had come. Each had seen a star, out of which a voice\r\nhad bidden them go to Jerusalem and ask, Where is he that is born King\r\nof the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99 They obeyed. From Jerusalem they were led by a star to\r\nBethlehem, where, in a cave, they found a child newly born, which they\r\nfell down and worshipped; and after worshipping it, and giving it\r\ncostly presents, and bearing witness of what it was, they took to their\r\ncamels, and fled without pause to the sheik, because if Herod\xe2\x80\x94meaning\r\nhim surnamed the Great\xe2\x80\x94could lay hands upon them, he would certainly\r\nkill them. And, faithful to his habit, the sheik took care of them, and\r\nkept them concealed for a year, when they departed, leaving with him\r\ngifts of great value, and each going a separate way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, indeed, a most wonderful story,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur exclaimed at its\r\nconclusion. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you say they were to ask at Jerusalem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were to ask, \xe2\x80\x98Where is he that is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was more to the question, but I cannot recall it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they found the child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and worshipped him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a miracle, Malluch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIlderim is a grave man, though excitable as all Arabs are. A lie on\r\nhis tongue is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch spoke positively. Thereupon the dromedaries were forgotten,\r\nand, quite as unmindful of their riders, they turned off the road to\r\nthe growing grass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas Ilderim heard nothing more of the three men?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nbecame of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, that was the cause of his coming to Simonides the day of\r\nwhich I was speaking. Only the night before that day the Egyptian\r\nreappeared to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere at the door of the tent to which we are coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow knew he the man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you knew the horses to-day\xe2\x80\x94by face and manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy nothing else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe rode the same great white camel, and gave him the same\r\nname\xe2\x80\x94Balthasar, the Egyptian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a wonder of the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur spoke with excitement.\r\n\r\nAnd Malluch, wondering, asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBalthasar, you said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Balthasar, the Egyptian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was the name the old man gave us at the fountain today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, at the reminder, Malluch became excited.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand the camel was the same\xe2\x80\x94and you saved the\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the woman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, like one speaking to himself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe woman\r\nwas his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe fell to thinking; and even the reader will say he was having a\r\nvision of the woman, and that it was more welcome than that of Esther,\r\nif only because it stayed longer with him; but no\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, presently. \xe2\x80\x9cWere the three to ask, \xe2\x80\x98Where is\r\nhe that is to be King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot exactly. The words were BORN TO BE KING OF THE JEWS. Those were\r\nthe words as the old sheik caught them first in the desert, and he has\r\never since been waiting the coming of the king; nor can any one shake\r\nhis faith that he will come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x94as king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and bringing the doom of Rome\xe2\x80\x94so says the sheik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur kept silent awhile, thinking and trying to control his\r\nfeelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old man is one of many millions,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, slowly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cone of many\r\nmillions each with a wrong to avenge; and this strange faith, Malluch,\r\nis bread and wine to his hope; for who but a Herod may be King of the\r\nJews while Rome endures? But, following the story, did you hear what\r\nSimonides said to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Ilderim is a grave man, Simonides is a wise one,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch replied.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI listened, and he said\xe2\x80\x94 But hark! Some one comes overtaking us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe noise grew louder, until presently they heard the rumble of wheels\r\nmixed with the beating of horse-hoofs\xe2\x80\x94a moment later Sheik Ilderim\r\nhimself appeared on horseback, followed by a train, among which were\r\nthe four wine-red Arabs drawing the chariot. The sheik\xe2\x80\x99s chin, in its\r\nmuffling of long white beard, was drooped upon his breast. Our friends\r\nhad out-travelled him; but at sight of them he raised his head and\r\nspoke kindly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you!\xe2\x80\x94Ah, my friend Malluch! Welcome! And tell me you are not\r\ngoing, but just come; that you have something for me from the good\r\nSimonides\xe2\x80\x94may the Lord of his fathers keep him in life for many years\r\nto come! Ay, take up the straps, both of you, and follow me. I have\r\nbread and leben, or, if you prefer it, arrack, and the flesh of young\r\nkid. Come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey followed after him to the door of the tent, in which, when they\r\nwere dismounted, he stood to receive them, holding a platter with three\r\ncups filled with creamy liquor just drawn from a great smoke-stained\r\nskin bottle, pendent from the central post.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, heartily, \xe2\x80\x9cdrink, for this is the fear-naught of the\r\ntentmen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey each took a cup, and drank till but the foam remained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnter now, in God\xe2\x80\x99s name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd when they were gone in, Malluch took the sheik aside, and spoke to\r\nhim privately; after which he went to Ben-Hur and excused himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told the sheik about you, and he will give you the trial of his\r\nhorses in the morning. He is your friend. Having done for you all I\r\ncan, you must do the rest, and let me return to Antioch. There is one\r\nthere who has my promise to meet him to-night. I have no choice but to\r\ngo. I will come back to-morrow prepared, if all goes well in the\r\nmeantime, to stay with you until the games are over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith blessings given and received, Malluch set out in return.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\n\r\nWhat time the lower horn of a new moon touched the castellated piles on\r\nMount Sulpius, and two thirds of the people of Antioch were out on\r\ntheir house-tops comforting themselves with the night breeze when it\r\nblew, and with fans when it failed, Simonides sat in the chair which\r\nhad come to be a part of him, and from the terrace looked down over the\r\nriver, and his ships a-swing at their moorings. The wall at his back\r\ncast its shadow broadly over the water to the opposite shore. Above him\r\nthe endless tramp upon the bridge went on. Esther was holding a plate\r\nfor him containing his frugal supper\xe2\x80\x94some wheaten cakes, light as\r\nwafers, some honey, and a bowl of milk, into which he now and then\r\ndipped the wafers after dipping them into the honey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalluch is a laggard to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, showing where his thoughts\r\nwere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe he will come?\xe2\x80\x9d Esther asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnless he has taken to the sea or the desert, and is yet following on,\r\nhe will come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides spoke with quiet confidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe may write,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, Esther. He would have despatched a letter when he found he\r\ncould not return, and told me so; because I have not received such a\r\nletter, I know he can come, and will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, very softly.\r\n\r\nSomething in the utterance attracted his attention; it might have been\r\nthe tone, it might have been the wish. The smallest bird cannot light\r\nupon the greatest tree without sending a shock to its most distant\r\nfibre; every mind is at times no less sensitive to the most trifling\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish him to come, Esther?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, lifting her eyes to his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? Can you tell me?\xe2\x80\x9d he persisted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she hesitated, then began again\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbecause the young man is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe stop was full.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur master. Is that the word?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you still think I should not suffer him to go away without telling\r\nhim to come, if he chooses, and take us\xe2\x80\x94and all we have\xe2\x80\x94all, Esther\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ngoods, the shekels, the ships, the slaves, and the mighty credit, which\r\nis a mantle of cloth of gold and finest silver spun for me by the\r\ngreatest of the angels of men\xe2\x80\x94Success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes that move you nothing? No?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with the slightest taint of\r\nbitterness. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, I have found, Esther, the worst reality is\r\nnever unendurable when it comes out from behind the clouds through\r\nwhich we at first see it darkly\xe2\x80\x94never\xe2\x80\x94not even the rack. I suppose it\r\nwill be so with death. And by that philosophy the slavery to which we\r\nare going must afterwhile become sweet. It pleases me even now to think\r\nwhat a favored man our master is. The fortune cost him nothing\xe2\x80\x94not an\r\nanxiety, not a drop of sweat, not so much as a thought; it attaches to\r\nhim undreamed of, and in his youth. And, Esther, let me waste a little\r\nvanity with the reflection; he gets what he could not go into the\r\nmarket and buy with all the pelf in a sum\xe2\x80\x94thee, my child, my darling;\r\nthou blossom from the tomb of my lost Rachel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew her to him, and kissed her twice\xe2\x80\x94once for herself, once for her\r\nmother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay not so,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, when his hand fell from her neck. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us think\r\nbetter of him; he knows what sorrow is, and will set us free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, thy instincts are fine, Esther; and thou knowest I lean upon them\r\nin doubtful cases where good or bad is to be pronounced of a person\r\nstanding before thee as he stood this morning. But\xe2\x80\x94but\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94his voice rose\r\nand hardened\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthese limbs upon which I cannot stand\xe2\x80\x94this body drawn and\r\nbeaten out of human shape\xe2\x80\x94they are not all I bring him of myself. Oh\r\nno, no! I bring him a soul which has triumphed over torture and Roman\r\nmalice keener than any torture\xe2\x80\x94I bring him a mind which has eyes to see\r\ngold at a distance farther than the ships of Solomon sailed, and power\r\nto bring it to hand\xe2\x80\x94ay, Esther, into my palm here for the fingers to\r\ngrip and keep lest it take wings at some other\xe2\x80\x99s word\xe2\x80\x94a mind skilled at\r\nscheming\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he stopped and laughed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Esther, before the new moon\r\nwhich in the courts of the Temple on the Holy Hill they are this moment\r\ncelebrating passes into its next quartering I could ring the world so\r\nas to startle even Caesar; for know you, child, I have that faculty\r\nwhich is better than any one sense, better than a perfect body, better\r\nthan courage and will, better than experience, ordinarily the best\r\nproduct of the longest lives\xe2\x80\x94the faculty divinest of men, but which\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nstopped, and laughed again, not bitterly, but with real zest\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut which\r\neven the great do not sufficiently account, while with the herd it is a\r\nnon-existent\xe2\x80\x94the faculty of drawing men to my purpose and holding them\r\nfaithfully to its achievement, by which, as against things to be done,\r\nI multiply myself into hundreds and thousands. So the captains of my\r\nships plough the seas, and bring me honest returns; so Malluch follows\r\nthe youth, our master, and will\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94just then a footstep was heard upon\r\nthe terrace\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHa, Esther! said I not so? He is here\xe2\x80\x94and we will have\r\ntidings. For thy sake, sweet child\xe2\x80\x94my lily just budded\xe2\x80\x94I pray the Lord\r\nGod, who has not forgotten his wandering sheep of Israel, that they be\r\ngood and comforting. Now we will know if he will let thee go with all\r\nthy beauty, and me with all my faculties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch came to the chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, good master,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a low obeisance\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand to you,\r\nEsther, most excellent of daughters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stood before them deferentially, and the attitude and the address\r\nleft it difficult to define his relation to them; the one was that of a\r\nservant, the other indicated the familiar and friend. On the other\r\nside, Simonides, as was his habit in business, after answering the\r\nsalutation went straight to the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of the young man, Malluch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe events of the day were told quietly and in the simplest words, and\r\nuntil he was through there was no interruption; nor did the listener in\r\nthe chair so much as move a hand during the narration; but for his\r\neyes, wide open and bright, and an occasional long-drawn breath, he\r\nmight have been accounted an effigy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, thank you, Malluch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, heartily, at the conclusion;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou have done well\xe2\x80\x94no one could have done better. Now what say you of\r\nthe young man\xe2\x80\x99s nationality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is an Israelite, good master, and of the tribe of Judah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are positive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery positive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe appears to have told you but little of his life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has somewhere learned to be prudent. I might call him distrustful.\r\nHe baffled all my attempts upon his confidence until we started from\r\nthe Castalian fount going to the village of Daphne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA place of abomination! Why went he there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would say from curiosity, the first motive of the many who go; but,\r\nvery strangely, he took no interest in the things he saw. Of the\r\nTemple, he merely asked if it were Grecian. Good master, the young man\r\nhas a trouble of mind from which he would hide, and he went to the\r\nGrove, I think, as we go to sepulchres with our dead\xe2\x80\x94he went to bury\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat were well, if so,\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides said, in a low voice; then louder,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalluch, the curse of the time is prodigality. The poor make\r\nthemselves poorer as apes of the rich, and the merely rich carry\r\nthemselves like princes. Saw you signs of the weakness in the youth?\r\nDid he display moneys\xe2\x80\x94coin of Rome or Israel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone, none, good master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely, Malluch, where there are so many inducements to folly\xe2\x80\x94so much,\r\nI mean, to eat and drink\xe2\x80\x94surely he made you generous offer of some\r\nsort. His age, if nothing more, would warrant that much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe neither ate nor drank in my company.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what he said or did, Malluch, could you in anywise detect his\r\nmaster-idea? You know they peep through cracks close enough to stop the\r\nwind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me to understand you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, in doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know we nor speak nor act, much less decide grave questions\r\nconcerning ourselves, except as we be driven by a motive. In that\r\nrespect, what made you of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to that, Master Simonides, I can answer with much assurance. He is\r\ndevoted to finding his mother and sister\xe2\x80\x94that first. Then he has a\r\ngrievance against Rome; and as the Messala of whom I told you had\r\nsomething to do with the wrong, the great present object is to\r\nhumiliate him. The meeting at the fountain furnished an opportunity,\r\nbut it was put aside as not sufficiently public.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messala is influential,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but the next meeting will be in the Circus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94and then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son of Arrius will win.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow know you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am judging by what he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; there is a much better sign\xe2\x80\x94his spirit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy; but, Malluch, his idea of vengeance\xe2\x80\x94what is its scope? Does he\r\nlimit it to the few who did him the wrong, or does he take in the many?\r\nAnd more\xe2\x80\x94is his feeling but the vagary of a sensitive boy, or has it\r\nthe seasoning of suffering manhood to give it endurance? You know,\r\nMalluch, the vengeful thought that has root merely in the mind is but a\r\ndream of idlest sort which one clear day will dissipate; while revenge\r\nthe passion is a disease of the heart which climbs up, up to the brain,\r\nand feeds itself on both alike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn this question, Simonides for the first time showed signs of feeling;\r\nhe spoke with rapid utterance, and with clenched hands and the\r\neagerness of a man illustrating the disease he described.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood my master,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch replied, \xe2\x80\x9cone of my reasons for believing the\r\nyoung man a Jew is the intensity of his hate. It was plain to me he had\r\nhimself under watch, as was natural, seeing how long he has lived in an\r\natmosphere of Roman jealousy; yet I saw it blaze\xe2\x80\x94once when he wanted to\r\nknow Ilderim\xe2\x80\x99s feeling towards Rome, and again when I told him the\r\nstory of the sheik and the wise man, and spoke of the question, \xe2\x80\x98Where\r\nis he that is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides leaned forward quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Malluch, his words\xe2\x80\x94give me his words; let me judge the impression\r\nthe mystery made upon him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wanted to know the exact words. Were they TO BE or BORN TO BE? It\r\nappeared he was struck by a seeming difference in the effect of the two\r\nphrases.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides settled back into his pose of listening judge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, \xe2\x80\x9cI told him Ilderim\xe2\x80\x99s view of the mystery\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nthe king would come with the doom of Rome. The young man\xe2\x80\x99s blood rose\r\nover his cheeks and forehead, and he said earnestly, \xe2\x80\x98Who but a Herod\r\ncan be king while Rome endures?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeaning what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the empire must be destroyed before there could be another rule.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides gazed for a time at the ships and their shadows slowly\r\nswinging together in the river; when he looked up, it was to end the\r\ninterview.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, Malluch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cGet you to eat, and make ready to return\r\nto the Orchard of Palms; you must help the young man in his coming\r\ntrial. Come to me in the morning. I will send a letter to Ilderim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThen in an undertone, as if to himself, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cI may attend the\r\nCircus myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Malluch after the customary benediction given and received was\r\ngone, Simonides took a deep draught of milk, and seemed refreshed and\r\neasy of mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut the meal down, Esther,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cit is over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe obeyed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe resumed her place upon the arm of the chair close to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is good to me, very good,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, fervently. \xe2\x80\x9cHis habit is to\r\nmove in mystery, yet sometimes he permits us to think we see and\r\nunderstand him. I am old, dear, and must go; but now, in this eleventh\r\nhour, when my hope was beginning to die, he sends me this one with a\r\npromise, and I am lifted up. I see the way to a great part in a\r\ncircumstance itself so great that it shall be as a new birth to the\r\nwhole world. And I see a reason for the gift of my great riches, and\r\nthe end for which they were designed. Verily, my child, I take hold on\r\nlife anew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther nestled closer to him, as if to bring his thoughts from their\r\nfar-flying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king has been born\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, imagining he was still speaking\r\nto her, \xe2\x80\x9cand he must be near the half of common life. Balthasar says he\r\nwas a child on his mother\xe2\x80\x99s lap when he saw him, and gave him presents\r\nand worship; and Ilderim holds it was twenty-seven years ago last\r\nDecember when Balthasar and his companions came to his tent asking a\r\nhiding-place from Herod. Wherefore the coming cannot now be long\r\ndelayed. To-night\xe2\x80\x94to-morrow it may be. Holy fathers of Israel, what\r\nhappiness in the thought! I seem to hear the crash of the falling of\r\nold walls and the clamor of a universal change\xe2\x80\x94ay, and for the\r\nuttermost joy of men, the earth opens to take Rome in, and they look up\r\nand laugh and sing that she is not, while we are;\xe2\x80\x9d then he laughed at\r\nhimself. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Esther, heard you ever the like? Surely, I have on me\r\nthe passion of a singer, the heat of blood and the thrill of Miriam and\r\nDavid. In my thoughts, which should be those of a plain worker in\r\nfigures and facts, there is a confusion of cymbals clashing and\r\nharp-strings loud beaten, and the voices of a multitude standing around\r\na new-risen throne. I will put the thinking by for the present; only,\r\ndear, when the king comes he will need money and men, for as he was a\r\nchild born of woman he will be but a man after all, bound to human ways\r\nas you and I are. And for the money he will have need of getters and\r\nkeepers, and for the men leaders. There, there! See you not a broad\r\nroad for my walking, and the running of the youth our master?\xe2\x80\x94and at\r\nthe end of it glory and revenge for us both?\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he paused, struck\r\nwith the selfishness of a scheme in which she had no part or good\r\nresult; then added, kissing her, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd happiness for thy mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchild.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe sat still, saying nothing. Then he remembered the difference in\r\nnatures, and the law by which we are not permitted always to take\r\ndelight in the same cause or be equally afraid of the same thing. He\r\nremembered she was but a girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what are you thinking, Esther?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in his common home-like\r\nway. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the thought have the form of a wish, give it me, little one,\r\nwhile the power remains mine. For power, you know, is a fretful thing,\r\nand hath its wings always spread for flight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe answered with a simplicity almost childish,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend for him, father. Send for him to-night, and do not let him go\r\ninto the Circus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, prolonging the exclamation; and again his eyes fell upon\r\nthe river, where the shadows were more shadowy than ever, since the\r\nmoon had sunk far down behind Sulpius, leaving the city to the\r\nineffectual stars. Shall we say it, reader? He was touched by a twinge\r\nof jealousy. If she should really love the young master! Oh no! That\r\ncould not be; she was too young. But the idea had fast grip, and\r\ndirectly held him still and cold. She was sixteen. He knew it well. On\r\nthe last natal day he had gone with her to the shipyard where there was\r\na launch, and the yellow flag which the galley bore to its bridal with\r\nthe waves had on it \xe2\x80\x9cEsther;\xe2\x80\x9d so they celebrated the day together. Yet\r\nthe fact struck him now with the force of a surprise. There are\r\nrealizations which come to us all painfully; mostly, however, such as\r\npertain to ourselves; that we are growing old, for instance; and, more\r\nterrible, that we must die. Such a one crept into his heart, shadowy as\r\nthe shadows, yet substantial enough to wring from him a sigh which was\r\nalmost a groan. It was not sufficient that she should enter upon her\r\nyoung womanhood a servant, but she must carry to her master her\r\naffections, the truth and tenderness and delicacy of which he the\r\nfather so well knew, because to this time they had all been his own\r\nundividedly. The fiend whose task it is to torture us with fears and\r\nbitter thoughts seldom does his work by halves. In the pang of the\r\nmoment, the brave old man lost sight of his new scheme, and of the\r\nmiraculous king its subject. By a mighty effort, however, he controlled\r\nhimself, and asked, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cNot go into the Circus, Esther? Why,\r\nchild?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not a place for a son of Israel, father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRabbinical, rabbinical, Esther! Is that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tone of the inquiry was searching, and went to her heart, which\r\nbegan to beat loudly\xe2\x80\x94so loudly she could not answer. A confusion new\r\nand strangely pleasant fell upon her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man is to have the fortune,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, taking her hand, and\r\nspeaking more tenderly; \xe2\x80\x9che is to have the ships and the shekels\xe2\x80\x94all,\r\nEsther, all. Yet I did not feel poor, for thou wert left me, and thy\r\nlove so like the dead Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s. Tell me, is he to have that too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe bent over him, and laid her cheek against his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, Esther. I will be the stronger of the knowledge. In warning\r\nthere is strength.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe sat up then, and spoke as if she were Truth\xe2\x80\x99s holy self.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cComfort thee, father. I will never leave thee; though he take my love,\r\nI will be thy handmaid ever as now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, stooping, she kissed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd more,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, continuing: \xe2\x80\x9che is comely in my sight, and the\r\npleading of his voice drew me to him, and I shudder to think of him in\r\ndanger. Yes, father, I would be more than glad to see him again. Still,\r\nthe love that is unrequited cannot be perfect love, wherefore I will\r\nwait a time, remembering I am thy daughter and my mother\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very blessing of the Lord art thou, Esther! A blessing to keep me\r\nrich, though all else be lost. And by his holy name and everlasting\r\nlife, I swear thou shalt not suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt his request, a little later, the servant came and rolled the chair\r\ninto the room, where he sat for a time thinking of the coming of the\r\nking, while she went off and slept the sleep of the innocent.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe palace across the river nearly opposite Simonides\xe2\x80\x99 place is said to\r\nhave been completed by the famous Epiphanes, and was all such a\r\nhabitation can be imagined; though he was a builder whose taste ran to\r\nthe immense rather than the classical, now so called\xe2\x80\x94an architectural\r\nimitator, in other words, of the Persians instead of the Greeks.\r\n\r\nThe wall enclosing the whole island to the waters edge, and built for\r\nthe double purpose of bulwark against the river and defence against the\r\nmob, was said to have rendered the palace unfit for constant occupancy,\r\ninsomuch that the legates abandoned it and moved to another residence\r\nerected for them on the western ridge of Mount Sulpius, under the\r\nTemple of Jupiter. Persons were not wanting, however, who flatly denied\r\nthe bill against the ancient abode. They said, with shrewdness at\r\nleast, that the real object of the removal of the legates was not a\r\nmore healthful locality, but the assurance afforded them by the huge\r\nbarracks, named, according to the prevalent style, citadel, situated\r\njust over the way on the eastern ridge of the mount. And the opinion\r\nhad plausible showing. Among other pertinent things, it was remarked\r\nthat the palace was kept in perpetual readiness for use; and when a\r\nconsul, general of the army, king, or visiting potentate of any kind\r\narrived at Antioch, quarters were at once assigned him on the island.\r\n\r\nAs we have to do with but one apartment in the old pile, the residue of\r\nit is left to the reader\xe2\x80\x99s fancy; and as pleases him, he may go through\r\nits gardens, baths, halls, and labyrinth of rooms to the pavilions on\r\nthe roof, all furnished as became a house of fame in a city which was\r\nmore nearly Milton\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cgorgeous East\xe2\x80\x9d than any other in the world.\r\n\r\nAt this age the apartment alluded to would be termed a saloon. It was\r\nquite spacious, floored with polished marble slabs, and lighted in the\r\nday by skylights in which colored mica served as glass. The walls were\r\nbroken by Atlantes, no two of which were alike, but all supporting a\r\ncornice wrought with arabesques exceedingly intricate in form, and more\r\nelegant on account of superadditions of color\xe2\x80\x94blue, green, Tyrian\r\npurple, and gold. Around the room ran a continuous divan of Indian\r\nsilks and wool of Cashmere. The furniture consisted of tables and\r\nstools of Egyptian patterns grotesquely carved. We have left Simonides\r\nin his chair perfecting his scheme in aid of the miraculous king, whose\r\ncoming he has decided is so close at hand. Esther is asleep; and now,\r\nhaving crossed the river by the bridge, and made way through the\r\nlion-guarded gate and a number of Babylonian halls and courts, let us\r\nenter the gilded saloon.\r\n\r\nThere are five chandeliers hanging by sliding bronze chains from the\r\nceiling\xe2\x80\x94one in each corner, and in the centre one\xe2\x80\x94enormous pyramids of\r\nlighted lamps, illuminating even the demoniac faces of the Atlantes and\r\nthe complex tracery of the cornice. About the tables, seated or\r\nstanding, or moving restlessly from one to another, there are probably\r\na hundred persons, whom we must study at least for a moment.\r\n\r\nThey are all young, some of them little more than boys. That they are\r\nItalians and mostly Romans is past doubt. They all speak Latin in\r\npurity, while each one appears in the in-door dress of the great\r\ncapital on the Tiber; that is, in tunics short of sleeve and skirt, a\r\nstyle of vesture well adapted to the climate of Antioch, and especially\r\ncomfortable in the too close atmosphere of the saloon. On the divan\r\nhere and there togas and lacernae lie where they have been carelessly\r\ntossed, some of them significantly bordered with purple. On the divan\r\nalso lie sleepers stretched at ease; whether they were overcome by the\r\nheat and fatigue of the sultry day or by Bacchus we will not pause to\r\ninquire.\r\n\r\nThe hum of voices is loud and incessant. Sometimes there is an\r\nexplosion of laughter, sometimes a burst of rage or exultation; but\r\nover all prevails a sharp, prolonged rattle, at first somewhat\r\nconfusing to the non-familiar. If we approach the tables, however, the\r\nmystery solves itself. The company is at the favorite games, draughts\r\nand dice, singly or together, and the rattle is merely of the tesserae,\r\nor ivory cubes, loudly shaken, and the moving of the hostes on the\r\ncheckered boards.\r\n\r\nWho are the company?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Flavius,\xe2\x80\x9d said a player, holding his piece in suspended movement,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthou seest yon lacerna; that one in front of us on the divan. It is\r\nfresh from the shop, and hath a shoulder-buckle of gold broad as a\r\npalm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Flavius, intent upon his game, \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen such before;\r\nwherefore thine may not be old, yet, by the girdle of Venus, it is not\r\nnew! What of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing. Only I would give it to find a man who knows everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha! For something cheaper, I will find thee here several with\r\npurple who will take thy offer. But play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x94check!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, by all the Jupiters! Now, what sayest thou? Again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the wager?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sestertium.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen each drew his tablets and stilus and made a memorandum; and, while\r\nthey were resetting the pieces, Flavius returned to his friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nremark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man who knows everything! Hercle! the oracles would die. What\r\nwouldst thou with such a monster?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer to one question, my Flavius; then, perpol! I would cut his\r\nthroat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would have him tell me the hour\xe2\x80\x94 Hour, said I?\xe2\x80\x94nay, the\r\nminute\xe2\x80\x94Maxentius will arrive to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood play, good play! I have you! And why the minute?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast thou ever stood uncovered in the Syrian sun on the quay at which\r\nhe will land? The fires of the Vesta are not so hot; and, by the Stator\r\nof our father Romulus, I would die, if die I must, in Rome. Avernus is\r\nhere; there, in the square before the Forum, I could stand, and, with\r\nmy hand raised thus, touch the floor of the gods. Ha, by Venus, my\r\nFlavius, thou didst beguile me! I have lost. O Fortune!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must have back my sestertium.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they played again and again; and when day, stealing through the\r\nskylights, began to dim the lamps, it found the two in the same places\r\nat the same table, still at the game. Like most of the company, they\r\nwere military attaches of the consul, awaiting his arrival and amusing\r\nthemselves meantime.\r\n\r\nDuring this conversation a party entered the room, and, unnoticed at\r\nfirst, proceeded to the central table. The signs were that they had\r\ncome from a revel just dismissed. Some of them kept their feet with\r\ndifficulty. Around the leader\xe2\x80\x99s brow was a chaplet which marked him\r\nmaster of the feast, if not the giver. The wine had made no impression\r\nupon him unless to heighten his beauty, which was of the most manly\r\nRoman style; he carried his head high raised; the blood flushed his\r\nlips and cheeks brightly; his eyes glittered; though the manner in\r\nwhich, shrouded in a toga spotless white and of ample folds, he walked\r\nwas too nearly imperial for one sober and not a Caesar. In going to the\r\ntable, he made room for himself and his followers with little ceremony\r\nand no apologies; and when at length he stopped, and looked over it and\r\nat the players, they all turned to him, with a shout like a cheer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessala! Messala!\xe2\x80\x9d they cried.\r\n\r\nThose in distant quarters, hearing the cry, re-echoed it where they\r\nwere. Instantly there were dissolution of groups, and breaking-up of\r\ngames, and a general rush towards the centre.\r\n\r\nMessala took the demonstration indifferently, and proceeded presently\r\nto show the ground of his popularity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA health to thee, Drusus, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the player next at\r\nhis right; \xe2\x80\x9ca health\xe2\x80\x94and thy tablets a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe raised the waxen boards, glanced at the memoranda of wagers, and\r\ntossed them down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDenarii, only denarii\xe2\x80\x94coin of cartmen and butchers!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a\r\nscornful laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the drunken Semele, to what is Rome coming, when a\r\nCaesar sits o\xe2\x80\x99 nights waiting a turn of fortune to bring him but a\r\nbeggarly denarius!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe scion of the Drusi reddened to his brows, but the bystanders broke\r\nin upon his reply by surging closer around the table, and shouting,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messala! the Messala!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen of the Tiber,\xe2\x80\x9d Messala continued, wresting a box with the dice in\r\nit from a hand near-by, \xe2\x80\x9cwho is he most favored of the gods? A Roman.\r\nWho is he lawgiver of the nations? A Roman. Who is he, by sword right,\r\nthe universal master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe company were of the easily inspired, and the thought was one to\r\nwhich they were born; in a twinkling they snatched the answer from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Roman, a Roman!\xe2\x80\x9d they shouted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet\xe2\x80\x94yet\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he lingered to catch their ears\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyet there is a better than\r\nthe best of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tossed his patrician head and paused, as if to sting them with his\r\nsneer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear ye?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a better than the best of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy\xe2\x80\x94Hercules!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBacchus!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled a satirist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJove\xe2\x80\x94Jove!\xe2\x80\x9d thundered the crowd.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d Messala answered, \xe2\x80\x9camong men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cName him, name him!\xe2\x80\x9d they demanded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, the next lull. \xe2\x80\x9cHe who to the perfection of Rome\r\nhath added the perfection of the East; who to the arm of conquest,\r\nwhich is Western, hath also the art needful to the enjoyment of\r\ndominion, which is Eastern.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerpol! His best is a Roman, after all,\xe2\x80\x9d some one shouted; and there\r\nwas a great laugh, and long clapping of hands\xe2\x80\x94an admission that Messala\r\nhad the advantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the East\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have no gods, only Wine, Women, and\r\nFortune, and the greatest of them is Fortune; wherefore our motto, \xe2\x80\x98Who\r\ndareth what I dare?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94fit for the senate, fit for battle, fittest for\r\nhim who, seeking the best, challenges the worst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis voice dropped into an easy, familiar tone, but without relaxing the\r\nascendancy he had gained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the great chest up in the citadel I have five talents coin current\r\nin the markets, and here are the receipts for them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom his tunic he drew a roll of paper, and, flinging it on the table,\r\ncontinued, amidst breathless silence, every eye having him in view\r\nfixed on his, every ear listening:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sum lies there the measure of what I dare. Who of you dares so\r\nmuch! You are silent. Is it too great? I will strike off one talent.\r\nWhat! still silent? Come, then, throw me once for these three\r\ntalents\xe2\x80\x94only three; for two; for one\xe2\x80\x94one at least\xe2\x80\x94one for the honor of\r\nthe river by which you were born\xe2\x80\x94Rome East against Rome West!\xe2\x80\x94Orontes\r\nthe barbarous against Tiber the sacred!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rattled the dice overhead while waiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Orontes against the Tiber!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, with an increase of\r\nscornful emphasis.\r\n\r\nNot a man moved; then he flung the box upon the table and, laughing,\r\ntook up the receipts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! By the Olympian Jove, I know now ye have fortunes to make\r\nor to mend; therefore are ye come to Antioch.
