Ho, Cecilius!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Messala!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a man behind him; \xe2\x80\x9chere am I, perishing in the\r\nmob, and begging a drachma to settle with the ragged ferryman. But,\r\nPluto take me! these new ones have not so much as an obolus among\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sally provoked a burst of laughter, under which the saloon rang and\r\nrang again. Messala alone kept his gravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, thou,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Cecilius, \xe2\x80\x9cto the chamber whence we came, and\r\nbid the servants bring the amphorae here, and the cups and goblets. If\r\nthese our countrymen, looking for fortune, have not purses, by the\r\nSyrian Bacchus, I will see if they are not better blessed with\r\nstomachs! Haste thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he turned to Drusus, with a laugh heard throughout the apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, my friend! Be thou not offended because I levelled the Caesar\r\nin thee down to the denarii. Thou seest I did but use the name to try\r\nthese fine fledglings of our old Rome. Come, my Drusus, come!\xe2\x80\x9d He took\r\nup the box again and rattled the dice merrily. \xe2\x80\x9cHere, for what sum thou\r\nwilt, let us measure fortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manner was frank, cordial, winsome. Drusus melted in a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the Nymphae, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cI will throw with thee,\r\nMessala\xe2\x80\x94for a denarius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA very boyish person was looking over the table watching the scene.\r\nSuddenly Messala turned to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho art thou?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nThe lad drew back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, by Castor! and his brother too! I meant not offence. It is a rule\r\namong men, in matters other than dice, to keep the record closest when\r\nthe deal is least. I have need of a clerk. Wilt thou serve me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young fellow drew his tablets ready to keep the score: the manner\r\nwas irresistible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, Messala, hold!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Drusus. \xe2\x80\x9cI know not if it be ominous to\r\nstay the poised dice with a question; but one occurs to me, and I must\r\nask it though Venus slap me with her girdle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, my Drusus, Venus with her girdle off is Venus in love. To thy\r\nquestion\xe2\x80\x94I will make the throw and hold it against mischance. Thus\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned the box upon the table and held it firmly over the dice.\r\n\r\nAnd Drusus asked, \xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see one Quintus Arrius?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe duumvir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94his son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew not he had a son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d Drusus added, indifferently; \xe2\x80\x9conly, my Messala,\r\nPollux was not more like Castor than Arrius is like thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe remark had the effect of a signal: twenty voices took it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, true! His eyes\xe2\x80\x94his face,\xe2\x80\x9d they cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d answered one, disgusted. \xe2\x80\x9cMessala is a Roman; Arrius is a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou sayest right,\xe2\x80\x9d a third exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Jew, or Momus lent his\r\nmother the wrong mask.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was promise of a dispute; seeing which, Messala interposed. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nwine is not come, my Drusus; and, as thou seest, I have the freckled\r\nPythias as they were dogs in leash. As to Arrius, I will accept thy\r\nopinion of him, so thou tell me more about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be he Jew or Roman\xe2\x80\x94and, by the great god Pan, I say it not in\r\ndisrespect of thy feelings, my Messala!\xe2\x80\x94this Arrius is handsome and\r\nbrave and shrewd. The emperor offered him favor and patronage, which he\r\nrefused. He came up through mystery, and keepeth distance as if he felt\r\nhimself better or knew himself worse than the rest of us. In the\r\npalaestrae he was unmatched; he played with the blue-eyed giants from\r\nthe Rhine and the hornless bulls of Sarmatia as they were willow wisps.\r\nThe duumvir left him vastly rich. He has a passion for arms, and thinks\r\nof nothing but war. Maxentius admitted him into his family, and he was\r\nto have taken ship with us, but we lost him at Ravenna. Nevertheless he\r\narrived safely. We heard of him this morning. Perpol! Instead of coming\r\nto the palace or going to the citadel, he dropped his baggage at the\r\nkhan, and hath disappeared again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the beginning of the speech Messala listened with polite\r\nindifference; as it proceeded, he became more attentive; at the\r\nconclusion, he took his hand from the dice-box, and called out, \xe2\x80\x9cHo, my\r\nCaius! Dost thou hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA youth at his elbow\xe2\x80\x94his Myrtilus, or comrade, in the day\xe2\x80\x99s chariot\r\npractice\xe2\x80\x94answered, much pleased with the attention, \xe2\x80\x9cDid I not, my\r\nMessala, I were not thy friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDost thou remember the man who gave thee the fall to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the love-locks of Bacchus, have I not a bruised shoulder to help me\r\nkeep it in mind?\xe2\x80\x9d and he seconded the words with a shrug that submerged\r\nhis ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be thou grateful to the Fates\xe2\x80\x94I have found thy enemy. Listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon Messala turned to Drusus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell us more of him\xe2\x80\x94perpol!\xe2\x80\x94of him who is both Jew and Roman\xe2\x80\x94by\r\nPhoebus, a combination to make a Centaur lovely! What garments doth he\r\naffect, my Drusus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose of the Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHearest thou, Caius?\xe2\x80\x9d said Messala. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fellow is young\xe2\x80\x94one; he hath\r\nthe visage of a Roman\xe2\x80\x94two; he loveth best the garb of a Jew\xe2\x80\x94three; and\r\nin the palaestrae fame and fortune come of arms to throw a horse or\r\ntilt a chariot, as the necessity may order\xe2\x80\x94four. And, Drusus, help thou\r\nmy friend again. Doubtless this Arrius hath tricks of language;\r\notherwise he could not so confound himself, to-day a Jew, to-morrow a\r\nRoman; but of the rich tongue of Athene\xe2\x80\x94discourseth he in that as\r\nwell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith such purity, Messala, he might have been a contestant in the\r\nIsthmia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou listening, Caius?\xe2\x80\x9d said Messala. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fellow is qualified to\r\nsalute a woman\xe2\x80\x94for that matter Aristomache herself\xe2\x80\x94in the Greek; and as\r\nI keep the count, that is five. What sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast found him, my Messala,\xe2\x80\x9d Caius answered; \xe2\x80\x9cor I am not\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy pardon, Drusus\xe2\x80\x94and pardon of all\xe2\x80\x94for speaking in riddles thus,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nMessala said, in his winsome way. \xe2\x80\x9cBy all the decent gods, I would not\r\nstrain thy courtesy to the point of breaking, but now help thou me.\r\nSee!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he put his hand on the dice-box again, laughing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSee how close I\r\nhold the Pythias and their secret! Thou didst speak, I think, of\r\nmystery in connection with the coming of the son of Arrius. Tell me of\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis nothing, Messala, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d Drusus replied; \xe2\x80\x9ca child\xe2\x80\x99s story.\r\nWhen Arrius, the father, sailed in pursuit of the pirates, he was\r\nwithout wife or family; he returned with a boy\xe2\x80\x94him of whom we speak\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnext day adopted him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdopted him?\xe2\x80\x9d Messala repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the gods, Drusus, thou dost,\r\nindeed, interest me! Where did the duumvir find the boy? And who was\r\nhe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho shall answer thee that, Messala? who but the young Arrius himself?\r\nPerpol! in the fight the duumvir\xe2\x80\x94then but a tribune\xe2\x80\x94lost his galley. A\r\nreturning vessel found him and one other\xe2\x80\x94all of the crew who\r\nsurvived\xe2\x80\x94afloat upon the same plank. I give you now the story of the\r\nrescuers, which hath this excellence at least\xe2\x80\x94it hath never been\r\ncontradicted. They say, the duumvir\xe2\x80\x99s companion on the plank was a\r\nJew\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a slave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow Drusus? A slave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen the two were lifted to the deck, the duumvir was in his tribune\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narmor, and the other in the vesture of a rower.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala rose from leaning against the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA galley\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he checked the debasing word, and looked around, for once in\r\nhis life at loss. Just then a procession of slaves filed into the room,\r\nsome with great jars of wine, others with baskets of fruits and\r\nconfections, others again with cups and flagons, mostly silver. There\r\nwas inspiration in the sight. Instantly Messala climbed upon a stool.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen of the Tiber,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a clear voice, \xe2\x80\x9clet us turn this\r\nwaiting for our chief into a feast of Bacchus. Whom choose ye for\r\nmaster?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrusus arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho shall be master but the giver of the feast?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnswer,\r\nRomans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey gave their reply in a shout.\r\n\r\nMessala took the chaplet from his head, gave it to Drusus, who climbed\r\nupon the table, and, in the view of all, solemnly replaced it, making\r\nMessala master of the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere came with me into the room,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9csome friends just risen\r\nfrom table. That our feast may have the approval of sacred custom,\r\nbring hither that one of them most overcome by wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA din of voices answered, \xe2\x80\x9cHere he is, here he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd from the floor where he had fallen, a youth was brought forward, so\r\neffeminately beautiful he might have passed for the drinking-god\r\nhimself\xe2\x80\x94only the crown would have dropped from his head, and the\r\nthyrsus from his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLift him upon the table,\xe2\x80\x9d the master said.\r\n\r\nIt was found he could not sit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp him, Drusus, as the fair Nyone may yet help thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrusus took the inebriate in his arms.\r\n\r\nThen addressing the limp figure, Messala said, amidst profound silence,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Bacchus! greatest of the gods, be thou propitious to-night. And for\r\nmyself, and these thy votaries, I vow this chaplet\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and from his head\r\nhe raised it reverently\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI vow this chaplet to thy altar in the Grove\r\nof Daphne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed, replaced the crown upon his locks, then stooped and uncovered\r\nthe dice, saying, with a laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cSee, my Drusus, by the ass of Silenus,\r\nthe denarius is mine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a shout that set the floor to quaking, and the grim Atlantes\r\nto dancing, and the orgies began.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\n\r\n\r\nSheik Ilderim was a man of too much importance to go about with a small\r\nestablishment. He had a reputation to keep with his tribe, such as\r\nbecame a prince and patriarch of the greatest following in all the\r\nDesert east of Syria; with the people of the cities he had another\r\nreputation, which was that of one of the richest personages not a king\r\nin all the East; and, being rich in fact\xe2\x80\x94in money as well as in\r\nservants, camels, horses, and flocks of all kinds\xe2\x80\x94he took pleasure in a\r\ncertain state, which, besides magnifying his dignity with strangers,\r\ncontributed to his personal pride and comfort. Wherefore the reader\r\nmust not be misled by the frequent reference to his tent in the Orchard\r\nof Palms. He had there really a respectable dowar; that is to say, he\r\nhad there three large tents\xe2\x80\x94one for himself, one for visitors, one for\r\nhis favorite wife and her women; and six or eight lesser ones, occupied\r\nby his servants and such tribal retainers as he had chosen to bring\r\nwith him as a body-guard\xe2\x80\x94strong men of approved courage, and skillful\r\nwith bow, spear, and horses.\r\n\r\nTo be sure, his property of whatever kind was in no danger at the\r\nOrchard; yet as the habits of a man go with him to town not less than\r\nthe country, and as it is never wise to slip the bands of discipline,\r\nthe interior of the dowar was devoted to his cows, camels, goats, and\r\nsuch property in general as might tempt a lion or a thief.\r\n\r\nTo do him full justice, Ilderim kept well all the customs of his\r\npeople, abating none, not even the smallest; in consequence his life at\r\nthe Orchard was a continuation of his life in the Desert; nor that\r\nalone, it was a fair reproduction of the old patriarchal modes\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ngenuine pastoral life of primitive Israel.\r\n\r\nRecurring to the morning the caravan arrived at the Orchard\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\r\nplant it here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stopping his horse, and thrusting a spear into\r\nthe ground. \xe2\x80\x9cDoor to the south; the lake before it thus; and these, the\r\nchildren of the Desert, to sit under at the going-down of the sun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the last words he went to a group of three great palm-trees, and\r\npatted one of them as he would have patted his horse\xe2\x80\x99s neck, or the\r\ncheek of the child of his love.\r\n\r\nWho but the sheik could of right say to the caravan, Halt! or of the\r\ntent, Here be it pitched? The spear was wrested from the ground, and\r\nover the wound it had riven in the sod the base of the first pillar of\r\nthe tent was planted, marking the centre of the front door. Then eight\r\nothers were planted\xe2\x80\x94in all, three rows of pillars, three in a row.\r\nThen, at call, the women and children came, and unfolded the canvas\r\nfrom its packing on the camels. Who might do this but the women? Had\r\nthey not sheared the hair from the brown goats of the flock? and\r\ntwisted it into thread? and woven the thread into cloth? and stitched\r\nthe cloth together, making the perfect roof, dark-brown in fact, though\r\nin the distance black as the tents of Kedar? And, finally, with what\r\njests and laughter, and pulls altogether, the united following of the\r\nsheik stretched the canvas from pillar to pillar, driving the stakes\r\nand fastening the cords as they went! And when the walls of open reed\r\nmatting were put in place\xe2\x80\x94the finishing-touch to the building after the\r\nstyle of the Desert\xe2\x80\x94with what hush of anxiety they waited the good\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s judgment! When he walked in and out, looking at the house in\r\nconnection with the sun, the trees, and the lake, and said, rubbing his\r\nhands with might of heartiness, \xe2\x80\x9cWell done! Make the dowar now as ye\r\nwell know, and to-night we will sweeten the bread with arrack, and the\r\nmilk with honey, and at every fire there shall be a kid. God with ye!\r\nWant of sweet water there shall not be, for the lake is our well;\r\nneither shall the bearers of burden hunger, or the least of the flock,\r\nfor here is green pasture also. God with you all, my children! Go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, shouting, the many happy went their ways then to pitch their own\r\nhabitations. A few remained to arrange the interior for the sheik; and\r\nof these the men-servants hung a curtain to the central row of pillars,\r\nmaking two apartments; the one on the right sacred to Ilderim himself,\r\nthe other sacred to his horses\xe2\x80\x94his jewels of Solomon\xe2\x80\x94which they led in,\r\nand with kisses and love-taps set at liberty. Against the middle pillar\r\nthey then erected the arms-rack, and filled it with javelins and\r\nspears, and bows, arrows, and shields; outside of them hanging the\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s sword, modelled after the new moon; and the glitter of its\r\nblade rivalled the glitter of the jewels bedded in its grip. Upon one\r\nend of the rack they hung the housings of the horses, gay some of them\r\nas the livery of a king\xe2\x80\x99s servant, while on the other end they\r\ndisplayed the great man\xe2\x80\x99s wearing apparel\xe2\x80\x94his robes woollen and robes\r\nlinen, his tunics and trousers, and many colored kerchiefs for the\r\nhead. Nor did they give over the work until he pronounced it well.\r\n\r\nMeantime the women drew out and set up the divan, more indispensable to\r\nhim than the beard down-flowing over his breast, white as Aaron\xe2\x80\x99s. They\r\nput a frame together in shape of three sides of a square, the opening\r\nto the door, and covered it with cushions and base curtains, and the\r\ncushions with a changeable spread striped brown and yellow; at the\r\ncorners they placed pillows and bolsters sacked in cloth blue and\r\ncrimson; then around the divan they laid a margin of carpet, and the\r\ninner space they carpeted as well; and when the carpet was carried from\r\nthe opening of the divan to the door of the tent, their work was done;\r\nwhereupon they again waited until the master said it was good. Nothing\r\nremained then but to bring and fill the jars with water, and hang the\r\nskin bottles of arrack ready for the hand\xe2\x80\x94to-morrow the leben. Nor\r\nmight an Arab see why Ilderim should not be both happy and generous\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nhis tent by the lake of sweet waters, under the palms of the Orchard of\r\nPalms.\r\n\r\nSuch was the tent at the door of which we left Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nServants were already waiting the master\xe2\x80\x99s direction. One of them took\r\noff his sandals; another unlatched Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s Roman shoes; then the two\r\nexchanged their dusty outer garments for fresh ones of white linen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnter\xe2\x80\x94in God\xe2\x80\x99s name, enter, and take thy rest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host,\r\nheartily, in the dialect of the Market-place of Jerusalem; forthwith he\r\nled the way to the divan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will sit here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said next, pointing; \xe2\x80\x9cand there the stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA woman\xe2\x80\x94in the old time she would have been called a handmaid\xe2\x80\x94answered,\r\nand dexterously piled the pillows and bolsters as rests for the back;\r\nafter which they sat upon the side of the divan, while water was\r\nbrought fresh from the lake, and their feet bathed and dried with\r\nnapkins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have a saying in the Desert,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim began, gathering his beard,\r\nand combing it with his slender fingers, \xe2\x80\x9cthat a good appetite is the\r\npromise of a long life. Hast thou such?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy that rule, good sheik, I will live a hundred years. I am a hungry\r\nwolf at thy door,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, thou shalt not be sent away like a wolf. I will give thee the\r\nbest of the flocks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim clapped his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeek the stranger in the guest-tent, and say I, Ilderim, send him a\r\nprayer that his peace may be as incessant as the flowing of waters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man in waiting bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, also,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim continued, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I have returned with another for\r\nbreaking of bread; and, if Balthasar the wise careth to share the loaf,\r\nthree may partake of it, and the portion of the birds be none the\r\nless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe second servant went away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us take our rest now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon Ilderim settled himself upon the divan, as at this day\r\nmerchants sit on their rugs in the bazaars of Damascus; and when fairly\r\nat rest, he stopped combing his beard, and said, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cThat thou\r\nart my guest, and hast drunk my leben, and art about to taste my salt,\r\nought not to forbid a question: Who art thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSheik Ilderim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, calmly enduring his gaze, \xe2\x80\x9cI pray thee\r\nnot to think me trifling with thy just demand; but was there never a\r\ntime in thy life when to answer such a question would have been a crime\r\nto thyself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the splendor of Solomon, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim answered. \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayal of self\r\nis at times as base as the betrayal of a tribe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, thanks, good sheik!\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever answer became thee better. Now I know thou dost but seek\r\nassurance to justify the trust I have come to ask, and that such\r\nassurance is of more interest to thee than the affairs of my poor\r\nlife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik in his turn bowed, and Ben-Hur hastened to pursue his\r\nadvantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it please thee then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfirst, I am not a Roman, as the\r\nname given thee as mine implieth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim clasped the beard overflowing his breast, and gazed at the\r\nspeaker with eyes faintly twinkling through the shade of the heavy\r\nclose-drawn brows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the next place,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI am an Israelite of the tribe\r\nof Judah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik raised his brows a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor that merely. Sheik, I am a Jew with a grievance against Rome\r\ncompared with which thine is not more than a child\xe2\x80\x99s trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man combed his beard with nervous haste, and let fall his brows\r\nuntil even the twinkle of the eyes went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill further: I swear to thee, Sheik Ilderim\xe2\x80\x94I swear by the covenant\r\nthe Lord made with my fathers\xe2\x80\x94so thou but give me the revenge I seek,\r\nthe money and the glory of the race shall be thine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s brows relaxed; his head arose; his face began to beam; and it\r\nwas almost possible to see the satisfaction taking possession of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf at the roots of thy tongue there is a lie in\r\ncoil, Solomon himself had not been safe against thee. That thou art not\r\na Roman\xe2\x80\x94that as a Jew thou hast a grievance against Rome, and revenge\r\nto compass, I believe; and on that score enough. But as to thy skill.\r\nWhat experience hast thou in racing with chariots? And the horses\xe2\x80\x94canst\r\nthou make them creatures of thy will?\xe2\x80\x94to know thee? to come at call? to\r\ngo, if thou sayest it, to the last extreme of breath and strength? and\r\nthen, in the perishing moment, out of the depths of thy life thrill\r\nthem to one exertion the mightiest of all? The gift, my son, is not to\r\nevery one. Ah, by the splendor of God! I knew a king who governed\r\nmillions of men, their perfect master, but could not win the respect of\r\na horse. Mark! I speak not of the dull brutes whose round it is to\r\nslave for slaves\xe2\x80\x94the debased in blood and image\xe2\x80\x94the dead in spirit; but\r\nof such as mine here\xe2\x80\x94the kings of their kind; of a lineage reaching\r\nback to the broods of the first Pharaoh; my comrades and friends,\r\ndwellers in tents, whom long association with me has brought up to my\r\nplane; who to their instincts have added our wits and to their senses\r\njoined our souls, until they feel all we know of ambition, love, hate,\r\nand contempt; in war, heroes; in trust, faithful as women. Ho, there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA servant came forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet my Arabs come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man drew aside part of the division curtain of the tent, exposing\r\nto view a group of horses, who lingered a moment where they were as if\r\nto make certain of the invitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim said to them. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy stand ye there? What have I that is\r\nnot yours? Come, I say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey stalked slowly in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Israel,\xe2\x80\x9d the master said, \xe2\x80\x9cthy Moses was a mighty man, but\xe2\x80\x94ha,\r\nha ha!\xe2\x80\x94I must laugh when I think of his allowing thy fathers the\r\nplodding ox and the dull, slow-natured ass, and forbidding them\r\nproperty in horses. Ha, ha, ha! Thinkest thou he would have done so had\r\nhe seen that one\xe2\x80\x94and that\xe2\x80\x94and this?\xe2\x80\x9d At the word he laid his hand upon\r\nthe face of the first to reach him, and patted it with infinite pride\r\nand tenderness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a misjudgment, sheik, a misjudgment,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur said, warmly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoses was a warrior as well as a lawgiver beloved by God; and to\r\nfollow war\xe2\x80\x94ah, what is it but to love all its creatures\xe2\x80\x94these among the\r\nrest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA head of exquisite turn\xe2\x80\x94with large eyes, soft as a deer\xe2\x80\x99s, and half\r\nhidden by the dense forelock, and small ears, sharp-pointed and sloped\r\nwell forward\xe2\x80\x94approached then quite to his breast, the nostrils open,\r\nand the upper lip in motion. \xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d it asked, plainly as ever\r\nman spoke. Ben-Hur recognized one of the four racers he had seen on the\r\ncourse, and gave his open hand to the beautiful brute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will tell you, the blasphemers!\xe2\x80\x94may their days shorten as they\r\ngrow fewer!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the sheik spoke with the feeling of a man repelling a\r\npersonal defamation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthey will tell you, I say, that our horses of the\r\nbest blood are derived from the Nesaean pastures of Persia. God gave\r\nthe first Arab a measureless waste of sand, with some treeless\r\nmountains, and here and there a well of bitter waters; and said to him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Behold thy country!\xe2\x80\x99 And when the poor man complained, the Mighty One\r\npitied him, and said again, \xe2\x80\x98Be of cheer! for I will twice bless thee\r\nabove other men.\xe2\x80\x99 The Arab heard, and gave thanks, and with faith set\r\nout to find the blessings. He travelled all the boundaries first, and\r\nfailed; then he made a path into the desert, and went on and on\xe2\x80\x94and in\r\nthe heart of the waste there was an island of green very beautiful to\r\nsee; and in the heart of the island, lo! a herd of camels, and another\r\nof horses! He took them joyfully and kept them with care for what they\r\nwere\xe2\x80\x94best gifts of God. And from that green isle went forth all the\r\nhorses of the earth; even to the pastures of Nesaea they went; and\r\nnorthward to the dreadful vales perpetually threshed by blasts from the\r\nSea of Chill Winds. Doubt not the story; or if thou dost, may never\r\namulet have charm for an Arab again. Nay, I will give thee proof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe clapped his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring me the records of the tribe,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the servant who\r\nresponded.\r\n\r\nWhile waiting, the sheik played with the horses, patting their cheeks,\r\ncombing their forelocks with his fingers, giving each one a token of\r\nremembrance. Presently six men appeared with chests of cedar reinforced\r\nby bands of brass, and hinged and bolted with brass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, when they were all set down by the divan, \xe2\x80\x9cI meant\r\nnot all of them; only the records of the horses\xe2\x80\x94that one. Open it and\r\ntake back the others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chest was opened, disclosing a mass of ivory tablets strung on\r\nrings of silver wire; and as the tablets were scarcely thicker than\r\nwafers, each ring held several hundreds of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, taking some of the rings in his hand\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI know\r\nwith what care and zeal, my son, the scribes of the Temple in the Holy\r\nCity keep the names of the newly born, that every son of Israel may\r\ntrace his line of ancestry to its beginning, though it antedate the\r\npatriarchs. My fathers\xe2\x80\x94may the recollection of them be green\r\nforever!\xe2\x80\x94did not think it sinful to borrow the idea, and apply it to\r\ntheir dumb servants. See these tablets!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took the rings, and separating the tablets saw they bore rude\r\nhieroglyphs in Arabic, burned on the smooth surface by a sharp point of\r\nheated metal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCanst thou read them, O son of Israel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. Thou must tell me their meaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnow thou, then, each tablet records the name of a foal of the pure\r\nblood born to my fathers through the hundreds of years passed; and also\r\nthe names of sire and dam. Take them, and note their age, that thou\r\nmayst the more readily believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome of the tablets were nearly worn away. All were yellow with age.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the chest there, I can tell thee now, I have the perfect history;\r\nperfect because certified as history seldom is\xe2\x80\x94showing of what stock\r\nall these are sprung\xe2\x80\x94this one, and that now supplicating thy notice and\r\ncaress; and as they come to us here, their sires, even the furthest\r\nremoved in time, came to my sires, under a tent-roof like this of mine,\r\nto eat their measure of barley from the open hand, and be talked to as\r\nchildren; and as children kiss the thanks they have not speech to\r\nexpress. And now, O son of Israel, thou mayst believe my declaration\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nI am a lord of the Desert, behold my ministers! Take them from me, and\r\nI become as a sick man left by the caravan to die. Thanks to them, age\r\nhath not diminished the terror of me on the highways between cities;\r\nand it will not while I have strength to go with them. Ha, ha, ha! I\r\ncould tell thee marvels done by their ancestors. In a favoring time I\r\nmay do so; for the present, enough that they were never overtaken in\r\nretreat; nor, by the sword of Solomon, did they ever fail in pursuit!\r\nThat, mark you, on the sands and under saddle; but now\xe2\x80\x94I do not know\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nam afraid, for they are under yoke the first time, and the conditions\r\nof success are so many. They have the pride and the speed and the\r\nendurance. If I find them a master, they will win. Son of Israel! so\r\nthou art the man, I swear it shall be a happy day that brought thee\r\nthither. Of thyself now speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy it is that in the love of an Arab his\r\nhorse is next to his children; and I know, also, why the Arab horses\r\nare the best in the world; but, good sheik, I would not have you judge\r\nme by words alone; for, as you know, all promises of men sometimes\r\nfail. Give me the trial first on some plain hereabout, and put the four\r\nin my hand to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s face beamed again, and he would have spoken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA moment, good sheik, a moment!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me say further.\r\nFrom the masters in Rome I learned many lessons, little thinking they\r\nwould serve me in a time like this. I tell thee these thy sons of the\r\nDesert, though they have separately the speed of eagles and the\r\nendurance of lions, will fail if they are not trained to run together\r\nunder the yoke. For bethink thee, sheik, in every four there is one the\r\nslowest and one the swiftest; and while the race is always to the\r\nslowest, the trouble is always with the swiftest. It was so to-day; the\r\ndriver could not reduce the best to harmonious action with the poorest.\r\nMy trial may have no better result; but if so, I will tell thee of it:\r\nthat I swear. Wherefore, in the same spirit I say, can I get them to\r\nrun together, moved by my will, the four as one, thou shalt have the\r\nsestertii and the crown, and I my revenge. What sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim listened, combing his beard the while. At the end he said, with\r\na laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cI think better of thee, son of Israel. We have a saying in\r\nthe Desert, \xe2\x80\x98If you will cook the meal with words, I will promise an\r\nocean of butter.\xe2\x80\x99 Thou shalt have the horses in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that moment there was a stir at the rear entrance to the tent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe supper\xe2\x80\x94it is here! and yonder my friend Balthasar, whom thou shalt\r\nknow. He hath a story to tell which an Israelite should never tire of\r\nhearing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd to the servants he added,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake the records away, and return my jewels to their apartment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they did as he ordered.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV\r\n\r\n\r\nIf the reader will return now to the repast of the wise men at their\r\nmeeting in the desert, he will understand the preparations for the\r\nsupper in Ilderim\xe2\x80\x99s tent. The differences were chiefly such as were\r\nincident to ampler means and better service.\r\n\r\nThree rugs were spread on the carpet within the space so nearly\r\nenclosed by the divan; a table not more than a foot in height was\r\nbrought and set within the same place, and covered with a cloth. Off to\r\none side a portable earthenware oven was established under the\r\npresidency of a woman whose duty it was to keep the company in bread,\r\nor, more precisely, in hot cakes of flour from the handmills grinding\r\nwith constant sound in a neighboring tent.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Balthasar was conducted to the divan, where Ilderim and\r\nBen-Hur received him standing. A loose black gown covered his person;\r\nhis step was feeble, and his whole movement slow and cautious,\r\napparently dependent upon a long staff and the arm of a servant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, respectfully. \xe2\x80\x9cPeace and\r\nwelcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian raised his head and replied, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd to thee, good sheik\xe2\x80\x94to\r\nthee and thine, peace and the blessing of the One God\xe2\x80\x94God the true and\r\nloving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manner was gentle and devout, and impressed Ben-Hur with a feeling\r\nof awe; besides which the blessing included in the answering salutation\r\nhad been partly addressed to him, and while that part was being spoken,\r\nthe eyes of the aged guest, hollow yet luminous, rested upon his face\r\nlong enough to stir an emotion new and mysterious, and so strong that\r\nhe again and again during the repast scanned the much wrinkled and\r\nbloodless face for its meaning; but always there was the expression\r\nbland, placid, and trustful as a child\xe2\x80\x99s. A little later he found that\r\nexpression habitual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is he, O Balthasar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sheik, laying his hand on Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narm, \xe2\x80\x9cwho will break bread with us this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian glanced at the young man, and looked again surprised and\r\ndoubting; seeing which the sheik continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI have promised him my\r\nhorses for trial to-morrow; and if all goes well, he will drive them in\r\nthe Circus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar continued his gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe came well recommended,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim pursued, much puzzled. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may\r\nknow him as the son of Arrius, who was a noble Roman sailor,\r\nthough\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the sheik hesitated, then resumed, with a laugh\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthough he\r\ndeclares himself an Israelite of the tribe of Judah; and, by the\r\nsplendor of God, I believe what he tells me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar could no longer withhold explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-day, O most generous sheik, my life was in peril, and would have\r\nbeen lost had not a youth, the counterpart of this one\xe2\x80\x94if, indeed, he\r\nbe not the very same\xe2\x80\x94intervened when all others fled, and saved me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThen he addressed Ben-Hur directly, \xe2\x80\x9cArt thou not he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot answer so far,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied, with modest deference. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nhe who stopped the horses of the insolent Roman when they were rushing\r\nupon thy camel at the Fountain of Castalia. Thy daughter left a cup\r\nwith me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the bosom of his tunic he produced the cup, and gave it to\r\nBalthasar.\r\n\r\nA glow lighted the faded countenance of the Egyptian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord sent thee to me at the Fountain to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a\r\ntremulous voice, stretching his hand towards Ben-Hur; \xe2\x80\x9cand he sends\r\nthee to me now. I give him thanks; and praise him thou, for of his\r\nfavor I have wherewith to give thee great reward, and I will. The cup\r\nis thine; keep it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took back the gift, and Balthasar, seeing the inquiry upon\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s face, related the occurrence at the Fountain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sheik to Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cThou saidst nothing of this to me,\r\nwhen better recommendation thou couldst not have brought. Am I not an\r\nArab, and sheik of my tribe of tens of thousands? And is not he my\r\nguest? And is it not in my guest-bond that the good or evil thou dost\r\nhim is good or evil done to me? Whither shouldst thou go for reward but\r\nhere? And whose the hand to give it but mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis voice at the end of the speech rose to cutting shrillness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood sheik, spare me, I pray. I came not for reward, great or small;\r\nand that I may be acquitted of the thought, I say the help I gave this\r\nexcellent man would have been given as well to thy humblest servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is my friend, my guest\xe2\x80\x94not my servant; and seest thou not in\r\nthe difference the favor of Fortune?\xe2\x80\x9d Then to Balthasar the sheik\r\nsubjoined, \xe2\x80\x9cAh, by the splendor of God! I tell thee again he is not a\r\nRoman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that he turned away, and gave attention to the servants, whose\r\npreparations for the supper were about complete.\r\n\r\nThe reader who recollects the history of Balthasar as given by himself\r\nat the meeting in the desert will understand the effect of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nassertion of disinterestedness upon that worthy. In his devotion to men\r\nthere had been, it will be remembered, no distinctions; while the\r\nredemption which had been promised him in the way of reward\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nredemption for which he was waiting\xe2\x80\x94was universal. To him, therefore,\r\nthe assertion sounded somewhat like an echo of himself. He took a step\r\nnearer Ben-Hur, and spoke to him in the childlike way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did the sheik say I should call you? It was a Roman name, I\r\nthink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArrius, the son of Arrius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet thou art not a Roman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll my people were Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere, saidst thou? Are they not living?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question was subtle as well as simple; but Ilderim saved Ben-Hur\r\nfrom reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to them, \xe2\x80\x9cthe meal is ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur gave his arm to Balthasar, and conducted him to the table,\r\nwhere shortly they were all seated on their rugs Eastern fashion. The\r\nlavers were brought them, and they washed and dried their hands; then\r\nthe sheik made a sign, the servants stopped, and the voice of the\r\nEgyptian arose tremulous with holy feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather of All\xe2\x80\x94God! What we have is of thee; take our thanks, and bless\r\nus, that we may continue to do thy will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the grace the good man had said simultaneously with his brethren\r\nGaspar the Greek and Melchior the Hindoo, the utterance in diverse\r\ntongues out of which had come the miracle attesting the Divine Presence\r\nat the meal in the desert years before.\r\n\r\nThe table to which they immediately addressed themselves was, as may be\r\nthought, rich in the substantials and delicacies favorite in the\r\nEast\xe2\x80\x94in cakes hot from the oven, vegetables from the gardens, meats\r\nsingly, compounds of meats and vegetables, milk of kine, and honey and\r\nbutter\xe2\x80\x94all eaten or drunk, it should be remarked, without any of the\r\nmodern accessories\xe2\x80\x94knives, forks, spoons, cups, or plates; and in this\r\npart of the repast but little was said, for they were hungry. But when\r\nthe dessert was in course it was otherwise. They laved their hands\r\nagain, had the lap-cloths shaken out, and with a renewed table and the\r\nsharp edge of their appetites gone they were disposed to talk and\r\nlisten.\r\n\r\nWith such a company\xe2\x80\x94an Arab, a Jew, and an Egyptian, all believers\r\nalike in one God\xe2\x80\x94there could be at that age but one subject of\r\nconversation; and of the three, which should be speaker but he to whom\r\nthe Deity had been so nearly a personal appearance, who had seen him in\r\na star, had heard his voice in direction, had been led so far and so\r\nmiraculously by his Spirit? And of what should he talk but that of\r\nwhich he had been called to testify?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\n\r\n\r\nThe shadows cast over the Orchard of Palms by the mountains at set of\r\nsun left no sweet margin time of violet sky and drowsing earth between\r\nthe day and night. The latter came early and swift; and against its\r\nglooming in the tent this evening the servants brought four\r\ncandlesticks of brass, and set them by the corners of the table. To\r\neach candlestick there were four branches, and on each branch a lighted\r\nsilver lamp and a supply cup of olive-oil. In light ample, even\r\nbrilliant, the group at dessert continued their conversation, speaking\r\nin the Syriac dialect, familiar to all peoples in that part of the\r\nworld.\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian told his story of the meeting of the three in the desert,\r\nand agreed with the sheik that it was in December, twenty-seven years\r\nbefore, when he and his companions fleeing from Herod arrived at the\r\ntent praying shelter. The narrative was heard with intense interest;\r\neven the servants lingering when they could to catch its details.\r\nBen-Hur received it as became a man listening to a revelation of deep\r\nconcern to all humanity, and to none of more concern than the people of\r\nIsrael. In his mind, as we shall presently see, there was crystallizing\r\nan idea which was to change his course of life, if not absorb it\r\nabsolutely.\r\n\r\nAs the recital proceeded, the impression made by Balthasar upon the\r\nyoung Jew increased; at its conclusion, his feeling was too profound to\r\npermit a doubt of its truth; indeed, there was nothing left him\r\ndesirable in the connection but assurances, if such were to be had,\r\npertaining exclusively to the consequences of the amazing event.\r\n\r\nAnd now there is wanting an explanation which the very discerning may\r\nhave heretofore demanded; certainly it can be no longer delayed. Our\r\ntale begins, in point of date not less than fact, to trench close upon\r\nthe opening of the ministry of the Son of Mary, whom we have seen but\r\nonce since this same Balthasar left him worshipfully in his mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlap in the cave by Bethlehem. Henceforth to the end the mysterious\r\nChild will be a subject of continual reference; and slowly though\r\nsurely the current of events with which we are dealing will bring us\r\nnearer and nearer to him, until finally we see him a man\xe2\x80\x94we would like,\r\nif armed contrariety of opinion would permit it, to add\xe2\x80\x94A MAN WHOM THE\r\nWORLD COULD NOT DO WITHOUT. Of this declaration, apparently so simple,\r\na shrewd mind inspired by faith will make much\xe2\x80\x94and in welcome. Before\r\nhis time, and since, there have been men indispensable to particular\r\npeople and periods; but his indispensability was to the whole race, and\r\nfor all time\xe2\x80\x94a respect in which it is unique, solitary, divine.\r\n\r\nTo Sheik Ilderim the story was not new. He had heard it from the three\r\nwise men together under circumstances which left no room for doubt; he\r\nhad acted upon it seriously, for the helping a fugitive escape from the\r\nanger of the first Herod was dangerous. Now one of the three sat at his\r\ntable again, a welcome guest and revered friend. Sheik Ilderim\r\ncertainly believed the story; yet, in the nature of things, its mighty\r\ncentral fact could not come home to him with the force and absorbing\r\neffect it came to Ben-Hur. He was an Arab, whose interest in the\r\nconsequences was but general; on the other hand, Ben-Hur was an\r\nIsraelite and a Jew, with more than a special interest in\xe2\x80\x94if the\r\nsolecism can be pardoned\xe2\x80\x94the truth of the fact. He laid hold of the\r\ncircumstance with a purely Jewish mind.\r\n\r\nFrom his cradle, let it be remembered, he had heard of the Messiah; at\r\nthe colleges he had been made familiar with all that was known of that\r\nBeing at once the hope, the fear, and the peculiar glory of the chosen\r\npeople; the prophets from the first to the last of the heroic line\r\nforetold him; and the coming had been, and yet was, the theme of\r\nendless exposition with the rabbis\xe2\x80\x94in the synagogues, in the schools,\r\nin the Temple, of fast-days and feast-days, in public and in private,\r\nthe national teachers expounded and kept expounding until all the\r\nchildren of Abraham, wherever their lots were cast, bore the Messiah in\r\nexpectation, and by it literally, and with iron severity, ruled and\r\nmoulded their lives.\r\n\r\nDoubtless, it will be understood from this that there was much argument\r\namong the Jews themselves about the Messiah, and so there was; but the\r\ndisputation was all limited to one point, and one only\xe2\x80\x94when would he\r\ncome?\r\n\r\nDisquisition is for the preacher; whereas the writer is but telling a\r\ntale, and that he may not lose his character, the explanation he is\r\nmaking requires notice merely of a point connected with the Messiah\r\nabout which the unanimity among the chosen people was matter of\r\nmarvellous astonishment: he was to be, when come, the KING OF THE\r\nJEWS\xe2\x80\x94their political King, their Caesar. By their instrumentality he\r\nwas to make armed conquest of the earth, and then, for their profit and\r\nin the name of God, hold it down forever. On this faith, dear reader,\r\nthe Pharisees or Separatists\xe2\x80\x94the latter being rather a political\r\nterm\xe2\x80\x94in the cloisters and around the altars of the Temple, built an\r\nedifice of hope far overtopping the dream of the Macedonian. His but\r\ncovered the earth; theirs covered the earth and filled the skies; that\r\nis to say, in their bold, boundless fantasy of blasphemous egotism, God\r\nthe Almighty was in effect to suffer them for their uses to nail him by\r\nthe ear to a door in sign of eternal servitude.\r\n\r\nReturning directly to Ben-Hur, it is to be observed now that there were\r\ntwo circumstances in his life the result of which had been to keep him\r\nin a state comparatively free from the influence and hard effects of\r\nthe audacious faith of his Separatist countrymen.\r\n\r\nIn the first place, his father followed the faith of the Sadducees, who\r\nmay, in a general way, be termed the Liberals of their time. They had\r\nsome loose opinions in denial of the soul. They were strict\r\nconstructionists and rigorous observers of the Law as found in the\r\nbooks of Moses; but they held the vast mass of Rabbinical addenda to\r\nthose books in derisive contempt. They were unquestionably a sect, yet\r\ntheir religion was more a philosophy than a creed; they did not deny\r\nthemselves the enjoyments of life, and saw many admirable methods and\r\nproductions among the Gentile divisions of the race. In politics they\r\nwere the active opposition of the Separatists. In the natural order of\r\nthings, these circumstances and conditions, opinions and peculiarities,\r\nwould have descended to the son as certainly and really as any portion\r\nof his father\xe2\x80\x99s estate; and, as we have seen, he was actually in course\r\nof acquiring them, when the second saving event overtook him.\r\n\r\nUpon a youth of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s mind and temperament the influence of five\r\nyears of affluent life in Rome can be appreciated best by recalling\r\nthat the great city was then, in fact, the meeting-place of the\r\nnations\xe2\x80\x94their meeting-place politically and commercially, as well as\r\nfor the indulgence of pleasure without restraint. Round and round the\r\ngolden mile-stone in front of the Forum\xe2\x80\x94now in gloom of eclipse, now in\r\nunapproachable splendor\xe2\x80\x94flowed all the active currents of humanity. If\r\nexcellences of manner, refinements of society, attainments of\r\nintellect, and glory of achievement made no impression upon him, how\r\ncould he, as the son of Arrius, pass day after day, through a period so\r\nlong, from the beautiful villa near Misenum into the receptions of\r\nCaesar, and be wholly uninfluenced by what he saw there of kings,\r\nprinces, ambassadors, hostages, and delegates, suitors all of them from\r\nevery known land, waiting humbly the yes or no which was to make or\r\nunmake them? As mere assemblages, to be sure, there was nothing to\r\ncompare with the gatherings at Jerusalem in celebration of the\r\nPassover; yet when he sat under the purple velaria of the Circus\r\nMaximus one of three hundred and fifty thousand spectators, he must\r\nhave been visited by the thought that possibly there might be some\r\nbranches of the family of man worthy divine consideration, if not\r\nmercy, though they were of the uncircumcised\xe2\x80\x94some, by their sorrows,\r\nand, yet worse, by their hopelessness in the midst of sorrows, fitted\r\nfor brotherhood in the promises to his countrymen.\r\n\r\nThat he should have had such a thought under such circumstances was but\r\nnatural; we think so much, at least, will be admitted: but when the\r\nreflection came to him, and he gave himself up to it, he could not have\r\nbeen blind to a certain distinction. The wretchedness of the masses,\r\nand their hopeless condition, had no relation whatever to religion;\r\ntheir murmurs and groans were not against their gods or for want of\r\ngods. In the oak-woods of Britain the Druids held their followers; Odin\r\nand Freya maintained their godships in Gaul and Germany and among the\r\nHyperboreans; Egypt was satisfied with her crocodiles and Anubis; the\r\nPersians were yet devoted to Ormuzd and Ahriman, holding them in equal\r\nhonor; in hope of the Nirvana, the Hindoos moved on patient as ever in\r\nthe rayless paths of Brahm; the beautiful Greek mind, in pauses of\r\nphilosophy, still sang the heroic gods of Homer; while in Rome nothing\r\nwas so common and cheap as gods. According to whim, the masters of the\r\nworld, because they were masters, carried their worship and offerings\r\nindifferently from altar to altar, delighted in the pandemonium they\r\nhad erected. Their discontent, if they were discontented, was with the\r\nnumber of gods; for, after borrowing all the divinities of the earth\r\nthey proceeded to deify their Caesars, and vote them altars and holy\r\nservice. No, the unhappy condition was not from religion, but\r\nmisgovernment and usurpations and countless tyrannies. The Avernus men\r\nhad been tumbled into, and were praying to be relieved from, was\r\nterribly but essentially political. The supplication\xe2\x80\x94everywhere alike,\r\nin Lodinum, Alexandria, Athens, Jerusalem\xe2\x80\x94was for a king to conquer\r\nwith, not a god to worship.\r\n\r\nStudying the situation after two thousand years, we can see and say\r\nthat religiously there was no relief from the universal confusion\r\nexcept some God could prove himself a true God, and a masterful one,\r\nand come to the rescue; but the people of the time, even the discerning\r\nand philosophical, discovered no hope except in crushing Rome; that\r\ndone, the relief would follow in restorations and reorganizations;\r\ntherefore they prayed, conspired, rebelled, fought, and died, drenching\r\nthe soil to-day with blood, to-morrow with tears\xe2\x80\x94and always with the\r\nsame result.\r\n\r\nIt remains to be said now that Ben-Hur was in agreement with the mass\r\nof men of his time not Romans. The five years\xe2\x80\x99 residence in the capital\r\nserved him with opportunity to see and study the miseries of the\r\nsubjugated world; and in full belief that the evils which afflicted it\r\nwere political, and to be cured only by the sword, he was going forth\r\nto fit himself for a part in the day of resort to the heroic remedy. By\r\npractice of arms he was a perfect soldier; but war has its higher\r\nfields, and he who would move successfully in them must know more than\r\nto defend with shield and thrust with spear. In those fields the\r\ngeneral finds his tasks, the greatest of which is the reduction of the\r\nmany into one, and that one himself; the consummate captain is a\r\nfighting-man armed with an army. This conception entered into the\r\nscheme of life to which he was further swayed by the reflection that\r\nthe vengeance he dreamed of, in connection with his individual wrongs,\r\nwould be more surely found in some of the ways of war than in any\r\npursuit of peace.\r\n\r\nThe feelings with which he listened to Balthasar can be now understood.\r\nThe story touched two of the most sensitive points of his being so they\r\nrang within him. His heart beat fast\xe2\x80\x94and faster still when, searching\r\nhimself, he found not a doubt either that the recital was true in every\r\nparticular, or that the Child so miraculously found was the Messiah.\r\nMarvelling much that Israel rested so dead to the revelation, and that\r\nhe had never heard of it before that day, two questions presented\r\nthemselves to him as centring all it was at that moment further\r\ndesirable to know:\r\n\r\nWhere was the Child then?\r\n\r\nAnd what was his mission?\r\n\r\nWith apologies for the interruptions, he proceeded to draw out the\r\nopinions of Balthasar, who was in nowise loath to speak.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could answer you,\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar said, in his simple, earnest, devout\r\nway\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9coh, if I knew where he is, how quickly I would go to him! The seas\r\nshould not stay me, nor the mountains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have tried to find him, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nA smile flitted across the face of the Egyptian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first task I charged myself with after leaving the shelter given\r\nme in the desert\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Balthasar cast a grateful look at Ilderim\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwas to\r\nlearn what became of the Child. But a year had passed, and I dared not\r\ngo up to Judea in person, for Herod still held the throne bloody-minded\r\nas ever. In Egypt, upon my return, there were a few friends to believe\r\nthe wonderful things I told them of what I had seen and heard\xe2\x80\x94a few who\r\nrejoiced with me that a Redeemer was born\xe2\x80\x94a few who never tired of the\r\nstory. Some of them came up for me looking after the Child. They went\r\nfirst to Bethlehem, and found there the khan and the cave; but the\r\nsteward\xe2\x80\x94he who sat at the gate the night of the birth, and the night we\r\ncame following the star\xe2\x80\x94was gone. The king had taken him away, and he\r\nwas no more seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they found some proofs, surely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, proofs written in blood\xe2\x80\x94a village in mourning; mothers yet crying\r\nfor their little ones. You must know, when Herod heard of our flight,\r\nhe sent down and slew the youngest-born of the children of Bethlehem.\r\nNot one escaped. The faith of my messengers was confirmed; but they\r\ncame to me saying the Child was dead, slain with the other innocents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ben-Hur, aghast. \xe2\x80\x9cDead, sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, my son, I did not say so. I said they, my messengers, told me the\r\nChild was dead. I did not believe the report then; I do not believe it\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see\xe2\x80\x94thou hast some special knowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, not so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, dropping his gaze. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Spirit was to\r\ngo with us no farther than to the Child. When we came out of the cave,\r\nafter our presents were given and we had seen the babe, we looked first\r\nthing for the star; but it was gone, and we knew we were left to\r\nourselves. The last inspiration of the Holy One\xe2\x80\x94the last I can\r\nrecall\xe2\x80\x94was that which sent us to Ilderim for safety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sheik, fingering his beard nervously. \xe2\x80\x9cYou told me you\r\nwere sent to me by a Spirit\xe2\x80\x94I remember it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no special knowledge,\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar continued, observing the\r\ndejection which had fallen upon Ben-Hur; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, my son, I have given the\r\nmatter much thought\xe2\x80\x94thought continuing through years, inspired by\r\nfaith, which, I assure you, calling God for witness, is as strong in me\r\nnow as in the hour I heard the voice of the Spirit calling me by the\r\nshore of the lake. If you will listen, I will tell you why I believe\r\nthe Child is living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth Ilderim and Ben-Hur looked assent, and appeared to summon their\r\nfaculties that they might understand as well as hear. The interest\r\nreached the servants, who drew near to the divan, and stood listening.\r\nThroughout the tent there was the profoundest silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe three believe in God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar bowed his head as he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he is the Truth,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cHis word is God. The hills may turn\r\nto dust, and the seas be drunk dry by south winds; but his word shall\r\nstand, because it is the Truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe utterance was in a manner inexpressibly solemn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe voice, which was his, speaking to me by the lake, said, \xe2\x80\x98Blessed\r\nart thou, O son of Mizraim! The Redemption cometh. With two others from\r\nthe remotenesses of the earth, thou shalt see the Savior.\xe2\x80\x99 I have seen\r\nthe Savior\xe2\x80\x94blessed be his name!\xe2\x80\x94but the Redemption, which was the\r\nsecond part of the promise, is yet to come. Seest thou now? If the\r\nChild be dead, there is no agent to bring the Redemption about, and the\r\nword is naught, and God\xe2\x80\x94nay, I dare not say it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe threw up both hands in horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Redemption was the work for which the Child was born; and so long\r\nas the promise abides, not even death can separate him from his work\r\nuntil it is fulfilled, or at least in the way of fulfilment. Take you\r\nthat now as one reason for my belief; then give me further attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe good man paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilt thou not taste the wine? It is at thy hand\xe2\x80\x94see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim,\r\nrespectfully.\r\n\r\nBalthasar drank, and, seeming refreshed, continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Savior I saw was born of woman, in nature like us, and subject to\r\nall our ills\xe2\x80\x94even death. Let that stand as the first proposition.\r\nConsider next the work set apart to him. Was it not a performance for\r\nwhich only a man is fitted?\xe2\x80\x94a man wise, firm, discreet\xe2\x80\x94a man, not a\r\nchild? To become such he had to grow as we grow. Bethink you now of the\r\ndangers his life was subject to in the interval\xe2\x80\x94the long interval\r\nbetween childhood and maturity. The existing powers were his enemies;\r\nHerod was his enemy; and what would Rome have been? And as for\r\nIsrael\xe2\x80\x94that he should not be accepted by Israel was the motive for\r\ncutting him off. See you now. What better way was there to take care of\r\nhis life in the helpless growing time than by passing him into\r\nobscurity? Wherefore I say to myself, and to my listening faith, which\r\nis never moved except by yearning of love\xe2\x80\x94I say he is not dead, but\r\nlost; and, his work remaining undone, he will come again. There you\r\nhave the reasons for my belief. Are they not good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s small Arab eyes were bright with understanding, and Ben-Hur,\r\nlifted from his dejection, said heartily, \xe2\x80\x9cI, at least, may not gainsay\r\nthem. What further, pray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast thou not enough, my son? Well,\xe2\x80\x9d he began, in calmer tone, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing\r\nthat the reasons were good\xe2\x80\x94more plainly, seeing it was God\xe2\x80\x99s will that\r\nthe Child should not be found\xe2\x80\x94I settled my faith into the keeping of\r\npatience, and took to waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d He raised his eyes, full of holy trust,\r\nand broke off abstractedly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI am waiting now. He lives, keeping well\r\nhis mighty secret. What though I cannot go to him, or name the hill or\r\nthe vale of his abiding-place? He lives\xe2\x80\x94it may be as the fruit in\r\nblossom, it may be as the fruit just ripening; but by the certainty\r\nthere is in the promise and reason of God, I know he lives.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA thrill of awe struck Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x94a thrill which was but the dying of his\r\nhalf-formed doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere thinkest thou he is?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, in a low voice, and hesitating,\r\nlike one who feels upon his lips the pressure of a sacred silence.\r\n\r\nBalthasar looked at him kindly, and replied, his mind not entirely\r\nfreed from its abstraction,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my house on the Nile, so close to the river that the passers-by in\r\nboats see it and its reflection in the water at the same time\xe2\x80\x94in my\r\nhouse, a few weeks ago, I sat thinking. A man thirty years old, I said\r\nto myself, should have his fields of life all ploughed, and his\r\nplanting well done; for after that it is summer-time, with space scarce\r\nenough to ripen his sowing. The Child, I said further, is now\r\ntwenty-seven\xe2\x80\x94his time to plant must be at hand. I asked myself, as you\r\nhere asked me, my son, and answered by coming hither, as to a good\r\nresting-place close by the land thy fathers had from God. Where else\r\nshould he appear, if not in Judea? In what city should he begin his\r\nwork, if not in Jerusalem? Who should be first to receive the blessings\r\nhe is to bring, if not the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; in\r\nlove, at least, the children of the Lord? If I were bidden go seek him,\r\nI would search well the hamlets and villages on the slopes of the\r\nmountains of Judea and Galilee falling eastwardly into the valley of\r\nthe Jordan. He is there now. Standing in a door or on a hill-top, only\r\nthis evening he saw the sun set one day nearer the time when he himself\r\nshall become the light of the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar ceased, with his hand raised and finger pointing as if at\r\nJudea. All the listeners, even the dull servants outside the divan,\r\naffected by his fervor, were startled as if by a majestic presence\r\nsuddenly apparent within the tent. Nor did the sensation die away at\r\nonce: of those at the table, each sat awhile thinking. The spell was\r\nfinally broken by Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see, good Balthasar,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat thou hast been much and\r\nstrangely favored. I see, also, that thou art a wise man indeed. It is\r\nnot in my power to tell how grateful I am for the things thou hast told\r\nme. I am warned of the coming of great events, and borrow somewhat from\r\nthy faith. Complete the obligation, I pray thee, by telling further of\r\nthe mission of him for whom thou art waiting, and for whom from this\r\nnight I too shall wait as becomes a believing son of Judah. He is to be\r\na Savior, thou saidst; is he not to be King of the Jews also?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, in his benignant way, \xe2\x80\x9cthe mission is yet a\r\npurpose in the bosom of God. All I think about it is wrung from the\r\nwords of the Voice in connection with the prayer to which they were in\r\nanswer. Shall we refer to them again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art the teacher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cause of my disquiet,\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar began, calmly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat which made me\r\na preacher in Alexandria and in the villages of the Nile; that which\r\ndrove me at last into the solitude where the Spirit found me\xe2\x80\x94was the\r\nfallen condition of men, occasioned, as I believed, by loss of the\r\nknowledge of God. I sorrowed for the sorrows of my kind\xe2\x80\x94not of one\r\nclass, but all of them. So utterly were they fallen it seemed to me\r\nthere could be no Redemption unless God himself would make it his work;\r\nand I prayed him to come, and that I might see him. \xe2\x80\x98Thy good works\r\nhave conquered. The Redemption cometh; thou shalt see the Savior\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94thus\r\nthe Voice spake; and with the answer I went up to Jerusalem rejoicing.\r\nNow, to whom is the Redemption? To all the world. And how shall it be?\r\nStrengthen thy faith, my son! Men say, I know, that there will be no\r\nhappiness until Rome is razed from her hills. That is to say, the ills\r\nof the time are not, as I thought them, from ignorance of God, but from\r\nthe misgovernment of rulers. Do we need to be told that human\r\ngovernments are never for the sake of religion? How many kings have you\r\nheard of who were better than their subjects? Oh no, no! The Redemption\r\ncannot be for a political purpose\xe2\x80\x94to pull down rulers and powers, and\r\nvacate their places merely that others may take and enjoy them. If that\r\nwere all of it, the wisdom of God would cease to be surpassing. I tell\r\nyou, though it be but the saying of blind to blind, he that comes is to\r\nbe a Savior of souls; and the Redemption means God once more on earth,\r\nand righteousness, that his stay here may be tolerable to himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDisappointment showed plainly on Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face\xe2\x80\x94his head drooped; and\r\nif he was not convinced, he yet felt himself incapable that moment of\r\ndisputing the opinion of the Egyptian. Not so Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the splendor of God!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, impulsively, \xe2\x80\x9cthe judgment does\r\naway with all custom. The ways of the world are fixed, and cannot be\r\nchanged. There must be a leader in every community clothed with power,\r\nelse there is no reform.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar received the burst gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy wisdom, good sheik, is of the world; and thou dost forget that it\r\nis from the ways of the world we are to be redeemed. Man as a subject\r\nis the ambition of a king; the soul of a man for its salvation is the\r\ndesire of a God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim, though silenced, shook his head, unwilling to believe. Ben-Hur\r\ntook up the argument for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather\xe2\x80\x94I call thee such by permission,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cfor whom wert thou\r\nrequired to ask at the gates of Jerusalem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik threw him a grateful look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was to ask of the people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Where is he\r\nthat is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you saw him in the cave by Bethlehem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe saw and worshipped him, and gave him presents\xe2\x80\x94Melchior, gold;\r\nGaspar, frankincense; and I, myrrh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen thou dost speak of fact, O father, to hear thee is to believe,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Ben-Hur; \xe2\x80\x9cbut in the matter of opinion, I cannot understand the\r\nkind of king thou wouldst make of the Child\xe2\x80\x94I cannot separate the ruler\r\nfrom his powers and duties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have the habit of studying closely the\r\nthings which chance to lie at our feet, giving but a look at the\r\ngreater objects in the distance. Thou seest now but the title\xe2\x80\x94KING OF\r\nTHE JEWS; wilt thou lift thine eyes to the mystery beyond it, the\r\nstumbling-block will disappear. Of the title, a word. Thy Israel hath\r\nseen better days\xe2\x80\x94days in which God called thy people endearingly his\r\npeople, and dealt with them through prophets. Now, if in those days he\r\npromised them the Savior I saw\xe2\x80\x94promised him as KING OF THE JEWS\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nappearance must be according to the promise, if only for the word\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsake. Ah, thou seest the reason of my question at the gate!\xe2\x80\x94thou seest,\r\nand I will no more of it, but pass on. It may be, next, thou art\r\nregarding the dignity of the Child; if so, bethink thee\xe2\x80\x94what is it to\r\nbe a successor of Herod?\xe2\x80\x94by the world\xe2\x80\x99s standard of honor, what? Could\r\nnot God better by his beloved? If thou canst think of the Almighty\r\nFather in want of a title, and stooping to borrow the inventions of\r\nmen, why was I not bidden ask for a Caesar at once? Oh, for the\r\nsubstance of that whereof we speak, look higher, I pray thee! Ask\r\nrather of what he whom we await shall be king; for I do tell, my son,\r\nthat is the key to the mystery, which no man shall understand without\r\nthe key.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar raised his eyes devoutly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a kingdom on the earth, though it is not of it\xe2\x80\x94a kingdom of\r\nwider bounds than the earth\xe2\x80\x94wider than the sea and the earth, though\r\nthey were rolled together as finest gold and spread by the beating of\r\nhammers. Its existence is a fact as our hearts are facts, and we\r\njourney through it from birth to death without seeing it; nor shall any\r\nman see it until he hath first known his own soul; for the kingdom is\r\nnot for him, but for his soul. And in its dominion there is glory such\r\nas hath not entered imagination\xe2\x80\x94original, incomparable, impossible of\r\nincrease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat thou sayest, father, is a riddle to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cI never\r\nheard of such a kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor did I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I may not tell more of it,\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar added, humbly dropping his\r\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat it is, what it is for, how it may be reached, none can know\r\nuntil the Child comes to take possession of it as his own. He brings\r\nthe key of the viewless gate, which he will open for his beloved, among\r\nwhom will be all who love him, for of such only the redeemed will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter that there was a long silence, which Balthasar accepted as the\r\nend of the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in his placid way, \xe2\x80\x9cto-morrow or the next day I\r\nwill go up to the city for a time. My daughter wishes to see the\r\npreparations for the games. I will speak further about the time of our\r\ngoing. And, my son, I will see you again. To you both, peace and\r\ngood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey all arose from the table. The sheik and Ben-Hur remained looking\r\nafter the Egyptian until he was conducted out of the tent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSheik Ilderim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur then, \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard strange things\r\ntonight. Give me leave, I pray, to walk by the lake that I may think of\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo; and I will come after you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey washed their hands again; after which, at a sign from the master,\r\na servant brought Ben-Hur his shoes, and directly he went out.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\n\r\n\r\nUp a little way from the dower there was a cluster of palms, which\r\nthrew its shade half in the water, half on the land. A bulbul sang from\r\nthe branches a song of invitation. Ben-Hur stopped beneath to listen.\r\nAt any other time the notes of the bird would have driven thought away;\r\nbut the story of the Egyptian was a burden of wonder, and he was a\r\nlaborer carrying it, and, like other laborers, there was to him no\r\nmusic in the sweetest music until mind and body were happily attuned by\r\nrest.\r\n\r\nThe night was quiet. Not a ripple broke upon the shore. The old stars\r\nof the old East were all out, each in its accustomed place; and there\r\nwas summer everywhere\xe2\x80\x94on land, on lake, in the sky.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s imagination was heated, his feelings aroused, his will all\r\nunsettled.\r\n\r\nSo the palms, the sky, the air, seemed to him of the far south zone\r\ninto which Balthasar had been driven by despair for men; the lake, with\r\nits motionless surface, was a suggestion of the Nilotic mother by which\r\nthe good man stood praying when the Spirit made its radiant appearance.\r\nHad all these accessories of the miracle come to Ben-Hur? or had he\r\nbeen transferred to them? And what if the miracle should be\r\nrepeated\xe2\x80\x94and to him? He feared, yet wished, and even waited for the\r\nvision. When at last his feverish mood was cooled, permitting him to\r\nbecome himself, he was able to think.\r\n\r\nHis scheme of life has been explained. In all reflection about it\r\nheretofore there had been one hiatus which he had not been able to\r\nbridge or fill up\xe2\x80\x94one so broad he could see but vaguely to the other\r\nside of it. When, finally, he was graduated a captain as well as a\r\nsoldier, to what object should he address his efforts? Revolution he\r\ncontemplated, of course; but the processes of revolution have always\r\nbeen the same, and to lead men into them there have always been\r\nrequired, first, a cause or presence to enlist adherents; second, an\r\nend, or something as a practical achievement. As a rule he fights well\r\nwho has wrongs to redress; but vastly better fights he who, with wrongs\r\nas a spur, has also steadily before him a glorious result in prospect\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nresult in which he can discern balm for wounds, compensation for valor,\r\nremembrance and gratitude in the event of death.\r\n\r\nTo determine the sufficiency of either the cause or the end, it was\r\nneedful that Ben-Hur should study the adherents to whom he looked when\r\nall was ready for action. Very naturally, they were his countrymen. The\r\nwrongs of Israel were to every son of Abraham, and each one was a cause\r\nvastly holy, vastly inspiring.\r\n\r\nAy, the cause was there; but the end\xe2\x80\x94what should it be?\r\n\r\nThe hours and days he had given this branch of his scheme were past\r\ncalculation\xe2\x80\x94all with the same conclusion\xe2\x80\x94a dim, uncertain, general idea\r\nof national liberty. Was it sufficient? He could not say no, for that\r\nwould have been the death of his hope; he shrank from saying yes,\r\nbecause his judgment taught him better. He could not assure himself\r\neven that Israel was able single-handed to successfully combat Rome. He\r\nknew the resources of that great enemy; he knew her art was superior to\r\nher resources. A universal alliance might suffice, but, alas! that was\r\nimpossible, except\xe2\x80\x94and upon the exception how long and earnestly he had\r\ndwelt!\xe2\x80\x94except a hero would come from one of the suffering nations, and\r\nby martial successes accomplish a renown to fill the whole earth. What\r\nglory to Judea could she prove the Macedonia of the new Alexander!\r\nAlas, again! Under the rabbis valor was possible, but not discipline.\r\nAnd then the taunt of Messala in the garden of Herod\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAll you conquer\r\nin the six days, you lose on the seventh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo it happened he never approached the chasm thinking to surmount it,\r\nbut he was beaten back; and so incessantly had he failed in the object\r\nthat he had about given it over, except as a thing of chance. The hero\r\nmight be discovered in his day, or he might not. God only knew. Such\r\nhis state of mind, there need be no lingering upon the effect of\r\nMalluch\xe2\x80\x99s skeleton recital of the story of Balthasar. He heard it with\r\na bewildering satisfaction\xe2\x80\x94a feeling that here was the solution of the\r\ntrouble\xe2\x80\x94here was the requisite hero found at last; and he a son of the\r\nLion tribe, and King of the Jews! Behind the hero, lo! the world in\r\narms.\r\n\r\nThe king implied a kingdom; he was to be a warrior glorious as David, a\r\nruler wise and magnificent as Solomon; the kingdom was to be a power\r\nagainst which Rome was to dash itself to pieces. There would be\r\ncolossal war, and the agonies of death and birth\xe2\x80\x94then peace, meaning,\r\nof course, Judean dominion forever.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s heart beat hard as for an instant he had a vision of\r\nJerusalem the capital of the world, and Zion, the site of the throne of\r\nthe Universal Master.\r\n\r\nIt seemed to the enthusiast rare fortune that the man who had seen the\r\nking was at the tent to which he was going. He could see him there, and\r\nhear him, and learn of him what all he knew of the coming change,\r\nespecially all he knew of the time of its happening. If it were at\r\nhand, the campaign with Maxentius should be abandoned; and he would go\r\nand set about organizing and arming the tribes, that Israel might be\r\nready when the great day of the restoration began to break.\r\n\r\nNow, as we have seen, from Balthasar himself Ben-Hur had the marvelous\r\nstory. Was he satisfied?\r\n\r\nThere was a shadow upon him deeper than that of the cluster of\r\npalms\xe2\x80\x94the shadow of a great uncertainty, which\xe2\x80\x94take note, O reader!\r\nwhich pertained more to the kingdom than the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of this kingdom? And what is it to be?\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur asked himself in\r\nthought.\r\n\r\nThus early arose the questions which were to follow the Child to his\r\nend, and survive him on earth\xe2\x80\x94incomprehensible in his day, a dispute in\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94an enigma to all who do not or cannot understand that every man is\r\ntwo in one\xe2\x80\x94a deathless Soul and a mortal Body.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it to be?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nFor us, O reader, the Child himself has answered; but for Ben-Hur there\r\nwere only the words of Balthasar, \xe2\x80\x9cOn the earth, yet not of it\xe2\x80\x94not for\r\nmen, but for their souls\xe2\x80\x94a dominion, nevertheless, of unimaginable\r\nglory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat wonder the hapless youth found the phrases but the darkening of a\r\nriddle?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hand of man is not in it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, despairingly. \xe2\x80\x9cNor has the\r\nking of such a kingdom use for men; neither toilers, nor councillors,\r\nnor soldiers.
