The earth must die or be made anew, and for government\r\nnew principles must be discovered\xe2\x80\x94something besides armed\r\nhands\xe2\x80\x94something in place of Force. But what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain, O reader!\r\n\r\nThat which we will not see, he could not. The power there is in Love\r\nhad not yet occurred to any man; much less had one come saying directly\r\nthat for government and its objects\xe2\x80\x94peace and order\xe2\x80\x94Love is better and\r\nmightier than Force.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of his reverie a hand was laid upon his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a word to say, O son of Arrius,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, stopping by his\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca word, and then I must return, for the night is going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you welcome, sheik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to the things you have heard but now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, almost without\r\npause, \xe2\x80\x9ctake in belief all save that relating to the kind of kingdom\r\nthe Child will set up when he comes; as to so much keep virgin mind\r\nuntil you hear Simonides the merchant\xe2\x80\x94a good man here in Antioch, to\r\nwhom I will make you known. The Egyptian gives you coinage of his\r\ndreams which are too good for the earth; Simonides is wiser; he will\r\nring you the sayings of your prophets, giving book and page, so you\r\ncannot deny that the Child will be King of the Jews in fact\xe2\x80\x94ay, by the\r\nsplendor of God! a king as Herod was, only better and far more\r\nmagnificent. And then, see you, we will taste the sweetness of\r\nvengeance. I have said. Peace to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay\xe2\x80\x94sheik!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf Ilderim heard his call, he did not stay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides again!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cSimonides here, Simonides\r\nthere; from this one now, then from that! I am like to be well ridden\r\nby my father\xe2\x80\x99s servant, who knows at least to hold fast that which is\r\nmine; wherefore he is richer, if indeed he be not wiser, than the\r\nEgyptian. By the covenant! it is not to the faithless a man should go\r\nto find a faith to keep\xe2\x80\x94and I will not. But, hark! singing\xe2\x80\x94and the\r\nvoice a woman\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94or an angel\xe2\x80\x99s! It comes this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDown the lake towards the dower came a woman singing. Her voice floated\r\nalong the hushed water melodious as a flute, and louder growing each\r\ninstant. Directly the dipping of oars was heard in slow measure; a\r\nlittle later the words were distinguishable\xe2\x80\x94words in purest Greek, best\r\nfitted of all the tongues of the day for the expression of passionate\r\ngrief.\r\n\r\nTHE LAMENT.\r\n(Egyptian.)\r\n\r\n\r\nI sigh as I sing for the story land\r\n     Across the Syrian sea.\r\nThe odorous winds from the musky sand\r\n     Were breaths of life to me.\r\nThey play with the plumes of the whispering palm\r\n     For me, alas! no more;\r\nNor more does the Nile in the moonlit calm\r\n     Moan past the Memphian shore.\r\n\r\nO Nilus! thou god of my fainting soul!\r\n     In dreams thou comest to me;\r\nAnd, dreaming, I play with the lotus bowl,\r\n     And sing old songs to thee;\r\nAnd hear from afar the Memnonian strain,\r\n     And calls from dear Simbel;\r\nAnd wake to a passion of grief and pain\r\n     That e\xe2\x80\x99er I said\xe2\x80\x94Farewell!\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the conclusion of the song the singer was past the cluster of palms.\r\nThe last word\xe2\x80\x94farewell\xe2\x80\x94floated past Ben-Hur weighted with all the sweet\r\nsorrow of parting. The passing of the boat was as the passing of a\r\ndeeper shadow into the deeper night.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur drew a long breath hardly distinguishable from a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know her by the song\xe2\x80\x94the daughter of Balthasar. How beautiful it\r\nwas! And how beautiful is she!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe recalled her large eyes curtained slightly by the drooping lids, the\r\ncheeks oval and rosy rich, the lips full and deep with dimpling in the\r\ncorners, and all the grace of the tall lithe figure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful she is!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated.\r\n\r\nAnd his heart made answer by a quickening of its movement.\r\n\r\nThen, almost the same instant, another face, younger and quite as\r\nbeautiful\xe2\x80\x94more childlike and tender, if not so passionate\xe2\x80\x94appeared as\r\nif held up to him out of the lake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cAs I wished, a star has been sent to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned, and passed slowly back to the tent.\r\n\r\nHis life had been crowded with griefs and with vengeful\r\npreparations\xe2\x80\x94too much crowded for love. Was this the beginning of a\r\nhappy change?\r\n\r\nAnd if the influence went with him into the tent, whose was it? Esther\r\nhad given him a cup. So had the Egyptian. And both had come to him at\r\nthe same time under the palms.\r\n\r\nWhich?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK FIFTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly the actions of the just\r\nSmell sweet and blossom in the dust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                    SHIRLEY.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, through the heat of conflict, keeps the law,\r\nIn calmness made, and sees what he foresaw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                    WORDSWORTH.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThe morning after the bacchanalia in the saloon of the palace, the\r\ndivan was covered with young patricians. Maxentius might come, and the\r\ncity throng to receive him; the legion might descend from Mount Sulpius\r\nin glory of arms and armor; from Nymphaeum to Omphalus there might be\r\nceremonial splendors to shame the most notable ever before seen or\r\nheard of in the gorgeous East; yet would the many continue to sleep\r\nignominiously on the divan where they had fallen or been carelessly\r\ntumbled by the indifferent slaves; that they would be able to take part\r\nin the reception that day was about as possible as for the lay-figures\r\nin the studio of a modern artist to rise and go bonneted and plumed\r\nthrough the one, two, three of a waltz.\r\n\r\nNot all, however, who participated in the orgy were in the shameful\r\ncondition. When dawn began to peer through the skylights of the saloon,\r\nMessala arose, and took the chaplet from his head, in sign that the\r\nrevel was at end; then he gathered his robe about him, gave a last look\r\nat the scene, and, without a word, departed for his quarters. Cicero\r\ncould not have retired with more gravity from a night-long senatorial\r\ndebate.\r\n\r\nThree hours afterwards two couriers entered his room, and from his own\r\nhand received each a despatch, sealed and in duplicate, and consisting\r\nchiefly of a letter to Valerius Gratus, the procurator, still resident\r\nin Caesarea. The importance attached to the speedy and certain delivery\r\nof the paper may be inferred. One courier was to proceed overland, the\r\nother by sea; both were to make the utmost haste.\r\n\r\nIt is of great concern now that the reader should be fully informed of\r\nthe contents of the letter thus forwarded, and it is accordingly given:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cANTIOCH, XII. Kal. Jul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessala to Gratus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my Midas!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray thou take no offense at the address, seeing it is one of love\r\nand gratitude, and an admission that thou art most fortunate among men;\r\nseeing, also, that thy ears are as they were derived from thy mother,\r\nonly proportionate to thy matured condition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my Midas!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have to relate to thee an astonishing event, which, though as yet\r\nsomewhat in the field of conjecture, will, I doubt not, justify thy\r\ninstant consideration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me first to revive thy recollection. Remember, a good many years\r\nago, a family of a prince of Jerusalem, incredibly ancient and vastly\r\nrich\xe2\x80\x94by name Ben-Hur. If thy memory have a limp or ailment of any kind,\r\nthere is, if I mistake not, a wound on thy head which may help thee to\r\na revival of the circumstance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNext, to arouse thy interest. In punishment of the attempt upon thy\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94for dear repose of conscience, may all the gods forbid it should\r\never prove to have been an accident!\xe2\x80\x94the family were seized and\r\nsummarily disposed of, and their property confiscated. And inasmuch, O\r\nmy Midas! as the action had the approval of our Caesar, who was as just\r\nas he was wise\xe2\x80\x94be there flowers upon his altars forever!\xe2\x80\x94there should\r\nbe no shame in referring to the sums which were realized to us\r\nrespectively from that source, for which it is not possible I can ever\r\ncease to be grateful to thee, certainly not while I continue, as at\r\npresent, in the uninterrupted enjoyment of the part which fell to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn vindication of thy wisdom\xe2\x80\x94a quality for which, as I am now advised,\r\nthe son of Gordius, to whom I have boldly likened thee, was never\r\ndistinguished among men or gods\xe2\x80\x94I recall further that thou didst make\r\ndisposition of the family of Hur, both of us at the time supposing the\r\nplan hit upon to be the most effective possible for the purposes in\r\nview, which were silence and delivery over to inevitable but natural\r\ndeath. Thou wilt remember what thou didst with the mother and sister of\r\nthe malefactor; yet, if now I yield to a desire to learn whether they\r\nbe living or dead, I know, from knowing the amiability of thy nature, O\r\nmy Gratus, that thou wilt pardon me as one scarcely less amiable than\r\nthyself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs more immediately essential to the present business, however, I take\r\nthe liberty of inviting to thy remembrance that the actual criminal was\r\nsent to the galleys a slave for life\xe2\x80\x94so the precept ran; and it may\r\nserve to make the event which I am about to relate the more astonishing\r\nby saying here that I saw and read the receipt for his body delivered\r\nin course to the tribune commanding a galley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou mayst begin now to give me more especial heed, O my most\r\nexcellent Phrygian!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReferring to the limit of life at the oar, the outlaw thus justly\r\ndisposed of should be dead, or, better speaking, some one of the three\r\nthousand Oceanides should have taken him to husband at least five years\r\nago. And if thou wilt excuse a momentary weakness, O most virtuous and\r\ntender of men! inasmuch as I loved him in childhood, and also because\r\nhe was very handsome\xe2\x80\x94I used in much admiration to call him my\r\nGanymede\xe2\x80\x94he ought in right to have fallen into the arms of the most\r\nbeautiful daughter of the family. Of opinion, however, that he was\r\ncertainly dead, I have lived quite five years in calm and innocent\r\nenjoyment of the fortune for which I am in a degree indebted to him. I\r\nmake the admission of indebtedness without intending it to diminish my\r\nobligation to thee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I am at the very point of interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast night, while acting as master of the feast for a party just from\r\nRome\xe2\x80\x94their extreme youth and inexperience appealed to my compassion\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nheard a singular story. Maxentius, the consul, as you know, comes\r\nto-day to conduct a campaign against the Parthians. Of the ambitious\r\nwho are to accompany him there is one, a son of the late duumvir\r\nQuintus Arrius. I had occasion to inquire about him particularly. When\r\nArrius set out in pursuit of the pirates, whose defeat gained him his\r\nfinal honors, he had no family; when he returned from the expedition,\r\nhe brought back with him an heir. Now be thou composed as becomes the\r\nowner of so many talents in ready sestertii! The son and heir of whom I\r\nspeak is he whom thou didst send to the galleys\xe2\x80\x94the very Ben-Hur who\r\nshould have died at his oar five years ago\xe2\x80\x94returned now with fortune\r\nand rank, and possibly as a Roman citizen, to\xe2\x80\x94 Well, thou art too\r\nfirmly seated to be alarmed, but I, O my Midas! I am in danger\xe2\x80\x94no need\r\nto tell thee of what. Who should know, if thou dost not?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSayst thou to all this, tut-tut?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen Arrius, the father, by adoption, of this apparition from the arms\r\nof the most beautiful of the Oceanides (see above my opinion of what\r\nshe should be), joined battle with the pirates, his vessel was sunk,\r\nand but two of all her crew escaped drowning\xe2\x80\x94Arrius himself and this\r\none, his heir.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe officers who took them from the plank on which they were floating\r\nsay the associate of the fortunate tribune was a young man who, when\r\nlifted to the deck, was in the dress of a galley slave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis should be convincing, to say least; but lest thou say tut-tut\r\nagain, I tell thee, O my Midas! that yesterday, by good chance\xe2\x80\x94I have a\r\nvow to Fortune in consequence\xe2\x80\x94I met the mysterious son of Arrius face\r\nto face; and I declare now that, though I did not then recognize him,\r\nhe is the very Ben-Hur who was for years my playmate; the very Ben-Hur\r\nwho, if he be a man, though of the commonest grade, must this very\r\nmoment of my writing be thinking of vengeance\xe2\x80\x94for so would I were I\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x94vengeance not to be satisfied short of life; vengeance for country,\r\nmother, sister, self, and\xe2\x80\x94I say it last, though thou mayst think it\r\nwould be first\xe2\x80\x94for fortune lost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy this time, O good my benefactor and friend! my Gratus! in\r\nconsideration of thy sestertii in peril, their loss being the worst\r\nwhich could befall one of thy high estate\xe2\x80\x94I quit calling thee after the\r\nfoolish old King of Phrygia\xe2\x80\x94by this time, I say (meaning after having\r\nread me so far), I have faith to believe thou hast ceased saying\r\ntut-tut, and art ready to think what ought to be done in such\r\nemergency.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were vulgar to ask thee now what shall be done. Rather let me say I\r\nam thy client; or, better yet, thou art my Ulysses whose part it is to\r\ngive me sound direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I please myself thinking I see thee when this letter is put into\r\nthy hand. I see thee read it once; thy countenance all gravity, and\r\nthen again with a smile; then, hesitation ended, and thy judgment\r\nformed, it is this, or it is that; wisdom like Mercury\xe2\x80\x99s, promptitude\r\nlike Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sun is now fairly risen. An hour hence two messengers will depart\r\nfrom my door, each with a sealed copy hereof; one of them will go by\r\nland, the other by sea, so important do I regard it that thou shouldst\r\nbe early and particularly informed of the appearance of our enemy in\r\nthis part of our Roman world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will await thy answer here.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s going and coming will of course be regulated by his master,\r\nthe consul, who, though he exert himself without rest day and night,\r\ncannot get away under a month. Thou knowest what work it is to assemble\r\nand provide for an army destined to operate in a desolate, townless\r\ncountry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw the Jew yesterday in the Grove of Daphne; and if he be not there\r\nnow, he is certainly in the neighborhood, making it easy for me to keep\r\nhim in eye. Indeed, wert thou to ask me where he is now, I should say,\r\nwith the most positive assurance, he is to be found at the old Orchard\r\nof Palms, under the tent of the traitor Sheik Ilderim, who cannot long\r\nescape our strong hand. Be not surprised if Maxentius, as his first\r\nmeasure, places the Arab on ship for forwarding to Rome.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so particular about the whereabouts of the Jew because it will be\r\nimportant to thee, O illustrious! when thou comest to consider what is\r\nto be done; for already I know, and by the knowledge I flatter myself I\r\nam growing in wisdom, that in every scheme involving human action there\r\nare three elements always to be taken into account\xe2\x80\x94time, place, and\r\nagency.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou sayest this is the place, have thou then no hesitancy in\r\ntrusting the business to thy most loving friend, who would be thy\r\naptest scholar as well.\r\n\r\nMESSALA.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout the time the couriers departed from Messala\xe2\x80\x99s door with the\r\ndespatches (it being yet the early morning hour), Ben-Hur entered\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s tent. He had taken a plunge into the lake, and breakfasted,\r\nand appeared now in an under-tunic, sleeveless, and with skirt scarcely\r\nreaching to the knee.\r\n\r\nThe sheik saluted him from the divan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give thee peace, son of Arrius,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with admiration, for, in\r\ntruth, he had never seen a more perfect illustration of glowing,\r\npowerful, confident manhood. \xe2\x80\x9cI give thee peace and good-will. The\r\nhorses are ready, I am ready. And thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe peace thou givest me, good sheik, I give thee in return. I thank\r\nthee for so much good-will. I am ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim clapped his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will have the horses brought. Be seated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre they yoked?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen suffer me to serve myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is needful that I\r\nmake the acquaintance of thy Arabs. I must know them by name, O sheik,\r\nthat I may speak to them singly; nor less must I know their temper, for\r\nthey are like men: if bold, the better of scolding; if timid, the\r\nbetter of praise and flattery. Let the servants bring me the harness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the chariot?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sheik.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will let the chariot alone to-day. In its place, let them bring me a\r\nfifth horse, if thou hast it; he should be barebacked, and fleet as the\r\nothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s wonder was aroused, and he summoned a servant immediately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBid them bring the harness for the four,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe harness for the\r\nfour, and the bridle for Sirius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim then arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSirius is my love, and I am his, O son of Arrius. We have been\r\ncomrades for twenty years\xe2\x80\x94in tent, in battle, in all stages of the\r\ndesert we have been comrades. I will show him to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGoing to the division curtain, he held it, while Ben-Hur passed under.\r\nThe horses came to him in a body. One with a small head, luminous eyes,\r\nneck like the segment of a bended bow, and mighty chest, curtained\r\nthickly by a profusion of mane soft and wavy as a damsel\xe2\x80\x99s locks,\r\nnickered low and gladly at sight of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood horse,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sheik, patting the dark-brown cheek. \xe2\x80\x9cGood\r\nhorse, good-morning.\xe2\x80\x9d Turning then to Ben-Hur, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is\r\nSirius, father of the four here. Mira, the mother, awaits our return,\r\nbeing too precious to be hazarded in a region where there is a stronger\r\nhand than mine. And much I doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d he laughed as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmuch I\r\ndoubt, O son of Arrius, if the tribe could endure her absence. She is\r\ntheir glory; they worship her; did she gallop over them, they would\r\nlaugh. Ten thousand horsemen, sons of the desert, will ask to-day,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you heard of Mira?\xe2\x80\x99 And to the answer, \xe2\x80\x98She is well,\xe2\x80\x99 they will\r\nsay, \xe2\x80\x98God is good! blessed be God!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMira\xe2\x80\x94Sirius\xe2\x80\x94names of stars, are they not, O sheik?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur,\r\ngoing to each of the four, and to the sire, offering his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ilderim. \xe2\x80\x9cWert thou ever abroad on the desert at\r\nnight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen thou canst not know how much we Arabs depend upon the stars. We\r\nborrow their names in gratitude, and give them in love. My fathers all\r\nhad their Miras, as I have mine; and these children are stars no less.\r\nThere, see thou, is Rigel, and there Antares; that one is Atair, and he\r\nwhom thou goest to now is Aldebaran, the youngest of the brood, but\r\nnone the worse of that\xe2\x80\x94no, not he! Against the wind he will carry thee\r\ntill it roar in thy ears like Akaba; and he will go where thou sayest,\r\nson of Arrius\xe2\x80\x94ay, by the glory of Solomon! he will take thee to the\r\nlion\xe2\x80\x99s jaws, if thou darest so much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe harness was brought. With his own hands Ben-Hur equipped the\r\nhorses; with his own hands he led them out of the tent, and there\r\nattached the reins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring me Sirius,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAn Arab could not have better sprung to seat on the courser\xe2\x80\x99s back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now the reins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were given him, and carefully separated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI am ready. Let a guide go before me to the\r\nfield, and send some of thy men with water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no trouble at starting. The horses were not afraid. Already\r\nthere seemed a tacit understanding between them and the new driver, who\r\nhad performed his part calmly, and with the confidence which always\r\nbegets confidence. The order of going was precisely that of driving,\r\nexcept that Ben-Hur sat upon Sirius instead of standing in the chariot.\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s spirit arose. He combed his beard, and smiled with\r\nsatisfaction as he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cHe is not a Roman, no, by the splendor of\r\nGod!\xe2\x80\x9d He followed on foot, the entire tenantry of the dowar\xe2\x80\x94men, women,\r\nand children\xe2\x80\x94pouring after him, participants all in his solicitude, if\r\nnot in his confidence.\r\n\r\nThe field, when reached, proved ample and well fitted for the training,\r\nwhich Ben-Hur began immediately by driving the four at first slowly,\r\nand in perpendicular lines, and then in wide circles. Advancing a step\r\nin the course, he put them next into a trot; again progressing, he\r\npushed into a gallop; at length he contracted the circles, and yet\r\nlater drove eccentrically here and there, right, left, forward, and\r\nwithout a break. An hour was thus occupied. Slowing the gait to a walk,\r\nhe drove up to Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe work is done, nothing now but practice,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI give you joy,\r\nSheik Ilderim, that you have such servants as these. See,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncontinued, dismounting and going to the horses, \xe2\x80\x9csee, the gloss of\r\ntheir red coats is without spot; they breathe lightly as when I began.\r\nI give thee great joy, and it will go hard if\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he turned his flashing\r\neyes upon the old man\xe2\x80\x99s face\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif we have not the victory and our\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped, colored, bowed. At the sheik\xe2\x80\x99s side he observed, for the\r\nfirst time, Balthasar, leaning upon his staff, and two women closely\r\nveiled. At one of the latter he looked a second time, saying to\r\nhimself, with a flutter about his heart, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis the Egyptian!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nIlderim picked up his broken sentence\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe victory, and our revenge!\xe2\x80\x9d Then he said aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not afraid; I\r\nam glad. Son of Arrius, thou art the man. Be the end like the\r\nbeginning, and thou shalt see of what stuff is the lining of the hand\r\nof an Arab who is able to give.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank thee, good sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur returned, modestly. \xe2\x80\x9cLet the\r\nservants bring drink for the horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith his own hands he gave the water.\r\n\r\nRemounting Sirius, he renewed the training, going as before from walk\r\nto trot, from trot to gallop; finally, he pushed the steady racers into\r\nthe run, gradually quickening it to full speed. The performance then\r\nbecame exciting; and there were applause for the dainty handling of the\r\nreins, and admiration for the four, which were the same, whether they\r\nflew forward or wheeled in varying curvature. In their action there\r\nwere unity, power, grace, pleasure, all without effort or sign of\r\nlabor. The admiration was unmixed with pity or reproach, which would\r\nhave been as well bestowed upon swallows in their evening flight.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the exercises, and the attention they received from all\r\nthe bystanders, Malluch came upon the ground, seeking the sheik.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a message for you, O sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, availing himself of a\r\nmoment he supposed favorable for the speech\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca message from Simonides,\r\nthe merchant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated the Arab. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! \xe2\x80\x99tis well. May Abaddon take all\r\nhis enemies!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe bade me give thee first the holy peace of God,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch continued;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand then this despatch, with prayer that thou read it the instant of\r\nreceipt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim, standing in his place, broke the sealing of the package\r\ndelivered to him, and from a wrapping of fine linen took two letters,\r\nwhich he proceeded to read.\r\n\r\n[No. 1.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides to Sheik Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO friend!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssure thyself first of a place in my inner heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is in thy dowar a youth of fair presence, calling himself the\r\nson of Arrius; and such he is by adoption.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very dear to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hath a wonderful history, which I will tell thee; come thou to-day\r\nor to-morrow, that I may tell thee the history, and have thy counsel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeantime, favor all his requests, so they be not against honor. Should\r\nthere be need of reparation, I am bound to thee for it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I have interest in this youth, keep thou private.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember me to thy other guest. He, his daughter, thyself, and all\r\nwhom thou mayst choose to be of thy company, must depend upon me at the\r\nCircus the day of the games. I have seats already engaged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo thee and all thine, peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat should I be, O my friend, but thy friend?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSIMONIDES.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[No. 2.]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides to Sheik Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO friend!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut of the abundance of my experience, I send you a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a sign which all persons not Romans, and who have moneys or\r\ngoods subject to despoilment, accept as warning\xe2\x80\x94that is, the arrival at\r\na seat of power of some high Roman official charged with authority.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-day comes the Consul Maxentius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe thou warned!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother word of advice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA conspiracy, to be of effect against thee, O friend, must include the\r\nHerods as parties; thou hast great properties in their dominions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWherefore keep thou watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend this morning to thy trusty keepers of the roads leading south\r\nfrom Antioch, and bid them search every courier going and coming; if\r\nthey find private despatches relating to thee or thine affairs, THOU\r\nSHOULDST SEE THEM.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have received this yesterday, though it is not too late, if\r\nyou act promptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf couriers left Antioch this morning, your messengers know the\r\nbyways, and can get before them with your orders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not hesitate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBurn this after reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my friend! thy friend,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSIMONIDES.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim read the letters a second time, and refolded them in the linen\r\nwrap, and put the package under his girdle.\r\n\r\nThe exercises in the field continued but a little longer\xe2\x80\x94in all about\r\ntwo hours. At their conclusion, Ben-Hur brought the four to a walk, and\r\ndrove to Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith leave, O sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI will return thy Arabs to the tent,\r\nand bring them out again this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim walked to him as he sat on Sirius, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cI give them to\r\nyou, son of Arrius, to do with as you will until after the games. You\r\nhave done with them in two hours what the Roman\xe2\x80\x94may jackals gnaw his\r\nbones fleshless!\xe2\x80\x94could not in as many weeks. We will win\xe2\x80\x94by the\r\nsplendor of God, we will win!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the tent Ben-Hur remained with the horses while they were being\r\ncared for; then, after a plunge in the lake and a cup of arrack with\r\nthe sheik, whose flow of spirits was royally exuberant, he dressed\r\nhimself in his Jewish garb again, and walked with Malluch on into the\r\nOrchard.\r\n\r\nThere was much conversation between the two, not all of it important.\r\nOne part, however, must not be overlooked. Ben-Hur was speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9can order for my property stored in the\r\nkhan this side the river by the Seleucian Bridge. Bring it to me\r\nto-day, if you can. And, good Malluch\xe2\x80\x94if I do not overtask you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch protested heartily his willingness to be of service.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Malluch, thank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cI will take you at your\r\nword, remembering that we are brethren of the old tribe, and that the\r\nenemy is a Roman. First, then\xe2\x80\x94as you are a man of business, which I\r\nmuch fear Sheik Ilderim is not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArabs seldom are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, I do not impeach their shrewdness, Malluch. It is well, however,\r\nto look after them. To save all forfeit or hindrance in connection with\r\nthe race, you would put me perfectly at rest by going to the office of\r\nthe Circus, and seeing that he has complied with every preliminary\r\nrule; and if you can get a copy of the rules, the service may be of\r\ngreat avail to me. I would like to know the colors I am to wear, and\r\nparticularly the number of the crypt I am to occupy at the starting; if\r\nit be next Messala\xe2\x80\x99s on the right or left, it is well; if not, and you\r\ncan have it changed so as to bring me next the Roman, do so. Have you\r\ngood memory, Malluch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt has failed me, but never, son of Arrius, where the heart helped it\r\nas now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will venture, then, to charge you with one further service. I saw\r\nyesterday that Messala was proud of his chariot, as he might be, for\r\nthe best of Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s scarcely surpass it. Can you not make its display\r\nan excuse which will enable you to find if it be light or heavy? I\r\nwould like to have its exact weight and measurements\xe2\x80\x94and, Malluch,\r\nthough you fail in all else, bring me exactly the height his axle\r\nstands above the ground. You understand, Malluch? I do not wish him to\r\nhave any actual advantage of me. I do not care for his splendor; if I\r\nbeat him, it will make his fall the harder, and my triumph the more\r\ncomplete. If there are advantages really important, I want them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see, I see!\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch. \xe2\x80\x9cA line dropped from the centre of the\r\naxle is what you want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast it; and be glad, Malluch\xe2\x80\x94it is the last of my commissions.\r\nLet us return to the dowar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the door of the tent they found a servant replenishing the\r\nsmoke-stained bottles of leben freshly made, and stopped to refresh\r\nthemselves. Shortly afterwards Malluch returned to the city.\r\n\r\nDuring their absence, a messenger well mounted had been despatched with\r\norders as suggested by Simonides. He was an Arab, and carried nothing\r\nwritten.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIras, the daughter of Balthasar, sends me with salutation and a\r\nmessage,\xe2\x80\x9d said a servant to Ben-Hur, who was taking his ease in the\r\ntent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me the message.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould it please you to accompany her upon the lake?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will carry the answer myself. Tell her so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis shoes were brought him, and in a few minutes Ben-Hur sallied out to\r\nfind the fair Egyptian. The shadow of the mountains was creeping over\r\nthe Orchard of Palms in advance of night. Afar through the trees came\r\nthe tinkling of sheep bells, the lowing of cattle, and the voices of\r\nthe herdsmen bringing their charges home. Life at the Orchard, it\r\nshould be remembered, was in all respects as pastoral as life on the\r\nscantier meadows of the desert.\r\n\r\nSheik Ilderim had witnessed the exercises of the afternoon, being a\r\nrepetition of those of the morning; after which he had gone to the city\r\nin answer to the invitation of Simonides; he might return in the night;\r\nbut, considering the immensity of the field to be talked over with his\r\nfriend, it was hardly possible. Ben-Hur, thus left alone, had seen his\r\nhorses cared for; cooled and purified himself in the lake; exchanged\r\nthe field garb for his customary vestments, all white, as became a\r\nSadducean of the pure blood; supped early; and, thanks to the strength\r\nof youth, was well recovered from the violent exertion he had\r\nundergone.\r\n\r\nIt is neither wise nor honest to detract from beauty as a quality.\r\nThere cannot be a refined soul insensible to its influence. The story\r\nof Pygmalion and his statue is as natural as it is poetical. Beauty is\r\nof itself a power; and it was now drawing Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian was to him a wonderfully beautiful woman\xe2\x80\x94beautiful of\r\nface, beautiful of form. In his thought she always appeared to him as\r\nhe saw her at the fountain; and he felt the influence of her voice,\r\nsweeter because in tearful expression of gratitude to him, and of her\r\neyes\xe2\x80\x94the large, soft, black, almond-shaped eyes declarative of her\r\nrace\xe2\x80\x94eyes which looked more than lies in the supremest wealth of words\r\nto utter; and recurrences of the thought of her were returns just so\r\nfrequent of a figure tall, slender, graceful, refined, wrapped in rich\r\nand floating drapery, wanting nothing but a fitting mind to make her,\r\nlike the Shulamite, and in the same sense, terrible as an army with\r\nbanners. In other words, as she returned to his fancy, the whole\r\npassionate Song of Solomon came with her, inspired by her presence.\r\nWith this sentiment and that feeling, he was going to see if she\r\nactually justified them. It was not love that was taking him, but\r\nadmiration and curiosity, which might be the heralds of love.\r\n\r\nThe landing was a simple affair, consisting of a short stairway, and a\r\nplatform garnished by some lamp-posts; yet at the top of the steps he\r\npaused, arrested by what he beheld.\r\n\r\nThere was a shallop resting upon the clear water lightly as an\r\negg-shell. An Ethiop\xe2\x80\x94the camel-driver at the Castalian fount\xe2\x80\x94occupied\r\nthe rower\xe2\x80\x99s place, his blackness intensified by a livery of shining\r\nwhite. All the boat aft was cushioned and carpeted with stuffs\r\nbrilliant with Tyrian red. On the rudder seat sat the Egyptian herself,\r\nsunk in Indian shawls and a very vapor of most delicate veils and\r\nscarfs. Her arms were bare to the shoulders; and, not merely faultless\r\nin shape, they had the effect of compelling attention to them\xe2\x80\x94their\r\npose, their action, their expression; the hands, the fingers even,\r\nseemed endowed with graces and meaning; each was an object of beauty.\r\nThe shoulders and neck were protected from the evening air by an ample\r\nscarf, which yet did not hide them.\r\n\r\nIn the glance he gave her, Ben-Hur paid no attention to these details.\r\nThere was simply an impression made upon him; and, like strong light,\r\nit was a sensation, not a thing of sight or enumeration. Thy lips are\r\nlike a thread of scarlet; thy temples are like a piece of pomegranate\r\nwithin thy locks. Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away; for,\r\nlo! the winter is past, the rain is over and gone; the flowers appear\r\non the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice\r\nof the turtle is heard in the land\xe2\x80\x94such was the impression she made\r\nupon him translated into words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, observing him stop, \xe2\x80\x9ccome, or I shall think you a\r\npoor sailor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe red of his cheek deepened. Did she know anything of his life upon\r\nthe sea? He descended to the platform at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he took the vacant seat before her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf sinking the boat,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait until we are in deeper water,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, giving a signal to the\r\nblack, who dipped the oars, and they were off.\r\n\r\nIf love and Ben-Hur were enemies, the latter was never more at mercy.\r\nThe Egyptian sat where he could not but see her; she, whom he had\r\nalready engrossed in memory as his ideal of the Shulamite. With her\r\neyes giving light to his, the stars might come out, and he not see\r\nthem; and so they did. The night might fall with unrelieved darkness\r\neverywhere else; her look would make illumination for him. And then, as\r\neverybody knows, given youth and such companionship, there is no\r\nsituation in which the fancy takes such complete control as upon\r\ntranquil waters under a calm night sky, warm with summer. It is so easy\r\nat such time to glide imperceptibly out of the commonplace into the\r\nideal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me the rudder,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthat were to reverse the relation. Did I not ask\r\nyou to ride with me? I am indebted to you, and would begin payment. You\r\nmay talk and I will listen, or I will talk and you will listen: that\r\nchoice is yours; but it shall be mine to choose where we go, and the\r\nway thither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where may that be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are alarmed again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO fair Egyptian, I but asked you the first question of every captive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall me Egypt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather call you Iras.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may think of me by that name, but call me Egypt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEgypt is a country, and means many people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! And such a country!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see; it is to Egypt we are going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould we were! I would be so glad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe sighed as she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no care for me, then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, by that I know you were never there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is the land where there are no unhappy people, the desired of\r\nall the rest of the earth, the mother of all the gods, and therefore\r\nsupremely blest. There, O son of Arrius, there the happy find increase\r\nof happiness, and the wretched, going, drink once of the sweet water of\r\nthe sacred river, and laugh and sing, rejoicing like children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre not the very poor with you there as elsewhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very poor in Egypt are the very simple in wants and ways,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nreplied. \xe2\x80\x9cThey have no wish beyond enough, and how little that is, a\r\nGreek or a Roman cannot know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I am neither Greek nor Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a garden of roses, and in the midst of it is a tree, and its\r\nbloom is the richest of all. Whence came it, think you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Persia, the home of the rose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom India, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! one of the isles of Greece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said: \xe2\x80\x9ca traveller found it perishing by the\r\nroadside on the plain of Rephaim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, in Judea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI put it in the earth left bare by the receding Nile, and the soft\r\nsouth wind blew over the desert and nursed it, and the sun kissed it in\r\npity; after which it could not else than grow and flourish. I stand in\r\nits shade now, and it thanks me with much perfume. As with the roses,\r\nso with the men of Israel. Where shall they reach perfection but in\r\nEgypt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoses was but one of millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, there was a reader of dreams. Will you forget him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe friendly Pharaohs are dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes! The river by which they dwelt sings to them in their tombs;\r\nyet the same sun tempers the same air to the same people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlexandria is but a Roman town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has but exchanged sceptres. Caesar took from her that of the\r\nsword, and in its place left that of learning. Go with me to the\r\nBrucheium, and I will show you the college of nations; to the\r\nSerapeion, and see the perfection of architecture; to the Library, and\r\nread the immortals; to the theatre, and hear the heroics of the Greeks\r\nand Hindoos; to the quay, and count the triumphs of commerce; descend\r\nwith me into the streets, O son of Arrius, and, when the philosophers\r\nhave dispersed, and taken with them the masters of all the arts, and\r\nall the gods have home their votaries, and nothing remains of the day\r\nbut its pleasures, you shall hear the stories that have amused men from\r\nthe beginning, and the songs which will never, never die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he listened, Ben-Hur was carried back to the night when, in the\r\nsummer-house in Jerusalem, his mother, in much the same poetry of\r\npatriotism, declaimed the departed glories of Israel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see now why you wish to be called Egypt. Will you sing me a song if\r\nI call you by that name? I heard you last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was a hymn of the Nile,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9ca lament which I sing\r\nwhen I would fancy I smell the breath of the desert, and hear the surge\r\nof the dear old river; let me rather give you a piece of the Indian\r\nmind. When we get to Alexandria, I will take you to the corner of the\r\nstreet where you can hear it from the daughter of the Ganga, who taught\r\nit to me. Kapila, you should know, was one of the most revered of the\r\nHindoo sages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, as if it were a natural mode of expression, she began the song.\r\n\r\nKAPILA.\r\n\r\n\r\nI.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKapila, Kapila, so young and true,\r\n    I yearn for a glory like thine,\r\nAnd hail thee from battle to ask anew,\r\n    Can ever thy Valor be mine?\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKapila sat on his charger dun,\r\n    A hero never so grave:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who loveth all things hath fear of none,\r\n    \xe2\x80\x99Tis love that maketh me brave.\r\nA woman gave me her soul one day,\r\nThe soul of my soul to be alway;\r\n    Thence came my Valor to me,\r\n    Go try it\xe2\x80\x94try it\xe2\x80\x94and see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nII.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKapila, Kapila, so old and gray,\r\n    The queen is calling for me;\r\nBut ere I go hence, I wish thou wouldst say,\r\n    How Wisdom first came to thee.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKapila stood in his temple door,\r\n    A priest in eremite guise:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It did not come as men get their lore,\r\n    \xe2\x80\x99Tis faith that maketh me wise.\r\nA woman gave me her heart one day,\r\nThe heart of my heart to be alway;\r\n    Thence came my Wisdom to me,\r\n    Go try it\xe2\x80\x94try it\xe2\x80\x94and see.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur had not time to express his thanks for the song before the keel\r\nof the boat grated upon the underlying sand, and, next moment, the bow\r\nran upon the shore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA quick voyage, O Egypt!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a briefer stay!\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, as, with a strong push, the black\r\nsent them shooting into the open water again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will give me the rudder now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cTo you, the chariot; to me, the boat. We\r\nare merely at the lake\xe2\x80\x99s end, and the lesson is that I must not sing\r\nany more. Having been to Egypt, let us now to the Grove of Daphne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout a song on the way?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in deprecation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me something of the Roman from whom you saved us to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nasked.\r\n\r\nThe request struck Ben-Hur unpleasantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish this were the Nile,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, evasively. \xe2\x80\x9cThe kings and queens,\r\nhaving slept so long, might come down from their tombs, and ride with\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were of the colossi, and would sink our boat. The pygmies would\r\nbe preferable. But tell me of the Roman. He is very wicked, is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he of noble family, and rich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot speak of his riches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful his horses were! and the bed of his chariot was gold,\r\nand the wheels ivory. And his audacity! The bystanders laughed as he\r\nrode away; they, who were so nearly under his wheels!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe laughed at the recollection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were rabble,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, bitterly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be one of the monsters who are said to be growing up in\r\nRome\xe2\x80\x94Apollos ravenous as Cerberus. Does he reside in Antioch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is of the East somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEgypt would suit him better than Syria.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHardly,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied. \xe2\x80\x9cCleopatra is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat instant the lamps burning before the door of the tent came into\r\nview.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe dowar!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then, we have not been to Egypt. I have not seen Karnak or Philae\r\nor Abydos. This is not the Nile. I have but heard a song of India, and\r\nbeen boating in a dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhilae\xe2\x80\x94Karnak. Mourn rather that you have not seen the Rameses at Aboo\r\nSimbel, looking at which makes it so easy to think of God, the maker of\r\nthe heavens and earth. Or why should you mourn at all? Let us go on to\r\nthe river; and if I cannot sing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she laughed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbecause I have said I\r\nwould not, yet I can tell you stories of Egypt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on! Ay, till morning comes, and the evening, and the next morning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, vehemently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what shall my stories be? Of the mathematicians?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the philosophers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the magicians and genii?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf war?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf love?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you a cure for love. It is the story of a queen. Listen\r\nreverently. The papyrus from which it was taken by the priests of\r\nPhilae was wrested from the hand of the heroine herself. It is correct\r\nin form, and must be true:\r\n\r\nNE-NE-HOFRA.\r\n\r\n\r\nI.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no parallelism in human lives.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo life runs a straight line.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe most perfect life develops as a circle, and terminates in its\r\nbeginning, making it impossible to say, This is the commencement, that\r\nthe end.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect lives are the treasures of God; of great days he wears them on\r\nthe ring-finger of his heart hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nII.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNe-ne-hofra dwelt in a house close by Essouan, yet closer to the first\r\ncataract\xe2\x80\x94so close, indeed, that the sound of the eternal battle waged\r\nthere between river and rocks was of the place a part.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe grew in beauty day by day, so that it was said of her, as of the\r\npoppies in her father\xe2\x80\x99s garden, What will she not be in the time of\r\nblooming?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEach year of her life was the beginning of a new song more delightful\r\nthan any of those which went before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChild was she of a marriage between the North, bounded by the sea, and\r\nthe South, bounded by the desert beyond the Luna mountains; and one\r\ngave her its passion, the other its genius; so when they beheld her,\r\nboth laughed, saying, not meanly, \xe2\x80\x98She is mine,\xe2\x80\x99 but generously, \xe2\x80\x98Ha,\r\nha! she is ours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll excellences in nature contributed to her perfection and rejoiced\r\nin her presence. Did she come or go, the birds ruffled their wings in\r\ngreeting; the unruly winds sank to cooling zephyrs; the white lotus\r\nrose from the water\xe2\x80\x99s depth to look at her; the solemn river loitered\r\non its way; the palm-trees, nodding, shook all their plumes; and they\r\nseemed to say, this one, I gave her of my grace; that, I gave her of my\r\nbrightness; the other, I gave her of my purity: and so each as it had a\r\nvirtue to give.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt twelve, Ne-ne-hofra was the delight of Essouan; at sixteen, the\r\nfame of her beauty was universal; at twenty, there was never a day\r\nwhich did not bring to her door princes of the desert on swift camels,\r\nand lords of Egypt in gilded barges; and, going away disconsolate, they\r\nreported everywhere, \xe2\x80\x98I have seen her, and she is not a woman, but\r\nAthor herself.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIII.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow of the three hundred and thirty successors of good King Menes,\r\neighteen were Ethiopians, of whom Oraetes was one hundred and ten years\r\nold. He had reigned seventy-six years. Under him the people thrived,\r\nand the land groaned with fatness of plenty. He practised wisdom\r\nbecause, having seen so much, he knew what it was. He dwelt in Memphis,\r\nhaving there his principal palace, his arsenals, and his\r\ntreasure-house. Frequently he went down to Butos to talk with Latona.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wife of the good king died. Too old was she for perfect\r\nembalmment; yet he loved her, and mourned as the inconsolable; seeing\r\nwhich, a colchyte presumed one day to speak to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98O Oraetes, I am astonished that one so wise and great should not know\r\nhow to cure a sorrow like this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Tell me a cure,\xe2\x80\x99 said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree times the colchyte kissed the floor, and then he replied,\r\nknowing the dead could not hear him, \xe2\x80\x98At Essouan lives Ne-ne-hofra,\r\nbeautiful as Athor the beautiful. Send for her. She has refused all the\r\nlords and princes, and I know not how many kings; but who can say no to\r\nOraetes?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIV.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNe-ne-hofra descended the Nile in a barge richer than any ever before\r\nseen, attended by an army in barges each but a little less fine. All\r\nNubia and Egypt, and a myriad from Libya, and a host of Troglodytes,\r\nand not a few Macrobii from beyond the Mountains of the Moon, lined the\r\ntented shores to see the cortege pass, wafted by perfumed winds and\r\ngolden oars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrough a dromos of sphinxes and couchant double-winged lions she was\r\nborne, and set down before Oraetes sitting on a throne specially\r\nerected at the sculptured pylon of the palace. He raised her up, gave\r\nher place by his side, clasped the uraeus upon her arm, kissed her, and\r\nNe-ne-hofra was queen of all queens.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was not enough for the wise Oraetes; he wanted love, and a queen\r\nhappy in his love. So he dealt with her tenderly, showing her his\r\npossessions, cities, palaces, people; his armies, his ships: and with\r\nhis own hand he led her through his treasure-house, saying, \xe2\x80\x98O.\r\nNe-ne-hofra! but kiss me in love, and they are all thine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, thinking she could be happy, if she was not then, she kissed him\r\nonce, twice, thrice\xe2\x80\x94kissed him thrice, his hundred and ten years\r\nnotwithstanding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first year she was happy, and it was very short; the third year\r\nshe was wretched, and it was very long; then she was enlightened: that\r\nwhich she thought love of Oraetes was only daze of his power. Well for\r\nher had the daze endured! Her spirits deserted her; she had long spells\r\nof tears, and her women could not remember when they heard her laugh;\r\nof the roses on her cheeks only ashes remained; she languished and\r\nfaded gradually, but certainly. Some said she was haunted by the\r\nErinnyes for cruelty to a lover; others, that she was stricken by some\r\ngod envious of Oraetes. Whatever the cause of her decline, the charms\r\nof the magicians availed not to restore her, and the prescript of the\r\ndoctor was equally without virtue. Ne-ne-hofra was given over to die.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOraetes chose a crypt for her up in the tombs of the queens; and,\r\ncalling the master sculptors and painters to Memphis, he set them to\r\nwork upon designs more elaborate than any even in the great galleries\r\nof the dead kings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98O thou beautiful as Athor herself, my queen!\xe2\x80\x99 said the king, whose\r\nhundred and thirteen years did not lessen his ardor as a lover, \xe2\x80\x98Tell\r\nme, I pray, the ailment of which, alas! thou art so certainly perishing\r\nbefore my eyes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You will not love me any more if I tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, in doubt and\r\nfear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Not love you! I will love you the more. I swear it, by the genii of\r\nAmente! by the eye of Osiris, I swear it! Speak!\xe2\x80\x99 he cried, passionate\r\nas a lover, authoritative as a king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Hear, then,\xe2\x80\x99 she said. \xe2\x80\x98There is an anchorite, the oldest and holiest\r\nof his class, in a cave near Essouan. His name is Menopha. He was my\r\nteacher and guardian. Send for him, O Oraetes, and he will tell you\r\nthat you seek to know; he will also help you find the cure for my\r\naffliction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOraetes arose rejoicing. He went away in spirit a hundred years\r\nyounger than when he came.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nV.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Speak!\xe2\x80\x99 said Oraetes to Menopha, in the palace at Memphis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Menopha replied, \xe2\x80\x98Most mighty king, if you were young, I should\r\nnot answer, because I am yet pleased with life; as it is, I will say\r\nthe queen, like any other mortal, is paying the penalty of a crime.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98A crime!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Oraetes, angrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMenopha bowed very low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes; to herself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I am not in mood for riddles,\xe2\x80\x99 said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What I say is not a riddle, as you shall hear. Ne-ne-hofra grew up\r\nunder my eyes, and confided every incident of her life to me; among\r\nothers, that she loved the son of her father\xe2\x80\x99s gardener, Barbec by\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOraetes\xe2\x80\x99s frown, strangely enough, began to dissipate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98With that love in her heart, O king, she came to you; of that love\r\nshe is dying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Where is the gardener\xe2\x80\x99s son now?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Oraetes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98In Essouan.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king went out and gave two orders. To one oeris he said, \xe2\x80\x98Go to\r\nEssouan and bring hither a youth named Barbec. You will find him in the\r\ngarden of the queen\xe2\x80\x99s father;\xe2\x80\x99 to another, \xe2\x80\x98Assemble workmen and cattle\r\nand tools, and construct for me in Lake Chemmis an island, which,\r\nthough laden with a temple, a palace, and a garden, and all manner of\r\ntrees bearing fruit, and all manner of vines, shall nevertheless float\r\nabout as the winds may blow it. Make the island, and let it be fully\r\nfurnished by the time the moon begins to wane.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen to the queen he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Be of cheer. I know all, and have sent for Barbec.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNe-ne-hofra kissed his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You shall have him to yourself, and he you to himself; nor shall any\r\ndisturb your loves for a year.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe kissed his feet; he raised her, and kissed her in return; and the\r\nrose came back to her cheek, the scarlet to her lips, and the laughter\r\nto her heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVI.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor one year Ne-ne-hofra and Barbec the gardener floated as the winds\r\nblew on the island of Chemmis, which became one of the wonders of the\r\nworld; never a home of love more beautiful; one year, seeing no one and\r\nexisting for no one but themselves. Then she returned in state to the\r\npalace in Memphis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Now whom lovest thou best?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe kissed his cheek and said, \xe2\x80\x98Take me back, O good king, for I am\r\ncured.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOraetes laughed, none the worse, that moment, of his hundred and\r\nfourteen years.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Then it is true, as Menopha said: ha, ha, ha! it is true, the cure of\r\nlove is love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Even so,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuddenly his manner changed, and his look became terrible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I did not find it so,\xe2\x80\x99 he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe shrank affrighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Thou guilty!\xe2\x80\x99 he continued. \xe2\x80\x98Thy offense to Oraetes the man he\r\nforgives; but thy offence to Oraetes the king remains to be punished.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe cast herself at his feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Hush!\xe2\x80\x99 he cried. \xe2\x80\x98Thou art dead!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe clapped his hands, and a terrible procession came in\xe2\x80\x94a procession\r\nof parachistes, or embalmers, each with some implement or material of\r\nhis loathsome art.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe King pointed to Ne-ne-hofra.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98She is dead. Do thy work well.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVII.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNe-ne-hofra the beautiful, after seventy-two days, was carried to the\r\ncrypt chosen for her the year before, and laid with her queenly\r\npredecessors; yet there was no funeral procession in her honor across\r\nthe sacred lake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the conclusion of the story, Ben-Hur was sitting at the Egyptian\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet, and her hand upon the tiller was covered by his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMenopha was wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove lives by loving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen there is no cure for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Oraetes found the cure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a good listener, O son of Arrius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so with conversation and stories, they whiled the hours away. As\r\nthey stepped ashore, she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow we go to the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will be at the games?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will send you my colors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that they separated.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nIlderim returned to the dowar next day about the third hour. As he\r\ndismounted, a man whom he recognized as of his own tribe came to him\r\nand said, \xe2\x80\x9cO sheik, I was bidden give thee this package, with request\r\nthat thou read it at once. If there be answer, I was to wait thy\r\npleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim gave the package immediate attention. The seal was already\r\nbroken. The address ran, _To Valerius Gratus at C\xc3\xa6sarea_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbaddon take him!\xe2\x80\x9d growled the sheik, at discovering a letter in\r\nLatin.\r\n\r\nHad the missive been in Greek or Arabic, he could have read it; as it\r\nwas, the utmost he could make out was the signature in bold Roman\r\nletters\xe2\x80\x94MESSALA\xe2\x80\x94whereat his eyes twinkled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the young Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the field with the horses,\xe2\x80\x9d a servant replied.\r\n\r\nThe sheik replaced the papyrus in its envelopes, and, tucking the\r\npackage under his girdle, remounted the horse. That moment a stranger\r\nmade his appearance, coming, apparently, from the city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am looking for Sheik Ilderim, surnamed the Generous,\xe2\x80\x9d the stranger\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\nHis language and attire bespoke him a Roman.\r\n\r\nWhat he could not read, he yet could speak; so the old Arab answered,\r\nwith dignity, \xe2\x80\x9cI am Sheik Ilderim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes fell; he raised them again, and said, with forced\r\ncomposure, \xe2\x80\x9cI heard you had need of a driver for the games.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s lip under the white mustache curled contemptuously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo thy way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have a driver.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned to ride away, but the man, lingering, spoke again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSheik, I am a lover of horses, and they say you have the most\r\nbeautiful in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man was touched; he drew rein, as if on the point of yielding\r\nto the flattery, but finally replied, \xe2\x80\x9cNot to-day, not to-day; some\r\nother time I will show them to you. I am too busy just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rode to the field, while the stranger betook himself to town again\r\nwith a smiling countenance. He had accomplished his mission.\r\n\r\nAnd every day thereafter, down to the great day of the games, a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94sometimes two or three men\xe2\x80\x94came to the sheik at the Orchard,\r\npretending to seek an engagement as driver.\r\n\r\nIn such manner Messala kept watch over Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sheik waited, well satisfied, until Ben-Hur drew his horses off the\r\nfield for the forenoon\xe2\x80\x94well satisfied, for he had seen them, after\r\nbeing put through all the other paces, run full speed in such manner\r\nthat it did not seem there were one the slowest and another the\r\nfastest\xe2\x80\x94run in other words, as if the four were one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis afternoon, O sheik, I will give Sirius back to you.\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur\r\npatted the neck of the old horse as he spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cI will give him back,\r\nand take to the chariot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo soon?\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith such as these, good sheik, one day suffices. They are not afraid;\r\nthey have a man\xe2\x80\x99s intelligence, and they love the exercise. This one,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe shook a rein over the back of the youngest of the four\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou called\r\nhim Aldebaran, I believe\xe2\x80\x94is the swiftest; in once round a stadium he\r\nwould lead the others thrice his length.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim pulled his beard, and said, with twinkling eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cAldebaran is\r\nthe swiftest; but what of the slowest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is he.\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur shook the rein over Antares. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is he: but he\r\nwill win, for, look you, sheik, he will run his utmost all day\xe2\x80\x94all day;\r\nand, as the sun goes down, he will reach his swiftest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have but one fear, O sheik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik became doubly serious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn his greed of triumph, a Roman cannot keep honor pure. In the\r\ngames\xe2\x80\x94all of them, mark you\xe2\x80\x94their tricks are infinite; in chariot\r\nracing their knavery extends to everything\xe2\x80\x94from horse to driver, from\r\ndriver to master. Wherefore, good sheik, look well to all thou hast;\r\nfrom this till the trial is over, let no stranger so much as see the\r\nhorses. Would you be perfectly safe, do more\xe2\x80\x94keep watch over them with\r\narmed hand as well as sleepless eye; then I will have no fear of the\r\nend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the door of the tent they dismounted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say shall be attended to. By the splendor of God, no hand\r\nshall come near them except it belong to one of the faithful. To-night\r\nI will set watches. But, son of Arrius\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Ilderim drew forth the package,\r\nand opened it slowly, while they walked to the divan and seated\r\nthemselves\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cson of Arrius, see thou here, and help me with thy Latin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe passed the despatch to Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere; read\xe2\x80\x94and read aloud, rendering what thou findest into the\r\ntongue of thy fathers. Latin is an abomination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was in good spirits, and began the reading carelessly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98MESSALA TO GRATUS!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d He paused. A premonition drove the blood to his\r\nheart. Ilderim observed his agitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell; I am waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur prayed pardon, and recommenced the paper, which, it is\r\nsufficient to say, was one of the duplicates of the letter despatched\r\nso carefully to Gratus by Messala the morning after the revel in the\r\npalace.\r\n\r\nThe paragraphs in the beginning were remarkable only as proof that the\r\nwriter had not outgrown his habit of mockery; when they were passed,\r\nand the reader came to the parts intended to refresh the memory of\r\nGratus, his voice trembled, and twice he stopped to regain his\r\nself-control. By a strong effort he continued. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I recall further,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nread, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98that thou didst make disposition of the family of Hur\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94there\r\nthe reader again paused and drew a long breath\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98both of us at the time\r\nsupposing the plan hit upon to be the most effective possible for the\r\npurposes in view, which were silence and delivery over to inevitable\r\nbut natural death.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Ben-Hur broke down utterly. The paper fell from his hands, and he\r\ncovered his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are dead\xe2\x80\x94dead. I alone am left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik had been a silent, but not unsympathetic, witness of the\r\nyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s suffering; now he arose and said, \xe2\x80\x9cSon of Arrius, it is for\r\nme to beg thy pardon. Read the paper by thyself. When thou art strong\r\nenough to give the rest of it to me, send word, and I will return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went out of the tent, and nothing in all his life became him better.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur flung himself on the divan and gave way to his feelings. When\r\nsomewhat recovered, he recollected that a portion of the letter\r\nremained unread, and, taking it up, he resumed the reading. \xe2\x80\x9cThou wilt\r\nremember,\xe2\x80\x9d the missive ran, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat thou didst with the mother and sister\r\nof the malefactor; yet, if now I yield to a desire to learn if they be\r\nliving or dead\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur started, and read again, and then again, and at\r\nlast broke into exclamation. \xe2\x80\x9cHe does not know they are dead; he does\r\nnot know it! Blessed be the name of the Lord! there is yet hope.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nfinished the sentence, and was strengthened by it, and went on bravely\r\nto the end of the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are not dead,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after reflection; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are not dead, or\r\nhe would have heard of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA second reading, more careful than the first, confirmed him in the\r\nopinion. Then he sent for the sheik.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn coming to your hospitable tent, O sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, calmly, when the\r\nArab was seated and they were alone, \xe2\x80\x9cit was not in my mind to speak of\r\nmyself further than to assure you I had sufficient training to be\r\nintrusted with your horses. I declined to tell you my history. But the\r\nchances which have sent this paper to my hand and given it to me to be\r\nread are so strange that I feel bidden to trust you with everything.\r\nAnd I am the more inclined to do so by knowledge here conveyed that we\r\nare both of us threatened by the same enemy, against whom it is needful\r\nthat we make common cause. I will read the letter and give you\r\nexplanation; after which you will not wonder I was so moved. If you\r\nthought me weak or childish, you will then excuse me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik held his peace, listening closely, until Ben-Hur came to the\r\nparagraph in which he was particularly mentioned: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I saw the Jew\r\nyesterday in the Grove of Daphne;\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d so ran the part, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98and if he be not\r\nthere now, he is certainly in the neighborhood, making it easy for me\r\nto keep him in eye. Indeed, wert thou to ask me where he is now, I\r\nshould say, with the most positive assurance, he is to be found at the\r\nold Orchard of Palms.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA\xe2\x80\x94h!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ilderim, in such a tone one might hardly say he was\r\nmore surprised than angry; at the same time, he clutched his beard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98At the old Orchard of Palms,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur repeated, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98under the tent of\r\nthe traitor Shiek Ilderim.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTraitor!\xe2\x80\x94I?\xe2\x80\x9d the old man cried, in his shrillest tone, while lip and\r\nbeard curled with ire, and on his forehead and neck the veins swelled\r\nand beat as they would burst.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet a moment, sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, with a deprecatory gesture. \xe2\x80\x9cSuch\r\nis Messala\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of you. Hear his threat.\xe2\x80\x9d And he read on\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98under\r\nthe tent of the traitor Sheik Ilderim, who cannot long escape our\r\nstrong hand. Be not surprised if Maxentius, as his first measure,\r\nplaces the Arab on ship for forwarding to Rome.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Rome! Me\xe2\x80\x94Ilderim\xe2\x80\x94sheik of ten thousand horsemen with spears\xe2\x80\x94me to\r\nRome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe leaped rather than rose to his feet, his arms outstretched, his\r\nfingers spread and curved like claws, his eyes glittering like a\r\nserpent\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO God!\xe2\x80\x94nay, by all the gods except of Rome!\xe2\x80\x94when shall this insolence\r\nend? A freeman am I; free are my people. Must we die slaves? Or, worse,\r\nmust I live a dog, crawling to a master\xe2\x80\x99s feet? Must I lick his hand,\r\nlest he lash me? What is mine is not mine; I am not my own; for breath\r\nof body I must be beholden to a Roman. Oh, if I were young again! Oh,\r\ncould I shake off twenty years\xe2\x80\x94or ten\xe2\x80\x94or five!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe ground his teeth and shook his hands overhead; then, under the\r\nimpulse of another idea, he walked away and back again to Ben-Hur\r\nswiftly, and caught his shoulder with a strong grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were as thou, son of Arrius\xe2\x80\x94as young, as strong, as practised in\r\narms; if I had a motive hissing me to revenge\xe2\x80\x94a motive, like thine,\r\ngreat enough to make hate holy\xe2\x80\x94 Away with disguise on thy part and on\r\nmine! Son of Hur, son of Hur, I say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that name all the currents of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s blood stopped; surprised,\r\nbewildered, he gazed into the Arab\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, now close to his, and\r\nfiercely bright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur, I say, were I as thou, with half thy wrongs, bearing about\r\nwith me memories like thine, I would not, I could not, rest.\xe2\x80\x9d Never\r\npausing, his words following each other torrent-like, the old man swept\r\non. \xe2\x80\x9cTo all my grievances, I would add those of the world, and devote\r\nmyself to vengeance. From land to land I would go firing all mankind.\r\nNo war for freedom but should find me engaged; no battle against Rome\r\nin which I would not bear a part. I would turn Parthian, if I could not\r\nbetter. If men failed me, still I would not give over the effort\xe2\x80\x94ha,\r\nha, ha! By the splendor of God! I would herd with wolves, and make\r\nfriends of lions and tigers, in hope of marshalling them against the\r\ncommon enemy. I would use every weapon. So my victims were Romans, I\r\nwould rejoice in slaughter. Quarter I would not ask; quarter I would\r\nnot give. To the flames everything Roman; to the sword every Roman\r\nborn. Of nights I would pray the gods, the good and the bad alike, to\r\nlend me their special terrors\xe2\x80\x94tempests, drought, heat, cold, and all\r\nthe nameless poisons they let loose in air, all the thousand things of\r\nwhich men die on sea and on land. Oh, I could not sleep. I\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik stopped for want of breath, panting, wringing his hands. And,\r\nsooth to say, of all the passionate burst Ben-Hur retained but a vague\r\nimpression wrought by fiery eyes, a piercing voice, and a rage too\r\nintense for coherent expression.\r\n\r\nFor the first time in years, the desolate youth heard himself addressed\r\nby his proper name. One man at least knew him, and acknowledged it\r\nwithout demand of identity; and he an Arab fresh from the desert!\r\n\r\nHow came the man by his knowledge? The letter? No. It told the\r\ncruelties from which his family had suffered; it told the story of his\r\nown misfortunes, but it did not say he was the very victim whose escape\r\nfrom doom was the theme of the heartless narrative. That was the point\r\nof explanation he had notified the sheik would follow the reading of\r\nthe letter. He was pleased, and thrilled with hope restored, yet kept\r\nan air of calmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood sheik, tell me how you came by this letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy people keep the roads between cities,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim answered, bluntly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey took it from a courier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre they known to be thy people?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. To the world they are robbers, whom it is mine to catch and slay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgain, sheik. You call me son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94my father\xe2\x80\x99s name. I did not think\r\nmyself known to a person on earth. How came you by the knowledge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim hesitated; but, rallying, he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI know you, yet I am\r\nnot free to tell you more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome one holds you in restraint?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik closed his mouth, and walked away; but, observing Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisappointment, he came back, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us say no more about the\r\nmatter now. I will go to town; when I return, I may talk to you fully.\r\nGive me the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim rolled the papyrus carefully, restored it to its envelopes, and\r\nbecame once more all energy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, while waiting for his horse and retinue.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told what I would do, were I thou, and thou hast made no answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI intended to answer, sheik, and I will.\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s countenance and\r\nvoice changed with the feeling invoked. \xe2\x80\x9cAll thou hast said, I will\r\ndo\xe2\x80\x94all at least in the power of a man. I devoted myself to vengeance\r\nlong ago. Every hour of the five years passed, I have lived with no\r\nother thought. I have taken no respite. I have had no pleasures of\r\nyouth. The blandishments of Rome were not for me. I wanted her to\r\neducate me for revenge. I resorted to her most famous masters and\r\nprofessors\xe2\x80\x94not those of rhetoric or philosophy: alas! I had no time for\r\nthem. The arts essential to a fighting-man were my desire. I associated\r\nwith gladiators, and with winners of prizes in the Circus; and they\r\nwere my teachers. The drill-masters in the great camp accepted me as a\r\nscholar, and were proud of my attainments in their line. O sheik, I am\r\na soldier; but the things of which I dream require me to be a captain.\r\nWith that thought, I have taken part in the campaign against the\r\nParthians; when it is over, then, if the Lord spare my life and\r\nstrength\xe2\x80\x94then\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he raised his clenched hands, and spoke vehemently\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthen\r\nI will be an enemy Roman-taught in all things; then Rome shall account\r\nto me in Roman lives for her ills. You have my answer, sheik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim put an arm over his shoulder, and kissed him, saying,\r\npassionately, \xe2\x80\x9cIf thy God favor thee not, son of Hur, it is because he\r\nis dead. Take thou this from me\xe2\x80\x94sworn to, if so thy preference run:\r\nthou shalt have my hands, and their fulness\xe2\x80\x94men, horses, camels, and\r\nthe desert for preparation. I swear it! For the present, enough. Thou\r\nshalt see or hear from me before night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTurning abruptly off, the sheik was speedily on the road to the city.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe intercepted letter was conclusive upon a number of points of great\r\ninterest to Ben-Hur.
