It had all the effect of a confession that the\r\nwriter was a party to the putting-away of the family with murderous\r\nintent; that he had sanctioned the plan adopted for the purpose; that\r\nhe had received a portion of the proceeds of the confiscation, and was\r\nyet in enjoyment of his part; that he dreaded the unexpected appearance\r\nof what he was pleased to call the chief malefactor, and accepted it as\r\na menace; that he contemplated such further action as would secure him\r\nin the future, and was ready to do whatever his accomplice in Caesarea\r\nmight advise.\r\n\r\nAnd, now that the letter had reached the hand of him really its\r\nsubject, it was notice of danger to come, as well as a confession of\r\nguilt. So when Ilderim left the tent, Ben-Hur had much to think about,\r\nrequiring immediate action. His enemies were as adroit and powerful as\r\nany in the East. If they were afraid of him, he had greater reason to\r\nbe afraid of them. He strove earnestly to reflect upon the situation,\r\nbut could not; his feelings constantly overwhelmed him. There was a\r\ncertain qualified pleasure in the assurance that his mother and sister\r\nwere alive; and it mattered little that the foundation of the assurance\r\nwas a mere inference. That there was one person who could tell him\r\nwhere they were seemed to his hope so long deferred as if discovery\r\nwere now close at hand. These were mere causes of feeling; underlying\r\nthem, it must be confessed he had a superstitious fancy that God was\r\nabout to make ordination in his behalf, in which event faith whispered\r\nhim to stand still.\r\n\r\nOccasionally, referring to the words of Ilderim, he wondered whence the\r\nArab derived his information about him; not from Malluch certainly; nor\r\nfrom Simonides, whose interests, all adverse, would hold him dumb.\r\nCould Messala have been the informant? No, no: disclosure might be\r\ndangerous in that quarter. Conjecture was vain; at the same time, often\r\nas Ben-Hur was beaten back from the solution, he was consoled with the\r\nthought that whoever the person with the knowledge might be, he was a\r\nfriend, and, being such, would reveal himself in good time. A little\r\nmore waiting\xe2\x80\x94a little more patience. Possibly the errand of the sheik\r\nwas to see the worthy; possibly the letter might precipitate a full\r\ndisclosure.\r\n\r\nAnd patient he would have been if only he could have believed Tirzah\r\nand his mother were waiting for him under circumstances permitting hope\r\non their part strong as his; if, in other words, conscience had not\r\nstung him with accusations respecting them.\r\n\r\nTo escape such accusations, he wandered far through the Orchard,\r\npausing now where the date-gatherers were busy, yet not too busy to\r\noffer him of their fruit and talk with him; then, under the great\r\ntrees, to watch the nesting birds, or hear the bees swarming about the\r\nberries bursting with honeyed sweetness, and filling all the green and\r\ngolden spaces with the music of their beating wings.\r\n\r\nBy the lake, however, he lingered longest. He might not look upon the\r\nwater and its sparkling ripples, so like sensuous life, without\r\nthinking of the Egyptian and her marvellous beauty, and of floating\r\nwith her here and there through the night, made brilliant by her songs\r\nand stories; he might not forget the charm of her manner, the lightness\r\nof her laugh, the flattery of her attention, the warmth of her little\r\nhand under his upon the tiller of the boat. From her it was for his\r\nthought but a short way to Balthasar, and the strange things of which\r\nhe had been witness, unaccountable by any law of nature; and from him,\r\nagain, to the King of the Jews, whom the good man, with such pathos of\r\npatience, was holding in holy promise, the distance was even nearer.\r\nAnd there his mind stayed, finding in the mysteries of that personage a\r\nsatisfaction answering well for the rest he was seeking. Because, it\r\nmay have been, nothing is so easy as denial of an idea not agreeable to\r\nour wishes, he rejected the definition given by Balthasar of the\r\nkingdom the king was coming to establish. A kingdom of souls, if not\r\nintolerable to his Sadducean faith, seemed to him but an abstraction\r\ndrawn from the depths of a devotion too fond and dreamy. A kingdom of\r\nJudea, on the other hand, was more than comprehensible: such had been,\r\nand, if only for that reason, might be again. And it suited his pride\r\nto think of a new kingdom broader of domain, richer in power, and of a\r\nmore unapproachable splendor than the old one; of a new king wiser and\r\nmightier than Solomon\xe2\x80\x94a new king under whom, especially, he could find\r\nboth service and revenge. In that mood he resumed to the dowar.\r\n\r\nThe mid-day meal disposed of, still further to occupy himself, Ben-Hur\r\nhad the chariot rolled out into the sunlight for inspection. The word\r\nbut poorly conveys the careful study the vehicle underwent. No point or\r\npart of it escaped him. With a pleasure which will be better understood\r\nhereafter, he saw the pattern was Greek, in his judgment preferable to\r\nthe Roman in many respects; it was wider between the wheels, and lower\r\nand stronger, and the disadvantage of greater weight would be more than\r\ncompensated by the greater endurance of his Arabs. Speaking generally,\r\nthe carriage-makers of Rome built for the games almost solely,\r\nsacrificing safety to beauty, and durability to grace; while the\r\nchariots of Achilles and \xe2\x80\x9cthe king of men,\xe2\x80\x9d designed for war and all\r\nits extreme tests, still ruled the tastes of those who met and\r\nstruggled for the crowns Isthmian and Olympic.\r\n\r\nNext he brought the horses, and, hitching them to the chariot, drove to\r\nthe field of exercise, where, hour after hour, he practised them in\r\nmovement under the yoke. When he came away in the evening, it was with\r\nrestored spirit, and a fixed purpose to defer action in the matter of\r\nMessala until the race was won or lost. He could not forego the\r\npleasure of meeting his adversary under the eyes of the East; that\r\nthere might be other competitors seemed not to enter his thought. His\r\nconfidence in the result was absolute; no doubt of his own skill; and\r\nas to the four, they were his full partners in the glorious game.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him look to it, let him look to it! Ha, Antares\xe2\x80\x94Aldebaran! Shall\r\nhe not, O honest Rigel? and thou, Atair, king among coursers, shall he\r\nnot beware of us? Ha, ha! good hearts!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo in rests he passed from horse to horse, speaking, not as a master,\r\nbut the senior of as many brethren.\r\n\r\nAfter nightfall, Ben-Hur sat by the door of the tent waiting for\r\nIlderim, not yet returned from the city. He was not impatient, or\r\nvexed, or doubtful. The sheik would be heard from, at least. Indeed,\r\nwhether it was from satisfaction with the performance of the four, or\r\nthe refreshment there is in cold water succeeding bodily exercise, or\r\nsupper partaken with royal appetite, or the reaction which, as a kindly\r\nprovision of nature, always follows depression, the young man was in\r\ngood-humor verging upon elation. He felt himself in the hands of\r\nProvidence no longer his enemy. At last there was a sound of horse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet coming rapidly, and Malluch rode up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Arrius,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, cheerily, after salutation, \xe2\x80\x9cI salute you for\r\nSheik Ilderim, who requests you to mount and go to the city. He is\r\nwaiting for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur asked no questions, but went in where the horses were feeding.\r\nAldebaran came to him, as if offering his service. He played with him\r\nlovingly, but passed on, and chose another, not of the four\xe2\x80\x94they were\r\nsacred to the race. Very shortly the two were on the road, going\r\nswiftly and in silence.\r\n\r\nSome distance below the Seleucian Bridge, they crossed the river by a\r\nferry, and, riding far round on the right bank, and recrossing by\r\nanother ferry, entered the city from the west. The detour was long, but\r\nBen-Hur accepted it as a precaution for which there was good reason.\r\n\r\nDown to Simonides\xe2\x80\x99 landing they rode, and in front of the great\r\nwarehouse, under the bridge, Malluch drew rein.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are come,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDismount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur recognized the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the sheik?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me. I will show you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA watchman took the horses, and almost before he realized it Ben-Hur\r\nstood once more at the door of the house up on the greater one,\r\nlistening to the response from within\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIn God\xe2\x80\x99s name, enter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nMalluch stopped at the door; Ben-Hur entered alone.\r\n\r\nThe room was the same in which he had formerly interviewed Simonides,\r\nand it had been in nowise changed, except now, close by the arm-chair,\r\na polished brazen rod, set on a broad wooden pedestal, arose higher\r\nthan a tall man, holding lamps of silver on sliding arms, half-a-dozen\r\nor more in number, and all burning. The light was clear, bringing into\r\nview the panelling on the walls, the cornice with its row of gilded\r\nballs, and the dome dully tinted with violet mica.\r\n\r\nWithin a few steps, Ben-Hur stopped.\r\n\r\nThree persons were present, looking at him\xe2\x80\x94Simonides, Ilderim, and\r\nEsther.\r\n\r\nHe glanced hurriedly from one to another, as if to find answer to the\r\nquestion half formed in his mind, What business can these have with me?\r\nHe became calm, with every sense on the alert, for the question was\r\nsucceeded by another, Are they friends or enemies?\r\n\r\nAt length, his eyes rested upon Esther.\r\n\r\nThe men returned his look kindly; in her face there was something more\r\nthan kindness\xe2\x80\x94something too _spirituel_ for definition, which yet went\r\nto his inner consciousness without definition.\r\n\r\nShall it be said, good reader? Back of his gaze there was a comparison\r\nin which the Egyptian arose and set herself over against the gentle\r\nJewess; but it lived an instant, and, as is the habit of such\r\ncomparisons, passed away without a conclusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe guest turned to the speaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, repeating the address slowly, and with\r\ndistinct emphasis, as if to impress all its meaning upon him most\r\ninterested in understanding it, \xe2\x80\x9ctake thou the peace of the Lord God of\r\nour fathers\xe2\x80\x94take it from me.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused, then added, \xe2\x80\x9cFrom me and\r\nmine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe speaker sat in his chair; there were the royal head, the bloodless\r\nface, the masterful air, under the influence of which visitors forgot\r\nthe broken limbs and distorted body of the man. The full black eyes\r\ngazed out under the white brows steadily, but not sternly. A moment\r\nthus, then he crossed his hands upon his breast.\r\n\r\nThe action, taken with the salutation, could not be misunderstood, and\r\nwas not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur answered, much moved, \xe2\x80\x9cthe holy peace you tender\r\nis accepted. As son to father, I return it to you. Only let there be\r\nperfect understanding between us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus delicately he sought to put aside the submission of the merchant,\r\nand, in place of the relation of master and servant, substitute one\r\nhigher and holier.\r\n\r\nSimonides let fall his hands, and, turning to Esther, said, \xe2\x80\x9cA seat for\r\nthe master, daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hastened, and brought a stool, and stood, with suffused face,\r\nlooking from one to the other\xe2\x80\x94from Ben-Hur to Simonides, from Simonides\r\nto Ben-Hur; and they waited, each declining the superiority direction\r\nwould imply. When at length the pause began to be embarrassing, Ben-Hur\r\nadvanced, and gently took the stool from her, and, going to the chair,\r\nplaced it at the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will sit here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHis eyes met hers\xe2\x80\x94an instant only; but both were better of the look. He\r\nrecognized her gratitude, she his generosity and forbearance.\r\n\r\nSimonides bowed his acknowledgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther, child, bring me the paper,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a breath of relief.\r\n\r\nShe went to a panel in the wall, opened it, took out a roll of papyri,\r\nand brought and gave it to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou saidst well, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides began, while unrolling the\r\nsheets. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us understand each other. In anticipation of the\r\ndemand\xe2\x80\x94which I would have made hadst thou waived it\xe2\x80\x94I have here a\r\nstatement covering everything necessary to the understanding required.\r\nI could see but two points involved\xe2\x80\x94the property first, and then our\r\nrelation. The statement is explicit as to both. Will it please thee to\r\nread it now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur received the papers, but glanced at Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sheik shall not deter thee from reading.\r\nThe account\xe2\x80\x94such thou wilt find it\xe2\x80\x94is of a nature requiring a witness.\r\nIn the attesting place at the end thou wilt find, when thou comest to\r\nit, the name\xe2\x80\x94Ilderim, Sheik. He knows all. He is thy friend. All he has\r\nbeen to me, that will he be to thee also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides looked at the Arab, nodding pleasantly, and the latter\r\ngravely returned the nod, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cThou hast said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI know already the excellence of his friendship, and\r\nhave yet to prove myself worthy of it.\xe2\x80\x9d Immediately he continued,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLater, O Simonides, I will read the papers carefully; for the present,\r\ndo thou take them, and if thou be not too weary, give me their\r\nsubstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides took back the roll.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Esther, stand by me and receive the sheets, lest they fall into\r\nconfusion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took place by his chair, letting her right arm fall lightly across\r\nhis shoulder, so, when he spoke, the account seemed to have rendition\r\nfrom both of them jointly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, drawing out the first leaf, \xe2\x80\x9cshows the money I\r\nhad of thy father\xe2\x80\x99s, being the amount saved from the Romans; there was\r\nno property saved, only money, and that the robbers would have secured\r\nbut for our Jewish custom of bills of exchange. The amount saved, being\r\nsums I drew from Rome, Alexandria, Damascus, Carthage, Valentia, and\r\nelsewhere within the circle of trade, was one hundred and twenty\r\ntalents Jewish money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gave the sheet to Esther, and took the next one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith that amount\xe2\x80\x94one hundred and twenty talents\xe2\x80\x94I charged myself. Hear\r\nnow my credits. I use the word, as thou wilt see, with reference rather\r\nto the proceeds gained from the use of the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom separate sheets he then read footings, which, fractions omitted,\r\nwere as follows:\r\n\r\nBy ships\t60 talents \xe2\x80\x9d goods in store\t110   \xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9d cargoes in\r\ntransit\t75   \xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9d camels, horses, etc.\t20   \xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9d warehouses\t10  \r\n\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9d bills due\t54   \xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9d money on hand and subject to draft\t224   \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 Total\t553   \xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo these now, to the five hundred and fifty-three talents gained, add\r\nthe original capital I had from thy father, and thou hast SIX HUNDRED\r\nAND SEVENTY THREE TALENTS!\xe2\x80\x94and all thine\xe2\x80\x94making thee, O son of Hur, the\r\nrichest subject in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the papyri from Esther, and, reserving one, rolled them and\r\noffered them to Ben-Hur. The pride perceptible in his manner was not\r\noffensive; it might have been from a sense of duty well done; it might\r\nhave been for Ben-Hur without reference to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, dropping his voice, but not his\r\neyes\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthere is nothing now thou mayst not do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe moment was one of absorbing interest to all present. Simonides\r\ncrossed his hands upon his breast again; Esther was anxious; Ilderim\r\nnervous. A man is never so on trial as in the moment of excessive\r\ngood-fortune.\r\n\r\nTaking the roll, Ben-Hur arose, struggling with emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this is to me as a light from heaven, sent to drive away a night\r\nwhich has been so long I feared it would never end, and so dark I had\r\nlost the hope of seeing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a husky voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI give first\r\nthanks to the Lord, who has not abandoned me, and my next to thee, O\r\nSimonides. Thy faithfulness outweighs the cruelty of others, and\r\nredeems our human nature. \xe2\x80\x98There is nothing I cannot do:\xe2\x80\x99 be it so.\r\nShall any man in this my hour of such mighty privilege be more generous\r\nthan I? Serve me as a witness now, Sheik Ilderim. Hear thou my words as\r\nI shall speak them\xe2\x80\x94hear and remember. And thou, Esther, good angel of\r\nthis good man! hear thou also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stretched his hand with the roll to Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe things these papers take into account\xe2\x80\x94all of them: ships, houses,\r\ngoods, camels, horses, money; the least as well as the greatest\xe2\x80\x94give I\r\nback to thee, O Simonides, making them all thine, and sealing them to\r\nthee and thine forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther smiled through her tears; Ilderim pulled his beard with rapid\r\nmotion, his eyes glistening like beads of jet. Simonides alone was\r\ncalm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSealing them to thee and thine forever,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur continued, with\r\nbetter control of himself, \xe2\x80\x9cwith one exception, and upon one\r\ncondition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe breath of the listeners waited upon his words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hundred and twenty talents which were my father\xe2\x80\x99s thou shalt\r\nreturn to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s countenance brightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou shalt join me in search of my mother and sister, holding all\r\nthine subject to the expense of discovery, even as I will hold mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides was much affected. Stretching out his hand, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI see\r\nthy spirit, son of Hur, and I am grateful to the Lord that he hath sent\r\nthee to me such as thou art. If I served well thy father in life, and\r\nhis memory afterwards, be not afraid of default to thee; yet must I say\r\nthe exception cannot stand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nExhibiting, then, the reserved sheet, he continued,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast not all the account. Take this and read\xe2\x80\x94read aloud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took the supplement, and read it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStatement of the servants of Hur, rendered by Simonides, steward of\r\nthe estate.\r\n\r\n1. Amrah, Egyptian, keeping the palace in Jerusalem.\r\n2. Simonides, the steward, in Antioch.\r\n3. Esther, daughter of Simonides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, in all his thoughts of Simonides, not once had it entered\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s mind that, by the law, a daughter followed the parent\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncondition. In all his visions of her, the sweet-faced Esther had\r\nfigured as the rival of the Egyptian, and an object of possible love.\r\nHe shrank from the revelation so suddenly brought him, and looked at\r\nher blushing; and, blushing, she dropped her eyes before him. Then he\r\nsaid, while the papyrus rolled itself together,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man with six hundred talents is indeed rich, and may do what he\r\npleases; but, rarer than the money, more priceless than the property,\r\nis the mind which amassed the wealth, and the heart it could not\r\ncorrupt when amassed. O Simonides\xe2\x80\x94and thou, fair Esther\xe2\x80\x94fear not. Sheik\r\nIlderim here shall be witness that in the same moment ye were declared\r\nmy servants, that moment I declared ye free; and what I declare, that\r\nwill I put in writing. Is it not enough? Can I do more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, \xe2\x80\x9cverily thou dost make servitude\r\nlightsome. I was wrong; there are some things thou canst not do; thou\r\ncanst not make us free in law. I am thy servant forever, because I went\r\nto the door with thy father one day, and in my ear the awl-marks yet\r\nabide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid my father that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudge him not,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Simonides, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe accepted me a servant of\r\nthat class because I prayed him to do so. I never repented the step. It\r\nwas the price I paid for Rachel, the mother of my child here; for\r\nRachel, who would not be my wife unless I became what she was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas she a servant forever?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur walked the floor in pain of impotent wish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was rich before,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stopping suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cI was rich with the\r\ngifts of the generous Arrius; now comes this greater fortune, and the\r\nmind which achieved it. Is there not a purpose of God in it all?\r\nCounsel me, O Simonides! Help me to see the right and do it. Help me to\r\nbe worthy my name, and what thou art in law to me, that will I be to\r\nthee in fact and deed. I will be thy servant forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides\xe2\x80\x99 face actually glowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO son of my dead master! I will do better than help; I will serve thee\r\nwith all my might of mind and heart. Body, I have not; it perished in\r\nthy cause; but with mind and heart I will serve thee. I swear it, by\r\nthe altar of our God, and the gifts upon the altar! Only make me\r\nformally what I have assumed to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cName it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs steward the care of the property will be mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount thyself steward now; or wilt thou have it in writing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy word simply is enough; it was so with the father, and I will not\r\nmore from the son. And now, if the understanding be perfect\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Simonides\r\npaused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, daughter of Rachel, speak!\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, lifting her arm\r\nfrom his shoulder.\r\n\r\nEsther, left thus alone, stood a moment abashed, her color coming and\r\ngoing; then she went to Ben-Hur, and said, with a womanliness\r\nsingularly sweet, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not better than my mother was; and, as she is\r\ngone, I pray you, O my master, let me care for my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took her hand, and led her back to the chair, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cThou art\r\na good child. Have thy will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides replaced her arm upon his neck, and there was silence for a\r\ntime in the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nSimonides looked up, none the less a master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cthe night is going fast; and, lest we\r\nbecome too weary for that which is before us, let the refreshments be\r\nbrought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe rang a bell. A servant answered with wine and bread, which she bore\r\nround.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe understanding, good my master,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Simonides, when all were\r\nserved, \xe2\x80\x9cis not perfect in my sight. Henceforth our lives will run on\r\ntogether like rivers which have met and joined their waters. I think\r\ntheir flowing will be better if every cloud is blown from the sky above\r\nthem. You left my door the other day with what seemed a denial of the\r\nclaims which I have just allowed in the broadest terms; but it was not\r\nso, indeed it was not. Esther is witness that I recognized you; and\r\nthat I did not abandon you, let Malluch say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalluch!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne bound to a chair, like me, must have many hands far-reaching, if\r\nhe would move the world from which he is so cruelly barred. I have many\r\nsuch, and Malluch is one of the best of them. And, sometimes\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he cast a\r\ngrateful glance at the sheik\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csometimes I borrow from others good of\r\nheart, like Ilderim the Generous\xe2\x80\x94good and brave. Let him say if I\r\neither denied or forgot you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked at the Arab.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is he, good Ilderim, this is he who told you of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x99s eyes twinkled as he nodded his answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, O my master,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, \xe2\x80\x9cmay we without trial tell what a\r\nman is? I knew you; I saw your father in you; but the kind of man you\r\nwere I did not know. There are people to whom fortune is a curse in\r\ndisguise. Were you of them? I sent Malluch to find out for me, and in\r\nthe service he was my eyes and ears. Do not blame him. He brought me\r\nreport of you which was all good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, heartily. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was wisdom in your\r\ngoodness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe words are very pleasant to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the merchant, with feeling,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cvery pleasant. My fear of misunderstanding is laid. Let the rivers run\r\non now as God may give them direction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter an interval he continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am compelled now by truth. The weaver sits weaving, and, as the\r\nshuttle flies, the cloth increases, and the figures grow, and he dreams\r\ndreams meanwhile; so to my hands the fortune grew, and I wondered at\r\nthe increase, and asked myself about it many times. I could see a care\r\nnot my own went with the enterprises I set going. The simooms which\r\nsmote others on the desert jumped over the things which were mine. The\r\nstorms which heaped the seashore with wrecks did but blow my ships the\r\nsooner into port. Strangest of all, I, so dependent upon others, fixed\r\nto a place like a dead thing, had never a loss by an agent\xe2\x80\x94never. The\r\nelements stooped to serve me, and all my servants, in fact, were\r\nfaithful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very strange,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I said, and kept saying. Finally, O my master, finally I came to be\r\nof your opinion\xe2\x80\x94God was in it\xe2\x80\x94and, like you, I asked, What can his\r\npurpose be? Intelligence is never wasted; intelligence like God\xe2\x80\x99s never\r\nstirs except with design. I have held the question in heart, lo! these\r\nmany years, watching for an answer. I felt sure, if God were in it,\r\nsome day, in his own good time, in his own way, he would show me his\r\npurpose, making it clear as a whited house upon a hill. And I believe\r\nhe has done so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur listened with every faculty intent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMany years ago, with my people\xe2\x80\x94thy mother was with me, Esther,\r\nbeautiful as morning over old Olivet\xe2\x80\x94I sat by the wayside out north of\r\nJerusalem, near the Tombs of the Kings, when three men passed by riding\r\ngreat white camels, such as had never been seen in the Holy City. The\r\nmen were strangers, and from far countries. The first one stopped and\r\nasked me a question. \xe2\x80\x98Where is he that is born King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x99 As if\r\nto allay my wonder, he went on to say, \xe2\x80\x98We have seen his star in the\r\neast, and have come to worship him.\xe2\x80\x99 I could not understand, but\r\nfollowed them to the Damascus Gate; and of every person they met on the\r\nway\xe2\x80\x94of the guard at the Gate, even\xe2\x80\x94they asked the question. All who\r\nheard it were amazed like me. In time I forgot the circumstance, though\r\nthere was much talk of it as a presage of the Messiah. Alas, alas! What\r\nchildren we are, even the wisest! When God walks the earth, his steps\r\nare often centuries apart. You have seen Balthasar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd heard him tell his story,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA miracle!\xe2\x80\x94a very miracle!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Simonides. \xe2\x80\x9cAs he told it to me,\r\ngood my master, I seemed to hear the answer I had so long waited; God\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npurpose burst upon me. Poor will the King be when he comes\xe2\x80\x94poor and\r\nfriendless; without following, without armies, without cities or\r\ncastles; a kingdom to be set up, and Rome reduced and blotted out. See,\r\nsee, O my master! thou flushed with strength, thou trained to arms,\r\nthou burdened with riches; behold the opportunity the Lord hath sent\r\nthee! Shall not his purpose be thine? Could a man be born to a more\r\nperfect glory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides put his whole force in the appeal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the kingdom, the kingdom!\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur answered, eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cBalthasar\r\nsays it is to be of souls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe pride of the Jew was strong in Simonides, and therefore the\r\nslightly contemptuous curl of the lip with which he began his reply:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBalthasar has been a witness of wonderful things\xe2\x80\x94of miracles, O my\r\nmaster; and when he speaks of them, I bow with belief, for they are of\r\nsight and sound personal to him. But he is a son of Mizraim, and not\r\neven a proselyte. Hardly may he be supposed to have special knowledge\r\nby virtue of which we must bow to him in a matter of God\xe2\x80\x99s dealing with\r\nour Israel. The prophets had their light from Heaven directly, even as\r\nhe had his\xe2\x80\x94many to one, and Jehovah the same forever. I must believe\r\nthe prophets.\xe2\x80\x94Bring me the Torah, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe proceeded without waiting for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the testimony of a whole people be slighted, my master? Though you\r\ntravel from Tyre, which is by the sea in the north, to the capital of\r\nEdom, which is in the desert south, you will not find a lisper of the\r\nShema, an alms-giver in the Temple, or any one who has ever eaten of\r\nthe lamb of the Passover, to tell you the kingdom the King is coming to\r\nbuild for us, the children of the covenant, is other than of this\r\nworld, like our father David\xe2\x80\x99s. Now where got they the faith, ask you!\r\nWe will see presently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther here returned, bringing a number of rolls carefully enveloped in\r\ndark-brown linen lettered quaintly in gold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep them, daughter, to give to me as I call for them,\xe2\x80\x9d the father\r\nsaid, in the tender voice he always used in speaking to her, and\r\ncontinued his argument:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were long, good my master\xe2\x80\x94too long, indeed\xe2\x80\x94for me to repeat to you\r\nthe names of the holy men who, in the providence of God, succeeded the\r\nprophets, only a little less favored than they\xe2\x80\x94the seers who have\r\nwritten and the preachers who have taught since the Captivity; the very\r\nwise who borrowed their lights from the lamp of Malachi, the last of\r\nhis line, and whose great names Hillel and Shammai never tired of\r\nrepeating in the colleges. Will you ask them of the kingdom? Thus, the\r\nLord of the sheep in the Book of Enoch\xe2\x80\x94who is he? Who but the King of\r\nwhom we are speaking? A throne is set up for him; he smites the earth,\r\nand the other kings are shaken from their thrones, and the scourges of\r\nIsrael flung into a cavern of fire flaming with pillars of fire. So\r\nalso the singer of the Psalms of Solomon\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Behold, O Lord, and raise up\r\nto Israel their king, the son of David, at the time thou knowest, O\r\nGod, to rule Israel, thy children.... And he will bring the peoples of\r\nthe heathen under his yoke to serve him.... And he shall be a righteous\r\nking taught of God, ... for he shall rule all the earth by the word of\r\nhis mouth forever.\xe2\x80\x99 And last, though not least, hear Ezra, the second\r\nMoses, in his visions of the night, and ask him who is the lion with\r\nhuman voice that says to the eagle\xe2\x80\x94which is Rome\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Thou hast loved\r\nliars, and overthrown the cities of the industrious, and razed their\r\nwalls, though they did thee no harm. Therefore, begone, that the earth\r\nmay be refreshed, and recover itself, and hope in the justice and piety\r\nof him who made her.\xe2\x80\x99 Whereat the eagle was seen no more. Surely, O my\r\nmaster, the testimony of these should be enough! But the way to the\r\nfountain\xe2\x80\x99s head is open. Let us go up to it at once.\xe2\x80\x94Some wine, Esther,\r\nand then the Torah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDost thou believe the prophets, master?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, after drinking. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow thou dost, for of such was the faith of all thy kindred.\xe2\x80\x94Give me,\r\nEsther, the book which hath in it the visions of Isaiah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took one of the rolls which she had unwrapped for him, and read,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The people that walked in darkness have seen a great light: they that\r\ndwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them hath the light\r\nshined.... For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the\r\ngovernment shall be upon his shoulder.... Of the increase of his\r\ngovernment and peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David,\r\nand upon his kingdom, to order it, and to establish it with judgment\r\nand with justice from henceforth even forever.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Believest thou the\r\nprophets, O my master?\xe2\x80\x94Now, Esther, the word of the Lord that came to\r\nMicah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe gave him the roll he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98But thou,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d he began reading\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98but thou, Bethlehem Ephrath, though\r\nthou be little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of thee shall he\r\ncome forth unto me that is to be ruler in Israel.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94This was he, the\r\nvery child Balthasar saw and worshipped in the cave. Believest thou the\r\nprophets, O my master?\xe2\x80\x94Give me, Esther, the words of Jeremiah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReceiving that roll, he read as before, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Behold, the days come, saith\r\nthe Lord, that I will raise unto David a righteous branch, and a king\r\nshall reign and prosper, and shall execute judgment and justice in the\r\nearth. In his days Judah shall be saved, and Israel shall dwell\r\nsafely.\xe2\x80\x99 As a king he shall reign\xe2\x80\x94as a king, O my master! Believest\r\nthou the prophets?\xe2\x80\x94Now, daughter, the roll of the sayings of that son\r\nof Judah in whom there was no blemish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe gave him the Book of Daniel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear, my master,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I saw in the night visions, and behold,\r\none like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven.... And there\r\nwas given him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom, that all people,\r\nnations, and languages should serve him; his dominion is an everlasting\r\ndominion, which shall not pass away, and his kingdom that which shall\r\nnot be destroyed.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Believest thou the prophets, O my master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough. I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Simonides. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the King come poor, will not my\r\nmaster, of his abundance, give him help?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp him? To the last shekel and the last breath. But why speak of his\r\ncoming poor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me, Esther, the word of the Lord as it came to Zechariah,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSimonides.\r\n\r\nShe gave him one of the rolls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear how the King will enter Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he read, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Rejoice\r\ngreatly, O daughter of Zion.... Behold, thy King cometh unto thee with\r\njustice and salvation; lowly, and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt,\r\nthe foal of an ass.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat see you, O my master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRome!\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, gloomily\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRome, and her legions. I have dwelt with\r\nthem in their camps. I know them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides. \xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt be a master of legions for the King,\r\nwith millions to choose from.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMillions!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nSimonides sat a moment thinking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe question of power should not trouble you,\xe2\x80\x9d he next said.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked at him inquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were seeing the lowly King in the act of coming to his own,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSimonides answered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cseeing him on the right hand, as it were, and on\r\nthe left the brassy legions of Caesar, and you were asking, What can he\r\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was my very thought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my master!\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides continued. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know how strong our\r\nIsrael is. You think of him as a sorrowful old man weeping by the\r\nrivers of Babylon. But go up to Jerusalem next Passover, and stand on\r\nthe Xystus or in the Street of Barter, and see him as he is. The\r\npromise of the Lord to father Jacob coming out of Padan-Aram was a law\r\nunder which our people have not ceased multiplying\xe2\x80\x94not even in\r\ncaptivity; they grew under foot of the Egyptian; the clench of the\r\nRoman has been but wholesome nurture to them; now they are indeed \xe2\x80\x98a\r\nnation and a company of nations.\xe2\x80\x99 Nor that only, my master; in fact, to\r\nmeasure the strength of Israel\xe2\x80\x94which is, in fact, measuring what the\r\nKing can do\xe2\x80\x94you shall not bide solely by the rule of natural increase,\r\nbut add thereto the other\xe2\x80\x94I mean the spread of the faith, which will\r\ncarry you to the far and near of the whole known earth. Further, the\r\nhabit is, I know, to think and speak of Jerusalem as Israel, which may\r\nbe likened to our finding an embroidered shred, and holding it up as a\r\nmagisterial robe of Caesar\xe2\x80\x99s. Jerusalem is but a stone of the Temple,\r\nor the heart in the body. Turn from beholding the legions, strong\r\nthough they be, and count the hosts of the faithful waiting the old\r\nalarm, \xe2\x80\x98To your tents, O Israel!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94count the many in Persia, children of\r\nthose who chose not to return with the returning; count the brethren\r\nwho swarm the marts of Egypt and Farther Africa; count the Hebrew\r\ncolonists eking profit in the West\xe2\x80\x94in Lodinum and the trade-courts of\r\nSpain; count the pure of blood and the proselytes in Greece and in the\r\nisles of the sea, and over in Pontus, and here in Antioch, and, for\r\nthat matter, those of that city lying accursed in the shadow of the\r\nunclean walls of Rome herself; count the worshippers of the Lord\r\ndwelling in tents along the deserts next us, as well as in the deserts\r\nbeyond the Nile: and in the regions across the Caspian, and up in the\r\nold lands of Gog and Magog even, separate those who annually send gifts\r\nto the Holy Temple in acknowledgment of God\xe2\x80\x94separate them, that they\r\nmay be counted also. And when you have done counting, lo! my master, a\r\ncensus of the sword hands that await you; lo! a kingdom ready fashioned\r\nfor him who is to do \xe2\x80\x98judgment and justice in the whole earth\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94in Rome\r\nnot less than in Zion. Have then the answer, What Israel can do, that\r\ncan the King.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe picture was fervently given.\r\n\r\nUpon Ilderim it operated like the blowing of a trumpet. \xe2\x80\x9cOh that I had\r\nback my youth!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, starting to his feet.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur sat still. The speech, he saw, was an invitation to devote his\r\nlife and fortune to the mysterious Being who was palpably as much the\r\ncentre of a great hope with Simonides as with the devout Egyptian. The\r\nidea, as we have seen, was not a new one, but had come to him\r\nrepeatedly; once while listening to Malluch in the Grove of Daphne;\r\nafterwards more distinctly while Balthasar was giving his conception of\r\nwhat the kingdom was to be; still later, in the walk through the old\r\nOrchard, it had risen almost, if not quite, into a resolve. At such\r\ntimes it had come and gone only an idea, attended with feelings more or\r\nless acute. Not so now. A master had it in charge, a master was working\r\nit up; already he had exalted it into a _cause_ brilliant with\r\npossibilities and infinitely holy. The effect was as if a door\r\ntheretofore unseen had suddenly opened flooding Ben-Hur with light, and\r\nadmitting him to a service which had been his one perfect dream\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nservice reaching far into the future, and rich with the rewards of duty\r\ndone, and prizes to sweeten and soothe his ambition. One touch more was\r\nneeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us concede all you say, O Simonides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat the King\r\nwill come, and his kingdom be as Solomon\xe2\x80\x99s; say also I am ready to give\r\nmyself and all I have to him and his cause; yet more, say that I should\r\ndo as was God\xe2\x80\x99s purpose in the ordering of my life and in your quick\r\namassment of astonishing fortune; then what? Shall we proceed like\r\nblind men building? Shall we wait till the King comes? Or until he\r\nsends for me? You have age and experience on your side. Answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides answered at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have no choice; none. This letter\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he produced Messala\xe2\x80\x99s despatch\r\nas he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthis letter is the signal for action. The alliance\r\nproposed between Messala and Gratus we are not strong enough to resist;\r\nwe have not the influence at Rome nor the force here. They will kill\r\nyou if we wait. How merciful they are, look at me and judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shuddered at the terrible recollection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO good my master,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, recovering himself; \xe2\x80\x9chow strong are\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94in purpose, I mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur did not understand him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember how pleasant the world was to me in my youth,\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides\r\nproceeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were capable of a great sacrifice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; for love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas not life other motives as strong?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is ambition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmbition is forbidden a son of Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, then, of revenge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe spark dropped upon the inflammable passion; the man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes gleamed;\r\nhis hands shook; he answered, quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cRevenge is a Jew\xe2\x80\x99s of right; it\r\nis the law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA camel, even a dog, will remember a wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ilderim.\r\n\r\nDirectly Simonides picked up the broken thread of his thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a work, a work for the King, which should be done in advance\r\nof his coming. We may not doubt that Israel is to be his right hand;\r\nbut, alas! it is a hand of peace, without cunning in war. Of the\r\nmillions, there is not one trained band, not a captain. The mercenaries\r\nof the Herods I do not count, for they are kept to crush us. The\r\ncondition is as the Roman would have it; his policy has fruited well\r\nfor his tyranny; but the time of change is at hand, when the shepherd\r\nshall put on armor, and take to spear and sword, and the feeding flocks\r\nbe turned to fighting lions. Some one, my son, must have place next the\r\nKing at his right hand. Who shall it be if not he who does this work\r\nwell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face flushed at the prospect, though he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI see; but\r\nspeak plainly. A deed to be done is one thing; how to do it is\r\nanother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides sipped the wine Esther brought him, and replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sheik, and thou, my master, shall be principals, each with a part.\r\nI will remain here, carrying on as now, and watchful that the spring go\r\nnot dry. Thou shalt betake thee to Jerusalem, and thence to the\r\nwilderness, and begin numbering the fighting-men of Israel, and telling\r\nthem into tens and hundreds, and choosing captains and training them,\r\nand in secret places hoarding arms, for which I shall keep thee\r\nsupplied. Commencing over in Perea, thou shalt go then to Galilee,\r\nwhence it is but a step to Jerusalem. In Perea, the desert will be at\r\nthy back, and Ilderim in reach of thy hand. He will keep the roads, so\r\nthat nothing shall pass without thy knowledge. He will help thee in\r\nmany ways. Until the ripening time no one shall know what is here\r\ncontracted. Mine is but a servant\xe2\x80\x99s part. I have spoken to Ilderim.\r\nWhat sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked at the sheik.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as he says, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d the Arab responded. \xe2\x80\x9cI have given my\r\nword, and he is content with it; but thou shalt have my oath, binding\r\nme, and the ready hands of my tribe, and whatever serviceable thing I\r\nhave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three\xe2\x80\x94Simonides, Ilderim, Esther\xe2\x80\x94gazed at Ben-Hur fixedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvery man,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, at first sadly, \xe2\x80\x9chas a cup of pleasure poured\r\nfor him, and soon or late it comes to his hand, and he tastes and\r\ndrinks\xe2\x80\x94every man but me. I see, Simonides, and thou, O generous\r\nsheik!\xe2\x80\x94I see whither the proposal tends. If I accept, and enter upon\r\nthe course, farewell peace, and the hopes which cluster around it. The\r\ndoors I might enter and the gates of quiet life will shut behind me,\r\nnever to open again, for Rome keeps them all; and her outlawry will\r\nfollow me, and her hunters; and in the tombs near cities and the dismal\r\ncaverns of remotest hills, I must eat my crust and take my rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe speech was broken by a sob. All turned to Esther, who hid her face\r\nupon her father\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not think of you, Esther,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, gently, for he was\r\nhimself deeply moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well enough, Simonides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cA man bears a hard doom\r\nbetter, knowing there is pity for him. Let me go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey gave him ear again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to say,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI have no choice, but take the\r\npart you assign me; and as remaining here is to meet an ignoble death,\r\nI will to the work at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we have writings?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Simonides, moved by his habit of\r\nbusiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rest upon your word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d Ilderim answered.\r\n\r\nThus simply was effected the treaty which was to alter Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s life.\r\nAnd almost immediately the latter added,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is done, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the God of Abraham help us!\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word now, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur said, more cheerfully. \xe2\x80\x9cBy your\r\nleave, I will be my own until after the games. It is not probable\r\nMessala will set peril on foot for me until he has given the procurator\r\ntime to answer him; and that cannot be in less than seven days from the\r\ndespatch of his letter. The meeting him in the Circus is a pleasure I\r\nwould buy at whatever risk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim, well pleased, assented readily, and Simonides, intent on\r\nbusiness, added, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is well; for look you, my master, the delay will\r\ngive me time to do you a good part. I understood you to speak of an\r\ninheritance derived from Arrius. Is it in property?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA villa near Misenum, and houses in Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suggest, then, the sale of the property, and safe deposit of the\r\nproceeds. Give me an account of it, and I will have authorities drawn,\r\nand despatch an agent on the mission forthwith. We will forestall the\r\nimperial robbers at least this once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall have the account to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, if there be nothing more, the work of the night is done,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSimonides.\r\n\r\nIlderim combed his beard complacently, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd well done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bread and wine again, Esther. Sheik Ilderim will make us happy by\r\nstaying with us till to-morrow, or at his pleasure; and thou, my\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet the horses be brought,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cI will return to the\r\nOrchard. The enemy will not discover me if I go now, and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he glanced at\r\nIlderim\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe four will be glad to see me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the day dawned, he and Malluch dismounted at the door of the tent.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\nNext night, about the fourth hour, Ben-Hur stood on the terrace of the\r\ngreat warehouse with Esther. Below them, on the landing, there was much\r\nrunning about, and shifting of packages and boxes, and shouting of men,\r\nwhose figures, stooping, heaving, hauling, looked, in the light of the\r\ncrackling torches kindled in their aid, like the laboring genii of the\r\nfantastic Eastern tales. A galley was being laden for instant\r\ndeparture. Simonides had not yet come from his office, in which, at the\r\nlast moment, he would deliver to the captain of the vessel instructions\r\nto proceed without stop to Ostia, the seaport of Rome, and, after\r\nlanding a passenger there, continue more leisurely to Valentia, on the\r\ncoast of Spain.\r\n\r\nThe passenger is the agent going to dispose of the estate derived from\r\nArrius the duumvir. When the lines of the vessel are cast off, and she\r\nis put about, and her voyage begun, Ben-Hur will be committed\r\nirrevocably to the work undertaken the night before. If he is disposed\r\nto repent the agreement with Ilderim, a little time is allowed him to\r\ngive notice and break it off. He is master, and has only to say the\r\nword.\r\n\r\nSuch may have been the thought at the moment in his mind. He was\r\nstanding with folded arms, looking upon the scene in the manner of a\r\nman debating with himself. Young, handsome, rich, but recently from the\r\npatrician circles of Roman society, it is easy to think of the world\r\nbesetting him with appeals not to give more to onerous duty or ambition\r\nattended with outlawry and danger. We can even imagine the arguments\r\nwith which he was pressed; the hopelessness of contention with Caesar;\r\nthe uncertainty veiling everything connected with the King and his\r\ncoming; the ease, honors, state, purchasable like goods in market; and,\r\nstrongest of all, the sense newly acquired of home, with friends to\r\nmake it delightful. Only those who have been wanderers long desolate\r\ncan know the power there was in the latter appeal.\r\n\r\nLet us add now, the world\xe2\x80\x94always cunning enough of itself; always\r\nwhispering to the weak, Stay, take thine ease; always presenting the\r\nsunny side of life\xe2\x80\x94the world was in this instance helped by Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompanion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you ever at Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d Esther replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid of Rome,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, with a perceptible tremor of the\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her then\xe2\x80\x94or rather down upon her, for at his side she\r\nappeared little more than a child. In the dim light he could not see\r\nher face distinctly; even the form was shadowy. But again he was\r\nreminded of Tirzah, and a sudden tenderness fell upon him\xe2\x80\x94just so the\r\nlost sister stood with him on the house-top the calamitous morning of\r\nthe accident to Gratus. Poor Tirzah! Where was she now? Esther had the\r\nbenefit of the feeling evoked. If not his sister, he could never look\r\nupon her as his servant; and that she was his servant in fact would\r\nmake him always the more considerate and gentle towards her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot think of Rome,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, recovering her voice, and\r\nspeaking in her quiet womanly way\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot think of Rome as a city of\r\npalaces and temples, and crowded with people; she is to me a monster\r\nwhich has possession of one of the beautiful lands, and lies there\r\nluring men to ruin and death\xe2\x80\x94a monster which it is not possible to\r\nresist\xe2\x80\x94a ravenous beast gorging with blood. Why\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe faltered, looked down, stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, reassuringly.\r\n\r\nShe drew closer to him, looked up again, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy must you make\r\nher your enemy? Why not rather make peace with her, and be at rest? You\r\nhave had many ills, and borne them; you have survived the snares laid\r\nfor you by foes. Sorrow has consumed your youth; is it well to give it\r\nthe remainder of your days?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girlish face under his eyes seemed to come nearer and get whiter as\r\nthe pleading went on; he stooped towards it, and asked, softly, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nwould you have me do, Esther?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hesitated a moment, then asked, in return, \xe2\x80\x9cIs the property near\r\nRome a residence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pretty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is beautiful\xe2\x80\x94a palace in the midst of gardens and shell-strewn\r\nwalks; fountains without and within; statuary in the shady nooks; hills\r\naround covered with vines, and so high that Neapolis and Vesuvius are\r\nin sight, and the sea an expanse of purpling blue dotted with restless\r\nsails. Caesar has a country-seat near-by, but in Rome they say the old\r\nArrian villa is the prettiest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the life there, is it quiet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was never a summer day, never a moonlit night, more quiet, save\r\nwhen visitors come. Now that the old owner is gone, and I am here,\r\nthere is nothing to break its silence\xe2\x80\x94nothing, unless it be the\r\nwhispering of servants, or the whistling of happy birds, or the noise\r\nof fountains at play; it is changeless, except as day by day old\r\nflowers fade and fall, and new ones bud and bloom, and the sunlight\r\ngives place to the shadow of a passing cloud. The life, Esther, was all\r\ntoo quiet for me. It made me restless by keeping always present a\r\nfeeling that I, who have so much to do, was dropping into idle habits,\r\nand tying myself with silken chains, and after a while\xe2\x80\x94and not a long\r\nwhile either\xe2\x80\x94would end with nothing done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked off over the river.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood my master\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Esther\xe2\x80\x94not that. Call me friend\xe2\x80\x94brother, if you will; I am not\r\nyour master, and will not be. Call me brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe could not see the flush of pleasure which reddened her face, and the\r\nglow of the eyes that went out lost in the void above the river.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot understand,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe nature which prefers the life you\r\nare going to\xe2\x80\x94a life of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf violence, and it may be of blood,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, completing the\r\nsentence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cthe nature which could prefer that life to such as\r\nmight be in the beautiful villa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther, you mistake. There is no preference. Alas! the Roman is not so\r\nkind. I am going of necessity. To stay here is to die; and if I go\r\nthere, the end will be the same\xe2\x80\x94a poisoned cup, a bravo\xe2\x80\x99s blow, or a\r\njudge\xe2\x80\x99s sentence obtained by perjury. Messala and the procurator Gratus\r\nare rich with plunder of my father\xe2\x80\x99s estate, and it is more important\r\nto them to keep their gains now than was their getting in the first\r\ninstance. A peaceable settlement is out of reach, because of the\r\nconfession it would imply. And then\xe2\x80\x94then\xe2\x80\x94 Ah, Esther, if I could buy\r\nthem, I do not know that I would. I do not believe peace possible to\r\nme; no, not even in the sleepy shade and sweet air of the marble\r\nporches of the old villa\xe2\x80\x94no matter who might be there to help me bear\r\nthe burden of the days, nor by what patience of love she made the\r\neffort. Peace is not possible to me while my people are lost, for I\r\nmust be watchful to find them. If I find them, and they have suffered\r\nwrong, shall not the guilty suffer for it? If they are dead by\r\nviolence, shall the murderers escape? Oh, I could not sleep for dreams!\r\nNor could the holiest love, by any stratagem, lull me to a rest which\r\nconscience would not strangle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it so bad then?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, her voice tremulous with feeling. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\r\nnothing, nothing, be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you care so much for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, simply.\r\n\r\nThe hand was warm, and in the palm of his it was lost. He felt it\r\ntremble. Then the Egyptian came, so the opposite of this little one; so\r\ntall, so audacious, with a flattery so cunning, a wit so ready, a\r\nbeauty so wonderful, a manner so bewitching. He carried the hand to his\r\nlips, and gave it back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall be another Tirzah to me, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is Tirzah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe little sister the Roman stole from me, and whom I must find before\r\nI can rest or be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then a gleam of light flashed athwart the terrace and fell upon\r\nthe two; and, looking round, they saw a servant roll Simonides in his\r\nchair out of the door. They went to the merchant, and in the after-talk\r\nhe was principal.\r\n\r\nImmediately the lines of the galley were cast off, and she swung round,\r\nand, midst the flashing of torches and the shouting of joyous sailors,\r\nhurried off to the sea\xe2\x80\x94leaving Ben-Hur committed to the cause of the\r\nKING WHO WAS TO COME.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\n\r\nThe day before the games, in the afternoon, all Ilderim\xe2\x80\x99s racing\r\nproperty was taken to the city, and put in quarters adjoining the\r\nCircus. Along with it the good man carried a great deal of property not\r\nof that class; so with servants, retainers mounted and armed, horses in\r\nleading, cattle driven, camels laden with baggage, his outgoing from\r\nthe Orchard was not unlike a tribal migration. The people along the\r\nroad failed not to laugh at his motley procession; on the other side,\r\nit was observed that, with all his irascibility, he was not in the\r\nleast offended by their rudeness. If he was under surveillance, as he\r\nhad reason to believe, the informer would describe the semi-barbarous\r\nshow with which he came up to the races. The Romans would laugh; the\r\ncity would be amused; but what cared he? Next morning the pageant would\r\nbe far on the road to the desert, and going with it would be every\r\nmovable thing of value belonging to the Orchard\xe2\x80\x94everything save such as\r\nwere essential to the success of his four. He was, in fact, started\r\nhome; his tents were all folded; the dowar was no more; in twelve hours\r\nall would be out of reach, pursue who might. A man is never safer than\r\nwhen he is under the laugh; and the shrewd old Arab knew it.\r\n\r\nNeither he nor Ben-Hur overestimated the influence of Messala; it was\r\ntheir opinion, however, that he would not begin active measures against\r\nthem until after the meeting in the Circus; if defeated there,\r\nespecially if defeated by Ben-Hur, they might instantly look for the\r\nworst he could do; he might not even wait for advices from Gratus. With\r\nthis view, they shaped their course, and were prepared to betake\r\nthemselves out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way. They rode together now in good spirits,\r\ncalmly confident of success on the morrow.\r\n\r\nOn the way, they came upon Malluch in waiting for them. The faithful\r\nfellow gave no sign by which it was possible to infer any knowledge on\r\nhis part of the relationship so recently admitted between Ben-Hur and\r\nSimonides, or of the treaty between them and Ilderim. He exchanged\r\nsalutations as usual, and produced a paper, saying to the sheik, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave here the notice of the editor of the games, just issued, in which\r\nyou will find your horses published for the race. You will find in it\r\nalso the order of exercises. Without waiting, good sheik, I\r\ncongratulate you upon your victory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gave the paper over, and, leaving the worthy to master it, turned to\r\nBen-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you also, son of Arrius, my congratulations. There is nothing now\r\nto prevent your meeting Messala. Every condition preliminary to the\r\nrace is complied with. I have the assurance from the editor himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, Malluch,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nMalluch proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour color is white, and Messala\xe2\x80\x99s mixed scarlet and gold. The good\r\neffects of the choice are visible already. Boys are now hawking white\r\nribbons along the streets; tomorrow every Arab and Jew in the city will\r\nwear them. In the Circus you will see the white fairly divide the\r\ngalleries with the red.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe galleries\xe2\x80\x94but not the tribunal over the Porta Pompae.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; the scarlet and gold will rule there. But if we win\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Malluch\r\nchuckled with the pleasure of the thought\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif we win, how the\r\ndignitaries will tremble! They will bet, of course, according to their\r\nscorn of everything not Roman\xe2\x80\x94two, three, five to one on Messala,\r\nbecause he is Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d Dropping his voice yet lower, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cIt ill\r\nbecomes a Jew of good standing in the Temple to put his money at such a\r\nhazard; yet, in confidence, I will have a friend next behind the\r\nconsul\xe2\x80\x99s seat to accept offers of three to one, or five, or ten\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nmadness may go to such height. I have put to his order six thousand\r\nshekels for the purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, Malluch,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, \xe2\x80\x9ca Roman will wager only in his Roman\r\ncoin. Suppose you find your friend to-night, and place to his order\r\nsestertii in such amount as you choose. And look you, Malluch\xe2\x80\x94let him\r\nbe instructed to seek wagers with Messala and his supporters; Ilderim\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfour against Messala\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch reflected a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe effect will be to centre interest upon your contest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very thing I seek, Malluch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see, I see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, Malluch; would you serve me perfectly, help me to fix the public\r\neye upon our race\xe2\x80\x94Messala\xe2\x80\x99s and mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch spoke quickly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt can be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let it be done,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnormous wagers offered will answer; if the offers are accepted, all\r\nthe better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch turned his eyes watchfully upon Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I not have back the equivalent of his robbery?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur,\r\npartly to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cAnother opportunity may not come. And if I could\r\nbreak him in fortune as well as in pride! Our father Jacob could take\r\nno offence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA look of determined will knit his handsome face, giving emphasis to\r\nhis further speech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it shall be. Hark, Malluch! Stop not in thy offer of sestertii.\r\nAdvance them to talents, if any there be who dare so high. Five, ten,\r\ntwenty talents; ay, fifty, so the wager be with Messala himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a mighty sum,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch. \xe2\x80\x9cI must have security.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo thou shalt. Go to Simonides, and tell him I wish the matter\r\narranged. Tell him my heart is set on the ruin of my enemy, and that\r\nthe opportunity hath such excellent promise that I choose such hazards.\r\nOn our side be the God of our fathers. Go, good Malluch. Let this not\r\nslip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Malluch, greatly delighted, gave him parting salutation, and\r\nstarted to ride away, but returned presently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was another matter. I could\r\nnot get near Messala\xe2\x80\x99s chariot myself, but I had another measure it;\r\nand, from his report, its hub stands quite a palm higher from the\r\nground than yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA palm! So much?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ben-Hur, joyfully.\r\n\r\nThen he leaned over to Malluch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs thou art a son of Judah, Malluch, and faithful to thy kin, get thee\r\na seat in the gallery over the Gate of Triumph, down close to the\r\nbalcony in front of the pillars, and watch well when we make the turns\r\nthere; watch well, for if I have favor at all, I will\xe2\x80\x94 Nay, Malluch,\r\nlet it go unsaid! Only get thee there, and watch well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that moment a cry burst from Ilderim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! By the splendor of God! what is this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew near Ben-Hur with a finger pointing on the face of the notice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; better thou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took the paper, which, signed by the prefect of the province as\r\neditor, performed the office of a modern programme, giving particularly\r\nthe several divertisements provided for the occasion. It informed the\r\npublic that there would be first a procession of extraordinary\r\nsplendor; that the procession would be succeeded by the customary\r\nhonors to the god Consus, whereupon the games would begin; running,\r\nleaping, wrestling, boxing, each in the order stated. The names of the\r\ncompetitors were given, with their several nationalities and schools of\r\ntraining, the trials in which they had been engaged, the prizes won,\r\nand the prizes now offered; under the latter head the sums of money\r\nwere stated in illuminated letters, telling of the departure of the day\r\nwhen the simple chaplet of pine or laurel was fully enough for the\r\nvictor, hungering for glory as something better than riches, and\r\ncontent with it.\r\n\r\nOver these parts of the programme Ben-Hur sped with rapid eyes. At last\r\nhe came to the announcement of the race. He read it slowly. Attending\r\nlovers of the heroic sports were assured they would certainly be\r\ngratified by an Orestean struggle unparalleled in Antioch. The city\r\noffered the spectacle in honor of the consul. One hundred thousand\r\nsestertii and a crown of laurel were the prizes. Then followed the\r\nparticulars. The entries were six in all\xe2\x80\x94fours only permitted; and, to\r\nfurther interest in the performance, the competitors would be turned\r\ninto the course together. Each four then received description.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI. A four of Lysippus the Corinthian\xe2\x80\x94two grays, a bay, and a black;\r\nentered at Alexandria last year, and again at Corinth, where they were\r\nwinners. Lysippus, driver. Color, yellow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cII. A four of Messala of Rome\xe2\x80\x94two white, two black; victors of the\r\nCircensian as exhibited in the Circus Maximus last year. Messala,\r\ndriver. Colors, scarlet and gold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIII. A four of Cleanthes the Athenian\xe2\x80\x94three gray, one bay; winners at\r\nthe Isthmian last year. Cleanthes, driver. Color, green.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIV. A four of Dicaeus the Byzantine\xe2\x80\x94two black, one gray, one bay;\r\nwinners this year at Byzantium. Dicaeus, driver. Color, black.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cV. A four of Admetus the Sidonian\xe2\x80\x94all grays. Thrice entered at\r\nCaesarea, and thrice victors. Admetus, driver. Color, blue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVI. A four of Ilderim, sheik of the Desert. All bays; first race.\r\nBen-Hur, a Jew, driver. Color, white.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBEN-HUR, A JEW, DRIVER!\r\n\r\nWhy that name instead of Arrius?\r\n\r\nBen-Hur raised his eyes to Ilderim. He had found the cause of the\r\nArab\xe2\x80\x99s outcry. Both rushed to the same conclusion.\r\n\r\nThe hand was the hand of Messala!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\n\r\nEvening was hardly come upon Antioch, when the Omphalus, nearly in the\r\ncentre of the city, became a troubled fountain from which in every\r\ndirection, but chiefly down to the Nymphaeum and east and west along\r\nthe Colonnade of Herod, flowed currents of people, for the time given\r\nup to Bacchus and Apollo.\r\n\r\nFor such indulgence anything more fitting cannot be imagined than the\r\ngreat roofed streets, which were literally miles on miles of porticos\r\nwrought of marble, polished to the last degree of finish, and all gifts\r\nto the voluptuous city by princes careless of expenditure where, as in\r\nthis instance, they thought they were eternizing themselves. Darkness\r\nwas not permitted anywhere; and the singing, the laughter, the\r\nshouting, were incessant, and in compound like the roar of waters\r\ndashing through hollow grots, confused by a multitude of echoes.\r\n\r\nThe many nationalities represented, though they might have amazed a\r\nstranger, were not peculiar to Antioch. Of the various missions of the\r\ngreat empire, one seems to have been the fusion of men and the\r\nintroduction of strangers to each other; accordingly, whole peoples\r\nrose up and went at pleasure, taking with them their costumes, customs,\r\nspeech, and gods; and where they chose, they stopped, engaged in\r\nbusiness, built houses, erected altars, and were what they had been at\r\nhome.\r\n\r\nThere was a peculiarity, however, which could not have failed the\r\nnotice of a looker-on this night in Antioch. Nearly everybody wore the\r\ncolors of one or other of the charioteers announced for the morrow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrace. Sometimes it was in form of a scarf, sometimes a badge; often a\r\nribbon or a feather. Whatever the form, it signified merely the\r\nwearer\xe2\x80\x99s partiality; thus, green published a friend of Cleanthes the\r\nAthenian, and black an adherent of the Byzantine. This was according to\r\na custom, old probably as the day of the race of Orestes\xe2\x80\x94a custom, by\r\nthe way, worthy of study as a marvel of history, illustrative of the\r\nabsurd yet appalling extremities to which men frequently suffer their\r\nfollies to drag them.\r\n\r\nThe observer abroad on this occasion, once attracted to the wearing of\r\ncolors, would have very shortly decided that there were three in\r\npredominance\xe2\x80\x94green, white, and the mixed scarlet and gold.\r\n\r\nBut let us from the streets to the palace on the island.\r\n\r\nThe five great chandeliers in the saloon are freshly lighted. The\r\nassemblage is much the same as that already noticed in connection with\r\nthe place. The divan has its corps of sleepers and burden of garments,\r\nand the tables yet resound with the rattle and clash of dice. Yet the\r\ngreater part of the company are not doing anything. They walk about, or\r\nyawn tremendously, or pause as they pass each other to exchange idle\r\nnothings. Will the weather be fair to-morrow? Are the preparations for\r\nthe games complete? Do the laws of the Circus in Antioch differ from\r\nthe laws of the Circus in Rome? Truth is, the young fellows are\r\nsuffering from ennui. Their heavy work is done; that is, we would find\r\ntheir tablets, could we look at them, covered with memoranda of\r\nwagers\xe2\x80\x94wagers on every contest; on the running, the wrestling, the\r\nboxing; on everything but the chariot-race.\r\n\r\nAnd why not on that?\r\n\r\nGood reader, they cannot find anybody who will hazard so much as a\r\ndenarius with them against Messala.\r\n\r\nThere are no colors in the saloon but his.\r\n\r\nNo one thinks of his defeat.\r\n\r\nWhy, they say, is he not perfect in his training? Did he not graduate\r\nfrom an imperial lanista? Were not his horses winners at the Circensian\r\nin the Circus Maximus? And then\xe2\x80\x94ah, yes! he is a Roman!\r\n\r\nIn a corner, at ease on the divan, Messala himself may be seen. Around\r\nhim, sitting or standing, are his courtierly admirers, plying him with\r\nquestions. There is, of course, but one topic.\r\n\r\nEnter Drusus and Cecilius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cries the young prince, throwing himself on the divan at\r\nMessala\xe2\x80\x99s feet, \xe2\x80\x9cAh, by Bacchus, I am tired!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither away?\xe2\x80\x9d asks Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUp the street; up to the Omphalus, and beyond\xe2\x80\x94who shall say how far?\r\nRivers of people; never so many in the city before. They say we will\r\nsee the whole world at the Circus to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala laughed scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe idiots! Perpol! They never beheld a Circensian with Caesar for\r\neditor. But, my Drusus, what found you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO\xe2\x80\x94ah! You forget,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cecilius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Drusus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe procession of whites.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMirabile!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Drusus, half rising. \xe2\x80\x9cWe met a faction of whites, and\r\nthey had a banner. But\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe fell back indolently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCruel Drusus\xe2\x80\x94not to go on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScum of the desert were they, my Messala, and garbage-eaters from the\r\nJacob\xe2\x80\x99s Temple in Jerusalem. What had I to do with them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cecilius, \xe2\x80\x9cDrusus is afraid of a laugh, but I am not, my\r\nMessala.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak thou, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we stopped the faction, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOffered them a wager,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drusus, relenting, and taking the word\r\nfrom the shadow\xe2\x80\x99s mouth. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x94one fellow with not enough\r\nskin on his face to make a worm for a carp stepped forth, and\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha,\r\nha!\xe2\x80\x94said yes. I drew my tablets. \xe2\x80\x98Who is your man?\xe2\x80\x99 I asked. \xe2\x80\x98Ben-Hur,\r\nthe Jew,\xe2\x80\x99 said he. Then I: \xe2\x80\x98What shall it be? How much?\xe2\x80\x99 He answered,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A\xe2\x80\x94a\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99 Excuse me, Messala. By Jove\xe2\x80\x99s thunder, I cannot go on for\r\nlaughter! Ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe listeners leaned forward.\r\n\r\nMessala looked to Cecilius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA shekel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA shekel! A shekel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA burst of scornful laughter ran fast upon the repetition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did Drusus?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Messala.\r\n\r\nAn outcry over about the door just then occasioned a rush to that\r\nquarter; and, as the noise there continued, and grew louder, even\r\nCecilius betook himself off, pausing only to say, \xe2\x80\x9cThe noble Drusus, my\r\nMessala, put up his tablets and\xe2\x80\x94lost the shekel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA white! A white!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis way, this way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese and like exclamations filled the saloon, to the stoppage of other\r\nspeech. The dice-players quit their games; the sleepers awoke, rubbed\r\ntheir eyes, drew their tablets, and hurried to the common centre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI offer you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe person so warmly received was the respectable Jew, Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfellow-voyager from Cyprus. He entered grave, quiet, observant. His\r\nrobe was spotlessly white; so was the cloth of his turban. Bowing and\r\nsmiling at the welcome, he moved slowly towards the central table.\r\nArrived there, he drew his robe about him in a stately manner, took\r\nseat, and waved his hand. The gleam of a jewel on a finger helped him\r\nnot a little to the silence which ensued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRomans\xe2\x80\x94most noble Romans\xe2\x80\x94I salute you!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEasy, by Jupiter! Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Drusus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA dog of Israel\xe2\x80\x94Sanballat by name\xe2\x80\x94purveyor for the army; residence,\r\nRome; vastly rich; grown so as a contractor of furnishments which he\r\nnever furnishes. He spins mischiefs, nevertheless, finer than spiders\r\nspin their webs. Come\xe2\x80\x94by the girdle of Venus! let us catch him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMessala arose as he spoke, and, with Drusus, joined the mass crowded\r\nabout the purveyor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt came to me on the street,\xe2\x80\x9d said that person, producing his tablets,\r\nand opening them on the table with an impressive air of business, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nthere was great discomfort in the palace because offers on Messala were\r\ngoing without takers. The gods, you know, must have sacrifices; and\r\nhere am I. You see my color; let us to the matter. Odds first, amounts\r\nnext.
