What will you give me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe audacity seemed to stun his hearers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaste!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have an engagement with the consul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe spur was effective.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo to one,\xe2\x80\x9d cried half a dozen in a voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the purveyor, astonished. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly two to one, and yours\r\na Roman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake three, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree say you\xe2\x80\x94only three\xe2\x80\x94and mine but a dog of a Jew! Give me four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said a boy, stung by the taunt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive\xe2\x80\x94give me five,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the purveyor, instantly.\r\n\r\nA profound stillness fell upon the assemblage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe consul\xe2\x80\x94your master and mine\xe2\x80\x94is waiting for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe inaction became awkward to the many.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me five\xe2\x80\x94for the honor of Rome, five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive let it be,\xe2\x80\x9d said one in answer.\r\n\r\nThere was a sharp cheer\xe2\x80\x94a commotion\xe2\x80\x94and Messala himself appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive let it be,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAnd Sanballat smiled, and made ready to write.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Caesar die to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cRome will not be all bereft. There\r\nis at least one other with spirit to take his place. Give me six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix be it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Messala.\r\n\r\nThere was another shout louder than the first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix be it,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Messala. \xe2\x80\x9cSix to one\xe2\x80\x94the difference between a\r\nRoman and a Jew. And, having found it, now, O redemptor of the flesh of\r\nswine, let us on. The amount\xe2\x80\x94and quickly. The consul may send for thee,\r\nand I will then be bereft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSanballat took the laugh against him coolly, and wrote, and offered the\r\nwriting to Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead, read!\xe2\x80\x9d everybody demanded.\r\n\r\nAnd Messala read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMem.\xe2\x80\x94Chariot-race. Messala of Rome, in wager with Sanballat, also of\r\nRome, says he will beat Ben-Hur, the Jew. Amount of wager, twenty\r\ntalents. Odds to Sanballat, six to one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWitnesses: SANBALLAT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no noise, no motion. Each person seemed held in the pose the\r\nreading found him. Messala stared at the memorandum, while the eyes\r\nwhich had him in view opened wide, and stared at him. He felt the gaze,\r\nand thought rapidly. So lately he stood in the same place, and in the\r\nsame way hectored the countrymen around him. They would remember it. If\r\nhe refused to sign, his hero-ship was lost. And sign he could not; he\r\nwas not worth one hundred talents, nor the fifth part of the sum.\r\nSuddenly his mind became a blank; he stood speechless; the color fled\r\nhis face. An idea at last came to his relief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere hast thou twenty talents? Show me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSanballat\xe2\x80\x99s provoking smile deepened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, offering Messala a paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead, read!\xe2\x80\x9d arose all around.\r\n\r\nAgain Messala read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAT ANTIOCH, Tammuz 16th day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bearer, Sanballat of Rome, hath now to his order with me fifty\r\ntalents, coin of Caesar.\r\n\r\nSIMONIDES.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty talents, fifty talents!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the throng, in amazement.\r\n\r\nThen Drusus came to the rescue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Hercules!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cthe paper lies, and the Jew is a liar. Who\r\nbut Caesar hath fifty talents at order? Down with the insolent white!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cry was angry, and it was angrily repeated; yet Sanballat kept his\r\nseat, and his smile grew more exasperating the longer he waited. At\r\nlength Messala spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush! One to one, my countrymen\xe2\x80\x94one to one, for love of our ancient\r\nRoman name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe timely action recovered him his ascendancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO thou circumcised dog!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, to Sanballat, \xe2\x80\x9cI gave thee six\r\nto one, did I not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, give me now the fixing of the amount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith reserve, if the amount be trifling, have thy will,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nSanballat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite, then, five in place of twenty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast thou so much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the mother of the gods, I will show you receipts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, the word of so brave a Roman must pass. Only make the sum\r\neven\xe2\x80\x94six make it, and I will write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite it so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd forthwith they exchanged writings.\r\n\r\nSanballat immediately arose and looked around him, a sneer in place of\r\nhis smile. No man better than he knew those with whom he was dealing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRomans,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9canother wager, if you dare! Five talents against\r\nfive talents that the white will win. I challenge you collectively.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were again surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, louder. \xe2\x80\x9cShall it be said in the Circus to-morrow\r\nthat a dog of Israel went into the saloon of the palace full of Roman\r\nnobles\xe2\x80\x94among them the scion of a Caesar\xe2\x80\x94and laid five talents before\r\nthem in challenge, and they had not the courage to take it up?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sting was unendurable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave done, O insolent!\xe2\x80\x9d said Drusus, \xe2\x80\x9cwrite the challenge, and leave\r\nit on the table; and to-morrow, if we find thou hast indeed so much\r\nmoney to put at such hopeless hazard, I, Drusus, promise it shall be\r\ntaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSanballat wrote again, and, rising, said, unmoved as ever, \xe2\x80\x9cSee,\r\nDrusus, I leave the offer with you. When it is signed, send it to me\r\nany time before the race begins. I will be found with the consul in a\r\nseat over the Porta Pompae. Peace to you; peace to all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed, and departed, careless of the shout of derision with which\r\nthey pursued him out of the door.\r\n\r\nIn the night the story of the prodigious wager flew along the streets\r\nand over the city; and Ben-Hur, lying with his four, was told of it,\r\nand also that Messala\xe2\x80\x99s whole fortune was on the hazard.\r\n\r\nAnd he slept never so soundly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Circus at Antioch stood on the south bank of the river, nearly\r\nopposite the island, differing in no respect from the plan of such\r\nbuildings in general.\r\n\r\nIn the purest sense, the games were a gift to the public; consequently,\r\neverybody was free to attend; and, vast as the holding capacity of the\r\nstructure was, so fearful were the people, on this occasion, lest there\r\nshould not be room for them, that, early the day before the opening of\r\nthe exhibition, they took up all the vacant spaces in the vicinity,\r\nwhere their temporary shelter suggested an army in waiting.\r\n\r\nAt midnight the entrances were thrown wide, and the rabble, surging in,\r\noccupied the quarters assigned to them, from which nothing less than an\r\nearthquake or an army with spears could have dislodged them. They dozed\r\nthe night away on the benches, and breakfasted there; and there the\r\nclose of the exercises found them, patient and sight-hungry as in the\r\nbeginning.\r\n\r\nThe better people, their seats secured, began moving towards the Circus\r\nabout the first hour of the morning, the noble and very rich among them\r\ndistinguished by litters and retinues of liveried servants.\r\n\r\nBy the second hour, the efflux from the city was a stream unbroken and\r\ninnumerable.\r\n\r\nExactly as the gnomon of the official dial up in the citadel pointed\r\nthe second hour half gone, the legion, in full panoply, and with all\r\nits standards on exhibit, descended from Mount Sulpius; and when the\r\nrear of the last cohort disappeared in the bridge, Antioch was\r\nliterally abandoned\xe2\x80\x94not that the Circus could hold the multitude, but\r\nthat the multitude was gone out to it, nevertheless.\r\n\r\nA great concourse on the river shore witnessed the consul come over\r\nfrom the island in a barge of state. As the great man landed, and was\r\nreceived by the legion, the martial show for one brief moment\r\ntranscended the attraction of the Circus.\r\n\r\nAt the third hour, the audience, if such it may be termed, was\r\nassembled; at last, a flourish of trumpets called for silence, and\r\ninstantly the gaze of over a hundred thousand persons was directed\r\ntowards a pile forming the eastern section of the building.\r\n\r\nThere was a basement first, broken in the middle by a broad arched\r\npassage, called the Porta Pompae, over which, on an elevated tribunal\r\nmagnificently decorated with insignia and legionary standards, the\r\nconsul sat in the place of honor. On both sides of the passage the\r\nbasement was divided into stalls termed carceres, each protected in\r\nfront by massive gates swung to statuesque pilasters. Over the stalls\r\nnext was a cornice crowned by a low balustrade; back of which the seats\r\narose in theatre arrangement, all occupied by a throng of dignitaries\r\nsuperbly attired. The pile extended the width of the Circus, and was\r\nflanked on both sides by towers which, besides helping the architects\r\ngive grace to their work, served the velaria, or purple awnings,\r\nstretched between them so as to throw the whole quarter in a shade that\r\nbecame exceedingly grateful as the day advanced.\r\n\r\nThis structure, it is now thought, can be made useful in helping the\r\nreader to a sufficient understanding of the arrangement of the rest of\r\nthe interior of the Circus. He has only to fancy himself seated on the\r\ntribunal with the consul, facing to the west, where everything is under\r\nhis eye.\r\n\r\nOn the right and left, if he will look, he will see the main entrances,\r\nvery ample, and guarded by gates hinged to the towers.\r\n\r\nDirectly below him is the arena\xe2\x80\x94a level plane of considerable extent,\r\ncovered with fine white sand. There all the trials will take place\r\nexcept the running.\r\n\r\nLooking across this sanded arena westwardly still, there is a pedestal\r\nof marble supporting three low conical pillars of gray stone, much\r\ncarven. Many an eye will hunt for those pillars before the day is done,\r\nfor they are the first goal, and mark the beginning and end of the\r\nrace-course. Behind the pedestal, leaving a passage-way and space for\r\nan altar, commences a wall ten or twelve feet in breadth and five or\r\nsix in height, extending thence exactly two hundred yards, or one\r\nOlympic stadium. At the farther, or westward, extremity of the wall\r\nthere is another pedestal, surmounted with pillars which mark the\r\nsecond goal.\r\n\r\nThe racers will enter the course on the right of the first goal, and\r\nkeep the wall all the time to their left. The beginning and ending\r\npoints of the contest lie, consequently, directly in front of the\r\nconsul across the arena; and for that reason his seat was admittedly\r\nthe most desirable in the Circus.\r\n\r\nNow if the reader, who is still supposed to be seated on the consular\r\ntribunal over the Porta Pompae, will look up from the ground\r\narrangement of the interior, the first point to attract his notice will\r\nbe the marking of the outer boundary-line of the course\xe2\x80\x94that is, a\r\nplain-faced, solid wall, fifteen or twenty feet in height, with a\r\nbalustrade on its cope, like that over the carceres, or stalls, in the\r\neast. This balcony, if followed round the course, will be found broken\r\nin three places to allow passages of exit and entrance, two in the\r\nnorth and one in the west; the latter very ornate, and called the Gate\r\nof Triumph, because, when all is over, the victors will pass out that\r\nway, crowned, and with triumphal escort and ceremonies.\r\n\r\nAt the west end the balcony encloses the course in the form of a half\r\ncircle, and is made to uphold two great galleries.\r\n\r\nDirectly behind the balustrade on the coping of the balcony is the\r\nfirst seat, from which ascend the succeeding benches, each higher than\r\nthe one in front of it; giving to view a spectacle of surpassing\r\ninterest\xe2\x80\x94the spectacle of a vast space ruddy and glistening with human\r\nfaces, and rich with varicolored costumes.\r\n\r\nThe commonalty occupy quarters over in the west, beginning at the point\r\nof termination of an awning, stretched, it would seem, for the\r\naccommodation of the better classes exclusively.\r\n\r\nHaving thus the whole interior of the Circus under view at the moment\r\nof the sounding of the trumpets, let the reader next imagine the\r\nmultitude seated and sunk to sudden silence, and motionless in its\r\nintensity of interest.\r\n\r\nOut of the Porta Pompae over in the east rises a sound mixed of voices\r\nand instruments harmonized. Presently, forth issues the chorus of the\r\nprocession with which the celebration begins; the editor and civic\r\nauthorities of the city, givers of the games, follow in robes and\r\ngarlands; then the gods, some on platforms borne by men, others in\r\ngreat four-wheel carriages gorgeously decorated; next them, again, the\r\ncontestants of the day, each in costume exactly as he will run,\r\nwrestle, leap, box, or drive.\r\n\r\nSlowly crossing the arena, the procession proceeds to make circuit of\r\nthe course. The display is beautiful and imposing. Approval runs before\r\nit in a shout, as the water rises and swells in front of a boat in\r\nmotion. If the dumb, figured gods make no sign of appreciation of the\r\nwelcome, the editor and his associates are not so backward.\r\n\r\nThe reception of the athletes is even more demonstrative, for there is\r\nnot a man in the assemblage who has not something in wager upon them,\r\nthough but a mite or farthing. And it is noticeable, as the classes\r\nmove by, that the favorites among them are speedily singled out: either\r\ntheir names are loudest in the uproar, or they are more profusely\r\nshowered with wreaths and garlands tossed to them from the balcony.\r\n\r\nIf there is a question as to the popularity with the public of the\r\nseveral games, it is now put to rest. To the splendor of the chariots\r\nand the superexcellent beauty of the horses, the charioteers add the\r\npersonality necessary to perfect the charm of their display. Their\r\ntunics, short, sleeveless, and of the finest woollen texture, are of\r\nthe assigned colors. A horseman accompanies each one of them except\r\nBen-Hur, who, for some reason\xe2\x80\x94possibly distrust\xe2\x80\x94has chosen to go alone;\r\nso, too, they are all helmeted but him. As they approach, the\r\nspectators stand upon the benches, and there is a sensible deepening of\r\nthe clamor, in which a sharp listener may detect the shrill piping of\r\nwomen and children; at the same time, the things roseate flying from\r\nthe balcony thicken into a storm, and, striking the men, drop into the\r\nchariot-beds, which are threatened with filling to the tops. Even the\r\nhorses have a share in the ovation; nor may it be said they are less\r\nconscious than their masters of the honors they receive.\r\n\r\nVery soon, as with the other contestants, it is made apparent that some\r\nof the drivers are more in favor than others; and then the discovery\r\nfollows that nearly every individual on the benches, women and children\r\nas well as men, wears a color, most frequently a ribbon upon the breast\r\nor in the hair: now it is green, now yellow, now blue; but, searching\r\nthe great body carefully, it is manifest that there is a preponderance\r\nof white, and scarlet and gold.\r\n\r\nIn a modern assemblage called together as this one is, particularly\r\nwhere there are sums at hazard upon the race, a preference would be\r\ndecided by the qualities or performance of the horses; here, however,\r\nnationality was the rule. If the Byzantine and Sidonian found small\r\nsupport, it was because their cities were scarcely represented on the\r\nbenches. On their side, the Greeks, though very numerous, were divided\r\nbetween the Corinthian and the Athenian, leaving but a scant showing of\r\ngreen and yellow. Messala\xe2\x80\x99s scarlet and gold would have been but little\r\nbetter had not the citizens of Antioch, proverbially a race of\r\ncourtiers, joined the Romans by adopting the color of their favorite.\r\nThere were left then the country people, or Syrians, the Jews, and the\r\nArabs; and they, from faith in the blood of the sheik\xe2\x80\x99s four, blent\r\nlargely with hate of the Romans, whom they desired, above all things,\r\nto see beaten and humbled, mounted the white, making the most noisy,\r\nand probably the most numerous, faction of all.\r\n\r\nAs the charioteers move on in the circuit, the excitement increases; at\r\nthe second goal, where, especially in the galleries, the white is the\r\nruling color, the people exhaust their flowers and rive the air with\r\nscreams.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessala! Messala!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBen-Hur! Ben-Hur!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch are the cries.\r\n\r\nUpon the passage of the procession, the factionists take their seats\r\nand resume conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, by Bacchus! was he not handsome?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaims a woman, whose Romanism\r\nis betrayed by the colors flying in her hair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how splendid his chariot!\xe2\x80\x9d replies a neighbor, of the same\r\nproclivities. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is all ivory and gold. Jupiter grant he wins!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe notes on the bench behind them were entirely different.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred shekels on the Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice is high and shrill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, be thou not rash,\xe2\x80\x9d whispers a moderating friend to the speaker.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe children of Jacob are not much given to Gentile sports, which are\r\ntoo often accursed in the sight of the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, but saw you ever one more cool and assured? And what an arm he\r\nhas!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what horses!\xe2\x80\x9d says a third.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for that,\xe2\x80\x9d a fourth one adds, \xe2\x80\x9cthey say he has all the tricks of\r\nthe Romans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA woman completes the eulogium:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he is even handsomer than the Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus encouraged, the enthusiast shrieks again, \xe2\x80\x9cA hundred shekels on\r\nthe Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou fool!\xe2\x80\x9d answers an Antiochian, from a bench well forward on the\r\nbalcony. \xe2\x80\x9cKnowest thou not there are fifty talents laid against him,\r\nsix to one, on Messala? Put up thy shekels, lest Abraham rise and smite\r\nthee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha! thou ass of Antioch! Cease thy bray. Knowest thou not it was\r\nMessala betting on himself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch the reply.\r\n\r\nAnd so ran the controversy, not always good-natured.\r\n\r\nWhen at length the march was ended and the Porta Pompae received back\r\nthe procession, Ben-Hur knew he had his prayer.\r\n\r\nThe eyes of the East were upon his contest with Messala.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout three o\xe2\x80\x99clock, speaking in modern style, the program was\r\nconcluded except the chariot-race. The editor, wisely considerate of\r\nthe comfort of the people, chose that time for a recess. At once the\r\nvomitoria were thrown open, and all who could hastened to the portico\r\noutside where the restaurateurs had their quarters. Those who remained\r\nyawned, talked, gossiped, consulted their tablets, and, all\r\ndistinctions else forgotten, merged into but two classes\xe2\x80\x94the winners,\r\nwho were happy, and the losers, who were grum and captious.\r\n\r\nNow, however, a third class of spectators, composed of citizens who\r\ndesired only to witness the chariot-race, availed themselves of the\r\nrecess to come in and take their reserved seats; by so doing they\r\nthought to attract the least attention and give the least offence.\r\nAmong these were Simonides and his party, whose places were in the\r\nvicinity of the main entrance on the north side, opposite the consul.\r\n\r\nAs the four stout servants carried the merchant in his chair up the\r\naisle, curiosity was much excited. Presently some one called his name.\r\nThose about caught it and passed it on along the benches to the west;\r\nand there was hurried climbing on seats to get sight of the man about\r\nwhom common report had coined and put in circulation a romance so mixed\r\nof good fortune and bad that the like had never been known or heard of\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\nIlderim was also recognized and warmly greeted; but nobody knew\r\nBalthasar or the two women who followed him closely veiled.\r\n\r\nThe people made way for the party respectfully, and the ushers seated\r\nthem in easy speaking distance of each other down by the balustrade\r\noverlooking the arena. In providence of comfort, they sat upon cushions\r\nand had stools for footrests.\r\n\r\nThe women were Iras and Esther.\r\n\r\nUpon being seated, the latter cast a frightened look over the Circus,\r\nand drew the veil closer about her face; while the Egyptian, letting\r\nher veil fall upon her shoulders, gave herself to view, and gazed at\r\nthe scene with the seeming unconsciousness of being stared at, which,\r\nin a woman, is usually the result of long social habitude.\r\n\r\nThe new-comers generally were yet making their first examination of the\r\ngreat spectacle, beginning with the consul and his attendants, when\r\nsome workmen ran in and commenced to stretch a chalked rope across the\r\narena from balcony to balcony in front of the pillars of the first\r\ngoal.\r\n\r\nAbout the same time, also, six men came in through the Porta Pompae and\r\ntook post, one in front of each occupied stall; whereat there was a\r\nprolonged hum of voices in every quarter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, see! The green goes to number four on the right; the Athenian is\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Messala\xe2\x80\x94yes, he is in number two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Corinthian\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWatch the white! See, he crosses over, he stops; number one it\r\nis\xe2\x80\x94number one on the left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the black stops there, and the white at number two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese gate-keepers, it should be understood, were dressed in tunics\r\ncolored like those of the competing charioteers; so, when they took\r\ntheir stations, everybody knew the particular stall in which his\r\nfavorite was that moment waiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see Messala?\xe2\x80\x9d the Egyptian asked Esther.\r\n\r\nThe Jewess shuddered as she answered no. If not her father\xe2\x80\x99s enemy, the\r\nRoman was Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is beautiful as Apollo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Iras spoke, her large eyes brightened and she shook her jeweled fan.\r\nEsther looked at her with the thought, \xe2\x80\x9cIs he, then, so much handsomer\r\nthan Ben-Hur?\xe2\x80\x9d Next moment she heard Ilderim say to her father, \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\r\nhis stall is number two on the left of the Porta Pompae;\xe2\x80\x9d and, thinking\r\nit was of Ben-Hur he spoke, her eyes turned that way. Taking but the\r\nbriefest glance at the wattled face of the gate, she drew the veil\r\nclose and muttered a little prayer.\r\n\r\nPresently Sanballat came to the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am just from the stalls, O sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, bowing gravely to\r\nIlderim, who began combing his beard, while his eyes glittered with\r\neager inquiry. \xe2\x80\x9cThe horses are in perfect condition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim replied simply, \xe2\x80\x9cIf they are beaten, I pray it be by some other\r\nthan Messala.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTurning then to Simonides, Sanballat drew out a tablet, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nbring you also something of interest. I reported, you will remember,\r\nthe wager concluded with Messala last night, and stated that I left\r\nanother which, if taken, was to be delivered to me in writing to-day\r\nbefore the race began. Here it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides took the tablet and read the memorandum carefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ctheir emissary came to ask me if you had so much money\r\nwith me. Keep the tablet close. If you lose, you know where to come; if\r\nyou win\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94his face knit hard\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif you win\xe2\x80\x94ah, friend, see to it! See the\r\nsigners escape not; hold them to the last shekel. That is what they\r\nwould with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the purveyor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you not sit with us?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very good,\xe2\x80\x9d the other returned; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if I leave the consul,\r\nyoung Rome yonder will boil over. Peace to you; peace to all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt length the recess came to an end.\r\n\r\nThe trumpeters blew a call at which the absentees rushed back to their\r\nplaces. At the same time, some attendants appeared in the arena, and,\r\nclimbing upon the division wall, went to an entablature near the second\r\ngoal at the west end, and placed upon it seven wooden balls; then\r\nreturning to the first goal, upon an entablature there they set up\r\nseven other pieces of wood hewn to represent dolphins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall they do with the balls and fishes, O sheik?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nBalthasar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHast thou never attended a race?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever before; and hardly know I why I am here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they are to keep the count. At the end of each round run thou\r\nshalt see one ball and one fish taken down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe preparations were now complete, and presently a trumpeter in gaudy\r\nuniform arose by the editor, ready to blow the signal of commencement\r\npromptly at his order. Straightway the stir of the people and the hum\r\nof their conversation died away. Every face near-by, and every face in\r\nthe lessening perspective, turned to the east, as all eyes settled upon\r\nthe gates of the six stalls which shut in the competitors.\r\n\r\nThe unusual flush upon his face gave proof that even Simonides had\r\ncaught the universal excitement. Ilderim pulled his beard fast and\r\nfurious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook now for the Roman,\xe2\x80\x9d said the fair Egyptian to Esther, who did not\r\nhear her, for, with close-drawn veil and beating heart, she sat\r\nwatching for Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nThe structure containing the stalls, it should be observed, was in form\r\nof the segment of a circle, retired on the right so that its central\r\npoint was projected forward, and midway the course, on the starting\r\nside of the first goal. Every stall, consequently, was equally distant\r\nfrom the starting-line or chalked rope above mentioned.\r\n\r\nThe trumpet sounded short and sharp; whereupon the starters, one for\r\neach chariot, leaped down from behind the pillars of the goal, ready to\r\ngive assistance if any of the fours proved unmanageable.\r\n\r\nAgain the trumpet blew, and simultaneously the gate-keepers threw the\r\nstalls open.\r\n\r\nFirst appeared the mounted attendants of the charioteers, five in all,\r\nBen-Hur having rejected the service. The chalked line was lowered to\r\nlet them pass, then raised again. They were beautifully mounted, yet\r\nscarcely observed as they rode forward; for all the time the trampling\r\nof eager horses, and the voices of drivers scarcely less eager, were\r\nheard behind in the stalls, so that one might not look away an instant\r\nfrom the gaping doors.\r\n\r\nThe chalked line up again, the gate-keepers called their men; instantly\r\nthe ushers on the balcony waved their hands, and shouted with all their\r\nstrength, \xe2\x80\x9cDown! down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs well have whistled to stay a storm.\r\n\r\nForth from each stall, like missiles in a volley from so many great\r\nguns, rushed the six fours; and up the vast assemblage arose,\r\nelectrified and irrepressible, and, leaping upon the benches, filled\r\nthe Circus and the air above it with yells and screams. This was the\r\ntime for which they had so patiently waited!\xe2\x80\x94this the moment of supreme\r\ninterest treasured up in talk and dreams since the proclamation of the\r\ngames!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is come\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x94look!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Iras, pointing to Messala.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Esther, looking at Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nThe veil was withdrawn. For an instant the little Jewess was brave. An\r\nidea of the joy there is in doing an heroic deed under the eyes of a\r\nmultitude came to her, and she understood ever after how, at such\r\ntimes, the souls of men, in the frenzy of performance, laugh at death\r\nor forget it utterly.\r\n\r\nThe competitors were now under view from nearly every part of the\r\nCircus, yet the race was not begun; they had first to make the chalked\r\nline successfully.\r\n\r\nThe line was stretched for the purpose of equalizing the start. If it\r\nwere dashed upon, discomfiture of man and horses might be apprehended;\r\non the other hand, to approach it timidly was to incur the hazard of\r\nbeing thrown behind in the beginning of the race; and that was certain\r\nforfeit of the great advantage always striven for\xe2\x80\x94the position next the\r\ndivision wall on the inner line of the course.\r\n\r\nThis trial, its perils and consequences, the spectators knew\r\nthoroughly; and if the opinion of old Nestor, uttered that time he\r\nhanded the reins to his son, were true\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not strength, but art, obtained the prize,\r\nAnd to be swift is less than to be wise\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\nall on the benches might well look for warning of the winner to be now\r\ngiven, justifying the interest with which they breathlessly watched for\r\nthe result.\r\n\r\nThe arena swam in a dazzle of light; yet each driver looked first thing\r\nfor the rope, then for the coveted inner line. So, all six aiming at\r\nthe same point and speeding furiously, a collision seemed inevitable;\r\nnor that merely. What if the editor, at the last moment, dissatisfied\r\nwith the start, should withhold the signal to drop the rope? Or if he\r\nshould not give it in time?\r\n\r\nThe crossing was about two hundred and fifty feet in width. Quick the\r\neye, steady the hand, unerring the judgment required. If now one look\r\naway! or his mind wander! or a rein slip! And what attraction in the\r\nensemble of the thousands over the spreading balcony! Calculating upon\r\nthe natural impulse to give one glance\xe2\x80\x94just one\xe2\x80\x94in sooth of curiosity\r\nor vanity, malice might be there with an artifice; while friendship and\r\nlove, did they serve the same result, might be as deadly as malice.\r\n\r\nThe divine last touch in perfecting the beautiful is animation. Can we\r\naccept the saying, then these latter days, so tame in pastime and dull\r\nin sports, have scarcely anything to compare to the spectacle offered\r\nby the six contestants. Let the reader try to fancy it; let him first\r\nlook down upon the arena, and see it glistening in its frame of\r\ndull-gray granite walls; let him then, in this perfect field, see the\r\nchariots, light of wheel, very graceful, and ornate as paint and\r\nburnishing can make them\xe2\x80\x94Messala\xe2\x80\x99s rich with ivory and gold; let him\r\nsee the drivers, erect and statuesque, undisturbed by the motion of the\r\ncars, their limbs naked, and fresh and ruddy with the healthful polish\r\nof the baths\xe2\x80\x94in their right hands goads, suggestive of torture dreadful\r\nto the thought\xe2\x80\x94in their left hands, held in careful separation, and\r\nhigh, that they may not interfere with view of the steeds, the reins\r\npassing taut from the fore ends of the carriage-poles; let him see the\r\nfours, chosen for beauty as well as speed; let him see them in\r\nmagnificent action, their masters not more conscious of the situation\r\nand all that is asked and hoped from them\xe2\x80\x94their heads tossing, nostrils\r\nin play, now distent, now contracted\xe2\x80\x94limbs too dainty for the sand\r\nwhich they touch but to spurn\xe2\x80\x94limbs slender, yet with impact crushing\r\nas hammers\xe2\x80\x94every muscle of the rounded bodies instinct with glorious\r\nlife, swelling, diminishing, justifying the world in taking from them\r\nits ultimate measure of force; finally, along with chariots, drivers,\r\nhorses, let the reader see the accompanying shadows fly; and, with such\r\ndistinctness as the picture comes, he may share the satisfaction and\r\ndeeper pleasure of those to whom it was a thrilling fact, not a feeble\r\nfancy. Every age has its plenty of sorrows; Heaven help where there are\r\nno pleasures!\r\n\r\nThe competitors having started each on the shortest line for the\r\nposition next the wall, yielding would be like giving up the race; and\r\nwho dared yield? It is not in common nature to change a purpose in\r\nmid-career; and the cries of encouragement from the balcony were\r\nindistinguishable and indescribable: a roar which had the same effect\r\nupon all the drivers.\r\n\r\nThe fours neared the rope together. Then the trumpeter by the editor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside blew a signal vigorously. Twenty feet away it was not heard.\r\nSeeing the action, however, the judges dropped the rope, and not an\r\ninstant too soon, for the hoof of one of Messala\xe2\x80\x99s horses struck it as\r\nit fell. Nothing daunted, the Roman shook out his long lash, loosed the\r\nreins, leaned forward, and, with a triumphant shout, took the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJove with us! Jove with us!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled all the Roman faction, in a frenzy\r\nof delight.\r\n\r\nAs Messala turned in, the bronze lion\xe2\x80\x99s head at the end of his axle\r\ncaught the fore-leg of the Athenian\xe2\x80\x99s right-hand trace-mate, flinging\r\nthe brute over against its yoke-fellow. Both staggered, struggled, and\r\nlost their headway. The ushers had their will at least in part. The\r\nthousands held their breath with horror; only up where the consul sat\r\nwas there shouting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJove with us!\xe2\x80\x9d screamed Drusus, frantically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wins! Jove with us!\xe2\x80\x9d answered his associates, seeing Messala speed\r\non.\r\n\r\nTablet in hand, Sanballat turned to them; a crash from the course below\r\nstopped his speech, and he could not but look that way.\r\n\r\nMessala having passed, the Corinthian was the only contestant on the\r\nAthenian\xe2\x80\x99s right, and to that side the latter tried to turn his broken\r\nfour; and then; as ill-fortune would have it, the wheel of the\r\nByzantine, who was next on the left, struck the tail-piece of his\r\nchariot, knocking his feet from under him. There was a crash, a scream\r\nof rage and fear, and the unfortunate Cleanthes fell under the hoofs of\r\nhis own steeds: a terrible sight, against which Esther covered her\r\neyes.\r\n\r\nOn swept the Corinthian, on the Byzantine, on the Sidonian.\r\n\r\nSanballat looked for Ben-Hur, and turned again to Drusus and his\r\ncoterie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred sestertii on the Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTaken!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Drusus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother hundred on the Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Sanballat.\r\n\r\nNobody appeared to hear him. He called again; the situation below was\r\ntoo absorbing, and they were too busy shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cMessala! Messala! Jove\r\nwith us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the Jewess ventured to look again, a party of workmen were\r\nremoving the horses and broken car; another party were taking off the\r\nman himself; and every bench upon which there was a Greek was vocal\r\nwith execrations and prayers for vengeance. Suddenly she dropped her\r\nhands; Ben-Hur, unhurt, was to the front, coursing freely forward along\r\nwith the Roman! Behind them, in a group, followed the Sidonian, the\r\nCorinthian, and the Byzantine.\r\n\r\nThe race was on; the souls of the racers were in it; over them bent the\r\nmyriads.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the dash for position began, Ben-Hur, as we have seen, was on the\r\nextreme left of the six. For a moment, like the others, he was half\r\nblinded by the light in the arena; yet he managed to catch sight of his\r\nantagonists and divine their purpose. At Messala, who was more than an\r\nantagonist to him, he gave one searching look. The air of passionless\r\nhauteur characteristic of the fine patrician face was there as of old,\r\nand so was the Italian beauty, which the helmet rather increased; but\r\nmore\xe2\x80\x94it may have been a jealous fancy, or the effect of the brassy\r\nshadow in which the features were at the moment cast, still the\r\nIsraelite thought he saw the soul of the man as through a glass,\r\ndarkly: cruel, cunning, desperate; not so excited as determined\xe2\x80\x94a soul\r\nin a tension of watchfulness and fierce resolve.\r\n\r\nIn a time not longer than was required to turn to his four again,\r\nBen-Hur felt his own resolution harden to a like temper. At whatever\r\ncost, at all hazards, he would humble this enemy! Prize, friends,\r\nwagers, honor\xe2\x80\x94everything that can be thought of as a possible interest\r\nin the race was lost in the one deliberate purpose. Regard for life\r\neven should not hold him back. Yet there was no passion, on his part;\r\nno blinding rush of heated blood from heart to brain, and back again;\r\nno impulse to fling himself upon Fortune: he did not believe in\r\nFortune; far otherwise. He had his plan, and, confiding in himself, he\r\nsettled to the task never more observant, never more capable. The air\r\nabout him seemed aglow with a renewed and perfect transparency.\r\n\r\nWhen not half-way across the arena, he saw that Messala\xe2\x80\x99s rush would,\r\nif there was no collision, and the rope fell, give him the wall; that\r\nthe rope would fall, he ceased as soon to doubt; and, further, it came\r\nto him, a sudden flash-like insight, that Messala knew it was to be let\r\ndrop at the last moment (prearrangement with the editor could safely\r\nreach that point in the contest); and it suggested, what more\r\nRoman-like than for the official to lend himself to a countryman who,\r\nbesides being so popular, had also so much at stake? There could be no\r\nother accounting for the confidence with which Messala pushed his four\r\nforward the instant his competitors were prudentially checking their\r\nfours in front of the obstruction\xe2\x80\x94no other except madness.\r\n\r\nIt is one thing to see a necessity and another to act upon it. Ben-Hur\r\nyielded the wall for the time.\r\n\r\nThe rope fell, and all the fours but his sprang into the course under\r\nurgency of voice and lash. He drew head to the right, and, with all the\r\nspeed of his Arabs, darted across the trails of his opponents, the\r\nangle of movement being such as to lose the least time and gain the\r\ngreatest possible advance. So, while the spectators were shivering at\r\nthe Athenian\xe2\x80\x99s mishap, and the Sidonian, Byzantine, and Corinthian were\r\nstriving, with such skill as they possessed, to avoid involvement in\r\nthe ruin, Ben-Hur swept around and took the course neck and neck with\r\nMessala, though on the outside. The marvellous skill shown in making\r\nthe change thus from the extreme left across to the right without\r\nappreciable loss did not fail the sharp eyes upon the benches; the\r\nCircus seemed to rock and rock again with prolonged applause. Then\r\nEsther clasped her hands in glad surprise; then Sanballat, smiling,\r\noffered his hundred sestertii a second time without a taker; and then\r\nthe Romans began to doubt, thinking Messala might have found an equal,\r\nif not a master, and that in an Israelite!\r\n\r\nAnd now, racing together side by side, a narrow interval between them,\r\nthe two neared the second goal.\r\n\r\nThe pedestal of the three pillars there, viewed from the west, was a\r\nstone wall in the form of a half-circle, around which the course and\r\nopposite balcony were bent in exact parallelism. Making this turn was\r\nconsidered in all respects the most telling test of a charioteer; it\r\nwas, in fact, the very feat in which Oraetes failed. As an involuntary\r\nadmission of interest on the part of the spectators, a hush fell over\r\nall the Circus, so that for the first time in the race the rattle and\r\nclang of the cars plunging after the tugging steeds were distinctly\r\nheard. Then, it would seem, Messala observed Ben-Hur, and recognized\r\nhim; and at once the audacity of the man flamed out in an astonishing\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDown Eros, up Mars!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, whirling his lash with practised\r\nhand\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDown Eros, up Mars!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, and caught the well-doing Arabs\r\nof Ben-Hur a cut the like of which they had never known.\r\n\r\nThe blow was seen in every quarter, and the amazement was universal.\r\nThe silence deepened; up on the benches behind the consul the boldest\r\nheld his breath, waiting for the outcome. Only a moment thus: then,\r\ninvoluntarily, down from the balcony, as thunder falls, burst the\r\nindignant cry of the people.\r\n\r\nThe four sprang forward affrighted. No hand had ever been laid upon\r\nthem except in love; they had been nurtured ever so tenderly; and as\r\nthey grew, their confidence in man became a lesson to men beautiful to\r\nsee. What should such dainty natures do under such indignity but leap\r\nas from death?\r\n\r\nForward they sprang as with one impulse, and forward leaped the car.\r\nPast question, every experience is serviceable to us. Where got Ben-Hur\r\nthe large hand and mighty grip which helped him now so well? Where but\r\nfrom the oar with which so long he fought the sea? And what was this\r\nspring of the floor under his feet to the dizzy eccentric lurch with\r\nwhich in the old time the trembling ship yielded to the beat of\r\nstaggering billows, drunk with their power? So he kept his place, and\r\ngave the four free rein, and called to them in soothing voice, trying\r\nmerely to guide them round the dangerous turn; and before the fever of\r\nthe people began to abate, he had back the mastery. Nor that only: on\r\napproaching the first goal, he was again side by side with Messala,\r\nbearing with him the sympathy and admiration of every one not a Roman.\r\nSo clearly was the feeling shown, so vigorous its manifestation, that\r\nMessala, with all his boldness, felt it unsafe to trifle further.\r\n\r\nAs the cars whirled round the goal, Esther caught sight of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface\xe2\x80\x94a little pale, a little higher raised, otherwise calm, even\r\nplacid.\r\n\r\nImmediately a man climbed on the entablature at the west end of the\r\ndivision wall, and took down one of the conical wooden balls. A dolphin\r\non the east entablature was taken down at the same time.\r\n\r\nIn like manner, the second ball and second dolphin disappeared.\r\n\r\nAnd then the third ball and third dolphin.\r\n\r\nThree rounds concluded: still Messala held the inside position; still\r\nBen-Hur moved with him side by side; still the other competitors\r\nfollowed as before. The contest began to have the appearance of one of\r\nthe double races which became so popular in Rome during the later\r\nCaesarean period\xe2\x80\x94Messala and Ben-Hur in the first, the Corinthian,\r\nSidonian, and Byzantine in the second. Meantime the ushers succeeded in\r\nreturning the multitude to their seats, though the clamor continued to\r\nrun the rounds, keeping, as it were, even pace with the rivals in the\r\ncourse below.\r\n\r\nIn the fifth round the Sidonian succeeded in getting a place outside\r\nBen-Hur, but lost it directly.\r\n\r\nThe sixth round was entered upon without change of relative position.\r\n\r\nGradually the speed had been quickened\xe2\x80\x94gradually the blood of the\r\ncompetitors warmed with the work. Men and beasts seemed to know alike\r\nthat the final crisis was near, bringing the time for the winner to\r\nassert himself.\r\n\r\nThe interest which from the beginning had centred chiefly in the\r\nstruggle between the Roman and the Jew, with an intense and general\r\nsympathy for the latter, was fast changing to anxiety on his account.\r\nOn all the benches the spectators bent forward motionless, except as\r\ntheir faces turned following the contestants. Ilderim quitted combing\r\nhis beard, and Esther forgot her fears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred sestertii on the Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Sanballat to the Romans under\r\nthe consul\xe2\x80\x99s awning.\r\n\r\nThere was no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA talent\xe2\x80\x94or five talents, or ten; choose ye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shook his tablets at them defiantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will take thy sestertii,\xe2\x80\x9d answered a Roman youth, preparing to\r\nwrite.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not so,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed a friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessala hath reached his utmost speed. See him lean over his chariot\r\nrim, the reins loose as flying ribbons. Look then at the Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe first one looked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Hercules!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, his countenance falling. \xe2\x80\x9cThe dog throws all\r\nhis weight on the bits. I see, I see! If the gods help not our friend,\r\nhe will be run away with by the Israelite. No, not yet. Look! Jove with\r\nus, Jove with us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cry, swelled by every Latin tongue, shook the velaria over the\r\nconsul\xe2\x80\x99s head.\r\n\r\nIf it were true that Messala had attained his utmost speed, the effort\r\nwas with effect; slowly but certainly he was beginning to forge ahead.\r\nHis horses were running with their heads low down; from the balcony\r\ntheir bodies appeared actually to skim the earth; their nostrils showed\r\nblood red in expansion; their eyes seemed straining in their sockets.\r\nCertainly the good steeds were doing their best! How long could they\r\nkeep the pace? It was but the commencement of the sixth round. On they\r\ndashed. As they neared the second goal, Ben-Hur turned in behind the\r\nRoman\xe2\x80\x99s car.\r\n\r\nThe joy of the Messala faction reached its bound: they screamed and\r\nhowled, and tossed their colors; and Sanballat filled his tablets with\r\nwagers of their tendering.\r\n\r\nMalluch, in the lower gallery over the Gate of Triumph, found it hard\r\nto keep his cheer. He had cherished the vague hint dropped to him by\r\nBen-Hur of something to happen in the turning of the western pillars.\r\nIt was the fifth round, yet the something had not come; and he had said\r\nto himself, the sixth will bring it; but, lo! Ben-Hur was hardly\r\nholding a place at the tail of his enemy\xe2\x80\x99s car.\r\n\r\nOver in the east end, Simonides\xe2\x80\x99 party held their peace. The merchant\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhead was bent low. Ilderim tugged at his beard, and dropped his brows\r\ntill there was nothing of his eyes but an occasional sparkle of light.\r\nEsther scarcely breathed. Iras alone appeared glad.\r\n\r\nAlong the home-stretch\xe2\x80\x94sixth round\xe2\x80\x94Messala leading, next him Ben-Hur,\r\nand so close it was the old story:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst flew Eumelus on Pheretian steeds;\r\nWith those of Tros bold Diomed succeeds;\r\nClose on Eumelus\xe2\x80\x99 back they puff the wind,\r\nAnd seem just mounting on his car behind;\r\nFull on his neck he feels the sultry breeze,\r\nAnd, hovering o\xe2\x80\x99er, their stretching shadow sees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThus to the first goal, and round it. Messala, fearful of losing his\r\nplace, hugged the stony wall with perilous clasp; a foot to the left,\r\nand he had been dashed to pieces; yet, when the turn was finished, no\r\nman, looking at the wheel-tracks of the two cars, could have said, here\r\nwent Messala, there the Jew. They left but one trace behind them.\r\n\r\nAs they whirled by, Esther saw Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face again, and it was whiter\r\nthan before.\r\n\r\nSimonides, shrewder than Esther, said to Ilderim, the moment the rivals\r\nturned into the course, \xe2\x80\x9cI am no judge, good sheik, if Ben-Hur be not\r\nabout to execute some design. His face hath that look.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo which Ilderim answered, \xe2\x80\x9cSaw you how clean they were and fresh? By\r\nthe splendor of God, friend, they have not been running! But now\r\nwatch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne ball and one dolphin remained on the entablatures; and all the\r\npeople drew a long breath, for the beginning of the end was at hand.\r\n\r\nFirst, the Sidonian gave the scourge to his four, and, smarting with\r\nfear and pain, they dashed desperately forward, promising for a brief\r\ntime to go to the front. The effort ended in promise. Next, the\r\nByzantine and the Corinthian each made the trial with like result,\r\nafter which they were practically out of the race. Thereupon, with a\r\nreadiness perfectly explicable, all the factions except the Romans\r\njoined hope in Ben-Hur, and openly indulged their feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBen-Hur! Ben-Hur!\xe2\x80\x9d they shouted, and the blent voices of the many\r\nrolled overwhelmingly against the consular stand.\r\n\r\nFrom the benches above him as he passed, the favor descended in fierce\r\ninjunctions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeed thee, Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake the wall now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn! loose the Arabs! Give them rein and scourge!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him not have the turn on thee again. Now or never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOver the balustrade they stooped low, stretching their hands\r\nimploringly to him.\r\n\r\nEither he did not hear, or could not do better, for halfway round the\r\ncourse and he was still following; at the second goal even still no\r\nchange!\r\n\r\nAnd now, to make the turn, Messala began to draw in his left-hand\r\nsteeds, an act which necessarily slackened their speed. His spirit was\r\nhigh; more than one altar was richer of his vows; the Roman genius was\r\nstill president. On the three pillars only six hundred feet away were\r\nfame, increase of fortune, promotions, and a triumph ineffably\r\nsweetened by hate, all in store for him! That moment Malluch, in the\r\ngallery, saw Ben-Hur lean forward over his Arabs, and give them the\r\nreins. Out flew the many-folded lash in his hand; over the backs of the\r\nstartled steeds it writhed and hissed, and hissed and writhed again and\r\nagain; and though it fell not, there were both sting and menace in its\r\nquick report; and as the man passed thus from quiet to resistless\r\naction, his face suffused, his eyes gleaming, along the reins he seemed\r\nto flash his will; and instantly not one, but the four as one, answered\r\nwith a leap that landed them alongside the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s car. Messala, on the\r\nperilous edge of the goal, heard, but dared not look to see what the\r\nawakening portended. From the people he received no sign. Above the\r\nnoises of the race there was but one voice, and that was Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s. In\r\nthe old Aramaic, as the sheik himself, he called to the Arabs,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn, Atair! On, Rigel! What, Antares! dost thou linger now? Good\r\nhorse\xe2\x80\x94oho, Aldebaran! I hear them singing in the tents. I hear the\r\nchildren singing and the women\xe2\x80\x94singing of the stars, of Atair, Antares,\r\nRigel, Aldebaran, victory!\xe2\x80\x94and the song will never end. Well done! Home\r\nto-morrow, under the black tent\xe2\x80\x94home! On, Antares! The tribe is waiting\r\nfor us, and the master is waiting! \xe2\x80\x99Tis done! \xe2\x80\x99tis done! Ha, ha! We\r\nhave overthrown the proud. The hand that smote us is in the dust. Ours\r\nthe glory! Ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x94steady! The work is done\xe2\x80\x94soho! Rest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere had never been anything of the kind more simple; seldom anything\r\nso instantaneous.\r\n\r\nAt the moment chosen for the dash, Messala was moving in a circle round\r\nthe goal. To pass him, Ben-Hur had to cross the track, and good\r\nstrategy required the movement to be in a forward direction; that is,\r\non a like circle limited to the least possible increase. The thousands\r\non the benches understood it all: they saw the signal given\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nmagnificent response; the four close outside Messala\xe2\x80\x99s outer wheel;\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s inner wheel behind the other\xe2\x80\x99s car\xe2\x80\x94all this they saw. Then\r\nthey heard a crash loud enough to send a thrill through the Circus,\r\nand, quicker than thought, out over the course a spray of shining white\r\nand yellow flinders flew. Down on its right side toppled the bed of the\r\nRoman\xe2\x80\x99s chariot. There was a rebound as of the axle hitting the hard\r\nearth; another and another; then the car went to pieces; and Messala,\r\nentangled in the reins, pitched forward headlong.\r\n\r\nTo increase the horror of the sight by making death certain, the\r\nSidonian, who had the wall next behind, could not stop or turn out.\r\nInto the wreck full speed he drove; then over the Roman, and into the\r\nlatter\xe2\x80\x99s four, all mad with fear. Presently, out of the turmoil, the\r\nfighting of horses, the resound of blows, the murky cloud of dust and\r\nsand, he crawled, in time to see the Corinthian and Byzantine go on\r\ndown the course after Ben-Hur, who had not been an instant delayed.\r\n\r\nThe people arose, and leaped upon the benches, and shouted and\r\nscreamed. Those who looked that way caught glimpses of Messala, now\r\nunder the trampling of the fours, now under the abandoned cars. He was\r\nstill; they thought him dead; but far the greater number followed\r\nBen-Hur in his career. They had not seen the cunning touch of the reins\r\nby which, turning a little to the left, he caught Messala\xe2\x80\x99s wheel with\r\nthe iron-shod point of his axle, and crushed it; but they had seen the\r\ntransformation of the man, and themselves felt the heat and glow of his\r\nspirit, the heroic resolution, the maddening energy of action with\r\nwhich, by look, word, and gesture, he so suddenly inspired his Arabs.\r\nAnd such running! It was rather the long leaping of lions in harness;\r\nbut for the lumbering chariot, it seemed the four were flying. When the\r\nByzantine and Corinthian were halfway down the course, Ben-Hur turned\r\nthe first goal.\r\n\r\nAND THE RACE WAS WON!\r\n\r\nThe consul arose; the people shouted themselves hoarse; the editor came\r\ndown from his seat, and crowned the victors.\r\n\r\nThe fortunate man among the boxers was a low-browed, yellow-haired\r\nSaxon, of such brutalized face as to attract a second look from\r\nBen-Hur, who recognized a teacher with whom he himself had been a\r\nfavorite at Rome. From him the young Jew looked up and beheld Simonides\r\nand his party on the balcony. They waved their hands to him. Esther\r\nkept her seat; but Iras arose, and gave him a smile and a wave of her\r\nfan\xe2\x80\x94favors not the less intoxicating to him because we know, O reader,\r\nthey would have fallen to Messala had he been the victor.\r\n\r\nThe procession was then formed, and, midst the shouting of the\r\nmultitude which had had its will, passed out of the Gate of Triumph.\r\n\r\nAnd the day was over.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur tarried across the river with Ilderim; for at midnight, as\r\npreviously determined, they would take the road which the caravan, then\r\nthirty hours out, had pursued.\r\n\r\nThe sheik was happy; his offers of gifts had been royal; but Ben-Hur\r\nhad refused everything, insisting that he was satisfied with the\r\nhumiliation of his enemy. The generous dispute was long continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink,\xe2\x80\x9d the sheik would say, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat thou hast done for me. In every\r\nblack tent down to the Akaba and to the ocean, and across to the\r\nEuphrates, and beyond to the sea of the Scythians, the renown of my\r\nMira and her children will go; and they who sing of them will magnify\r\nme, and forget that I am in the wane of life; and all the spears now\r\nmasterless will come to me, and my sword-hands multiply past counting.\r\nThou dost not know what it is to have sway of the desert such as will\r\nnow be mine. I tell thee it will bring tribute incalculable from\r\ncommerce, and immunity from kings. Ay, by the sword of Solomon! doth my\r\nmessenger seek favor for me of Caesar, that will he get. Yet\r\nnothing\xe2\x80\x94nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Ben-Hur would answer,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, sheik, have I not thy hand and heart? Let thy increase of power\r\nand influence inure to the King who comes. Who shall say it was not\r\nallowed thee for him? In the work I am going to, I may have great need.\r\nSaying no now will leave me to ask of thee with better grace\r\nhereafter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the midst of a controversy of the kind, two messengers\r\narrived\xe2\x80\x94Malluch and one unknown. The former was admitted first.\r\n\r\nThe good fellow did not attempt to hide his joy over the event of the\r\nday.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, coming to that with which I am charged,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe master\r\nSimonides sends me to say that, upon the adjournment of the games, some\r\nof the Roman faction made haste to protest against payment of the money\r\nprize.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim started up, crying, in his shrillest tones,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the splendor of God! the East shall decide whether the race was\r\nfairly won.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, good sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch, \xe2\x80\x9cthe editor has paid the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen they said Ben-Hur struck Messala\xe2\x80\x99s wheel, the editor laughed, and\r\nreminded them of the blow the Arabs had at the turn of the goal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what of the Athenian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Ilderim. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat fortune these Roman monsters have!\r\nMessala escaped?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEscaped\xe2\x80\x94yes, O sheik, with life; but it shall be a burden to him. The\r\nphysicians say he will live, but never walk again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked silently up to heaven. He had a vision of Messala,\r\nchairbound like Simonides, and, like him, going abroad on the shoulders\r\nof servants. The good man had abode well; but what would this one with\r\nhis pride and ambition?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimonides bade me say, further,\xe2\x80\x9d Malluch continued, \xe2\x80\x9cSanballat is\r\nhaving trouble. Drusus, and those who signed with him, referred the\r\nquestion of paying the five talents they lost to the Consul Maxentius,\r\nand he has referred it to Caesar. Messala also refused his losses, and\r\nSanballat, in imitation of Drusus, went to the consul, where the matter\r\nis still in advisement. The better Romans say the protestants shall not\r\nbe excused; and all the adverse factions join with them. The city rings\r\nwith the scandal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat says Simonides?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe master laughs, and is well pleased. If the Roman pays, he is\r\nruined; if he refuses to pay, he is dishonored. The imperial policy\r\nwill decide the matter. To offend the East would be a bad beginning\r\nwith the Parthians; to offend Sheik Ilderim would be to antagonize the\r\nDesert, over which lie all Maxentius\xe2\x80\x99s lines of operation. Wherefore\r\nSimonides bade me tell you to have no disquiet; Messala will pay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim was at once restored to his good-humor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us be off now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rubbing his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cThe business will do\r\nwell with Simonides. The glory is ours. I will order the horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malluch. \xe2\x80\x9cI left a messenger outside. Will you see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the splendor of God! I forgot him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch retired, and was succeeded by a lad of gentle manners and\r\ndelicate appearance, who knelt upon one knee, and said, winningly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIras, the daughter of Balthasar, well known to good Sheik Ilderim,\r\nhath intrusted me with a message to the sheik, who, she saith, will do\r\nher great favor so he receive her congratulations on account of the\r\nvictory of his four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe daughter of my friend is kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ilderim, with sparkling eyes.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo thou give her this jewel, in sign of the pleasure I have from her\r\nmessage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took a ring from his finger as he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will as thou sayest, O sheik,\xe2\x80\x9d the lad replied, and continued, \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\ndaughter of the Egyptian charged me further. She prays the good Sheik\r\nIlderim to send word to the youth Ben-Hur that her father hath taken\r\nresidence for a time in the palace of Idernee, where she will receive\r\nthe youth after the fourth hour to-morrow. And if, with her\r\ncongratulations, Sheik Ilderim will accept her gratitude for this other\r\nfavor done, she will be ever so pleased.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sheik looked at Ben-Hur, whose face was suffused with pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy your leave, O sheik, I will see the fair Egyptian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIlderim laughed, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cShall not a man enjoy his youth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Ben-Hur answered the messenger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay to her who sent you that I, Ben-Hur, will see her at the palace of\r\nIdernee, wherever that may be, to-morrow at noon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe lad arose, and, with silent salute, departed.\r\n\r\nAt midnight Ilderim took the road, having arranged to leave a horse and\r\na guide for Ben-Hur, who was to follow him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\n\r\n\r\nGoing next day to fill his appointment with Iras, Ben-Hur turned from\r\nthe Omphalus, which was in the heart of the city, into the Colonnade of\r\nHerod, and came shortly to the palace of Idernee.\r\n\r\nFrom the street he passed first into a vestibule, on the sides of which\r\nwere stairways under cover, leading up to a portico. Winged lions sat\r\nby the stairs; in the middle there was a gigantic ibis spouting water\r\nover the floor; the lions, ibis, walls, and floor were reminders of the\r\nEgyptians: everything, even the balustrading of the stairs, was of\r\nmassive gray stone.\r\n\r\nAbove the vestibule, and covering the landing of the steps, arose the\r\nportico, a pillared grace, so light, so exquisitely proportioned, it\r\nwas at that period hardly possible of conception except by a Greek. Of\r\nmarble snowy white, its effect was that of a lily dropped carelessly\r\nupon a great bare rock.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur paused in the shade of the portico to admire its tracery and\r\nfinish, and the purity of its marble; then he passed on into the\r\npalace. Ample folding-doors stood open to receive him. The passage into\r\nwhich he first entered was high, but somewhat narrow; red tiling formed\r\nthe floor, and the walls were tinted to correspond. Yet this plainness\r\nwas a warning of something beautiful to come.\r\n\r\nHe moved on slowly, all his faculties in repose. Presently he would be\r\nin the presence of Iras; she was waiting for him; waiting with song and\r\nstory and badinage, sparkling, fanciful, capricious\xe2\x80\x94with smiles which\r\nglorified her glance, and glances which lent voluptuous suggestion to\r\nher whisper. She had sent for him the evening of the boat-ride on the\r\nlake in the Orchard of Palms; she had sent for him now; and he was\r\ngoing to her in the beautiful palace of Idernee. He was happy and\r\ndreamful rather than thoughtless.\r\n\r\nThe passage brought him to a closed door, in front of which he paused;\r\nand, as he did so, the broad leaves began to open of themselves,\r\nwithout creak or sound of lock or latch, or touch of foot or finger.\r\nThe singularity was lost in the view that broke upon him.\r\n\r\nStanding in the shade of the dull passage, and looking through the\r\ndoorway, he beheld the atrium of a Roman house, roomy and rich to a\r\nfabulous degree of magnificence.\r\n\r\nHow large the chamber was cannot be stated, because of the deceit there\r\nis in exact proportions; its depth was vista-like, something never to\r\nbe said of an equal interior. When he stopped to make survey, and\r\nlooked down upon the floor, he was standing upon the breast of a Leda,\r\nrepresented as caressing a swan; and, looking farther, he saw the whole\r\nfloor was similarly laid in mosaic pictures of mythological subjects.\r\nAnd there were stools and chairs, each a separate design, and a work of\r\nart exquisitely composed, and tables much carven, and here and there\r\ncouches which were invitations of themselves. The articles of\r\nfurniture, which stood out from the walls, were duplicated on the floor\r\ndistinctly as if they floated unrippled water; even the panelling of\r\nthe walls, the figures upon them in painting and bas-relief, and the\r\nfresco of the ceiling were reflected on the floor. The ceiling curved\r\nup towards the centre, where there was an opening through which the\r\nsunlight poured without hindrance, and the sky, ever so blue, seemed in\r\nhand-reach; the impluvium under the opening was guarded by bronzed\r\nrails; the gilded pillars supporting the roof at the edges of the\r\nopening shone like flame where the sun struck them, and their\r\nreflections beneath seemed to stretch to infinite depth. And there were\r\ncandelabra quaint and curious, and statuary and vases; the whole making\r\nan interior that would have befitted well the house on the Palatine\r\nHill which Cicero bought of Crassus, or that other, yet more famous for\r\nextravagance, the Tusculan villa of Scaurus.\r\n\r\nStill in his dreamful mood, Ben-Hur sauntered about, charmed by all he\r\nbeheld, and waiting. He did not mind a little delay; when Iras was\r\nready, she would come or send a servant. In every well-regulated Roman\r\nhouse the atrium was the reception chamber for visitors.\r\n\r\nTwice, thrice, he made the round. As often he stood under the opening\r\nin the roof, and pondered the sky and its azure depth; then, leaning\r\nagainst a pillar, he studied the distribution of light and shade, and\r\nits effects; here a veil diminishing objects, there a brilliance\r\nexaggerating others; yet nobody came. Time, or rather the passage of\r\ntime, began at length to impress itself upon him, and he wondered why\r\nIras stayed so long. Again he traced out the figures upon the floor,\r\nbut not with the satisfaction the first inspection gave him. He paused\r\noften to listen: directly impatience blew a little fevered breath upon\r\nhis spirit; next time it blew stronger and hotter; and at last he woke\r\nto a consciousness of the silence which held the house in thrall, and\r\nthe thought of it made him uneasy and distrustful. Still he put the\r\nfeeling off with a smile and a promise. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, she is giving the last\r\ntouch to her eyelids, or she is arranging a chaplet for me; she will\r\ncome presently, more beautiful of the delay!\xe2\x80\x9d He sat down then to\r\nadmire a candelabrum\xe2\x80\x94a bronze plinth on rollers, filigree on the sides\r\nand edges; the post at one end, and on the end opposite it an altar and\r\na female celebrant; the lamp-rests swinging by delicate chains from the\r\nextremities of drooping palm-branches; altogether a wonder in its way.\r\nBut the silence would obtrude itself: he listened even as he looked at\r\nthe pretty object\xe2\x80\x94he listened, but there was not a sound; the palace\r\nwas still as a tomb.\r\n\r\nThere might be a mistake. No, the messenger had come from the Egyptian,\r\nand this was the palace of Idernee. Then he remembered how mysteriously\r\nthe door had opened so soundlessly, so of itself. He would see!\r\n\r\nHe went to the same door. Though he walked ever so lightly the sound of\r\nhis stepping was loud and harsh, and he shrank from it. He was getting\r\nnervous. The cumbrous Roman lock resisted his first effort to raise it;\r\nand the second\xe2\x80\x94the blood chilled in his cheeks\xe2\x80\x94he wrenched with all his\r\nmight: in vain\xe2\x80\x94the door was not even shaken. A sense of danger seized\r\nhim, and for a moment he stood irresolute.\r\n\r\nWho in Antioch had the motive to do him harm?\r\n\r\nMessala!\r\n\r\nAnd this palace of Idernee? He had seen Egypt in the vestibule, Athens\r\nin the snowy portico; but here, in the atrium, was Rome; everything\r\nabout him betrayed Roman ownership. True, the site was on the great\r\nthoroughfare of the city, a very public place in which to do him\r\nviolence; but for that reason it was more accordant with the audacious\r\ngenius of his enemy. The atrium underwent a change; with all its\r\nelegance and beauty, it was no more than a trap. Apprehension always\r\npaints in black.\r\n\r\nThe idea irritated Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nThere were many doors on the right and left of the atrium, leading,\r\ndoubtless, to sleeping-chambers; he tried them, but they were all\r\nfirmly fastened. Knocking might bring response. Ashamed to make outcry,\r\nhe betook himself to a couch, and, lying down, tried to reflect.\r\n\r\nAll too plainly he was a prisoner; but for what purpose? and by whom?\r\n\r\nIf the work were Messala\xe2\x80\x99s! He sat up, looked about, and smiled\r\ndefiantly. There were weapons in every table. But birds had been\r\nstarved in golden cages; not so would he\xe2\x80\x94the couches would serve him as\r\nbattering-rams; and he was strong, and there was such increase of might\r\nin rage and despair!\r\n\r\nMessala himself could not come. He would never walk again; he was a\r\ncripple like Simonides; still he could move others. And where were\r\nthere not others to be moved by him? Ben-Hur arose, and tried the doors\r\nagain. Once he called out; the room echoed so that he was startled.\r\nWith such calmness as he could assume, he made up his mind to wait a\r\ntime before attempting to break a way out.\r\n\r\nIn such a situation the mind has its ebb and flow of disquiet, with\r\nintervals of peace between. At length\xe2\x80\x94how long, though, he could not\r\nhave said\xe2\x80\x94he came to the conclusion that the affair was an accident or\r\nmistake. The palace certainly belonged to somebody; it must have care\r\nand keeping: and the keeper would come; the evening or the night would\r\nbring him. Patience!\r\n\r\nSo concluding, he waited.\r\n\r\nHalf an hour passed\xe2\x80\x94a much longer period to Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x94when the door which\r\nhad admitted him opened and closed noiselessly as before, and without\r\nattracting his attention.\r\n\r\nThe moment of the occurrence he was sitting at the farther end of the\r\nroom. A footstep startled him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt last she has come!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, with a throb of relief and\r\npleasure, and arose.\r\n\r\nThe step was heavy, and accompanied with the gride and clang of coarse\r\nsandals. The gilded pillars were between him and the door; he advanced\r\nquietly, and leaned against one of them. Presently he heard voices\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nvoices of men\xe2\x80\x94one of them rough and guttural. What was said he could\r\nnot understand, as the language was not of the East or South of Europe.\r\n\r\nAfter a general survey of the room, the strangers crossed to their\r\nleft, and were brought into Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s view\xe2\x80\x94two men, one very stout,\r\nboth tall, and both in short tunics. They had not the air of masters of\r\nthe house or domestics. Everything they saw appeared wonderful to them;\r\neverything they stopped to examine they touched. They were vulgarians.\r\nThe atrium seemed profaned by their presence. At the same time, their\r\nleisurely manner and the assurance with which they proceeded pointed to\r\nsome right or business; if business, with whom?\r\n\r\nWith much jargon they sauntered this way and that, all the time\r\ngradually approaching the pillar by which Ben-Hur was standing. Off a\r\nlittle way, where a slanted gleam of the sun fell with a glare upon the\r\nmosaic of the floor, there was a statue which attracted their notice.\r\nIn examining it, they stopped in the light.\r\n\r\nThe mystery surrounding his own presence in the palace tended, as we\r\nhave seen, to make Ben-Hur nervous; so now, when in the tall stout\r\nstranger he recognized the Northman whom he had known in Rome, and seen\r\ncrowned only the day before in the Circus as the winning pugilist; when\r\nhe saw the man\xe2\x80\x99s face, scarred with the wounds of many battles, and\r\nimbruted by ferocious passions; when he surveyed the fellow\xe2\x80\x99s naked\r\nlimbs, very marvels of exercise and training, and his shoulders of\r\nHerculean breadth, a thought of personal danger started a chill along\r\nevery vein. A sure instinct warned him that the opportunity for murder\r\nwas too perfect to have come by chance; and here now were the\r\nmyrmidons, and their business was with him. He turned an anxious eye\r\nupon the Northman\xe2\x80\x99s comrade\xe2\x80\x94young, black-eyed, black-haired, and\r\naltogether Jewish in appearance; he observed, also, that both the men\r\nwere in costume exactly such as professionals of their class were in\r\nthe habit of wearing in the arena. Putting the several circumstances\r\ntogether, Ben-Hur could not be longer in doubt: he had been lured into\r\nthe palace with design. Out of reach of aid, in this splendid privacy,\r\nhe was to die!\r\n\r\nAt a loss what to do, he gazed from man to man, while there was enacted\r\nwithin him that miracle of mind by which life is passed before us in\r\nawful detail, to be looked at by ourselves as if it were another\xe2\x80\x99s; and\r\nfrom the evolvement, from a hidden depth, cast up, as it were, by a\r\nhidden hand, he was given to see that he had entered upon a new life,\r\ndifferent from the old one in this: whereas, in that, he had been the\r\nvictim of violences done to him, henceforth he was to be the aggressor.\r\nOnly yesterday he had found his first victim! To the purely Christian\r\nnature the presentation would have brought the weakness of remorse. Not\r\nso with Ben-Hur; his spirit had its emotions from the teachings of the\r\nfirst lawgiver, not the last and greatest one. He had dealt punishment,\r\nnot wrong, to Messala. By permission of the Lord, he had triumphed; and\r\nhe derived faith from the circumstance\xe2\x80\x94faith the source of all rational\r\nstrength, especially strength in peril.\r\n\r\nNor did the influence stop there. The new life was made appear to him a\r\nmission just begun, and holy as the King to come was holy, and certain\r\nas the coming of the King was certain\xe2\x80\x94a mission in which force was\r\nlawful if only because it was unavoidable. Should he, on the very\r\nthreshold of such an errand, be afraid?\r\n\r\nHe undid the sash around his waist, and, baring his head and casting\r\noff his white Jewish gown, stood forth in an undertunic not unlike\r\nthose of the enemy, and was ready, body and mind. Folding his arms, he\r\nplaced his back against the pillar, and calmly waited.\r\n\r\nThe examination of the statue was brief. Directly the Northman turned,\r\nand said something in the unknown tongue; then both looked at Ben-Hur.\r\nA few more words, and they advanced towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, in Latin.\r\n\r\nThe Northman fetched a smile which did not relieve his face of its\r\nbrutalism, and answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarbarians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the palace of Idernee. Whom seek you? Stand and answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words were spoken with earnestness. The strangers stopped; and in\r\nhis turn the Northman asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe giant laid his head back upon his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! I have heard how a god once came from a cow licking a\r\nsalted stone; but not even a god can make a Roman of a Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe laugh over, he spoke to his companion again, and they moved nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, quitting the pillar. \xe2\x80\x9cOne word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey stopped again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA word!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Saxon, folding his immense arms across his\r\nbreast, and relaxing the menace beginning to blacken his face. \xe2\x80\x9cA word!\r\nSpeak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are Thord the Northman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe giant opened his blue eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were lanista in Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThord nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was your scholar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Thord, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the beard of Irmin, I had never\r\na Jew to make a fighting-man of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I will prove my saying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou came here to kill me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let this man fight me singly, and I will make the proof on his\r\nbody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA gleam of humor shone in the Northman\xe2\x80\x99s face. He spoke to his\r\ncompanion, who made answer; then he replied with the naivete of a\r\ndiverted child,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait till I say begin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy repeated touches of his foot, he pushed a couch out on the floor,\r\nand proceeded leisurely to stretch his burly form upon it; when\r\nperfectly at ease, he said, simply, \xe2\x80\x9cNow begin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout ado, Ben-Hur walked to his antagonist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDefend thyself,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe man, nothing loath, put up his hands.\r\n\r\nAs the two thus confronted each other in approved position, there was\r\nno discernible inequality between them; on the contrary, they were as\r\nlike as brothers. To the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s confident smile, Ben-Hur opposed an\r\nearnestness which, had his skill been known, would have been accepted\r\nfair warning of danger. Both knew the combat was to be mortal.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur feinted with his right hand. The stranger warded, slightly\r\nadvancing his left arm. Ere he could return to guard, Ben-Hur caught\r\nhim by the wrist in a grip which years at the oar had made terrible as\r\na vise. The surprise was complete, and no time given.
