To throw himself\r\nforward; to push the arm across the man\xe2\x80\x99s throat and over his right\r\nshoulder, and turn him left side front; to strike surely with the ready\r\nleft hand; to strike the bare neck under the ear\xe2\x80\x94were but petty\r\ndivisions of the same act. No need of a second blow. The myrmidon fell\r\nheavily, and without a cry, and lay still.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur turned to Thord.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! What! By the beard of Irmin!\xe2\x80\x9d the latter cried, in astonishment,\r\nrising to a sitting posture. Then he laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! I could not have done it better myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe viewed Ben-Hur coolly from head to foot, and, rising, faced him with\r\nundisguised admiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was my trick\xe2\x80\x94the trick I have practised for ten years in the\r\nschools of Rome. You are not a Jew. Who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou knew Arrius the duumvir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuintus Arrius? Yes, he was my patron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had a son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Thord, his battered features lighting dully, \xe2\x80\x9cI knew the\r\nboy; he would have made a king gladiator. Caesar offered him his\r\npatronage. I taught him the very trick you played on this one here\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ntrick impossible except to a hand and arm like mine. It has won me many\r\na crown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am that son of Arrius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThord drew nearer, and viewed him carefully; then his eyes brightened\r\nwith genuine pleasure, and, laughing, he held out his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! He told me I would find a Jew here\xe2\x80\x94a Jew\xe2\x80\x94a dog of a\r\nJew\xe2\x80\x94killing whom was serving the gods.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur, taking the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x94Messala\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen, Thord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought he was hurt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will never walk again. On his bed he told me between groans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA very vivid portrayal of hate in a few words; and Ben-Hur saw that the\r\nRoman, if he lived, would still be capable and dangerous, and follow\r\nhim unrelentingly. Revenge remained to sweeten the ruined life;\r\ntherefore the clinging to fortune lost in the wager with Sanballat.\r\nBen-Hur ran the ground over, with a distinct foresight of the many ways\r\nin which it would be possible for his enemy to interfere with him in\r\nthe work he had undertaken for the King who was coming. Why not he\r\nresort to the Roman\xe2\x80\x99s methods? The man hired to kill him could be hired\r\nto strike back. It was in his power to offer higher wages. The\r\ntemptation was strong; and, half yielding, he chanced to look down at\r\nhis late antagonist lying still, with white upturned face, so like\r\nhimself. A light came to him, and he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cThord, what was Messala to\r\ngive you for killing me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand sestertii.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall have them yet; and so you do now what I tell you, I will add\r\nthree thousand more to the sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe giant reflected aloud,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won five thousand yesterday; from the Roman one\xe2\x80\x94six. Give me four,\r\ngood Arrius\xe2\x80\x94four more\xe2\x80\x94and I will stand firm for you, though old Thor,\r\nmy namesake, strike me with his hammer. Make it four, and I will kill\r\nthe lying patrician, if you say so. I have only to cover his mouth with\r\nmy hand\xe2\x80\x94thus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe illustrated the process by clapping his hand over his own mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur; \xe2\x80\x9cten thousand sestertii is a fortune. It will\r\nenable you to return to Rome, and open a wine-shop near the Great\r\nCircus, and live as becomes the first of the lanistae.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe very scars on the giant\xe2\x80\x99s face glowed afresh with the pleasure the\r\npicture gave him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will make it four thousand,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur continued; \xe2\x80\x9cand in what you\r\nshall do for the money there will be no blood on your hands, Thord.\r\nHear me now. Did not your friend here look like me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would have said he was an apple from the same tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if I put on his tunic, and dress him in these clothes of mine,\r\nand you and I go away together, leaving him here, can you not get your\r\nsestertii from Messala all the same? You have only to make him believe\r\nit me that is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThord laughed till the tears ran into his mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! Ten thousand sestertii were never won so easily. And a\r\nwine-shop by the Great Circus!\xe2\x80\x94all for a lie without blood in it! Ha,\r\nha, ha! Give me thy hand, O son of Arrius. Get on now, and\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha,\r\nha!\xe2\x80\x94if ever you come to Rome, fail not to ask for the wine-shop of\r\nThord the Northman. By the beard of Irmin, I will give you the best,\r\nthough I borrow it from Caesar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey shook hands again; after which the exchange of clothes was\r\neffected. It was arranged then that a messenger should go at night to\r\nThord\xe2\x80\x99s lodging-place with the four thousand sestertii. When they were\r\ndone, the giant knocked at the front door; it opened to him; and,\r\npassing out of the atrium, he led Ben-Hur into a room adjoining, where\r\nthe latter completed his attire from the coarse garments of the dead\r\npugilist. They separated directly in the Omphalus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFail not, O son of Arrius, fail not the wine-shop near the Great\r\nCircus! Ha, ha, ha! By the beard of Irmin, there was never fortune\r\ngained so cheap. The gods keep you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon leaving the atrium, Ben-Hur gave a last look at the myrmidon as he\r\nlay in the Jewish vestments, and was satisfied. The likeness was\r\nstriking. If Thord kept faith, the cheat was a secret to endure\r\nforever.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt night, in the house of Simonides, Ben-Hur told the good man all that\r\nhad taken place in the palace of Idernee; and it was agreed that, after\r\na few days, public inquiry should be set afloat for the discovery of\r\nthe whereabouts of the son of Arrius. Eventually the matter was to be\r\ncarried boldly to Maxentius; then, if the mystery came not out, it was\r\nconcluded that Messala and Gratus would be at rest and happy, and\r\nBen-Hur free to betake himself to Jerusalem, to make search for his\r\nlost people.\r\n\r\nAt the leave-taking, Simonides sat in his chair out on the terrace\r\noverlooking the river, and gave his farewell and the peace of the Lord\r\nwith the impressment of a father. Esther went with the young man to the\r\nhead of the steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I find my mother, Esther, thou shalt go to her at Jerusalem, and be\r\na sister to Tirzah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd with the words he kissed her.\r\n\r\nWas it only a kiss of peace?\r\n\r\nHe crossed the river next to the late quarters of Ilderim, where he\r\nfound the Arab who was to serve him as guide. The horses were brought\r\nout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis one is thine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Arab.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked, and, lo! it was Aldebaran, the swiftest and brightest\r\nof the sons of Mira, and, next to Sirius, the beloved of the sheik; and\r\nhe knew the old man\xe2\x80\x99s heart came to him along with the gift.\r\n\r\nThe corpse in the atrium was taken up and buried by night; and, as part\r\nof Messala\xe2\x80\x99s plan, a courier was sent off to Gratus to make him at rest\r\nby the announcement of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s death\xe2\x80\x94this time past question.\r\n\r\nEre long a wine-shop was opened near the Circus Maximus, with\r\ninscription over the door:\r\n\r\nTHORD THE NORTHMAN.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SIXTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that a Death? and are there two?\r\nIs Death that woman\xe2\x80\x99s mate?\r\n\r\nHer skin was as white as leprosy,\r\nThe Nightmare Life-in-Death was she,\r\nWho thicks man\xe2\x80\x99s blood with cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCOLERIDGE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nOur story moves forward now thirty days from the night Ben-Hur left\r\nAntioch to go out with Sheik Ilderim into the desert.\r\n\r\nA great change has befallen\xe2\x80\x94great at least as respects the fortunes of\r\nour hero. _Valerius Gratus has been succeeded by Pontius Pilate!_\r\n\r\nThe removal, it may be remarked, cost Simonides exactly five talents\r\nRoman money in hand paid to Sejanus, who was then in height of power as\r\nimperial favorite; the object being to help Ben-Hur, by lessening his\r\nexposure while in and about Jerusalem attempting discovery of his\r\npeople. To such pious use the faithful servant put the winnings from\r\nDrusus and his associates; all of whom, having paid their wagers,\r\nbecame at once and naturally the enemies of Messala, whose repudiation\r\nwas yet an unsettled question in Rome.\r\n\r\nBrief as the time was, already the Jews knew the change of rulers was\r\nnot for the better.\r\n\r\nThe cohorts sent to relieve the garrison of Antonia made their entry\r\ninto the city by night; next morning the first sight that greeted the\r\npeople resident in the neighborhood was the walls of the old Tower\r\ndecorated with military ensigns, which unfortunately consisted of busts\r\nof the emperor mixed with eagles and globes. A multitude, in passion,\r\nmarched to Caesarea, where Pilate was lingering, and implored him to\r\nremove the detested images. Five days and nights they beset his palace\r\ngates; at last he appointed a meeting with them in the Circus. When\r\nthey were assembled, he encircled them with soldiers; instead of\r\nresisting, they offered him their lives, and conquered. He recalled the\r\nimages and ensigns to Caesarea, where Gratus, with more consideration,\r\nhad kept such abominations housed during the eleven years of his reign.\r\n\r\nThe worst of men do once in a while vary their wickednesses by good\r\nacts; so with Pilate. He ordered an inspection of all the prisons in\r\nJudea, and a return of the names of the persons in custody, with a\r\nstatement of the crimes for which they had been committed. Doubtless,\r\nthe motive was the one so common with officials just installed\xe2\x80\x94dread of\r\nentailed responsibility; the people, however, in thought of the good\r\nwhich might come of the measure, gave him credit, and, for a period,\r\nwere comforted. The revelations were astonishing. Hundreds of persons\r\nwere released against whom there were no accusations; many others came\r\nto light who had long been accounted dead; yet more amazing, there was\r\nopening of dungeons not merely unknown at the time by the people, but\r\nactually forgotten by the prison authorities. With one instance of the\r\nlatter kind we have now to deal; and, strange to say, it occurred in\r\nJerusalem.\r\n\r\nThe Tower of Antonia, which will be remembered as occupying two thirds\r\nof the sacred area on Mount Moriah, was originally a castle built by\r\nthe Macedonians. Afterwards, John Hyrcanus erected the castle into a\r\nfortress for the defence of the Temple, and in his day it was\r\nconsidered impregnable to assault; but when Herod came with his bolder\r\ngenius, he strengthened its walls and extended them, leaving a vast\r\npile which included every appurtenance necessary for the stronghold he\r\nintended it to be forever; such as offices, barracks, armories,\r\nmagazines, cisterns, and last, though not least, prisons of all grades.\r\nHe levelled the solid rock, and tapped it with deep excavations, and\r\nbuilt over them; connecting the whole great mass with the Temple by a\r\nbeautiful colonnade, from the roof of which one could look down over\r\nthe courts of the sacred structure. In such condition the Tower fell at\r\nlast out of his hands into those of the Romans, who were quick to see\r\nits strength and advantages, and convert it to uses becoming such\r\nmasters. All through the administration of Gratus it had been a\r\ngarrisoned citadel and underground prison terrible to revolutionists.\r\nWoe when the cohorts poured from its gates to suppress disorder! Woe\r\nnot less when a Jew passed the same gates going in under arrest!\r\n\r\nWith this explanation, we hasten to our story.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe order of the new procurator requiring a report of the persons in\r\ncustody was received at the Tower of Antonia, and promptly executed;\r\nand two days have gone since the last unfortunate was brought up for\r\nexamination. The tabulated statement, ready for forwarding, lies on the\r\ntable of the tribune in command; in five minutes more it will be on the\r\nway to Pilate, sojourning in the palace up on Mount Zion.\r\n\r\nThe tribune\xe2\x80\x99s office is spacious and cool, and furnished in a style\r\nsuitable to the dignity of the commandant of a post in every respect so\r\nimportant. Looking in upon him about the seventh hour of the day, the\r\nofficer appears weary and impatient; when the report is despatched, he\r\nwill to the roof of the colonnade for air and exercise, and the\r\namusement to be had watching the Jews over in the courts of the Temple.\r\nHis subordinates and clerks share his impatience.\r\n\r\nIn the spell of waiting a man appeared in a doorway leading to an\r\nadjoining apartment. He rattled a bunch of keys, each heavy as a\r\nhammer, and at once attracted the chief\xe2\x80\x99s attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Gesius! come in,\xe2\x80\x9d the tribune said.\r\n\r\nAs the new-comer approached the table behind which the chief sat in an\r\neasy-chair, everybody present looked at him, and, observing a certain\r\nexpression of alarm and mortification on his face, became silent that\r\nthey might hear what he had to say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO tribune!\xe2\x80\x9d he began, bending low, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear to tell what now I bring\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother mistake\xe2\x80\x94ha, Gesius?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could persuade myself it is but a mistake, I would not be\r\nafraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA crime then\xe2\x80\x94or, worse, a breach of duty. Thou mayst laugh at Caesar,\r\nor curse the gods, and live; but if the offence be to the eagles\xe2\x80\x94ah,\r\nthou knowest, Gesius\xe2\x80\x94go on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is now about eight years since Valerius Gratus selected me to be\r\nkeeper of prisoners here in the Tower,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, deliberately. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nremember the morning I entered upon the duties of my office. There had\r\nbeen a riot the day before, and fighting in the streets. We slew many\r\nJews, and suffered on our side. The affair came, it was said, of an\r\nattempt to assassinate Gratus, who had been knocked from his horse by a\r\ntile thrown from a roof. I found him sitting where you now sit, O\r\ntribune, his head swathed in bandages. He told me of my selection, and\r\ngave me these keys, numbered to correspond with the numbers of the\r\ncells; they were the badges of my office, he said, and not to be parted\r\nwith. There was a roll of parchment on the table. Calling me to him, he\r\nopened the roll. \xe2\x80\x98Here are maps of the cells,\xe2\x80\x99 said he. There were\r\nthree of them. \xe2\x80\x98This one,\xe2\x80\x99 he went on, \xe2\x80\x98shows the arrangement of the\r\nupper floor; this second one gives you the second floor; and this last\r\nis of the lower floor. I give them to you in trust.\xe2\x80\x99 I took them from\r\nhis hand, and he said, further, \xe2\x80\x98Now you have the keys and the maps; go\r\nimmediately, and acquaint yourself with the whole arrangement; visit\r\neach cell, and see to its condition. When anything is needed for the\r\nsecurity of a prisoner, order it according to your judgment, for you\r\nare the master under me, and no other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saluted him, and turned to go away; he called me back. \xe2\x80\x98Ah, I\r\nforgot,\xe2\x80\x99 he said. \xe2\x80\x98Give me the map of the third floor.\xe2\x80\x99 I gave it to\r\nhim, and he spread it upon the table. \xe2\x80\x98Here, Gesius,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98see\r\nthis cell.\xe2\x80\x99 He laid his finger on the one numbered V. \xe2\x80\x98There are three\r\nmen confined in that cell, desperate characters, who by some means got\r\nhold of a state secret, and suffer for their curiosity, which\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nlooked at me severely\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98in such matters is worse than a crime.\r\nAccordingly, they are blind and tongueless, and are placed there for\r\nlife. They shall have nothing but food and drink, to be given them\r\nthrough a hole, which you will find in the wall covered by a slide. Do\r\nyou hear, Gesius?\xe2\x80\x99 I made him answer. \xe2\x80\x98It is well,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued. \xe2\x80\x98One\r\nthing more which you shall not forget, or\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94he looked at me\r\nthreateningly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98The door of their cell\xe2\x80\x94cell number V. on the same\r\nfloor\xe2\x80\x94this one, Gesius\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94he put his finger on the particular cell to\r\nimpress my memory\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98shall never be opened for any purpose, neither to\r\nlet one in nor out, not even yourself.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98But if they die?\xe2\x80\x99 I asked. \xe2\x80\x98If\r\nthey die,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98the cell shall be their tomb. They were put there\r\nto die, and be lost. The cell is leprous. Do you understand?\xe2\x80\x99 With that\r\nhe let me go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGesius stopped, and from the breast of his tunic drew three parchments,\r\nall much yellowed by time and use; selecting one of them, he spread it\r\nupon the table before the tribune, saying, simply, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the lower\r\nfloor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe whole company looked at\r\n\r\nTHE MAP\r\n\r\n   __________________________________________\r\n  |                                          |\r\n  |                 Passage                  |\r\n  |                                          |\r\n  |--][---+---][---+---][---+---][---+---][--|\r\n  |       |        |        |        |       |\r\n  |   V   |   IV   |   III  |   II   |   I   |\r\n  |_______|________|________|________|_______|\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is exactly, O tribune, as I had it from Gratus. See, there is\r\ncell number V.,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gesius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d the tribune replied. \xe2\x80\x9cGo on now. The cell was leprous, he\r\nsaid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would like to ask you a question,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the keeper, modestly.\r\n\r\nThe tribune assented.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad I not a right, under the circumstances, to believe the map a true\r\none?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else couldst thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is not a true one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chief looked up surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not a true one,\xe2\x80\x9d the keeper repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cIt shows but five cells\r\nupon that floor, while there are six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix, sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will show you the floor as it is\xe2\x80\x94or as I believe it to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon a page of his tablets, Gesius drew the following diagram, and gave\r\nit to the tribune:\r\n\r\n   __________________________________________\r\n  |                                          |\r\n  |--][---+---][---+---][---+---][---+---][--|\r\n  |       |        |        |        |       |\r\n  |   V   |   IV   |   III  |   II   |   I   |\r\n  |--][---+--------+--------+--------+-------|\r\n  |                    VI                    |\r\n  |__________________________________________|\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast done well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the tribune, examining the drawing, and\r\nthinking the narrative at an end. \xe2\x80\x9cI will have the map corrected, or,\r\nbetter, I will have a new one made, and given thee. Come for it in the\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut hear me further, O tribune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, Gesius, to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat which I have yet to tell will not wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune good-naturedly resumed his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will hurry,\xe2\x80\x9d said the keeper, humbly, \xe2\x80\x9conly let me ask another\r\nquestion. Had I not a right to believe Gratus in what he further told\r\nme as to the prisoners in cell number V.?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was thy duty to believe there were three prisoners in the\r\ncell\xe2\x80\x94prisoners of state\xe2\x80\x94blind and without tongues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the keeper, \xe2\x80\x9cthat was not true either.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said the tribune, with returning interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear, and judge for yourself, O tribune. As required, I visited all\r\nthe cells, beginning with those on the first floor, and ending with\r\nthose on the lower. The order that the door of number V. should not be\r\nopened had been respected; through all the eight years food and drink\r\nfor three men had been passed through a hole in the wall. I went to the\r\ndoor yesterday, curious to see the wretches who, against all\r\nexpectation, had lived so long. The locks refused the key. We pulled a\r\nlittle, and the door fell down, rusted from its hinges. Going in, I\r\nfound but one man, old, blind, tongueless, and naked. His hair dropped\r\nin stiffened mats below his waist. His skin was like the parchment\r\nthere. He held his hands out, and the finger-nails curled and twisted\r\nlike the claws of a bird. I asked him where his companions were. He\r\nshook his head in denial. Thinking to find the others, we searched the\r\ncell. The floor was dry; so were the walls. If three men had been shut\r\nin there, and two of them had died, at least their bones would have\r\nendured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWherefore thou thinkest\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, O tribune, there has been but one prisoner there in the eight\r\nyears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chief regarded the keeper sharply, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cHave a care; thou art\r\nmore than saying Valerius lied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGesius bowed, but said, \xe2\x80\x9cHe might have been mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he was right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the tribune, warmly. \xe2\x80\x9cBy thine own statement\r\nhe was right. Didst thou not say but now that for eight years food and\r\ndrink had been furnished three men?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bystanders approved the shrewdness of their chief; yet Gesius did\r\nnot seem discomfited.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have but half the story, O tribune. When you have it all, you will\r\nagree with me. You know what I did with the man: that I sent him to the\r\nbath, and had him shorn and clothed, and then took him to the gate of\r\nthe Tower, and bade him go free. I washed my hands of him. To-day he\r\ncame back, and was brought to me. By signs and tears he at last made me\r\nunderstand he wished to return to his cell, and I so ordered. As they\r\nwere leading him off, he broke away and kissed my feet, and, by piteous\r\ndumb imploration, insisted I should go with him; and I went. The\r\nmystery of the three men stayed in my mind. I was not satisfied about\r\nit. Now I am glad I yielded to his entreaty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe whole company at this point became very still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen we were in the cell again, and the prisoner knew it, he caught my\r\nhand eagerly, and led me to a hole like that through which we were\r\naccustomed to pass him his food. Though large enough to push your\r\nhelmet through, it escaped me yesterday. Still holding my hand, he put\r\nhis face to the hole and gave a beast-like cry. A sound came faintly\r\nback. I was astonished, and drew him away, and called out, \xe2\x80\x98Ho, here!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nAt first there was no answer. I called again, and received back these\r\nwords, \xe2\x80\x98Be thou praised, O Lord!\xe2\x80\x99 Yet more astonishing, O tribune, the\r\nvoice was a woman\xe2\x80\x99s. And I asked, \xe2\x80\x98Who are you?\xe2\x80\x99 and had reply, \xe2\x80\x98A\r\nwoman of Israel, entombed here with her daughter. Help us quickly, or\r\nwe die.\xe2\x80\x99 I told them to be of cheer, and hurried here to know your\r\nwill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune arose hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou wert right, Gesius,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I see now. The map was a lie,\r\nand so was the tale of the three men. There have been better Romans\r\nthan Valerius Gratus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the keeper. \xe2\x80\x9cI gleaned from the prisoner that he had\r\nregularly given the women of the food and drink he had received.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is accounted for,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the tribune, and observing the\r\ncountenances of his friends, and reflecting how well it would be to\r\nhave witnesses, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us rescue the women. Come all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGesuis was pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will have to pierce the wall,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI found where a door had\r\nbeen, but it was filled solidly with stones and mortar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune stayed to say to a clerk, \xe2\x80\x9cSend workmen after me with\r\ntools. Make haste; but hold the report, for I see it will have to be\r\ncorrected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a short time they were gone.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woman of Israel, entombed here with her daughter. Help us quickly,\r\nor we die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch was the reply Gesius, the keeper, had from the cell which appears\r\non his amended map as VI. The reader, when he observed the answer, knew\r\nwho the unfortunates were, and, doubtless, said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cAt last\r\nthe mother of Ben-Hur, and Tirzah, his sister!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so it was.\r\n\r\nThe morning of their seizure, eight years before, they had been carried\r\nto the Tower, where Gratus proposed to put them out of the way. He had\r\nchosen the Tower for the purpose as more immediately in his own\r\nkeeping, and cell VI. because, first, it could be better lost than any\r\nother; and, secondly, it was infected with leprosy; for these prisoners\r\nwere not merely to be put in a safe place, but in a place to die. They\r\nwere, accordingly, taken down by slaves in the night-time, when there\r\nwere no witnesses of the deed; then, in completion of the savage task,\r\nthe same slaves walled up the door, after which they were themselves\r\nseparated, and sent away never to be heard of more. To save accusation,\r\nand, in the event of discovery, to leave himself such justification as\r\nmight be allowed in a distinction between the infliction of a\r\npunishment and the commission of a double murder, Gratus preferred\r\nsinking his victims where natural death was certain, though slow. That\r\nthey might linger along, he selected a convict who had been made blind\r\nand tongueless, and sank him in the only connecting cell, there to\r\nserve them with food and drink. Under no circumstances could the poor\r\nwretch tell the tale or identify either the prisoners or their\r\ndoomsman. So, with a cunning partly due to Messala, the Roman, under\r\ncolor of punishing a brood of assassins, smoothed a path to\r\nconfiscation of the estate of the Hurs, of which no portion ever\r\nreached the imperial coffers.\r\n\r\nAs the last step in the scheme, Gratus summarily removed the old keeper\r\nof the prisons; not because he knew what had been done\xe2\x80\x94for he did\r\nnot\xe2\x80\x94but because, knowing the underground floors as he did, it would be\r\nnext to impossible to keep the transaction from him. Then, with\r\nmasterly ingenuity, the procurator had new maps drawn for delivery to a\r\nnew keeper, with the omission, as we have seen, of cell VI. The\r\ninstructions given the latter, taken with the omission on the map,\r\naccomplished the design\xe2\x80\x94the cell and its unhappy tenants were all alike\r\nlost.\r\n\r\nWhat may be thought of the life of the mother and daughter during the\r\neight years must have relation to their culture and previous habits.\r\nConditions are pleasant or grievous to us according to our\r\nsensibilities. It is not extreme to say, if there was a sudden exit of\r\nall men from the world, heaven, as prefigured in the Christian idea,\r\nwould not be a heaven to the majority; on the other hand, neither would\r\nall suffer equally in the so-called Tophet. Cultivation has its\r\nbalances. As the mind is made intelligent, the capacity of the soul for\r\npure enjoyment is proportionally increased. Well, therefore, if it be\r\nsaved! If lost, however, alas that it ever had cultivation! its\r\ncapacity for enjoyment in the one case is the measure of its capacity\r\nto suffer in the other. Wherefore repentance must be something more\r\nthan mere remorse for sins; it comprehends a change of nature befitting\r\nheaven.\r\n\r\nWe repeat, to form an adequate idea of the suffering endured by the\r\nmother of Ben-Hur, the reader must think of her spirit and its\r\nsensibilities as much as, if not more than, of the conditions of the\r\nimmurement; the question being, not what the conditions were, but how\r\nshe was affected by them. And now we may be permitted to say it was in\r\nanticipation of this thought that the scene in the summer-house on the\r\nroof of the family palace was given so fully in the beginning of the\r\nSecond Book of our story. So, too, to be helpful when the inquiry\r\nshould come up, we ventured the elaborate description of the palace of\r\nthe Hurs.\r\n\r\nIn other words, let the serene, happy, luxurious life in the princely\r\nhouse be recalled and contrasted with this existence in the lower\r\ndungeon of the Tower of Antonia; then if the reader, in his effort to\r\nrealize the misery of the woman, persists in mere reference to\r\nconditions physical, he cannot go amiss; as he is a lover of his kind,\r\ntender of heart, he will be melted with much sympathy. But will he go\r\nfurther; will he more than sympathize with her; will he share her agony\r\nof mind and spirit; will he at least try to measure it\xe2\x80\x94let him recall\r\nher as she discoursed to her son of God and nations and heroes; one\r\nmoment a philosopher, the next a teacher, and all the time a mother.\r\n\r\nWould you hurt a man keenest, strike at his self-love; would you hurt a\r\nwoman worst, aim at her affections.\r\n\r\nWith quickened remembrance of these unfortunates\xe2\x80\x94remembrance of them as\r\nthey were\xe2\x80\x94let us go down and see them as they are.\r\n\r\nThe cell VI. was in form as Gesius drew it on his map. Of its\r\ndimensions but little idea can be had; enough that it was a roomy,\r\nroughened interior, with ledged and broken walls and floor.\r\n\r\nIn the beginning, the site of the Macedonian Castle was separated from\r\nthe site of the Temple by a narrow but deep cliff somewhat in shape of\r\na wedge. The workmen, wishing to hew out a series of chambers, made\r\ntheir entry in the north face of the cleft, and worked in, leaving a\r\nceiling of the natural stone; delving farther, they executed the cells\r\nV., IV., III., II., I., with no connection with number VI. except\r\nthrough number V. In like manner, they constructed the passage and\r\nstairs to the floor above. The process of the work was precisely that\r\nresorted to in carving out the Tombs of the Kings, yet to be seen a\r\nshort distance north of Jerusalem; only when the cutting was done, cell\r\nVI. was enclosed on its outer side by a wall of prodigious stones, in\r\nwhich, for ventilation, narrow apertures were left bevelled like modern\r\nport-holes. Herod, when he took hold of the Temple and Tower, put a\r\nfacing yet more massive upon this outer wall, and shut up all the\r\napertures but one, which yet admitted a little vitalizing air, and a\r\nray of light not nearly strong enough to redeem the room from darkness.\r\n\r\nSuch was cell VI.\r\n\r\nStartle not now!\r\n\r\nThe description of the blind and tongueless wretch just liberated from\r\ncell V. may be accepted to break the horror of what is coming.\r\n\r\nThe two women are grouped close by the aperture; one is seated, the\r\nother is half reclining against her; there is nothing between them and\r\nthe bare rock. The light, slanting upwards, strikes them with ghastly\r\neffect, and we cannot avoid seeing they are without vesture or\r\ncovering. At the same time we are helped to the knowledge that love is\r\nthere yet, for the two are in each other\xe2\x80\x99s arms. Riches take wings,\r\ncomforts vanish, hope withers away, but love stays with us. Love is\r\nGod.\r\n\r\nWhere the two are thus grouped the stony floor is polished shining\r\nsmooth. Who shall say how much of the eight years they have spent in\r\nthat space there in front of the aperture, nursing their hope of rescue\r\nby that timid yet friendly ray of light? When the brightness came\r\ncreeping in, they knew it was dawn; when it began to fade, they knew\r\nthe world was hushing for the night, which could not be anywhere so\r\nlong and utterly dark as with them. The world! Through that crevice, as\r\nif it were broad and high as a king\xe2\x80\x99s gate, they went to the world in\r\nthought, and passed the weary time going up and down as spirits go,\r\nlooking and asking, the one for her son, the other for her brother. On\r\nthe seas they sought him, and on the islands of the seas; to-day he was\r\nin this city, to-morrow in that other; and everywhere, and at all\r\ntimes, he was a flitting sojourner; for, as they lived waiting for him,\r\nhe lived looking for them. How often their thoughts passed each other\r\nin the endless search, his coming, theirs going! It was such sweet\r\nflattery for them to say to each other, \xe2\x80\x9cWhile he lives, we shall not\r\nbe forgotten; as long as he remembers us, there is hope!\xe2\x80\x9d The strength\r\none can eke from little, who knows till he has been subjected to the\r\ntrial?\r\n\r\nOur recollections of them in former days enjoin us to be respectful;\r\ntheir sorrows clothe them with sanctity. Without going too near, across\r\nthe dungeon, we see they have undergone a change of appearance not to\r\nbe accounted for by time or long confinement. The mother was beautiful\r\nas a woman, the daughter beautiful as a child; not even love could say\r\nso much now. Their hair is long, unkempt, and strangely white; they\r\nmake us shrink and shudder with an indefinable repulsion, though the\r\neffect may be from an illusory glozing of the light glimmering dismally\r\nthrough the unhealthy murk; or they may be enduring the tortures of\r\nhunger and thirst, not having had to eat or drink since their servant,\r\nthe convict, was taken away\xe2\x80\x94that is, since yesterday.\r\n\r\nTirzah, reclining against her mother in half embrace, moans piteously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe quiet, Tirzah. They will come. God is good. We have been mindful of\r\nhim, and forgotten not to pray at every sounding of the trumpets over\r\nin the Temple. The light, you see, is still bright; the sun is standing\r\nin the south sky yet, and it is hardly more than the seventh hour.\r\nSomebody will come to us. Let us have faith. God is good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus the mother. The words were simple and effective, although, eight\r\nyears being now to be added to the thirteen she had attained when last\r\nwe saw her, Tirzah was no longer a child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will try and be strong, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYour suffering must be\r\nas great as mine; and I do so want to live for you and my brother! But\r\nmy tongue burns, my lips scorch. I wonder where he is, and if he will\r\never, ever find us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere is something in the voices that strikes us singularly\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nunexpected tone, sharp, dry, metallic, unnatural.\r\n\r\nThe mother draws the daughter closer to her breast, and says, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ndreamed about him last night, and saw him as plainly, Tirzah, as I see\r\nyou. We must believe in dreams, you know, because our fathers did. The\r\nLord spoke to them so often in that way. I thought we were in the\r\nWomen\xe2\x80\x99s Court just before the Gate Beautiful; there were many women\r\nwith us; and he came and stood in the shade of the Gate, and looked\r\nhere and there, at this one and that. My heart beat strong. I knew he\r\nwas looking for us, and stretched my arms to him, and ran, calling him.\r\nHe heard me and saw me, but he did not know me. In a moment he was\r\ngone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould it not be so, mother, if we were to meet him in fact? We are so\r\nchanged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might be so; but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d The mother\xe2\x80\x99s head droops, and her face knits as\r\nwith a wrench of pain; recovering, however, she goes on\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut we could\r\nmake ourselves known to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah tossed her arms, and moaned again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWater, mother, water, though but a drop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother stares around in blank helplessness. She has named God so\r\noften, and so often promised in his name, the repetition is beginning\r\nto have a mocking effect upon herself. A shadow passes before her\r\ndimming the dim light, and she is brought down to think of death as\r\nvery near, waiting to come in as her faith goes out. Hardly knowing\r\nwhat she does, speaking aimlessly, because speak she must, she says\r\nagain,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience, Tirzah; they are coming\xe2\x80\x94they are almost here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe thought she heard a sound over by the little trap in the\r\npartition-wall through which they held all their actual communication\r\nwith the world. And she was not mistaken. A moment, and the cry of the\r\nconvict rang through the cell. Tirzah heard it also; and they both\r\narose, still keeping hold of each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPraised be the Lord forever!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the mother, with the fervor of\r\nrestored faith and hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo, there!\xe2\x80\x9d they heard next; and then, \xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice was strange. What matter? Except from Tirzah, they were the\r\nfirst and only words the mother had heard in eight years. The revulsion\r\nwas mighty\xe2\x80\x94from death to life\xe2\x80\x94and so instantly!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woman of Israel, entombed here with her daughter. Help us quickly,\r\nor we die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe of cheer. I will return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe women sobbed aloud. They were found; help was coming. From wish to\r\nwish hope flew as the twittering swallows fly. They were found; they\r\nwould be released. And restoration would follow\xe2\x80\x94restoration to all they\r\nhad lost\xe2\x80\x94home, society, property, son and brother! The scanty light\r\nglozed them with the glory of day, and, forgetful of pain and thirst\r\nand hunger, and of the menace of death, they sank upon the floor and\r\ncried, keeping fast hold of each other the while.\r\n\r\nAnd this time they had not long to wait. Gesius, the keeper, told his\r\ntale methodically, but finished it at last. The tribune was prompt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithin there!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted through the trap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere!\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother, rising.\r\n\r\nDirectly she heard another sound in another place, as of blows on the\r\nwall\xe2\x80\x94blows quick, ringing, and delivered with iron tools. She did not\r\nspeak, nor did Tirzah, but they listened, well knowing the meaning of\r\nit all\xe2\x80\x94that a way to liberty was being made for them. So men a long\r\ntime buried in deep mines hear the coming of rescuers, heralded by\r\nthrust of bar and beat of pick, and answer gratefully with\r\nheart-throbs, their eyes fixed upon the spot whence the sounds proceed;\r\nand they cannot look away, lest the work should cease, and they be\r\nreturned to despair.\r\n\r\nThe arms outside were strong, the hands skillful, the will good. Each\r\ninstant the blows sounded more plainly; now and then a piece fell with\r\na crash; and liberty came nearer and nearer. Presently the workmen\r\ncould be heard speaking. Then\xe2\x80\x94O happiness!\xe2\x80\x94through a crevice flashed a\r\nred ray of torches. Into the darkness it cut incisive as diamond\r\nbrilliance, beautiful as if from a spear of the morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he, mother, it is he! He has found us at last!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Tirzah,\r\nwith the quickened fancy of youth.\r\n\r\nBut the mother answered meekly, \xe2\x80\x9cGod is good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA block fell inside, and another\xe2\x80\x94then a great mass, and the door was\r\nopen. A man grimed with mortar and stone-dust stepped in, and stopped,\r\nholding a torch over his head. Two or three others followed with\r\ntorches, and stood aside for the tribune to enter.\r\n\r\nRespect for women is not all a conventionality, for it is the best\r\nproof of their proper nature. The tribune stopped, because they fled\r\nfrom him\xe2\x80\x94not with fear, be it said, but shame; nor yet, O reader, from\r\nshame alone! From the obscurity of their partial hiding he heard these\r\nwords, the saddest, most dreadful, most utterly despairing of the human\r\ntongue:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome not near us\xe2\x80\x94unclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men flared their torches while they stared at each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d came from the corner again, a slow tremulous wail\r\nexceedingly sorrowful. With such a cry we can imagine a spirit\r\nvanishing from the gates of Paradise, looking back the while.\r\n\r\nSo the widow and mother performed her duty, and in the moment realized\r\nthat the freedom she had prayed for and dreamed of, fruit of scarlet\r\nand gold seen afar, was but an apple of Sodom in the hand.\r\n\r\nSHE AND TIRZAH WERE\xe2\x80\x94LEPERS!\r\n\r\nPossibly the reader does not know all the word means. Let him be told\r\nit with reference to the Law of that time, only a little modified in\r\nthis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese four are accounted as dead\xe2\x80\x94the blind, the leper, the poor, and\r\nthe childless.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus the Talmud.\r\n\r\nThat is, to be a leper was to be treated as dead\xe2\x80\x94to be excluded from\r\nthe city as a corpse; to be spoken to by the best beloved and most\r\nloving only at a distance; to dwell with none but lepers; to be utterly\r\nunprivileged; to be denied the rites of the Temple and the synagogue;\r\nto go about in rent garments and with covered mouth, except when\r\ncrying, \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d to find home in the wilderness or in\r\nabandoned tombs; to become a materialized specter of Hinnom and\r\nGehenna; to be at all times less a living offence to others than a\r\nbreathing torment to self; afraid to die, yet without hope except in\r\ndeath.\r\n\r\nOnce\xe2\x80\x94she might not tell the day or the year, for down in the haunted\r\nhell even time was lost\xe2\x80\x94once the mother felt a dry scurf in the palm of\r\nher right hand, a trifle which she tried to wash away. It clung to the\r\nmember pertinaciously; yet she thought but little of the sign till\r\nTirzah complained that she, too, was attacked in the same way. The\r\nsupply of water was scant, and they denied themselves drink that they\r\nmight use it as a curative. At length the whole hand was attacked; the\r\nskin cracked open, the fingernails loosened from the flesh. There was\r\nnot much pain withal, chiefly a steadily increasing discomfort. Later\r\ntheir lips began to parch and seam. One day the mother, who was cleanly\r\nto godliness, and struggled against the impurities of the dungeon with\r\nall ingenuity, thinking the enemy was taking hold on Tirzah\xe2\x80\x99s face, led\r\nher to the light, and, looking with the inspiration of a terrible\r\ndread, lo! the young girl\xe2\x80\x99s eyebrows were white as snow.\r\n\r\nOh, the anguish of that assurance!\r\n\r\nThe mother sat awhile speechless, motionless, paralyzed of soul, and\r\ncapable of but one thought\xe2\x80\x94leprosy, leprosy!\r\n\r\nWhen she began to think, mother-like, it was not of herself, but her\r\nchild, and, mother-like, her natural tenderness turned to courage, and\r\nshe made ready for the last sacrifice of perfect heroism. She buried\r\nher knowledge in her heart; hopeless herself, she redoubled her\r\ndevotion to Tirzah, and with wonderful ingenuity\xe2\x80\x94wonderful chiefly in\r\nits very inexhaustibility\xe2\x80\x94continued to keep the daughter ignorant of\r\nwhat they were beset with, and even hopeful that it was nothing. She\r\nrepeated her little games, and retold her stories, and invented new\r\nones, and listened with ever so much pleasure to the songs she would\r\nhave from Tirzah, while on her own wasting lips the psalms of the\r\nsinging king and their race served to bring soothing of forgetfulness,\r\nand keep alive in them both the recollection of the God who would seem\r\nto have abandoned them\xe2\x80\x94the world not more lightly or utterly.\r\n\r\nSlowly, steadily, with horrible certainty, the disease spread, after a\r\nwhile bleaching their heads white, eating holes in their lips and\r\neyelids, and covering their bodies with scales; then it fell to their\r\nthroats shrilling their voices, and to their joints, hardening the\r\ntissues and cartilages\xe2\x80\x94slowly, and, as the mother well knew, past\r\nremedy, it was affecting their lungs and arteries and bones, at each\r\nadvance making the sufferers more and more loathsome; and so it would\r\ncontinue till death, which might be years before them.\r\n\r\nAnother day of dread at length came\xe2\x80\x94the day the mother, under impulsion\r\nof duty, at last told Tirzah the name of their ailment; and the two, in\r\nagony of despair, prayed that the end might come quickly.\r\n\r\nStill, as is the force of habit, these so afflicted grew in time not\r\nmerely to speak composedly of their disease; they beheld the hideous\r\ntransformation of their persons as of course, and in despite clung to\r\nexistence. One tie to earth remained to them; unmindful of their own\r\nloneliness, they kept up a certain spirit by talking and dreaming of\r\nBen-Hur. The mother promised reunion with him to the sister, and she to\r\nthe mother, not doubting, either of them, that he was equally faithful\r\nto them, and would be equally happy of the meeting. And with the\r\nspinning and respinning of this slender thread they found pleasure, and\r\nexcused their not dying. In such manner as we have seen, they were\r\nsolacing themselves the moment Gesius called them, at the end of twelve\r\nhours\xe2\x80\x99 fasting and thirst.\r\n\r\nThe torches flashed redly through the dungeon, and liberty was come.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is good,\xe2\x80\x9d the widow cried\xe2\x80\x94not for what had been, O reader, but for\r\nwhat was. In thankfulness for present mercy, nothing so becomes us as\r\nlosing sight of past ills.\r\n\r\nThe tribune came directly; then in the corner to which she had fled,\r\nsuddenly a sense of duty smote the elder of the women, and straightway\r\nthe awful warning\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAh, the pang the effort to acquit herself of that duty cost the mother!\r\nNot all the selfishness of joy over the prospect could keep her blind\r\nto the consequences of release, now that it was at hand. The old happy\r\nlife could never be again. If she went near the house called home, it\r\nwould be to stop at the gate and cry, \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d She must go\r\nabout with the yearnings of love alive in her breast strong as ever,\r\nand more sensitive even, because return in kind could not be. The boy\r\nof whom she had so constantly thought, and with all sweet promises such\r\nas mothers find their purest delight in, must, at meeting her, stand\r\nafar off. If he held out his hands to her, and called \xe2\x80\x9cMother, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nfor very love of him she must answer, \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d And this\r\nother child, before whom, in want of other covering, she was spreading\r\nher long tangled locks, bleached unnaturally white\xe2\x80\x94ah! that she was she\r\nmust continue, sole partner of her blasted remainder of life. Yet, O\r\nreader, the brave woman accepted the lot, and took up the cry which had\r\nbeen its sign immemorially, and which thenceforward was to be her\r\nsalutation without change\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tribune heard it with a tremor, but kept his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo women dying of hunger and thirst. Yet\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the mother did not\r\nfalter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ccome not near us, nor touch the floor or the wall. Unclean,\r\nunclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me thy story, woman\xe2\x80\x94thy name, and when thou wert put here, and by\r\nwhom, and for what.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was once in this city of Jerusalem a Prince Ben-Hur, the friend\r\nof all generous Romans, and who had Caesar for his friend. I am his\r\nwidow, and this one with me is his child. How may I tell you for what\r\nwe were sunk here, when I do not know, unless it was because we were\r\nrich? Valerius Gratus can tell you who our enemy was, and when our\r\nimprisonment began. I cannot. See to what we have been reduced\xe2\x80\x94oh, see,\r\nand have pity!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe air was heavy with the pest and the smoke of the torches, yet the\r\nRoman called one of the torch-bearers to his side, and wrote the answer\r\nnearly word for word. It was terse, and comprehensive, containing at\r\nonce a history, an accusation, and a prayer. No common person could\r\nhave made it, and he could not but pity and believe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt have relief, woman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, closing the tablets. \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nsend thee food and drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd raiment, and purifying water, we pray you, O generous Roman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs thou wilt,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the widow, sobbing. \xe2\x80\x9cMay his peace abide with you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, further,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot see thee again. Make preparation,\r\nand to-night I will have thee taken to the gate of the Tower, and set\r\nfree. Thou knowest the law. Farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe spoke to the men, and went out the door.\r\n\r\nVery shortly some slaves came to the cell with a large gurglet of\r\nwater, a basin and napkins, a platter with bread and meat, and some\r\ngarments of women\xe2\x80\x99s wear; and, setting them down within reach of the\r\nprisoners, they ran away.\r\n\r\nAbout the middle of the first watch, the two were conducted to the\r\ngate, and turned into the street. So the Roman quit himself of them,\r\nand in the city of their fathers they were once more free.\r\n\r\nUp to the stars, twinkling merrily as of old, they looked; then they\r\nasked themselves,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next? and where to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout the hour Gesius, the keeper, made his appearance before the\r\ntribune in the Tower of Antonia, a footman was climbing the eastern\r\nface of Mount Olivet. The road was rough and dusty, and vegetation on\r\nthat side burned brown, for it was the dry season in Judea. Well for\r\nthe traveller that he had youth and strength, not to speak of the cool,\r\nflowing garments with which he was clothed.\r\n\r\nHe proceeded slowly, looking often to his right and left; not with the\r\nvexed, anxious expression which marks a man going forward uncertain of\r\nthe way, but rather the air with which one approaches as old\r\nacquaintance after a long separation\xe2\x80\x94half of pleasure, half of inquiry;\r\nas if he were saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI am glad to be with you again; let me see in\r\nwhat you are changed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he arose higher, he sometimes paused to look behind him over the\r\ngradually widening view terminating in the mountains of Moab; but when\r\nat length he drew near the summit, he quickened his step, unmindful of\r\nfatigue, and hurried on without pause or turning of the face. On the\r\nsummit\xe2\x80\x94to reach which he bent his steps somewhat right of the beaten\r\npath\xe2\x80\x94he came to a dead stop, arrested as if by a strong hand. Then one\r\nmight have seen his eyes dilate, his cheeks flush, his breath quicken,\r\neffects all of one bright sweeping glance at what lay before him.\r\n\r\nThe traveller, good reader, was no other than Ben-Hur; the spectacle,\r\nJerusalem.\r\n\r\nNot the Holy City of to-day, but the Holy City as left by Herod\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nHoly City of the Christ. Beautiful yet, as seen from old Olivet, what\r\nmust it have been then?\r\n\r\nBen-Hur betook him to a stone and sat down, and, stripping his head of\r\nthe close white handkerchief which served it for covering, made the\r\nsurvey at leisure.\r\n\r\nThe same has been done often since by a great variety of persons, under\r\ncircumstances surpassingly singular\xe2\x80\x94by the son of Vespasian, by the\r\nIslamite, by the Crusader, conquerors all of them; by many a pilgrim\r\nfrom the great New World, which waited discovery nearly fifteen hundred\r\nyears after the time of our story; but of the multitude probably not\r\none has taken that view with sensations more keenly poignant, more\r\nsadly sweet, more proudly bitter, than Ben-Hur. He was stirred by\r\nrecollections of his countrymen, their triumphs and vicissitudes, their\r\nhistory the history of God. The city was of their building, at once a\r\nlasting testimony of their crimes and devotion, their weakness and\r\ngenius, their religion and their irreligion. Though he had seen Rome to\r\nfamiliarity, he was gratified. The sight filled a measure of pride\r\nwhich would have made him drunk with vainglory but for the thought,\r\nprincely as the property was, it did not any longer belong to his\r\ncountrymen; the worship in the Temple was by permission of strangers;\r\nthe hill where David dwelt was a marbled cheat\xe2\x80\x94an office in which the\r\nchosen of the Lord were wrung and wrung for taxes, and scourged for\r\nvery deathlessness of faith. These, however, were pleasures and griefs\r\nof patriotism common to every Jew of the period; in addition, Ben-Hur\r\nbrought with him a personal history which would not out of mind for\r\nother consideration whatever, which the spectacle served only to\r\nfreshen and vivify.\r\n\r\nA country of hills changes but little; where the hills are of rock, it\r\nchanges not at all. The scene Ben-Hur beheld is the same now, except as\r\nrespects the city. The failure is in the handiwork of man alone.\r\n\r\nThe sun dealt more kindly by the west side of Olivet than by the east,\r\nand men were certainly more loving towards it. The vines with which it\r\nwas partially clad, and the sprinkling of trees, chiefly figs and old\r\nwild olives, were comparatively green. Down to the dry bed of the\r\nCedron the verdure extended, a refreshment to the vision; there Olivet\r\nceased and Moriah began\xe2\x80\x94a wall of bluff boldness, white as snow,\r\nfounded by Solomon, completed by Herod. Up, up the wall the eye climbed\r\ncourse by course of the ponderous rocks composing it\xe2\x80\x94up to Solomon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nPorch, which was as the pedestal of the monument, the hill being the\r\nplinth. Lingering there a moment, the eye resumed its climbing, going\r\nnext to the Gentiles\xe2\x80\x99 Court, then to the Israelites\xe2\x80\x99 Court, then to the\r\nWomen\xe2\x80\x99s Court, then to the Court of the Priests, each a pillared tier\r\nof white marble, one above the other in terraced retrocession; over\r\nthem all a crown of crowns infinitely sacred, infinitely beautiful,\r\nmajestic in proportions, effulgent with beaten gold\xe2\x80\x94lo! the Tent, the\r\nTabernacle, the Holy of Holies. The Ark was not there, but Jehovah\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94in the faith of every child of Israel he was there a personal\r\nPresence. As a temple, as a monument, there was nowhere anything of\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s building to approach that superlative apparition. Now, not a\r\nstone of it remains above another. Who shall rebuild that building?\r\nWhen shall the rebuilding be begun? So asks every pilgrim who has stood\r\nwhere Ben-Hur was\xe2\x80\x94he asks, knowing the answer is in the bosom of God,\r\nwhose secrets are not least marvellous in their well-keeping. And then\r\nthe third question, What of him who foretold the ruin which has so\r\ncertainly befallen? God? Or man of God? Or\xe2\x80\x94enough that the question is\r\nfor us to answer.\r\n\r\nAnd still Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s eyes climbed on and up\xe2\x80\x94up over the roof of the\r\nTemple, to the hill Zion, consecrated to sacred memories, inseparable\r\nfrom the anointed kings. He knew the Cheesemonger\xe2\x80\x99s Valley dipped deep\r\ndown between Moriah and Zion; that it was spanned by the Xystus; that\r\nthere were gardens and palaces in its depths; but over them all his\r\nthoughts soared with his vision to the great grouping on the royal\r\nhill\xe2\x80\x94the house of Caiaphas, the Central Synagogue, the Roman\r\nPraetorium, Hippicus the eternal, and the sad but mighty cenotaphs\r\nPhasaelus and Mariamne\xe2\x80\x94all relieved against Gareb, purpling in the\r\ndistance. And when midst them he singled out the palace of Herod, what\r\ncould he but think of the King Who Was Coming, to whom he was himself\r\ndevoted, whose path he had undertaken to smooth, whose empty hands he\r\ndreamed of filling? And forward ran his fancy to the day the new King\r\nshould come to claim his own and take possession of it\xe2\x80\x94of Moriah and\r\nits Temple; of Zion and its towers and palaces; of Antonia, frowning\r\ndarkly there just to the right of the Temple; of the new unwalled city\r\nof Bezetha; of the millions of Israel to assemble with palm-branches\r\nand banners, to sing rejoicing because the Lord had conquered and given\r\nthem the world.\r\n\r\nMen speak of dreaming as if it were a phenomenon of night and sleep.\r\nThey should know better. All results achieved by us are self-promised,\r\nand all self-promises are made in dreams awake. Dreaming is the relief\r\nof labor, the wine that sustains us in act. We learn to love labor, not\r\nfor itself, but for the opportunity it furnishes for dreaming, which is\r\nthe great under-monotone of real life, unheard, unnoticed, because of\r\nits constancy. Living is dreaming. Only in the grave are there no\r\ndreams. Let no one smile at Ben-Hur for doing that which he himself\r\nwould have done at that time and place under the same circumstances.\r\n\r\nThe sun stooped low in its course. Awhile the flaring disk seemed to\r\nperch itself on the far summit of the mountains in the west, brazening\r\nall the sky above the city, and rimming the walls and towers with the\r\nbrightness of gold. Then it disappeared as with a plunge. The quiet\r\nturned Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s thought homeward. There was a point in the sky a\r\nlittle north of the peerless front of the Holy of Holies upon which he\r\nfixed his gaze: under it, straight as a leadline would have dropped,\r\nlay his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, if yet the house endured.\r\n\r\nThe mellowing influences of the evening mellowed his feelings, and,\r\nputting his ambitions aside, he thought of the duty that was bringing\r\nhim to Jerusalem.\r\n\r\nOut in the desert while with Ilderim, looking for strong places and\r\nacquainting himself with it generally, as a soldier studies a country\r\nin which he has projected a campaign, a messenger came one evening with\r\nthe news that Gratus was removed, and Pontius Pilate sent to take his\r\nplace.\r\n\r\nMessala was disabled and believed him dead; Gratus was powerless and\r\ngone; why should Ben-Hur longer defer the search for his mother and\r\nsister? There was nothing to fear now. If he could not himself see into\r\nthe prisons of Judea, he could examine them with the eyes of others. If\r\nthe lost were found, Pilate could have no motive in holding them in\r\ncustody\xe2\x80\x94none, at least, which could not be overcome by purchase. If\r\nfound, he would carry them to a place of safety, and then, in calmer\r\nmind, his conscience at rest, this one first duty done, he could give\r\nhimself more entirely to the King Who Was Coming. He resolved at once.\r\nThat night he counselled with Ilderim, and obtained his assent. Three\r\nArabs came with him to Jericho, where he left them and the horses, and\r\nproceeded alone and on foot. Malluch was to meet him in Jerusalem.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s scheme, be it observed, was as yet a generality.\r\n\r\nIn view of the future, it was advisable to keep himself in hiding from\r\nthe authorities, particularly the Romans. Malluch was shrewd and\r\ntrusty; the very man to charge with the conduct of the investigation.\r\n\r\nWhere to begin was the first point. He had no clear idea about it. His\r\nwish was to commence with the Tower of Antonia. Tradition not of long\r\nstanding planted the gloomy pile over a labyrinth of prison-cells,\r\nwhich, more even than the strong garrison, kept it a terror to the\r\nJewish fancy. A burial, such as his people had been subjected to, might\r\nbe possible there. Besides, in such a strait, the natural inclination\r\nis to start search at the place where the loss occurred, and he could\r\nnot forget that his last sight of the loved ones was as the guard\r\npushed them along the street in the direction to the Tower. If they\r\nwere not there now, but had been, some record of the fact must remain,\r\na clew which had only to be followed faithfully to the end.\r\n\r\nUnder this inclination, moreover, there was a hope which he could not\r\nforego. From Simonides he knew Amrah, the Egyptian nurse, was living.\r\nIt will be remembered, doubtless, that the faithful creature, the\r\nmorning the calamity overtook the Hurs, broke from the guard and ran\r\nback into the palace, where, along with other chattels, she had been\r\nsealed up. During the years following, Simonides kept her supplied; so\r\nshe was there now, sole occupant of the great house, which, with all\r\nhis offers, Gratus had not been able to sell. The story of its rightful\r\nowners sufficed to secure the property from strangers, whether\r\npurchasers or mere occupants. People going to and fro passed it with\r\nwhispers. Its reputation was that of a haunted house; derived probably\r\nfrom the infrequent glimpses of poor old Amrah, sometimes on the roof,\r\nsometimes in a latticed window. Certainly no more constant spirit ever\r\nabided than she; nor was there ever a tenement so shunned and fitted\r\nfor ghostly habitation. Now, if he could get to her, Ben-Hur fancied\r\nshe could help him to knowledge which, though faint, might yet be\r\nserviceable. Anyhow, sight of her in that place, so endeared by\r\nrecollection, would be to him a pleasure next to finding the objects of\r\nhis solicitude.\r\n\r\nSo, first of all things, he would go to the old house, and look for\r\nAmrah.\r\n\r\nThus resolved, he arose shortly after the going-down of the sun, and\r\nbegan descent of the Mount by the road which, from the summit, bends a\r\nlittle north of east. Down nearly at the foot, close by the bed of the\r\nCedron, he came to the intersection with the road leading south to the\r\nvillage of Siloam and the pool of that name. There he fell in with a\r\nherdsman driving some sheep to market. He spoke to the man, and joined\r\nhim, and in his company passed by Gethsemane on into the city through\r\nthe Fish Gate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was dark when, parting with the drover inside the gate, Ben-Hur\r\nturned into a narrow lane leading to the south. A few of the people\r\nwhom he met saluted him. The bouldering of the pavement was rough. The\r\nhouses on both sides were low, dark, and cheerless; the doors all\r\nclosed: from the roofs, occasionally, he heard women crooning to\r\nchildren. The loneliness of his situation, the night, the uncertainty\r\ncloaking the object of his coming, all affected him cheerlessly. With\r\nfeelings sinking lower and lower, he came directly to the deep\r\nreservoir now known as the Pool of Bethesda, in which the water\r\nreflected the over-pending sky. Looking up, he beheld the northern wall\r\nof the Tower of Antonia, a black frowning heap reared into the dim\r\nsteel-gray sky. He halted as if challenged by a threatening sentinel.\r\n\r\nThe Tower stood up so high, and seemed so vast, resting apparently upon\r\nfoundations so sure, that he was constrained to acknowledge its\r\nstrength. If his mother were there in living burial, what could he do\r\nfor her? By the strong hand, nothing. An army might beat the stony face\r\nwith ballista and ram, and be laughed at. Against him alone, the\r\ngigantic southeast turret looked down in the self-containment of a\r\nhill. And he thought, cunning is so easily baffled; and God, always the\r\nlast resort of the helpless\xe2\x80\x94God is sometimes so slow to act!\r\n\r\nIn doubt and misgiving, he turned into the street in front of the\r\nTower, and followed it slowly on to the west.\r\n\r\nOver in Bezetha he knew there was a khan, where it was his intention to\r\nseek lodging while in the city; but just now he could not resist the\r\nimpulse to go home. His heart drew him that way.\r\n\r\nThe old formal salutation which he received from the few people who\r\npassed him had never sounded so pleasantly. Presently, all the eastern\r\nsky began to silver and shine, and objects before invisible in the\r\nwest\xe2\x80\x94chiefly the tall towers on Mount Zion\xe2\x80\x94emerged as from a shadowy\r\ndepth, and put on spectral distinctness, floating, as it were, above\r\nthe yawning blackness of the valley below, very castles in the air.\r\n\r\nHe came, at length, to his father\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\nOf those who read this page, some there will be to divine his feelings\r\nwithout prompting. They are such as had happy homes in their youth, no\r\nmatter how far that may have been back in time\xe2\x80\x94homes which are now the\r\nstarting-points of all recollection; paradises from which they went\r\nforth in tears, and which they would now return to, if they could, as\r\nlittle children; places of laughter and singing, and associations\r\ndearer than any or all the triumphs of after-life.\r\n\r\nAt the gate on the north side of the old house Ben-Hur stopped. In the\r\ncorners the wax used in the sealing-up was still plainly seen, and\r\nacross the valves was the board with the inscription\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTHIS IS THE PROPERTY OF\r\nTHE EMPEROR.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNobody had gone in or out the gate since the dreadful day of the\r\nseparation. Should he knock as of old? It was useless, he knew; yet he\r\ncould not resist the temptation. Amrah might hear, and look out of one\r\nof the windows on that side. Taking a stone, he mounted the broad stone\r\nstep, and tapped three times. A dull echo replied. He tried again,\r\nlouder than before; and again, pausing each time to listen. The silence\r\nwas mocking. Retiring into the street, he watched the windows; but\r\nthey, too, were lifeless. The parapet on the roof was defined sharply\r\nagainst the brightening sky; nothing could have stirred upon it unseen\r\nby him, and nothing did stir.\r\n\r\nFrom the north side he passed to the west, where there were four\r\nwindows which he watched long and anxiously, but with as little effect.\r\nAt times his heart swelled with impotent wishes; at others, he trembled\r\nat the deceptions of his own fancy. Amrah made no sign\xe2\x80\x94not even a ghost\r\nstirred.\r\n\r\nSilently, then, he stole round to the south. There, too, the gate was\r\nsealed and inscribed. The mellow splendor of the August moon, pouring\r\nover the crest of Olivet, since termed the Mount of Offence, brought\r\nthe lettering boldly out; and he read, and was filled with rage. All he\r\ncould do was to wrench the board from its nailing, and hurl it into the\r\nditch. Then he sat upon the step, and prayed for the New King, and that\r\nhis coming might be hastened. As his blood cooled, insensibly he\r\nyielded to the fatigue of long travel in the summer heat, and sank down\r\nlower, and, at last, slept.\r\n\r\nAbout that time two women came down the street from the direction of\r\nthe Tower of Antonia, approaching the palace of the Hurs. They advanced\r\nstealthily, with timid steps, pausing often to listen. At the corner of\r\nthe rugged pile, one said to the other, in a low voice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is it, Tirzah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Tirzah, after a look, caught her mother\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and leaned upon her\r\nheavily, sobbing, but silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on, my child, because\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the mother hesitated and trembled;\r\nthen, with an effort to be calm, continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbecause when morning comes\r\nthey will put us out of the gate of the city to\xe2\x80\x94return no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah sank almost to the stones.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, between sobs; \xe2\x80\x9cI forgot. I had the feeling of\r\ngoing home. But we are lepers, and have no homes; we belong to the\r\ndead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother stooped and raised her tenderly, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWe have nothing to\r\nfear. Let us go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIndeed, lifting their empty hands, they could have run upon a legion\r\nand put it to flight.\r\n\r\nAnd, creeping in close to the rough wall, they glided on, like two\r\nghosts, till they came to the gate, before which they also paused.\r\nSeeing the board, they stepped upon the stone in the scarce cold tracks\r\nof Ben-Hur, and read the inscription\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the Property of the\r\nEmperor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen the mother clasped her hands, and, with upraised eyes, moaned in\r\nunutterable anguish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat now, mother? You scare me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the answer was, presently, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Tirzah, the poor are dead! He is\r\ndead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour brother! They took everything from him\xe2\x80\x94everything\xe2\x80\x94even this\r\nhouse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tirzah, vacantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will never be able to help us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow\xe2\x80\x94to-morrow, my child, we must find a seat by the wayside, and\r\nbeg alms as the lepers do; beg, or\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah leaned upon her again, and said, whispering, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us\xe2\x80\x94let us\r\ndie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d the mother said, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord has appointed our times, and\r\nwe are believers in the Lord. We will wait on him even in this. Come\r\naway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe caught Tirzah\xe2\x80\x99s hand as she spoke, and hastened to the west corner\r\nof the house, keeping close to the wall. No one being in sight there,\r\nthey kept on to the next corner, and shrank from the moonlight, which\r\nlay exceedingly bright over the whole south front, and along a part of\r\nthe street. The mother\xe2\x80\x99s will was strong. Casting one look back and up\r\nto the windows on the west side, she stepped out into the light,\r\ndrawing Tirzah after her; and the extent of their affliction was then\r\nto be seen\xe2\x80\x94on their lips and cheeks, in their bleared eyes, in their\r\ncracked hands; especially in the long, snaky locks, stiff with\r\nloathsome ichor, and, like their eyebrows, ghastly white. Nor was it\r\npossible to have told which was mother, which daughter; both alike\r\nseemed witch-like old.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHist!\xe2\x80\x9d said the mother. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is some one lying upon the step\xe2\x80\x94a man.\r\nLet us go round him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey crossed to the opposite side of the street quickly, and, in the\r\nshade there, moved on till before the gate, where they stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is asleep, Tirzah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man was very still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay here, and I will try the gate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the mother stole noiselessly across, and ventured to touch\r\nthe wicket; she never knew if it yielded, for that moment the man\r\nsighed, and, turning restlessly, shifted the handkerchief on his head\r\nin such manner that the face was left upturned and fair in the broad\r\nmoonlight. She looked down at it and started; then looked again,\r\nstooping a little, and arose and clasped her hands and raised her eyes\r\nto heaven in mute appeal. An instant so, and she ran back to Tirzah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs the Lord liveth, the man is my son\xe2\x80\x94thy brother!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in an\r\nawe-inspiring whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother?\xe2\x80\x94Judah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother caught her hand eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in the same enforced whisper, \xe2\x80\x9clet us look at him\r\ntogether\xe2\x80\x94once more\xe2\x80\x94only once\xe2\x80\x94then help thou thy servants, Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey crossed the street hand in hand ghostly-quick, ghostly-still. When\r\ntheir shadows fell upon him, they stopped. One of his hands was lying\r\nout upon the step palm up. Tirzah fell upon her knees, and would have\r\nkissed it; but the mother drew her back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for thy life; not for thy life! Unclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered.\r\n\r\nTirzah shrank from him, as if he were the leprous one.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was handsome as the manly are. His cheeks and forehead were\r\nswarthy from exposure to the desert sun and air; yet under the light\r\nmustache the lips were red, and the teeth shone white, and the soft\r\nbeard did not hide the full roundness of chin and throat. How beautiful\r\nhe appeared to the mother\xe2\x80\x99s eyes! How mightily she yearned to put her\r\narms about him, and take his head upon her bosom and kiss him, as had\r\nbeen her wont in his happy childhood! Where got she the strength to\r\nresist the impulse? From her love, O, reader!\xe2\x80\x94her mother-love, which,\r\nif thou wilt observe well, hath this unlikeness to any other love:\r\ntender to the object, it can be infinitely tyrannical to itself, and\r\nthence all its power of self-sacrifice. Not for restoration to health\r\nand fortune, not for any blessing of life, not for life itself, would\r\nshe have left her leprous kiss upon his cheek! Yet touch him she must;\r\nin that instant of finding him she must renounce him forever! How\r\nbitter, bitter hard it was, let some other mother say! She knelt down,\r\nand, crawling to his feet, touched the sole of one of his sandals with\r\nher lips, yellow though it was with the dust of the street\xe2\x80\x94and touched\r\nit again and again; and her very soul was in the kisses.\r\n\r\nHe stirred, and tossed his hand. They moved back, but heard him mutter\r\nin his dream,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother! Amrah! Where is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe fell off into the deep sleep.\r\n\r\nTirzah stared wistfully. The mother put her face in the dust,\r\nstruggling to suppress a sob so deep and strong it seemed her heart was\r\nbursting. Almost she wished he might waken.\r\n\r\nHe had asked for her; she was not forgotten; in his sleep he was\r\nthinking of her. Was it not enough?\r\n\r\nPresently mother beckoned to Tirzah, and they arose, and taking one\r\nmore look, as if to print his image past fading, hand in hand they\r\nrecrossed the street. Back in the shade of the wall there, they retired\r\nand knelt, looking at him, waiting for him to wake\xe2\x80\x94waiting some\r\nrevelation, they knew not what. Nobody has yet given us a measure for\r\nthe patience of a love like theirs.\r\n\r\nBy-and-by, the sleep being yet upon him, another woman appeared at the\r\ncorner of the palace. The two in the shade saw her plainly in the\r\nlight; a small figure, much bent, dark-skinned, gray-haired, dressed\r\nneatly in servant\xe2\x80\x99s garb, and carrying a basket full of vegetables.\r\n\r\nAt sight of the man upon the step the new-comer stopped; then, as if\r\ndecided, she walked on\xe2\x80\x94very lightly as she drew near the sleeper.\r\nPassing round him, she went to the gate, slid the wicket latch easily\r\nto one side, and put her hand in the opening. One of the broad boards\r\nin the left valve swung ajar without noise. She put the basket through,\r\nand was about to follow, when, yielding to curiosity, she lingered to\r\nhave one look at the stranger whose face was below her in open view.\r\n\r\nThe spectators across the street heard a low exclamation, and saw the\r\nwoman rub her eyes as if to renew their power, bend closer down, clasp\r\nher hands, gaze wildly around, look at the sleeper, stoop and raise the\r\noutlying hand, and kiss it fondly\xe2\x80\x94that which they wished so mightily to\r\ndo, but dared not.\r\n\r\nAwakened by the action, Ben-Hur instinctively withdrew the hand; as he\r\ndid so, his eyes met the woman\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah! O Amrah, is it thou?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe good heart made no answer in words, but fell upon his neck, crying\r\nfor joy.\r\n\r\nGently he put her arms away, and lifting the dark face wet with tears,\r\nkissed it, his joy only a little less than hers. Then those across the\r\nway heard him say,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x94Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94O Amrah, tell me of them! Speak, speak, I pray thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah only cried afresh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou has seen them, Amrah. Thou knowest where they are; tell me they\r\nare at home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah moved, but her mother, divining her purpose, caught her and\r\nwhispered, \xe2\x80\x9cDo not go\xe2\x80\x94not for life. Unclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer love was in tyrannical mood. Though both their hearts broke, he\r\nshould not become what they were; and she conquered.\r\n\r\nMeantime, Amrah, so entreated, only wept the more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWert thou going in?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, presently, seeing the board swung back.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then. I will go with thee.\xe2\x80\x9d He arose as he spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Romans\xe2\x80\x94be\r\nthe curse of the Lord upon them!\xe2\x80\x94the Romans lied. The house is mine.\r\nRise, Amrah, and let us go in.\xe2\x80\x9d A moment and they were gone, leaving\r\nthe two in the shade to behold the gate staring blankly at them\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ngate which they might not ever enter more. They nestled together in the\r\ndust.\r\n\r\nThey had done their duty.\r\n\r\nTheir love was proven.\r\n\r\nNext morning they were found, and driven out the city with stones.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegone!
