Ye are of the dead; go to the dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the doom ringing in their ears, they went forth.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nNowadays travellers in the Holy Land looking for the famous place with\r\nthe beautiful name, the King\xe2\x80\x99s Garden, descend the bed of the Cedron or\r\nthe curve of Gihon and Hinnom as far as the old well En-rogel, take a\r\ndrink of the sweet living water, and stop, having reached the limit of\r\nthe interesting in that direction. They look at the great stones with\r\nwhich the well is curbed, ask its depth, smile at the primitive mode of\r\ndrawing the purling treasure, and waste some pity on the ragged wretch\r\nwho presides over it; then, facing about, they are enraptured with the\r\nmounts Moriah and Zion, both of which slope towards them from the\r\nnorth, one terminating in Ophel, the other in what used to be the site\r\nof the city of David. In the background, up far in the sky, the\r\ngarniture of the sacred places is visible: here the Haram, with its\r\ngraceful dome; yonder the stalward remains of Hippicus, defiant even in\r\nruins. When that view has been enjoyed, and is sufficiently impressed\r\nupon the memory, the travellers glance at the Mount of Offence standing\r\nin rugged stateliness at their right hand, and then at the Hill of Evil\r\nCounsel over on the left, in which, if they be well up in Scriptural\r\nhistory and in the traditions rabbinical and monkish, they will find a\r\ncertain interest not to be overcome by superstitious horror.\r\n\r\nIt were long to tell all the points of interest grouped around that\r\nhill; for the present purpose, enough that its feet are planted in the\r\nveritable orthodox Hell of the moderns\xe2\x80\x94the Hell of brimstone and\r\nfire\xe2\x80\x94in the old nomenclature Gehenna; and that now, as in the days of\r\nChrist, its bluff face opposite the city on the south and southeast is\r\nseamed and pitted with tombs which have been immemorially the\r\ndwelling-places of lepers, not singly, but collectively. There they set\r\nup their government and established their society; there they founded a\r\ncity and dwelt by themselves, avoided as the accursed of God.\r\n\r\nThe second morning after the incidents of the preceding chapter, Amrah\r\ndrew near the well En-rogel, and seated herself upon a stone. One\r\nfamiliar with Jerusalem, looking at her, would have said she was the\r\nfavorite servant of some well-to-do family. She brought with her a\r\nwater-jar and a basket, the contents of the latter covered with a\r\nsnow-white napkin. Placing them on the ground at her side, she loosened\r\nthe shawl which fell from her head, knit her fingers together in her\r\nlap, and gazed demurely up to where the hill drops steeply down into\r\nAceldama and the Potter\xe2\x80\x99s Field.\r\n\r\nIt was very early, and she was the first to arrive at the well. Soon,\r\nhowever, a man came bringing a rope and a leathern bucket. Saluting the\r\nlittle dark-faced woman, he undid the rope, fixed it to the bucket, and\r\nwaited customers. Others who chose to do so might draw water for\r\nthemselves, he was a professional in the business, and would fill the\r\nlargest jar the stoutest woman could carry for a gerah.\r\n\r\nAmrah sat still, and had nothing to say. Seeing the jar, the man asked\r\nafter a while if she wished it filled; she answered him civilly, \xe2\x80\x9cNot\r\nnow;\xe2\x80\x9d whereupon he gave her no more attention. When the dawn was fairly\r\ndefined over Olivet, his patrons began to arrive, and he had all he\r\ncould do to attend to them. All the time she kept her seat, looking\r\nintently up at the hill.\r\n\r\nThe sun made its appearance, yet she sat watching and waiting; and\r\nwhile she thus waits, let us see what her purpose is.\r\n\r\nHer custom had been to go to market after nightfall. Stealing out\r\nunobserved, she would seek the shops in the Tyropoeon, or those over by\r\nthe Fish Gate in the east, make her purchases of meat and vegetables,\r\nand return and shut herself up again.\r\n\r\nThe pleasure she derived from the presence of Ben-Hur in the old house\r\nonce more may be imagined. She had nothing to tell him of her mistress\r\nor Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94nothing. He would have had her move to a place not so\r\nlonesome; she refused. She would have had him take his own room again,\r\nwhich was just as he had left it; but the danger of discovery was too\r\ngreat, and he wished above all things to avoid inquiry. He would come\r\nand see her often as possible. Coming in the night, he would also go\r\naway in the night. She was compelled to be satisfied, and at once\r\noccupied herself contriving ways to make him happy. That he was a man\r\nnow did not occur to her; nor did it enter her mind that he might have\r\nput by or lost his boyish tastes; to please him, she thought to go on\r\nher old round of services. He used to be fond of confections; she\r\nremembered the things in that line which delighted him most, and\r\nresolved to make them, and have a supply always ready when he came.\r\nCould anything be happier? So next night, earlier than usual, she stole\r\nout with her basket, and went over to the Fish Gate Market. Wandering\r\nabout, seeking the best honey, she chanced to hear a man telling a\r\nstory.\r\n\r\nWhat the story was the reader can arrive at with sufficient certainty\r\nwhen told that the narrator was one of the men who had held torches for\r\nthe commandant of the Tower of Antonia when, down in cell VI., the Hurs\r\nwere found. The particulars of the finding were all told, and she heard\r\nthem, with the names of the prisoners, and the widow\xe2\x80\x99s account of\r\nherself.\r\n\r\nThe feelings with which Amrah listened to the recital were such as\r\nbecame the devoted creature she was. She made her purchases, and\r\nreturned home in a dream. What a happiness she had in store for her\r\nboy! She had found his mother!\r\n\r\nShe put the basket away, now laughing, now crying. Suddenly she stopped\r\nand thought. It would kill him to be told that his mother and Tirzah\r\nwere lepers. He would go through the awful city over on the Hill of\r\nEvil Counsel\xe2\x80\x94into each infected tomb he would go without rest, asking\r\nfor them, and the disease would catch him, and their fate would be his.\r\nShe wrung her hands. What should she do?\r\n\r\nLike many a one before her, and many a one since, she derived\r\ninspiration, if not wisdom, from her affection, and came to a singular\r\nconclusion.\r\n\r\nThe lepers, she knew, were accustomed of mornings to come down from\r\ntheir sepulchral abodes in the hill, and take a supply of water for the\r\nday from the well En-rogel. Bringing their jars, they would set them on\r\nthe ground and wait, standing afar until they were filled. To that the\r\nmistress and Tirzah must come; for the law was inexorable, and admitted\r\nno distinction. A rich leper was no better than a poor one.\r\n\r\nSo Amrah decided not to speak to Ben-Hur of the story she had heard,\r\nbut go alone to the well and wait. Hunger and thirst would drive the\r\nunfortunates thither, and she believed she could recognize them at\r\nsight; if not, they might recognize her.\r\n\r\nMeantime Ben-Hur came, and they talked much. To-morrow Malluch would\r\narrive; then the search should be immediately begun. He was impatient\r\nto be about it. To amuse himself he would visit the sacred places in\r\nthe vicinity. The secret, we may be sure, weighed heavily on the woman,\r\nbut she held her peace.\r\n\r\nWhen he was gone she busied herself in the preparation of things good\r\nto eat, applying her utmost skill to the work. At the approach of day,\r\nas signalled by the stars, she filled the basket, selected a jar, and\r\ntook the road to En-rogel, going out by the Fish Gate which was\r\nearliest open, and arriving as we have seen.\r\n\r\nShortly after sunrise, when business at the well was most pressing, and\r\nthe drawer of water most hurried; when, in fact, half a dozen buckets\r\nwere in use at the same time, everybody making haste to get away before\r\nthe cool of the morning melted into the heat of the day, the tenantry\r\nof the hill began to appear and move about the doors of their tombs.\r\nSomewhat later they were discernible in groups, of which not a few were\r\nchildren so young that they suggested the holiest relation. Numbers\r\ncame momentarily around the turn of the bluff\xe2\x80\x94women with jars upon\r\ntheir shoulders, old and very feeble men hobbling along on staffs and\r\ncrutches. Some leaned upon the shoulders of others; a few\xe2\x80\x94the utterly\r\nhelpless\xe2\x80\x94lay, like heaps of rags, upon litters. Even that community of\r\nsuperlative sorrow had its love-light to make life endurable and\r\nattractive. Distance softened without entirely veiling the misery of\r\nthe outcasts.\r\n\r\nFrom her seat by the well Amrah kept watch upon the spectral groups.\r\nShe scarcely moved. More than once she imagined she saw those she\r\nsought. That they were there upon the hill she had no doubt; that they\r\nmust come down and near she knew; when the people at the well were all\r\nserved they would come.\r\n\r\nNow, quite at the base of the bluff there was a tomb which had more\r\nthan once attracted Amrah by its wide gaping. A stone of large\r\ndimensions stood near its mouth. The sun looked into it through the\r\nhottest hours of the day, and altogether it seemed uninhabitable by\r\nanything living, unless, perchance, by some wild dogs returning from\r\nscavenger duty down in Gehenna. Thence, however, and greatly to her\r\nsurprise, the patient Egyptian beheld two women come, one half\r\nsupporting, half leading, the other. They were both white-haired; both\r\nlooked old; but their garments were not rent, and they gazed about them\r\nas if the locality were new. The witness below thought she even saw\r\nthem shrink terrified at the spectacle offered by the hideous\r\nassemblage of which they found themselves part. Slight reasons,\r\ncertainly, to make her heart beat faster, and draw her attention to\r\nthem exclusively; but so they did.\r\n\r\nThe two remained by the stone awhile; then they moved slowly,\r\npainfully, and with much fear towards the well, whereat several voices\r\nwere raised to stop them; yet they kept on. The drawer of water picked\r\nup some pebbles, and made ready to drive them back. The company cursed\r\nthem. The greater company on the hill shouted shrilly, \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean,\r\nunclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Amrah of the two, as they kept coming\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csurely, they\r\nare strangers to the usage of lepers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe arose, and went to meet them, taking the basket and jar. The alarm\r\nat the well immediately subsided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fool,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a fool to give good bread to\r\nthe dead in that way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to think of her coming so far!\xe2\x80\x9d said another. \xe2\x80\x9cI would at least\r\nmake them meet me at the gate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah, with better impulse, proceeded. If she should be mistaken! Her\r\nheart arose into her throat. And the farther she went the more doubtful\r\nand confused she became. Four or five yards from where they stood\r\nwaiting for her she stopped.\r\n\r\nThat the mistress she loved! whose hand she had so often kissed in\r\ngratitude! whose image of matronly loveliness she had treasured in\r\nmemory so faithfully! And that the Tirzah she had nursed through\r\nbabyhood! whose pains she had soothed, whose sports she had shared!\r\nthat the smiling, sweet-faced, songful Tirzah, the light of the great\r\nhouse, the promised blessing of her old age! Her mistress, her\r\ndarling\xe2\x80\x94they? The soul of the woman sickened at the sight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are old women,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw them before. I\r\nwill go back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the lepers.\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian dropped the jar, and looked back, trembling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho called me?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant\xe2\x80\x99s wondering eyes settled upon the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d she cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are they you are seeking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah fell upon her knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my mistress, my mistress! As I have made your God my God, be he\r\npraised that he has led me to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd upon her knees the poor overwhelmed creature began moving forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Amrah! Come not nearer. Unclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words sufficed. Amrah fell upon her face, sobbing so loud the\r\npeople at the well heard her. Suddenly she arose upon her knees again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my mistress, where is Tirzah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am, Amrah, here! Will you not bring me a little water?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe habit of the servant renewed itself. Putting back the coarse hair\r\nfallen over her face, Amrah arose and went to the basket and uncovered\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9chere are bread and meat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe would have spread the napkin upon the ground, but the mistress\r\nspoke again,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not so, Amrah. Those yonder may stone you, and refuse us drink.\r\nLeave the basket with me. Take up the jar and fill it, and bring it\r\nhere. We will carry them to the tomb with us. For this day you will\r\nthen have rendered all the service that is lawful. Haste, Amrah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people under whose eyes all this had passed made way for the\r\nservant, and even helped her fill the jar, so piteous was the grief her\r\ncountenance showed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d a woman asked.\r\n\r\nAmrah meekly answered, \xe2\x80\x9cThey used to be good to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRaising the jar upon her shoulder, she hurried back. In forgetfulness,\r\nshe would have gone to them, but the cry \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean! Beware!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\narrested her. Placing the water by the basket, she stepped back, and\r\nstood off a little way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Amrah,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mistress, taking the articles into\r\npossession. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is very good of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there nothing more I can do?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Amrah.\r\n\r\nThe mother\xe2\x80\x99s hand was upon the jar, and she was fevered with thirst;\r\nyet she paused, and rising, said firmly, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know that Judah has\r\ncome home. I saw him at the gate night before last asleep on the step.\r\nI saw you wake him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah clasped her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my mistress! You saw it, and did not come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would have been to kill him. I can never take him in my arms\r\nagain. I can never kiss him more. O Amrah, Amrah, you love him, I\r\nknow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the true heart, bursting into tears again, and kneeling. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwould die for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProve to me what you say, Amrah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you shall not tell him where we are or that you have seen us\xe2\x80\x94only\r\nthat, Amrah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is looking for you. He has come from afar to find you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must not find us. He shall not become what we are. Hear, Amrah. You\r\nshall serve us as you have this day. You shall bring us the little we\r\nneed\xe2\x80\x94not long now\xe2\x80\x94not long. You shall come every morning and evening\r\nthus, and\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the voice trembled, the strong will almost broke\r\ndown\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand you shall tell us of him, Amrah; but to him you shall say\r\nnothing of us. Hear you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it will be so hard to hear him speak of you, and see him going\r\nabout looking for you\xe2\x80\x94to see all his love, and not tell him so much as\r\nthat you are alive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you tell him we are well, Amrah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant bowed her head in her arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d the mistress continued; \xe2\x80\x9cwherefore to be silent altogether. Go\r\nnow, and come this evening. We will look for you. Till then, farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe burden will be heavy, O my mistress, and hard to bear,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAmrah, falling upon her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much harder would it be to see him as we are,\xe2\x80\x9d the mother answered\r\nas she gave the basket to Tirzah. \xe2\x80\x9cCome again this evening,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nrepeated, taking up the water, and starting for the tomb.\r\n\r\nAmrah waited kneeling until they had disappeared; then she took the\r\nroad sorrowfully home.\r\n\r\nIn the evening she returned; and thereafter it became her custom to\r\nserve them in the morning and evening, so that they wanted for nothing\r\nneedful. The tomb, though ever so stony and desolate, was less\r\ncheerless than the cell in the Tower had been. Daylight gilded its\r\ndoor, and it was in the beautiful world. Then, one can wait death with\r\nso much more faith out under the open sky.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe morning of the first day of the seventh month\xe2\x80\x94Tishri in the Hebrew,\r\nOctober in English\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur arose from his couch in the khan ill\r\nsatisfied with the whole world.\r\n\r\nLittle time had been lost in consultation upon the arrival of Malluch.\r\nThe latter began the search at the Tower of Antonia, and began it\r\nboldly, by a direct inquiry of the tribune commanding. He gave the\r\nofficer a history of the Hurs, and all the particulars of the accident\r\nto Gratus, describing the affair as wholly without criminality. The\r\nobject of the quest now, he said, was if any of the unhappy family were\r\ndiscovered alive to carry a petition to the feet of Caesar, praying\r\nrestitution of the estate and return to their civil rights. Such a\r\npetition, he had no doubt, would result in an investigation by the\r\nimperial order, a proceeding of which the friends of the family had no\r\nfear.\r\n\r\nIn reply the tribune stated circumstantially the discovery of the women\r\nin the Tower, and permitted a reading of the memorandum he had taken of\r\ntheir account of themselves; when leave to copy it was prayed, he even\r\npermitted that.\r\n\r\nMalluch thereupon hurried to Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nIt were useless to attempt description of the effect the terrible story\r\nhad upon the young man. The pain was not relieved by tears or\r\npassionate outcries; it was too deep for any expression. He sat still a\r\nlong time, with pallid face and laboring heart. Now and then, as if to\r\nshow the thoughts which were most poignant, he muttered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLepers, lepers! They\xe2\x80\x94my mother and Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94they lepers! How long, how\r\nlong, O Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne moment he was torn by a virtuous rage of sorrow, next by a longing\r\nfor vengeance which, it must be admitted, was scarcely less virtuous.\r\n\r\nAt length he arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must look for them. They may be dying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere will you look?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Malluch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is but one place for them to go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMalluch interposed, and finally prevailed so far as to have the\r\nmanagement of the further attempt intrusted to him. Together they went\r\nto the gate over on the side opposite the Hill of Evil Counsel,\r\nimmemorially the lepers\xe2\x80\x99 begging-ground. There they stayed all day,\r\ngiving alms, asking for the two women, and offering rich rewards for\r\ntheir discovery. So they did in repetition day after day through the\r\nremainder of the fifth month, and all the sixth. There was diligent\r\nscouring of the dread city on the hill by lepers to whom the rewards\r\noffered were mighty incentives, for they were only dead in law. Over\r\nand over again the gaping tomb down by the well was invaded, and its\r\ntenants subjected to inquiry; but they kept their secret fast. The\r\nresult was failure. And now, the morning of the first day of the\r\nseventh month, the extent of the additional information gained was that\r\nnot long before two leprous women had been stoned from the Fish Gate by\r\nthe authorities. A little pressing of the clew, together with some\r\nshrewd comparison of dates, led to the sad assurance that the sufferers\r\nwere the Hurs, and left the old questions darker than ever. Where were\r\nthey? And what had become of them?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not enough that my people should be made lepers,\xe2\x80\x9d said the son,\r\nover and over again, with what intensity of bitterness the reader may\r\nimagine; \xe2\x80\x9cthat was not enough. Oh no! They must be stoned from their\r\nnative city! My mother is dead! she has wandered to the wilderness! she\r\nis dead! Tirzah is dead! I alone am left. And for what? How long, O\r\nGod, thou Lord God of my fathers, how long shall this Rome endure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAngry, hopeless, vengeful, he entered the court of the khan, and found\r\nit crowded with people come in during the night. While he ate his\r\nbreakfast, he listened to some of them. To one party he was specially\r\nattracted. They were mostly young, stout, active, hardy men, in manner\r\nand speech provincial. In their look, the certain indefinable air, the\r\npose of the head, glance of the eye, there was a spirit which did not,\r\nas a rule, belong to the outward seeming of the lower orders of\r\nJerusalem; the spirit thought by some to be a peculiarity of life in\r\nmountainous districts, but which may be more surely traced to a life of\r\nhealthful freedom. In a short time he ascertained they were Galileans,\r\nin the city for various purposes, but chiefly to take part in the Feast\r\nof Trumpets, set for that day. They became to him at once objects of\r\ninterest, as hailing from the region in which he hoped to find readiest\r\nsupport in the work he was shortly to set about.\r\n\r\nWhile observing them, his mind running ahead in thought of achievements\r\npossible to a legion of such spirits disciplined after the severe Roman\r\nstyle, a man came into the court, his face much flushed, his eyes\r\nbright with excitement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the Galileans. \xe2\x80\x9cThe rabbis and elders\r\nare going from the Temple to see Pilate. Come, make haste, and let us\r\ngo with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey surrounded him in a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo see Pilate! For what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have discovered a conspiracy. Pilate\xe2\x80\x99s new aqueduct is to be paid\r\nfor with money of the Temple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, with the sacred treasure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey repeated the question to each other with flashing eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Corban\xe2\x80\x94money of God. Let him touch a shekel of it if he dare!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the messenger. \xe2\x80\x9cThe procession is by this time across the\r\nbridge. The whole city is pouring after. We may be needed. Make haste!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs if the thought and the act were one, there was quick putting away of\r\nuseless garments, and the party stood forth bareheaded, and in the\r\nshort sleeveless under-tunics they were used to wearing as reapers in\r\nthe field and boatmen on the lake\xe2\x80\x94the garb in which they climbed the\r\nhills following the herds, and plucked the ripened vintage, careless of\r\nthe sun. Lingering only to tighten their girdles, they said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are\r\nready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Ben-Hur spoke to them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen of Galilee,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a son of Judah. Will you take me in\r\nyour company?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe may have to fight,\xe2\x80\x9d they replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then, I will not be first to run away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey took the retort in good humor, and the messenger said, \xe2\x80\x9cYou seem\r\nstout enough. Come along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur put off his outer garments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think there may be fighting?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, quietly, as he tightened\r\nhis girdle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe guard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLegionaries?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom else can a Roman trust?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you to fight with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey looked at him silently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will have to do the best we can; but had we\r\nnot better choose a leader? The legionaries always have one, and so are\r\nable to act with one mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Galileans stared more curiously, as if the idea were new to them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us at least agree to stay together,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I am ready, if\r\nyou are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe khan, it should not be forgotten, was in Bezetha, the new town; and\r\nto get to the Praetorium, as the Romans resonantly styled the palace of\r\nHerod on Mount Zion, the party had to cross the lowlands north and west\r\nof the Temple. By streets\xe2\x80\x94if they may be so called\xe2\x80\x94trending north and\r\nsouth, with intersections hardly up to the dignity of alleys, they\r\npassed rapidly round the Akra district to the Tower of Mariamne, from\r\nwhich the way was short to the grand gate of the walled heights. In\r\ngoing, they overtook, or were overtaken by, people like themselves\r\nstirred to wrath by news of the proposed desecration. When, at length,\r\nthey reached the gate of the Praetorium, the procession of elders and\r\nrabbis had passed in with a great following, leaving a greater crowd\r\nclamoring outside.\r\n\r\nA centurion kept the entrance with a guard drawn up full armed under\r\nthe beautiful marble battlements. The sun struck the soldiers fervidly\r\non helm and shield; but they kept their ranks indifferent alike to its\r\ndazzle and to the mouthings of the rabble. Through the open bronze\r\ngates a current of citizens poured in, while a much lesser one poured\r\nout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is going on?\xe2\x80\x9d one of the Galileans asked an outcomer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply. \xe2\x80\x9cThe rabbis are before the door of the palace\r\nasking to see Pilate. He has refused to come out. They have sent one to\r\ntell him they will not go away till he has heard them. They are\r\nwaiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, in his quiet way, seeing what his\r\ncompanions probably did not, that there was not only a disagreement\r\nbetween the suitors and the governor, but an issue joined, and a\r\nserious question as to who should have his will.\r\n\r\nInside the gate there was a row of trees in leaf, with seats under\r\nthem. The people, whether going or coming, carefully avoided the shade\r\ncast gratefully upon the white, clean-swept pavement; for, strange as\r\nit may seem, a rabbinical ordinance, alleged to have been derived from\r\nthe law, permitted no green thing to be grown within the walls of\r\nJerusalem. Even the wise king, it was said, wanting a garden for his\r\nEgyptian bride, was constrained to found it down in the meeting-place\r\nof the valleys above En-rogel.\r\n\r\nThrough the tree-tops shone the outer fronts of the palace. Turning to\r\nthe right, the party proceeded a short distance to a spacious square,\r\non the west side of which stood the residence of the governor. An\r\nexcited multitude filled the square. Every face was directed towards a\r\nportico built over a broad doorway which was closed. Under the portico\r\nthere was another array of legionaries.\r\n\r\nThe throng was so close the friends could not well have advanced if\r\nsuch had been their desire; they remained therefore in the rear,\r\nobservers of what was going on. About the portico they could see the\r\nhigh turbans of the rabbis, whose impatience communicated at times to\r\nthe mass behind them; a cry was frequent to the effect \xe2\x80\x9cPilate, if thou\r\nbe a governor, come forth, come forth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnce a man coming out pushed through the crowd, his face red with\r\nanger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsrael is of no account here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a loud voice. \xe2\x80\x9cOn this holy\r\nground we are no better than dogs of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill he not come out, think you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome? Has he not thrice refused?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will the rabbis do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs at Caesarea\xe2\x80\x94camp here till he gives them ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will not dare touch the treasure, will he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one of the\r\nGalileans.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho can say? Did not a Roman profane the Holy of Holies? Is there\r\nanything sacred from Romans?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn hour passed, and though Pilate deigned them no answer, the rabbis\r\nand crowd remained. Noon came, bringing a shower from the west, but no\r\nchange in the situation, except that the multitude was larger and much\r\nnoisier, and the feeling more decidedly angry. The shouting was almost\r\ncontinuous, Come forth, come forth! The cry was sometimes with\r\ndisrespectful variations. Meanwhile Ben-Hur held his Galilean friends\r\ntogether. He judged the pride of the Roman would eventually get the\r\nbetter of his discretion, and that the end could not be far off. Pilate\r\nwas but waiting for the people to furnish him an excuse for resort to\r\nviolence.\r\n\r\nAnd at last the end came. In the midst of the assemblage there was\r\nheard the sound of blows, succeeded instantly by yells of pain and\r\nrage, and a most furious commotion. The venerable men in front of the\r\nportico faced about aghast. The common people in the rear at first\r\npushed forward; in the centre, the effort was to get out; and for a\r\nshort time the pressure of opposing forces was terrible. A thousand\r\nvoices made inquiry, raised all at once; as no one had time to answer,\r\nthe surprise speedily became a panic.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur kept his senses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot see?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to one of the Galileans.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will raise you up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe caught the man about the middle, and lifted him bodily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are some armed with clubs, and they\r\nare beating the people. They are dressed like Jews.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRomans, as the Lord liveth! Romans in disguise. Their clubs fly like\r\nflails! There, I saw a rabbi struck down\xe2\x80\x94an old man! They spare\r\nnobody!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur let the man down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen of Galilee,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a trick of Pilate\xe2\x80\x99s. Now, will you do\r\nwhat I say, we will get even with the club-men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Galilean spirit arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d they answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go back to the trees by the gate, and we may find the planting\r\nof Herod, though unlawful, has some good in it after all. Come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey ran back all of them fast as they could; and, by throwing their\r\nunited weight upon the limbs, tore them from the trunks. In a brief\r\ntime they, too, were armed. Returning, at the corner of the square they\r\nmet the crowd rushing madly for the gate. Behind, the clamor\r\ncontinued\xe2\x80\x94a medley of shrieks, groans, and execrations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the wall!\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur shouted. \xe2\x80\x9cTo the wall!\xe2\x80\x94and let the herd go by!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo, clinging to the masonry at their right hand, they escaped the might\r\nof the rush, and little by little made headway until, at last, the\r\nsquare was reached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep together now, and follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy this time Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s leadership was perfect; and as he pushed into\r\nthe seething mob his party closed after him in a body. And when the\r\nRomans, clubbing the people and making merry as they struck them down,\r\ncame hand to hand with the Galileans, lithe of limb, eager for the\r\nfray, and equally armed, they were in turn surprised. Then the shouting\r\nwas close and fierce; the crash of sticks rapid and deadly; the advance\r\nfurious as hate could make it. No one performed his part as well as\r\nBen-Hur, whose training served him admirably; for, not merely he knew\r\nto strike and guard; his long arm, perfect action, and incomparable\r\nstrength helped him, also, to success in every encounter. He was at the\r\nsame time fighting-man and leader. The club he wielded was of goodly\r\nlength and weighty, so he had need to strike a man but once. He seemed,\r\nmoreover, to have eyes for each combat of his friends, and the faculty\r\nof being at the right moment exactly where he was most needed. In his\r\nfighting cry there were inspiration for his party and alarm for his\r\nenemies. Thus surprised and equally matched, the Romans at first\r\nretired, but finally turned their backs and fled to the portico. The\r\nimpetuous Galileans would have pursued them to the steps, but Ben-Hur\r\nwisely restrained them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, my men!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe centurion yonder is coming with the\r\nguard. They have swords and shields; we cannot fight them. We have done\r\nwell; let us get back and out of the gate while we may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey obeyed him, though slowly; for they had frequently to step over\r\ntheir countrymen lying where they had been felled; some writhing and\r\ngroaning, some praying help, others mute as the dead. But the fallen\r\nwere not all Jews. In that there was consolation.\r\n\r\nThe centurion shouted to them as they went off; Ben-Hur laughed at him,\r\nand replied in his own tongue, \xe2\x80\x9cIf we are dogs of Israel, you are\r\njackals of Rome. Remain here, and we will come again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Galileans cheered, and laughing went on.\r\n\r\nOutside the gate there was a multitude the like of which Ben-Hur had\r\nnever seen, not even in the circus at Antioch. The house-tops, the\r\nstreets, the slope of the hill, appeared densely covered with people\r\nwailing and praying. The air was filled with their cries and\r\nimprecations.\r\n\r\nThe party were permitted to pass without challenge by the outer guard.\r\nBut hardly were they out before the centurion in charge at the portico\r\nappeared, and in the gateway called to Ben-Hur,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo, insolent! Art thou a Roman or a Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a son of Judah, born here. What wouldst thou\r\nwith me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay and fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSingly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs thou wilt!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur laughed derisively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO brave Roman! Worthy son of the bastard Roman Jove! I have no arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt have mine,\xe2\x80\x9d the centurion answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI will borrow of the\r\nguard here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people in hearing of the colloquy became silent; and from them the\r\nhush spread afar. But lately Ben-Hur had beaten a Roman under the eyes\r\nof Antioch and the Farther East; now, could he beat another one under\r\nthe eyes of Jerusalem, the honor might be vastly profitable to the\r\ncause of the New King. He did not hesitate. Going frankly to the\r\ncenturion, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI am willing. Lend me thy sword and shield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the helm and breastplate?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Roman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep them. They might not fit me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe arms were as frankly delivered, and directly the centurion was\r\nready. All this time the soldiers in rank close by the gate never\r\nmoved; they simply listened. As to the multitude, only when the\r\ncombatants advanced to begin the fight the question sped from mouth to\r\nmouth, \xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d And no one knew.\r\n\r\nNow the Roman supremacy in arms lay in three things\xe2\x80\x94submission to\r\ndiscipline, the legionary formation of battle, and a peculiar use of\r\nthe short sword. In combat, they never struck or cut; from first to\r\nlast they thrust\xe2\x80\x94they advanced thrusting, they retired thrusting; and\r\ngenerally their aim was at the foeman\xe2\x80\x99s face. All this was well known\r\nto Ben-Hur. As they were about to engage he said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told thee I was a son of Judah; but I did not tell that I am\r\nlanista-taught. Defend thyself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the last word Ben-Hur closed with his antagonist. A moment, standing\r\nfoot to foot, they glared at each other over the rims of their embossed\r\nshields; then the Roman pushed forward and feinted an under-thrust. The\r\nJew laughed at him. A thrust at the face followed. The Jew stepped\r\nlightly to the left; quick as the thrust was, the step was quicker.\r\nUnder the lifted arm of the foe he slid his shield, advancing it until\r\nthe sword and sword-arm were both caught on its upper surface; another\r\nstep, this time forward and left, and the man\xe2\x80\x99s whole right side was\r\noffered to the point. The centurion fell heavily on his breast,\r\nclanging the pavement, and Ben-Hur had won. With his foot upon his\r\nenemy\xe2\x80\x99s back, he raised his shield overhead after a gladiatorial\r\ncustom, and saluted the imperturbable soldiers by the gate.\r\n\r\nWhen the people realized the victory they behaved like mad. On the\r\nhouses far as the Xystus, fast as the word could fly, they waved their\r\nshawls and handkerchiefs and shouted; and if he had consented, the\r\nGalileans would have carried Ben-Hur off upon their shoulders.\r\n\r\nTo a petty officer who then advanced from the gate he said, \xe2\x80\x9cThy\r\ncomrade died like a soldier. I leave him undespoiled. Only his sword\r\nand shield are mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that, he walked away. Off a little he spoke to the Galileans.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrethren, you have behaved well. Let us now separate, lest we be\r\npursued. Meet me to-night at the khan in Bethany. I have something to\r\npropose to you of great interest to Israel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d they asked him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA son of Judah,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, simply.\r\n\r\nA throng eager to see him surged around the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you come to Bethany?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we will come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen bring with you this sword and shield that I may know you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPushing brusquely through the increasing crowd, he speedily\r\ndisappeared.\r\n\r\nAt the instance of Pilate, the people went up from the city, and\r\ncarried off their dead and wounded, and there was much mourning for\r\nthem; but the grief was greatly lightened by the victory of the unknown\r\nchampion, who was everywhere sought, and by every one extolled. The\r\nfainting spirit of the nation was revived by the brave deed; insomuch\r\nthat in the streets and up in the Temple even, amidst the solemnities\r\nof the feast, old tales of the Maccabees were told again, and thousands\r\nshook their heads whispering wisely,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little longer, only a little longer, brethren, and Israel will come\r\nto her own. Let there be faith in the Lord, and patience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn such manner Ben-Hur obtained hold on Galilee, and paved the way to\r\ngreater services in the cause of the King Who Was Coming.\r\n\r\nAnd with what result we shall see.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK SEVENTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, waking, I beheld her there\r\nSea-dreaming in the moted air,\r\nA siren lithe and debonair,\r\nWith wristlets woven of scarlet weeds,\r\nAnd oblong lucent amber beads\r\nOf sea-kelp shining in her hair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTHOMAS BAILEY ALDRICH.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThe meeting took place in the khan of Bethany as appointed. Thence\r\nBen-Hur went with the Galileans into their country, where his exploits\r\nup in the old Market-place gave him fame and influence. Before the\r\nwinter was gone he raised three legions, and organized them after the\r\nRoman pattern. He could have had as many more, for the martial spirit\r\nof that gallant people never slept. The proceeding, however, required\r\ncareful guarding as against both Rome and Herod Antipas. Contenting\r\nhimself for the present with the three, he strove to train and educate\r\nthem for systematic action. For that purpose he carried the officers\r\nover into the lava-beds of Trachonitis, and taught them the use of\r\narms, particularly the javelin and sword, and the manoeuvering peculiar\r\nto the legionary formation; after which he sent them home as teachers.\r\nAnd soon the training became a pastime of the people.\r\n\r\nAs may be thought, the task called for patience, skill, zeal, faith,\r\nand devotion on his part\xe2\x80\x94qualities into which the power of inspiring\r\nothers in matters of difficulty is always resolvable; and never man\r\npossessed them in greater degree or used them to better effect. How he\r\nlabored! And with utter denial of self! Yet withal he would have failed\r\nbut for the support he had from Simonides, who furnished him arms and\r\nmoney, and from Ilderim, who kept watch and brought him supplies. And\r\nstill he would have failed but for the genius of the Galileans.\r\n\r\nUnder that name were comprehended the four tribes\xe2\x80\x94Asher, Zebulon,\r\nIssachar, and Naphthali\xe2\x80\x94and the districts originally set apart to them.\r\nThe Jew born in sight of the Temple despised these brethren of the\r\nnorth; but the Talmud itself has said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Galilean loves honor, and\r\nthe Jew money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHating Rome fervidly as they loved their own country, in every revolt\r\nthey were first in the field and last to leave it. One hundred and\r\nfifty thousand Galilean youths perished in the final war with Rome. For\r\nthe great festal days, they went up to Jerusalem marching and camping\r\nlike armies; yet they were liberal in sentiment, and even tolerant to\r\nheathenism. In Herod\xe2\x80\x99s beautiful cities, which were Roman in all\r\nthings, in Sepphoris and Tiberias especially, they took pride, and in\r\nthe building them gave loyal support. They had for fellow-citizens men\r\nfrom the outside world everywhere, and lived in peace with them. To the\r\nglory of the Hebrew name they contributed poets like the singer of the\r\nSong of Songs and prophets like Hosea.\r\n\r\nUpon such a people, so quick, so proud, so brave, so devoted, so\r\nimaginative, a tale like that of the coming of the King was\r\nall-powerful. That he was coming to put Rome down would have been\r\nsufficient to enlist them in the scheme proposed by Ben-Hur; but when,\r\nbesides, they were assured he was to rule the world, more mighty than\r\nCaesar, more magnificent than Solomon, and that the rule was to last\r\nforever, the appeal was irresistible, and they vowed themselves to the\r\ncause body and soul. They asked Ben-Hur his authority for the sayings,\r\nand he quoted the prophets, and told them of Balthasar in waiting over\r\nin Antioch; and they were satisfied, for it was the old much-loved\r\nlegend of the Messiah, familiar to them almost as the name of the Lord;\r\nthe long-cherished dream with a time fixed for its realization. The\r\nKing was not merely coming now; he was at hand.\r\n\r\nSo with Ben-Hur the winter months rolled by, and spring came, with\r\ngladdening showers blown over from the summering sea in the west; and\r\nby that time so earnestly and successfully had he toiled that he could\r\nsay to himself and his followers, \xe2\x80\x9cLet the good King come. He has only\r\nto tell us where he will have his throne set up. We have the\r\nsword-hands to keep it for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd in all his dealings with the many men they knew him only as a son\r\nof Judah, and by that name.\r\n\r\n\r\nOne evening, over in Trachonitis, Ben-Hur was sitting with some of his\r\nGalileans at the mouth of the cave in which he quartered, when an Arab\r\ncourier rode to him, and delivered a letter. Breaking the package, he\r\nread,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJerusalem, Nisan IV.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA prophet has appeared who men say is Elias. He has been in the\r\nwilderness for years, and to our eyes he is a prophet; and such also is\r\nhis speech, the burden of which is of one much greater than himself,\r\nwho, he says, is to come presently, and for whom he is now waiting on\r\nthe eastern shore of the River Jordan. I have been to see and hear him,\r\nand the one he is waiting for is certainly the King you are awaiting.\r\nCome and judge for yourself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll Jerusalem is going out to the prophet, and with many people else\r\nthe shore on which he abides is like Mount Olivet in the last days of\r\nthe Passover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMALLUCH.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s face flushed with joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy this word, O my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cby this word, our waiting is at\r\nend. The herald of the King has appeared and announced him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon hearing the letter read, they also rejoiced at the promise it held\r\nout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet ready now,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cand in the morning set your faces homeward;\r\nwhen arrived there, send word to those under you, and bid them be ready\r\nto assemble as I may direct. For myself and you, I will go see if the\r\nKing be indeed at hand, and send you report. Let us, in the meantime,\r\nlive in the pleasure of the promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGoing into the cave, he addressed a letter to Ilderim, and another to\r\nSimonides, giving notice of the news received, and of his purpose to go\r\nup immediately to Jerusalem. The letters he despatched by swift\r\nmessengers. When night fell, and the stars of direction came out, he\r\nmounted, and with an Arab guide set out for the Jordan, intending to\r\nstrike the track of the caravans between Rabbath-Ammon and Damascus.\r\n\r\nThe guide was sure, and Aldebaran swift; so by midnight the two were\r\nout of the lava fastness speeding southward.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s purpose to turn aside at the break of day, and find a\r\nsafe place in which to rest; but the dawn overtook him while out in the\r\nDesert, and he kept on, the guide promising to bring him afterwhile to\r\na vale shut in by great rocks, where there were a spring, some\r\nmulberry-trees, and herbage in plenty for the horses.\r\n\r\nAs he rode thinking of the wondrous events so soon to happen, and of\r\nthe changes they were to bring about in the affairs of men and nations,\r\nthe guide, ever on the alert, called attention to an appearance of\r\nstrangers behind them. Everywhere around the Desert stretched away in\r\nwaves of sand, slowly yellowing in the growing light, and without any\r\ngreen thing visible. Over on the left, but still far off, a range of\r\nlow mountains extended, apparently interminable. In the vacancy of such\r\na waste an object in motion could not long continue a mystery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a camel with riders,\xe2\x80\x9d the guide said, directly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre there others behind?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is alone. No, there is a man on horseback\xe2\x80\x94the driver, probably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA little later Ben-Hur himself could see the camel was white and\r\nunusually large, reminding him of the wonderful animal he had seen\r\nbring Balthasar and Iras to the fountain in the Grove of Daphne. There\r\ncould be no other like it. Thinking then of the fair Egyptian,\r\ninsensibly his gait became slower, and at length fell into the merest\r\nloiter, until finally he could discern a curtained houdah, and two\r\npersons seated within it. If they were Balthasar and Iras! Should he\r\nmake himself known to them? But it could not be: this was the\r\nDesert\xe2\x80\x94and they were alone. But while he debated the question the long\r\nswinging stride of the camel brought its riders up to him. He heard the\r\nringing of the tiny bells, and beheld the rich housings which had been\r\nso attractive to the crowd at the Castalian fount. He beheld also the\r\nEthiopian, always attendant upon the Egyptians. The tall brute stopped\r\nclose by his horse, and Ben-Hur, looking up, lo! Iras herself under the\r\nraised curtain looking down at him, her great swimming eyes bright with\r\nastonishment and inquiry!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe blessing of the true God upon you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, in his\r\ntremulous voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to thee and thine be the peace of the Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy eyes are weak with years,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar; \xe2\x80\x9cbut they approve you\r\nthat son of Hur whom lately I knew an honored guest in the tent of\r\nIlderim the Generous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou art that Balthasar, the wise Egyptian, whose speech\r\nconcerning certain holy things in expectation is having so much to do\r\nwith the finding me in this waste place. What dost thou here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is never alone who is where God is\xe2\x80\x94and God is everywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nBalthasar answered, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cbut in the sense of your asking, there is\r\na caravan short way behind us going to Alexandria; and as it is to pass\r\nthrough Jerusalem, I thought best to avail myself of its company as far\r\nas the Holy City, whither I am journeying. This morning, however, in\r\ndiscontent with its slow movement\xe2\x80\x94slower because of a Roman cohort in\r\nattendance upon it\xe2\x80\x94we rose early, and ventured thus far in advance. As\r\nto robbers along the way, we are not afraid, for I have here a signet\r\nof Sheik Ilderim; against beasts of prey, God is our sufficient trust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur bowed and said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe good sheik\xe2\x80\x99s signet is a safeguard\r\nwherever the wilderness extends, and the lion shall be swift that\r\novertakes this king of his kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe patted the neck of the camel as he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Iras, with a smile which was not lost upon the youth, whose\r\neyes, it must be admitted, had several times turned to her during the\r\ninterchange of speeches with the elder\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYet even he would be better if\r\nhis fast were broken. Kings have hunger and headaches. If you be,\r\nindeed, the Ben-Hur of whom my father has spoken, and whom it was my\r\npleasure to have known as well, you will be happy, I am sure, to show\r\nus some near path to living water, that with its sparkle we may grace a\r\nmorning\xe2\x80\x99s meal in the Desert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur, nothing loath, hastened to answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair Egyptian, I give you sympathy. Can you bear suffering a little\r\nlonger, we will find the spring you ask for, and I promise that its\r\ndraught shall be as sweet and cooling as that of the more famous\r\nCastalia. With leave, we will make haste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you the blessing of the thirsty,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied; \xe2\x80\x9cand offer you\r\nin return a bit of bread from the city ovens, dipped in fresh butter\r\nfrom the dewy meadows of Damascus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA most rare favor! Let us go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, Ben-Hur rode forward with the guide, one of the\r\ninconveniences of travelling with camels being that it is necessarily\r\nan interdiction of polite conversation.\r\n\r\nAfterwhile the party came to a shallow wady, down which, turning to the\r\nright hand, the guide led them. The bed of the cut was somewhat soft\r\nfrom recent rains, and quite bold in its descent. Momentarily, however,\r\nit widened; and erelong the sides became bluffs ribbed with rocks much\r\nscarred by floods rushing to lower depths ahead. Finally, from a narrow\r\npassage, the travellers entered a spreading vale which was very\r\ndelightful; but come upon suddenly from the yellow, unrelieved,\r\nverdureless plain, it had the effect of a freshly discovered Paradise.\r\nThe water-channels winding here and there, definable by crisp white\r\nshingling, appeared like threads tangled among islands green with\r\ngrasses and fringed with reeds. Up from the final depths of the valley\r\nof the Jordan some venturous oleanders had crept, and with their large\r\nbloom now starred the sunken place. One palm-tree arose in royal\r\nassertion. The bases of the boundary-walls were cloaked with clambering\r\nvines, and under a leaning cliff over on the left the mulberry grove\r\nhad planted itself, proclaiming the spring which the party were\r\nseeking. And thither the guide conducted them, careless of whistling\r\npartridges and lesser birds of brighter hues roused whirring from the\r\nreedy coverts.\r\n\r\nThe water started from a crack in the cliff which some loving hand had\r\nenlarged into an arched cavity. Graven over it in bold Hebraic letters\r\nwas the word GOD. The graver had no doubt drunk there, and tarried many\r\ndays, and given thanks in that durable form. From the arch the stream\r\nran merrily over a flag spotted with bright moss, and leaped into a\r\npool glassy clear; thence it stole away between grassy banks, nursing\r\nthe trees before it vanished in the thirsty sand. A few narrow paths\r\nwere noticeable about the margin of the pool; otherwise the space\r\naround was untrodden turf, at sight of which the guide was assured of\r\nrest free from intrusion by men. The horses were presently turned\r\nloose, and from the kneeling camel the Ethiopian assisted Balthasar and\r\nIras; whereupon the old man, turning his face to the east, crossed his\r\nhands reverently upon his breast and prayed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring me a cup,\xe2\x80\x9d Iras said, with some impatience.\r\n\r\nFrom the houdah the slave brought her a crystal goblet; then she said\r\nto Ben-Hur,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will be your servant at the fountain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey walked to the pool together. He would have dipped the water for\r\nher, but she refused his offer, and kneeling, held the cup to be filled\r\nby the stream itself; nor yet content, when it was cooled and\r\noverrunning, she tendered him the first draught.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, putting the graceful hand aside, and seeing only the\r\nlarge eyes half hidden beneath the arches of the upraised brows, \xe2\x80\x9cbe\r\nthe service mine, I pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe persisted in having her way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my country, O son of Hur, we have a saying, \xe2\x80\x98Better a cupbearer to\r\nthe fortunate than minister to a king.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortunate!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThere were both surprise and inquiry in the tone of his voice and in\r\nhis look, and she said quickly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gods give us success as a sign by which we may know them on our\r\nside. Were you not winner in the Circus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis cheeks began to flush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was one sign. There is another. In a combat with swords you slew\r\na Roman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe flush deepened\xe2\x80\x94not so much for the triumphs themselves as the\r\nflattery there was in the thought that she had followed his career with\r\ninterest. A moment, and the pleasure was succeeded by a reflection. The\r\ncombat, he knew, was matter of report throughout the East; but the name\r\nof the victor had been committed to a very few\xe2\x80\x94Malluch, Ilderim, and\r\nSimonides. Could they have made a confidante of the woman? So with\r\nwonder and gratification he was confused; and seeing it, she arose and\r\nsaid, holding the cup over the pool,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO gods of Egypt! I give thanks for a hero discovered\xe2\x80\x94thanks that the\r\nvictim in the Palace of Idernee was not my king of men. And so, O holy\r\ngods, I pour and drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPart of the contents of the cup she returned to the stream, the rest\r\nshe drank. When she took the crystal from her lips, she laughed at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO son of Hur, is it a fashion of the very brave to be so easily\r\novercome by a woman? Take the cup now, and see if you cannot find a\r\nhappy word in it for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the cup, and stooped to refill it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA son of Israel has no gods whom he can libate,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, playing with\r\nthe water to hide his amazement, now greater than before. What more did\r\nthe Egyptian know about him? Had she been told of his relations with\r\nSimonides? And there was the treaty with Ilderim\xe2\x80\x94had she knowledge of\r\nthat also? He was struck with mistrust. Somebody had betrayed his\r\nsecrets, and they were serious. And, besides, he was going to\r\nJerusalem, just then of all the world the place where such intelligence\r\npossessed by an enemy might be most dangerous to him, his associates,\r\nand the cause. But was she an enemy? It is well for us that, while\r\nwriting is slow, thought is instantaneous. When the cup was fairly\r\ncooled, he filled it and arose, saying, with indifference well\r\naffected,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost fair, were I an Egyptian or a Greek or a Roman, I would say\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nraised the goblet overhead as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cO ye better gods! I give thanks\r\nthat there are yet left to the world, despite its wrongs and\r\nsufferings, the charm of beauty and the solace of love, and I drink to\r\nher who best represents them\xe2\x80\x94to Iras, loveliest of the daughters of the\r\nNile!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe laid her hand softly upon his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have offended against the law. The gods you have drunk to are\r\nfalse gods. Why shall I not tell the rabbis on you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is very little to tell for one who\r\nknows so much else that is really important.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go further\xe2\x80\x94I will go to the little Jewess who makes the roses\r\ngrow and the shadows flame in the house of the great merchant over in\r\nAntioch. To the rabbis I will accuse you of impenitence; to her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, to her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will repeat what you have said to me under the lifted cup, with the\r\ngods for witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was still a moment, as if waiting for the Egyptian to go on. With\r\nquickened fancy he saw Esther at her father\xe2\x80\x99s side listening to the\r\ndespatches he had forwarded\xe2\x80\x94sometimes reading them. In her presence he\r\nhad told Simonides the story of the affair in the Palace of Idernee.\r\nShe and Iras were acquainted; this one was shrewd and worldly; the\r\nother was simple and affectionate, and therefore easily won. Simonides\r\ncould not have broken faith\xe2\x80\x94nor Ilderim\xe2\x80\x94for if not held by honor, there\r\nwas no one, unless it might be himself, to whom the consequences of\r\nexposure were more serious and certain. Could Esther have been the\r\nEgyptian\xe2\x80\x99s informant? He did not accuse her; yet a suspicion was sown\r\nwith the thought, and suspicions, as we all know, are weeds of the mind\r\nwhich grow of themselves, and most rapidly when least wanted. Before he\r\ncould answer the allusion to the little Jewess, Balthasar came to the\r\npool.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are greatly indebted to you, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in his grave\r\nmanner. \xe2\x80\x9cThis vale is very beautiful; the grass, the trees, the shade,\r\ninvite us to stay and rest, and the spring here has the sparkle of\r\ndiamonds in motion, and sings to me of a loving God. It is not enough\r\nto thank you for the enjoyment we find; come sit with us, and taste our\r\nbread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuffer me first to serve you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that Ben-Hur filled the goblet, and gave it to Balthasar, who\r\nlifted his eyes in thanksgiving.\r\n\r\nImmediately the slave brought napkins; and after laving their hands and\r\ndrying them, the three seated themselves in Eastern style under the\r\ntent which years before had served the Wise Men at the meeting in the\r\nDesert. And they ate heartily of the good things taken from the camel\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npack.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nThe tent was cosily pitched beneath a tree where the gurgle of the\r\nstream was constantly in ear. Overhead the broad leaves hung motionless\r\non their stems; the delicate reed-stalks off in the pearly haze stood\r\nup arrowy-straight; occasionally a home-returning bee shot humming\r\nathwart the shade, and a partridge creeping from the sedge drank,\r\nwhistled to his mate, and ran away. The restfulness of the vale, the\r\nfreshness of the air, the garden beauty, the Sabbath stillness, seemed\r\nto have affected the spirits of the elder Egyptian; his voice,\r\ngestures, and whole manner were unusually gentle; and often as he bent\r\nhis eyes upon Ben-Hur conversing with Iras, they softened with pity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen we overtook you, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, at the conclusion of the\r\nrepast, \xe2\x80\x9cit seemed your face was also turned towards Jerusalem. May I\r\nask, without offence, if you are going so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going to the Holy City.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the great need I have to spare myself prolonged toil, I will\r\nfurther ask you, Is there a shorter road than that by Rabbath-Ammon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA rougher route, but shorter, lies by Gerasa and Rabbath-Gilead. It is\r\nthe one I design taking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am impatient,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar. \xe2\x80\x9cLatterly my sleep has been visited\r\nby dreams\xe2\x80\x94or rather by the same dream in repetition. A voice\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nnothing more\xe2\x80\x94comes and tells me, \xe2\x80\x98Haste\xe2\x80\x94arise! He whom thou hast so\r\nlong awaited is at hand.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean he that is to be King of the Jews?\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur asked, gazing at\r\nthe Egyptian in wonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have heard nothing of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, except the words of the voice in the dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, then, are tidings to make you glad as they made me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom his gown Ben-Hur drew the letter received from Malluch. The hand\r\nthe Egyptian held out trembled violently. He read aloud, and as he read\r\nhis feelings increased; the limp veins in his neck swelled and\r\nthrobbed. At the conclusion he raised his suffused eyes in thanksgiving\r\nand prayer. He asked no questions, yet had no doubts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast been very good to me, O God,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me, I pray\r\nthee, to see the Saviour again, and worship him, and thy servant will\r\nbe ready to go in peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words, the manner, the singular personality of the simple prayer,\r\ntouched Ben-Hur with a sensation new and abiding. God never seemed so\r\nactual and so near by; it was as if he were there bending over them or\r\nsitting at their side\xe2\x80\x94a Friend whose favors were to be had by the most\r\nunceremonious asking\xe2\x80\x94a Father to whom all his children were alike in\r\nlove\xe2\x80\x94Father, not more of the Jew than of the Gentile\xe2\x80\x94the Universal\r\nFather, who needed no intermediates, no rabbis, no priests, no\r\nteachers. The idea that such a God might send mankind a Saviour instead\r\nof a king appeared to Ben-Hur in a light not merely new, but so plain\r\nthat he could almost discern both the greater want of such a gift and\r\nits greater consistency with the nature of such a Deity. So he could\r\nnot resist asking,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow that he has come, O Balthasar, you still think he is to be a\r\nSaviour, and not a king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar gave him a look thoughtful as it was tender.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow shall I understand you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, in return. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Spirit, which\r\nwas the Star that was my guide of old, has not appeared to me since I\r\nmet you in the tent of the good sheik; that is to say, I have not seen\r\nor heard it as formerly. I believe the voice that spoke to me in my\r\ndreams was it; but other than that I have no revelation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will recall the difference between us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, with\r\ndeference. \xe2\x80\x9cYou were of opinion that he would be a king, but not as\r\nCaesar is; you thought his sovereignty would be spiritual, not of the\r\nworld.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes,\xe2\x80\x9d the Egyptian answered; \xe2\x80\x9cand I am of the same opinion now. I\r\nsee the divergence in our faith. You are going to meet a king of men, I\r\na Saviour of souls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused with the look often seen when people are struggling, with\r\nintroverted effort, to disentangle a thought which is either too high\r\nfor quick discernment or too subtle for simple expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me try, O son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, directly, \xe2\x80\x9cand help you to a clear\r\nunderstanding of my belief; then it may be, seeing how the spiritual\r\nkingdom I expect him to set up can be more excellent in every sense\r\nthan anything of mere Caesarean splendor, you will better understand\r\nthe reason of the interest I take in the mysterious person we are going\r\nto welcome.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you when the idea of a Soul in every man had its origin.\r\nMost likely the first parents brought it with them out of the garden in\r\nwhich they had their first dwelling. We all do know, however, that it\r\nhas never perished entirely out of mind. By some peoples it was lost,\r\nbut not by all; in some ages it dulled and faded, in others it was\r\noverwhelmed with doubts; but, in great goodness, God kept sending us at\r\nintervals mighty intellects to argue it back to faith and hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should there be a Soul in every man? Look, O son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94for one\r\nmoment look at the necessity of such a device. To lie down and die, and\r\nbe no more\xe2\x80\x94no more forever\xe2\x80\x94time never was when man wished for such an\r\nend; nor has the man ever been who did not in his heart promise himself\r\nsomething better. The monuments of the nations are all protests against\r\nnothingness after death; so are statues and inscriptions; so is\r\nhistory. The greatest of our Egyptian kings had his effigy cut-out of a\r\nhill of solid rock. Day after day he went with a host in chariots to\r\nsee the work; at last it was finished, never effigy so grand, so\r\nenduring: it looked like him\xe2\x80\x94the features were his, faithful even in\r\nexpression. Now may we not think of him saying in that moment of pride,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let Death come; there is an after-life for me!\xe2\x80\x99 He had his wish. The\r\nstatue is there yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is the after-life he thus secured? Only a recollection by\r\nmen\xe2\x80\x94a glory unsubstantial as moonshine on the brow of the great bust; a\r\nstory in stone\xe2\x80\x94nothing more. Meantime what has become of the king?\r\nThere is an embalmed body up in the royal tombs which once was his\xe2\x80\x94an\r\neffigy not so fair to look at as the other out in the Desert. But\r\nwhere, O son of Hur, where is the king himself? Is he fallen into\r\nnothingness? Two thousand years have gone since he was a man alive as\r\nyou and I are. Was his last breath the end of him?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo say yes would be to accuse God; let us rather accept his better\r\nplan of attaining life after death for us\xe2\x80\x94actual life, I mean\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsomething more than a place in mortal memory; life with going and\r\ncoming, with sensation, with knowledge, with power and all\r\nappreciation; life eternal in term though it may be with changes of\r\ncondition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk you what God\xe2\x80\x99s plan is? The gift of a Soul to each of us at birth,\r\nwith this simple law\xe2\x80\x94there shall be no immortality except through the\r\nSoul. In that law see the necessity of which I spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us turn from the necessity now. A word as to the pleasure there is\r\nin the thought of a Soul in each of us. In the first place, it robs\r\ndeath of its terrors by making dying a change for the better, and\r\nburial but the planting of a seed from which there will spring a new\r\nlife. In the next place, behold me as I am\xe2\x80\x94weak, weary, old, shrunken\r\nin body, and graceless; look at my wrinkled face, think of my failing\r\nsenses, listen to my shrilled voice. Ah! what happiness to me in the\r\npromise that when the tomb opens, as soon it will, to receive the\r\nworn-out husk I call myself, the now viewless doors of the universe,\r\nwhich is but the palace of God, will swing wide ajar to receive me, a\r\nliberated immortal Soul!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would I could tell the ecstasy there must be in that life to come!\r\nDo not say I know nothing about it. This much I know, and it is enough\r\nfor me\xe2\x80\x94the being a Soul implies conditions of divine superiority. In\r\nsuch a being there is no dust, nor any gross thing; it must be finer\r\nthan air, more impalpable than light, purer than essence\xe2\x80\x94it is life in\r\nabsolute purity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat now, O son of Hur? Knowing so much, shall I dispute with myself\r\nor you about the unnecessaries\xe2\x80\x94about the form of my soul? Or where it\r\nis to abide? Or whether it eats and drinks? Or is winged, or wears this\r\nor that? No. It is more becoming to trust in God. The beautiful in this\r\nworld is all from his hand declaring the perfection of taste; he is the\r\nauthor of all form; he clothes the lily, he colors the rose, he distils\r\nthe dew-drop, he makes the music of nature; in a word, he organized us\r\nfor this life, and imposed its conditions; and they are such guaranty\r\nto me that, trustful as a little child, I leave to him the organization\r\nof my Soul, and every arrangement for the life after death. I know he\r\nloves me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe good man stopped and drank, and the hand carrying the cup to his\r\nlips trembled; and both Iras and Ben-Hur shared his emotion and\r\nremained silent. Upon the latter a light was breaking. He was beginning\r\nto see, as never before, that there might be a spiritual kingdom of\r\nmore import to men than any earthly empire; and that after all a\r\nSaviour would indeed be a more godly gift than the greatest king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might ask you now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, continuing, \xe2\x80\x9cwhether this human\r\nlife, so troubled and brief, is preferable to the perfect and\r\neverlasting life designed for the Soul? But take the question, and\r\nthink of it for yourself, formulating thus: Supposing both to be\r\nequally happy, is one hour more desirable than one year? From that then\r\nadvance to the final inquiry, what are threescore and ten years on\r\nearth to all eternity with God? By-and-by, son of Hur, thinking in such\r\nmanner, you will be filled with the meaning of the fact I present you\r\nnext, to me the most amazing of all events, and in its effects the most\r\nsorrowful; it is that the very idea of life as a Soul is a light almost\r\ngone out in the world. Here and there, to be sure, a philosopher may be\r\nfound who will talk to you of a Soul, likening it to a principle; but\r\nbecause philosophers take nothing upon faith, they will not go the\r\nlength of admitting a Soul to be a being, and on that account its\r\npurpose is compressed darkness to them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything animate has a mind measurable by its wants. Is there to you\r\nno meaning in the singularity that power in full degree to speculate\r\nupon the future was given to man alone? By the sign as I see it, God\r\nmeant to make us know ourselves created for another and a better life,\r\nsuch being in fact the greatest need of our nature. But, alas! into\r\nwhat a habit the nations have fallen! They live for the day, as if the\r\npresent were the all in all, and go about saying, \xe2\x80\x98There is no\r\nto-morrow after death; or if there be, since we know nothing about it,\r\nbe it a care unto itself.\xe2\x80\x99 So when Death calls them, \xe2\x80\x98Come,\xe2\x80\x99 they may\r\nnot enter into enjoyment of the glorious after-life because of their\r\nunfitness. That is to say, the ultimate happiness of man was\r\neverlasting life in the society of God. Alas, O son of Hur, that I\r\nshould say it! but as well yon sleeping camel constant in such society\r\nas the holiest priests this day serving the highest altars in the most\r\nrenowned temples. So much are men given to this lower earthly life! So\r\nnearly have they forgotten that other which is to come!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee now, I pray you, that which is to be saved to us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my part, speaking with the holiness of truth, I would not give one\r\nhour of life as a Soul for a thousand years of life as a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the Egyptian seemed to become unconscious of companionship and\r\nfall away into abstraction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis life has its problems,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand there are men who spend\r\ntheir days trying to solve them; but what are they to the problems of\r\nthe hereafter? What is there like knowing God? Not a scroll of the\r\nmysteries, but the mysteries themselves would for that hour at least\r\nlie before me revealed; even the innermost and most awful\xe2\x80\x94the power\r\nwhich now we shrink from thought of\xe2\x80\x94which rimmed the void with shores,\r\nand lighted the darkness, and out of nothing appointed the universe.\r\nAll places would be opened. I would be filled with divine knowledge; I\r\nwould see all glories, taste all delights; I would revel in being. And\r\nif, at the end of the hour, it should please God to tell me, \xe2\x80\x98I take\r\nthee into my service forever,\xe2\x80\x99 the furthest limit of desire would be\r\npassed; after which the attainable ambitions of life, and its joys of\r\nwhatever kind, would not be so much as the tinkling of little bells.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar paused as if to recover from very ecstasy of feeling; and to\r\nBen-Hur it seemed the speech had been the delivery of a Soul speaking\r\nfor itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray pardon, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d the good man continued, with a bow the\r\ngravity of which was relieved by the tender look that followed it, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmeant to leave the life of a Soul, its conditions, pleasures,\r\nsuperiority, to your own reflection and finding out. The joy of the\r\nthought has betrayed me into much speech. I set out to show, though\r\never so faintly, the reason of my faith. It grieves me that words are\r\nso weak. But help yourself to truth. Consider first the excellence of\r\nthe existence which was reserved for us after death, and give heed to\r\nthe feelings and impulses the thought is sure to awaken in you\xe2\x80\x94heed\r\nthem, I say, because they are your own Soul astir, doing what it can to\r\nurge you in the right way. Consider next that the afterlife has become\r\nso obscured as to justify calling it a lost light. If you find it,\r\nrejoice, O son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94rejoice as I do, though in beggary of words. For\r\nthen, besides the great gift which is to be saved to us, you will have\r\nfound the need of a Saviour so infinitely greater than the need of a\r\nking; and he we are going to meet will not longer hold place in your\r\nhope a warrior with a sword or a monarch with a crown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA practical question presents itself\xe2\x80\x94How shall we know him at sight?\r\nIf you continue in your belief as to his character\xe2\x80\x94that he is to be a\r\nking as Herod was\xe2\x80\x94of course you will keep on until you meet a man\r\nclothed in purple and with a sceptre. On the other hand, he I look for\r\nwill be one poor, humble, undistinguished\xe2\x80\x94a man in appearance as other\r\nmen; and the sign by which I will know him will be never so simple. He\r\nwill offer to show me and all mankind the way to the eternal life; the\r\nbeautiful pure Life of the Soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe company sat a moment in silence which was broken by Balthasar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us arise now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clet us arise and set forward again. What I\r\nhave said has caused a return of impatience to see him who is ever in\r\nmy thought; and if I seem to hurry you, O son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94and you, my\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x94be that my excuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt his signal the slave brought them wine in a skin bottle; and they\r\npoured and drank, and shaking the lap-cloths out arose.\r\n\r\nWhile the slave restored the tent and wares to the box under the\r\nhoudah, and the Arab brought up the horses, the three principals laved\r\nthemselves in the pool.\r\n\r\nIn a little while they were retracing their steps back through the\r\nwady, intending to overtake the caravan if it had passed them by.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nThe caravan, stretched out upon the Desert, was very picturesque; in\r\nmotion, however, it was like a lazy serpent. By-and-by its stubborn\r\ndragging became intolerably irksome to Balthasar, patient as he was;\r\nso, at his suggestion, the party determined to go on by themselves.\r\n\r\nIf the reader be young, or if he has yet a sympathetic recollection of\r\nthe romanticisms of his youth, he will relish the pleasure with which\r\nBen-Hur, riding near the camel of the Egyptians, gave a last look at\r\nthe head of the straggling column almost out of sight on the shimmering\r\nplain.\r\n\r\nTo be definite as may be, and perfectly confidential, Ben-Hur found a\r\ncertain charm in Iras\xe2\x80\x99s presence. If she looked down upon him from her\r\nhigh place, he made haste to get near her; if she spoke to him, his\r\nheart beat out of its usual time. The desire to be agreeable to her was\r\na constant impulse. Objects on the way, though ever so common, became\r\ninteresting the moment she called attention to them; a black swallow in\r\nthe air pursued by her pointing finger went off in a halo; if a bit of\r\nquartz or a flake of mica was seen to sparkle in the drab sand under\r\nkissing of the sun, at a word he turned aside and brought it to her;\r\nand if she threw it away in disappointment, far from thinking of the\r\ntrouble he had been put to, he was sorry it proved so worthless, and\r\nkept a lookout for something better\xe2\x80\x94a ruby, perchance a diamond.
