So the\r\npurple of the far mountains became intensely deep and rich if she\r\ndistinguished it with an exclamation of praise; and when, now and then,\r\nthe curtain of the houdah fell down, it seemed a sudden dulness had\r\ndropped from the sky bedraggling all the landscape. Thus disposed,\r\nyielding to the sweet influence, what shall save him from the dangers\r\nthere are in days of the close companionship with the fair Egyptian\r\nincident to the solitary journey they were entered upon?\r\n\r\nFor that there is no logic in love, nor the least mathematical element,\r\nit is simply natural that she shall fashion the result who has the\r\nwielding of the influence.\r\n\r\nTo quicken the conclusion, there were signs, too, that she well knew\r\nthe influence she was exercising over him. From some place under hand\r\nshe had since morning drawn a caul of golden coins, and adjusted it so\r\nthe gleaming strings fell over her forehead and upon her cheeks,\r\nblending lustrously with the flowing of her blue-black hair. From the\r\nsame safe deposit she had also produced articles of jewelry\xe2\x80\x94rings for\r\nfinger and ear, bracelets, a necklace of pearls\xe2\x80\x94also, a shawl\r\nembroidered with threads of fine gold\xe2\x80\x94the effect of all which she\r\nsoftened with a scarf of Indian lace skillfully folded about her throat\r\nand shoulders. And so arrayed, she plied Ben-Hur with countless\r\ncoquetries of speech and manner; showering him with smiles; laughing in\r\nflute-like tremolo\xe2\x80\x94and all the while following him with glances, now\r\nmelting-tender, now sparkling-bright. By such play Antony was weaned\r\nfrom his glory; yet she who wrought his ruin was really not half so\r\nbeautiful as this her countrywoman.\r\n\r\nAnd so to them the nooning came, and the evening.\r\n\r\nThe sun at its going down behind a spur of the old Bashan, left the\r\nparty halted by a pool of clear water of the rains out in the Abilene\r\nDesert. There the tent was pitched, the supper eaten, and preparations\r\nmade for the night.\r\n\r\nThe second watch was Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s; and he was standing, spear in hand,\r\nwithin arm-reach of the dozing camel, looking awhile at the stars, then\r\nover the veiled land. The stillness was intense; only after long spells\r\na warm breath of wind would sough past, but without disturbing him, for\r\nyet in thought he entertained the Egyptian, recounting her charms, and\r\nsometimes debating how she came by his secrets, the uses she might make\r\nof them, and the course he should pursue with her. And through all the\r\ndebate Love stood off but a little way\xe2\x80\x94a strong temptation, the\r\nstronger of a gleam of policy behind. At the very moment he was most\r\ninclined to yield to the allurement, a hand very fair even in the\r\nmoonless gloaming was laid softly upon his shoulder. The touch thrilled\r\nhim; he started, turned\xe2\x80\x94and she was there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you asleep,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, presently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSleep is for old people and little children, and I came out to look at\r\nmy friends, the stars in the south\xe2\x80\x94those now holding the curtains of\r\nmidnight over the Nile. But confess yourself surprised!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the hand which had fallen from his shoulder, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\r\nwas it by an enemy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no! To be an enemy is to hate, and hating is a sickness which Isis\r\nwill not suffer to come near me. She kissed me, you should know, on the\r\nheart when I was a child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour speech does not sound in the least like your father\xe2\x80\x99s. Are you\r\nnot of his faith?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might have been\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and she laughed low\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI might have been had I seen\r\nwhat he has. I may be when I get old like him. There should be no\r\nreligion for youth, only poetry and philosophy; and no poetry except\r\nsuch as is the inspiration of wine and mirth and love, and no\r\nphilosophy that does not nod excuse for follies which cannot outlive a\r\nseason. My father\xe2\x80\x99s God is too awful for me. I failed to find him in\r\nthe Grove of Daphne. He was never heard of as present in the atria of\r\nRome. But, son of Hur, I have a wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA wish! Where is he who could say it no?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will try you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell it then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very simple. I wish to help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe drew closer as she spoke.\r\n\r\nHe laughed, and replied, lightly, \xe2\x80\x9cO Egypt!\xe2\x80\x94I came near saying dear\r\nEgypt!\xe2\x80\x94does not the sphinx abide in your country?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are one of its riddles. Be merciful, and give me a little clew to\r\nhelp me understand you. In what do I need help? And how can you help\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took her hand from him, and, turning to the camel, spoke to it\r\nendearingly, and patted its monstrous head as it were a thing of\r\nbeauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO thou last and swiftest and stateliest of the herds of Job! Sometimes\r\nthou, too, goest stumbling, because the way is rough and stony and the\r\nburden grievous. How is it thou knowest the kind intent by a word; and\r\nalways makest answer gratefully, though the help offered is from a\r\nwoman? I will kiss thee, thou royal brute!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she stooped and touched its\r\nbroad forehead with her lips, saying immediately, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause in thy\r\nintelligence there is no suspicion!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Ben-Hur, restraining himself, said calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cThe reproach has not\r\nfailed its mark, O Egypt! I seem to say thee no; may it not be because\r\nI am under seal of honor, and by my silence cover the lives and\r\nfortunes of others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay be!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shrank a step, and asked, his voice sharp with amazement, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat all\r\nknowest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe answered, after a laugh,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do men deny that the senses of women are sharper than theirs? Your\r\nface has been under my eyes all day. I had but to look at it to see you\r\nbore some weight in mind; and to find the weight, what had I to do more\r\nthan recall your debates with my father? Son of Hur!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she lowered her\r\nvoice with singular dexterity, and, going nearer, spoke so her breath\r\nwas warm upon his cheek\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cson of Hur! he thou art going to find is to be\r\nKing of the Jews, is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis heart beat fast and hard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA King of the Jews like Herod, only greater,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued.\r\n\r\nHe looked away\xe2\x80\x94into the night, up to the stars; then his eyes met hers,\r\nand lingered there; and her breath was on his lips, so near was she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince morning,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, further, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have been having visions. Now\r\nif I tell you mine, will you serve me as well? What! silent still?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe pushed his hand away, and turned as if to go; but he caught her,\r\nand said, eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cStay\xe2\x80\x94stay and speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went back, and with her hand upon his shoulder, leaned against him;\r\nand he put his arm around her, and drew her close, very close; and in\r\nthe caress was the promise she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, and tell me thy visions, O Egypt, dear Egypt! A prophet\xe2\x80\x94nay,\r\nnot the Tishbite, not even the Lawgiver\xe2\x80\x94could have refused an asking of\r\nthine. I am at thy will. Be merciful\xe2\x80\x94merciful, I pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe entreaty passed apparently unheard, for looking up and nestling in\r\nhis embrace, she said, slowly, \xe2\x80\x9cThe vision which followed me was of\r\nmagnificent war\xe2\x80\x94war on land and sea\xe2\x80\x94with clashing of arms and rush of\r\narmies, as if Caesar and Pompey were come again, and Octavius and\r\nAntony. A cloud of dust and ashes arose and covered the world, and Rome\r\nwas not any more; all dominion returned to the East; out of the cloud\r\nissued another race of heroes; and there were vaster satrapies and\r\nbrighter crowns for giving away than were ever known. And, son of Hur,\r\nwhile the vision was passing, and after it was gone, I kept asking\r\nmyself, \xe2\x80\x98What shall he not have who served the King earliest and\r\nbest?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain Ben-Hur recoiled. The question was the very question which had\r\nbeen with him all day. Presently he fancied he had the clew he wanted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have you now. The satrapies and crowns are the things\r\nto which you would help me. I see, I see! And there never was such\r\nqueen as you would be, so shrewd, so beautiful, so royal\xe2\x80\x94never! But,\r\nalas, dear Egypt! by the vision as you show it me the prizes are all of\r\nwar, and you are but a woman, though Isis did kiss you on the heart.\r\nAnd crowns are starry gifts beyond your power of help, unless, indeed,\r\nyou have a way to them more certain than that of the sword. If so, O\r\nEgypt, Egypt, show it me, and I will walk in it, if only for your\r\nsake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe removed his arm, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cSpread your cloak upon the sand\xe2\x80\x94here,\r\nso I can rest against the camel. I will sit, and tell you a story which\r\ncame down the Nile to Alexandria, where I had it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did as she said, first planting the spear in the ground near by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what shall I do?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, ruefully, when she was seated. \xe2\x80\x9cIn\r\nAlexandria is it customary for the listeners to sit or stand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the comfortable place against the old domestic she answered,\r\nlaughing, \xe2\x80\x9cThe audiences of story-tellers are wilful, and sometimes\r\nthey do as they please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout more ado he stretched himself upon the sand, and put her arm\r\nabout his neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAnd directly she began:\r\n\r\nHOW THE BEAUTIFUL CAME TO THE EARTH.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must know, in the first place, that Isis was\xe2\x80\x94and, for that matter,\r\nshe may yet be\xe2\x80\x94the most beautiful of deities; and Osiris, her husband,\r\nthough wise and powerful, was sometimes stung with jealousy of her, for\r\nonly in their loves are the gods like mortals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe palace of the Divine Wife was of silver, crowning the tallest\r\nmountain in the moon, and thence she passed often to the sun, in the\r\nheart of which, a source of eternal light, Osiris kept his palace of\r\ngold too shining for men to look at.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne time\xe2\x80\x94there are no days with the gods\xe2\x80\x94while she was full pleasantly\r\nwith him on the roof of the golden palace, she chanced to look, and\r\nafar, just on the line of the universe, saw Indra passing with an army\r\nof simians, all borne upon the backs of flying eagles. He, the Friend\r\nof Living Things\xe2\x80\x94so with much love is Indra called\xe2\x80\x94was returning from\r\nhis final war with the hideous Rakshakas\xe2\x80\x94returning victorious; and in\r\nhis suite were Rama, the hero, and Sita, his bride, who, next to Isis\r\nherself, was the very most beautiful. And Isis arose, and took off her\r\ngirdle of stars, and waved it to Sita\xe2\x80\x94to Sita, mind you\xe2\x80\x94waved it in\r\nglad salute. And instantly, between the marching host and the two on\r\nthe golden roof, a something as of night fell, and shut out the view;\r\nbut it was not night\xe2\x80\x94only the frown of Osiris.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt happened the subject of his speech that moment was such as none\r\nelse than they could think of; and he arose, and said, majestically,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get thee home. I will do the work myself. To make a perfectly happy\r\nbeing I do not need thy help. Get thee gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow Isis had eyes large as those of the white cow which in the temple\r\neats sweet grasses from the hands of the faithful even while they say\r\ntheir prayers; and her eyes were the color of the cows, and quite as\r\ntender. And she too arose and said, smiling as she spoke, so her look\r\nwas little more than the glow of the moon in the hazy harvest-month,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Farewell, good my lord. You will call me presently, I know; for\r\nwithout me you cannot make the perfectly happy creature of which you\r\nwere thinking, any more\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and she stopped to laugh, knowing well the\r\ntruth of the saying\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98any more, my lord, than you yourself can be\r\nperfectly happy without me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98We will see,\xe2\x80\x99 he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she went her way, and took her needles and her chair, and on the\r\nroof of the silver palace sat watching and knitting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the will of Osiris, at labor in his mighty breast, was as the\r\nsound of the mills of all the other gods grinding at once, so loud that\r\nthe near stars rattled like seeds in a parched pod; and some dropped\r\nout and were lost. And while the sound kept on she waited and knit; nor\r\nlost she ever a stitch the while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon a spot appeared in the space over towards the sun; and it grew\r\nuntil it was great as the moon, and then she knew a world was intended;\r\nbut when, growing and growing, at last it cast her planet in the shade,\r\nall save the little point lighted by her presence, she knew how very\r\nangry he was; yet she knit away, assured that the end would be as she\r\nhad said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so came the earth, at first but a cold gray mass hanging listless\r\nin the hollow void. Later she saw it separate into divisions; here a\r\nplain, there a mountain, yonder a sea, all as yet without a sparkle.\r\nAnd then, by a river-bank, something moved; and she stopped her\r\nknitting for wonder. The something arose, and lifted its hands to the\r\nsun in sign of knowledge whence it had its being. And this First Man\r\nwas beautiful to see. And about him were the creations we call\r\nnature\xe2\x80\x94the grass, the trees, birds, beasts, even the insects and\r\nreptiles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for a time the man went about happy in his life: it was easy to\r\nsee how happy he was. And in the lull of the sound of the laboring will\r\nIsis heard a scornful laugh, and presently the words, blown across from\r\nthe sun,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Thy help, indeed! Behold a creature perfectly happy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Isis fell to knitting again, for she was patient as Osiris was\r\nstrong; and if he could work, she could wait; and wait she did, knowing\r\nthat mere life is not enough to keep anything content.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd sure enough. Not long until the Divine Wife could see a change in\r\nthe man. He grew listless, and kept to one place prone by the river,\r\nand looked up but seldom, and then always with a moody face. Interest\r\nwas dying in him. And when she made sure of it, even while she was\r\nsaying to herself, \xe2\x80\x98The creature is sick of his being,\xe2\x80\x99 there was a\r\nroar of the creative will at work again, and in a twinkling the earth,\r\ntheretofore all a thing of coldest gray, flamed with colors; the\r\nmountains swam in purple, the plains bearing grass and trees turned\r\ngreen, the sea blue, and the clouds varied infinitely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the man sprang up and clapped his hands, for he was cured and happy\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Isis smiled, and knit away, saying to herself, \xe2\x80\x98It was well\r\nthought, and will do a little while; but mere beauty in a world is not\r\nenough for such a being. My lord must try again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the last word, the thunder of the will at work shook the moon,\r\nand, looking, Isis dropped her knitting and clapped her hands; for\r\ntheretofore everything on the earth but the man had been fixed to a\r\ngiven place; now all living, and much that was not living, received the\r\ngift of Motion. The birds took to wing joyously; beasts great and small\r\nwent about, each in its way; the trees shook their verdurous branches,\r\nnodding to the enamoured winds; the rivers ran to the seas, and the\r\nseas tossed in their beds and rolled in crested waves, and with surging\r\nand ebbing painted the shores with glistening foam; and over all the\r\nclouds floated like sailed ships unanchored.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the man rose up happy as a child; whereat Osiris was pleased, so\r\nthat he shouted, \xe2\x80\x98Ha, ha! See how well I am doing without thee!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe good wife took up her work, and answered ever so quietly, \xe2\x80\x98It was\r\nwell thought, my lord\xe2\x80\x94ever so well thought\xe2\x80\x94and will serve awhile.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as before, so again. The sight of things in motion became to the\r\nman as of course. The birds in flight, the rivers running, the seas in\r\ntumult of action, ceased to amuse him, and he pined again even worse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Isis waited, saying to herself, \xe2\x80\x98Poor creature! He is more\r\nwretched than ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, as if he heard the thought, Osiris stirred, and the noise of his\r\nwill shook the universe; the sun in its central seat alone stood firm.\r\nAnd Isis looked, but saw no change; then while she was smiling, assured\r\nthat her lord\xe2\x80\x99s last invention was sped, suddenly the creature arose,\r\nand seemed to listen; and his face brightened, and he clapped his hands\r\nfor joy, for Sounds were heard the first time on earth\xe2\x80\x94sounds\r\ndissonant, sounds harmonious. The winds murmured in the trees; the\r\nbirds sang, each kind a song of its own, or chattered in speech; the\r\nrivulets running to the rivers became so many harpers with harps of\r\nsilver strings all tinkling together; and the rivers running to the\r\nseas surged on in solemn accord, while the seas beat the land to a tune\r\nof thunder. There was music, music everywhere, and all the time; so the\r\nman could not but be happy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Isis mused, thinking how well, how wondrous well, her lord was\r\ndoing; but presently she shook her head: Color, Motion, Sound\xe2\x80\x94and she\r\nrepeated them slowly\xe2\x80\x94there was no element else of beauty except Form\r\nand Light, and to them the earth had been born. Now, indeed, Osiris was\r\ndone; and if the creature should again fall off into wretchedness, her\r\nhelp must be asked; and her fingers flew\xe2\x80\x94two, three, five, even ten\r\nstitches she took at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the man was happy a long time\xe2\x80\x94longer than ever before; it seemed,\r\nindeed, he would never tire again. But Isis knew better; and she waited\r\nand waited, nor minded the many laughs flung at her from the sun; she\r\nwaited and waited, and at last saw signs of the end. Sounds became\r\nfamiliar to him, and in their range, from the chirruping of the cricket\r\nunder the roses to the roar of the seas and the bellow of the clouds in\r\nstorm, there was not anything unusual. And he pined and sickened, and\r\nsought his place of moping by the river, and at last fell down\r\nmotionless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Isis in pity spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98My lord,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98the creature is dying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Osiris, though seeing it all, held his peace; he could do no more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Shall I help him?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOsiris was too proud to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Isis took the last stitch in her knitting, and gathering her work\r\nin a roll of brilliance flung it off\xe2\x80\x94flung it so it fell close to the\r\nman. And he, hearing the sound of the fall so near by, looked up, and\r\nlo! a Woman\xe2\x80\x94the First Woman\xe2\x80\x94was stooping to help him! She reached a\r\nhand to him; he caught it and arose; and nevermore was miserable, but\r\nevermore happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch, O son of Hur! is the genesis of the beautiful, as they tell it\r\non the Nile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pretty invention, and cunning,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, directly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is\r\nimperfect. What did Osiris afterwards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. \xe2\x80\x9cHe called the Divine Wife back to the sun, and\r\nthey went on all pleasantly together, each helping the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall I not do as the first man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe carried the hand resting upon his neck to his lips. \xe2\x80\x9cIn love\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nlove!\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHis head dropped softly into her lap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will find the King,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, placing her other hand caressingly\r\nupon his head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will go on and find the King and serve him. With\r\nyour sword you will earn his richest gifts; and his best soldier will\r\nbe my hero.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned his face, and saw hers close above. In all the sky there was\r\nthat moment nothing so bright to him as her eyes, enshadowed though\r\nthey were. Presently he sat up, and put his arms about her, and kissed\r\nher passionately, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cO Egypt, Egypt! If the King has crowns in\r\ngift, one shall be mine; and I will bring it and put it here over the\r\nplace my lips have marked. You shall be a queen\xe2\x80\x94my queen\xe2\x80\x94no one more\r\nbeautiful! And we will be ever, ever so happy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will tell me everything, and let me help you in all?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, kissing him in return.\r\n\r\nThe question chilled his fervor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not enough that I love you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect love means perfect faith,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. \xe2\x80\x9cBut never mind\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nwill know me better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took her hand from him and arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are cruel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nMoving away, she stopped by the camel, and touched its front face with\r\nher lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO thou noblest of thy kind!\xe2\x80\x94that, because there is no suspicion in thy\r\nlove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn instant, and she was gone.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nThe third day of the journey the party nooned by the river Jabbok,\r\nwhere there were a hundred or more men, mostly of Peraea, resting\r\nthemselves and their beasts. Hardly had they dismounted, before a man\r\ncame to them with a pitcher of water and a bowl, and offered them\r\ndrink; as they received the attention with much courtesy, he said,\r\nlooking at the camel, \xe2\x80\x9cI am returning from the Jordan, where just now\r\nthere are many people from distant parts, travelling as you are,\r\nillustrious friend; but they had none of them the equal of your servant\r\nhere. A very noble animal. May I ask of what breed he is sprung?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar answered, and sought his rest; but Ben-Hur, more curious,\r\ntook up the remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what place on the river are the people?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Bethabara.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt used to be a lonesome ford,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot understand how\r\nit can have become of such interest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d the stranger replied; \xe2\x80\x9cyou, too, are from abroad, and have not\r\nheard the good tidings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat tidings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, a man has appeared out of the wilderness\xe2\x80\x94a very holy man\xe2\x80\x94with\r\nhis mouth full of strange words, which take hold of all who hear them.\r\nHe calls himself John the Nazarite, son of Zacharias, and says he is\r\nthe messenger sent before the Messiah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEven Iras listened closely while the man continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say of this John that he has spent his life from childhood in a\r\ncave down by En-Gedi, praying and living more strictly than the\r\nEssenes. Crowds go to hear him preach. I went to hear him with the\r\nrest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave all these, your friends, been there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost of them are going; a few are coming away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does he preach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA new doctrine\xe2\x80\x94one never before taught in Israel, as all say. He calls\r\nit repentance and baptism. The rabbis do not know what to make of him;\r\nnor do we. Some have asked him if he is the Christ, others if he is\r\nElias; but to them all he has the answer, \xe2\x80\x98I am the voice of one crying\r\nin the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point the man was called away by his friends; as he was going,\r\nBalthasar spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood stranger!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, tremulously, \xe2\x80\x9ctell us if we shall find the\r\npreacher at the place you left him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, at Bethabara.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho should this Nazarite be?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur to Iras, \xe2\x80\x9cif not the herald\r\nof our King?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn so short a time he had come to regard the daughter as more\r\ninterested in the mysterious personage he was looking for than the aged\r\nfather! Nevertheless, the latter with a positive glow in his sunken\r\neyes half arose, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us make haste. I am not tired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey turned away to help the slave.\r\n\r\nThere was little conversation between the three at the stopping-place\r\nfor the night west of Ramoth-Gilead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us arise early, son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Saviour may\r\ncome, and we not there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe King cannot be far behind his herald,\xe2\x80\x9d Iras whispered, as she\r\nprepared to take her place on the camel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow we will see!\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur replied, kissing her hand.\r\n\r\nNext day about the third hour, out of the pass through which, skirting\r\nthe base of Mount Gilead, they had journeyed since leaving Ramoth, the\r\nparty came upon the barren steppe east of the sacred river. Opposite\r\nthem they saw the upper limit of the old palm lands of Jericho,\r\nstretching off to the hill-country of Judea. Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s blood ran\r\nquickly, for he knew the ford was close at hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cContent you, good Balthasar,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cwe are almost there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe driver quickened the camel\xe2\x80\x99s pace. Soon they caught sight of booths\r\nand tents and tethered animals; and then of the river, and a multitude\r\ncollected down close by the bank, and yet another multitude on the\r\nwestern shore. Knowing that the preacher was preaching, they made\r\ngreater haste; yet, as they were drawing near, suddenly there was a\r\ncommotion in the mass, and it began to break up and disperse.\r\n\r\nThey were too late!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us stay here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur to Balthasar, who was wringing his\r\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Nazarite may come this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people were too intent upon what they had heard, and too busy in\r\ndiscussion, to notice the new-comers. When some hundreds were gone by,\r\nand it seemed the opportunity to so much as see the Nazarite was lost\r\nto the latter, up the river not far away they beheld a person coming\r\ntowards them of such singular appearance they forgot all else.\r\n\r\nOutwardly the man was rude and uncouth, even savage. Over a thin, gaunt\r\nvisage of the hue of brown parchment, over his shoulders and down his\r\nback below the middle, in witch-like locks, fell a covering of\r\nsun-scorched hair. His eyes were burning-bright. All his right side was\r\nnaked, and of the color of his face, and quite as meagre; a shirt of\r\nthe coarsest camel\xe2\x80\x99s-hair\xe2\x80\x94coarse as Bedouin tent-cloth\xe2\x80\x94clothed the rest\r\nof his person to the knees, being gathered at the waist by a broad\r\ngirdle of untanned leather. His feet were bare. A scrip, also of\r\nuntanned leather, was fastened to the girdle. He used a knotted staff\r\nto help him forward. His movement was quick, decided, and strangely\r\nwatchful. Every little while he tossed the unruly hair from his eyes,\r\nand peered round as if searching for somebody.\r\n\r\nThe fair Egyptian surveyed the son of the Desert with surprise, not to\r\nsay disgust. Presently, raising the curtain of the houdah, she spoke to\r\nBen-Hur, who sat his horse near by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that the herald of thy King?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the Nazarite,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, without looking up.\r\n\r\nIn truth, he was himself more than disappointed. Despite his\r\nfamiliarity with the ascetic colonists in En-Gedi\xe2\x80\x94their dress, their\r\nindifference to all worldly opinion, their constancy to vows which gave\r\nthem over to every imaginable suffering of body, and separated them\r\nfrom others of their kind as absolutely as if they had not been born\r\nlike them\xe2\x80\x94and notwithstanding he had been notified on the way to look\r\nfor a Nazarite whose simple description of himself was a Voice from the\r\nWilderness\xe2\x80\x94still Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s dream of the King who was to be so great and\r\ndo so much had colored all his thought of him, so that he never doubted\r\nto find in the forerunner some sign or token of the goodliness and\r\nroyalty he was announcing. Gazing at the savage figure before him, the\r\nlong trains of courtiers whom he had been used to see in the thermae\r\nand imperial corridors at Rome arose before him, forcing a comparison.\r\nShocked, shamed, bewildered, he could only answer,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the Nazarite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith Balthasar it was very different. The ways of God, he knew, were\r\nnot as men would have them. He had seen the Saviour a child in a\r\nmanger, and was prepared by his faith for the rude and simple in\r\nconnection with the Divine reappearance. So he kept his seat, his hands\r\ncrossed upon his breast, his lips moving in prayer. He was not\r\nexpecting a king.\r\n\r\nIn this time of such interest to the new-comers, and in which they were\r\nso differently moved, another man had been sitting by himself on a\r\nstone at the edge of the river, thinking yet, probably, of the sermon\r\nhe had been hearing. Now, however, he arose, and walked slowly up from\r\nthe shore, in a course to take him across the line the Nazarite was\r\npursuing and bring him near the camel.\r\n\r\nAnd the two\xe2\x80\x94the preacher and the stranger\xe2\x80\x94kept on until they came, the\r\nformer within twenty yards of the animal, the latter within ten feet.\r\nThen the preacher stopped, and flung the hair from his eyes, looked at\r\nthe stranger, threw his hands up as a signal to all the people in\r\nsight; and they also stopped, each in the pose of a listener; and when\r\nthe hush was perfect, slowly the staff in the Nazarite\xe2\x80\x99s right hand\r\ncame down and pointed to the stranger.\r\n\r\nAll those who before were but listeners became watchers also.\r\n\r\nAt the same instant, under the same impulse, Balthasar and Ben-Hur\r\nfixed their gaze upon the man pointed out, and both took the same\r\nimpression, only in different degree. He was moving slowly towards them\r\nin a clear space a little to their front, a form slightly above the\r\naverage in stature, and slender, even delicate. His action was calm and\r\ndeliberate, like that habitual to men much given to serious thought\r\nupon grave subjects; and it well became his costume, which was an\r\nundergarment full-sleeved and reaching to the ankles, and an outer robe\r\ncalled the talith; on his left arm he carried the usual handkerchief\r\nfor the head, the red fillet swinging loose down his side. Except the\r\nfillet and a narrow border of blue at the lower edge of the talith, his\r\nattire was of linen yellowed with dust and road stains. Possibly the\r\nexception should be extended to the tassels, which were blue and white,\r\nas prescribed by law for rabbis. His sandals were of the simplest kind.\r\nHe was without scrip or girdle or staff.\r\n\r\nThese points of appearance, however, the three beholders observed\r\nbriefly, and rather as accessories to the head and face of the man,\r\nwhich\xe2\x80\x94especially the latter\xe2\x80\x94were the real sources of the spell they\r\ncaught in common with all who stood looking at him.\r\n\r\nThe head was open to the cloudless light, except as it was draped with\r\nhair long and slightly waved, and parted in the middle, and auburn in\r\ntint, with a tendency to reddish golden where most strongly touched by\r\nthe sun. Under a broad, low forehead, under black well arched brows,\r\nbeamed eyes dark-blue and large, and softened to exceeding tenderness\r\nby lashes of the great length sometimes seen on children, but seldom,\r\nif ever, on men. As to the other features, it would have been difficult\r\nto decide whether they were Greek or Jewish. The delicacy of the\r\nnostrils and mouth was unusual to the latter type; and when it was\r\ntaken into account with the gentleness of the eyes, the pallor of the\r\ncomplexion, the fine texture of the hair, and the softness of the\r\nbeard, which fell in waves over his throat to his breast, never a\r\nsoldier but would have laughed at him in encounter, never a woman who\r\nwould not have confided in him at sight, never a child that would not,\r\nwith quick instinct, have given him its hand and whole artless trust;\r\nnor might any one have said he was not beautiful.\r\n\r\nThe features, it should be further said, were ruled by a certain\r\nexpression which, as the viewer chose, might with equal correctness\r\nhave been called the effect of intelligence, love, pity, or sorrow;\r\nthough, in better speech, it was a blending of them all\xe2\x80\x94a look easy to\r\nfancy as the mark of a sinless soul doomed to the sight and\r\nunderstanding of the utter sinfulness of those among whom it was\r\npassing; yet withal no one could have observed the face with a thought\r\nof weakness in the man; so, at least, would not they who know that the\r\nqualities mentioned\xe2\x80\x94love, sorrow, pity\xe2\x80\x94are the results of a\r\nconsciousness of strength to bear suffering oftener than strength to\r\ndo; such has been the might of martyrs and devotees and the myriads\r\nwritten down in saintly calendars. And such, indeed, was the air of\r\nthis one.\r\n\r\nSlowly he drew near\xe2\x80\x94nearer the three.\r\n\r\nNow Ben-Hur, mounted and spear in hand, was an object to claim the\r\nglance of a king; yet the eyes of the man approaching were all the time\r\nraised above him\xe2\x80\x94and not to Iras, whose loveliness has been so often\r\nremarked, but to Balthasar, the old and unserviceable.\r\n\r\nThe hush was profound.\r\n\r\nPresently the Nazarite, still pointing with his staff, cried, in a loud\r\nvoice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBehold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe many standing still, arrested by the action of the speaker, and\r\nlistening for what might follow, were struck with awe by words so\r\nstrange and past their understanding; upon Balthasar they were\r\noverpowering. He was there to see once more the Redeemer of men. The\r\nfaith which had brought him the singular privileges of the time long\r\ngone abode yet in his heart; and if now it gave him a power of vision\r\nabove that of his fellows\xe2\x80\x94a power to see and know him for whom he was\r\nlooking\xe2\x80\x94better than calling the power a miracle, let it be thought of\r\nas the faculty of a soul not yet entirely released from the divine\r\nrelations to which it had been formerly admitted, or as the fitting\r\nreward of a life in that age so without examples of holiness\xe2\x80\x94a life\r\nitself a miracle. The ideal of his faith was before him, perfect in\r\nface, form, dress, action, age; and he was in its view, and the view\r\nwas recognition. Ah, now if something should happen to identify the\r\nstranger beyond all doubt!\r\n\r\nAnd that was what did happen.\r\n\r\nExactly at the fitting moment, as if to assure the trembling Egyptian,\r\nthe Nazarite repeated the outcry,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBehold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar fell upon his knees. For him there was no need of\r\nexplanation; and as if the Nazarite knew it, he turned to those more\r\nimmediately about him staring in wonder, and continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is he of whom I said, After me cometh a man which is preferred\r\nbefore me, for he was before me. And I knew him not: but that he should\r\nbe manifest to Israel, therefore am I come baptizing with water. I saw\r\nthe Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and it abode upon him.\r\nAnd I knew him not: but he that sent me to baptize with water, the same\r\nsaid unto me, Upon whom thou shalt see the Spirit descending and\r\nremaining on him, the same is he which baptizeth with the Holy Ghost.\r\nAnd I saw and bare record, that this\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he paused, his staff still\r\npointing at the stranger in the white garments, as if to give a more\r\nabsolute certainty to both his words and the conclusions intended\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nbare record, THAT THIS IS THE SON OF GOD!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he, it is he!\xe2\x80\x9d Balthasar cried, with upraised tearful eyes. Next\r\nmoment he sank down insensible.\r\n\r\nIn this time, it should be remembered, Ben-Hur was studying the face of\r\nthe stranger, though with an interest entirely different. He was not\r\ninsensible to its purity of feature, and its thoughtfulness,\r\ntenderness, humility, and holiness; but just then there was room in his\r\nmind for but one thought\xe2\x80\x94Who is this man? And what? Messiah or king?\r\nNever was apparition more unroyal. Nay, looking at that calm, benignant\r\ncountenance, the very idea of war and conquest, and lust of dominion,\r\nsmote him like a profanation. He said, as if speaking to his own heart,\r\nBalthasar must be right and Simonides wrong. This man has not come to\r\nrebuild the throne of Solomon; he has neither the nature nor the genius\r\nof Herod; king he may be, but not of another and greater than Rome.\r\n\r\nIt should be understood now that this was not a conclusion with\r\nBen-Hur, but an impression merely; and while it was forming, while yet\r\nhe gazed at the wonderful countenance, his memory began to throe and\r\nstruggle. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen the man; but where\r\nand when?\xe2\x80\x9d That the look, so calm, so pitiful, so loving, had somewhere\r\nin a past time beamed upon him as that moment it was beaming upon\r\nBalthasar became an assurance. Faintly at first, at last a clear light,\r\na burst of sunshine, the scene by the well at Nazareth what time the\r\nRoman guard was dragging him to the galleys returned, and all his being\r\nthrilled. Those hands had helped him when he was perishing. The face\r\nwas one of the pictures he had carried in mind ever since. In the\r\neffusion of feeling excited, the explanation of the preacher was lost\r\nby him, all but the last words\xe2\x80\x94words so marvellous that the world yet\r\nrings with them:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94this is the SON OF GOD!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur leaped from his horse to render homage to his benefactor; but\r\nIras cried to him, \xe2\x80\x9cHelp, son of Hur, help, or my father will die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped, looked back, then hurried to her assistance. She gave him a\r\ncup; and leaving the slave to bring the camel to its knees, he ran to\r\nthe river for water. The stranger was gone when he came back.\r\n\r\nAt last Balthasar was restored to consciousness. Stretching forth his\r\nhands, he asked, feebly, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Iras.\r\n\r\nAn intense instant interest shone upon the good man\xe2\x80\x99s face, as if a\r\nlast wish had been gratified, and he answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x94the Redeemer\xe2\x80\x94the Son of God, whom I have seen again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelievest thou so?\xe2\x80\x9d Iras asked in a low voice of Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe time is full of wonders; let us wait,\xe2\x80\x9d was all he said.\r\n\r\nAnd next day while the three were listening to him, the Nazarite broke\r\noff in mid-speech, saying reverently, \xe2\x80\x9cBehold the Lamb of God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLooking to where he pointed, they beheld the stranger again. As Ben-Hur\r\nsurveyed the slender figure, and holy beautiful countenance\r\ncompassionate to sadness, a new idea broke upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBalthasar is right\xe2\x80\x94so is Simonides. May not the Redeemer be a king\r\nalso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he asked one at his side, \xe2\x80\x9cWho is the man walking yonder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other laughed mockingly, and replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is the son of a carpenter over in Nazareth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK EIGHTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho could resist? Who in this universe?\r\nShe did so breathe ambrosia, so immerse\r\nMy fine existence in a golden clime.\r\nShe took me like a child of suckling-time,\r\nAnd cradled me in roses. Thus condemn\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nThe current of my former life was stemm\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAnd to this arbitrary queen of sense\r\nI bow\xe2\x80\x99d a tranced vassal.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94KEATS, Endymion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the resurrection and the life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEsther\xe2\x80\x94Esther! Speak to the servant below that he may bring me a cup\r\nof water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you not rather have wine, father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him bring both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was in the summer-house upon the roof of the old palace of the\r\nHurs in Jerusalem. From the parapet overlooking the court-yard Esther\r\ncalled to a man in waiting there; at the same moment another\r\nman-servant came up the steps and saluted respectfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA package for the master,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, giving her a letter enclosed in\r\nlinen cloth, tied and sealed.\r\n\r\nFor the satisfaction of the reader, we stop to say that it is the\r\ntwenty-first day of March, nearly three years after the annunciation of\r\nthe Christ at Bethabara.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile, Malluch, acting for Ben-Hur, who could not longer\r\nendure the emptiness and decay of his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, had bought it\r\nfrom Pontius Pilate; and, in process of repair, gates, courts, lewens,\r\nstairways, terraces, rooms, and roof had been cleansed and thoroughly\r\nrestored; not only was there no reminder left of the tragic\r\ncircumstances so ruinous to the family, but the refurnishment was in a\r\nstyle richer than before. At every point, indeed, a visitor was met by\r\nevidences of the higher tastes acquired by the young proprietor during\r\nhis years of residence in the villa by Misenum and in the Roman\r\ncapital.\r\n\r\nNow it should not be inferred from this explanation that Ben-Hur had\r\npublicly assumed ownership of the property. In his opinion, the hour\r\nfor that was not yet come. Neither had he yet taken his proper name.\r\nPassing the time in the labors of preparation in Galilee, he waited\r\npatiently the action of the Nazarene, who became daily more and more a\r\nmystery to him, and by prodigies done, often before his eyes, kept him\r\nin a state of anxious doubt both as to his character and mission.\r\nOccasionally he came up to the Holy City, stopping at the paternal\r\nhouse; always, however, as a stranger and a guest.\r\n\r\nThese visits of Ben-Hur, it should also be observed, were for more than\r\nmere rest from labor. Balthasar and Iras made their home in the palace;\r\nand the charm of the daughter was still upon him with all its original\r\nfreshness, while the father, though feebler in body, held him an\r\nunflagging listener to speeches of astonishing power, urging the\r\ndivinity of the wandering miracle-worker of whom they were all so\r\nexpectant.\r\n\r\nAs to Simonides and Esther, they had arrived from Antioch only a few\r\ndays before this their reappearance\xe2\x80\x94a wearisome journey to the\r\nmerchant, borne, as he had been, in a palanquin swung between two\r\ncamels, which, in their careening, did not always keep the same step.\r\nBut now that he was come, the good man, it seemed, could not see enough\r\nof his native land. He delighted in the perch upon the roof, and spent\r\nmost of his day hours there seated in an arm-chair, the duplicate of\r\nthat one kept for him in the cabinet over the store-house by the\r\nOrontes. In the shade of the summer-house he could drink fully of the\r\ninspiring air lying lightly upon the familiar hills; he could better\r\nwatch the sun rise, run its course, and set as it used to in the\r\nfar-gone, not a habit lost; and with Esther by him it was so much\r\neasier up there close to the sky, to bring back the other Esther, his\r\nlove in youth, his wife, dearer growing with the passage of years. And\r\nyet he was not unmindful of business. Every day a messenger brought him\r\na despatch from Sanballat, in charge of the big commerce behind; and\r\nevery day a despatch left him for Sanballat with directions of such\r\nminuteness of detail as to exclude all judgment save his own, and all\r\nchances except those the Almighty has refused to submit to the most\r\nmindful of men.\r\n\r\nAs Esther started in return to the summer-house, the sunlight fell\r\nsoftly upon the dustless roof, showing her a woman now\xe2\x80\x94small, graceful\r\nin form, of regular features, rosy with youth and health, bright with\r\nintelligence, beautiful with the outshining of a devoted nature\xe2\x80\x94a woman\r\nto be loved because loving was a habit of life irrepressible with her.\r\n\r\nShe looked at the package as she turned, paused, looked at it a second\r\ntime more closely than at first; and the blood rose reddening her\r\ncheeks\xe2\x80\x94the seal was Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s. With quickened steps she hastened on.\r\n\r\nSimonides held the package a moment while he also inspected the seal.\r\nBreaking it open, he gave her the roll it contained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHis eyes were upon her as he spoke, and instantly a troubled expression\r\nfell upon his own face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know who it is from, I see, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94from\xe2\x80\x94our master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough the manner was halting, she met his gaze with modest sincerity.\r\nSlowly his chin sank into the roll of flesh puffed out under it like a\r\ncushion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou love him, Esther,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you thought well of what you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have tried not to think of him, father, except as the master to whom\r\nI am dutifully bound. The effort has not helped me to strength.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good girl, a good girl, even as thy mother was,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, dropping\r\ninto reverie, from which she roused him by unrolling the paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord forgive me, but\xe2\x80\x94but thy love might not have been vainly given\r\nhad I kept fast hold of all I had, as I might have done\xe2\x80\x94such power is\r\nthere in money!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would have been worse for me had you done so, father; for then I\r\nhad been unworthy a look from him, and without pride in you. Shall I\r\nnot read now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me, for your sake, my child, show you the\r\nworst. Seeing it with me may make it less terrible to you. His love,\r\nEsther, is all bestowed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Egyptian has him in her net,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cShe has the cunning\r\nof her race, with beauty to help her\xe2\x80\x94much beauty, great cunning; but,\r\nlike her race again, no heart. The daughter who despises her father\r\nwill bring her husband to grief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes she that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBalthasar is a wise man who has been wonderfully favored for a\r\nGentile, and his faith becomes him; yet she makes a jest of it. I heard\r\nher say, speaking of him yesterday, \xe2\x80\x98The follies of youth are\r\nexcusable; nothing is admirable in the aged except wisdom, and when\r\nthat goes from them, they should die.\xe2\x80\x99 A cruel speech, fit for a Roman.\r\nI applied it to myself, knowing a feebleness like her father\xe2\x80\x99s will\r\ncome to me also\xe2\x80\x94nay, it is not far off. But you, Esther, will never say\r\nof me\xe2\x80\x94no, never\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98It were better he were dead.\xe2\x80\x99 No, your mother was a\r\ndaughter of Judah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith half-formed tears, she kissed him, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cI am my mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchild.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and my daughter\xe2\x80\x94my daughter, who is to me all the Temple was to\r\nSolomon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a silence, he laid his hand upon her shoulder, and resumed: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen\r\nhe has taken the Egyptian to wife, Esther, he will think of you with\r\nrepentance and much calling of the spirit; for at last he will awake to\r\nfind himself but the minister of her bad ambition. Rome is the centre\r\nof all her dreams. To her he is the son of Arrius the duumvir, not the\r\nson of Hur, Prince of Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther made no attempt to conceal the effect of these words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSave him, father! It is not too late!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, entreatingly.\r\n\r\nHe answered, with a dubious smile, \xe2\x80\x9cA man drowning may be saved; not so\r\na man in love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have influence with him. He is alone in the world. Show him\r\nhis danger. Tell him what a woman she is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat might save him from her. Would it give him to you, Esther? No,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand his brows fell darkly over his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a servant, as my fathers\r\nwere for generations; yet I could not say to him, \xe2\x80\x98Lo, master, my\r\ndaughter! She is fairer than the Egyptian, and loves thee better!\xe2\x80\x99 I\r\nhave caught too much from years of liberty and direction. The words\r\nwould blister my tongue. The stones upon the old hills yonder would\r\nturn in their beds for shame when I go out to them. No, by the\r\npatriarchs, Esther, I would rather lay us both with your mother to\r\nsleep as she sleeps!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA blush burned Esther\xe2\x80\x99s whole face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not mean you to tell him so, father. I was concerned for him\r\nalone\xe2\x80\x94for his happiness, not mine. Because I have dared love him, I\r\nshall keep myself worthy his respect; so only can I excuse my folly.\r\nLet me read his letter now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe began at once, in haste to conclude the distasteful subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNisan, 8th day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the road from Galilee to Jerusalem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Nazarene is on the way also. With him, though without his\r\nknowledge, I am bringing a full legion of mine. A second legion\r\nfollows. The Passover will excuse the multitude. He said upon setting\r\nout, \xe2\x80\x98We will go up to Jerusalem, and all things that are written by\r\nthe prophets concerning me shall be accomplished.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur waiting draws to an end.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn haste.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to thee, Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBEN-HUR.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther returned the letter to her father, while a choking sensation\r\ngathered in her throat. There was not a word in the missive for her\xe2\x80\x94not\r\neven in the salutation had she a share\xe2\x80\x94and it would have been so easy\r\nto have written \xe2\x80\x9cand to thine, peace.\xe2\x80\x9d For the first time in her life\r\nshe felt the smart of a jealous sting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe eighth day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, \xe2\x80\x9cthe eighth day; and this, Esther,\r\nthis is the\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ninth,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then, they may be in Bethany now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd possibly we may see him to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, pleased into\r\nmomentary forgetfulness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be, it may be! To-morrow is the Feast of Unleavened Bread, and\r\nhe may wish to celebrate it; so may the Nazarene; and we may see him\xe2\x80\x94we\r\nmay see both of them, Esther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point the servant appeared with the wine and water. Esther\r\nhelped her father, and in the midst of the service Iras came upon the\r\nroof.\r\n\r\nTo the Jewess the Egyptian never appeared so very, very beautiful as at\r\nthat moment. Her gauzy garments fluttered about her like a little cloud\r\nof mist; her forehead, neck, and arms glittered with the massive\r\njewelry so affected by her people. Her countenance was suffused with\r\npleasure. She moved with buoyant steps, and self-conscious, though\r\nwithout affectation. Esther at the sight shrank within herself, and\r\nnestled closer to her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, Simonides, and to the pretty Esther peace,\xe2\x80\x9d said Iras,\r\ninclining her head to the latter. \xe2\x80\x9cYou remind me, good master\xe2\x80\x94if I may\r\nsay it without offence-you remind me of the priests in Persia who climb\r\ntheir temples at the decline of day to send prayers after the departing\r\nsun. Is there anything in the worship you do not know, let me call my\r\nfather. He is Magian-bred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair Egyptian,\xe2\x80\x9d the merchant replied, nodding with grave politeness,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyour father is a good man who would not be offended if he knew I told\r\nyou his Persian lore is the least part of his wisdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIras\xe2\x80\x99s lip curled slightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo speak like a philosopher, as you invite me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe least\r\npart always implies a greater. Let me ask what you esteem the greater\r\npart of the rare quality you are pleased to attribute to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides turned upon her somewhat sternly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPure wisdom always directs itself towards God; the purest wisdom is\r\nknowledge of God; and no man of my acquaintance has it in higher\r\ndegree, or makes it more manifest in speech and act, than the good\r\nBalthasar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo end the parley, he raised the cup and drank.\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian turned to Esther a little testily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man who has millions in store, and fleets of ships at sea, cannot\r\ndiscern in what simple women like us find amusement. Let us leave him.\r\nBy the wall yonder we can talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went to the parapet then, stopping at the place where, years\r\nbefore, Ben-Hur loosed the broken tile upon the head of Gratus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not been to Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d Iras began, toying the while with one of\r\nher unclasped bracelets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Esther, demurely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not wished to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how little there has been of your life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sigh that succeeded the exclamation could not have been more\r\npiteously expressive had the loss been the Egyptian\xe2\x80\x99s own. Next moment\r\nher laugh might have been heard in the street below; and she said \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\noh, my pretty simpleton! The half-fledged birds nested in the ear of\r\nthe great bust out on the Memphian sands know nearly as much as you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, seeing Esther\xe2\x80\x99s confusion, she changed her manner, and said in a\r\nconfiding tone, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must not take offence. Oh no! I was playing. Let\r\nme kiss the hurt, and tell you what I would not to any other\xe2\x80\x94not if\r\nSimbel himself asked it of me, offering a lotus-cup of the spray of the\r\nNile!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother laugh, masking excellently the look she turned sharply upon the\r\nJewess, and she said, \xe2\x80\x9cThe King is coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther gazed at her in innocent surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Nazarene,\xe2\x80\x9d Iras continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9che whom our fathers have been talking\r\nabout so much, whom Ben-Hur has been serving and toiling for so\r\nlong\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94her voice dropped several tones lower\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe Nazarene will be here\r\nto-morrow, and Ben-Hur to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther struggled to maintain her composure, but failed: her eyes fell,\r\nthe tell-tale blood surged to her cheek and forehead, and she was saved\r\nsight of the triumphant smile that passed, like a gleam, over the face\r\nof the Egyptian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, here is his promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd from her girdle she took a roll.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRejoice with me, O my friend! He will be here tonight! On the Tiber\r\nthere is a house, a royal property, which he has pledged to me; and to\r\nbe its mistress is to be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA sound of some one walking swiftly along the street below interrupted\r\nthe speech, and she leaned over the parapet to see. Then she drew back,\r\nand cried, with hands clasped above her head, \xe2\x80\x9cNow blessed be Isis!\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis he\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur himself! That he should appear while I had such thought\r\nof him! There are no gods if it be not a good omen. Put your arms about\r\nme, Esther\xe2\x80\x94and a kiss!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jewess looked up. Upon each cheek there was a glow; her eyes\r\nsparkled with a light more nearly of anger than ever her nature emitted\r\nbefore. Her gentleness had been too roughly overridden. It was not\r\nenough for her to be forbidden more than fugitive dreams of the man she\r\nloved; a boastful rival must tell her in confidence of her better\r\nsuccess, and of the brilliant promises which were its rewards. Of her,\r\nthe servant of a servant, there had been no hint of remembrance; this\r\nother could show his letter, leaving her to imagine all it breathed. So\r\nshe said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDost thou love him so much, then, or Rome so much better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Egyptian drew back a step; then she bent her haughty head quite\r\nnear her questioner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is he to thee, daughter of Simonides?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther, all thrilling, began, \xe2\x80\x9cHe is my\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA thought blasting as lightning stayed the words: she paled, trembled,\r\nrecovered, and answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is my father\xe2\x80\x99s friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer tongue had refused to admit her servile condition.\r\n\r\nIras laughed more lightly than before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more than that?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, by the lover-gods of Egypt, thou\r\nmayst keep thy kisses\xe2\x80\x94keep them. Thou hast taught me but now that there\r\nare others vastly more estimable waiting me here in Judea; and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nturned away, looking back over her shoulder\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI will go get them. Peace\r\nto thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther saw her disappear down the steps, when, putting her hands over\r\nher face, she burst into tears so they ran scalding through her\r\nfingers\xe2\x80\x94tears of shame and choking passion. And, to deepen the paroxysm\r\nto her even temper so strange, up with a new meaning of withering force\r\nrose her father\xe2\x80\x99s words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThy love might not have been vainly given had\r\nI kept fast hold of all I had, as I might have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd all the stars were out, burning low above the city and the dark\r\nwall of mountains about it, before she recovered enough to go back to\r\nthe summer-house, and in silence take her accustomed place at her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s side, humbly waiting his pleasure. To such duty it seemed her\r\nyouth, if not her life, must be given. And, let the truth be said, now\r\nthat the pang was spent, she went not unwillingly back to the duty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nAn hour or thereabouts after the scene upon the roof, Balthasar and\r\nSimonides, the latter attended by Esther, met in the great chamber of\r\nthe palace; and while they were talking, Ben-Hur and Iras came in\r\ntogether.\r\n\r\nThe young Jew, advancing in front of his companion, walked first to\r\nBalthasar, and saluted him, and received his reply; then he turned to\r\nSimonides, but paused at sight of Esther.\r\n\r\nIt is not often we have hearts roomy enough for more than one of the\r\nabsorbing passions at the same time; in its blaze the others may\r\ncontinue to live, but only as lesser lights. So with Ben-Hur, much\r\nstudy of possibilities, indulgence of hopes and dreams, influences born\r\nof the condition of his country, influences more direct\xe2\x80\x94that of Iras,\r\nfor example\xe2\x80\x94had made him in the broadest worldly sense ambitious; and\r\nas he had given the passion place, allowing it to become a rule, and\r\nfinally an imperious governor, the resolves and impulses of former days\r\nfaded imperceptibly out of being, and at last almost out of\r\nrecollection. It is at best so easy to forget our youth; in his case it\r\nwas but natural that his own sufferings and the mystery darkening the\r\nfate of his family should move him less and less as, in hope at least,\r\nhe approached nearer and nearer the goals which occupied all his\r\nvisions. Only let us not judge him too harshly.\r\n\r\nHe paused in surprise at seeing Esther a woman now, and so beautiful;\r\nand as he stood looking at her a still voice reminded him of broken\r\nvows and duties undone: almost his old self returned.\r\n\r\nFor an instant he was startled; but recovering, he went to Esther, and\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cPeace to thee, sweet Esther\xe2\x80\x94peace; and thou, Simonides\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nlooked to the merchant as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe blessing of the Lord be thine,\r\nif only because thou hast been a good father to the fatherless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther heard him with downcast face; Simonides answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI repeat the welcome of the good Balthasar, son of Hur\xe2\x80\x94welcome to thy\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s house; and sit, and tell us of thy travels, and of thy work,\r\nand of the wonderful Nazarene\xe2\x80\x94who he is, and what. If thou art not at\r\nease here, who shall be? Sit, I pray\xe2\x80\x94there, between us, that we may all\r\nhear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther stepped out quickly and brought a covered stool, and set it for\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to her, gratefully.\r\n\r\nWhen seated, after some other conversation, he addressed himself to the\r\nmen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come to tell you of the Nazarene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two became instantly attentive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor many days now I have followed him with such watchfulness as one\r\nmay give another upon whom he is waiting so anxiously. I have seen him\r\nunder all circumstances said to be trials and tests of men; and while I\r\nam certain he is a man as I am, not less certain am I that he is\r\nsomething more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat more?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome one coming into the room interrupted him; he turned, and arose\r\nwith extended hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah! Dear old Amrah!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n\r\nShe came forward; and they, seeing the joy in her face, thought not\r\nonce how wrinkled and tawny it was. She knelt at his feet, clasped his\r\nknees, and kissed his hands over and over; and when he could he put the\r\nlank gray hair from her cheeks, and kissed them, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cGood Amrah,\r\nhave you nothing, nothing of them\xe2\x80\x94not a word\xe2\x80\x94not one little sign?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen she broke into sobbing which made him answer plainer even than the\r\nspoken word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s will has been done,\xe2\x80\x9d he next said, solemnly, in a tone to make\r\neach listener know he had no hope more of finding his people. In his\r\neyes there were tears which he would not have them see, because he was\r\na man.\r\n\r\nWhen he could again, he took seat, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, sit by me,\r\nAmrah\xe2\x80\x94here. No? then at my feet; for I have much to say to these good\r\nfriends of a wonderful man come into the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she went off, and stooping with her back to the wall, joined her\r\nhands before her knees, content, they all thought, with seeing him.\r\nThen Ben-Hur, bowing to the old men, began again:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear to answer the question asked me about the Nazarene without\r\nfirst telling you some of the things I have seen him do; and to that I\r\nam the more inclined, my friends, because to-morrow he will come to the\r\ncity, and go up into the Temple, which he calls his father\xe2\x80\x99s house,\r\nwhere, it is further said, he will proclaim himself. So, whether you\r\nare right, O Balthasar, or you, Simonides, we and Israel shall know\r\nto-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar rubbed his hands tremulously together, and asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\r\nshall I go to see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe pressure of the crowd will be very great. Better, I think, that\r\nyou all go upon the roof above the cloisters\xe2\x80\x94say upon the Porch of\r\nSolomon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you be with us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, \xe2\x80\x9cmy friends will require me, perhaps, in the\r\nprocession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProcession!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Simonides. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes he travel in state?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur saw the argument in mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe brings twelve men with him, fishermen, tillers of the soil, one a\r\npublican, all of the humbler class; and he and they make their journeys\r\non foot, careless of wind, cold, rain, or sun. Seeing them stop by the\r\nwayside at nightfall to break bread or lie down to sleep, I have been\r\nreminded of a party of shepherds going back to their flocks from\r\nmarket, not of nobles and kings. Only when he lifts the corners of his\r\nhandkerchief to look at some one or shake the dust from his head, I am\r\nmade known he is their teacher as well as their companion\xe2\x80\x94their\r\nsuperior not less than their friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are shrewd men,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur resumed, after a pause. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know what\r\ncreatures of certain master motives we are, and that it has become\r\nlittle less than a law of our nature to spend life in eager pursuit of\r\ncertain objects; now, appealing to that law as something by which we\r\nmay know ourselves, what would you say of a man who could be rich by\r\nmaking gold of the stones under his feet, yet is poor of choice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Greeks would call him a philosopher,\xe2\x80\x9d said Iras.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, \xe2\x80\x9cthe philosophers had never the power\r\nto do such thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow know you this man has?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur answered quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw him turn water into wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery strange, very strange,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is not so strange\r\nto me as that he should prefer to live poor when he could be so rich.\r\nIs he so poor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe owns nothing, and envies nobody his owning. He pities the rich. But\r\npassing that, what would you say to see a man multiply seven loaves and\r\ntwo fishes, all his store, into enough to feed five thousand people,\r\nand have full baskets over? That I saw the Nazarene do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou saw it?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, and ate of the bread and fish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore marvellous still,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat would you say of a\r\nman in whom there is such healing virtue that the sick have but to\r\ntouch the hem of his garment to be cured, or cry to him afar? That,\r\ntoo, I witnessed, not once, but many times. As we came out of Jericho\r\ntwo blind men by the wayside called to the Nazarene, and he touched\r\ntheir eyes, and they saw. So they brought a palsied man to him, and he\r\nsaid merely, \xe2\x80\x98Go unto thy house,\xe2\x80\x99 and the man went away well. What say\r\nyou to these things?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merchant had no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink you now, as I have heard others argue, that what I have told you\r\nare tricks of jugglery? Let me answer by recalling greater things which\r\nI have seen him do. Look first to that curse of God\xe2\x80\x94comfortless, as you\r\nall know, except by death\xe2\x80\x94leprosy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words Amrah dropped her hands to the floor, and in her\r\neagerness to hear him half arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, with increased earnestness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nwould you say to have seen that I now tell you? A leper came to the\r\nNazarene while I was with him down in Galilee, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Lord, if thou\r\nwilt, thou canst make me clean.\xe2\x80\x99 He heard the cry, and touched the\r\noutcast with his hand, saying, \xe2\x80\x98Be thou clean;\xe2\x80\x99 and forthwith the man\r\nwas himself again, healthful as any of us who beheld the cure, and we\r\nwere a multitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Amrah arose, and with her gaunt fingers held the wiry locks from\r\nher eyes. The brain of the poor creature had long since gone to heart,\r\nand she was troubled to follow the speech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, without stop, \xe2\x80\x9cten lepers came to him one\r\nday in a body, and falling at his feet, called out\xe2\x80\x94I saw and heard it\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94called out, \xe2\x80\x98Master, Master, have mercy upon us!\xe2\x80\x99 He told them,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Go, show yourselves to the priest, as the law requires; and before you\r\nare come there ye shall be healed.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd were they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. On the road going their infirmity left them, so that there was\r\nnothing to remind us of it except their polluted clothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch thing was never heard before\xe2\x80\x94never in all Israel!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSimonides, in undertone.\r\n\r\nAnd then, while he was speaking, Amrah turned away, and walked\r\nnoiselessly to the door, and went out; and none of the company saw her\r\ngo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe thoughts stirred by such things done under my eyes I leave you to\r\nimagine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, continuing; \xe2\x80\x9cbut my doubts, my misgivings, my\r\namazement, were not yet at the full. The people of Galilee are, as you\r\nknow, impetuous and rash; after years of waiting their swords burned\r\ntheir hands; nothing would do them but action. \xe2\x80\x98He is slow to declare\r\nhimself; let us force him,\xe2\x80\x99 they cried to me. And I too became\r\nimpatient. If he is to be king, why not now? The legions are ready. So\r\nas he was once teaching by the seaside we would have crowned him\r\nwhether or not; but he disappeared, and was next seen on a ship\r\ndeparting from the shore. Good Simonides, the desires that make other\r\nmen mad\xe2\x80\x94riches, power, even kingships offered out of great love by a\r\ngreat people\xe2\x80\x94move this one not at all. What say you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merchant\xe2\x80\x99s chin was low upon his breast; raising his head, he\r\nreplied, resolutely, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lord liveth, and so do the words of the\r\nprophets. Time is in the green yet; let to-morrow answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, smiling.\r\n\r\nAnd Ben-Hur said, \xe2\x80\x9cBe it so.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he went on: \xe2\x80\x9cBut I have not yet\r\ndone. From these things, not too great to be above suspicion by such as\r\ndid not see them in performance as I did, let me carry you now to\r\nothers infinitely greater, acknowledged since the world began to be\r\npast the power of man. Tell me, has any one to your knowledge ever\r\nreached out and taken from Death what Death has made his own? Who ever\r\ngave again the breath of a life lost? Who but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod!\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar, reverently.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO wise Egyptian! I may not refuse the name you lend me. What would\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94or you, Simonides\xe2\x80\x94what would you either or both have said had you\r\nseen as I did, a man, with few words and no ceremony, without effort\r\nmore than a mother\xe2\x80\x99s when she speaks to wake her child asleep, undo the\r\nwork of Death? It was down at Nain. We were about going into the gate,\r\nwhen a company came out bearing a dead man. The Nazarene stopped to let\r\nthe train pass. There was a woman among them crying. I saw his face\r\nsoften with pity. He spoke to her, then went and touched the bier, and\r\nsaid to him who lay upon it dressed for burial, \xe2\x80\x98Young man, I say unto\r\nthee, Arise!\xe2\x80\x99 And instantly the dead sat up and talked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod only is so great,\xe2\x80\x9d said Balthasar to Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMark you,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cI do but tell you things of which I was\r\na witness, together with a cloud of other men. On the way hither I saw\r\nanother act still more mighty. In Bethany there was a man named\r\nLazarus, who died and was buried; and after he had lain four days in a\r\ntomb, shut in by a great stone, the Nazarene was shown to the place.\r\nUpon rolling the stone away, we beheld the man lying inside bound and\r\nrotting. There were many people standing by, and we all heard what the\r\nNazarene said, for he spoke in a loud voice: \xe2\x80\x98Lazarus, come forth!\xe2\x80\x99 I\r\ncannot tell you my feelings when in answer, as it were, the man arose\r\nand came out to us with all his cerements about him. \xe2\x80\x98Loose him,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe Nazarene next, \xe2\x80\x98loose him, and let him go.\xe2\x80\x99 And when the napkin was\r\ntaken from the face of the resurrected, lo, my friends! the blood ran\r\nanew through the wasted body, and he was exactly as he had been in life\r\nbefore the sickness that took him off. He lives yet, and is hourly seen\r\nand spoken to. You may go see him to-morrow. And now, as nothing more\r\nis needed for the purpose, I ask you that which I came to ask, it being\r\nbut a repetition of what you asked me, O Simonides, What more than a\r\nman is this Nazarene?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question was put solemnly, and long after midnight the company sat\r\nand debated it; Simonides being yet unwilling to give up his\r\nunderstanding of the sayings of the prophets, and Ben-Hur contending\r\nthat the elder disputants were both right\xe2\x80\x94that the Nazarene was the\r\nRedeemer, as claimed by Balthasar, and also the destined king the\r\nmerchant would have.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow we will see. Peace to you all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, Ben-Hur took his leave, intending to return to Bethany.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nThe first person to go out of the city upon the opening of the Sheep\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGate next morning was Amrah, basket on arm. No questions were asked her\r\nby the keepers, since the morning itself had not been more regular in\r\ncoming than she; they knew her somebody\xe2\x80\x99s faithful servant, and that\r\nwas enough for them.\r\n\r\nDown the eastern valley she took her way. The side of Olivet, darkly\r\ngreen, was spotted with white tents recently put up by people attending\r\nthe feasts; the hour, however, was too early for the strangers to be\r\nabroad; still, had it not been so, no one would have troubled her. Past\r\nGethsemane; past the tombs at the meeting of the Bethany roads; past\r\nthe sepulchral village of Siloam she went. Occasionally the decrepit\r\nlittle body staggered; once she sat down to get her breath; rising\r\nshortly, she struggled on with renewed haste. The great rocks on either\r\nhand, if they had had ears, might have heard her mutter to herself;\r\ncould they have seen, it would have been to observe how frequently she\r\nlooked up over the Mount, reproving the dawn for its promptness; if it\r\nhad been possible for them to gossip, not improbably they would have\r\nsaid to each other, \xe2\x80\x9cOur friend is in a hurry this morning; the mouths\r\nshe goes to feed must be very hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen at last she reached the King\xe2\x80\x99s Garden she slackened her gait; for\r\nthen the grim city of the lepers was in view, extending far round the\r\npitted south hill of Hinnom.\r\n\r\nAs the reader must by this time have surmised, she was going to her\r\nmistress, whose tomb, it will be remembered, overlooked the well\r\nEn-Rogel.\r\n\r\nEarly as it was, the unhappy woman was up and sitting outside, leaving\r\nTirzah asleep within. The course of the malady had been terribly swift\r\nin the three years. Conscious of her appearance, with the refined\r\ninstincts of her nature, she kept her whole person habitually covered.\r\nSeldom as possible she permitted even Tirzah to see her.\r\n\r\nThis morning she was taking the air with bared head, knowing there was\r\nno one to be shocked by the exposure. The light was not full, but\r\nenough to show the ravages to which she had been subject. Her hair was\r\nsnow-white and unmanageably coarse, falling over her back and shoulders\r\nlike so much silver wire. The eyelids, the lips, the nostrils, the\r\nflesh of the cheeks, were either gone or reduced to fetid rawness. The\r\nneck was a mass of ash-colored scales. One hand lay outside the folds\r\nof her habit rigid as that of a skeleton; the nails had been eaten\r\naway; the joints of the fingers, if not bare to the bone, were swollen\r\nknots crusted with red secretion. Head, face, neck, and hand indicated\r\nall too plainly the condition of the whole body.
