Seeing her thus, it\r\nwas easy to understand how the once fair widow of the princely Hur had\r\nbeen able to maintain her incognito so well through such a period of\r\nyears.\r\n\r\nWhen the sun would gild the crest of Olivet and the Mount of Offence\r\nwith light sharper and more brilliant in that old land than in the\r\nWest, she knew Amrah would come, first to the well, then to a stone\r\nmidway the well and the foot of the hill on which she had her abode,\r\nand that the good servant would there deposit the food she carried in\r\nthe basket, and fill the water-jar afresh for the day. Of her former\r\nplentitude of happiness, that brief visit was all that remained to the\r\nunfortunate. She could then ask about her son, and be told of his\r\nwelfare, with such bits of news concerning him as the messenger could\r\nglean. Usually the information was meagre enough, yet comforting; at\r\ntimes she heard he was at home; then she would issue from her dreary\r\ncell at break of day, and sit till noon, and from noon to set of sun, a\r\nmotionless figure draped in white, looking, statue-like, invariably to\r\none point\xe2\x80\x94over the Temple to the spot under the rounded sky where the\r\nold house stood, dear in memory, and dearer because he was there.\r\nNothing else was left her. Tirzah she counted of the dead; and as for\r\nherself, she simply waited the end, knowing every hour of life was an\r\nhour of dying\xe2\x80\x94happily, of painless dying.\r\n\r\nThe things of nature about the hill to keep her sensitive to the\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x99s attractions were wretchedly scant; beasts and birds avoided the\r\nplace as if they knew its history and present use; every green thing\r\nperished in its first season; the winds warred upon the shrubs and\r\nventurous grasses, leaving to drought such as they could not uproot.\r\nLook where she would, the view was made depressingly suggestive by\r\ntombs\xe2\x80\x94tombs above her, tombs below, tombs opposite her own tomb\xe2\x80\x94all now\r\nfreshly whitened in warning to visiting pilgrims. In the sky\xe2\x80\x94clear,\r\nfair, inviting\xe2\x80\x94one would think she might have found some relief to her\r\nache of mind; but, alas! in making the beautiful elsewhere the sun\r\nserved her never so unfriendly\xe2\x80\x94it did but disclose her growing\r\nhideousness. But for the sun she would not have been the horror she was\r\nto herself, nor been waked so cruelly from dreams of Tirzah as she used\r\nto be. The gift of seeing can be sometimes a dreadful curse.\r\n\r\nDoes one ask why she did not make an end to her sufferings?\r\n\r\nTHE LAW FORBADE HER!\r\n\r\nA Gentile may smile at the answer; but so will not a son of Israel.\r\n\r\nWhile she sat there peopling the dusky solitude with thoughts even more\r\ncheerless, suddenly a woman came up the hill staggering and spent with\r\nexertion.\r\n\r\nThe widow arose hastily, and covering her head, cried, in a voice\r\nunnaturally harsh, \xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a moment, heedless of the notice, Amrah was at her feet. All the\r\nlong-pent love of the simple creature burst forth: with tears and\r\npassionate exclamations she kissed her mistress\xe2\x80\x99s garments, and for a\r\nwhile the latter strove to escape from her; then, seeing she could not,\r\nshe waited till the violence of the paroxysm was over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done, Amrah?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it by such disobedience you\r\nprove your love for us? Wicked woman! You are lost; and he\xe2\x80\x94your\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94you can never, never go back to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah grovelled sobbing in the dust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ban of the Law is upon you, too; you cannot return to Jerusalem.\r\nWhat will become of us? Who will bring us bread? O wicked, wicked\r\nAmrah! We are all, all undone alike!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy, mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d Amrah answered from the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have been merciful to yourself, and by so doing been most\r\nmerciful to us. Now where can we fly? There is no one to help us. O\r\nfalse servant! The wrath of the Lord was already too heavy upon us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Tirzah, awakened by the noise, appeared at the door of the tomb.\r\nThe pen shrinks from the picture she presented. In the half-clad\r\napparition, patched with scales, lividly seamed, nearly blind, its\r\nlimbs and extremities swollen to grotesque largeness, familiar eyes\r\nhowever sharpened by love could not have recognized the creature of\r\nchildish grace and purity we first beheld her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it Amrah, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant tried to crawl to her also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Amrah!\xe2\x80\x9d the widow cried, imperiously. \xe2\x80\x9cI forbid you touching\r\nher. Rise, and get you gone before any at the well see you here. Nay, I\r\nforgot\xe2\x80\x94it is too late! You must remain now and share our doom. Rise, I\r\nsay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah rose to her knees, and said, brokenly and with clasped hands, \xe2\x80\x9cO\r\ngood mistress! I am not false\xe2\x80\x94I am not wicked. I bring you good\r\ntidings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Judah?\xe2\x80\x9d and as she spoke, the widow half withdrew the cloth from\r\nher head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a wonderful man,\xe2\x80\x9d Amrah continued, \xe2\x80\x9cwho has power to cure\r\nyou. He speaks a word, and the sick are made well, and even the dead\r\ncome to life. I have come to take you to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Amrah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tirzah, compassionately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Amrah, detecting the doubt underlying the expression\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno,\r\nas the Lord lives, even the Lord of Israel, my God as well as yours, I\r\nspeak the truth. Go with me, I pray, and lose no time. This morning he\r\nwill pass by on his way to the city. See! the day is at hand. Take the\r\nfood here\xe2\x80\x94eat, and let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother listened eagerly. Not unlikely she had heard of the\r\nwonderful man, for by this time his fame had penetrated every nook in\r\nthe land.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Nazarene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you about him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudah told you? Is he at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe came last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe widow, trying to still the beating of her heart, was silent awhile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Judah send you to tell us this?\xe2\x80\x9d she next asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. He believes you dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a prophet once who cured a leper,\xe2\x80\x9d the mother said\r\nthoughtfully to Tirzah; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he had his power from God.\xe2\x80\x9d Then\r\naddressing Amrah, she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cHow does my son know this man so\r\npossessed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was travelling with him, and heard the lepers call, and saw them go\r\naway well. First there was one man; then there were ten; and they were\r\nall made whole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe elder listener was silent again. The skeleton hand shook. We may\r\nbelieve she was struggling to give the story the sanction of faith,\r\nwhich is always an absolutist in demand, and that it was with her as\r\nwith the men of the day, eye-witnesses of what was done by the Christ,\r\nas well as the myriads who have succeeded them. She did not question\r\nthe performance, for her own son was the witness testifying through the\r\nservant; but she strove to comprehend the power by which work so\r\nastonishing could be done by a man. Well enough to make inquiry as to\r\nthe fact; to comprehend the power, on the other hand, it is first\r\nnecessary to comprehend God; and he who waits for that will die\r\nwaiting. With her, however, the hesitation was brief. To Tirzah she\r\nsaid,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis must be the Messiah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe spoke not coldly, like one reasoning a doubt away, but as a woman\r\nof Israel familiar with the promises of God to her race\xe2\x80\x94a woman of\r\nunderstanding, ready to be glad over the least sign of the realization\r\nof the promises.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a time when Jerusalem and all Judea were filled with a story\r\nthat he was born. I remember it. By this time he should be a man. It\r\nmust be\xe2\x80\x94it is he. Yes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Amrah, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will go with you. Bring\r\nthe water which you will find in the tomb in a jar, and set the food\r\nfor us. We will eat and be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe breakfast, partaken under excitement, was soon despatched, and the\r\nthree women set out on their extraordinary journey. As Tirzah had\r\ncaught the confident spirit of the others, there was but one fear that\r\ntroubled the party. Bethany, Amrah said, was the town the man was\r\ncoming from; now from that to Jerusalem there were three roads, or\r\nrather paths\xe2\x80\x94one over the first summit of Olivet, a second at its base,\r\na third between the second summit and the Mount of Offence. The three\r\nwere not far apart; far enough, however, to make it possible for the\r\nunfortunates to miss the Nazarene if they failed the one he chose to\r\ncome by.\r\n\r\nA little questioning satisfied the mother that Amrah knew nothing of\r\nthe country beyond the Cedron, and even less of the intentions of the\r\nman they were going to see, if they could. She discerned, also, that\r\nboth Amrah and Tirzah\xe2\x80\x94the one from confirmed habits of servitude, the\r\nother from natural dependency\xe2\x80\x94looked to her for guidance; and she\r\naccepted the charge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will go first to Bethphage,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to them. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, if the Lord\r\nfavor us, we may learn what else to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey descended the hill to Tophet and the King\xe2\x80\x99s Garden, and paused in\r\nthe deep trail furrowed through them by centuries of wayfaring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid of the road,\xe2\x80\x9d the matron said. \xe2\x80\x9cBetter that we keep to the\r\ncountry among the rocks and trees. This is feast-day, and on the\r\nhill-sides yonder I see signs of a great multitude in attendance. By\r\ngoing across the Mount of Offence here we may avoid them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTirzah had been walking with great difficulty; upon hearing this her\r\nheart began to fail her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mount is steep, mother; I cannot climb it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, we are going to find health and life. See, my child, how the\r\nday brightens around us! And yonder are women coming this way to the\r\nwell. They will stone us if we stay here. Come, be strong this once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus the mother, not less tortured herself, sought to inspire the\r\ndaughter; and Amrah came to her aid. To this time the latter had not\r\ntouched the persons of the afflicted, nor they her; now, in disregard\r\nof consequences as well as of command, the faithful creature went to\r\nTirzah, and put her arm over her shoulder, and whispered, \xe2\x80\x9cLean on me.\r\nI am strong, though I am old; and it is but a little way off. There\xe2\x80\x94now\r\nwe can go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe face of the hill they essayed to cross was somewhat broken with\r\npits, and ruins of old structures; but when at last they stood upon the\r\ntop to rest, and looked at the spectacle presented them over in the\r\nnorthwest\xe2\x80\x94at the Temple and its courtly terraces, at Zion, at the\r\nenduring towers white beetling into the sky beyond\xe2\x80\x94the mother was\r\nstrengthened with a love of life for life\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook, Tirzah,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clook at the plates of gold on the Gate\r\nBeautiful. How they give back the flames of the sun, brightness for\r\nbrightness! Do you remember we used to go up there? Will it not be\r\npleasant to do so again? And think\xe2\x80\x94home is but a little way off. I can\r\nalmost see it over the roof of the Holy of Holies; and Judah will be\r\nthere to receive us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the side of the middle summit garnished green with myrtle and\r\nolive trees, they saw, upon looking that way next, thin columns of\r\nsmoke rising lightly and straight up into the pulseless morning, each a\r\nwarning of restless pilgrims astir, and of the flight of the pitiless\r\nhours, and the need of haste.\r\n\r\nThough the good servant toiled faithfully to lighten the labor in\r\ndescending the hill-side, not sparing herself in the least, the girl\r\nmoaned at every step; sometimes in extremity of anguish she cried out.\r\nUpon reaching the road\xe2\x80\x94that is, the road between the Mount of Offence\r\nand the middle or second summit of Olivet\xe2\x80\x94she fell down exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on with Amrah, mother, and leave me here,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Tirzah. What would the gain be to me if I were healed and you\r\nnot? When Judah asks for you, as he will, what would I have to say to\r\nhim were I to leave you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him I loved him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe elder leper arose from bending over the fainting sufferer, and\r\ngazed about her with that sensation of hope perishing which is more\r\nnearly like annihilation of the soul than anything else. The supremest\r\njoy of the thought of cure was inseparable from Tirzah, who was not too\r\nold to forget, in the happiness of healthful life to come, the years of\r\nmisery by which she had been so reduced in body and broken in spirit.\r\nEven as the brave woman was about leaving the venture they were engaged\r\nin to the determination of God, she saw a man on foot coming rapidly up\r\nthe road from the east.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage, Tirzah! Be of cheer,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYonder I know is one to tell\r\nus of the Nazarene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmrah helped the girl to a sitting posture, and supported her while the\r\nman advanced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn your goodness, mother, you forget what we are. The stranger will go\r\naround us; his best gift to us will be a curse, if not a stone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no other answer to be given, since the mother was too well\r\nand sadly acquainted with the treatment outcasts of the class to which\r\nshe belonged were accustomed to at the hands of her countrymen.\r\n\r\nAs has been said, the road at the edge of which the group was posted\r\nwas little more than a worn path or trail, winding crookedly through\r\ntumuli of limestone. If the stranger kept it, he must meet them face to\r\nface; and he did so, until near enough to hear the cry she was bound to\r\ngive. Then, uncovering her head, a further demand of the law, she\r\nshouted shrilly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo her surprise, the man came steadily on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, stopping opposite them not four yards\r\noff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou seest us. Have a care,\xe2\x80\x9d the mother said, with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman, I am the courier of him who speaketh but once to such as thou\r\nand they are healed. I am not afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Nazarene?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messiah,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it true that he cometh to the city to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is now at Bethphage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what road, master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe clasped her hands, and looked up thankfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor whom takest thou him?\xe2\x80\x9d the man asked, with pity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Son of God,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay thou here then; or, as there is a multitude with him, take thy\r\nstand by the rock yonder, the white one under the tree; and as he goeth\r\nby fail not to call to him; call, and fear not. If thy faith but equal\r\nthy knowledge, he will hear thee though all the heavens thunder. I go\r\nto tell Israel, assembled in and about the city, that he is at hand,\r\nand to make ready to receive him. Peace to thee and thine, woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger moved on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you hear, Tirzah? Did you hear? The Nazarene is on the road, on\r\nthis one, and he will hear us. Once more, my child\xe2\x80\x94oh, only once! and\r\nlet us to the rock. It is but a step.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus encouraged Tirzah took Amrah\xe2\x80\x99s hand and arose; but as they were\r\ngoing, Amrah said, \xe2\x80\x9cStay; the man is returning.\xe2\x80\x9d And they waited for\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray your grace, woman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, upon overtaking them. \xe2\x80\x9cRemembering\r\nthat the sun will be hot before the Nazarene arrives, and that the city\r\nis near by to give me refreshment should I need it, I thought this\r\nwater would do thee better than it will me. Take it and be of good\r\ncheer. Call to him as he passes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe followed the words by offering her a gourd full of water, such as\r\nfoot-travellers sometimes carried with them in their journeys across\r\nthe hills; and instead of placing the gift on the ground for her to\r\ntake up when he was at a safe distance, he gave it into her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou a Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am that, and better; I am a disciple of the Christ who teacheth\r\ndaily by word and example this thing which I have done unto you. The\r\nworld hath long known the word charity without understanding it. Again\r\nI say peace and good cheer to thee and thine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went on, and they went slowly to the rock he had pointed out to\r\nthem, high as their heads, and scarcely thirty yards from the road on\r\nthe right. Standing in front of it, the mother satisfied herself they\r\ncould be seen and heard plainly by passers-by whose notice they desired\r\nto attract. There they cast themselves under the tree in its shade, and\r\ndrank of the gourd, and rested refreshed. Ere long Tirzah slept, and\r\nfearing to disturb her, the others held their peace.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the third hour the road in front of the resting-place of the\r\nlepers became gradually more and more frequented by people going in the\r\ndirection of Bethphage and Bethany; now, however, about the\r\ncommencement of the fourth hour, a great crowd appeared over the crest\r\nof Olivet, and as it defiled down the road thousands in number, the two\r\nwatchers noticed with wonder that every one in it carried a palm-branch\r\nfreshly cut. As they sat absorbed by the novelty, the noise of another\r\nmultitude approaching from the east drew their eyes that way. Then the\r\nmother awoke Tirzah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the meaning of it all?\xe2\x80\x9d the latter asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is coming,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the mother. \xe2\x80\x9cThese we see are from the city\r\ngoing to meet him; those we hear in the east are his friends bearing\r\nhim company; and it will not be strange if the processions meet here\r\nbefore us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear, if they do, we cannot be heard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe same thought was in the elder\xe2\x80\x99s mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen Judah spoke of the healing of the ten, in\r\nwhat words did he say they called to the Nazarene?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEither they said, \xe2\x80\x98Lord, have mercy upon us,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98Master, have\r\nmercy.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more that I heard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet it was enough,\xe2\x80\x9d the mother added, to herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Amrah, \xe2\x80\x9cJudah said he saw them go away well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeantime the people in the east came up slowly. When at length the\r\nforemost of them were in sight, the gaze of the lepers fixed upon a man\r\nriding in the midst of what seemed a chosen company which sang and\r\ndanced about him in extravagance of joy. The rider was bareheaded and\r\nclad all in white. When he was in distance to be more clearly observed,\r\nthese, looking anxiously, saw an olive-hued face shaded by long\r\nchestnut hair slightly sunburned and parted in the middle. He looked\r\nneither to the right nor left. In the noisy abandon of his followers he\r\nappeared to have no part; nor did their favor disturb him in the least,\r\nor raise him out of the profound melancholy into which, as his\r\ncountenance showed, he was plunged. The sun beat upon the back of his\r\nhead, and lighting up the floating hair gave it a delicate likeness to\r\na golden nimbus. Behind him the irregular procession, pouring forward\r\nwith continuous singing and shouting, extended out of view. There was\r\nno need of any one to tell the lepers that this was he\xe2\x80\x94the wonderful\r\nNazarene!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is here, Tirzah,\xe2\x80\x9d the mother said; \xe2\x80\x9che is here. Come, my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she spoke she glided in front of the white rock and fell upon her\r\nknees.\r\n\r\nDirectly the daughter and servant were by her side. Then at sight of\r\nthe procession in the west, the thousands from the city halted, and\r\nbegan to wave their green branches, shouting, or rather chanting (for\r\nit was all in one voice),\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlessed is the King of Israel that cometh in the name of the Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd all the thousands who were of the rider\xe2\x80\x99s company, both those near\r\nand those afar, replied so the air shook with the sound, which was as a\r\ngreat wind threshing the side of the hill. Amidst the din, the cries of\r\nthe poor lepers were not more than the twittering of dazed sparrows.\r\n\r\nThe moment of the meeting of the hosts was come, and with it the\r\nopportunity the sufferers were seeking; if not taken, it would be lost\r\nforever, and they would be lost as well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNearer, my child\xe2\x80\x94let us get nearer. He cannot hear us,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nmother.\r\n\r\nShe arose, and staggered forward. Her ghastly hands were up, and she\r\nscreamed with horrible shrillness. The people saw her\xe2\x80\x94saw her hideous\r\nface, and stopped awe-struck\xe2\x80\x94an effect for which extreme human misery,\r\nvisible as in this instance, is as potent as majesty in purple and\r\ngold. Tirzah, behind her a little way, fell down too faint and\r\nfrightened to follow farther.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe lepers! the lepers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStone them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe accursed of God! Kill them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese, with other yells of like import, broke in upon the hosannas of\r\nthe part of the multitude too far removed to see and understand the\r\ncause of the interruption. Some there were, however, near by familiar\r\nwith the nature of the man to whom the unfortunates were appealing\xe2\x80\x94some\r\nwho, by long intercourse with him, had caught somewhat of his divine\r\ncompassion: they gazed at him, and were silent while, in fair view, he\r\nrode up and stopped in front of the woman. She also beheld his\r\nface\xe2\x80\x94calm, pitiful, and of exceeding beauty, the large eyes tender with\r\nbenignant purpose.\r\n\r\nAnd this was the colloquy that ensued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Master, Master! Thou seest our need; thou canst make us clean. Have\r\nmercy upon us\xe2\x80\x94mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelievest thou I am able to do this?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art he of whom the prophets spake\xe2\x80\x94thou art the Messiah!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nreplied.\r\n\r\nHis eyes grew radiant, his manner confident.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cgreat is thy faith; be it unto thee even as thou\r\nwilt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe lingered an instant after, apparently unconscious of the presence of\r\nthe throng\xe2\x80\x94an instant\xe2\x80\x94then he rode away.\r\n\r\nTo the heart divinely original, yet so human in all the better elements\r\nof humanity, going with sure prevision to a death of all the inventions\r\nof men the foulest and most cruel, breathing even then in the forecast\r\nshadow of the awful event, and still as hungry and thirsty for love and\r\nfaith as in the beginning, how precious and ineffably soothing the\r\nfarewell exclamation of the grateful woman:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo God in the highest, glory! Blessed, thrice blessed, the Son whom he\r\nhath given us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nImmediately both the hosts, that from the city and that from Bethphage,\r\nclosed around him with their joyous demonstrations, with hosannas and\r\nwaving of palms, and so he passed from the lepers forever. Covering her\r\nhead, the elder hastened to Tirzah, and folded her in her arms, crying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter, look up! I have his promise; he is indeed the Messiah. We\r\nare saved\xe2\x80\x94saved!\xe2\x80\x9d And the two remained kneeling while the procession,\r\nslowly going, disappeared over the mount. When the noise of its singing\r\nafar was a sound scarcely heard the miracle began.\r\n\r\nThere was first in the hearts of the lepers a freshening of the blood;\r\nthen it flowed faster and stronger, thrilling their wasted bodies with\r\nan infinitely sweet sense of painless healing. Each felt the scourge\r\ngoing from her; their strength revived; they were returning to be\r\nthemselves. Directly, as if to make the purification complete, from\r\nbody to spirit the quickening ran, exalting them to a very fervor of\r\necstasy. The power possessing them to this good end was most nearly\r\nthat of a draught of swift and happy effect; yet it was unlike and\r\nsuperior in that its healing and cleansing were absolute, and not\r\nmerely a delicious consciousness while in progress, but the planting,\r\ngrowing, and maturing all at once of a recollection so singular and so\r\nholy that the simple thought of it should be of itself ever after a\r\nformless yet perfect thanksgiving.\r\n\r\nTo this transformation\xe2\x80\x94for such it may be called quite as properly as a\r\ncure\xe2\x80\x94there was a witness other than Amrah. The reader will remember the\r\nconstancy with which Ben-Hur had followed the Nazarene throughout his\r\nwanderings; and now, recalling the conversation of the night before,\r\nthere will be little surprise at learning that the young Jew was\r\npresent when the leprous woman appeared in the path of the pilgrims. He\r\nheard her prayer, and saw her disfigured face; he heard the answer\r\nalso, and was not so accustomed to incidents of the kind, frequent as\r\nthey had been, as to have lost interest in them. Had such thing been\r\npossible with him, still the bitter disputation always excited by the\r\nsimplest display of the Master\xe2\x80\x99s curative gift would have sufficed to\r\nkeep his curiosity alive. Besides that, if not above it as an\r\nincentive, his hope to satisfy himself upon the vexed question of the\r\nmission of the mysterious man was still upon him strong as in the\r\nbeginning; we might indeed say even stronger, because of a belief that\r\nnow quickly, before the sun went down, the man himself would make all\r\nknown by public proclamation. At the close of the scene, consequently,\r\nBen-Hur had withdrawn from the procession, and seated himself upon a\r\nstone to wait its passage.\r\n\r\nFrom his place he nodded recognition to many of the people\xe2\x80\x94Galileans in\r\nhis league, carrying short swords under their long abbas. After a\r\nlittle a swarthy Arab came up leading two horses; at a sign from\r\nBen-Hur he also drew out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay here,\xe2\x80\x9d the young master said, when all were gone by, even the\r\nlaggards. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish to be at the city early, and Aldebaran must do me\r\nservice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stroked the broad forehead of the horse, now in his prime of\r\nstrength and beauty, then crossed the road towards the two women.\r\n\r\nThey were to him, it should be borne in mind, strangers in whom he felt\r\ninterest only as they were subjects of a superhuman experiment, the\r\nresult of which might possibly help him to solution of the mystery that\r\nhad so long engaged him. As he proceeded, he glanced casually at the\r\nfigure of the little woman over by the white rock, standing there, her\r\nface hidden in her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs the Lord liveth, it is Amrah!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself.\r\n\r\nHe hurried on, and passing by the mother and daughter, still without\r\nrecognizing them, he stopped before the servant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to her, \xe2\x80\x9cAmrah, what do you here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe rushed forward, and fell upon her knees before him, blinded by her\r\ntears, nigh speechless with contending joy and fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO master, master! Thy God and mine, how good he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knowledge we gain from much sympathy with others passing through\r\ntrials is but vaguely understood; strangely enough, it enables us,\r\namong other things, to merge our identity into theirs often so\r\ncompletely that their sorrows and their delights become our own. So\r\npoor Amrah, aloof and hiding her face, knew the transformation the\r\nlepers were undergoing without a word spoken to her\xe2\x80\x94knew it, and shared\r\nall their feeling to the full. Her countenance, her words, her whole\r\nmanner, betrayed her condition; and with swift presentiment he\r\nconnected it with the women he had just passed: he felt her presence\r\nthere at that time was in some way associated with them, and turned\r\nhastily as they arose to their feet. His heart stood still, he became\r\nrooted in his tracks\xe2\x80\x94dumb past outcry\xe2\x80\x94awe-struck.\r\n\r\nThe woman he had seen before the Nazarene was standing with her hands\r\nclasped and eyes streaming, looking towards heaven. The mere\r\ntransformation would have been a sufficient surprise; but it was the\r\nleast of the causes of his emotion. Could he be mistaken? Never was\r\nthere in life a stranger so like his mother; and like her as she was\r\nthe day the Roman snatched her from him. There was but one difference\r\nto mar the identity\xe2\x80\x94the hair of this person was a little streaked with\r\ngray; yet that was not impossible of reconcilement, since the\r\nintelligence which had directed the miracle might have taken into\r\nconsideration the natural effects of the passage of years. And who was\r\nit by her side, if not Tirzah?\xe2\x80\x94fair, beautiful, perfect, more mature,\r\nbut in all other respects exactly the same in appearance as when she\r\nlooked with him over the parapet the morning of the accident to Gratus.\r\nHe had given them over as dead, and time had accustomed him to the\r\nbereavement; he had not ceased mourning for them, yet, as something\r\ndistinguishable, they had simply dropped out of his plans and dreams.\r\nScarcely believing his senses, he laid his hand upon the servant\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhead, and asked, tremulously,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmrah, Amrah\xe2\x80\x94my mother! Tirzah! tell me if I see aright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak to them, O master, speak to them!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nHe waited no longer, but ran, with outstretched arms, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cMother!\r\nmother! Tirzah! Here I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey heard his call, and with a cry as loving started to meet him.\r\nSuddenly the mother stopped, drew back, and uttered the old alarm,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, Judah, my son; come not nearer. Unclean, unclean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe utterance was not from habit, grown since the dread disease struck\r\nher, as much as fear; and the fear was but another form of the\r\never-thoughtful maternal love. Though they were healed in person, the\r\ntaint of the scourge might be in their garments ready for\r\ncommunication. He had no such thought. They were before him; he had\r\ncalled them, they had answered. Who or what should keep them from him\r\nnow? Next moment the three, so long separated, were mingling their\r\ntears in each other\xe2\x80\x99s arms.\r\n\r\nThe first ecstasy over, the mother said, \xe2\x80\x9cIn this happiness, O my\r\nchildren, let us not be ungrateful. Let us begin life anew by\r\nacknowledgment of him to whom we are all so indebted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey fell upon their knees, Amrah with the rest; and the prayer of the\r\nelder outspoken was as a psalm.\r\n\r\nTirzah repeated it word for word; so did Ben-Hur, but not with the same\r\nclear mind and questionless faith; for when they were risen, he asked,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Nazareth, where the man was born, mother, they call him the son of\r\na carpenter. What is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer eyes rested upon him with all their old tenderness, and she\r\nanswered as she had answered the Nazarene himself\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is the Messiah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whence has he his power?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe may know by the use he makes of it. Can you tell me any ill he has\r\ndone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy that sign then I answer, He has his power from God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is not an easy thing to shake off in a moment the expectations\r\nnurtured through years until they have become essentially a part of us;\r\nand though Ben-Hur asked himself what the vanities of the world were to\r\nsuch a one, his ambition was obdurate and would not down. He persisted\r\nas men do yet every day in measuring the Christ by himself. How much\r\nbetter if we measured ourselves by the Christ!\r\n\r\nNaturally, the mother was the first to think of the cares of life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we do now, my son? Where shall we go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Ben-Hur, recalled to duty, observed how completely every trace of\r\nthe scourge had disappeared from his restored people; that each had\r\nback her perfection of person; that, as with Naaman when he came up out\r\nof the water, their flesh had come again like unto the flesh of a\r\nlittle child; and he took off his cloak, and threw it over Tirzah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cthe eye of the stranger would have\r\nshunned you before, now it shall not offend you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe act exposed a sword belted to his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it a time of war?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the mother, anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, then, are you armed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be necessary to defend the Nazarene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus Ben-Hur evaded the whole truth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he enemies? Who are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, mother, they are not all Romans!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he not of Israel, and a man of peace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was never one more so; but in the opinion of the rabbis and\r\nteachers he is guilty of a great crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat crime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn his eyes the uncircumcised Gentile is as worthy favor as a Jew of\r\nthe strictest habit. He preaches a new dispensation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe mother was silent, and they moved to the shade of the tree by the\r\nrock. Calming his impatience to have them home again and hear their\r\nstory, he showed them the necessity of obedience to the law governing\r\nin cases like theirs, and in conclusion called the Arab, bidding him\r\ntake the horses to the gate by Bethesda and await him there; whereupon\r\nthey set out by the way of the Mount of Offence. The return was very\r\ndifferent from the coming; they walked rapidly and with ease, and in\r\ngood time reached a tomb newly made near that of Absalom, overlooking\r\nthe depths of Cedron. Finding it unoccupied, the women took possession,\r\nwhile he went on hastily to make the preparations required for their\r\nnew condition.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur pitched two tents out on the Upper Cedron east a short space of\r\nthe Tombs of the Kings, and furnished them with every comfort at his\r\ncommand; and thither, without loss of time, he conducted his mother and\r\nsister, to remain until the examining priest could certify their\r\nperfect cleansing.\r\n\r\nIn course of the duty, the young man had subjected himself to such\r\nserious defilement as to debar him from participation in the ceremonies\r\nof the great feast, then near at hand. He could not enter the least\r\nsacred of the courts of the Temple. Of necessity, not less than choice,\r\ntherefore, he stayed at the tents with his beloved people. There was a\r\ngreat deal to hear from them, and a great deal to tell them of himself.\r\n\r\nStories such as theirs\xe2\x80\x94sad experiences extending through a lapse of\r\nyears, sufferings of body, acuter sufferings of mind\xe2\x80\x94are usually long\r\nin the telling, the incidents seldom following each other in threaded\r\nconnection. He listened to the narrative and all they told him, with\r\noutward patience masking inward feeling. In fact, his hatred of Rome\r\nand Romans reached a higher mark than ever; his desire for vengeance\r\nbecame a thirst which attempts at reflection only intensified. In the\r\nalmost savage bitterness of his humor many mad impulses took hold of\r\nhim. The opportunities of the highways presented themselves with\r\nsingular force of temptation; he thought seriously of insurrection in\r\nGalilee; even the sea, ordinarily a retrospective horror to him,\r\nstretched itself map-like before his fancy, laced and interlaced with\r\nlines of passage crowded with imperial plunder and imperial travellers;\r\nbut the better judgment matured in calmer hours was happily too firmly\r\nfixed to be supplanted by present passion however strong. Each mental\r\nventure in reach of new expedients brought him back to the old\r\nconclusion\xe2\x80\x94that there could be no sound success except in a war\r\ninvolving all Israel in solid union; and all musing upon the subject,\r\nall inquiry, all hope, ended where they began\xe2\x80\x94in the Nazarene and his\r\npurposes.\r\n\r\nAt odd moments the excited schemer found a pleasure in fashioning a\r\nspeech for that person:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear, O Israel! I am he, the promised of God, born King of the\r\nJews\xe2\x80\x94come to you with the dominion spoken of by the prophets. Rise now,\r\nand lay hold on the world!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWould the Nazarene but speak these few words, what a tumult would\r\nfollow! How many mouths performing the office of trumpets would take\r\nthem up and blow them abroad for the massing of armies!\r\n\r\nWould he speak them?\r\n\r\nAnd eager to begin the work, and answering in the worldly way, Ben-Hur\r\nlost sight of the double nature of the man, and of the other\r\npossibility, that the divine in him might transcend the human. In the\r\nmiracle of which Tirzah and his mother were the witnesses even more\r\nnearly than himself, he saw and set apart and dwelt upon a power ample\r\nenough to raise and support a Jewish crown over the wrecks of the\r\nItalian, and more than ample to remodel society, and convert mankind\r\ninto one purified happy family; and when that work was done, could any\r\none say the peace which might then be ordered without hindrance was not\r\na mission worthy a son of God? Could any one then deny the Redeemership\r\nof the Christ? And discarding all consideration of political\r\nconsequences, what unspeakable personal glory there would then be to\r\nhim as a man? It was not in the nature of any mere mortal to refuse\r\nsuch a career.\r\n\r\nMeantime down the Cedron, and in towards Bezetha, especially on the\r\nroadsides quite up to the Damascus Gate, the country filled rapidly\r\nwith all kinds of temporary shelters for pilgrims to the Passover.\r\nBen-Hur visited the strangers, and talked with them; and returning to\r\nhis tents, he was each time more and more astonished at the vastness of\r\ntheir numbers. And when he further discovered that every part of the\r\nworld was represented among them\xe2\x80\x94cities upon both shores of the\r\nMediterranean far off as the Pillars of the West, river-towns in\r\ndistant India, provinces in northernmost Europe; and that, though they\r\nfrequently saluted him with tongues unacquainted with a syllable of the\r\nold Hebrew of the fathers, these representatives had all the same\r\nobject\xe2\x80\x94celebration of the notable feast\xe2\x80\x94an idea tinged mistily with\r\nsuperstitious fancy forced itself upon him. Might he not after all have\r\nmisunderstood the Nazarene? Might not that person by patient waiting be\r\ncovering silent preparation, and proving his fitness for the glorious\r\ntask before him? How much better this time for the movement than that\r\nother when, by Gennesaret, the Galileans would have forced assumption\r\nof the crown? Then the support would have been limited to a few\r\nthousands; now his proclamation would be responded to by millions\xe2\x80\x94who\r\ncould say how many? Pursuing this theory to its conclusions, Ben-Hur\r\nmoved amidst brilliant promises, and glowed with the thought that the\r\nmelancholy man, under gentle seeming and wondrous self-denial, was in\r\nfact carrying in disguise the subtlety of a politician and the genius\r\nof a soldier.\r\n\r\nSeveral times also, in the meanwhile, low-set, brawny men, bareheaded\r\nand black-bearded, came and asked for Ben-Hur at the tent; his\r\ninterviews with them were always apart; and to his mother\xe2\x80\x99s question\r\nwho they were he answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome good friends of mine from Galilee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThrough them he kept informed of the movements of the Nazarene, and of\r\nthe schemes of the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s enemies, Rabbinical and Roman. That the\r\ngood man\xe2\x80\x99s life was in danger, he knew; but that there were any bold\r\nenough to attempt to take it at that time, he could not believe. It\r\nseemed too securely intrenched in a great fame and an assured\r\npopularity. The very vastness of the attendance in and about the city\r\nbrought with it a seeming guaranty of safety. And yet, to say truth,\r\nBen-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s confidence rested most certainly upon the miraculous power of\r\nthe Christ. Pondering the subject in the purely human view, that the\r\nmaster of such authority over life and death, used so frequently for\r\nthe good of others, would not exert it in care of himself was simply as\r\nmuch past belief as it was past understanding.\r\n\r\nNor should it be forgotten that all these were incidents of occurrence\r\nbetween the twenty-first day of March\xe2\x80\x94counting by the modern\r\ncalendar\xe2\x80\x94and the twenty-fifth. The evening of the latter day Ben-Hur\r\nyielded to his impatience, and rode to the city, leaving behind him a\r\npromise to return in the night.\r\n\r\nThe horse was fresh, and choosing his own gait, sped swiftly. The eyes\r\nof the clambering vines winked at the rider from the garden fences on\r\nthe way; there was nothing else to see him, nor child nor woman nor\r\nman. Through the rocky float in the hollows of the road the agate hoofs\r\ndrummed, ringing like cups of steel; but without notice from any\r\nstranger. In the houses passed there were no tenants; the fires by the\r\ntent-doors were out; the road was deserted; for this was the first\r\nPassover eve, and the hour \xe2\x80\x9cbetween the evenings\xe2\x80\x9d when the visiting\r\nmillions crowded the city, and the slaughter of lambs in offering\r\nreeked the fore-courts of the Temple, and the priests in ordered lines\r\ncaught the flowing blood and carried it swiftly to the dripping\r\naltars\xe2\x80\x94when all was haste and hurry, racing with the stars fast coming\r\nwith the signal after which the roasting and the eating and the singing\r\nmight go on, but not the preparation more.\r\n\r\nThrough the great northern gate the rider rode, and lo! Jerusalem\r\nbefore the fall, in ripeness of glory, illuminated for the Lord.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur alighted at the gate of the khan from which the three Wise Men\r\nmore than thirty years before departed, going down to Bethlehem. There,\r\nin keeping of his Arab followers, he left the horse, and shortly after\r\nwas at the wicket of his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, and in a yet briefer space in\r\nthe great chamber. He called for Malluch first; that worthy being out,\r\nhe sent a salutation to his friends the merchant and the Egyptian. They\r\nwere being carried abroad to see the celebration. The latter, he was\r\ninformed, was very feeble, and in a state of deep dejection.\r\n\r\nYoung people of that time who were supposed hardly to know their own\r\nhearts indulged the habit of politic indirection quite as much as young\r\npeople in the same condition indulge it in this time; so when Ben-Hur\r\ninquired for the good Balthasar, and with grave courtesy desired to\r\nknow if he would be pleased to see him, he really addressed the\r\ndaughter a notice of his arrival. While the servant was answering for\r\nthe elder, the curtain of the doorway was drawn aside, and the younger\r\nEgyptian came in, and walked\xe2\x80\x94or floated, upborne in a white cloud of\r\nthe gauzy raiment she so loved and lived in\xe2\x80\x94to the centre of the\r\nchamber, where the light cast by lamps from the seven-armed brazen\r\nstick planted upon the floor was the strongest. With her there was no\r\nfear of light.\r\n\r\nThe servant left the two alone.\r\n\r\nIn the excitement occasioned by the events of the few days past Ben-Hur\r\nhad scarcely given a thought to the fair Egyptian. If she came to his\r\nmind at all, it was merely as a briefest pleasure, a suggestion of a\r\ndelight which could wait for him, and was waiting.\r\n\r\nBut now the influence of the woman revived with all its force the\r\ninstant Ben-Hur beheld her. He advanced to her eagerly, but stopped and\r\ngazed. Such a change he had never seen!\r\n\r\nTheretofore she had been a lover studious to win him\xe2\x80\x94in manner all\r\nwarmth, each glance an admission, each action an avowal. She had\r\nshowered him with incense of flattery. While he was present, she had\r\nimpressed him with her admiration; going away, he carried the\r\nimpression with him to remain a delicious expectancy hastening his\r\nreturn. It was for him the painted eyelids drooped lowest over the\r\nlustrous almond eyes; for him the love-stories caught from the\r\nprofessionals abounding in the streets of Alexandria were repeated with\r\nemphasis and lavishment of poetry; for him endless exclamations of\r\nsympathy, and smiles, and little privileges with hand and hair and\r\ncheek and lips, and songs of the Nile, and displays of jewelry, and\r\nsubtleties of lace in veils and scarfs, and other subtleties not less\r\nexquisite in flosses of Indian silk. The idea, old as the oldest of\r\npeoples, that beauty is the reward of the hero had never such realism\r\nas she contrived for his pleasure; insomuch that he could not doubt he\r\nwas her hero; she avouched it in a thousand artful ways as natural with\r\nher as her beauty\xe2\x80\x94winsome ways reserved, it would seem, by the\r\npassionate genius of old Egypt for its daughters.\r\n\r\nSuch the Egyptian had been to Ben-Hur from the night of the boat-ride\r\non the lake in the Orchard of Palms. But now!\r\n\r\nElsewhere in this volume the reader may have observed a term of\r\nsomewhat indefinite meaning used reverently in a sacred connection; we\r\nrepeat it now with a general application. There are few persons who\r\nhave not a double nature, the real and the acquired; the latter a kind\r\nof addendum resulting from education, which in time often perfects it\r\ninto a part of the being as unquestionable as the first. Leaving the\r\nthought to the thoughtful, we proceed to say that now the real nature\r\nof the Egyptian made itself manifest.\r\n\r\nIt was not possible for her to have received a stranger with repulsion\r\nmore incisive; yet she was apparently as passionless as a statue, only\r\nthe small head was a little tilted, the nostrils a little drawn, and\r\nthe sensuous lower lip pushed the upper the least bit out of its\r\nnatural curvature.\r\n\r\nShe was the first to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour coming is timely, O son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a voice sharply\r\ndistinct. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish to thank you for hospitality; after to-morrow I may\r\nnot have the opportunity to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur bowed slightly without taking his eyes from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of a custom which the dice-players observe with good\r\nresult among themselves,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen the game is over, they\r\nrefer to their tablets and cast up their accounts; then they libate the\r\ngods and put a crown upon the happy winner. We have had a game\xe2\x80\x94it has\r\nlasted through many days and nights. Why, now that it is at an end,\r\nshall not we see to which the chaplet belongs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYet very watchful, Ben-Hur answered, lightly, \xe2\x80\x9cA man may not balk a\r\nwoman bent on having her way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, inclining her head, and permitting the sneer\r\nto become positive\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctell me, O prince of Jerusalem, where is he, that\r\nson of the carpenter of Nazareth, and son not less of God, from whom so\r\nlately such mighty things were expected?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe waved his hand impatiently, and replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not his keeper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe beautiful head sank forward yet lower.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he broken Rome to pieces?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain, but with anger, Ben-Hur raised his hand in deprecation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere has he seated his capital?\xe2\x80\x9d she proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cCannot I go see his\r\nthrone and its lions of bronze? And his palace\xe2\x80\x94he raised the dead; and\r\nto such a one, what is it to raise a golden house? He has but to stamp\r\nhis foot and say the word, and the house is, pillared like Karnak, and\r\nwanting nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was by this time slight ground left to believe her playing; the\r\nquestions were offensive, and her manner pointed with unfriendliness;\r\nseeing which, he on his side became more wary, and said, with good\r\nhumor, \xe2\x80\x9cO Egypt, let us wait another day, even another week, for him,\r\nthe lions, and the palace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went on without noticing the suggestion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how is it I see you in that garb? Such is not the habit of\r\ngovernors in India or vice-kings elsewhere. I saw the satrap of Teheran\r\nonce, and he wore a turban of silk and a cloak of cloth of gold, and\r\nthe hilt and scabbard of his sword made me dizzy with their splendor of\r\nprecious stones. I thought Osiris had lent him a glory from the sun. I\r\nfear you have not entered upon your kingdom\xe2\x80\x94the kingdom I was to share\r\nwith you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe daughter of my wise guest is kinder than she imagines herself; she\r\nis teaching me that Isis may kiss a heart without making it better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur spoke with cold courtesy, and Iras, after playing with the\r\npendent solitaire of her necklace of coins, rejoined, \xe2\x80\x9cFor a Jew, the\r\nson of Hur is clever. I saw your dreaming Caesar make his entry into\r\nJerusalem. You told us he would that day proclaim himself King of the\r\nJews from the steps of the Temple. I beheld the procession descend the\r\nmountain bringing him. I heard their singing. They were beautiful with\r\npalms in motion. I looked everywhere among them for a figure with a\r\npromise of royalty\xe2\x80\x94a horseman in purple, a chariot with a driver in\r\nshining brass, a stately warrior behind an orbed shield, rivalling his\r\nspear in stature. I looked for his guard. It would have been pleasant\r\nto have seen a prince of Jerusalem and a cohort of the legions of\r\nGalilee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe flung her listener a glance of provoking disdain, then laughed\r\nheartily, as if the ludicrousness of the picture in her mind were too\r\nstrong for contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstead of a Sesostris returning in triumph or a Caesar helmed and\r\nsworded\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x94I saw a man with a woman\xe2\x80\x99s face and hair, riding an\r\nass\xe2\x80\x99s colt, and in tears. The King! the Son of God! the Redeemer of the\r\nworld! Ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn spite of himself, Ben-Hur winced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not quit my place, O prince of Jerusalem,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, before he\r\ncould recover. \xe2\x80\x9cI did not laugh. I said to myself, \xe2\x80\x98Wait. In the Temple\r\nhe will glorify himself as becomes a hero about to take possession of\r\nthe world.\xe2\x80\x99 I saw him enter the Gate of Shushan and the Court of the\r\nWomen. I saw him stop and stand before the Gate Beautiful. There were\r\npeople with me on the porch and in the courts, and on the cloisters and\r\non the steps of the three sides of the Temple there were other people\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwill say a million of people, all waiting breathlessly to hear his\r\nproclamation. The pillars were not more still than we. Ha, ha, ha! I\r\nfancied I heard the axles of the mighty Roman machine begin to crack.\r\nHa, ha, ha! O prince, by the soul of Solomon, your King of the World\r\ndrew his gown about him and walked away, and out by the farthest gate,\r\nnor opened his mouth to say a word; and\xe2\x80\x94the Roman machine is running\r\nyet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn simple homage to a hope that instant lost\xe2\x80\x94a hope which, as it began\r\nto fall and while it was falling, he unconsciously followed with a\r\nparting look down to its disappearance\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur lowered his eyes.\r\n\r\nAt no previous time, whether when Balthasar was plying him with\r\narguments, or when miracles were being done before his face, had the\r\ndisputed nature of the Nazarene been so plainly set before him. The\r\nbest way, after all, to reach an understanding of the divine is by\r\nstudy of the human. In the things superior to men we may always look to\r\nfind God. So with the picture given by the Egyptian of the scene when\r\nthe Nazarene turned from the Gate Beautiful; its central theme was an\r\nact utterly beyond performance by a man under control of merely human\r\ninspirations. A parable to a parable-loving people, it taught what the\r\nChrist had so often asserted\xe2\x80\x94that his mission was not political. There\r\nwas not much more time for thought of all this than that allowed for a\r\ncommon respiration; yet the idea took fast hold of Ben-Hur, and in the\r\nsame instant he followed his hope of vengeance out of sight, and the\r\nman with the woman\xe2\x80\x99s face and hair, and in tears, came near to him\xe2\x80\x94near\r\nenough to leave something of his spirit behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter of Balthasar,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with dignity, \xe2\x80\x9cif this be the game of\r\nwhich you spoke to me, take the chaplet\xe2\x80\x94I accord it yours. Only let us\r\nmake an end of words. That you have a purpose I am sure. To it, I pray,\r\nand I will answer you; then let us go our several ways, and forget we\r\never met. Say on; I will listen, but not to more of that which you have\r\ngiven me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe regarded him intently a moment, as if determining what to\r\ndo\xe2\x80\x94possibly she might have been measuring his will\xe2\x80\x94then she said,\r\ncoldly, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have my leave\xe2\x80\x94go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you,\xe2\x80\x9d he responded, and walked away.\r\n\r\nAs he was about passing out of the door, she called to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stopped where he was, and looked back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsider all I know about you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO most fair Egyptian,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, returning, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat all do you know about\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at him absently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are more of a Roman, son of Hur, then any of your Hebrew\r\nbrethren.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I so unlike my countrymen?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, indifferently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe demi-gods are all Roman now,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd therefore you will tell me what more you know about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe likeness is not lost upon me. It might induce me to save you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSave me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe pink-stained fingers toyed daintily with the lustrous pendant at\r\nthe throat, and her voice was exceeding low and soft; only a tapping on\r\nthe floor with her silken sandal admonished him to have a care.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was a Jew, an escaped galley-slave, who killed a man in the\r\nPalace of Idernee,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, slowly.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was startled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same Jew slew a Roman soldier before the Market-place here in\r\nJerusalem; the same Jew has three trained legions from Galilee to seize\r\nthe Roman governor to-night; the same Jew has alliances perfected for\r\nwar upon Rome, and Ilderim the Sheik is one of his partners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrawing nearer him, she almost whispered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have lived in Rome. Suppose these things repeated in ears we know\r\nof. Ah! you change color.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew back from her with somewhat of the look which may be imagined\r\nupon the face of a man who, thinking to play with a kitten, has run\r\nupon a tiger; and she proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are acquainted in the antechamber, and know the Lord Sejanus.\r\nSuppose it were told him with the proofs in hand\xe2\x80\x94or without the\r\nproofs\xe2\x80\x94that the same Jew is the richest man in the East\xe2\x80\x94nay, in all the\r\nempire. The fishes of the Tiber would have fattening other than that\r\nthey dig out of its ooze, would they not? And while they were\r\nfeeding\xe2\x80\x94ha! son of Hur!\xe2\x80\x94what splendor there would be on exhibition in\r\nthe Circus! Amusing the Roman people is a fine art; getting the money\r\nto keep them amused is another art even finer; and was there ever an\r\nartist the equal of the Lord Sejanus?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur was not too much stirred by the evident baseness of the woman\r\nfor recollection. Not unfrequently when all the other faculties are\r\nnumb and failing memory does its offices with the greatest fidelity.\r\nThe scene at the spring on the way to the Jordan reproduced itself; and\r\nhe remembered thinking then that Esther had betrayed him, and thinking\r\nso now, he said calmly as he could,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo give you pleasure, daughter of Egypt, I acknowledge your cunning,\r\nand that I am at your mercy. It may also please you to hear me\r\nacknowledge I have no hope of your favor. I could kill you, but you are\r\na woman. The Desert is open to receive me; and though Rome is a good\r\nhunter of men, there she would follow long and far before she caught\r\nme, for in its heart there are wildernesses of spears as well as\r\nwildernesses of sand, and it is not unlovely to the unconquered\r\nParthian. In the toils as I am\xe2\x80\x94dupe that I have been\xe2\x80\x94yet there is one\r\nthing my due: who told you all you know about me? In flight or\r\ncaptivity, dying even, there will be consolation in leaving the traitor\r\nthe curse of a man who has lived knowing nothing but wretchedness. Who\r\ntold you all you know about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt might have been a touch of art, or might have been sincere\xe2\x80\x94that as\r\nit may\xe2\x80\x94the expression of the Egyptian\xe2\x80\x99s face became sympathetic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are in my country, O son of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, presently, \xe2\x80\x9cworkmen\r\nwho make pictures by gathering vari-colored shells here and there on\r\nthe sea-shore after storms, and cutting them up, and patching the\r\npieces as inlaying on marble slabs. Can you not see the hint there is\r\nin the practice to such as go searching for secrets? Enough that from\r\nthis person I gathered a handful of little circumstances, and from that\r\nother yet another handful, and that afterwhile I put them together, and\r\nwas happy as a woman can be who has at disposal the fortune and life of\r\na man whom\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94she stopped, and beat the floor with her foot, and looked\r\naway as if to hide a sudden emotion from him; with an air of even\r\npainful resolution she presently finished the sentence\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhom she is at\r\nloss what to do with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is not enough,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur said, unmoved by the play\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is not\r\nenough. To-morrow you will determine what to do with me. I may die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined quickly and with emphasis, \xe2\x80\x9cI had something from\r\nSheik Ilderim as he lay with my father in a grove out in the Desert.\r\nThe night was still, very still, and the walls of the tent, sooth to\r\nsay, were poor ward against ears outside listening to\xe2\x80\x94birds and beetles\r\nflying through the air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe smiled at the conceit, but proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome other things\xe2\x80\x94bits of shell for the picture\xe2\x80\x94I had from\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son of Hur himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas there no other who contributed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHur drew a breath of relief, and said, lightly, \xe2\x80\x9cThanks. It were not\r\nwell to keep the Lord Sejanus waiting for you. The Desert is not so\r\nsensitive. Again, O Egypt, peace!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this time he had been standing uncovered; now he took the\r\nhandkerchief from his arm where it had been hanging, and adjusting it\r\nupon his head, turned to depart. But she arrested him; in her\r\neagerness, she even reached a hand to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nHe looked back at her, but without taking the hand, though it was very\r\nnoticeable for its sparkling of jewels; and he knew by her manner that\r\nthe reserved point of the scene which was so surprising to him was now\r\nto come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, and do not distrust me, O son of Hur, if I declare I know why\r\nthe noble Arrius took you for his heir. And, by Isis! by all the gods\r\nof Egypt! I swear I tremble to think of you, so brave and generous,\r\nunder the hand of the remorseless minister. You have left a portion of\r\nyour youth in the atria of the great capital; consider, as I do, what\r\nthe Desert will be to you in contrast of life. Oh, I give you\r\npity\xe2\x80\x94pity! And if you but do what I say, I will save you. That, also, I\r\nswear, by our holy Isis!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWords of entreaty and prayer these, poured forth volubly and with\r\nearnestness and the mighty sanction of beauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlmost\xe2\x80\x94almost I believe you,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur said, yet hesitatingly, and in a\r\nvoice low and indistinct; for a doubt remained with him grumbling\r\nagainst the yielding tendency of the man\xe2\x80\x94a good sturdy doubt, such a\r\none as has saved many a life and fortune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe perfect life for a woman is to live in love; the greatest\r\nhappiness for a man is the conquest of himself; and that, O prince, is\r\nwhat I have to ask of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe spoke rapidly, and with animation; indeed, she had never appeared\r\nto him so fascinating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had once a friend,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was in your boyhood. There\r\nwas a quarrel, and you and he became enemies. He did you wrong. After\r\nmany years you met him again in the Circus at Antioch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessala!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Messala. You are his creditor. Forgive the past; admit him to\r\nfriendship again; restore the fortune he lost in the great wager;\r\nrescue him. The six talents are as nothing to you; not so much as a bud\r\nlost upon a tree already in full leaf; but to him\xe2\x80\x94 Ah, he must go about\r\nwith a broken body; wherever you meet him he must look up to you from\r\nthe ground. O Ben-Hur, noble prince! to a Roman descended as he is\r\nbeggary is the other most odious name for death. Save him from\r\nbeggary!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf the rapidity with which she spoke was a cunning invention to keep\r\nhim from thinking, either she never knew or else had forgotten that\r\nthere are convictions which derive nothing from thought, but drop into\r\nplace without leave or notice. It seemed to him, when at last she\r\npaused to have his answer, that he could see Messala himself peering at\r\nhim over her shoulder; and in its expression the countenance of the\r\nRoman was not that of a mendicant or a friend; the sneer was as\r\npatrician as ever, and the fine edge of the hauteur as flawless and\r\nirritating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe appeal has been decided then, and for once a Messala takes\r\nnothing. I must go and write it in my book of great occurrences\xe2\x80\x94a\r\njudgment by a Roman against a Roman! But did he\xe2\x80\x94did Messala send you to\r\nme with this request, O Egypt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has a noble nature, and judged you by it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur took the hand upon arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you know him in such friendly way, fair Egyptian, tell me, would he\r\ndo for me, there being a reversal of the conditions, that he asks of\r\nme? Answer, by Isis! Answer, for the truth\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was insistence in the touch of his hand, and in his look also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d she began, \xe2\x80\x9che is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Roman, you were about to say; meaning that I, a Jew, must not\r\ndetermine dues from me to him by any measure of dues from him to me;\r\nbeing a Jew, I must forgive him my winnings because he is a Roman. If\r\nyou have more to tell me, daughter of Balthasar, speak quickly,\r\nquickly; for by the Lord God of Israel, when this heat of blood, hotter\r\nwaxing, attains its highest, I may not be able longer to see that you\r\nare a woman, and beautiful! I may see but the spy of a master the more\r\nhateful because the master is a Roman. Say on, and quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe threw his hand off and stepped back into the full light, with all\r\nthe evil of her nature collected in her eyes and voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou drinker of lees, feeder upon husks! He would have\r\nbeen satisfied with release of the six talents; but I say to the six\r\nthou shalt add twenty\xe2\x80\x94twenty, dost thou hear? The kissings of my little\r\nfinger which thou hast taken from him, though with my consent, shall be\r\npaid for; and that I have followed thee with affection of sympathy, and\r\nendured thee so long, enter into the account not less because I was\r\nserving him. The merchant here is thy keeper of moneys. If by to-morrow\r\nat noon he has not thy order acted upon in favor of my Messala for\r\nsix-and-twenty talents\xe2\x80\x94mark the sum!\xe2\x80\x94thou shalt settle with the Lord\r\nSejanus. Be wise and\xe2\x80\x94farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she was going to the door, he put himself in her way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old Egypt lives in you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhether you see Messala\r\nto-morrow or the next day, here or in Rome, give him this message. Tell\r\nhim I have back the money, even the six talents, he robbed me of by\r\nrobbing my father\xe2\x80\x99s estate; tell him I survived the galleys to which he\r\nhad me sent, and in my strength rejoice in his beggary and dishonor;\r\ntell him I think the affliction of body which he has from my hand is\r\nthe curse of our Lord God of Israel upon him more fit than death for\r\nhis crimes against the helpless; tell him my mother and sister whom he\r\nhad sent to a cell in Antonia that they might die of leprosy, are alive\r\nand well, thanks to the power of the Nazarene whom you so despise; tell\r\nhim that, to fill my measure of happiness, they are restored to me, and\r\nthat I will go hence to their love, and find in it more than\r\ncompensation for the impure passions which you leave me to take to him;\r\ntell him\xe2\x80\x94this for your comfort, O cunning incarnate, as much as\r\nhis\xe2\x80\x94tell him that when the Lord Sejanus comes to despoil me he will\r\nfind nothing; for the inheritance I had from the duumvir, including the\r\nvilla by Misenum, has been sold, and the money from the sale is out of\r\nreach, afloat in the marts of the world as bills of exchange; and that\r\nthis house and the goods and merchandise and the ships and caravans\r\nwith which Simonides plies his commerce with such princely profits are\r\ncovered by imperial safeguards\xe2\x80\x94a wise head having found the price of\r\nthe favor, and the Lord Sejanus preferring a reasonable gain in the way\r\nof gift to much gain fished from pools of blood and wrong; tell him if\r\nall this were not so, if the money and property were all mine, yet\r\nshould he not have the least part of it, for when he finds our Jewish\r\nbills, and forces them to give up their values, there is yet another\r\nresort left me\xe2\x80\x94a deed of gift to Caesar\xe2\x80\x94so much, O Egypt, I found out\r\nin the atria of the great capital; tell him that along with my defiance\r\nI do not send him a curse in words, but, as a better expression of my\r\nundying hate, I send him one who will prove to him the sum of all\r\ncurses; and when he looks at you repeating this my message, daughter of\r\nBalthasar, his Roman shrewdness will tell him all I mean. Go now\xe2\x80\x94and I\r\nwill go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe conducted her to the door, and, with ceremonious politeness, held\r\nback the curtain while she passed out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as she disappeared.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Ben-Hur left the guest-chamber, there was not nearly so much life\r\nin his action as when he entered it; his steps were slower, and he went\r\nalong with his head quite upon his breast. Having made discovery that a\r\nman with a broken back may yet have a sound brain, he was reflecting\r\nupon the discovery.\r\n\r\nForasmuch as it is easy after a calamity has befallen to look back and\r\nsee the proofs of its coming strewn along the way, the thought that he\r\nhad not even suspected the Egyptian as in Messala\xe2\x80\x99s interest, but had\r\ngone blindly on through whole years putting himself and his friends\r\nmore and more at her mercy, was a sore wound to the young man\xe2\x80\x99s vanity.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cshe had no word of indignation for\r\nthe perfidious Roman at the Fountain of Castalia! I remember she\r\nextolled him at the boat-ride on the lake in the Orchard of Palms! And,\r\nah!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he stopped, and beat his left hand violently with his right\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cah!\r\nthat mystery about the appointment she made with me at the Palace of\r\nIdernee is no mystery now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe wound, it should be observed, was to his vanity; and fortunately it\r\nis not often that people die of such hurts, or even continue a long\r\ntime sick. In Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s case, moreover, there was a compensation; for\r\npresently he exclaimed aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cPraised be the Lord God that the woman\r\ntook not a more lasting hold on me! I see I did not love her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, as if he had already parted with not a little of the weight on\r\nhis mind, he stepped forward more lightly; and, coming to the place on\r\nthe terrace where one stairway led down to the court-yard below, and\r\nanother ascended to the roof, he took the latter and began to climb. As\r\nhe made the last step in the flight he stopped again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan Balthasar have been her partner in the long mask she has been\r\nplaying? No, no. Hypocrisy seldom goes with wrinkled age like that.\r\nBalthasar is a good man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this decided opinion he stepped upon the roof. There was a full\r\nmoon overhead, yet the vault of the sky at the moment was lurid with\r\nlight cast up from the fires burning in the streets and open places of\r\nthe city, and the chanting and chorusing of the old psalmody of Israel\r\nfilled it with plaintive harmonies to which he could not but listen.\r\nThe countless voices bearing the burden seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cThus, O son of\r\nJudah, we prove our worshipfulness of the Lord God, and our loyalty to\r\nthe land he gave us. Let a Gideon appear, or a David, or a Maccabaeus,\r\nand we are ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat seemed an introduction; for next he saw the man of Nazareth.\r\n\r\nIn certain moods the mind is disposed to mock itself with inapposite\r\nfancies.\r\n\r\nThe tearful woman-like face of the Christ stayed with him while he\r\ncrossed the roof to the parapet above the street on the north side of\r\nthe house, and there was in it no sign of war; but rather as the\r\nheavens of calm evenings look peace upon everything, so it looked,\r\nprovoking the old question, What manner of man is he?\r\n\r\nBen-Hur permitted himself one glance over the parapet, then turned and\r\nwalked mechanically towards the summer-house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them do their worst,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he went slowly on. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not\r\nforgive the Roman. I will not divide my fortune with him, nor will I\r\nfly from this city of my fathers. I will call on Galilee first, and\r\nhere make the fight. By brave deeds I will bring the tribes to our\r\nside. He who raised up Moses will find us a leader, if I fail. If not\r\nthe Nazarene, then some other of the many ready to die for freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe interior of the summer-house, when Ben-Hur, slow sauntering, came\r\nto it, was murkily lighted. The faintest of shadows lay along the floor\r\nfrom the pillars on the north and west sides. Looking in, he saw the\r\narm-chair usually occupied by Simonides drawn to a spot from which a\r\nview of the city over towards the Market-place could be best had.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe good man is returned. I will speak with him, unless he be asleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked in, and with a quiet step approached the chair. Peering over\r\nthe high back, he beheld Esther nestled in the seat asleep\xe2\x80\x94a small\r\nfigure snugged away under her father\xe2\x80\x99s lap-robe. The hair dishevelled\r\nfell over her face. Her breathing was low and irregular. Once it was\r\nbroken by a long sigh, ending in a sob. Something\xe2\x80\x94it might have been\r\nthe sigh or the loneliness in which he found her\xe2\x80\x94imparted to him the\r\nidea that the sleep was a rest from sorrow rather than fatigue. Nature\r\nkindly sends such relief to children, and he was used to thinking\r\nEsther scarcely more than a child. He put his arms upon the back of the\r\nchair, and thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not wake her. I have nothing to tell her\xe2\x80\x94nothing unless\xe2\x80\x94unless\r\nit be my love.... She is a daughter of Judah, and beautiful, and so\r\nunlike the Egyptian; for there it is all vanity, here all truth; there\r\nambition, here duty; there selfishness, here self-sacrifice.... Nay,\r\nthe question is not do I love her, but does she love me? She was my\r\nfriend from the beginning. The night on the terrace at Antioch, how\r\nchild-like she begged me not to make Rome my enemy, and had me tell her\r\nof the villa by Misenum, and of the life there! That she should not see\r\nI saw her cunning drift I kissed her. Can she have forgotten the kiss!\r\nI have not. I love her.... They do not know in the city that I have\r\nback my people. I shrank from telling it to the Egyptian; but this\r\nlittle one will rejoice with me over their restoration, and welcome\r\nthem with love and sweet services of hand and heart. She will be to my\r\nmother another daughter; in Tirzah she will find her other self. I\r\nwould wake her and tell her these things, but\xe2\x80\x94out on the sorceress of\r\nEgypt! Of that folly I could not command myself to speak. I will go\r\naway, and wait another and a better time. I will wait. Fair Esther,\r\ndutiful child, daughter of Judah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe retired silently as he came.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe streets were full of people going and coming, or grouped about the\r\nfires roasting meat, and feasting and singing, and happy. The odor of\r\nscorching flesh mixed with the odor of cedar-wood aflame and smoking\r\nloaded the air; and as this was the occasion when every son of Israel\r\nwas full brother to every other son of Israel, and hospitality was\r\nwithout bounds, Ben-Hur was saluted at every step, while the groups by\r\nthe fires insisted, \xe2\x80\x9cStay and partake with us. We are brethren in the\r\nlove of the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d But with thanks to them he hurried on, intending to\r\ntake horse at the khan and return to the tents on the Cedron.\r\n\r\nTo make the place, it was necessary for him to cross the thoroughfare\r\nso soon to receive sorrowful Christian perpetuation. There also the\r\npious celebration was at its height. Looking up the street, he noticed\r\nthe flames of torches in motion streaming out like pennons; then he\r\nobserved that the singing ceased where the torches came. His wonder\r\nrose to its highest, however, when he became certain that amidst the\r\nsmoke and dancing sparks he saw the keener sparkling of burnished\r\nspear-tips, arguing the presence of Roman soldiers. What were they, the\r\nscoffing legionaries, doing in a Jewish religious procession? The\r\ncircumstance was unheard of, and he stayed to see the meaning of it.\r\n\r\nThe moon was shining its best; yet, as if the moon and the torches, and\r\nthe fires in the street, and the rays streaming from windows and open\r\ndoors were not enough to make the way clear, some of the processionists\r\ncarried lighted lanterns; and fancying he discovered a special purpose\r\nin the use of such equipments, Ben-Hur stepped into the street so close\r\nto the line of march as to bring every one of the company under view\r\nwhile passing. The torches and the lanterns were being borne by\r\nservants, each of whom was armed with a bludgeon or a sharpened stave.\r\nTheir present duty seemed to be to pick out the smoothest paths among\r\nthe rocks in the street for certain dignitaries among them\xe2\x80\x94elders and\r\npriests; rabbis with long beards, heavy brows, and beaked noses; men of\r\nthe class potential in the councils of Caiaphas and Hannas. Where could\r\nthey be going? Not to the Temple, certainly, for the route to the\r\nsacred house from Zion, whence these appeared to be coming, was by the\r\nXystus. And their business\xe2\x80\x94if peaceful, why the soldiers?\r\n\r\nAs the procession began to go by Ben-Hur, his attention was\r\nparticularly called to three persons walking together. They were well\r\ntowards the front, and the servants who went before them with lanterns\r\nappeared unusually careful in the service.
