In the person moving on the\r\nleft of this group he recognized a chief policeman of the Temple; the\r\none on the right was a priest; the middle man was not at first so\r\neasily placed, as he walked leaning heavily upon the arms of the\r\nothers, and carried his head so low upon his breast as to hide his\r\nface. His appearance was that of a prisoner not yet recovered from the\r\nfright of arrest, or being taken to something dreadful\xe2\x80\x94to torture or\r\ndeath. The dignitaries helping him on the right and left, and the\r\nattention they gave him, made it clear that if he were not himself the\r\nobject moving the party, he was at least in some way connected with the\r\nobject\xe2\x80\x94a witness or a guide, possibly an informer. So if it could be\r\nfound who he was the business in hand might be shrewdly guessed. With\r\ngreat assurance, Ben-Hur fell in on the right of the priest, and walked\r\nalong with him. Now if the man would lift his head! And presently he\r\ndid so, letting the light of the lanterns strike full in his face,\r\npale, dazed, pinched with dread; the beard roughed; the eyes filmy,\r\nsunken, and despairing. In much going about following the Nazarene,\r\nBen-Hur had come to know his disciples as well as the Master; and now,\r\nat sight of the dismal countenance, he cried out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x99Scariot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSlowly the head of the man turned until his eyes settled upon Ben-Hur,\r\nand his lips moved as if he were about to speak; but the priest\r\ninterfered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho art thou? Begone!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Ben-Hur, pushing him away.\r\n\r\nThe young man took the push good-naturedly, and, waiting an\r\nopportunity, fell into the procession again. Thus he was carried\r\npassively along down the street, through the crowded lowlands between\r\nthe hill Bezetha and the Castle of Antonia, and on by the Bethesda\r\nreservoir to the Sheep Gate. There were people everywhere, and\r\neverywhere the people were engaged in sacred observances.\r\n\r\nIt being Passover night, the valves of the Gate stood open. The keepers\r\nwere off somewhere feasting. In front of the procession as it passed\r\nout unchallenged was the deep gorge of the Cedron, with Olivet beyond,\r\nits dressing of cedar and olive trees darker of the moonlight silvering\r\nall the heavens. Two roads met and merged into the street at the\r\ngate\xe2\x80\x94one from the northeast, the other from Bethany. Ere Ben-Hur could\r\nfinish wondering whether he were to go farther, and if so, which road\r\nwas to be taken, he was led off down into the gorge. And still no hint\r\nof the purpose of the midnight march.\r\n\r\nDown the gorge and over the bridge at the bottom of it. There was a\r\ngreat clatter on the floor as the crowd, now a straggling rabble,\r\npassed over beating and pounding with their clubs and staves. A little\r\nfarther, and they turned off to the left in the direction of an olive\r\norchard enclosed by a stone wall in view from the road. Ben-Hur knew\r\nthere was nothing in the place but old gnarled trees, the grass, and a\r\ntrough hewn out of a rock for the treading of oil after the fashion of\r\nthe country. While, yet more wonder-struck, he was thinking what could\r\nbring such a company at such an hour to a quarter so lonesome, they\r\nwere all brought to a standstill. Voices called out excitedly in front;\r\na chill sensation ran from man to man; there was a rapid falling-back,\r\nand a blind stumbling over each other. The soldiers alone kept their\r\norder.\r\n\r\nIt took Ben-Hur but a moment to disengage himself from the mob and run\r\nforward. There he found a gateway without a gate admitting to the\r\norchard, and he halted to take in the scene.\r\n\r\nA man in white clothes, and bareheaded, was standing outside the\r\nentrance, his hands crossed before him\xe2\x80\x94a slender, stooping figure, with\r\nlong hair and thin face\xe2\x80\x94in an attitude of resignation and waiting.\r\n\r\nIt was the Nazarene!\r\n\r\nBehind him, next the gateway, were the disciples in a group; they were\r\nexcited, but no man was ever calmer than he. The torchlight beat redly\r\nupon him, giving his hair a tint ruddier than was natural to it; yet\r\nthe expression of the countenance was as usual all gentleness and pity.\r\n\r\nOpposite this most unmartial figure stood the rabble, gaping, silent,\r\nawed, cowering\xe2\x80\x94ready at a sign of anger from him to break and run. And\r\nfrom him to them\xe2\x80\x94then at Judas, conspicuous in their midst\xe2\x80\x94Ben-Hur\r\nlooked\xe2\x80\x94one quick glance, and the object of the visit lay open to his\r\nunderstanding. Here was the betrayer, there the betrayed; and these\r\nwith clubs and staves, and the legionaries, were brought to take him.\r\n\r\nA man may not always tell what he will do until the trial is upon him.\r\nThis was the emergency for which Ben-Hur had been for years preparing.\r\nThe man to whose security he had devoted himself, and upon whose life\r\nhe had been building so largely, was in personal peril; yet he stood\r\nstill. Such contradictions are there in human nature! To say truth, O\r\nreader, he was not entirely recovered from the picture of the Christ\r\nbefore the Gate Beautiful as it had been given by the Egyptian; and,\r\nbesides that, the very calmness with which the mysterious person\r\nconfronted the mob held him in restraint by suggesting the possession\r\nof a power in reserve more than sufficient for the peril. Peace and\r\ngood-will, and love and non-resistance, had been the burden of the\r\nNazarene\xe2\x80\x99s teaching; would he put his preaching into practice? He was\r\nmaster of life; he could restore it when lost; he could take it at\r\npleasure. What use would he make of the power now? Defend himself? And\r\nhow? A word\xe2\x80\x94a breath\xe2\x80\x94a thought were sufficient. That there would be\r\nsome signal exhibition of astonishing force beyond the natural Ben-Hur\r\nbelieved, and in that faith waited. And in all this he was still\r\nmeasuring the Nazarene by himself\xe2\x80\x94by the human standard.\r\n\r\nPresently the clear voice of the Christ arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom seek ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJesus of Nazareth,\xe2\x80\x9d the priest replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these simplest of words, spoken without passion or alarm, the\r\nassailants fell back several steps, the timid among them cowering to\r\nthe ground; and they might have let him alone and gone away had not\r\nJudas walked over to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHail, master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this friendly speech, he kissed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudas,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Nazarene, mildly, \xe2\x80\x9cbetrayest thou the Son of man with\r\na kiss? Wherefore art thou come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReceiving no reply, the Master spoke to the crowd again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom seek ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJesus of Nazareth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told you that I am he. If, therefore, you seek me, let these go\r\ntheir way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words of entreaty the rabbis advanced upon him; and, seeing\r\ntheir intent, some of the disciples for whom he interceded drew nearer;\r\none of them cut off a man\xe2\x80\x99s ear, but without saving the Master from\r\nbeing taken. And yet Ben-Hur stood still! Nay, while the officers were\r\nmaking ready with their ropes the Nazarene was doing his greatest\r\ncharity\xe2\x80\x94not the greatest in deed, but the very greatest in illustration\r\nof his forbearance, so far surpassing that of men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuffer ye thus far,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the wounded man, and healed him with a\r\ntouch.\r\n\r\nBoth friends and enemies were confounded\xe2\x80\x94one side that he could do such\r\na thing, the other that he would do it under the circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely he will not allow them to bind him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus thought Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut up thy sword into the sheath; the cup which my Father hath given\r\nme, shall I not drink it?\xe2\x80\x9d From the offending follower, the Nazarene\r\nturned to his captors. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you come out as against a thief, with\r\nswords and staves to take me? I was daily with you in the Temple, and\r\nyou took me not; but this is your hour, and the power of darkness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe posse plucked up courage and closed about him; and when Ben-Hur\r\nlooked for the faithful they were gone\xe2\x80\x94not one of them remained.\r\n\r\nThe crowd about the deserted man seemed very busy with tongue, hand,\r\nand foot. Over their heads, between the torch-sticks, through the\r\nsmoke, sometimes in openings between the restless men, Ben-Hur caught\r\nmomentary glimpses of the prisoner. Never had anything struck him as so\r\npiteous, so unfriended, so forsaken! Yet, he thought, the man could\r\nhave defended himself\xe2\x80\x94he could have slain his enemies with a breath,\r\nbut he would not. What was the cup his father had given him to drink?\r\nAnd who was the father to be so obeyed? Mystery upon mystery\xe2\x80\x94not one,\r\nbut many.\r\n\r\nDirectly the mob started in return to the city, the soldiers in the\r\nlead. Ben-Hur became anxious; he was not satisfied with himself. Where\r\nthe torches were in the midst of the rabble he knew the Nazarene was to\r\nbe found. Suddenly he resolved to see him again. He would ask him one\r\nquestion.\r\n\r\nTaking off his long outer garment and the handkerchief from his head,\r\nhe threw them upon the orchard wall, and started after the posse, which\r\nhe boldly joined. Through the stragglers he made way, and by littles at\r\nlength reached the man who carried the ends of the rope with which the\r\nprisoner was bound.\r\n\r\nThe Nazarene was walking slowly, his head down, his hands bound behind\r\nhim; the hair fell thickly over his face, and he stooped more than\r\nusual; apparently he was oblivious to all going on around him. In\r\nadvance a few steps were priests and elders talking and occasionally\r\nlooking back. When, at length, they were all near the bridge in the\r\ngorge, Ben-Hur took the rope from the servant who had it, and stepped\r\npast him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster, master!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, hurriedly, speaking close to the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s\r\near. \xe2\x80\x9cDost thou hear, master? A word\xe2\x80\x94one word. Tell me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fellow from whom he had taken the rope now claimed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur continued, \xe2\x80\x9cgoest thou with these of thine own\r\naccord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people were come up now, and in his own ears asking angrily, \xe2\x80\x9cWho\r\nart thou, man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO master,\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur made haste to say, his voice sharp with anxiety, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nam thy friend and lover. Tell me, I pray thee, if I bring rescue, wilt\r\nthou accept it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Nazarene never so much as looked up or allowed the slightest sign\r\nof recognition; yet the something which when we are suffering is always\r\ntelling it to such as look at us, though they be strangers, failed not\r\nnow. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him alone,\xe2\x80\x9d it seemed to say; \xe2\x80\x9che has been abandoned by his\r\nfriends; the world has denied him; in bitterness of spirit, he has\r\ntaken farewell of men; he is going he knows not where, and he cares\r\nnot. Let him alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd to that Ben-Hur was now driven. A dozen hands were upon him, and\r\nfrom all sides there was shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cHe is one of them. Bring him along;\r\nclub him\xe2\x80\x94kill him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a gust of passion which gave him many times his ordinary force,\r\nBen-Hur raised himself, turned once about with arms outstretched, shook\r\nthe hands off, and rushed through the circle which was fast hemming him\r\nin. The hands snatching at him as he passed tore his garments from his\r\nback, so he ran off the road naked; and the gorge, in keeping of the\r\nfriendly darkness, darker there than elsewhere, received him safe.\r\n\r\nReclaiming his handkerchief and outer garments from the orchard wall,\r\nhe followed back to the city gate; thence he went to the khan, and on\r\nthe good horse rode to the tents of his people out by the Tombs of the\r\nKings.\r\n\r\nAs he rode, he promised himself to see the Nazarene on the\r\nmorrow\xe2\x80\x94promised it, not knowing that the unfriended man was taken\r\nstraightway to the house of Hannas to be tried that night.\r\n\r\nThe heart the young man carried to his couch beat so heavily he could\r\nnot sleep; for now clearly his renewed Judean kingdom resolved itself\r\ninto what it was\xe2\x80\x94only a dream. It is bad enough to see our castles\r\noverthrown one after another with an interval between in which to\r\nrecover from the shock, or at least let the echoes of the fall die\r\naway; but when they go altogether\xe2\x80\x94go as ships sink, as houses tumble in\r\nearthquakes\xe2\x80\x94the spirits which endure it calmly are made of stuffs\r\nsterner than common, and Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s was not of them. Through vistas in\r\nthe future, he began to catch glimpses of a life serenely beautiful,\r\nwith a home instead of a palace of state, and Esther its mistress.\r\nAgain and again through the leaden-footed hours of the night he saw the\r\nvilla by Misenum, and with his little countrywoman strolled through the\r\ngarden, and rested in the panelled atrium; overhead the Neapolitan sky,\r\nat their feet the sunniest of sun-lands and the bluest of bays.\r\n\r\nIn plainest speech, he was entering upon a crisis with which to-morrow\r\nand the Nazarene will have everything to do.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\nNext morning, about the second hour, two men rode full speed to the\r\ndoors of Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s tents, and dismounting, asked to see him. He was not\r\nyet risen, but gave directions for their admission.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, brethren,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, for they were of his Galileans, and\r\ntrusted officers. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you be seated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d the senior replied, bluntly, \xe2\x80\x9cto sit and be at ease is to let\r\nthe Nazarene die. Rise, son of Judah, and go with us. The judgment has\r\nbeen given. The tree of the cross is already at Golgotha.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur stared at them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cross!\xe2\x80\x9d was all he could for the moment say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey took him last night, and tried him,\xe2\x80\x9d the man continued. \xe2\x80\x9cAt dawn\r\nthey led him before Pilate. Twice the Roman denied his guilt; twice he\r\nrefused to give him over. At last he washed his hands, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Be it\r\nupon you then;\xe2\x80\x99 and they answered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho answered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x94the priests and people\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98His blood be upon us and our children.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly father Abraham!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ben-Hur; \xe2\x80\x9ca Roman kinder to an Israelite\r\nthan his own kin! And if\xe2\x80\x94ah, if he should indeed be the son of God,\r\nwhat shall ever wash his blood from their children? It must not be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis\r\ntime to fight!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis face brightened with resolution, and he clapped his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe horses\xe2\x80\x94and quickly!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the Arab who answered the signal.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd bid Amrah send me fresh garments, and bring my sword! It is time\r\nto die for Israel, my friends. Tarry without till I come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe ate a crust, drank a cup of wine, and was soon upon the road.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither would you go first?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Galilean.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo collect the legions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d the man replied, throwing up his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy alas?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the man spoke with shame\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmaster, I and my friend here are all\r\nthat are faithful. The rest do follow the priests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeeking what?\xe2\x80\x9d and Ben-Hur drew rein.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo kill him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the Nazarene?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have said it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur looked slowly from one man to the other. He was hearing again\r\nthe question of the night before: \xe2\x80\x9cThe cup my Father hath given me,\r\nshall I not drink it?\xe2\x80\x9d In the ear of the Nazarene he was putting his\r\nown question, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I bring thee rescue, wilt thou accept it?\xe2\x80\x9d He was\r\nsaying to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cThis death may not be averted. The man has been\r\ntravelling towards it with full knowledge from the day he began his\r\nmission: it is imposed by a will higher than his; whose but the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s!\r\nIf he is consenting, if he goes to it voluntarily, what shall another\r\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d Nor less did Ben-Hur see the failure of the scheme he had built\r\nupon the fidelity of the Galileans; their desertion, in fact, left\r\nnothing more of it. But how singular it should happen that morning of\r\nall others! A dread seized him. It was possible his scheming, and\r\nlabor, and expenditure of treasure might have been but blasphemous\r\ncontention with God. When he picked up the reins and said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\r\nbrethren,\xe2\x80\x9d all before him was uncertainty. The faculty of resolving\r\nquickly, without which one cannot be a hero in the midst of stirring\r\nscenes, was numb within him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go, brethren; let us to Golgotha.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey passed through excited crowds of people going south, like\r\nthemselves. All the country north of the city seemed aroused and in\r\nmotion.\r\n\r\nHearing that the procession with the condemned might be met with\r\nsomewhere near the great white towers left by Herod, the three friends\r\nrode thither, passing round southeast of Akra. In the valley below the\r\nPool of Hezekiah, passage-way against the multitude became impossible,\r\nand they were compelled to dismount, and take shelter behind the corner\r\nof a house and wait.\r\n\r\nThe waiting was as if they were on a river bank, watching a flood go\r\nby, for such the people seemed.\r\n\r\nThere are certain chapters in the First Book of this story which were\r\nwritten to give the reader an idea of the composition of the Jewish\r\nnationality as it was in the time of Christ. They were also written in\r\nanticipation of this hour and scene; so that he who has read them with\r\nattention can now see all Ben-Hur saw of the going to the crucifixion\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nrare and wonderful sight!\r\n\r\nHalf an hour\xe2\x80\x94an hour\xe2\x80\x94the flood surged by Ben-Hur and his companions,\r\nwithin arm\xe2\x80\x99s reach, incessant, undiminished. At the end of that time he\r\ncould have said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen all the castes of Jerusalem, all the\r\nsects of Judea, all the tribes of Israel, and all the nationalities of\r\nearth represented by them.\xe2\x80\x9d The Libyan Jew went by, and the Jew of\r\nEgypt, and the Jew from the Rhine; in short, Jews from all East\r\ncountries and all West countries, and all islands within commercial\r\nconnection; they went by on foot, on horseback, on camels, in litters\r\nand chariots, and with an infinite variety of costumes, yet with the\r\nsame marvellous similitude of features which to-day particularizes the\r\nchildren of Israel, tried as they have been by climates and modes of\r\nlife; they went by speaking all known tongues, for by that means only\r\nwere they distinguishable group from group; they went by in\r\nhaste\xe2\x80\x94eager, anxious, crowding\xe2\x80\x94all to behold one poor Nazarene die, a\r\nfelon between felons.\r\n\r\nThese were the many, but they were not all.\r\n\r\nBorne along with the stream were thousands not Jews\xe2\x80\x94thousands hating\r\nand despising them\xe2\x80\x94Greeks, Romans, Arabs, Syrians, Africans, Egyptians,\r\nEasterns. So that, studying the mass, it seemed the whole world was to\r\nbe represented, and, in that sense, present at the crucifixion.\r\n\r\nThe going was singularly quiet. A hoof-stroke upon a rock, the glide\r\nand rattle of revolving wheels, voices in conversation, and now and\r\nthen a calling voice, were all the sounds heard above the rustle of the\r\nmighty movement. Yet was there upon every countenance the look with\r\nwhich men make haste to see some dreadful sight, some sudden wreck, or\r\nruin, or calamity of war. And by such signs Ben-Hur judged that these\r\nwere the strangers in the city come up to the Passover, who had had no\r\npart in the trial of the Nazarene, and might be his friends.\r\n\r\nAt length, from the direction of the great towers, Ben-Hur heard, at\r\nfirst faint in the distance, a shouting of many men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark! they are coming now,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of his friends.\r\n\r\nThe people in the street halted to hear; but as the cry rang on over\r\ntheir heads, they looked at each other, and in shuddering silence moved\r\nalong.\r\n\r\nThe shouting drew nearer each moment; and the air was already full of\r\nit and trembling, when Ben-Hur saw the servants of Simonides coming\r\nwith their master in his chair, and Esther walking by his side; a\r\ncovered litter was next behind them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace to you, O Simonides\xe2\x80\x94and to you, Esther,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, meeting\r\nthem. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are for Golgotha, stay until the procession passes; I\r\nwill then go with you. There is room to turn in by the house here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe merchant\xe2\x80\x99s large head rested heavily upon his breast; rousing\r\nhimself, he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak to Balthasar; his pleasure will be mine.\r\nHe is in the litter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur hastened to draw aside the curtain. The Egyptian was lying\r\nwithin, his wan face so pinched as to appear like a dead man\xe2\x80\x99s. The\r\nproposal was submitted to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan we see him?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, faintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Nazarene? yes; he must pass within a few feet of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d the old man cried, fervently. \xe2\x80\x9cOnce more, once more! Oh,\r\nit is a dreadful day for the world!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShortly the whole party were in waiting under shelter of the house.\r\nThey said but little, afraid, probably, to trust their thoughts to each\r\nother; everything was uncertain, and nothing so much so as opinions.\r\nBalthasar drew himself feebly from the litter, and stood supported by a\r\nservant; Esther and Ben-Hur kept Simonides company.\r\n\r\nMeantime the flood poured along, if anything, more densely than before;\r\nand the shouting came nearer, shrill up in the air, hoarse along the\r\nearth, and cruel. At last the procession was up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, bitterly; \xe2\x80\x9cthat which cometh now is Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe advance was in possession of an army of boys, hooting and\r\nscreaming, \xe2\x80\x9cThe King of the Jews! Room, room for the King of the Jews!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides watched them as they whirled and danced along, like a cloud\r\nof summer insects, and said, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen these come to their\r\ninheritance, son of Hur, alas for the city of Solomon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA band of legionaries fully armed followed next, marching in sturdy\r\nindifference, the glory of burnished brass about them the while.\r\n\r\nThen came the NAZARENE!\r\n\r\nHe was nearly dead. Every few steps he staggered as if he would fall. A\r\nstained gown badly torn hung from his shoulders over a seamless\r\nundertunic. His bare feet left red splotches upon the stones. An\r\ninscription on a board was tied to his neck. A crown of thorns had been\r\ncrushed hard down upon his head, making cruel wounds from which streams\r\nof blood, now dry and blackened, had run over his face and neck. The\r\nlong hair, tangled in the thorns, was clotted thick. The skin, where it\r\ncould be seen, was ghastly white. His hands were tied before him. Back\r\nsomewhere in the city he had fallen exhausted under the transverse beam\r\nof his cross, which, as a condemned person, custom required him to bear\r\nto the place of execution; now a countryman carried the burden in his\r\nstead. Four soldiers went with him as a guard against the mob, who\r\nsometimes, nevertheless, broke through, and struck him with sticks, and\r\nspit upon him. Yet no sound escaped him, neither remonstrance nor\r\ngroan; nor did he look up until he was nearly in front of the house\r\nsheltering Ben-Hur and his friends, all of whom were moved with quick\r\ncompassion. Esther clung to her father; and he, strong of will as he\r\nwas, trembled. Balthasar fell down speechless. Even Ben-Hur cried out,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO my God! my God!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as if he divined their feelings or heard the\r\nexclamation, the Nazarene turned his wan face towards the party, and\r\nlooked at them each one, so they carried the look in memory through\r\nlife. They could see he was thinking of them, not himself, and the\r\ndying eyes gave them the blessing he was not permitted to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are thy legions, son of Hur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Simonides, aroused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHannas can tell thee better than I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, faithless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll but these two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen all is lost, and this good man must die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe face of the merchant knit convulsively as he spoke, and his head\r\nsank upon his breast. He had borne his part in Ben-Hur\xe2\x80\x99s labors well,\r\nand he had been inspired by the same hopes, now blown out never to be\r\nrekindled.\r\n\r\nTwo other men succeeded the Nazarene bearing cross-beams.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are these?\xe2\x80\x9d Ben-Hur asked of the Galileans.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThieves appointed to die with the Nazarene,\xe2\x80\x9d they replied.\r\n\r\nNext in the procession stalked a mitred figure clad all in the golden\r\nvestments of the high-priest. Policemen from the Temple curtained him\r\nround about; and after him, in order, strode the sanhedrim, and a long\r\narray of priests, the latter in their plain white garments, overwrapped\r\nby abnets of many folds and gorgeous colors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son-in-law of Hannas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur, in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaiaphas! I have seen him,\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides replied, adding, after a pause\r\nduring which he thoughtfully watched the haughty pontiff, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now am I\r\nconvinced. With such assurance as proceeds from clear enlightenment of\r\nthe spirit\xe2\x80\x94with absolute assurance\xe2\x80\x94now know I that he who first goes\r\nyonder with the inscription about his neck is what the inscription\r\nproclaims him\xe2\x80\x94KING OF THE JEWS. A common man, an impostor, a felon, was\r\nnever thus waited upon. For look! Here are the nations\xe2\x80\x94Jerusalem,\r\nIsrael. Here is the ephod, here the blue robe with its fringe, and\r\npurple pomegranates, and golden bells, not seen in the street since the\r\nday Jaddua went out to meet the Macedonian\xe2\x80\x94proofs all that this\r\nNazarene is King. Would I could rise and go after him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur listened surprised; and directly, as if himself awakening to\r\nhis unusual display of feeling, Simonides said, impatiently,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak to Balthasar, I pray you, and let us begone. The vomit of\r\nJerusalem is coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Esther spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see some women there, and they are weeping. Who are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFollowing the pointing of her hand, the party beheld four women in\r\ntears; one of them leaned upon the arm of a man of aspect not unlike\r\nthe Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s. Presently Ben-Hur answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man is the disciple whom the Nazarene loves the best of all; she\r\nwho leans upon his arm is Mary, the Master\xe2\x80\x99s mother; the others are\r\nfriendly women of Galilee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther pursued the mourners with glistening eyes until the multitude\r\nreceived them out of sight.\r\n\r\nIt may be the reader will fancy the foregoing snatches of conversation\r\nwere had in quiet; but it was not so. The talking was, for the most\r\npart, like that indulged by people at the seaside under the sound of\r\nthe surf; for to nothing else can the clamor of this division of the\r\nmob be so well likened.\r\n\r\nThe demonstration was the forerunner of those in which, scarce thirty\r\nyears later, under rule of the factions, the Holy City was torn to\r\npieces; it was quite as great in numbers, as fanatical and\r\nbloodthirsty; boiled and raved, and had in it exactly the same\r\nelements\xe2\x80\x94servants, camel-drivers, marketmen, gate-keepers, gardeners,\r\ndealers in fruits and wines, proselytes, and foreigners not proselytes,\r\nwatchmen and menials from the Temple, thieves, robbers, and the myriad\r\nnot assignable to any class, but who, on such occasions as this,\r\nappeared no one could say whence, hungry and smelling of caves and old\r\ntombs\xe2\x80\x94bareheaded wretches with naked arms and legs, hair and beard in\r\nuncombed mats, and each with one garment the color of clay; beasts with\r\nabysmal mouths, in outcry effective as lions calling each other across\r\ndesert spaces. Some of them had swords; a greater number flourished\r\nspears and javelins; though the weapons of the many were staves and\r\nknotted clubs, and slings, for which latter selected stones were stored\r\nin scrips, and sometimes in sacks improvised from the foreskirts of\r\ntheir dirty tunics. Among the mass here and there appeared persons of\r\nhigh degree\xe2\x80\x94scribes, elders, rabbis, Pharisees with broad fringing,\r\nSadducees in fine cloaks\xe2\x80\x94serving for the time as prompters and\r\ndirectors. If a throat tired of one cry, they invented another for it;\r\nif brassy lungs showed signs of collapse, they set them going again;\r\nand yet the clamor, loud and continuous as it was, could have been\r\nreduced to a few syllables\xe2\x80\x94King of the Jews! Room for the King of the\r\nJews!\xe2\x80\x94Defiler of the Temple!\xe2\x80\x94Blasphemer of God!\xe2\x80\x94Crucify him, crucify\r\nhim! And of these cries the last one seemed in greatest favor, because,\r\ndoubtless, it was more directly expressive of the wish of the mob, and\r\nhelped to better articulate its hatred of the Nazarene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, when Balthasar was ready to proceed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ccome, let\r\nus forward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur did not hear the call. The appearance of the part of the\r\nprocession then passing, its brutality and hunger for life, were\r\nreminding him of the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x94his gentleness, and the many charities he\r\nhad seen him do for suffering men. Suggestions beget suggestions; so he\r\nremembered suddenly his own great indebtedness to the man; the time he\r\nhimself was in the hands of a Roman guard going, as was supposed, to a\r\ndeath as certain and almost as terrible as this one of the cross; the\r\ncooling drink he had at the well by Nazareth, and the divine expression\r\nof the face of him who gave it; the later goodness, the miracle of\r\nPalm-Sunday; and with these recollections, the thought of his present\r\npowerlessness to give back help for help or make return in kind stung\r\nhim keenly, and he accused himself. He had not done all he might; he\r\ncould have watched with the Galileans, and kept them true and ready;\r\nand this\xe2\x80\x94ah! this was the moment to strike! A blow well given now would\r\nnot merely disperse the mob and set the Nazarene free; it would be a\r\ntrumpet-call to Israel, and precipitate the long-dreamt-of war for\r\nfreedom. The opportunity was going; the minutes were bearing it away;\r\nand if lost! God of Abraham! Was there nothing to be done\xe2\x80\x94nothing?\r\n\r\nThat instant a party of Galileans caught his eye. He rushed through the\r\npress and overtook them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI would have speech with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men obeyed him, and when they were under shelter of the house, he\r\nspoke again:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are of those who took my swords, and agreed with me to strike for\r\nfreedom and the King who was coming. You have the swords now, and now\r\nis the time to strike with them. Go, look everywhere, and find our\r\nbrethren, and tell them to meet me at the tree of the cross making\r\nready for the Nazarene. Haste all of you! Nay, stand not so! The\r\nNazarene is the King, and freedom dies with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey looked at him respectfully, but did not move.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nThen one of them replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Judah\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94by that name they knew him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cson of Judah, it is you who\r\nare deceived, not we or our brethren who have your swords. The Nazarene\r\nis not the King; neither has he the spirit of a king. We were with him\r\nwhen he came into Jerusalem; we saw him in the Temple; he failed\r\nhimself, and us, and Israel; at the Gate Beautiful he turned his back\r\nupon God and refused the throne of David. He is not King, and Galilee\r\nis not with him. He shall die the death. But hear you, son of Judah. We\r\nhave your swords, and we are ready now to draw them and strike for\r\nfreedom; and so is Galilee. Be it for freedom, O son of Judah, for\r\nfreedom! and we will meet you at the tree of the cross.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sovereign moment of his life was upon Ben-Hur. Could he have taken\r\nthe offer and said the word, history might have been other than it is;\r\nbut then it would have been history ordered by men, not God\xe2\x80\x94something\r\nthat never was, and never will be. A confusion fell upon him; he knew\r\nnot how, though afterwards he attributed it to the Nazarene; for when\r\nthe Nazarene was risen, he understood the death was necessary to faith\r\nin the resurrection, without which Christianity would be an empty husk.\r\nThe confusion, as has been said, left him without the faculty of\r\ndecision; he stood helpless\xe2\x80\x94wordless even. Covering his face with his\r\nhand, he shook with the conflict between his wish, which was what he\r\nwould have ordered, and the power that was upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome; we are waiting for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, the fourth time.\r\n\r\nThereupon he walked mechanically after the chair and the litter. Esther\r\nwalked with him. Like Balthasar and his friends, the Wise Men, the day\r\nthey went to the meeting in the desert, he was being led along the way.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the party\xe2\x80\x94Balthasar, Simonides, Ben-Hur, Esther, and the two\r\nfaithful Galileans\xe2\x80\x94reached the place of crucifixion, Ben-Hur was in\r\nadvance leading them. How they had been able to make way through the\r\ngreat press of excited people, he never knew; no more did he know the\r\nroad by which they came or the time it took them to come. He had walked\r\nin total unconsciousness, neither hearing nor seeing anybody or\r\nanything, and without a thought of where he was going, or the\r\nghostliest semblance of a purpose in his mind. In such condition a\r\nlittle child could have done as much as he to prevent the awful crime\r\nhe was about to witness. The intentions of God are always strange to\r\nus; but not more so than the means by which they are wrought out, and\r\nat last made plain to our belief.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur came to a stop; those following him also stopped. As a curtain\r\nrises before an audience, the spell holding him in its sleep-awake\r\nrose, and he saw with a clear understanding.\r\n\r\nThere was a space upon the top of a low knoll rounded like a skull, and\r\ndry, dusty, and without vegetation, except some scrubby hyssop. The\r\nboundary of the space was a living wall of men, with men behind\r\nstruggling, some to look over, others to look through it. An inner wall\r\nof Roman soldiery held the dense outer wall rigidly to its place. A\r\ncenturion kept eye upon the soldiers. Up to the very line so vigilantly\r\nguarded Ben-Hur had been led; at the line he now stood, his face to the\r\nnorthwest. The knoll was the old Aramaic Golgotha\xe2\x80\x94in Latin, Calvaria;\r\nanglicized, Calvary; translated, The Skull.\r\n\r\nOn its slopes, in the low places, on the swells and higher hills, the\r\nearth sparkled with a strange enamelling. Look where he would outside\r\nthe walled space, he saw no patch of brown soil, no rock, no green\r\nthing; he saw only thousands of eyes in ruddy faces; off a little way\r\nin the perspective only ruddy faces without eyes; off a little farther\r\nonly a broad, broad circle, which the nearer view instructed him was\r\nalso of faces. And this was the ensemble of three millions of people;\r\nunder it three millions of hearts throbbing with passionate interest in\r\nwhat was taking place upon the knoll; indifferent as to the thieves,\r\ncaring only for the Nazarene, and for him only as he was an object of\r\nhate or fear or curiosity\xe2\x80\x94he who loved them all, and was about to die\r\nfor them.\r\n\r\nIn the spectacle of a great assemblage of people there are always the\r\nbewilderment and fascination one feels while looking over a stretch of\r\nsea in agitation, and never had this one been exceeded; yet Ben-Hur\r\ngave it but a passing glance, for that which was going on in the space\r\ndescribed would permit no division of his interest.\r\n\r\nUp on the knoll so high as to be above the living wall, and visible\r\nover the heads of an attending company of notables, conspicuous because\r\nof his mitre and vestments and his haughty air, stood the high priest.\r\nUp the knoll still higher, up quite to the round summit, so as to be\r\nseen far and near, was the Nazarene, stooped and suffering, but silent.\r\nThe wit among the guard had complemented the crown upon his head by\r\nputting a reed in his hand for a sceptre. Clamors blew upon him like\r\nblasts\xe2\x80\x94laughter\xe2\x80\x94execrations\xe2\x80\x94sometimes both together indistinguishably.\r\nA man\xe2\x80\x94ONLY a man, O reader, would have charged the blasts with the\r\nremainder of his love for the race, and let it go forever.\r\n\r\nAll the eyes then looking were fixed upon the Nazarene. It may have\r\nbeen pity with which he was moved; whatever the cause, Ben-Hur was\r\nconscious of a change in his feelings. A conception of something better\r\nthan the best of this life\xe2\x80\x94something so much better that it could serve\r\na weak man with strength to endure agonies of spirit as well as of\r\nbody; something to make death welcome\xe2\x80\x94perhaps another life purer than\r\nthis one\xe2\x80\x94perhaps the spirit-life which Balthasar held to so fast, began\r\nto dawn upon his mind clearer and clearer, bringing to him a certain\r\nsense that, after all, the mission of the Nazarene was that of guide\r\nacross the boundary for such as loved him; across the boundary to where\r\nhis kingdom was set up and waiting for him. Then, as something borne\r\nthrough the air out of the almost forgotten, he heard again, or seemed\r\nto hear, the saying of the Nazarene,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI AM THE RESURRECTION AND THE LIFE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the words repeated themselves over and over, and took form, and the\r\ndawn touched them with its light, and filled them with a new meaning.\r\nAnd as men repeat a question to grasp and fix the meaning, he asked,\r\ngazing at the figure on the hill fainting under its crown, Who the\r\nResurrection? and who the Life?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI AM,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nthe figure seemed to say\xe2\x80\x94and say it for him; for instantly he was\r\nsensible of a peace such as he had never known\xe2\x80\x94the peace which is the\r\nend of doubt and mystery, and the beginning of faith and love and clear\r\nunderstanding.\r\n\r\nFrom this dreamy state Ben-Hur was aroused by the sound of hammering.\r\nOn the summit of the knoll he observed then what had escaped him\r\nbefore\xe2\x80\x94some soldiers and workmen preparing the crosses. The holes for\r\nplanting the trees were ready, and now the transverse beams were being\r\nfitted to their places.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBid the men make haste,\xe2\x80\x9d said the high-priest to the centurion.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he pointed to the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmust be dead by the going-down\r\nof the sun, and buried that the land may not be defiled. Such is the\r\nLaw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a better mind, a soldier went to the Nazarene and offered him\r\nsomething to drink, but he refused the cup. Then another went to him\r\nand took from his neck the board with the inscription upon it, which he\r\nnailed to the tree of the cross\xe2\x80\x94and the preparation was complete.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe crosses are ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said the centurion to the pontiff, who\r\nreceived the report with a wave of the hand and the reply,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet the blasphemer go first. The Son of God should be able to save\r\nhimself. We will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people to whom the preparation in its several stages was visible,\r\nand who to this time had assailed the hill with incessant cries of\r\nimpatience, permitted a lull which directly became a universal hush.\r\nThe part of the infliction most shocking, at least to the thought, was\r\nreached\xe2\x80\x94the men were to be nailed to their crosses. When for that\r\npurpose the soldiers laid their hands upon the Nazarene first, a\r\nshudder passed through the great concourse; the most brutalized shrank\r\nwith dread. Afterwards there were those who said the air suddenly\r\nchilled and made them shiver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow very still it is!\xe2\x80\x9d Esther said, as she put her arm about her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s neck.\r\n\r\nAnd remembering the torture he himself had suffered, he drew her face\r\ndown upon his breast, and sat trembling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAvoid it, Esther, avoid it!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI know not but all who stand\r\nand see it\xe2\x80\x94the innocent as well as the guilty\xe2\x80\x94may be cursed from this\r\nhour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar sank upon his knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, with increasing excitement\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cson of Hur,\r\nif Jehovah stretch not forth his hand, and quickly, Israel is lost\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nwe are lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur answered, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cI have been in a dream, Simonides, and heard\r\nin it why all this should be, and why it should go on. It is the will\r\nof the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x94it is God\xe2\x80\x99s will. Let us do as the Egyptian here\xe2\x80\x94let us\r\nhold our peace and pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he looked up on the knoll again, the words were wafted to him\r\nthrough the awful stillness\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI AM THE RESURRECTION AND THE LIFE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed reverently as to a person speaking.\r\n\r\nUp on the summit meantime the work went on. The guard took the\r\nNazarene\xe2\x80\x99s clothes from him; so that he stood before the millions\r\nnaked. The stripes of the scourging he had received in the early\r\nmorning were still bloody upon his back; yet he was laid pitilessly\r\ndown, and stretched upon the cross\xe2\x80\x94first, the arms upon the transverse\r\nbeam; the spikes were sharp\xe2\x80\x94a few blows, and they were driven through\r\nthe tender palms; next, they drew his knees up until the soles of the\r\nfeet rested flat upon the tree; then they placed one foot upon the\r\nother, and one spike fixed both of them fast. The dulled sound of the\r\nhammering was heard outside the guarded space; and such as could not\r\nhear, yet saw the hammer as it fell, shivered with fear. And withal not\r\na groan, or cry, or word of remonstrance from the sufferer: nothing at\r\nwhich an enemy could laugh; nothing a lover could regret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich way wilt thou have him faced?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a soldier, bluntly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTowards the Temple,\xe2\x80\x9d the pontiff replied. \xe2\x80\x9cIn dying I would have him\r\nsee the holy house hath not suffered by him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe workmen put their hands to the cross, and carried it, burden and\r\nall, to the place of planting. At a word, they dropped the tree into\r\nthe hole; and the body of the Nazarene also dropped heavily, and hung\r\nby the bleeding hands. Still no cry of pain\xe2\x80\x94only the exclamation\r\ndivinest of all recorded exclamations,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, forgive them, for they know not what they do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cross, reared now above all other objects, and standing singly out\r\nagainst the sky, was greeted with a burst of delight; and all who could\r\nsee and read the writing upon the board over the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s head made\r\nhaste to decipher it. Soon as read, the legend was adopted by them and\r\ncommunicated, and presently the whole mighty concourse was ringing the\r\nsalutation from side to side, and repeating it with laughter and\r\ngroans,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKing of the Jews! Hail, King of the Jews!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe pontiff, with a clearer idea of the import of the inscription,\r\nprotested against it, but in vain; so the titled King, looking from the\r\nknoll with dying eyes, must have had the city of his fathers at rest\r\nbelow him\xe2\x80\x94she who had so ignominiously cast him out.\r\n\r\nThe sun was rising rapidly to noon; the hills bared their brown breasts\r\nlovingly to it; the more distant mountains rejoiced in the purple with\r\nwhich it so regally dressed them. In the city, the temples, palaces,\r\ntowers, pinnacles, and all points of beauty and prominence seemed to\r\nlift themselves into the unrivalled brilliance, as if they knew the\r\npride they were giving the many who from time to time turned to look at\r\nthem. Suddenly a dimness began to fill the sky and cover the earth\xe2\x80\x94at\r\nfirst no more than a scarce perceptible fading of the day; a twilight\r\nout of time; an evening gliding in upon the splendors of noon. But it\r\ndeepened, and directly drew attention; whereat the noise of the\r\nshouting and laughter fell off, and men, doubting their senses, gazed\r\nat each other curiously: then they looked to the sun again; then at the\r\nmountains, getting farther away; at the sky and the near landscape,\r\nsinking in shadow; at the hill upon which the tragedy was enacting; and\r\nfrom all these they gazed at each other again, and turned pale, and\r\nheld their peace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is only a mist or passing cloud,\xe2\x80\x9d Simonides said soothingly to\r\nEsther, who was alarmed. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will brighten presently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur did not think so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not a mist or a cloud,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe spirits who live in the\r\nair\xe2\x80\x94the prophets and saints\xe2\x80\x94are at work in mercy to themselves and\r\nnature. I say to you, O Simonides, truly as God lives, he who hangs\r\nyonder is the Son of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd leaving Simonides lost in wonder at such a speech from him, he went\r\nwhere Balthasar was kneeling near by, and laid his hand upon the good\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO wise Egyptian, hearken! Thou alone wert right\xe2\x80\x94the Nazarene is indeed\r\nthe Son of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBalthasar drew him down to him, and replied, feebly, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw him a child\r\nin the manger where he was first laid; it is not strange that I knew\r\nhim sooner than thou; but oh that I should live to see this day! Would\r\nI had died with my brethren! Happy Melchior! Happy, happy Gaspar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cComfort thee!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless they too are here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dimness went on deepening into obscurity, and that into positive\r\ndarkness, but without deterring the bolder spirits upon the knoll. One\r\nafter the other the thieves were raised on their crosses, and the\r\ncrosses planted. The guard was then withdrawn, and the people set free\r\nclosed in upon the height, and surged up it, like a converging wave. A\r\nman might take a look, when a new-comer would push him on, and take his\r\nplace, to be in turn pushed on\xe2\x80\x94and there were laughter and ribaldry and\r\nrevilements, all for the Nazarene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha! If thou be King of the Jews, save thyself,\xe2\x80\x9d a soldier shouted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said a priest, \xe2\x80\x9cif he will come down to us now, we will believe\r\nin him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOthers wagged their heads wisely, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cHe would destroy the Temple,\r\nand rebuild it in three days, but cannot save himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOthers still: \xe2\x80\x9cHe called himself the Son of God; let us see if God will\r\nhave him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat all there is in prejudice no one has ever said. The Nazarene had\r\nnever harmed the people; far the greater part of them had never seen\r\nhim except in this his hour of calamity; yet\xe2\x80\x94singular contrariety!\xe2\x80\x94they\r\nloaded him with their curses, and gave their sympathy to the thieves.\r\n\r\nThe supernatural night, dropped thus from the heavens, affected Esther\r\nas it began to affect thousands of others braver and stronger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go home,\xe2\x80\x9d she prayed\xe2\x80\x94twice, three times\xe2\x80\x94saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the\r\nfrown of God, father. What other dreadful things may happen, who can\r\ntell? I am afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides was obstinate. He said little, but was plainly under great\r\nexcitement. Observing, about the end of the first hour, that the\r\nviolence of the crowding up on the knoll was somewhat abated, at his\r\nsuggestion the party advanced to take position nearer the crosses.\r\nBen-Hur gave his arm to Balthasar; yet the Egyptian made the ascent\r\nwith difficulty. From their new stand, the Nazarene was imperfectly\r\nvisible, appearing to them not more than a dark suspended figure. They\r\ncould hear him, however\xe2\x80\x94hear his sighing, which showed an endurance or\r\nexhaustion greater than that of his fellow-sufferers; for they filled\r\nevery lull in the noises with their groans and entreaties.\r\n\r\nThe second hour after the suspension passed like the first one. To the\r\nNazarene they were hours of insult, provocation, and slow dying. He\r\nspoke but once in the time. Some women came and knelt at the foot of\r\nhis cross. Among them he recognized his mother with the beloved\r\ndisciple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, raising his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cbehold thy son!\xe2\x80\x9d And to the\r\ndisciple, \xe2\x80\x9cBehold thy mother!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe third hour came, and still the people surged round the hill, held\r\nto it by some strange attraction, with which, in probability, the night\r\nin midday had much to do. They were quieter than in the preceding hour;\r\nyet at intervals they could be heard off in the darkness shouting to\r\neach other, multitude calling unto multitude. It was noticeable, also,\r\nthat coming now to the Nazarene, they approached his cross in silence,\r\ntook the look in silence, and so departed. This change extended even to\r\nthe guard, who so shortly before had cast lots for the clothes of the\r\ncrucified; they stood with their officers a little apart, more watchful\r\nof the one convict than of the throngs coming and going. If he but\r\nbreathed heavily, or tossed his head in a paroxysm of pain, they were\r\ninstantly on the alert. Most marvellous of all, however, was the\r\naltered behavior of the high-priest and his following, the wise men who\r\nhad assisted him in the trial in the night, and, in the victim\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\nkept place by him with zealous approval. When the darkness began to\r\nfall, they began to lose their confidence. There were among them many\r\nlearned in astronomy, and familiar with the apparitions so terrible in\r\nthose days to the masses; much of the knowledge was descended to them\r\nfrom their fathers far back; some of it had been brought away at the\r\nend of the Captivity; and the necessities of the Temple service kept it\r\nall bright. These closed together when the sun commenced to fade before\r\ntheir eyes, and the mountains and hills to recede; they drew together\r\nin a group around their pontiff, and debated what they saw. \xe2\x80\x9cThe moon\r\nis at its full,\xe2\x80\x9d they said, with truth, \xe2\x80\x9cand this cannot be an\r\neclipse.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as no one could answer the question common with them\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94as no one could account for the darkness, or for its occurrence at\r\nthat particular time, in their secret hearts they associated it with\r\nthe Nazarene, and yielded to an alarm which the long continuance of the\r\nphenomenon steadily increased. In their place behind the soldiers, they\r\nnoted every word and motion of the Nazarene, and hung with fear upon\r\nhis sighs, and talked in whispers. The man might be the Messiah, and\r\nthen\xe2\x80\x94 But they would wait and see!\r\n\r\nIn the meantime Ben-Hur was not once visited by the old spirit. The\r\nperfect peace abode with him. He prayed simply that the end might be\r\nhastened. He knew the condition of Simonides\xe2\x80\x99 mind\xe2\x80\x94that he was\r\nhesitating on the verge of belief. He could see the massive face\r\nweighed down by solemn reflection. He noticed him casting inquiring\r\nglances at the sun, as seeking the cause of the darkness. Nor did he\r\nfail to notice the solicitude with which Esther clung to him,\r\nsmothering her fears to accommodate his wishes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe not afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d he heard him say to her; \xe2\x80\x9cbut stay and watch with me.\r\nThou mayst live twice the span of my life, and see nothing of human\r\ninterest equal to this; and there may be revelations more. Let us stay\r\nto the close.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the third hour was about half gone, some men of the rudest\r\nclass\xe2\x80\x94wretches from the tombs about the city\xe2\x80\x94came and stopped in front\r\nof the centre cross.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is he, the new King of the Jews,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of them.\r\n\r\nThe others cried, with laughter, \xe2\x80\x9cHail, all hail, King of the Jews!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReceiving no reply, they went closer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou be King of the Jews, or Son of God, come down,\xe2\x80\x9d they said,\r\nloudly.\r\n\r\nAt this, one of the thieves quit groaning, and called to the Nazarene,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if thou be Christ, save thyself and us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe people laughed and applauded; then, while they were listening for a\r\nreply, the other felon was heard to say to the first one, \xe2\x80\x9cDost thou\r\nnot fear God? We receive the due rewards of our deeds; but this man\r\nhath done nothing amiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bystanders were astonished; in the midst of the hush which ensued,\r\nthe second felon spoke again, but this time to the Nazarene:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cremember me when thou comest into thy kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides gave a great start. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen thou comest into thy kingdom!\xe2\x80\x9d It\r\nwas the very point of doubt in his mind; the point he had so often\r\ndebated with Balthasar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidst thou hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur to him. \xe2\x80\x9cThe kingdom cannot be of this\r\nworld. Yon witness saith the King is but going to his kingdom; and, in\r\neffect, I heard the same in my dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, more imperiously than ever before in speech to\r\nBen-Hur. \xe2\x80\x9cHush, I pray thee! If the Nazarene should answer\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd as he spoke the Nazarene did answer, in a clear voice, full of\r\nconfidence:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVerily I say unto thee, To-day shalt thou be with me in Paradise!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides waited to hear if that were all; then he folded his hands and\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cNo more, no more, Lord! The darkness is gone; I see with other\r\neyes\xe2\x80\x94even as Balthasar, I see with eyes of perfect faith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe faithful servant had at last his fitting reward. His broken body\r\nmight never be restored; nor was there riddance of the recollection of\r\nhis sufferings, or recall of the years embittered by them; but suddenly\r\na new life was shown him, with assurance that it was for him\xe2\x80\x94a new life\r\nlying just beyond this one\xe2\x80\x94and its name was Paradise. There he would\r\nfind the Kingdom of which he had been dreaming, and the King. A perfect\r\npeace fell upon him.\r\n\r\nOver the way, in front of the cross, however, there were surprise and\r\nconsternation. The cunning casuists there put the assumption underlying\r\nthe question and the admission underlying the answer together. For\r\nsaying through the land that he was the Messiah, they had brought the\r\nNazarene to the cross; and, lo! on the cross, more confidently than\r\never, he had not only reasserted himself, but promised enjoyment of his\r\nParadise to a malefactor. They trembled at what they were doing. The\r\npontiff, with all his pride, was afraid. Where got the man his\r\nconfidence except from Truth? And what should the Truth be but God? A\r\nvery little now would put them all to flight.\r\n\r\nThe breathing of the Nazarene grew harder, his sighs became great\r\ngasps. Only three hours upon the cross, and he was dying!\r\n\r\nThe intelligence was carried from man to man, until every one knew it;\r\nand then everything hushed; the breeze faltered and died; a stifling\r\nvapor loaded the air; heat was superadded to darkness; nor might any\r\none unknowing the fact have thought that off the hill, out under the\r\noverhanging pall, there were three millions of people waiting\r\nawe-struck what should happen next\xe2\x80\x94they were so still!\r\n\r\nThen there went out through the gloom, over the heads of such as were\r\non the hill within hearing of the dying man, a cry of despair, if not\r\nreproach:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God! my God! why hast thou forsaken me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice startled all who heard it. One it touched uncontrollably.\r\n\r\nThe soldiers in coming had brought with them a vessel of wine and\r\nwater, and set it down a little way from Ben-Hur. With a sponge dipped\r\ninto the liquor, and put on the end of a stick, they could moisten the\r\ntongue of a sufferer at their pleasure. Ben-Hur thought of the draught\r\nhe had had at the well near Nazareth; an impulse seized him; catching\r\nup the sponge, he dipped it into the vessel, and started for the cross.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him be!\xe2\x80\x9d the people in the way shouted, angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him be!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout minding them, he ran on, and put the sponge to the Nazarene\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlips.\r\n\r\nToo late, too late!\r\n\r\nThe face then plainly seen by Ben-Hur, bruised and black with blood and\r\ndust as it was, lighted nevertheless with a sudden glow; the eyes\r\nopened wide, and fixed upon some one visible to them alone in the far\r\nheavens; and there were content and relief, even triumph, in the shout\r\nthe victim gave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is finished! It is finished!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo a hero, dying in the doing a great deed, celebrates his success with\r\na last cheer.\r\n\r\nThe light in the eyes went out; slowly the crowned head sank upon the\r\nlaboring breast. Ben-Hur thought the struggle over; but the fainting\r\nsoul recollected itself, so that he and those around him caught the\r\nother and last words, spoken in a low voice, as if to one listening\r\nclose by:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, into thy hands I commend my spirit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tremor shook the tortured body; there was a scream of fiercest\r\nanguish, and the mission and the earthly life were over at once. The\r\nheart, with all its love, was broken; for of that, O reader, the man\r\ndied!\r\n\r\nBen-Hur went back to his friends, saying, simply, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is over; he is\r\ndead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a space incredibly short the multitude was informed of the\r\ncircumstance. No one repeated it aloud; there was a murmur which spread\r\nfrom the knoll in every direction; a murmur that was little more than a\r\nwhispering, \xe2\x80\x9cHe is dead! he is dead!\xe2\x80\x9d and that was all. The people had\r\ntheir wish; the Nazarene was dead; yet they stared at each other\r\naghast. His blood was upon them! And while they stood staring at each\r\nother, the ground commenced to shake; each man took hold of his\r\nneighbor to support himself; in a twinkling the darkness disappeared,\r\nand the sun came out; and everybody, as with the same glance, beheld\r\nthe crosses upon the hill all reeling drunken-like in the earthquake.\r\nThey beheld all three of them; but the one in the centre was arbitrary;\r\nit alone would be seen; and for that it seemed to extend itself\r\nupwards, and lift its burden, and swing it to and fro higher and higher\r\nin the blue of the sky. And every man among them who had jeered at the\r\nNazarene; every one who had struck him; every one who had voted to\r\ncrucify him; every one who had marched in the procession from the city;\r\nevery one who had in his heart wished him dead, and they were as ten to\r\none, felt that he was in some way individually singled out from the\r\nmany, and that if he would live he must get away quickly as possible\r\nfrom that menace in the sky. They started to run; they ran with all\r\ntheir might; on horseback, and camels, and in chariots they ran, as\r\nwell as on foot; but then as if it were mad at them for what they had\r\ndone, and had taken up the cause of the unoffending and friendless\r\ndead, the earthquake pursued them, and tossed them about, and flung\r\nthem down, and terrified them yet more by the horrible noise of great\r\nrocks grinding and rending beneath them. They beat their breasts and\r\nshrieked with fear. His blood was upon them! The home-bred and the\r\nforeign, priest and layman, beggar, Sadducee, Pharisee, were overtaken\r\nin the race, and tumbled about indiscriminately. If they called on the\r\nLord, the outraged earth answered for him in fury, and dealt them all\r\nalike. It did not even know wherein the high-priest was better than his\r\nguilty brethren; overtaking him, it tripped him up also, and smirched\r\nthe fringing of his robe, and filled the golden bells with sand, and\r\nhis mouth with dust. He and his people were alike in the one thing at\r\nleast\xe2\x80\x94the blood of the Nazarene was upon them all!\r\n\r\nWhen the sunlight broke upon the crucifixion, the mother of the\r\nNazarene, the disciple, and the faithful women of Galilee, the\r\ncenturion and his soldiers, and Ben-Hur and his party, were all who\r\nremained upon the hill. These had not time to observe the flight of the\r\nmultitude; they were too loudly called upon to take care of themselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeat thyself here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur to Esther, making a place for her at\r\nher father\xe2\x80\x99s feet. \xe2\x80\x9cNow cover thine eyes and look not up; but put thy\r\ntrust in God, and the spirit of yon just man so foully slain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides, reverently, \xe2\x80\x9clet us henceforth speak of him as\r\nthe Christ.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nPresently a wave of the earthquake struck the hill. The shrieks of the\r\nthieves upon the reeling crosses were terrible to hear. Though giddy\r\nwith the movements of the ground, Ben-Hur had time to look at\r\nBalthasar, and beheld him prostrate and still. He ran to him and\r\ncalled\xe2\x80\x94there was no reply. The good man was dead! Then Ben-Hur\r\nremembered to have heard a cry in answer, as it were, to the scream of\r\nthe Nazarene in his last moment; but he had not looked to see from whom\r\nit had proceeded; and ever after he believed the spirit of the Egyptian\r\naccompanied that of his Master over the boundary into the kingdom of\r\nParadise. The idea rested not only upon the cry heard, but upon the\r\nexceeding fitness of the distinction. If faith were worthy reward in\r\nthe person of Gaspar, and love in that of Melchior, surely he should\r\nhave some special meed who through a long life and so excellently\r\nillustrated the three virtues in combination\xe2\x80\x94Faith, Love, and Good\r\nWorks.\r\n\r\nThe servants of Balthasar had deserted their master; but when all was\r\nover, the two Galileans bore the old man in his litter back to the\r\ncity.\r\n\r\nIt was a sorrowful procession that entered the south gate of the palace\r\nof the Hurs about the set of sun that memorable day. About the same\r\nhour the body of the Christ was taken down from the cross.\r\n\r\nThe remains of Balthasar were carried to the guest-chamber. All the\r\nservants hastened weeping to see him; for he had the love of every\r\nliving thing with which he had in anywise to do; but when they beheld\r\nhis face, and the smile upon it, they dried their tears, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nwell. He is happier this evening than when he went out in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur would not trust a servant to inform Iras what had befallen her\r\nfather. He went himself to see her and bring her to the body. He\r\nimagined her grief; she would now be alone in the world; it was a time\r\nto forgive and pity her. He remembered he had not asked why she was not\r\nof the party in the morning, or where she was; he remembered he had not\r\nthought of her; and, from shame, he was ready to make any amends, the\r\nmore so as he was about to plunge her into such acute grief.\r\n\r\nHe shook the curtains of her door; and though he heard the ringing of\r\nthe little bells echoing within, he had no response; he called her\r\nname, and again he called\xe2\x80\x94still no answer. He drew the curtain aside\r\nand went into the room; she was not there. He ascended hastily to the\r\nroof in search of her; nor was she there. He questioned the servants;\r\nnone of them had seen her during the day. After a long quest everywhere\r\nthrough the house, Ben-Hur returned to the guest-chamber, and took the\r\nplace by the dead which should have been hers; and he bethought him\r\nthere how merciful the Christ had been to his aged servant. At the gate\r\nof the kingdom of Paradise happily the afflictions of this life, even\r\nits desertions, are left behind and forgotten by those who go in and\r\nrest.\r\n\r\nWhen the gloom of the burial was nigh gone, on the ninth day after the\r\nhealing, the law being fulfilled, Ben-Hur brought his mother and Tirzah\r\nhome; and from that day, in that house the most sacred names possible\r\nof utterance by men were always coupled worshipfully together,\r\n\r\nGOD THE FATHER AND CHRIST THE SON.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nAbout five years after the crucifixion, Esther, the wife of Ben-Hur,\r\nsat in her room in the beautiful villa by Misenum. It was noon, with a\r\nwarm Italian sun making summer for the roses and vines outside.\r\nEverything in the apartment was Roman, except that Esther wore the\r\ngarments of a Jewish matron. Tirzah and two children at play upon a\r\nlion skin on the floor were her companions; and one had only to observe\r\nhow carefully she watched them to know that the little ones were hers.\r\n\r\nTime had treated her generously. She was more than ever beautiful, and\r\nin becoming mistress of the villa, she had realized one of her\r\ncherished dreams.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of this simple, home-like scene, a servant appeared in the\r\ndoorway, and spoke to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woman in the atrium to speak with the mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her come. I will receive her here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPresently the stranger entered. At sight of her the Jewess arose, and\r\nwas about to speak; then she hesitated, changed color, and finally drew\r\nback, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI have known you, good woman. You are\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was Iras, the daughter of Balthasar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther conquered her surprise, and bade the servant bring the Egyptian\r\na seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Iras, coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cI will retire directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two gazed at each other. We know what Esther presented\xe2\x80\x94a beautiful\r\nwoman, a happy mother, a contented wife. On the other side, it was very\r\nplain that fortune had not dealt so gently with her former rival. The\r\ntall figure remained with some of its grace; but an evil life had\r\ntainted the whole person. The face was coarse; the large eyes were red\r\nand pursed beneath the lower lids; there was no color in her cheeks.\r\nThe lips were cynical and hard, and general neglect was leading rapidly\r\nto premature old age. Her attire was ill chosen and draggled. The mud\r\nof the road clung to her sandals. Iras broke the painful silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are thy children?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEsther looked at them, and smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Will you not speak to them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would scare them,\xe2\x80\x9d Iras replied. Then she drew closer to Esther, and\r\nseeing her shrink, said, \xe2\x80\x9cBe not afraid. Give thy husband a message for\r\nme. Tell him his enemy is dead, and that for the much misery he brought\r\nme I slew him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis enemy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Messala. Further, tell thy husband that for the harm I sought to\r\ndo him I have been punished until even he would pity me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTears arose in Esther\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, and she was about to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Iras, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not want pity or tears. Tell him, finally, I\r\nhave found that to be a Roman is to be a brute. Farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe moved to go. Esther followed her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, and see my husband. He has no feeling against you. He sought for\r\nyou everywhere. He will be your friend. I will be your friend. We are\r\nChristians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other was firm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I am what I am of choice. It will be over shortly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Esther hesitated\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chave we nothing you would wish; nothing to\xe2\x80\x94to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countenance of the Egyptian softened; something like a smile played\r\nabout her lips. She looked at the children upon the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nEsther followed her eyes, and with quick perception answered, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nyours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIras went to them, and knelt on the lion\xe2\x80\x99s skin, and kissed them both.\r\nRising slowly, she looked at them; then passed to the door and out of\r\nit without a parting word. She walked rapidly, and was gone before\r\nEsther could decide what to do.\r\n\r\nBen-Hur, when he was told of the visit, knew certainly what he had long\r\nsurmised\xe2\x80\x94that on the day of the crucifixion Iras had deserted her\r\nfather for Messala. Nevertheless, he set out immediately and hunted for\r\nher vainly; they never saw her more, or heard of her. The blue bay,\r\nwith all its laughing under the sun, has yet its dark secrets. Had it a\r\ntongue, it might tell us of the Egyptian.\r\n\r\nSimonides lived to be a very old man. In the tenth year of Nero\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreign, he gave up the business so long centred in the warehouse at\r\nAntioch. To the last he kept a clear head and a good heart, and was\r\nsuccessful.\r\n\r\nOne evening, in the year named, he sat in his arm-chair on the terrace\r\nof the warehouse. Ben-Hur and Esther, and their three children, were\r\nwith him. The last of the ships swung at mooring in the current of the\r\nriver; all the rest had been sold. In the long interval between this\r\nand the day of the crucifixion but one sorrow had befallen them: that\r\nwas when the mother of Ben-Hur died; and then and now their grief would\r\nhave been greater but for their Christian faith.\r\n\r\nThe ship spoken of had arrived only the day before, bringing\r\nintelligence of the persecution of Christians begun by Nero in Rome,\r\nand the party on the terrace were talking of the news when Malluch, who\r\nwas still in their service, approached and delivered a package to\r\nBen-Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho brings this?\xe2\x80\x9d the latter asked, after reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn Arab.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe left immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben-Hur to Simonides.\r\n\r\nHe read then the following letter:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, Ilderim, the son of Ilderim the Generous, and sheik of the tribe of\r\nIlderim, to Judah, son of Hur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnow, O friend of my father\xe2\x80\x99s, how my father loved you. Read what is\r\nherewith sent, and you will know. His will is my will; therefore what\r\nhe gave is thine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the Parthians took from him in the great battle in which they slew\r\nhim I have retaken\xe2\x80\x94this writing, with other things, and vengeance, and\r\nall the brood of that Mira who in his time was mother of so many stars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace be to you and all yours.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis voice out of the desert is the voice of\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIlderim, Shiek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBen-Hur next unrolled a scrap of papyrus yellow as a withered mulberry\r\nleaf. It required the daintiest handling. Proceeding, he read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIlderim, surnamed the Generous, sheik of the tribe of Ilderim, to the\r\nson who succeeds me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll I have, O son, shall be thine in the day of thy succession, except\r\nthat property by Antioch known as the Orchard of Palms; and it shall be\r\nto the son of Hur who brought us such glory in the Circus\xe2\x80\x94to him and\r\nhis forever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDishonor not thy father. ILDERIM THE GENEROUS, Sheik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat say you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur, of Simonides.\r\n\r\nEsther took the papers pleased, and read them to herself. Simonides\r\nremained silent. His eyes were upon the ship; but he was thinking. At\r\nlength he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSon of Hur,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Lord has been good to you in these\r\nlater years. You have much to be thankful for. Is it not time to decide\r\nfinally the meaning of the gift of the great fortune now all in your\r\nhand, and growing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI decided that long ago. The fortune was meant for the service of the\r\nGiver; not a part, Simonides, but all of it. The question with me has\r\nbeen, How can I make it most useful in his cause? And of that tell me,\r\nI pray you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSimonides answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe great sums you have given to the Church here in Antioch, I am\r\nwitness to. Now, instantly almost with this gift of the generous\r\nsheik\xe2\x80\x99s, comes the news of the persecution of the brethren in Rome. It\r\nis the opening of a new field. The light must not go out in the\r\ncapital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me how I can keep it alive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you. The Romans, even this Nero, hold two things sacred\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nknow of no others they so hold\xe2\x80\x94they are the ashes of the dead and all\r\nplaces of burial. If you cannot build temples for the worship of the\r\nLord above ground, then build them below the ground; and to keep them\r\nfrom profanation, carry to them the bodies of all who die in the\r\nfaith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen-Hur arose excitedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a great idea,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not wait to begin it. Time\r\nforbids waiting. The ship that brought the news of the suffering of our\r\nbrethren shall take me to Rome. I will sail to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned to Malluch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet the ship ready, Malluch, and be thou ready to go with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Simonides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, Esther, what sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ben-Hur.\r\n\r\nEsther came to his side, and put her hand on his arm, and answered,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo wilt thou best serve the Christ. O my husband, let me not hinder,\r\nbut go with thee and help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIf any of my readers, visiting Rome, will make the short journey to the\r\nCatacomb of San Calixto, which is more ancient than that of San\r\nSebastiano, he will see what became of the fortune of Ben-Hur, and give\r\nhim thanks. Out of that vast tomb Christianity issued to supersede the\r\nCaesars.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK BEN-HUR: A TALE OF THE CHRIST ***\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the\r\nUnited States without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
